column2: THIS book takes its title from ebullient instrumental conversation held in a Chicago recording studio in 1928, which came out on disks back in the old 78-r.p.m. days. The band included Louis Armstrong, Earl Hines and Zutty Singleton, who are also among the 150 or so contributors to this literary jam session.

Say farewell to spring, all ye who gauge time and life by calendars. According to the calculations, summer begins at 11:32 P. M. on Tuesday, which makes it very close to Wednesday on the calendar. That is the time of the summer solstice.

THE Bandung Conference showed in Asia and Africa a strong pro-democratic alignment and a considerable reservoir of goodwill toward the United States. But it also underlined a fact that Americans should know: The United States is not as popular with many of the Asians and the Africans as her friends would want her to be.

Now that the huffing and puffing ppreliminaries are over, the power-boat competitive season is ready to start. During the week ahead two major events will focus attention, first on navigating cruisers in Long Island Sound and, second on speeding outboards, mainly stock outboards, on a chain of Wisconsin rivers and lakes.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 18 -- Whether Free Vietnam can become a viable state and survive against the Communist North is still uncertain; but the southern Government of Ngo Dinh Diem has lately achieved progress of the kind that might make survival possible.

COLD weather and snow in the Chilean Andes is good news for skiers seeking vacation spots to indulge their favorite sport. Sparking the South American season is the new ski resort just opened near Santiago.

THE trudging burro, the spiked maguey cactus and the shady sombrero are still the symbols of the Mexican countryside, but more and more they are becoming just symbols. The real picture of Mexico has changed.
DAYTON, Ohio, June 18 (AP) -- Benjamin Smilg, tearful and greatful early today thanked a Federal jury that found him innocent of perjury.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A complete report of this week's first test of Government operations under simulated full-scale atomic attack will be presented to President Eisenhower and his Cabinet July 1.

The Camp Fire Girls grew in numbers from 392,000 at the close of 1953 to 430,125 at the close of 1954. The 1954 annual report of the organization, released last week, notes that the increase was the largest since 1947.

Members of the United Nations will convene in San Francisco this week for a special session marking the tenth anniversary of the signing of the U. N. Charter. What follows is a brief history of the organization, its accomplishments and failures, and some of the proposals that have been made for strengthening it.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 18 -- A sharp division of opinion regarding the desirability of Congressional investigations into anti-Semitism developed here tonight. Involved were representatives of Jewish organizations attending the annual plenary session of the National Community Relations Advisory Council.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 18 -- Mrs. John Gray Byler of Larchmont, N. Y., and South Londonderry, Vt., was elected president of the board of directors of the Wellesley College Alumnae Association at the annual meeting held on the campus today.

THIS is a lean, suspenseful history of a crack squadron of the Royal Air Force in World War II written by an Australian fighter pilot, author of the recent "Reach for the Sky." Packed with accounts of personal courage in bombing raids, the story of Squadron 617 is a demonstration that exceptional skill and ingenuity can, as Paul Brickhill puts it, "give one man or one unit the effectiveness of ten."

NEW DELHI, India, June 18 -- The Indian newspaper men covering the tour of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru in the Soviet Union think he has gleaned many new ideas for his country's second five-year plan. This plan is now in preparation.

Ten years ago, in San Francisco's War Memorial Opera House, Harry S. Truman addressed diplomats of fifty nations as Chief of State of their host. The signing of the Charter of the United Nations was under way. Mr. Truman's message was full of hope for the era ahead.

THE days when Stilicho, the Visigoth who became a Roman general, tried to shore up the timbers of a falling empire, set the time and Bordeaux, Rome and the Holy Land provide the place for this new historical novel by Helen C. White.

JmUST five years ago an experiment called the Children's International Summer Village began, with two unique aims---to bring together children from many lands for a month so that they might develop international friendships before they developed national prejudices, and to study their behavior under these unusual conditions.

PRIYAGOPAL, the Hindu dancer who taught at the famous Tagore school and is said besides to be the only exponent in this country of the Manipuri style, is giving a series of studio recitals under the auspices of Sunya Shurman at the Shurman Center, 251 West Seventy-second Street on Tuesday, Wednesday and Saturday evenings through June 29.

LINVILLE, N. C., June 18 (AP) Charlie Harrison, a 23-year-old insurance man from Atlanta, birdied the thirty-seventh hole to upset Billy Joe Patton in the final of the Southern Golf Association amateur golf tournament today.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 18 -- Mrs. George D. Widener's Evening Out won the $23,950 Regret Handicap at Monmouth Park today. The 4-year-old daughter of Shut Out responded to the guidance of Sammy Boulmetis in the stretch of the six-furlong fixture and scored by a half-length over Gandharva of the Brookmeade Stable.
Totally disabled workers need worry no longer about losing their Federal Social Security benefits.

Joseph Wechsberg in his mouth-watering "Tribute to a Prince of Gourmets" (June 5) is unjust to both Brillat-Savarin and America in writing that "he must have been unimpressed by America's culinary achievements."
SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- Station KQED provides a striking case history of the problems of educational television.

The Girl Scouts of the United States stressed self-government in the troop and resourcefulness in the girl in 1954. This was done, says the annual report, "to help each girl meet the challenge of living as a good citizen in her home, her nation and the world."
BERLIN, June 18 -- West Berlin, whose economy has long been sick, is beginning to confound the gloomy prognosis of its physicians.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- The stage was set here today for a two-phase diplomatic program, on which the curtain rises Monday afternoon.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 18 (UP) -- Hundreds of refugees besieged headquarters of the International Armistice Control Commission here today seeking to be returned to Communist North Vietnam.
ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 18 (Reuters) -- An American surgeon crossing the Atlantic on the line Nieuw Amsterdam saved the life of a 19-year-old Greek seaman in a mid-ocean operation.

OF late I have been importuned by younger friends to write my memoirs -- an invitation I recoil from since it carries the implication "before it is too late." In any case, I have no intention of doing so. In memoirs almost nothing seems to be set down in friendship; personal references are either too scant or too lukewarm to please the subject who inspired them.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 -- The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia noted that business activity has been "bouncing back faster from the 1953-54 recession than had been anticipated." The report said incomes are high and rising, with retail sales, especially in automobiles and department stores, exceeding expectations.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Bipartisanship in foreign policy has been the most flourishing and the most arresting product of the rather strange partnership of accommodation between the Republican White House and the Democratic Congress.
Last Friday was Ted Atkinsons's thirty - ninth birthday. Backers of the great jockey's mounts had no reason to bake him any cakes. He was beaten on three successive favorites.

TAIPEI, Formosa, June 18 -- The United States is expanding and realigning its command structure on Formosa. It is geared to continued "cold war" as well as to the possbile eruption of a hot war in this theatre.
Able Baker, that ubiquitous veteran of the airways, is still more popular than the upstart competitor, name of Alfa Bravo.

A week ago yesterday, the Yankees were in first place, five-and-a-half lengths ahead of the field. By late afternoon yesterday, following a 6-3 setback by the Chicago White Sox at the Stadium, Casey Stengels' Bombers were in second place, trailing the Pale Hose by 14 percentage points.

KENNEBUNKPORT, Me. -- A double-decker tramcar from Blackpool, England, has added an international flavor to the New England Electric Railway Historical Society, Inc., outdoor museum, off U. S. Route 1, in this coastal town.

THE particular problem of living on an isolated island and the universal one of learning how to be tolerant are skillfully interwoven in this story of Ann, the 9-year-old daughter of a Maine lighthouse family, and Betsy, a reluctant visitor from the Midwest.
VIENNA, June 18 -- The International Pen Club concluded its twenty-seventh congress here today after beating off a Communist attempt to infiltrate and make use of its organization.

It is almost ten years since Juan Peron strode from behind the scenes, where he wielded decisive power, to the center of the Argentine political arena and assumed the role of President. They have been ten tumultous years for Argentina. To foreign observers Peron seems a showman and poseur -- limitlessly ambitious, brilliant and capricious by turns, and above all, ruthless in manipulating the levers of powers.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 18 (AP) -- President Eisenhower mixed work with golf today -- and happily reported a couple of birdies after eighteen holes.

HIGH fidelity buffs can have themselves a field day with a new disk that comes from Westminster encased in a plastic, zipper-closed envelope and is specifically designed to show off the merits of a hi-fi set.

ON finishing this latest novel by Arthur C. Clarke, I had the eerie feeling that I had just returned from an actual stay on the moon. But this is more than just a brilliant essay on conditions as they are, and life as it may be lived, on our satellite.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 18 -- The American Association for the United Nations announced today that Walter W. Morrison, an 18-year-old high school junior of Bluefield, West Va., had won its annual high school contest. The prize is $500.

I was somewhat taken aback by Mrs. Durdin's reaction to the incident in which two native policemen leveled machine guns at her and ordered her off a sidewalk in order to let two Asians attending the Bandung Conference pass.
BUENOS AIRES, June 18 -- This is how Argentina's revolution began:

DARIEN, Conn., June 18 -The Saxon Woods Farm's Naute Mia gained the lead for the working hunter title in the first day of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show today. Naute Mia took blues in three events and placed second in two other tests.

Central Park was not a place of natural beauty one hundred years ago. It was marsh and swamp and ugly rock. Man took what nature left unfinished and through the years has helped to improve both its looks and its usefulness to the public.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Hoover Commission recommended today that the Government do what most Americans wished they could do -- exercise better control over spending.

Your editorial on June 7 entitled "What Verne Conceived" raises in my mind once again an old question. Without attempting to detract from Jules Verne's just fame, I nevertheless would like to ask: Did his ideas come out of his mind as pure originals or was there something, somebody who provided him at least with a spark or the germ of the idea of what has come to be known as science fiction?
A congregation was urged yesterday not to "prejudge as lawbreakers" those who gave the luncheon for William J. Keating when he was released from jail.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Irregular price fluctuations marked the grain and soybean futures trade last week. Wheat displayed considerable early strength, with buying based largely on the high prices at which new wheat was selling in the Southwest.

ST. LOUIS, June 19 -- If there is one thing the 1955 Dodgers seem able to do better than anything else it's to bounce back from adversity. Still smarting under the sting of losing last night's ten-inning thriller, Walter Alston's Brooks whipped the Cardinals today.

SUMMIT, N. J., June 19 (UP) -- A spokesman at the training camp of the light-heavyweight champion, Archie Moore, said today "it is pretty much understood" that Moore had successfully reduced to the light-heavyweight limit of 175 pounds.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The railroads and the railroad unions have joined to seek support for legislation backing the Administration's transportation policy.
New York begins its annual welcoming handshake to hot-weather visitors tomorrow when the Summer Festival opens.
ANCONA, Italy, June 19 (AP) -- Three speeding motorcycle drivers were killed today and three others and a girl bicyclist were injured in Italy's tenth Milan - to - Taranto motorcycle race.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- Ben Hogan said today he was "through with competition."
MANILA, Monday, June 20 (AP) -- The longest total eclipse in this century -- some scientists say the longest in nearly 1250 years -- today rolled an eighteen-mile wide path of darkness over Asia.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- Diplomatic notes from San Francisco:
SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- A man who was practically unknown in the world of sports a few days ago became the United States open golf champion today.

Debt service was paid in full in 1954 on $3,415,808,075, or 76.4 per cent of the total of $4,467,279,321 of publicly offered foreign dollar bonds outstanding on Dec. 31, according to a study issued by the Institute of International Finance of New York University.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 19 -- (AP) Jimmy Jackson of St. Louis retained his trans-Mississippi golf championship today with a 2-and-1 victory over Rex Baxter Jr., the 19-year-old Amarillo (Tex.) collegian Jimmy defeated in the final last year.
LONDON, June 19 -- For the stock markets the ending of the railway strike came as something of an anticlimax.

ASPEN, Colo. -- Women have the reputation of being over-talkative. However, in the opinion of Dr. Samuel Hayakawa, educator, writer and language expert, they are less so than men. Dr. Hayakawa, interviewed while attending the Fifth International Design Conference just concluded here, opened the meetings with some constructive comments on how to attend a conference.
Fifty to 100 private colleges and universities will share in $50,000,000 to be given by the Ford Foundation to help increase faculty salaries.
STRATFORD, Conn., June 19 (UP) -- The twenty-third annual Great Eastern skeet shoot was completed at the Lordship range today with shoot-offs in nearly every event.

A sense of shock must be felt by any thinking citizen who studies the state of science teaching in our high schools as described in these columns yesterday. Only about half of our high schools offer courses in chemistry or physics, and less than 5 per cent of our high school students study physics.
Frederick Hill Atkinson, 20-year-old son of Frederick Griswold Atkinson, vice president of R. H. Macy Co., was killed Friday in a crash of his own plane in British Columbia.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- Jack Fleck, golf's new open champion, comes from Davenport, Iowa., the heart of the corn belt. "But Ive never been a farmer," he said today soon after receiving the trophy and the check of $6,000 that goes to the winner.
BERLIN, June 19 -- West German Government leaders believe the first task in the forthcoming negotiations with Moscow will be to strike at the roots of Soviet fear of Germany.

A building containing forty-four apartments and five stores at 1984 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by the Cutler Realty Corporation to the Portchester Realty Corporation for investment. Assessed at $150,000, the parcel went for cash over two mortgages amounting to $125,000.

Robert Byrne of Indiauapolis, who will leave with the American team for Moscow on Thursday, won ten games yesterday to capture first prize at the Manhattan Chess Club. The club was celebrating its successful defense of the Metropolitan Chess League championship.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 19 -- The Mayor of Haifa, an Israeli Labor party member, and the Mayor of Nazareth, a Christian Arab, both told Mayor Wagner today that New York was "the greatest city in the world."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- President Eisenhower flew into San Francisco tonight to convey to diplomats the "abiding hope" of the people of the United States that the next decade will make the United Nations an increasingly potent force for peace.

BUENOS AIRES, June 19 (AP) -Argentina's new military strong man, Army Minister Franklin Lucero, in the communique tonight sharply criticized rumormongers he said were trying to prevent the country from returning to normal.

FROM anyone who likes food, a trip to the Washington Market is particularly rewarding at this season. Produce stalls are piled high with vegetables fresh from near-by gardens. On fish counters a wide variety of delicacies from the sea are arranged in neat, iced rows.
A comprehensive program for eliminating abuses in labor-management pension and welfare funds was sent to Federal and state agencies yesterday by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Senator Stuart Symington warned today that the Soviet Union had "thousands more" jet fighters and light jet bombers than the United States. The Russians also "probably" lead in long-range jet bombers and guided missiles, he said.
Dr. Channing H. Tobias, chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, denied yesterday that salvation depended upon a detailed creed.

Lee Thompson Smith, vice chairman of the traffic and parking committee of the Real Estate Board of New York, addressing a City Council committee at a public hearing on an anti-noise bill, said some harsh things about auto horns. Honking, Mr. Smith maintained, raises the blood pressure and pulse rates, befogs the brain and possibly causes strokes.
A clergyman marked the close of his second "lifetime" career yesterday when he preached his final sermon as minister of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold and members of his staff dropped in at the War Memorial Opera House this morning to inspect the final arrangements for tomorrow's United Nations tenth anniversary program and found everything in order.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- The Council of State Chambers of Commerce branded the $1,000,000,000 Upper Colorado River project today "one of the most expensive but least economic water resource projects ever acted upon by Congress."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19 -- Dr. Donald H. Menzel, director of the Harvard College Observatory, announced today that six observatories in six countries would take part in the program of the Boyden Station in South Africa, beginning July 1. They will share observing time.

SYRACUSE, June 19 (AP) -- Navy's great Olympic championship crew of 1952 is coming back intact next year to give Cornell's college kingpins and other contenders a battle for a berth on the 1956 Olympic squad.
DARIEN, Conn., June 19 -- Waiting Home, owned and shown by Peggy Augustus of Cobham, Va., captured the conformation hunter championship as the two-day Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show ended today.
DAVENPORT, Iowa, June 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Lynn Fleck, the 26-year-old wife of the new national open golf champion, sat by the telephone tonight with a slip of paper in her hand.

May I express my appreciation of "Topics of The Times" of June 7, dealing with official participation of Americans with their Government in European trade fairs? As you so vividly point out, the cold war now is moving to the fair grounds; and along with this basic object of simplifying trade there comes international amity and understanding.
One of West Germany's major industrial organizations is now in the early stages of a drive aimed at expanding use of Diesel equipment in the United States.

GIVE Hollywood a little longer and it will be turning television into a coast-to-coast trailer. Last night, the Warner brothers hit the jackpot on the Ed Sullivan Show, "Toast of the Town," with a sixty-minute advertisement for their forthcoming film version of the stage success "Mister Roberts."
Gordon Dean, former chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, last night condemned what he said was Government failure to implement the President's "atoms for peace" proposal.

Philippine President Magsaysay has let it be known that Manila and Tokyo have reached an agreement on reparations. The Filipinos scaled down their original claims drastically and agreed to a program that is within Japan's capacity. Actual cash indemnification will be only $20,000,000 and this payment is to be spread over five years.

A new emphasis on the importance of surprise attack in the age of nuclear weapons is being openly disseminated by Soviet military leaders in the Soviet press. The concept that such an attack by planes or guided missiles delivering atomic and hydrogen weapons may be decisive in war is apparently being incorporated in Soviet strategic doctrine.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 19 -- Stanleigh P. Friedman of New York City, composer of the music for Yale's football song, "Down the Field," was honored by his alma mater today when he returned for his fiftieth class reunion.
Msgr. Edwin B. Broderick yesterday reprimanded Roman Catholics who arrogate to themselves God's right to judge who shall be saved.

The George Gershwin Memorial Foundation of B'nai Birith Victory Lodge has set Aug. 31 as the deadline for its eleventh annual competition for an unpublished orchestral composition by a young American composer. As in previous years the prize will consist of $1,000 and a performance by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- During the first quarter of this year foreign nations sold about $190,000,000 more in the United States than they bought here, exclusive of military aid.

F. A. Mitchell-Hedges, British archaeological explorer, has written his autobiography which Little, Brown will issue Aug. 15 under the title "Danger My Ally." He tells how he rose from a penniless boy to a millionaire explorer-collector and recounts his adventures.
Egg timers became pawns of the chess world yesterday in the Bohemian atmosphere of Washington Square Park.

BOSTON, June 19 (UP) -- The Boston Red Sox, led by Ted Williams, Jimmy Piersall and Norm Zauchin, today downed the Cleveland Indians, 11 -- 7. The victory was Boston's third over the league champions in the four-game series and the Sox' eleventh triumph in their last thirteen games.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The National Advisory Committee on Poliomyelitis Vaccine will meet here Wednesday for the first time since May 2.
New York strained almost to bursting between 1930 and 1955, the tensest quarter-century in her 302 municipal years.
Government, already a major factor in the American economy, seems destined to absorb an even larger share, according to the annual report of the National Bureau of Economic Research.
Five new films, including an import from the Soviet Union, are scheduled to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

BUENOS AIRES, June 19 -- Gen. Franklin Lucero declared today that the country was rapidly becoming "more and more tranquil." In a communique, the Army Minister issued orders that indicated the tranquillity in some sections of the country was an uneasy one.

EIGHT century-old brownstone-brick chimneys, sturdiest, and probably the last, of their kind in the city, are coming off the roof of the former J. P. Morgan mansion at Thirty-seventh Street and Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Zionist leaders stressed today the role of Israel's strategic position in the Middle East as a democratic bulwark. They also appealed to the Soviet Union to remove "oppressive measures" against Zionists.
More than a million persons in New York and New Jersey received old age and survivors insurance benefits last December under the Federal Social Security program.
Indications that the fall of Gen. Juan D. Person as dictator of Argentina was imminent were reported to The New York Times from Buenos Aires yesterday.

ZANDVOORT-ON-SEA the Netherlands, June 19 (AP) -- The world champion driver, Juan Manuel Fangio of Argentina, won his third Grand Prix automobile race of this season today, virtually assuring him of retaining the title.

HONG KONG, June 19 -- United States officials here are prepared to receive as civilians dishonorably discharged from the army three former American soldiers who have changed their minds about remaining in Communist China.

British sterling was on the soft side all week, selling down to $2.78-15/16, on Friday, lowest since early March. The decline carried from $2.79-15/32, on Tuesday. Friday's close was $2.78-31/32, a loss of 9/32 cent, from the previous week. Futures widened in sympathy with the easier spot rate. Transferable sterling closed at $2.77 15/.25.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 19 -- The new offerings market here is becoming very active. Several domestic industries need fresh equity or bond capital and an increasing number of foreign loans are being floated.

Representative Michael A. Feighan, Democrat of Ohio, charged today that Secretary of State Dulles had "become the unwitting victim of the tip-toe artists in the Department of State who have for years advocated a policy of delicate diplomacy in dealing with the Russian Communists."

Ethel Merman, who once appeared on a big anniversary program for the Ford Motor Company, may star in her own anniversary show on television. It would be tied in with the singer's legitimate theatre debut twenty-five years ago.

PARIS, June 19 -- During the tense decade since the United Nation Charter was signed in San Francisco the entire world power relationship has altered. Japan, in June, 1945, was still fighting for its life. China, first victim of the last war and therefore first Charter signatory, had not yet experienced its shattering revolution.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., June 19 -- Second seeded George Ball of New York won two matches today and reached the quarter-finals of the New Jersey State tennis championship.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission is awaiting a Federal Court of Appeals judgment on whether its general counsel must serve a sixty-day jail sentence for contempt of court.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The International Monetary Fund said today that progress had been made in the last year in removing depression-born and war-born shackles from international trade and finance.
Augustine Rivera, a restaurant owner who lives at 70 Gouverneur Place, the Bronx, took a 300-pound pig home with him last night and put it in the cellar.
Franklin Lucero had seldom appeared in the news in the United States prior to this time and is not listed in Who's Who in Latin America.

FRANKLIN LAKES, N. J., June 19 -- Nine children who got polio vaccinations last Thursday against the advice of local officials were asked by the Board of Education today to stay away from school this week.

FIFTY or seventy-five years ago, when the seventh (maybe) of ten children (perhaps) took to drink, ran afoul of the authorities or otherwise blotted his copybook, some neighbor was usually ready with the observation, "There's one in every family."

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 19 (Reuters) -- The prototype of the first Dutch airliner since the war, the Fokker F-27 Friendship, will be test flown this summer. The flight will mark the return of a famous name to civil aviation.
Two cash awards of $500 each have been added to the annual honors bestowed by the Fire Department for heroism and excellence in administration.
PARIS, June 19 -- The Senatorial elections demonstrated today the static quality of France's multifold political party divisions.
CAIRO, June 19 -- The United Nations Palestine truce chief suggested officially yesterday that the forthcoming Israeli-Egyptian talks on frontier tension be held in No Man's Land in Jerusalem.
Governor Harriman proposed yesterday that the state spend more money for probation officers.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, proposed today that Congress outlaw any pay-as-you-see television.

Unaccustomed as they were to being in first place, the Chicago White Sox did not hold the American League lead long enough to enjoy it. Kings, as it were, for a day, the Pale Hose were beaten twice by the Yankees, 7 -- 1 and 5 -- 2, at the Stadium yesterday and dusk found the Bombers back on top in the league race.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- The Administration is trying something new in its effort to hold back information it feels would help a potential enemy but that cannot be classfied as secret.
Showings of women's apparel to the trade are becoming major productions.
LONDON, June 19 -- The "Eden plan" for the reunification of Germany through free elections was reviewed and approved today by the British Prime Minister and the West German Chancellor.

Ten years after the international gathering of representatives of fifty governments that drew up the Charter of the United Nations the delegates of sixty governments are today meeting in San Francisco to commemorate a decade of uneasy peace and of hopes that sometimes dwindled but were never completely lost.

Fifty acres of land on North Division Street, near the Town of Cortlandt line, in Peekskill have been purchased by L. Philip Falk, New York realty investor and developer, for subdividing into 150 homes sites. The Westchester tract is about a mile from the main business district in Peekskill.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -President Eisenhower today urged members of the International Young People's Luther League to build "bridges of understanding" among nations.
The following book, published recently, may be of interest to parents:
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 19 -- There is a growing belief here than General Lucero, not President Peron, is giving the orders now in Argentina.

IN Zurich the streets are neat and clean, the traffic is orderly and the houses are gay with window boxes and balconies overflowing with red geraniums and white petunias. When I was there last July on the last day of my vacation flags were out and girls in traditional Swiss costumes were strolling about in honor of the national holiday.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 19 -- Prison conditions hold a threat to the country's entire social system, the National Probation and Parole Association was told tonight.

PARIS, June 19 -- French-Yugoslav financial and commercial negotiations will begin next month as a result of a recent visit to Belgrade of Pierre Abelin, French Secretary of State for Financial Affairs.

The prohibitions of the big city -- the absence of empty lots, the emphasis on private property, the lack of understanding from harried adults -- has contributed to youth's loneliness and restlessness, the Rev. Hugh McCandless said yesterday.
The keel of a 32,650-dead-weight-ton tanker, the first vessel to be built under the Government's "trade-in-and-build" program, will be laid tomorrow at Baltimore.
The Board of Estimate was reported yesterday to have received a request for planning funds for the first of at least fourteen factory projects here.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Republicans said today that an increase of at least 25 per cent in Social Security taxes would be required to finance a Democratic proposal for liberalization of the Old Age and Survivors' Insurance System.

Tariff reductions on textile items granted by the United States to Japan, as worked out at the Geneva conference of GATT (General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade), were denounced last week by the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute. Inc., as "a staggering blow."
MOSCOW, June 10 -- Ten days of harmony and amity between the Soviet Union and the United States in the sporting arena concluded tonight, with wine, food, music and dancing.

LONDON, June 19 -- In tennis circles, Wimbledon is the big one. An entry of 128 players, gathered from thirty countries, will open fire tomorrow on the hallowed lawns of the All England Tennis Club for what is usually regarded as the world championship.
Plans for the election of union officers by 15,000 New York furriers on Wednesday have been postponed indefinitely by the parent union.

THE one gimmick that lends speculative appeal to Wednesday's Polo Grounds championship fight between Archie Moore and Bobo Olso is a rather weighty one. It concerns the ability of the elderly Moore to reduce his avoirdupois until it complies with the 175-pound light-heavyweight limit. At catchweights the ancient Archie could be expected to pulverize the middleweight champion.
MOSCOW, June 19 -- Commentators in the Soviet Union, which has no visible Civil Defense organization, have for several days been ridiculing Operation Alert held last week in the United States.
KATONAH, N. Y., June 19 -- Give the public a worthwhile attraction in a handsome setting, and it will go out of its way to show its appreciation.

Transatlantic coal cargoes last week continued to lead the chartering market and brought slightly higher rates. Grain lagged a bit, however, as quickly converted tankers continued the invasion of this hitherto exclusively dry cargo vessel field.
Harris J. Klein called yesterday for a 25-cent combination bus-subway fare as a cure for the city's transit ills.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Eugene Meyer, chairman of the board of The Washington Post Company, announced today that he and his wife, Mrs. Agnes E. Meyer, were giving almost $500,000 of stock in the company to 711 employes and circulation contractors.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -Twenty-five leading doctors from twelve nations will begin tomorrow a thirty-seven-day tour to see how the United States is applying the atom to medicine. The visit is part of President Eisenhower's "atoms for peace" program.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- The General Motors Corporation announced today that it would conduct a giant display of high-powered trucks, trains, boats and machinery from Aug. 31 through Sept. 25. It will be on the lakefront site of Chicago's Century of Progress Exposition.

Pakistan has now announced that final agreement has been reached on the details of the plan through which the United States will furnish arms to its Asian ally. Shipments of materials are expected to go forward in the near future.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, said today that the times "are far from ripe for world government."
Candidly labeled "Almost Crazy," the satirical revue will begin its career at 8 o'clock this evening at the Longacre.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- This is a real birthday party the United Nations is having out here: free eats, free booze, flags and bunting all over Nob Hill and June and peace bustin' out all over.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- "The world moves," the philosopher Anon remarked. A delegate to the United Nations tenth anniversary session paraphrased the sentiment today to read: "What a whale of a difference a few years make!"

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 19 --Illustrative of the growing activity of Hollywood motion picture studios in television is the fact that five producing companies will participate in the collective bargaining contract negotiations between the Screen Actors Guild and the Alliance of Television Film Producers.

CHICAGO, June 19 (UP) -- Marv Blaylock's single and Willie Jones' double gave the Philadelphia Phillies a fifteen-inning 1-0 victory over Chicago today. Then the Cubs gained an 8-7 seven-inning triumph before 34,529 fans.

PITTSBURGH, June 19 -- Those automotive steel cutbacks reported in some circles in recent weeks turned out to be false alarms. On the heels of successful labor negotiations, expediters for automobile companies put their pressure on steel concern for bigger and faster deliveries.

ROME, June 19 -- The two prelates expelled by Argentina last week were wildly acclaimed when they officiated in an outdoor ceremony tonight. Earlier today they were honored by Pope Plus XII during a beatification rite in St. Peter's Basilica.
LONDON, June 19 -- Shipping officials in Liverpool were hopeful today that the three-week wildcat strike of trans-Atlantic crews would end this week.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, has told lawmakers he is willing to work under a "tight limit" on the national debt. He has said he will let Congress figure how high the ceiling should go.
Ship union leaders predicted yesterday a swift break in the united front of strikebound tanker operators.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 19 -- A welcome breeze from the southeast helped a record fleet of 103 craft scoot across the finish line in the Knickerbocker Yacht Club's regatta on Long Island Sound today.

Governor Harriman said yesterday that New York State "probably won't have too much additional vaccine until the end of July" for anti-polyiomyelitis injections.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- An Air Force spokesman said tonight that Capt. Harold Fischer Jr., Korean War jet ace who was a prisoner of the Chinese Reds, had "confessed" to his captors having taken part in germ warfare against them.
May I suggest that the recent automobile accident on Grand Central Parkway appears to give convincing evidence of the need for a law requiring automobile inspection.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 19 (Reuters) -- A two-member Princeton University expedition to Tirich Mir has conquered 24,242foot Istornal, another unclimbed peak in the western Karakorums near Chitral, the Pakistan radio said tonight.

The principle of "the large economy size" is to be applied to the American motorist and his consumption of products and services. There are two objectives to a promotion drive now getting under way on the theme: "Drive More.

Well, Father's Day is over now, and the occasion was a very pleasant one, indeed. There was beef for dinner, and while it was rare, as the cook prefers it, rather than well done, it came in accompanied by Yorkshire pudding.

MILWAUKEE, June 19 --Leaders and authorities in industry, finance, education and engineering will explore the future of the United States' economic health in a conference in business and economics at Marquette University Tuesday and Wednesday.
Co-existence is an impossible dream, a former prisoner of Communist China declared last night.
MILWAUKEE, June 19 -- Leo Durocher benched Willie Mays today for the first time in the Say-Hey Kid's baseball career, but it didn't change the Giants' fortunes.
SAN JUAN, P. R., June 19 -- Approximately 45,000 persons here will lose their jobs if the United States Senate bill 2168 becomes law, a Government spokesman said today.

Eino Keerd, an 18-year-old member of the New York Pioneer Club, broke a 19-year old shot-put record yesterday at the outdoor junior track and field championships of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union.

The eight-story loft building on a plot 120 by 142 feet at 227 West Seventeenth Street has been purchased for investment by David Green in a deal negotiated by Williams Co., brokers. The property is occupied by firms in the printing and allied trades and is assessed at $175,000.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Dr. Ralph E. Lapp, the atomic scientist, said today that the national civil defense test Operation Alert was obsolete before it began. He said there had been inadequate consideration of dangerous radio-active fall-out.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Davy Crockett, who has no statue to his memory in Congress' statuary hall, has acquired a stand-in who seems to satisfy children just as well.

OSTEND, Belgium, June 19 (UP) -- A crowd of Roman Catholics rioted today against the Government's school reform bill. The throng wrecked a waterfront cafe in an attempted attack on the son of Belgium's Socialist Premier, Achille van Acker.

The Urban League of Greater New York said yesterday that new hiring procedures going into effect this week on the Brooklyn Waterfront would offer a more equitable opportunity to the 1,000 Negroes among the 12,000 longshoremen there.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- The eve of the tenth anniversary celebration of the signing of the United Nations Charter recalled tonight the creation of that instrument here in 1945. President Truman at that time opened the conference with a telephoned message from Washington.

LONDON, June 20 -- There were indications today that 20,000 dock workers, who have been on strike in seven ports for a month, were getting ready to return to work. The seamen's unofficial strike also appeared to be easing.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 20 (AP) -- Top-seeded Crawford Henry of Atlanta breezed past two opponents today to advance to the third round of the forty-seventh annual national interscholastic tennis tournament.
Because of their size and variation, income taxes must be considered a part of production costs, the thirty-sixth annual International Cost Conference was advised yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (UP) -- The Smithsonian Institution reported today that 3,622 forms of mammals had been identified in North America.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Samuel Pines, a Republic Aviation Corporation chief engineer until suspended on security allegations, has been cleared by the Defense Department's Industrial Review Security Board.

The five-story building containing forty-two apartments and nine stores at 5 South Sixteenth Street in Mount Vernon, N. Y., has been purchased by George M. Munk from the A. M. R. Trading Corporation. The property was held at $225,000.
Edward S. Silver, Brooklyn District Attorney, found no evidence yesterday of criminal negligence in the collision of two subway trains Sunday in Coney Island.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 20 (UP) -- Evan R. Dale, 39 years old, Southern Illinois union leader now under a fifteen-year sentence for labor racketeering, pleaded guilty today and was sentenced to ten years imprisonment for income tax evasion.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- President Eisenhower talked to Republican politicians today like a man who was going to run for re-election.
American education is about to lose one of its most controversial school groups.

The tenth anniversary celebration of the United Nations began in flag-bedecked San Francisco yesterday with an opening speech by President Eisenhower which was at once a rededication of the United States to unswerving loyalty to the world organization, a major pronouncement on the fundamentals of American policy and a challenge to the Communist slave system.
TOKYO, June 16 -- Leading pro-American Japanese hope the United States will parole war criminals still held in Sugamo prison here as a friendly gesture on this tenth anniversary of Japan's surrender.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- President Eisenhower reaffirmed today the "unswerving loyalty" and "tireless support" of the United States for the purposes, aims and hopes of the United Nations.
The Board of Air Pollution Control moved yesterday to end the nuisance of smoke from the exhausts of gasoline-driven buses.
LOS ANGELES, June 20 (AP) -- A million Los Angeles Transit Lines patrons improvised ways to get to and from work today as busmen and motormen went on strike.

And still the autos roll out in record numbers. Yesterday the four-millionth passenger car of the year came off assembly lines. Never before had that figure been reached thus early in the year. In 1950, for instance, up until now the industry's biggest production year, the four-millionth car was manufactured in late August.
PARIS, June 20 -- Gilbert Grandval, chief of the French diplomatic mission to the Saar, was appointed today to succeed Francis Lacoste as Resident General in French Morocco.

ATLANTA, June 20 -- The country's "junior" business leaders were told today that the future of the American economy depended on their ability to inform educators of the long-range needs of industrial management.
WIENER NEUSTADT, Austria, June 20 (AP) -- Austrian prisoners who returned home from the Soviet Union today said they knew of eight Americans in Soviet labor camps.
HARTFORD, June 20 -- A program for streamlining of the Legislature was approved today by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff and the legislative leaders.
In two ceremonies yesterday fifty-five Salvation Army cadets dedicated their lives to the service of others and received commissions as probationary lieutenants.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- The Argentine uprising against President Juan D. Peron has brought changes in the country's delegation at the tenth anniversary commemorative meeting of the United Nations.
BUENOS AIRES, June 20 -- Argentina celebrated its Flag Day today without a message from President Juan D. Peron. It was more like Army Day.
The Bureau of Child Guidance yesterday sharply criticized Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, for providing a new salary differential between bureau social workers and psychologists.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Government has begun a study of the bearing of maritime labor costs on the subsidies it pays to ship operators.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Thirty-three months in prison in Red China -- thirty-three months of bad food, dungeons, grueling "mental coercion," and finally a forced confession of flying under orders into Chinese territory during the Korean War.
DETROIT, June 20 (AP) -- Henry Ford 2d said today he would like to see all the auto manufacturers bargain together with the United Auto Workers, C. I. O.

TWO of television's most warmly human characters, "Ethel and Albert," portrayed by Peg Lynch and Alan Bunce, returned to the air last night at 9:30 P. M. on Channel 2. They should be one of the bright spots on the summer dial.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 20 -- One-third of this country's prison inmates ought to be released immediately, a leading penologist said today.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- President Eisenhower asked the Senate today to approve permanent four-star rank for Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway. It would be effective when General Ridgway retires Jun e30 as Army Chief of Staff.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- United Air Lines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to deny route-type operations to the nonscheduled or irregular airlines.
In one sense Our Town comes of age today, when the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau opens what promises to be the first effective Visitor Information Center in our history.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- To the veterans of the organization meetings of the United Nations in 1945 its tenth anniversary celebration at San Francisco is demonstrating the durability of the French proverb that the more things change the more they remain the same.
Suburban retailing may continue to mushroom, but the downtown department store is far from dead.
JERUSALEM, June 20 -- Mayor Wagner of New York had a part today in starting the construction of the World Academy for Higher Jewish Studies.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The House of Representatives, by 370 to 3, passed a bill today to give a 7.5 per cent pay rise to more than 1,000,000 Government white-collar workers. The cost would be about $325,000,000 a year.
TAIPEI, Formosa, June 20 -- The Nationalist Chinese press took a bitter view of the United Nations' tenth anniversary today.

A juror who admitted he had read newspaper clippings about the defendant while serving on murder-case panel was sentenced yesterday to five days in jail and fined $250 by Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz.
ST. LOUIS, June 20 -- Former President Harry S. Truman said tonight that the drive to raise money for the library to house his personal papers was rapidly nearing its goal.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 20 -- By the margin of the best half-volley in tennis, Sven Davidson of Sweden outlasted Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., on Wimbledon's historic center court today. The score was 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, 4 -- 6, 8 -- 6.

Erie Railroad sold $3,270,000 of fifteen-year, 3 per cent equipment trust certificates yesterday to a group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., which had submitted a bid of 99.319. This represented an interest cost to the Erie of 3.085 per cent.
CINCINNATI, June 20 -- Home runs by Dusty Rhodes and Bill Taylor were not enough to pull the Giants out of their losing streak at Crosley Field tonight.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 20 (AP) -- John Marschall, an Iowa sophomore, took a commanding lead at the end of the first eighteen-hole qualifying round of the National Collegiate golf championship today. He shot a six-under-par 66.

A mother's honesty resulted last night in the solution by the police of a $2.700 Brooklyn theft that had not been reported. Another result was that five boys from 10 to 13 years old were questioned after a day's fun at Coney Island.
After fifty-four years and 2,000,000 miles with the Pennsylvania Railroad, 70-year-old engineer Henry L. Vogel made his last run yesterday.
Juan Domingo Peron is paying the price of having isolated himself. Much that is happening in Argentina is obscure, but one thing is clear: President Peron's position has been greatly weakened.

IT would be ungracious, indeed, to let pass unnoticed the retirement of Ben Hogan from the field of competitive golf. The doughty little Texan was too great a champion to get "the king is dead, long live the king" treatment. But the presumption has to be that he means to abdicate for keeps. It seemed yesterday as though Blazin' Ben was beginning to hedge slightly.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., June 20 -- A car carrying six young persons from a church baseball game collided head-on with a truck tonight. Four boys and a girl were killed and the sixth auto passenger was critically injured.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A sharply modified military reserves plan was presented to the House of Representatives today in an effort to revive the stalled program. The plan is to build up a 2,900,000-man trained and ready Reserve by 1960.
Elliott Murphy's "Aquashow" begins its eleventh season at the Amphitheatre in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens, tonight at 9 o'clock.

Coffee prices fell sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Most options dropped almost the 2-cents-a-pound limit. Trading was influenced by reports that Brazil intended to terminate buying of coffee to support prices, change the export classification and to eliminate minimum export prices.

ST. LOUIS, June 20 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals pushed across three unearned runs in the fourth inning tonight to defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 4 -- 1. Rookie southpaw Luis Arroyo scattered seven hits and batted in two runs.
CHICAGO, June 20 -- Most families are refurnishing more frequently than in the past, and they are doing it with less expensive furniture.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 (UP) -- Jack Fleck, who had trouble making enough money to buy hamburgers during the past few months on the golf tour, today suddenly was thrust into the merry-go-round that brings riches to the national open champion.
PARIS, June 20 -- Accidents in the streets of Paris have decreased one-fourth since Andre Dubois, Prefect of Police, issued his anti-horn edict last summer. The edict went into effect Aug. 1, 1954.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 20 (UP) -- First-round matches involving Americans and other leading players in the All-England tennis tournament today:

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France placed before the Soviet Union tonight proposals for conducting the forthcoming Big Four heads-of-government meeting.
PITTSBURGH, June 20 -- The country's biggest steel producer today promised its 200,000 unionized employes a pay increase that would take into account their "cooperation, loyalty and productivity."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- The Soviet Union is lobbying among other delegates in an attempt to get the United Nations anniversary meeting to endorse the general principles of great power cooperation, peace and the "spirit of San Francisco" that prevailed ten years ago.
ORANGE, N. J., June 20 -- Carmen Lampe of Forest Hills, the top-seeded player, won impressively today as the New Jersey State women's singles championship opened at the Berkeley Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby said tonight that the responsibility for Federal actions in the poliomyelitis vaccine situation rested with Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 20 -- Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer and Spencer Tracy were debating today whether the star would continue in the film "Tribute to a Bad Man."

In the letter from E. F. W. Wildermuth a portion of the Constitution of the United States was quoted in support of the Bricker amendment. The purpose of the quotation was to show that federal treaties are now above the Constitution and can supersede it.

Stockholders of the Allied Thermal Corporation will meet on June 28 to act on a proposed increase in authorized common stock preliminary to a 100 per cent stock dividend, it was announced yesterday by H. B. Bassette, secretary and treasurer.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 20 -- A leading Jewish spokesman proposed tonight that women be ordained as rabbis. In the long history of Judaism this has never been done.
CHICAGO, June 20 -- Uneasiness over the possibility that wheat growers will vote down the wheat quotas on Saturday affected the market today. Wheat sold off materially before meeting much support.
PIQUANT flavor combinations in mixed vegetables are just one of the reasons for mixing them. Practicality is another.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- Jose Maza, veteran Chilean diplomat, has been put forward as a leading candidate for the presidency of the next General Assembly session.
MANILA, Friday, June 21 -- Racing the shadow of the moon in a jet aircraft is one way to observe a total solar eclipse. Dr. Frank Back of New York is convinced it is the best way.
MADRID, June 20 -- The Falange party has asked that its political future be guaranteed by the Spanish Constitution.
The pause that is not so refreshing hit Coca-Cola deliveries in the metropolitan area yesterday.
The New York Red Cross Regional Blood Program received 512 pints of blood on Friday. Included were 173 pints taken at aPn American World Airways, New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- A calmer atmosphere and a better understanding among the nations of the world may be emerging in international affairs, Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, said today.
CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- Another climb in hog prices moved the top to $22.65, highest since a dime more was paid Aug. 26. Buying was fairly active at strong to mostly 25 cents higher levels.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 20 -- Harvard salvaged the last of its three-game baseball series with Yale by downing the Elis, 4 -- 2, before a reunion crowd of 6,000 at Yale Field today.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Henry H. Heimann, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men, warned both business and government today against unrestrained optimism that refuses to recognize the possibility of economic setbacks.
Oscar Pita, I45 1/2 pounds, Argentina, knocked out Gene Poirier, 147 1/4, Niagara Falls, N. Y., at the end of the eighth, round of a scheduled ten-round bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

The four - story apartment building accommodating thirty-five families at 28-46 Forty-first Street in Astoria, Queens, has been sold by John Dernpitch and John Spanjich to a client of Samuel Helpern, attorney. The property is assessed at $125,000.

The voice of James Stewart, the film actor, was on the telephone all day yesterday. Columbia Pictures, which is bringing out his new film, "The Man From Laramie," hit on a "Call Jimmy Stewart" advertising idea that is succeeding far beyond its hopes.
ORIENTAL fashions, which lately have gone to the heads of American designers, have gone to the feet at Bonwit Teller.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., June 20 (UP) -- A Denver man was held by the police today, accused of firings on at least ten passing automobiles because their drivers did not dim their lights. Four men were injured.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 20 -- DeCoursey Fales' schooner Nina was leading and the Naval Academy's big yawl Royono was out of contention with a parted headstay half-way in the ocean race to this port today.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The United States rejected again today a Soviet demand for release of a Soviet tanker and crew seized last June 23 by Chinese Nationalist forces.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 20 -- Clouds and rain covering most of Ceylon obscured a total eclipse of the sun today. Scientists from many parts of the world who were here to make observations, were disappointed.
The New York City Housing Authority will open bids on July 6 for $67,527,000 in short-term loan notes.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, June 20 -- The feverish boom in uranium stocks has simmered down.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (UP) -- The Internal Revenue Service has advised breweries to stop contending that their beer is non-fattening.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Mrs. Marie Natvig was jailed today under a sentence of eight months to two years for lying under oath in the Federal Communication Commission's hearing in the Edward O. Lamb case.

BONN, Germany, June 20 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer postponed tonight the Bundestag debate on the bill giving the government temporary authority to enlist volunteers for a new West German army.

A six-story building containing five stores and thirty-four apartments at 601 West 162d Street has been sold by the Charles Berlin estate to an investing client of Earl Gallant, attorney. The property occupies a plot about 42 by 69 by 175 feet at the northwest corner of Broadway.
Cracks began to develop yesterday in the solid front of strikebound oil tankers.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., June 20 (UP) -- Sgt. John Lester Tyler of Moundsville, W. Va., was arrested here today on the charge of collaborating with the enemy in Korea, the Public Information Office disclosed.
The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange on June 15 was the smallest since Jan. 15, 1954, apparently reflecting increased margin requirements.

LONDON, June 20 -- Sir Anthony Eden hailed today the atomic agreements. He said they were a "marked advance" that put Britain ahead of the other North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries in her relation to the United States.
The cotton futures market closed quiet on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, 3, points off to 3 up.
James J. Moran was convicted yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court of cheating the Government of $131,307 in personal income taxes.
" Summertime," the adaptation of the Arthur Laurents romantic drama "The Time of the Cuckoo," will have its premiere at 8:30 tonight at the Astor Theatre.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 20 -- Octavio Marcondes Ferraz, Minister of Transport, will back a plan to transform the Government-owned coastal lines into mixed corporations, with private capital taking a large share of their management, it was learned today.
" ALMOST CRAZY," which opened at the Longacre last evening, will probably appeal most to people who have difficulty in hearing. It looks better than it sounds.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov probably was the most closely observed figure, next to President Eisenhower, on the United Nations stage today.

Officials of the Friends of the City Center turned out yesterday to be "friends" of a sort of the Democratic National Committee. And it threatened to cost them a little amity. They were found to have made a deal -- postal, not political -- with the Democrats. They traded mailing lists.
SCHROON LAKE, N. Y., June 20 -- L. Judson Morhouse, chairman of the Republican State Committee, called today for legislative action to allow towns to revise their forms of government.
TOKYO, June 20 -- Japan expects to compromise with the Philippines on Manila's claim for $800,000,000 in World War II reparations, Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu said today.
ALBANY, June 20 -- Governor Harriman announced today that a loyalty questionnaire was being circulated to about sixty employes in the Executive Chamber.

EAST GREENBUSH, N. Y., June 20 (UP) -- A state trooper and four motorists were injured seriously early today when the trooper's car crashed into a stolen car he was chasing. The occupants of the stolen car -- two men and a woman -- were captured later.
THE Peconic Bay weakfish are now fairly plentiful, responsive, and seem to be running somewhat larger. However porgies still constitute a problem.
The stock market developed some easiness in the late trading yesterday and final prices were pretty well mixed.
ROME, June 20 -- All of the ministers in Premier Mario Scelba's Cabinet resigned today.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The development of the Navy's newest jet fighter, the XF8U-1, was announced today.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 20 -- An Argentine Congressman said here today that President Peron suspected Gen. Franklin Lucero had ambitions for power. He said President Peron had hurried back last year from a motion-picture festival because of rumors that General Lucero was organizing a plot.

A posthumous edition of the apperceptions and convictions of the late Justice Robert H. Jackson regarding the Supreme Court will be published July 8 by Harvard University Press. It has been titled "The Supreme Court in the American System of Government."

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today representatives of the State Public Service Commissions will sit with it at hearings in September on the question of continuing railroad freight rates at present levels.
Eleven Columbia University faculty members whose specialties range from banking to swimming will retire at the end of the month.
THE body beautiful will look better than ever on the beach this summer, if swim-suit makers have their way.

The nation's steel mills are expected to operate this week at 97.4 per cent of rated capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. In terms of production, this would amount to 2,350,000 tons, which if achieved, would set a new record.

Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries yesterday reported gains in gross reevnues and net income for twelve months ended May 31. Industrial activity throughout southeastern Michigan continues at a high level, according to the report. May sales to industrial customers soared to $5,469,635 from the $4,204,306 reported a year earlier.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- A golfer and a dictator swung public attention from the United Nations as it tenth anniversary meeting got under way here today.
ALBANY, June 20 -- The State Tax Commission issued a reminder today that a state tax of 30 cents was due on each carton of mail-order cigarettes that did not carry this state's tax stamps.

IN December, 1946, a French physician flew from Hanoi in Indochina to Kunming in Yunnan Province of China on the first leg of one of the most daring one-man expeditions of modern times. The doctor was 54 years old, well past the age at which most adventurers would willingly set forth on a strenuous journey in the mountains and desolate pla teaus of western China and eastern Tibet.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- The campaign for Congressional retention of Federal price controls over natural gas production was described as a "2-cent tempest" today by Samuel B. Pettengill, attorney for Pure Oil Company and former member of Congress. He assailed claims that removal of such controls would hurt the public.

LONDON, June 20 (AP) -- The marriage of Australian tennis stars Lewis Hoad and Jennifer Staley here last Saturday has touched off a bitter controversy between Sir Norman Brookes, president of the Lawn Tennis Association of Australia and Harry Hopman, captain-manager of the Australian Davis Cup team.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Office of Defense Mobilization promised today to supply data on so-called dollar-a-year men in the Government since 1950.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 20 (AP) -- Lehigh University today graduated a class of 371. It awarded five honorary degrees including the degree of Doctor of Laws to the Secretary of the Navy, Charles S. Thomas.
SUWON, Korea, June 20 -- The United States turned over today to the South Korean Air Force its first jet aircraft.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Senate repudiated today President Eisenhower's plan to cut the Marine Corps strength by 22,000 men and approved a $31,882,915,726 military appropriations bill.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 20 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today hailed 1954 as a year of important civil rights progress in the United States.
