Retailers plan to use more imported fashion accessories to trade up this class of merchandise for greater dollar valume in the fall season.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson said today he would suggest a new wheat program if farmers rejected marketing quotas for the 1956 crop. A referendum is to be held Saturday.

LONDON, June 20 -- The stock market here was buoyant again today and trading brisk. Electrical and engineering issues led the advance among industrials, and gains were recorded in almost every other section.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 20 -- The French High Command has bowed out of any responsibility for bringing the South into consultations with the North on elections for the unification of Vietnam.

Oil Painting, a 4-year-old filly owned by Mrs. Joe Goodwin, won the $29,350 Distaff Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. In registering the first stakes victory of her career, Oil Painting scored by a length and a half over John M. Lee's God Child. The latter had a neck over Edward P. Taylor's Canadiana.
One reads so much these days of men and women over 50 who cannot find work again. Some are bitter about it and some (probably the ones who are financially better off) take it more philosophically.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Val Peterson, Federal Civil Defense Administrator, said today that Operation Alert had exposed the nation's unreadiness to cope with a thermonuclear bomb attack.
State rent controls are expiring at the end of this month on 42 per cent of the housing outside of the city that is now subject to regulation.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Eisenhower told Congress today that agreements to share information on atomic weapons with Britain and Canada would "contribute greatly to the mutual defense efforts."

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Nine leaders of the Communist party in this area were sentenced to Federal penitentiary terms today for conspiracy to teach and advocate the violent overthrow of the Government.
PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Railroad reported today that its profits for the five months of 1955 were nearly $17,000,000 more than in the same period last year.
MILWAUKEE, June 20 (AP) -- Big Gene Conley hurled four-hit ball for Milwaukee tonight as the Braves downed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 2 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short term borrowing costs had dropped slightly.
PARIS, June 20 -- A young and at times sparkling American cast tonight presented the musical play "Oklahoma!" to an audience headed by the President of France.

BERLIN, June 20 -- The East German Communist leaders have completed the subjugation of 5,000,000 trade unionists to strict Soviet-type control. A new labor statute effectively prohibits strikes of any kind.

CAIRO, June 20 -- Premier Ismail el Azhari of Sudan, once the chief proponent of unity with Egypt, expunged pro-Egyptian influence from his Cabinet yesterday. His action came in the dismissal of Mohammed Nureddin, Deputy Premier and Minister of Public Works.
A 99 per cent turnout in Staten Island marked the start yesterday of the city's second round of 1955 polio vaccinations.

To fashion a program for greater public use of passenger common carriers admittedly is no easy burden, for current economics favor the great development of automobile ownership and "growth of family wealth" at the expense of activities of the mass -- including transportation.
GENEVA, July 20 -- Plans for a world tariff conference next year will be drawn up at a meeting that will start here on Thursday.
SOME of the most interesting wines available in New York are those from the Buena Vista vineyards in the Sonoma Valley, just north of San Francisco.
Hardy Amies, one of Queen Elizabeth's dressmakers, is going into the wholesale business, Reuters reports from London.

ST. LOUIS, June 21 -- President Eisenhower today was declared personally responsible for a "philosophy of scarcity" that was dragging farm prices down and failing to solve the problem of crop surpluses.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -- The Soviet Foreign Minister has received a brief lesson in American government from Edmund G. (Pat) Brown, Attorney General of California.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 21 -- The Uruguayants are following Argentine developments anxiously. These happenings have a direct bearing on Uruguay's welfare.

Federal employes at 70 Columbus Avenue gave 128 pints of blood on Monday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. The donors work for the United States Atomic Energy Commission and the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -Paul St. Sure, president of the Pacific Maritime Association, asked Congress today to set up a separate labor relations board in the maritime field.
Many of the best teachers are leaving the classrooms because they are not getting enough money and are badgered with too much clerical and paper work, it was reported here yesterday.

Hunt Foods, Inc., yesterday completed the purchase of two plants of Glass Containers, Inc., and the facilities of Nevada Silica Sands, Inc., it was announced by Norton Simon, Hunt chairman. Terms were not disclosed.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 21 (AP) -- The summaries of today's principal matches in the All-England tennis tournament:

LONDON, June 21 -- Sir Winston Churchill advised the West today not to expect too much too soon from the Geneva conference. An easing of international strain may be all that can be achieved now, he said.
PASADENA, Calif., June 21 (AP) -- Representative James Roosevelt was divorced today by the wife who once accused him of misconduct with a dozen women.
With motors displaying strength, yesterday's stock market seemed about ready to top the 1929 high. Rails and steels were sluggish, however, and the ceiling was not pierced.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 21 -The main development in the twenty-four hours between 8 A. M. yesterday and that hour this morning was that the Cuban yawl, Criollo, caught and passed DeCoursey Fales' schooner, Nina, in the ocean race from New London.
Gen. Lucius D. Clay, retired, and Robert K. Christenberry urged New York business men yesterday to contribute to a joint $500,000 fund-raising drive of veteran organizations.

MONTREAL, June 21 (AP) -Regulations governing Canadian railways are based on the assumption that they still are a monopoly, N. R. Crump, president of the Canadian Pacific Railway Co., said today. "Transportation has become a highly competitive business.
Dempster McIntosh, United States Ambassador to Uruguay, predicted yesterday that Latin America was on the threshold of a significant expansion of trade within its own area.

The calm, almost relaxed, atmosphere at the present session of Congress has tended to conceal the fact that time is swiftly passing and that adjournment can be only a few weeks away. In the past five months many things have been accomplished; but, as usual, many more remain to be done.
TRENTON, June 21 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today that even the rescinding of all states taxes would not enable New Jersey's railroads to make a profit on their passenger services.

The curtain goes down on the New York theatrical season in June but around the world it rises quickly on the universal puppet theatre. Summertime brings out the puppeteers who, by an inspired stroke of the Parks Department, we have come to expect in local parks and playgrounds.

Attorney General Jacob K. Javits declared yesterday, that the United States should risk the possible secession of the Communist bloc from the United Nations if the organization's charter is drastically revised.
CLEVELAND, June 21 (AP) -Tom M. Girdler stepped aside today as the chief executive officer of the Republic Steel Corporation and turned over that title to C. M. White, president.

BALTIMORE, June 22 -- A fifty - four - ton steel plate was "planted" this morning at the Bethlehem-Sparrows Point Shipyard. It is an ordinary piece of steel that in nine months will "grow" into the largest tanker to fly the United States flag.
SEOUL, Korea, June 21. -- A fighter pilot and a navigator of the North Korean Air Force flew south to this city in a training plane today and surrendered.
BOSTON, June 21 (UP) -- Ted Williams delivered an eighthinning three-run homer as the Boston Red Sox rallied to beat the Detroit Tigers, 5 -- 4, tonight.

EAST ORANGE, N. J. -- June 21 -- Eddie Moylan of Trenton, seeded first, breezed through three matches today. The defender's victories included a 6-1, 6-2 triumph over Ensign Ronald Kerdasha of North Bergen in the quarter-finals of the New Jersey State championships at the East Orange Tennis Club.

LOS ANGELES, June 21 -- Scientists and engineers dug deeply into technical matters today at the fifth International Aeronautical Conference. The joint meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences and the Royal Aeronautical Society of Great Britain opened yesterday and will continue through Thursday.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Deparhnent oft Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today '

Those who neglected "Morning's at Seven," which came to Broadway on Nov. 30, 1939, will have an opportunity to catch up with it at 8 o'clock this evening in the air-conditioned Cherry Lane Theatre in Greenwich Village.

The property used as a parking lot at the southeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas and Washington Place has been sold by the Bankers Federal Savings and Loan Association to a client of Walter Scott Co. for improvement with a twostory taxpayer building.
LONDON, une 21 -- The first major break in the month-old dock strike came tonight. A meeting of approximately 1,400 striking London stevedores voted overwhelmingly to return to work Monday.
By innocent chance the planned recreation center for elderly persons in Central Park would conflict with a significant prior function of the famous Ramble.
The familiar mail-order catalogue will take on a new tone when Spiegel, Inc., of Chicago presents fashion and home furnishings designs by noted American artists in its forthcoming fall-winter book.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 21 -- Ordinary granite rock, bountiful throughout much of the world, may become the atomic energy source of the future, with a theoretical fuel value fifty times its weight in coal.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -- Extra! Foreign Ministers Barred From U. N. Parley!
SEATTLE, June 21 (AP) -- A Federal court jury last night awarded a former service station operator $240,000 in damages against seven of the nation's largest oil companies.
LONDON, June 21 (UP) -- In his talk, Sir Winston said:

MUNSAN, Korea, June 21 ((UP)) -- The United Nations military command today declared itself on the side of romance in the little village of Taesong, which is isolated from the world in the midst of the no-man's-land created by the Korean truce.

HONG KONG, June 21 -- Li Fu-chun, head of Communist China's Planning Committee, has called for "stringent austerity" to help convert the nation to "socialism" within fifteen years and make it an "advanced" industrial country in half a century.
Two utilities, Southern New England Telephone Company and Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company, borrowed a total of $35,000,000 in the public market yesterday.

Three hundred residents of Riverdale attended a rally last night in support of turning over the twenty-eight-acre Seton Hospital site to the Parks Department as a recreation center. The meeting in Public School 24, just north of the former municipal tuberculosis hospital on Henry Hudson Parkway, was arranged by the Riverdale Neighborhood and Library Association.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP) -- The United States Fish and Wildlife Service said today that it had embarked on a project that might be as important to fishery science as Newton's laws of motion had been to mechanics.
ALBANY, June 21 (AP) -- The State Public Works Department plans to drop from its payroll all employes 70 years old or more.
The State Racing Commission gave its approval yesterday to the incorporation of the nonprofit racing association that is to modernize New York's antiquated racing plant.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- State Department officials said today they believed President Juan D. Peron had lost control of the Argentine Government. He may eventually be eased out of the governmental picture, according to their view.

Twenty-two children suffering from cerebral palsy played host yesterday to nearly 200 visitors at the Children's Unit of the Bird S. Coler Hospital on Welfare Island. Although the youngsters began receiving rehabilitation and education there last October, the tour through the unit was part of its official opening ceremony.

BALTIMORE, June 21 (AP) -Paul Richards, general manager of the Baltimore Orioles, said tonight it was up to Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick to make the final decision about the trade Baltimore made with the Cleveland Indians last week.

Washington Water Power Company and Chelan County Public Utility District have reached a settlement in a condemnation case pending in Chelan County, Wash., Superior Court, it was announced here yesterday.

" AT 18,000 I nose over, reduce power, and there it is again -- the world, new, and again always the same burst of exhilaration on the first look down, like Mondaymorning flight after a long week-end. Here is a kind of freedom that I find nowhere else. You are on top of it, nothing can hide from you, an explorer in an empty sky.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP) -- Albert M. Day, former director of the Fish and Wildlife Service, denied in today's Congressional Record that he ever was "caught red-handed shooting over bait," as was charged recently in the House.

Jail terms were asked yesterday for six beverage-control investigators of the State Liquor Authority charged with refusing to answer questions on their finances. They are Harry Newman, Louis Levine, Allen S. Peterman, Julius Fein, Samuel Singer, and Irving Reiss.

BONN, Germany, June 21 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer indicated today he expected Austria to return Germany's former huge assets in that nation. The recently signed treaty restoring Austria's independence forbids Austria to honor any foreign claim in excess of $10,000.

A TRANQUIL spot, unchanged for more than 100 years in The City of Endless Change, is the four-story brownstone with brass handrail up the high stoop, with old picket fence and curtained high windows, at 110 Second Avenue, between Sixth and Seventh Streets.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Senator Price Daniel, chairman of a Senate Judiciary subcommittee investigating narcotics, announced today that he would hold public hearings Friday and Saturday on the narcotics traffic in New York.

American women will demand more dressy clothes -- even in sportswear -- retailers were told at the fourth annual fall fashion clinic sponsored by Fernfield Associates, resident buying office, at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday.

A list of twenty-five suggestions for revitalizing the Federal Budget has been sent to Congress by the Hoover Commission. The least technical and most important of these proposals is one which would require the Government to figure its budget on the amount of money expected to be actually paid out during the coming year.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission urged a Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee today to approve a bill giving the F. C. C. authority to levy fines up to $100 on radio operatorss other than the broadcast stations.

Following are the text of an address of the United Nations ceremonies in San Francisco yesterday by Harold Macmillan of Britain, as recorded by The New York Times, and extracts from speeches by Paul-Henri Spaak of Beligum, Mohammad Mir Khan of Pakistan, Sir Leslie Knox Munro of New Zealand, Abba Eban of Israel and Khalid el-Azm of Syria:
CHICAGO, June 21 -- If the Cubs are still to be regarded as the last remaining threat to a Brooklyn pennant, the Dodgers did much to contradict that belief today.
Brief but violent hailstorms, with pellets as large as walnuts and with sharp bolts of lightning, struck parts of Long Island and Connecticut yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -The 1955 model Molotov, the "good fellow," is on view at the estate the Soviet delegation has rented from a San Francisco used-car dealer.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 21 -- The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, A. F. L., will seek to establish the five-day work week for the motion-picture industry in forthcoming contract negotiations with the Association of Motion Picture Producers.

Princely fabrics of old Persia and Turkey, of the kind that once adorned palace rooms and of the exotic figures who lived in them, will be on exhibition opening today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in the Special Accessions Room.
A City Council session was turned into an uproar yesterday as Robert E. Barnes, Queens Republican, attacked the Wagner Administration as the most extravagant in the city's history.

The traffic situation in the garment center was somewhat worse than usual yesterday morning -- that is, it was terrible. At times the jam was so bad that buses, taxis and and other vehicles were backed up through the Forties.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -The Civil Aeronautics Board today announced it had established new mail rates for the transAtlantic services of Pan American World Airways, Inc., and Trans World Airlines, Inc.

It is the responsibility of manufacturers, mills and retailers to foster the recent interest shown in color and fashion in the men's wear industry, according to Philip Svigals, vice president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc.
BUENOS AIRES, June 21 -President Peron spent a busy day today giving substance to an official Army report that all was well with the Government.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 21 -South Vietnam is experiencing a critical shortage of imported merchandise. Prices are high and the threat of inflation is worrying United States and Vietnamese officials here.

IN many respects the fight at the Polo Grounds tonight between Archie Moore and Bobo Olson is a matchmaker's dream. There's just enough element of uncertainty to give this bout enormous crowd appeal. However, if it doesn't draw well, television will be blamed.

In the first five races at Aqueduct yesterday the players of the favorites suffered severe battle damage. But in the six-furlong sixth, a $4,500 purse, Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin's Bradley galloped to the rescue.
" Summertime," a film of Venice, opened last night at the Astor Theatre with a benefit performance for the American National Theatre and Academy's "Salute to France."

A group of dissident stockholders of the Thermoid Company, Trenton, has filed preliminary proxy material with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The group, headed by Raphael L. Elias, New York attorney, as secretary, seeks to elect a new slate of directors.

LONDON, June 21 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of an address in Moscow today by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India and of a speech in reply by Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin. Mr. Nehru spoke in Hindi, which was translated into Russian for broadcast from Moscow and then translated into English in London by Reuters.
CINCINNATI, June 21 -- Neither the return of Willie Mays nor other shake-well line-up operations by Manager Leo Durocher could save the Giants from further suffering tonight.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 21 -Increasing numbers of petitions are being filed with local school boards in the South requesting the admission of Negro children to schools, it was reported here today.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures announced yesterday that it would produce a half-hour weekly television program, to begin next fall. The company thus became the fourth major motion picture studio to enter the television field in recent months.
Sales and earnings of the American-Marietta Company for the six months ended May 31 were the highest for any similar period in its history.

YONKERS, June 21 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of the Century Country Club captured lowgross honors in the Women's Tri-County Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Dunwoodie Golf Club today. Mrs. Untermeyer, the 1954 metropolitan champion, carded a threeover par 35, 39 -- 74.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 21 -- Africans in Kenya will be permitted to form political associations, it was announced today in Nairobi.

The city cleared another court hurdle yesterday in its plan for private redevelopment of Washington Square Southeast. The work is to be done with subsidies of $4,125,103 from the municipal treasury and $8,250,206 from the Federal Government.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Census Bureau said today that a million and a half men and women have quit smoking in the last year and a half.

The tenth anniversary ceremonies of the United Nations at San Francisco have revealed such an overwhelming and world-wide longing for peace that a move is gaining ground to crystallize this sentiment in something more than speeches. Accordingly, it is now proposed that there be adopted at the concluding session next Sunday what would be known as the San Francisco Declaration, committing all the sixty nations represented to peace and peaceful negotiations.

Joseph J. Stein, assistant vice president in charge of operations of the Chicago and North Western Railway, was reported to have declined the chairmanship of the New York Transit Authority. Joseph E. O'Grady, city Labor Commissioner, who will serve on the three-man board when it takes office July 1, said he understood that Mr. Stein would remain with his present employers at a higher salary and position.

A growing concern for better labor-management relations on New York's waterfront has spread to shipping management. The Grace Line began last night a series of weekly conferences on labor relations for thirty-four of its pier supervisors.

ROME, June 21 -- Expressing a "piercing anxiety" for the fate of billions of souls who are exposed to the influence of movies all over the world, Pope Pius XII today urged that the film industry exercise self-censorship as an alternative to censorship by public authorities.

Early last year Sir John Hunt published his account of the climbing of the world's tallest mountain in "Conquest of Everest" (Dutton). Early this month Tenzing Norgay, who with Edmund Hillary reached the top of Everest, wrote his autobiography in collaboration with James Ramsey Ullman, entitled "Tiger of the Snows" (Putnam).

LONDON, June 21 -- Prices of industrial shares went on to new strength today on fresh buying orders, some of them from the United States. The Financial Times index set a record high of 218.1 on a rise of 2.4 points over yesterday's level, and the volume of trading neared the peak set in January, 1947.

DETROIT, June 21 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Worker's Union, C.I.O. rejected today the suggestion made by Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company that the car manufacturers unite in industry-wide bargaining.

The Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor in France is trying to rally the workers to fight greater industrial productivity, our correspondent Michael L. Hoffman reports. Its campaign makes use of the hoary Marxian dogma that all the benefits of stepped-up output will go to the capitalists while the condition of the workers will grow steadily worse.
The State of Connecticut and the cities of Cleveland and Tacoma were the biggest borrowers in the municipal bond market yesterday.

ROME, June 21 -- Premier Mario Scelba was disowned today by his own party, the Christian Democrats. He is expected to tender the resignation of his sixteen-month-old Government to President Giovanni Gronchi tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -United States membership in a $100,000,000 International Finance Corporation was approved by the Senate today without dissent.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The House Armed Services Committee revolted today against a call by its chairman for immediate approval of a modified plan to build up a military Reserve.

Lawrence Tibbett has accepted the chairmanship of the executive board of the Committee to Save Carnegie Hall. He presided yesterday at a meeting on the stage of the hall. It was announced that the immediate goal of the committee was to raise $50,000 in the next few weeks.

HARRISBURG, June 21 -- The highly controversial "Big Truck" bill has been overwhelmingly approved by the Pennsylvania Legislature and has been sent to Gov. George M. Leader for his signature. He has indicated that he will sign it.
ASPEN, Colo. -- "The twentyhour week is inevitable," says Arnold F. Arnold, designer and author.

Archie Moore, the 38-year-old boxer who holds the light heavyweight championship of the world, will defend his title tonight against Carl (Bobo) Olson of San Francisco. The fight, scheduled for fifteen rounds, will be held in the Polo Grounds.
LOS ANGELES, June 21 (UP) -- More than 1,000,000 residents of Los Angeles probably will have to walk or drive to work for at least the rest of the week.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 21 -- Three young women of Long Island society made their debuts this evening at parties given by their parents. All graduated this month from finishing schools and are at home for the June "little season" of the North Shore.
THE salmon angler who likes to rough it and to pioneer new fishing waters will find a real opportunity in Labrador, which offers excellent fishing and a chance to explore.
DAVENPORT, Iowa, June 21 (UP) -- Jack Fleck, a week ago just a pro who ran two municipal golf courses, returned home today to a tumultuous welcome as the National Open champion.

ALBANY, June 21 -- State Education Commissioner Lewis A. Wilson closed the door today on an attempt by about 100 New York City Board of Education employes to obtain appointments as assistant principals of elementary schools.
Summer was welcomed with open arms and windows early today, but the welcome was a little hesitant around the city's airports.
The second annual New York Summer Festival began yesterday.

MOSCOW, June 21 -- Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin promised today that in next month's Big Four negotiations the Soviet Union would make every effort to reduce international tension and increase confidence among nations. At the same time, addressing a vast rally in Moscow's biggest stadium, he pledged this country's efforts to the realization of the "noble aims" of the United Nations Charter.

Arthur Krock's column of June 9 on the "Mathematics of Presidential Elections" refers to the Lodge-Gossett amendment, S. J. Res. 31 and the Mundt-Coudert proposal, all relating to the method of electing our President and Vice President. Mr. Krock notes that a motion will be made to substitute the Mundt-Coudert proposal for S. J. Res. 31.
State Senator Frank D. O'Connor was designated last night by the Queens Democratic Executive Committee as its candidate for District Attorney of Queens.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -- The Soviet Union dropped a strong hint today that it now would be willing to permit the admission of Austria, Italy and Finland to the United Nations in return for Western acceptance of three Soviet satellites.
A NEW YORK policeman made a decision last night that caused a collective sigh of relief in living rooms all over the country.
GALVESTON, Tex., June 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias, the famous athlete, will undergo spinal surgery "within a very few days" to correct a ruptured disc, her physician said today.
The first contract agreement with a major oil company in the week-old tanker strike was announced last night.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -Fifteen research experts will discuss for Congress tomorrow the Salk poliomyelitis vaccine.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -- The Big Four foreign ministers' meeting is turning into what one Frenchman said was a crusade of amiability.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- A Senate-House conference committee agreed today to cut five years off the maximum age for doctors and dentists who would be inducted under new draft legislation.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- This was the longest day of the year, but President Eisenhower could have used a few more hours to keep up with the busy schedule his office imposed.

PARIS, June 21 -- The objective of diplomatic conversations between the West and Soviet Russia this summer is to ascertain whether Moscow is sincere in its talk of accommodation and whether it is prepared to give convincing evidence of such sincerity. Hints of a new mood have already been produced by the Russians in Vienna, Belgrade, Paris Bonn and at the London disarmament talks.
The Childs Company, noted restaurant chain, is going into the hotel business.

PARIS, June 21 -- Premier Edgar Faure told the National Assembly today that his Government was resolved to carry out a new policy in French Morocco. This policy, he said, will involve the gradual transfer of authority from French to Moroccan hands and the concomitant development of modern Moroccan political institutions.
Last night's concert at Lewisohn Stadium offered a superb electrical display but somewhat unsatisfactory conditions for outdoor music listening.

LONDON, June 21 (Reuters) -- Britain's coal industry showed a financial loss of 3,749,000 ($10,400,000) last year and suffered the highest number of wildcat strikes since the Socialist Government nationalized it in 1947.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -The United States invited the nations of the world today to pool their information on the effects of atomic radiation on human health and safety.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 21 -- For a score of years, American women have dominated the Wimbledon tennis scene. But today, a brash, young team from Australia disturbed the picture.

A housing development is planned for the Deepdale Golf Club property at Lake Success, L. I. Hugh K. McGovern, real estate operator, has signed a contract for a purchase of the tract through his U. S. Properties, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Administration has asked Congress to consider its annual appropriations bills twice, once in the early part of each session, and again just before the new fiscal year begins on July 1.
WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., June 21 -- The third American Moravian Music Festival, first to be given in this wonderful old town of early Moravian settlement, opened last night in Memorial Hall.
The interesting letter from Curtis T. Ettinger on the use of gamma globulin against polio, published June 17, brings up several points that should be clarified.
Sales of the Allied Stores Corporation are running 6 1/2 per cent ahead of last year's record volume, B. Earl Puckett, chairman, told the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- A Presidential emergency board today opened an inquiry into a wage dispute between the nation's railroads and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen.
Nearly 90 per cent of the New York City children eligible for second injections of Salk polio vaccine this year have received the shots in the first two days of the second-round program.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 21 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. William M. Creasy, chief Army chemical officer, said today that the Army had developed measures to protect civilians from chemical and biological weapons. He said "it is up to the Civil Defense system to put them into public use."
HOUSTON, Tex., June 21 -Glenn H. McCarthy, Houston oil man, has received a $4,160,000 shot in the arm for his Bolivian oil venture.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Following an early dip in prices, more active buying developed in wheat, and there was a good rally from the early low spots. The May Contract was again under pressure on the possibility the market quota plan will be turned down, but other wheat deliveries displayed strength.

Two hold-up suspects were outwitted last night by their intended victim, a taxi driver, when he brought his cab to a screeching stop in front of a policeman in Central Park and yelled: "They are trying to stick me up!"

The American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday that blast furnace production of pig iron and ferroalloys in May reached a record 6,804,935 net tons. The blast furnaces were operated at an average of 95.4 per cent of capacity.

LONDON, June 21 (AP) -- The British Foreign Office today cleared the way to give visas to nineteen Soviet oarsmen expected here for the Henley regatta. The Foreign Office said the Russians had only themselves to blame for a mixup in their travel plans.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 21 (UP) -- Fernando Ledesma of Southern California surpassed the American college record for the two-mile today. He sped the eight laps in 8:57.7 to lower the mark of 8:58 set by Wes Santee last year.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 21 -Most of the country's detention facilities for delinquent children today were called "a disgrace to the nation."
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 21 (AP) -- All five seeded players easily reached the quarterfinals of the United States Lawn Tennis Association's interscholastic championships today.

HARRISON, N. Y., June 21 -Stones, ores and semi-precious stones from fifteen distant countries were sealed today in the cornerstone of the new $5,000,000 building here of the StandardVaccum Oil Company.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Eisenhower Administration protested without avail today against a Democratic drive for Congressional approval of new social security benefits.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 21 -- Vigorous opposition developed here today to a proposal that women be ordained as rabbis.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -United Nations delegates were warned today to keep "political disputes" from the floor of their tenth anniversary meeting here.
A significant private source of medium-term credit for United States exporters of capital goods will become a reality within a few days.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 21 -Brazil may drop supports on coffee prices and let supply and demand factors control the market. Statements by Finance Minister Jose Maria Whitaker here and in Sao Paulo indicate that Brazil's coffee policy will be completely revamped.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -President Eisenhower nominated Warren E. Burger, Assistant Attorney General, today to be a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

Most people in Rangoon, foreigners as well as Burmans, are following with special interest the Western trip of U Nu, Burma's Prime Minister. Indeed, we are following it with sympathy and with some vicarious pride, because we like U Nu, we think's he's doing well in a difficult position, and we wish him well.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -Pending a Big Four agreement, the time has not yet come to amend the United Nations Charter, delegates from Chile and Colombia told the United Nations' anniversary meeting today.
ATLANTA, June 21 -- William P. Rogers, Deputy Attorney General, rebuked today those who criticized the Eisenhower Administration for being too solicitous about the "welfare of the well-to-do."

A bill introduced yesterday in the City Council would attempt to establish by local law the legality of bingo when played under the auspices of charitable or religious institutions, with no admission fee charged.

There were assurances over the public address system that an approaching storm would not hit last night's opening performance of Elliott Murphy's "Aquashow." The information was obtained from the pilot of a helicopter in the employ of Mr. Murphy.

Governor Harriman in a week-end television appearance said he hoped to have ready for introduction in the next Legislature bills providing for compulsory automobile insurance, automobile inspection and physical examinations for drivers seeking to renew licenses.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously disapproved today an effort by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy to put restrictions on President Eisenhower in the forthcoming Big Four conference.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Rowland R. Hughes, the President's Budget Director, was peppered in a Democratic crossfire today for his role in the Dixon-Yates power contract.

It is to be hoped that the appointment of Ambassador Grandval as Resident General in French Morocco will usher in a new and more fruitful period in that tormented colony's history. The last year was barren of anything except terrorism by Moroccans and counterterrorism by French colonists.

" Too Bad She's Bad," an Italian-made romantic comedy starring Sophia Loren, has been acquired for release in this country by Don Getz and Edward Kingsley. Vittorio De Sica is co-starred in the feature, which was directed by Alessandro Blasetti. The distributors have scheduled the premiere for the early fall.
CHICAGO, June 21 -- The 1955 general fall catalogue of Sears, Roebuck Co., is en route to customers throughout the nation, it was announced today.

LONDON, June 21 -- Two of Britain's most influential newspapers expressed distaste today for the strict security limitations in the new Anglo-American atomic energy agreements. They argued that the restrictions would hamper defense of the free world.

The market represented by the country's working women -19,000,000 of them, with more than $30,000,000,000 a year in their paychecks -- is not only big but growing bigger. This was set forth at the weekly luncheon of the Sales Executives Club at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday.
Only the near-by July coffee position was steady yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The other contracts were sharply lower.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Eisenhower signed today the bill extending for three years the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -The United States opened negotiations today with South Korea on the management of that country's recovery program.

The age of peacetime atomic energy draws steadily nearer. According to Francis K. McCune, vice president and general manager of General Electric Company's atomic products division, components for atomic power plants will be in the big business category in a comparatively short time.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Defense and Commerce Departments today urged Congress to extend for two years the expiring Defense Production Act and grant the Administration new powers to cope with a possible war emergency.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The United States has told Turkey that if she wishes to qualify for a loan from the United States she must first put her financial house in order.

Among the 14,932 fans at the Stadium last night, the talk was not that the Yankees defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 6 -- 2. It was not that Tommy Byrne, whose reputation is that of an erratic left-hander, went all the way for his fifth victory walking only one.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 21 (AP) -- Johnny Pott of Louisiana State won medalist honors today with a five-under-par 67 to tie the National Collegiate golf championship thirty-six hole qualifying record of 136.
George Meany warned organized labor yesterday that the "sweet words" of Soviet leaders betokened no change in their basic aim of world domination.
CAIRO, June 22 -- Egypt has replied to Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns of Canada, United Nations truce chief, regarding Israel's plan to reduce armed friction on the Gaza line.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 22 -- The slowest of six ocean races to the mouth of the Severn neared its end tonight with one of the small Class C yachts the main winner.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Lyndon Baines Johnson of Johnson City, Tex., today as usual was the busiest man in the Senate, of which he is the majority leader. He was staging one of his parliamentary spectacles, and presenting it effectively as a political morality play.
LONDON, June 22 -- Three suggested answers to the Soviet proposal for the withdrawal of military forces from Germany have been explored in recent weeks.
CHICAGO, June 22 -- America's urban economy and the structure of city finance are being undermined by the national transit crisis, a transit expert declared here today.
HONG KONG, June 22 -- Ho Chi Minh, President of North Vietnam, left Hanoi today for the Soviet Union and Communist China. He headed a nine-member delegation.

The building containing fifty-six apartments and seven stores at 1800 University Avenue, the Bronx, bought about six months ago by the Goodman - Herman Company, operators, has been resold to a client of Howard Rothenberg, attorney.
The week-long tie-up of Atlantic and Gulf Coast shipping ended yesterday in a sweeping victory for the union officers and seamen.

HARTFORD, June 22 -- The General Assembly, meeting in special session, approved late today vital revenue and appropriations measures that it failed to pass before the close of the regular legislative session on June 8.

PERHAPS it's the Russian threat in next year's Olympic Games that has acted as a goad to American athletes. Maybe it would have happened anyway as part of the restless stirring of track and field operatives all over the globe. Whatever the reason, though, it's becoming increasingly apparent that the United States is assembling more and better foot-racers, leapers and hardware-heavers than ever before.

Clarence C. Vam Bell, who was blinded twenty years ago while playing semi-professional baseball, was designated yesterday as the Republican candidate for State Assemblyman in Manhattan's Third Assembly District. The election will be held Nov. 8.
The Port of New York can look forward to unrivaled prosperity if three basic requirements are fulfilled, Donald V. Lowe, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Senate and House conferees agreed today to support a 7 1/2 per cent pay increase for more than 1,000,000 Government employes.

BERLIN, N. H., June 22 (AP -- A proxy statement mailed today to stockholders of the Brown Company, pulp and paper manufacturer, proposes the election of A. B. Harold Fair of Brookline, Mass., as president.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 22 -- The Fort Slocum headquarters building, hitherto known only as Building 59, was named Barrett Hall by the Army today in memory of Lieut. Col. Myron K. Barrett.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 22 -Allen Steinhardt of Namm Loeser, Inc., won the Simon F. Rothschild Cup at the twentysixth New York City Newspaper -Retail Dry Goods Association golf tournament at the Century Country Club today.
A rare portrait of a young girl, by the seventeenth century Dutch artist Jan Vermeer, will go on exhibition today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
The City Planning Commission turned a deaf ear to loud opposition yesterday and approved plans for new low and middle-income housing in South Jamaica, Queens.

Newspaper advertising throughout the country produced an impressive array of records in May. A study of figures reported yesterday by Media Records on the basis of a survey of fifty-two cities showed this:
Those who have an interest in old houses will want to take advantage of two public viewings this week.
ALBANY, June 22 (AP) -- Governor Harriman today shelved a Public Works Department order to dismiss employes 70 years old or more.
Dr. Milton Helpern, chief medical examiner, disclosed yesterday that eight men had died this month from drinking liquor containing wood alcohol poisoning.

LONDON, June 22 -- Queen Elizabeth II launched the new liner Empress of Britain at Govan on the Clyde this afternoon. The 22,500-ton all-white vessel takes the place of the famed Canadian Pacific liner of the same name which was sunk in World War II.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- United States officials are gravely concerned over the situation in Laos. The kingdom in western Indochina remains divided in spite of the Geneva agreement last summer assuring its sovereignty and territorial integrity.

A decline of 948,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 165,285,000 barrels, compared with 166,233,000 a week earlier and 168,983,000 a year ago.

When will the police and other authorities in New York City begin to make the preparations and supply the concentrated supervision necessary to prevent traffic snarls caused or worsened by street repairs? They failed again early this week to cope adequately with such conditions, created by the closing of Thirty-eighth Street for one block between Seventh Avenue and Broadway in the heavily burdened garment area.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- The Big Four foreign ministers' meetings ended tonight with agreements on procedure but without any noticeable change in the fundamentals of policy.

The Italian political crisis has been talked about so long and so often in recent months that it is almost a relief to see it finally come to a head. This is something that the Italian body politic has to get out of its system. The Scelba Government has not even been able to present a regular budget to Parliament for six months.
SUCCULENT roast beef from the ribs or top round and a thick sirloin steak are the most attractive meats for this week-end from the standpoint of price as well as of palate.
"I'd like to meet Rocky Marciano next," declared an elated Archie Moore last night after his third-round knockout of Bobo Olson.

Ancient Archie Moore had the right answer to the $64,000 question last night. He never hesitated when the quiz master asked him, "Who will be Rocky Marciano's next opponent?" With considerable emphasis, Archie answered, "Me."
CHICAGO, June 22 -- The Cubs made another valiant effort to check the runaway flight of the Dodgers today, but again it was no go.
Thorvald Langaard and nineteen girls and boys sailed for Norway yesterday for Mr. Langaard's eighteenth summer devoted to encouraging friendship between American and Norwegian youngsters.
MOSCOW, June 22 -- Within twenty-four hours after reaching Moscow William Worthy, a New Yorker, was shaking hands this evening with the most important man in the Soviet Union.
CHICAGO, June 22 -- Home furnishing retailers today asserted that installment selling can still be expanded without endangering the economy.

BOGOTA, June 22 (AP) -- The Colombian Government granted today to Germany the first import license under its new barter system. The license is for 100 city buses to be bought in Germany by the municipality of Bogota.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 22 -- Government officials expressed satisfaction today over progress in the National Army campaign against the Hoa Hao rebels in West Cochin China.

Electric Bond and Share Company hopes to enter 1956 as an investment company, no longer bound by the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935. The company, once the nation's largest public utility holding concern, is celebrating its fiftieth anniversary.

TELEVISION had one of its most exciting and beguiling evenings of the season last night. The occasion was an hour-long version of the Paul Gregory Broadway musical, "3 for Tonight." It was superb video.

Four trucking concerns seeking a postponement of the pier loading tariff of the Port of New York Waterfront Terminal Operators suffered a double setback yesterday in the United States Court of Appeals. The rate is to become effective July 1.

The three-story Georgian brick residence at 161 East Seventy-eighth Street has been sold by Mrs. Nemone Balfour Gurevitch to Mrs. Judy Abbott Clark, daughter of George Abbott, the theatrical producer. The sale was announced by William B. May Co., brokers, who reported that they also had sold for Mrs. Clark the dwelling at 154 East Seventy-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Some members of Congress said today State Department experts had informed them the United States was trying to persuade Argentina to call off her antichurch campaign.
CHICAGO, June 22 -- Wheat futures had a good recovery after an early sell-off today, commission buying developing on the setbacks. Light offerings of new crop red winter wheat caused some buying.
Mickey Mantle slammed another homer yesterday. This one, his eighteenth of the season, sent the Yankees on their way to a 6-1 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
ON a second viewing Paul Osborn's "Morning's at Seven" is still an amusing comedy.

Jacoby Inc, imports-exports of steel and non-ferrous metals, in 444 Madison Ave through Cross Brown Co, agent; North American Phillips Co Inc, additional space, in 100 E 42d St; Grand Central Camera Exchange Inc, additional space in 521 5th Ave -- Cushman Wakefield Inc, brokers.

THE Second Symphony of Brahms was a casualty at last night's concert by the Stadium Symphony at City College's Lewisohn Stadium. Originally on the program, it was brushed aside to make room for the Vaughan Williams Symphony No. 4, the work that had been rained out of Tuesday night's program.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Homemakers planning to refurnish this fall will find three important trends from which to select. Two of them have been influenced by the traditions of other countries, the third is an American style of today.
MOSCOW, Thursday, June 23 -- India and the Soviet Union jointly called today for a complete ban on nuclear weapons and a substantial reduction of conventional armaments.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- Warren R. Austin, first permanent United States delegate to the United Nations, advised the international organization today to oppose the admission of Communist China.

KATONAH, N. Y., June 22 (AP) -- Ora Billingsley, brother of Sherman Billingsley, night club owner, was severely bitten by one of his dogs early yesterday when he prevented it from killing some kittens.
HACKENSACK, N. J., June 22 (AP) -- Six members of the Wallington Board of Education today were found guilty of attempting to obtain a $3,000 bribe from a school principal candidate.

Archie Moore is so old that he is barred by statute from boxing in some states. The light-heavyweight champion of the world was born in Collinsville, Ill., on Dec. 13, 1916. He was raised by an aunt in St. Louis, where he attended grammar and high school.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- The House Banking Committee, reversing an earlier Senate defeat for President Eisenhower, voted today to scuttle a big Democratic public housing plan and adopt the President's more modest program.
The National Broadcasting Company has paid $500,000 to put Sir Alexander Korda's new film, "Richard III," on television for its first showing in this country.

The General Electric Company issued a revised statement of its 1954 report showing a decline in net earnings last year to $198,913,221 or $2.30 a share from the previously announced net of $212,613,221 or $2.46 a share.

Interest in Wall Street centered yesterday on railroad stocks -- notable laggards during much of the current upward move. Demand for carrier shares was so persistent that for a while it looked as if The New York Times price index of fifty representative issues would pierce the 1929 top of 311.90.

Yesterday Mr. Molotov proposed an end of the cold war, an easing of international tension and "peaceful coexistence and peaceful cooperation" among nations.

Patrons of racing's $2 windows don't have much interest in 2-to-5 propositions. But some of the big-money bettors love 'em. So the big bettors were the customers who extracted the most enjoyment from the sixty-third running of the Tremont Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.
Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates bought $2,820,000 of Northern Pacific Railway equipment trust certificates yesterday with a bid of 99.1687 for 3 per cent coupons.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Miss Mary H. Donlon, a member of the New York State Workmen's Compensation Board, was nominated today by President Eisenhower to a judge of the United States Customs Court.

Operations of Schenley Industries, Inc., in the nine months ended May 31 resulted in net earnings of $3,527,229, compared with $2,250,928 earned in the similar period of the prior year, it was reported yesterday.

Albert Ackalitis, described by the Kings County District Attorney's office as one of the most feared persons on the waterfront, won his freedom in Kings County Court yesterday. He promised Judge Nathan R. Sobel that he would not seek work on New York City docks.

The huge and continuing glut of wheat has made it necessary for the Department of Agriculture to employ its two control devices for the past several years. These two instruments are (1) acreage allotments and (2) marketing quotas.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- An Administration spokesman formally presented today a scaled-down formula for relieving the domestic sugar surplus and increasing the domestic share of the United States sugar market.

One-third of the children eligible to receive second injections of the Salk vaccine against polio this year have so far received the vaccine. The program was scheduled to provide about 20,000 shots by the end of this week.

The Brazilian Coffee Institute will regulate the flow of coffee from producing centers to port areas in Brazil, it was announced yesterday. This move is aimed at preventing heavy accumulations at the seaboard, which could exert undue pressure on prices.

BONN, Germany, June 22 -- Prof. Werner Heisenberg said today West German scientists had been invited to attend an international nuclear conference in Moscow next month. He said no decision had yet been made to accept the invitation.

One of your readers recently went so far as to say that the Austrian people welcomed the Anschluss. I was living in Vienna at that time and really must beg to differ with the writer. He may have seen large numbers of Nazi youths, obviously imported for the occasion, crowding the streets and extremely vociferous, but he did not see the thousands of good Austrians who were crying their eyes out in their houses.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- President Eisenhower accepted the resignation of Robert T. Stevens as Secretary of the Army this morning and surprised the capital by nominating Wilber Marion Brucker to succeed him.
YONKERS, June 22 -- Fifty-five Democratic leaders of Westchester County met here tonight and chose candidates for four major county offices.
ROME, June 22 -- Premier Mario Scelba's Government resigned today. President Giovanni Gronchi asked it to stay in office as a caretaker Government until a new Cabinet was formed.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 22 -- The clubwoman of the type that was a mainstay of Helen Hokinson's cartoons seems to have disappeared over the last few years. According to Mrs. Chase Going Woodhouse, director of the bureau for women's organizations in Hartford, the clubwoman is "no longer a cartoon character but a real factor in the civic life of the country today."
BOSTON, June 22 -- More than three hundred persons, including the entire graduating class of a Boston junior high school, had the thrill of being rescued at sea in the outer harbor today.

MONTREAL, June 22 (Canadian Press) -- The Bowater Paper Corporation, Ltd., said today that ordinary shareholders of record June 1 would get rights to subscribe to additional shares at 70 shillings ($9.80) in the proportion of one share for every three held.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, June 22 (UP) -- The North Korean Air Force was put under command of a Soviet citizen after a North Korean pilot flew his Soviet-built MIG here in 1953, it was reported today.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 22 -- This country relies "far too much" on its prisons in dealing with crime, a nation-wide meeting of correction and probation officials was told today.

CAIRO, June 22 -- Iraqi Ambassador Najeeb el Rawy said here today that relations with Egypt had improved with termination of the bitter exchange of propaganda assaults. He added that the coming months would be propitious for attempts to achieve greater unity on policy toward the non-Arab world.

A store and office building erected about four years ago at 554-60 North Avenue in New Rochelle, N. Y., has been purchased by a syndicate headed by Irwin Halpern, lawyer. A group headed by Harry Rosen was the seller.
THE Eastern Long Island fishing is approaching a peak. Anglers fishing out of Montauk may find surprises in the form of school tuna and white marlin this week-end.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The market for refined copper probably will continue tight through the third quarter of this year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Five hundred employes of Liebmann Breweries, Inc., have registered to give blood today to the regional Red Cross at Public School 145, Central Avenue and Noll Street, Brooklyn. The Red Cross also will collect blood at the Whitestone Naval Reserve Armory, 150-74 Sixth Avenue, Queens.
What to call the new merged union movement has become labor's most vexing internal issue.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- Foreign Minister Molotov's appearance on the rostrum today removed from the United Nations meeting the threat of the doldrums.

Michael J. Quill, international president, and Matthew Guinan, president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., charged yesterday that speed-ups of subway train schedules and signal equipment failures had created dangerous conditions in the Coney Island area.
William Sherman Jackson 3d, called Skipper, died in Long Island Jewish Hospital on the Glen Oaks-New Hyde Park line a little after 1 o'clock yesterday morning.
A business expert has told hardware dealers to woo their employes' wives -- but for business reasons, according to an Associated Press dispatch.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 22 (AP) -- William G. Helis' Helioscope scored a six-and-a-half length victory over the Elkcam Stable's Ifabody in the $17,700 Salvator Mile today. The two-horse race, on which there was no betting, was watched by 15,005 Monmouth Park race-goers.

DESPITE the heavy migration from city to suburbs, not all New Yorkers have an ample backyard in which to spread family, guests and barbecue grill. Many count themselves lucky if they can dine al fresco on a bit of balcony, terrace or roof, or manage to squeeze both meal and friends into a handkerchief-sized garden.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Eleven farmers or agricultural experts who have been chosen to represent the United States on a tour of farm districts in Russia were named today. A twelfth will be named soon.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 22 (AP) -- The summaries of today's principal matches in the All-England tennis tournament:

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Three top scientists called today for a halt in the mass vaccination of children against poliomyelitis with Salk vaccine. They urged an immediate concentrated effort on producing a "safer" vaccine with regularity.

A proposal to merge the Kimberly-Clark Corporation and the International Cellucotton Products Company was endorsed by their boards of directors yesterday. If shareholders approve the proposal, joint activities of the paper products manufacturers will be conducted by Kimberly-Clark.
LONDON, June 22 -- The use of atomic radiation in sterilizing processed foodstuffs "may possibly" induce cancerous reactions, according to a report published today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -- The life story of Buster Keaton, sad-faced comedian who ranked close to Charlie Chaplin in the days of silent movies, will be the basis of a motion picture to be written by Robert Smith, who also plans to produce it.
PARIS, June 22 -- Three American employes of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, who failed to appear before a United States loyalty board, have been dismissed.

Preliminary arrangements for future acquisition of iron ore from Labrador have been made by Klockner - Humboldt - Deutz, A. G., a leading West German manufacturer of Diesel-powered machinery, vehicles and related equipment.
Subway trains of the B. M. T. Fourth Avenue line were tied up last night for more than half an hour at the height of the rush hour.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Senate smashed down today all of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's efforts to put restrictions on President Eisenhower's participation in the Big Four conference.
Archie Moore successfully defended the light-heavyweight championship of the world by knocking out Carl (Bobo) Olson at the Polo Grounds last night.
Pennsylvania borrowed $50,000,000 yesterday to build hospital and welfare facilities, improve state schools and penal institutions and finance other projects.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A new plan to build a trained and ready military Reserve of 2,900,000 men by 1960 was approved by a House Armed Services subcommittee today. It was a compromise expected to have hard riding through the full Armed Services Committee and the House of Representatives if it reaches the floor.

Guy Lombardo's 1955 version of "Arabian Nights," starring Lauritz Melchoir, will begin its summer engagement tonight at the Jones Beach (L. I.) Marine Amphitheatre, the New York State outdoor playhouse on the shores of Zachs Bay.

The General Cable Corporation, manufacturer of electrical and communications wire and cable, yesterday announced its entry into a contract for acquisition of General Insulated Wire Works, Inc. of Providence, R. I.
HARTFORD, June 22 -- The problem of whether Connecticut should supply water to New York State areas arose again in the General Assembly today.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A credit of $3,920,000 to help finance the purchase of railway and ore-handling equipment was granted by the Export-Import Bank today to the Cia. Vale do Rio Doce of Brazil.

Louis E. Wolfson, president and chairman of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, marine salvage and construction organization, obtained stockholders' approval yesterday of an increase in the authorized common stock from 6,000,000 to 10,000,000 shares. The vote was 3,326,056 to 102,917.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The House of Representatives passed the Administration's customs simplification bill today over sharp complaints by protectionists that "back-door" tariff cuts would result.

The resignation of Robert T. Stevens as Secretary of the Army, long rumored, has now become fact. Mr. Stevens accepted office originally at a very considerable financial sacrifice to himself. He has been a diligent and high-minded public servant. He now takes leave of his office with an expression of warm appreciation on the part of President Eisenhower for the work he has done.

One of New York's leading cash-and-carry specialty stores has built a booming and highly profitable business in imported merchandise by combing the world's markets for items to sell at popular prices.

NORWALK, Conn., June 22 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad will collect $1.00 a month for parking at the Norwalk station next Monday, or as soon as possible thereafter.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, appealed to the American people today to join the Soviet people in preventing a "third world war."
MOSCOW, June 21 -- Moscow which is entertaining an increasing number of visitors will have at least four new hotels in the coming years.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Thursday, June 23 -- The first coalition government in the eight-year history of Pakistan will be sworn in next month.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee today approved a bill to authorize wiretapping to obtain evidence in cases involving spies, saboteurs, traitors and kidnappers.

The Quakers of Plymouth Meeting, Pa., got $5,000 and words of praise yesterday for refusing to discharge their librarian because eight years ago she was employed by a school now on the Attorney General's subversive list.

ATHENS, June 22 -- Robert F. Wagner, Mayor of New York, was made an honorary and honored citizen of Athens today. At a ceremony in the council chamber of the Athens Club Hall, Mr. Wagner received a silver medal.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 22 -- President Eisenhower today advised patience in efforts to improve civil liberties and equality of economic opportunity.

The city is bringing a $363,963 damage suit against the five men convicted in Queens County Court of June 9 on charges of fraud and conspiracy in the construction of a two-mile sewer in Laurelton, Queens.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 22 -- The Central Conference of American Rabbis was sharply critical here today of the State Department for its "seeming indifference" to Arab-Israeli tensions.
MASSENA, N. Y., June 22 -- The State Power Authority has tentatively approved a plan to sell half of its St. Lawrence power to industries located near its hydroelectric works here.

A MAN stood looking down into the Grand Canyon of the Colorado, trying in his mind to express the wonder of the scene. He was brooding over various ideas, among them a thought that it looked rather like a measureless sea of Oriental rugs turned inside out. A voice behind him said: "Big hole, ain't it ?" That did it. For the time being, anyway.

Under the terms of the Geneva agreements Vietnam will be preparing, just about one year from now, for a general election. In simpler terms, it is supposed to decide if the country is to be Communist or free.

Congregational Christian Churches and Evangelical and Reformed Church will open their doors as the United Church of Christ on June 25, 1957, it was announced here yesterday. The date for union was set yesterday in Columbus, Ohio, by a meeting of the General Council of the Evangelical and Reformed Church and the General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved a $3,285,800,000 foreign aid bill today after cutting $145,000,000 from President Eisenhower's request for military aid around the world.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., June 22 -Howard Kaskel, a freshman at the University of Florida, set the pace in the Metropolitan Golf Association's junior championship today. Kaskel, a resident of New York City, led the qualifiers with a 75 over the North Shore Country Club course.
LONDON, June 22 -- The wildcat seamen's strike, which has tied up nine British and Canadian liners during the last month, showed signs of breaking up today.
HELSINKI, Finland, June 22 -- Prof. Frederic Joliot - Curie, French nuclear scientist, made the keynote speech at today's opening session here of the Communist-sponsored World Assembly for Peace.
The Cuban Ambassador to the United States yesterday described the growing crisis in the Cuban sugar market and its effects on his country's economy and international relations.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Representative George P. Miller, Democrat of California, touched off a controversy today in the House Merchant Marine Committee by saying maritime labor was the "whipping boy" of the current merchant marine investigation.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 22 -- An ex-champion was defeated and the titleholder perched precariously on his pedestal tonight in the All-England tennis tournament.

Proposals that the operators of certain heating equipment be required to install smoke-recording apparatus met opposition yesterday. Objections were raised by business associations and others at a hearing conducted by the Air Pollution Control Board at 125 Worth Street.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines called today for a reaffirmation of faith in the principles of the United Nations.
DETROIT, June 22 -- General Motors Corporation announced a new $500,000,000 expansion and modernization program today to increase its capacity to produce passenger cars and trucks.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., June 22 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair took a two-stroke lead in the first round of the thirty-second annual Women's New Jersey Golf Association's 54-hole medal play championship today.
The New York Times of June 15 reported that Chancellor Adenauer, told a press conference, "the danger of German militarism has disappeared. It is not there any more."

The 1955 Life Insurance Fact Book, published by the Institute of Life Insurance, offers some revealing statistics on the popularity of life insurance. For example, at the beginning of this year American families owned some 237,000,000 life-insurance policies, representing an aggregate protection of $334,000,000,000, or an average of $6,300 a family.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 23 -- Top-seeded Tony Trabert, the Cincinnati siege gun, blasted Hugh Stewart of Los Angeles, 6--4, 6--3, 6--1, in the all-England tennis championships today. Trabert led a six-man American delegation into the fourth round.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 (AP) -- "This guy Moore really punches hard," the middleweight champion, Carl (Bobo) Olson, commented today when he returned from his third-round knockout last night by the light-heavyweight king, Archie Moore.

BUENOS AIRES, June 23 -- President Juan D. Peron's Cabinet and other top Government officials resigned today. Tonight the President said in a broadcast to the nation he felt so much revulsion over last week's revolt that it was only his "great sense of duty, firm patriotism and will power" that kept him from resigning.

Bob Turley pitched his best game as a Yankee yesterday. Regaining the winning touch after five straight defeats, the hard-throwing right-hander shut out the Kansas City Athletics, 4 -- 0. His sparkling three-hit job supplied 7,444 customers at the Stadium with some choice conversational morsels for post-game consideration.
PITTSBURGH, June 23 -- The steel industry today offered its 600,000 unionized workers a pay rise of slightly more than 10 cents an hour. The offer drew an immediate and angry union rejection.

COOLED by the delightful breeze from the Atlantic, always a pleasant virtue during the hot nights of summer, the second edition of Guy Lombardo's "Arabian Nights" got under way at Jones Beach Marine Theatre last night.

NORTH CHICAGO, Ill., June 23 (AP) -- Abbott Laboratories offered today to buy back 36,000 shares of its 4 per cent convertible preferred stock. The company said it has 106,818 shares outstanding of the $100 par value preferred issued Dec. 7, 1951.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 23 -The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today criticized President Eisenhower for his opposition to an anti-segregation amendment to military Reserve legislation.

Ferris wheels, fortune tellers, prizes and varied articles for sale, all the ingredients for a summer fair. have been readied for the benefit on Wednesday for the Society of St. Johnland. Rain or shine, this annual event will be held on the society's grounds at Kings Park, L. I., from 11 A. M. to 5 P. M.

Foreign Minister Molotov's speech at San Francisco has visibly impaired the harmony of the commemorative session of the United Nations and jolted it into a new realization of realities. It has also cast a new shadow over the projected Geneva meeting of the heads of government.
William Zeckendorf and Billy Rose filed the preliminary plans yesterday for their projected "Palace of Progress" -- plus a check for $21,927.36.

NASHUA, N. H., June 23 (AP) -- The International Shoe Company said today it would close its plants in Nashua, Claremont and Newport, N. H., by late fall owing to "considerations of economy and efficiency."

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A recommendation that the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship, Inc., be required to register as a Communist-front organization was made today to the Subversive Activities Control Board. Headquarters of the organization are in New York.

LINCOLN, Mass., June 23 -The American premiere of Frank Wedekind's "King Nicolo" was presented last night in the estate garden of Mr. and Mrs. Constantin A. Pertzoff. An audience of about 300 persons watched from an area surrounded on three sides by a semi-circular stage.
MOSCOW, June 23 -- A remarkable experience for the Soviet people and Jawaharlal Nehru came to end this morning when the Indian Prime Minister left Moscow.

The threat of a rate war on trans-Atlantic air cargo has been ended. The airlines involved have agreed unanimously to go along with the proposal of Pan American World Airways to cut tariffs an average of 20 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Senate investigators set off today on the trail of a rumored $100,000 bribe to Government purchasing officers -- and ran into a solid wall of indignant denials.

Richard S. Aldrich, theatrical producer, and Elizabeth Boyd, a former model and daughter of a Louisiana school teacher, were married last Sunday in Tangiers. Morocco, the impresario's attorney, David Holtzmann, announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 23 -- Free enterprise can no longer provide adequate mass transportation, a transit official said here today.
Wise homemakers are cautioned to be wary of wool and wiring when preparing to launder and store electric blankets for the summer.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -- Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, rejected today Soviet proposals for an all-European security pact to replace the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

State Supreme Court Justice Farrell M. Kane refused yesterday to enjoin hiring rules promulgated recently by the Waterfront Commission. However, the way remains open for Local 920, International Longshoremen's Association, to pursue its attack on the present hiring system.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -Robert B. Anderson, the Deputy Secretary of Defense, will submit his resignation "in the next few months."

BONN, Germany, June 23 -- The Cabinet approved today the draft of the "soldier's law." Its authors believe such a law will form the basis for a democratically organized military establishment like those of the United States and Britain.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -A chairman's gavel stopped Nationalist China's foreign minister today in the midst of an attack upon communism.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- This city's first billion-dollar bank -- the First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company -- was in the process of formation today.

LONDON, June 23 (AP) -- J. Arthur Rank announced today he had put his multi-million dollar movie empire under the control of a trust to keep it in British hands. Profits of the trust will go to charity.

For about one hour yesterday, the stock market in some respects looked like 1929 plus. The New York Times composite average made a record high. The index pushed to 313.36, or 1.46 points above the Sept. 19, 1929, crest.
QUICK trick for outdoor cooks, and also for those who wish to save time in the kitchen, is found in ready-blended seasonings, flavored salts and herb and vegetable powders.

The Interstate Commerce Commission reaffirmed yesterday its order of May 26 approving a recapitalization plan of the Alleghany Corporation, railroad holding company which controls the New York Central Railroad.

I wish all of your readers could share with me the delight and satisfaction of watching a group of blind, aged and crippled women and girls depart for Shelter Island Camp. It seems incredible that just the anticipation of a few weeks in the country and seashore could inspire so much genuine happiness. Day after day, the year 'round, they carry on cheerfully and uncomplainingly.

TOKYO, Friday, June 24 -- United Nations Command headquarters has announced that two American soldiers who wandered into the Communist side of the Korean demilitarized zone Wednesday, had been returned yesterday afternoon by the Communists.

The Board of Estimate appropriated yesterday an additional $1,371,936 to expand the fight on juvenile delinquency. Of this, $976,000 went to the New York City Youth Board to step up its campaign. The Youth Board already has $2,357,120 for that work.
PARIS, June 23 -- Premier Edgar Faure said today that the United States Government had promised France priority to purchase helicopters for use against rebels in the eastern Algerian mountains.
LONDON, June 23 -- Aneurin Bevan has been elected to the Labor party's shadow Cabinet, but three of his most prominent supporters have been defeated.

With an astronomical inevitability something took place this week as it has in these parts annually for countless years. At exactly 12:32 A. M. Eastern daylight time on Wednesday the sun reached a solstice on the ecliptic midway between the equinoxes.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 23 -- Women were urged last night to use their power as citizens to help solve problems of infringement of civil liberties and of intolerance. The appeal came at a session of the sixth annual June conference of the Service Bureau for Women's Organizations, which concludes today.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -Quick Congressional action on a one-year extension of the present temporary $281,000,000,000 national debt ceiling was agreed on today by Administration and legislative leaders.

Today's new film is "Moon-fleet," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer period adventure starring Stewart Granger, Joan Crawford and George Sanders, at the Palace. Viveca Lindfors and Jon Whiteley also have leading roles. The screen play was written by Jan Lustig and Margaret Fitts from a novel by J. Meade Falkner.

FONTAINEBLEAU, France, June 23 -- The North Atlantic Alliance's biggest air war game of the year went into its nuclear phase this morning. Simulated atomic bombs hit seventeen military targets in France, West Germany and the Low Countries.
A 17-year-old errand boy was slain in an East Harlem grocery last night in revenge for the stabbing of a 17-year-old member of a rival youth gang in the same area earlier in the day.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A Ford Motor Company executive warned today that any attempt to impose a ceiling on the size of an auto manufacturing company would bring stagnation and eventually cripple the whole economy.

Brazil opened a new exhibit of its export products in New York yesterday as a basic part of a campaign to develop more diversified trade with the United States. The display, said to be the largest permanent exhibit of Brazilian products yet established in this country, was formally opened at the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau, 551 Fifth Avenue.

CAMDEN, N. J., June 23 -- More than 5,000 shipyard workers approved late tonight a new one-year contract with the New York Shipbuilding Corporation providing for an across - the - board wage increase of 7 cents an hour.

Prime Minister Nehru of India and Premier Bulganin of the Soviet Union signed a declaration in Moscow on Wednesday that will not contribute to the peace and equanimity of the world. The intentions, certainly on Mr. Nehru's part, were good.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- The Hotel Sherman Company management offered stockholders today $5 more a share for their holdings than the bid made by the Sheraton Hotel Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The successful strategy of Senate Leader Johnson of Texas, which was the subject of the column published in this space today, will have its greatest test next year. The political pressures engendered by the oncoming Presidential election will be much stronger then, and the unity of the Senate Democrats, which is one of Johnson's remarkable achievements, will probably not survive them.
Chief Inspector Stephen P. Kennedy called on 300 highranking officers of the Police Department yesterday for more action against juvenile delinquency and traffic snarls.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Gen. Robert E. Wood, retired chairman of Sears, Roebuck Co., Chicago mail order and retail enterprize, became the first merchant tonight to be elected to the Merchandise Mart Hall of Fame in his own lifetime. His election was announced at a dinner in the Mart's Merchants and Manufacturers Club attended by more than 500 business men and financiers from all parts of the country.
The city has decided to forego the prospect of appointment soon of 309 new patrolmen in favor of additional police supervision for existing patrols.

Consumers Power Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for May and for twelve months ended May 31. Operating revenues for twelve months reached $177,443,008 from the $163,978,698 reported a year earlier.
