Net income of $27,486,069, equal to $3.23 a share, compared with $25,730,011 or $2.99 a share in the like 1954 period.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- In about a year and a half, Federal tax inducements have helped to provide 10,000 jobs in labor-surplus areas.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 23 -- Technical developments of potential major importance in motion picture projection and production were introduced here today by the National Theatres Corporation, which operates some 350 houses from coast to coast.
BERLIN, June 23 -- Three editors and a proofreader of East Germany's main Communist organ were reported today to be in prison after allowing two damaging errors to appear in print Monday.
RICHMOND, Va., June 23 (AP) -- Gov. Thomas B. Stanley and the State Board of Education today announced a policy of continuing Virginia's segregated public schools the next school year.
Motorists traveling to and from the city this week-end can expect more than the usual number of vexing delays. There are detours or bottlenecks in prospect on twelve main routes

TODAY, 3:30 P. M.: The New York City Department of Parks' traveling marionette show will present "Hansel and Gretel" at Gun Hill Houses Playground, Magenta Street between Holland and Cruger Avenues, the Bronx.
ROME, June 23 -- President Giovanni Gronchi started official consultations today to solve the Italian Government crisis.
A young woman teacher from Champaign, Ill., got in the way of a speeding fire engine in midtown yesterday and caused a spectacular crash of eight vehicles and minor injuries to ten persons.
John Golden, Broadway producer who died last Friday, bequeathed his twenty-acre estate at Bayside, Queens, to the City of New York for use as a public park.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) The Senate voted 53 to 21 today to end cumulative or "one-shot" voting in election of national bank directors unless articles of the bank provide for it. The legislation, amending a 1933 act, now goes to the House.

ABOUT six months ago Archie Moore began to bombard sports desks with open letters that demanded that he receive a match with Rocky Marciano for the world heavyweight championship. The venerable world light-heavyweight king had to tour three continents in order to ply his trade and earn a living.

TRENTON, June 23 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today that the development of Island Beach by the state might be delayed indefinitely because three deed holders were not inclined to part with small parcels of land. One is a prominent Republican State Senator.

Shine its opening in May, 1891, with Tchaikovsky as guest conductor, Carnegie Hall has been the principal concert hall in New York. It has also served Presidents, politicians, preachers and other speakers, but its world fame rests on its hospitality to music.
CONCORD, N. H., June 23 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's informal talk before an outdoor session of the New Hampshire Legislature today:
HARTFORD, Conn., June 23 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff pledged today there would be "no war" between Connecticut and New York over water supplies.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., June 23 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair scored her second straight 78 today for a three-stroke lead in the thirty-second annual fifty-four-hole medal play championship of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Manager Walter Alston fielded a riddled Dodger team today. Duke Snider and Roy Campanella were both on the sidelines. Clem Labine, a member of the relief corps, was the starting pitcher.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 23 -- The South African Parliament adjourned today, ending one of its most significant sessions of recent years.

The defense rested its case yesterday in a hearing of the Waterfront Commission without calling any of the six respondents to the witness stand. The hearing concerns alleged kickbacks by longshoremen who worked at the Leonardo Naval Base at Earle, N. J.
The Fire Department honored its heroes yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -President Eisenhower was rebuffed today in his fight against attaching anti-segregation riders to essential legislative programs.
On a sales gain of 21.4 per cent, the United States Plywood Corporation in the fiscal year ended April 30 realized an increase of 57.8 per cent in earnings over the preceding fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (UP) -- President Eisenhower and former President Hoover urged Congress today to accept the gift of a memorial ball tower to commemorate the "simplicity and greatness" of the late Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio.

HELSINKI, June 23 -- On the second day of the Communist-organized "World Assembly for Peace" in Helsinki speakers dropped the reserve as regards the United States that had marked the opening day's orations and lambasted Uncle Sam as the real bad man of the world today.
The National Broadcasting Company reportedly has signed Maurice Chevalier to star in a television "spectacular" on Dec. 4.

The New York Times' average of the prices of fifty representative listed stocks reached 313.36 between noon and 1 P. M. yesterday. It was the first time that the average topped the 311.90 high-water mark of Sept. 19, 1929.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, June 23 -- The Communists have offered to negotiate directly to end the jungle war in Malaya, but the British have rejected the proposal.

We support with warm approval Governor Harriman's advocacy of more and improved probation work. He believes that state aid to increase probation personnel is "one of the most important things of all" to combat juvenile delinquency. In some localities the probation officer is nonexistent, in others so scarce in view of the caseload that he has twice as much work on his calendar as he can care for properly.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -The Russians still fascinate the United Nations and manage to set themselves apart in the attention of the delegates.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 23 -- Suburban living was stalled temporarily this evening when a driverless car plunged over an embankment onto the north-bound New York Central Railroad tracks just south of the station here.

A $250,000 damage suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court against Pierre Matisse, son of the late Henri Matisse, and his wife. The plaintiff is Matta X. Echaurren, surrealist artist internationally known as Matta.

Directors of the American- Hawaiian Steamship Company yesterday voted to suspend dividends until justified by retained earnings from intercoastal operations. Shareholders had received 75 cents quarterly the last of which was paid June 14.
GLEN HEAD, L. I., June 23 -- James Iverson of Siwanoy was among the double winners in the Metropolitan Golf Association's junior championship at the North Shore Country Club today.
A computer's computer has been perfected by Remington Rand, Inc.

"One Man's India," a travelogue by Arthur Stratton, will be published July 12 by Norton. He went to India in 1952 and traveled across the subcontinent from Darjeeling, Calcutta and the Juggernaut Temple in the east to Jodhpur, Bombay and "the carved and painted caves" of the Decann in the west.
Archie Moore relaxed in regal manner at his suite in the Hotel Warwick yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, arriving in Washington to become the new Army Chief of Staff, was greeted ceremoniously today by top officials of the Army.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -The dollar sign is missing as San Franciscans appraise the value of this week's tenth anniversary session of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The United States Court of Appeals upheld today the "natural right" of all citizens to travel abroad. It ruled unanimously that the State Department could not refuse to give a citizen his passport without "due process of law."
PORTLAND, Ore., June 23 (UP) -- Mike Fetchick of Mahopac, N. Y., checked in with a 68 in the twilight to lead the first round of the Western open golf championship today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -- Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov told Secretary of State Dulles today it would not be necessary to negotiate further about the procedures for the Big Four heads-of-Government meeting in Geneva.
DENVER, June 23 (UP) -- Seven regional Communist party leaders were sentenced today to prison terms ranging from two and one-half to five years and were fined from $1,500 to $5,000.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 23 (AP) -- Leo Durocher and his employer, Horace Stoneham, arrived here today on separate planes, both tight-lipped about reports that Durocher was finished as manager of the lagging Giants.
The oldest part of New York -- from Fourteenth Street southward --looks and is pretty much as it was twenty-five years ago with one spectacular exception.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 23 -- The Central Conference of American Rabbis agreed today to make a one-year study of the advisability of ordaining women to the rabbinate.

All those who are concerned about the intellectual climate and democratic functioning of our schools and colleges must view with profound dismay the situation in the public schools and colleges of New York City, where professors and teachers are being, in effect, forced into becoming informers.
As a good hostess never sends guests away empty, so a properly housebroken guest never arrives empty handed. Here are two suggestions for that weekend gift found in New York department stores.
The top divertissement at the Aqueduct track yesterday was a six-furlong sprint for a $10,000 purse. The finish was a ringtailed thriller.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The House of Representatives today condemned Western colonialism and Communist imperialism alike by a vote of 367 -- 0.

Your editorial "Night-time Horns," which appeared on June 20, and which referred to my appearance at the Council in support of the bill which would ban the use of the auto horn for any purpose between the hours of 10 P. M. and 6 A. M., was interesting, but arrived at a wrong conclusion.
THE rain that trout fishermen did not want early in the season would be welcome now, for many of the popular streams are running low and warm. But fly fishermen are still taking quite a few fish.
FLORENCE, Italy, June 23 -Twenty-three ancient skulls that have kept Florence in an uproar for years are about to be returned to their original tombs in the Basilica of San Lorenzo.

CONCORD, N. H., June 23 -- President Eisenhower implied jestingly today that he might have to seek a second term so his White House staff chief could complete a "lecture" series on the virtues of New Hampshire.
A capping ceremony, establishing sixty-eight high school students as practical nurse trainees, was held yesterday morning at the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday amounted to 785,425 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,282 cars or 0.2 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 78,188 cars or 11.1 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 27,153 cars or 3.3 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
ROME, June 23 -- United States welfare agencies here were investigating today an alleged black market in American gift food.
MOSCOW, June 23 -- A little man with a pink face and a neat blue suit was hurrying across the grounds of the Kremlin last evening. A respectful single pace behind him walked a tall army officer.
CHICAGO, June 23 -- Grain futures showed a firm undertone today, although the trade was on the quiet side, with no aggressive support.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Labor Department today recommended an increase from $35 to $50 a week in the maximum compensation for lost time through injury for workers covered by the Longshoremen's and Harbor Workers' Compensation Act.

THE principal feature of last night's concert by Dimitri Mitropoulos and the Stadium Symphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium was the first performance there of Rolf Liebermann's "Concerto for Jazz Band and Symphony Orchestra."

Cocoa futures tumbled the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The volume, 394 lots, was the second highest of the year. There were offerings at the limit down in all positions at the close but no buyers.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Col. Patrick W. Hayes, former Air Force Chief of Intelligence in Berlin, has been discharged by the Air Force under "conditions other than honorable" for getting involved with a Soviet woman spy.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 23 -- Connecticut commuters contend that parking charges to be levied by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad would constitute, in effect, "a fare increase by indirection." They will carry their protest to the Interstate Commerce Commission.
AGNES WARD'S throat was tight and her eyes filled last night in Hunter College Auditorium when Dr. Clarence D. O'Connor spoke to the 1955 graduates of the Lexington School for the Deaf.

Plans for "A Night in Monte Carlo" were discussed yesterday at a luncheon given at the Colony Club by Mrs. Hermann Irion. This was the first meeting of the organization committee for the event, which will take place on Jan. 6 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Government acted today to insure that no Government-owned agricultural surpluses reach Soviet Russia or her satellites through private exporters.
SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 23 -- The State Bar Association will award $250 to the newspaper reporter judged to have made the largest contribution to the administration of justice in each year.

Business men throughout the country will be urged soon, in large-space newspaper advertising, to promote their products or services all summer long because "people buy more in summer months than most other months of the year."

Another large commercial development will be started soon in White Plains by Sam Minskoff Sons, builders. They will erect a store center on a 50,000-square-foot site on East Post Road, which was bought from a syndicate headed by Gerald Blumberg.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -The Argentine spokesman in the United Nations conference indicated today that he remained loyal to President Juan D. Peron.

HANOVER, N. H., June 23 (AP) -- The president of the New York Stock Exchange said tonight that United States corporations will need $375,000,000,000 in new capital to reach economic levels projected for 1965.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A House of Representatives Government Operations subcommittee will investigate complaints that the Eisenhower Administration "has been withholding or suppressing" information.

The sale abroad of trademarked American products is making more friends for this country than almost any other factor, it was held yesterday by James A. Farley, chairman of the Coca-Cola Export Corporation.

Ten years after the close of the war there are some 300,000 refugees who, having fled their own countries because of political, racial or religious persecution, have not yet found permanent homes and still need special assistance and relief. Unsettled remnant of the millions of human beings who were uprooted by the war and the events that followed it, they are called the "residual refugees."
ROD SERLING, rapidly becoming the most prolific dramatist on television, was represented last night on "Climax!,'' seen over Channel 2.

SYRACUSE, June 23 -- About 600 national, state and local Protestant leaders attended ceremonies tonight dedicating the new Protestant Center of New York State. The center will become a focal point of activities for more than 1,500,000 Protestants in sixteen denominations.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 23 (AP) -- The summaries of today's principal matches in the All-England tennis tournament:

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Buyers battered hog prices another 25 to 75 cents a hundred pounds lower today as the trade was faced with the expanded Government pig crop report. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today follow:
Further anti-polio vaccinations here may be delayed until fall, Health Commissioner Leona Baumgartner forecast yesterday.

A test pilot flying over Long Island Sound yesterday bailed out of a new jet when it became disabled at 12,000 feet. Both he and the fighter plane landed in the water near a Coast Guard lighthouse. The uninjured flier was rescued in a joint Navy-Coast Guard operation and was safe at home less than two hours after the event.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Intercoastal steamship operators today told Congress that overtime wage costs were running their operations into the red.
Loans to business by leading New York City banks rose $26,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday.
The Tuition Plan, Inc., an organization founded in 1938 to provide pay-as-you go financing of academic fees, has been acquired by C. I. T. Financial Corporation.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The weekly average of member bank reserve balances for the week ending June 22, increased $320,000,000 to $18,998,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Pre-tax profits of United States men's wear stores decreased from 4.1 per cent of sales in 1953 to 2.9 per cent last year, according to a survey conducted by the New York University School of Retailing in cooperation with the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives readied today a "very strong statement" criticizing Yugoslavia for what it termed failure to cooperate fully with the West.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -Congress completed action today on the proposed 7.5 per cent pay rise for more than 1,000,000 classified and related Government employes. The increase would be retroactive to last March 1.

After a month of coma the program for a trained military reserve force has again been allowed to come alive in the House. The Armed Services Committee now has an approved recommendation of its subcommittee for a new measure that embodies some, if not all, of the original Administration proposals.
BERN, Switzerland, June 23 -- An advance was marked today in the campaign to permit wider Jesuit activities and the founding of new convents and religious orders in Switzerland.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Members of the National Retail Furniture Association voted by a two-to-one margin today to ratify the stand taken by the organization's board of directors opposing continuation of Fair Trade laws.

Aug. 16 is t opening date for "The Skin of Our Teeth" at the ANTA Theatre. Starring Helen Hayes, Mary Martin, George Abbott and Florence Reed, the Thornton Wilder play will be seen there for three weeks only.

I read with keen interest Dr. C. W. Jungeblut's letter of May 26 concerning the shortcomings of our present polio vaccine program. My letter is not intended in any way to criticize the statements of an authority on virus diseases, but merely to point out the unfortunate results of giving highly technical information to a lay public which is unable to properly evaluate the facts contained in his letter and other similar articles.

Sol Goldman, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the four-story twenty-four-family apartment house at 1502 Sixty-eighth Street in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, Joseph Andreas was the seller. The property, on plot 60 by 80 feet, is assessed at $68,000. Henry Futterweit was the broker.

In an investment deal in the heart of the Murray Hill section, a client of Joseph Howard Katz, attorney, bought the four-story private dwelling on lot 20 by 74 feet at 135 East Thirty-fifth Street from Samuel Blindman. The property adjoins the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and was sold through Victor Spitzer, broker.

Three young men, seized by a suspicious policeman on Ninth Avenue last night, admitted early today that they had held up the Stoeger Arms Corporation, 507 Fifth Avenue, on June 15. Their loot included seven revolvers, two shotguns and a large quantity of ammunition.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Following is the text of the opinion of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia and the separately concurring opinion of Judge Edgerton holding the passport function of the State Department subject to judicial review:
BUENOS AIRES, June 23 (AP) -- Following is the text, translated from the Spanish, of the radio speech tonight by President Peron:

ST. LOUIS, June 23 (AP) -- Basil O'Connor, answering critics of the Salk vaccine, said today that anyone seeking to prevent its use "for other than unanswerable scientific reasons would be acting neither as a scientist nor a humanitarian."

A pretty reliable barometer indicates that the present high rate of steel operations may be stepped up or, at the least, maintained well into the summer. The barometer, the price of steel scrap, a large share of which goes into making steel.

Dr. Maurice J. Lewi, 97-yearold physician, has treated himself to a new lease on an old career. He announced yesterday the establishment of the New York College of Podiatry, 53 East 124th Street, as an independent institution.

The International Transport Workers Federation is intensifying its drive to organize the thousands who man the 8,000-000-gross-ton fleet registered under the "runaway" flags of Panama, Liberia and Honduras.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Consumer Price Index remained at the same point both in midApril and in mid-May while factory workers take-home pay reached record levels.

A pretty reliable barometer indicates that the present high rate of steel operations may be stepped up or, at the least, maintained well into the summer. The barometer, the price of steel scrap, a large share of which goes into making steel.
LONDON, June 23 -- Sir Walter Monckton, Minister of Labor, cautioned Parliament today against adopting hasty or ill-considered legislation intended to halt the wave of industrial strikes.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A group of scientists voted 8 to 3 today for continuation of the mass inoculation of children during the summer with Salk poliomyelitis vaccine.

Dr. Maurice J. Lewi, 97-yearold physician, has treated himself to a new lease on an old career. He announced yesterday the establishment of the New York College of Podiatry, 53 East 124th Street, as an independent institution.

The International Transport Workers Federation is intensifying its drive to organize the thousands who man the 8,000-000-gross-ton fleet registered under the "runaway" flags of Panama, Liberia and Honduras.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Consumer Price Index remained at the same point both in midApril and in mid-May while factory workers take-home pay reached record levels.

Ed Balod and his l56-inch-long telescope, a mobile landmark for many years, have quit public life in Manhattan. The telescope case probably will go to work in Massachusetts, but nobody seems to know the whereabouts of Ed and his fine twelve-inch lens.
BUENOS AIRES, June 24 -The nation's press today ignored President Juan D. Peron's ministerial crisis. The newspapers tried to give the impression of "Government as usual."
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Domestic sugar producers, complaining of burdensome surpluses and no share in the growth of the United States sugar market, today asked Congress for immediate relief.
LONDON, June 24 (Reuters) -- South Africa today gained a first-inning lead of 171 runs, mainly due to a 142 by Roy McLean, in the second cricket test against England at Lords.

Several dozen artists have been pushing several tons of sculpture around in the last two days under burning and lowering skies, and liking it. Women as well as men were the enthusiastic movers in the vacant but verdant plot of land adjoining the Guggenheim Museum on Fifth Avenue at Eighty-ninth Street.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 24 (UP) -- Rex Baxter of Houston and Pat Schwab of Florida scored 1-up victories on the nineteenth hole today to lead the way into the semi-finals of the National Collegiate golf championships.
A Congressional investigation into management-paid labor espionage was predicted yesterday by the president of an American Federation of Labor union.

BONN, Germany, June 24 -The West German Bundestag (lower house of Parliament) approved the 1955-56 Federal budget of 36,600,000,000 marks (about $7,300,000,000) in the third and final reading yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24 -- The Motion Picture Association of America has cautioned the heads of studio publicity and advertising departments to softpedal sex and violence in exploiting movies.

By every rule of logic the Cleveland Indians should have won last night at the Stadium. They outhit the Yankees, they played errorless ball while the home side committed four misplays, they had runners aboard in each of the first seven innings.
John K. Chambers has been named manager of product development of the Seamless Rubber Company, New Haven, Conn.

The Port of New York Authority executive director, Austin Tobin, debates in your May 31 publication the issue I raised concerning our loss of 75,000,000 passengers, two-thirds our value, which I attribute largely to competitive tax-exempt Port Authority crossings sponsored by states which tax us as though their competition were non-existent, a strangling pincer process.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -V. K. Krishna Menon, India's roving Ambassador, told the United Nations anniversary celebration here today that Communist China wished to adjust its differences with the United States in the Far East without resort to war.

A merger of the Penn-Texas Corporation and the Niles-Bement-Pond Company is under consideration. Leopold D. Silberstein, president of both companies, announced yesterday that the directors of the two companies on Tuesday would consider such a step.

JERSEY CITY, June 24 -- A gas explosion, caused by a suicide attempt, shattered fifty-two windows in the Earl Hotel at Journal Square, early today. Two walls were cracked and two doors knocked off their hinges, but the would-be suicide received only superficial cuts and burns.

ANCHORAGE, June 24 (UP) -The pilot of the Neptune plane, Lieut. R. H. Fischer of Del Rey Oaks, Calif., said the three men who were wounded in the attack by Soviet MIG's were Aviation Electronic Technician 3/C Edward Benko, 25 years old, of Chicago; Ensign D. C. Assard, 21, navigator of Perryville, Conn., and Aviation Ordnanceman 2/C M. E. Berg, 31, of Alameda, Calif.

So much has been written during the past seven or eight months about the so-called "religious persecution" in Argentina and such undue publicity has been given in the American press to a misrepresented problem of the Argentine people that clarification of some erroneous concepts regarding conditions prevalent in that country would seem to be in order.
President Eisenhower yesterday authorized the Atomic Energy Commission to double this country's allocation of enriched uranium to friendly nations.
The Southern Pacific Company and wholly owned affiliates yesterday reported net income of $6,410,644 for May. Earnings for the same month last year were $3,859,568.

FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., June 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's son was among the 610 armed forces officers from the United States and thirty-five Allied nations to be graduated today from the Army's Command and General Staff College.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A New York shipowner told Congress today that for the first time intercoastal trade had a chance for stability because of recent strike settlements in New York.
CHICAGO, June 24 -- On the eve of the growers' referendum, the wheat market today displayed great strength.

The Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn has raised its dividend rate on savings deposits from 2 3/4 per cent to 3 per cent. The new rate, announced yesterday, will be paid to depositors for the quarter ending June 30.
Prime Minister U Nu of Burma arrived in New York yesterday by plane from London for a three-week visit to this country. He was accompanied by his wife and five aides.
Following is the text of an address by former President Truman, broadcast last night from San Francisco at the tenth anniversary celebration of the United Nations, as recorded by The New York Times:
SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -The Russians vetoed the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight and vice versa.

A new court, to be known as the Social Court for Men, will be opened on Hart Island on Sept. 5. It will handle the cases of homeless men arrested anywhere in the city, but it will be aimed primarily at aiding those picked up on the Bowery.
ASHEVILLE, N. C., June 24 -Lawyers were advised by Justice John M. Harlan today to rely more upon oral arguments and less on written briefs to win cases appealed to the higher courts.

Employes of Liebmann Breweries, Inc., gave 484 pints of blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program at Public School 145, Central Avenue and Noll Street, Brooklyn, on Thursday. The day's total was 718 pints.
Henceforth importers will not be able to register with the United States Patent Office a trade-mark used by a foreign manufacturer.
The official American reply to Mr. Molotov's latest proposals at San Francisco has now been delivered by Secretary Dulles.

Communist-directed terrorists in Malaya, after seven years of jungle warfare, have now asked the British to "negotiate." The suggestion has been promptly and rightly rebuffed. There is nothing about which to "negotiate." The terrorists may surrender, if they wish, and many of them have done so.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -Americans are buying on credit in record volume. As consumers, they owe $30,655,000,000. As home-buyers, they owe another $78,900,000,000.

Today may well be an important anniversary, a landmark along the winding path of progress. Just 2192 years ago today Archimedes may well have delivered himself of a conceit which has come down to the present in all reputable textbooks.
Stocks eased yesterday. Although they firmed in the afternoon, the forward move was not sufficient to erase the moderate losses suffered in the early hours of trading.
A new Kings County rackets grand jury will be empaneled next week to make a comprehensive investigation of the causes of juvenile delinquency.
A rooming house at 230 West Ninety-seventh Street was ordered vacated of its roomers yesterday by Bernice P. Rogers, Deputy Commissioner of Housing and Buildings.
Some of the world's finest silks are woven in Long Island City, Queens, across the river from Manhattan's Seventh Avenue fashion market and Madison Avenue's home decorating shops.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 24 -Housing experts warned today that poorly coordinated slum clearance programs were creating new slums.
GLEN HEAD, L. I., June 24 -- James E. Iverson of Siwanoy, a Northwestern University sophomore, became the Metropolitan Golf Association's junior champion today.
HARTFORD, June 24 -- The special session of the General Assembly adjourned its threeday meeting shortly after 6 P. M. today with words of praise from Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, June 24 -- The Government's refusal to negotiate with the Communists to end their rebellion has not met with the unanimity of approval that was first indicated.

The New York Shipping Association has demanded that leaders of the port's longshoremen call off a mass meeting scheduled for Monday. The meetings, it said, would be a violation of the prevailing wage agreement.
Of the many examinations given to pupils during the last few weeks of the school term, one test had a special significance.
The first groups of about 25,000 New York City children will leave next week for summer camps operated by Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish agencies.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government has adopted a resolution of tribute to its chairman, former President Hoover.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., June 24 (UP) -- Evan R. Dale, former head of the laborers union of the American Federation of Labor in Southern Illinois, pleaded guilty today to five Federal charges. He also withdrew an appeal from a previous conviction and a fifteen-year prison term.
GENEVA, June 24 -- A number of governments are studying a new plan for tariff reductions proposed by the Secretariat of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).
SEOUL, Korea, June 24 -Students of the economy of the Republic of Korea are agreed on one thing: there has been progress. They disagree on how much.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 24 -- Seven constestants in the United Nations' annual international essay contest have won first prizes of a four-week visit to the international organization's headquarters in New York.

The two-story taxpayer property at 341 Main Street in Huntington, L. I., has been sold by the Rubin estate to Joseph Singer. H. Clayton Smith Co. were the brokers. The attorneys were Morris Fried for the seller and Albert Baruth for the buyer. Ground-floor tenants include the Miles Shoe Company and Polly Perrey while the second floor is occupied by the Lyons Furniture Company.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Insects that can withstand DDT are threatened with a much deadlier mixture that was patented this week.
WHITEFIELD, N. H., June 24 -- Outwardly gay, President Eisenhower concealed today his deep concern over a new Soviet plane incident as he visited New Hampshire's White Mountain lake resorts.
BOULDER, Colo., June 24 (UP) -- Wes Santee staged a great rush in the final lap to pass Fred Dwyer and win the mile run at the National Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships today.
FRANCONIA NOTCH, N. H., June 24 (AP) -- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's informal talk here today:
Miss Angela R. Parisi of Brooklyn is resigning as vice chairman of the Democratic State Committee, it was learned yesterday.

Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation announced yesterday it had received Federal Power Commission approval for the removal of the major portion of its Little Big Inch System from natural gas service and construction of substitute facilities to maintain gas delivery capacity.
Again the concert season starts at Lewisohn Stadium. Again the performance by Rudolf Serkin and the Stadium Symphony Orchestra is interrupted periodically by droning or roaring planes.

BENNINTGON, Vt., June 24 (AP) -- Governor Harriman of New York declared tonight that the Eisenhower Administration had cut defense and scientific research programs "to justify a tax reduction to certain groups."
THE first white marlin taken off Long Island this season was boated yesterday by a cruising angler, who also reported sighting two broadbill swordfish.

HONOLULU, June 24 (AP) -- John Hendricks of Australia last night beat the United States champion, Bill Woolsey, in the 200-meter free-style and bettered Woolsey's American record. Hendricks' time was 2:06.9. He set the mark at the seventh annual Keo Nakama swim meet.
PITTSBURGH, June 24 -- Union steel workers received official instructions today to prepare for a strike at midnight Thursday.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -Secretary of State Dulles said today that if the Soviet Union wished to end the "cold war" it had only to comply with the United Nations Charter.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -Control relationships between the Atlas Corporation, New York management investment concern, and three other companies have been approved by a Civil Aeronautics Board examiner.
The contempt convictions against the International Longshoremen's Association, three of its officials and eight locals were reversed yesterday.

EASTON, Conn., June 24 -- The seventy-sixth year of a life that was blighted almost as soon as it began, but bloomed in immortal tribute to her unconquerable soul, begins Mon day for Helen Keller. In a world she has neither seen nor heard since she was 19 months old, this amazing woman has been watched and listened to with awe and admiration for more than half a century.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Pentagon and Congress took a grave view of the attack Wednesday by two Soviet planes on a Navy patrol plane.

With the sun hidden by clouds, Icarian "flew" to an expected victory in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. Installed the 7-10 favorite by the 17,819 fans at hand, the 4-year-old gelding from the Apheim Stable justified the price by registering a threequarter-length triumph over William C. Partee's Winning Count.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 24 -- Doris Hart and Mrs. Barbara Scofield Davidson were trounced by a pair of virtual unknowns today in the all-England tennis tournament.
PARIS, June 24 -- More than 200 suspects were reported to have been rounded up yesterday and today by French security forces operating against Arab terrorists in eastern Algeria.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The House Ways and Means Committee unanimously approved today a one-year extension of the temporary $281,000,000,000 national debt limit. The action followed testimony by Secretary George M. Humphrey that the Treasury would "try to live within" the ceiling but could not promise to do so.

Puerto Rican Government officials fear that the minimum wage bill now before Congress would, if enacted, throw 45,000 out of work on the island, with migration repercussions here. These views deserve widespread and sympathetic consideration -- especially on Capitol Hill. But some background, too little known on the mainland, is essential to understand them.

PARIS, June 24 -- There has been a marked change this year in the Soviet attitude toward world disarmament. Moscow's policy must still evolve considerably toward what the West considers a practicable formula before there can be hope of ending the arms race.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- The furniture business was described today by an Indiana furniture executive as "still living in the horse and buggy days" and "almost desperately" in need of change to chain store methods.
VIENNA, June 24 -- Austrian resentment of what is described as forcible Italianization of South Tyrol was expressed officially today for the first time.
What's good for the Eiffel Tower is good for outdoor metal furniture, according to the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association.
Trading was suspended yesterday in the new 6 per cent convertible preferred stock of the Alleghany Corporation. Alleghany is the holding company that controls the New York Central Railroad.

NO woman can ever go on a trip entirely alone. She always has at least one companion that she waits for by the hour on steamship docks, assists solicitously through customs, takes leave of with a stoic bravery on occasions when they are temporarily separated, and sometimes even carries over the terrain of railway station or airport terminal.
BOSTON, June 24 -- The Reserve Officers Association of the United States presented a distinguished service citation tonight to The New York Times for its contributions to national defense.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 24 (AP) -- Vince Martinez of Paterson, N. J., brought his hit-and-run style back to the ring tonight and scored a unanimous decision over a puzzled Chico Varona of Cuba. Martinez weighed 151 1/2, Varona 155.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were unchanged to 9 points (45 cents a bale) lower.

DETROIT, June 24 (AP) -- Ford Motor Company announced today a program of benefits for salaried workers. It parallels the demands gained by the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., for hourly rated employes.
Vice President Richard M. Nixon paid his first visit to Harlem yesterday and warned that anti-segregation riders to pending legislation would "defeat their own purpose."
The city and Westchester and Long Island communities continued yesterday second-round anti-polio inoculations of school children who received dummy shots last year.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 24 -- Col. James J. Roberts, commander of Mitchel Air Force Base here, has a ticket to prove that his crackdown on speeders is being rigidly enforced. He received a summons yesterday for driving thirty miles an hour in a twenty-five-mile-an-hour zone.
CHICAGO, June 24 -- The country's railroads will buy 38,000 new freight cars, costing $300,000,000, to meet anticipated traffic demands, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
The Pelham Bay Little League controversy is an excellent example of the departmentalized thinking of the modern American; in particular, the Throgs Neck property owners.

A study that links, the development of American cities and towns with the "broad cultural manifestations" of American history will be issued July 4 by Houghton Mifflin. It is called "American Skyline: The Growth and Form of Our Cities and Towns.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -- Former President Truman declared tonight that the world faced the choice of adhering to United Nations principles or plunging into anarchy and possibly destruction. He appealed for as swift progress as possible toward armament reduction under effective international controls and, bybroad inference, endorsed the mid-July Geneva conference of the Big Four powers.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Saturday, June 25 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali declared today that he would join forces with Fazlul Huq, 84-year-old political leader whom he dismissed from the chief ministership of East Pakistan last year.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A Democratic bill for new Social Security benefits was sharply modified today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

The Ohio Edison Company and its subsidiary, the Pennsylvania Power Company, reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for May and for the five and twelve months through May. On a consolidated basis, the system's kilowatt hour sales in April topped the half-billion mark for the first time.

Pausing momentarily yesterday before taking off for the West Coast, Kermit Bloomgarden, whose theatrical agenda calls for the presentation of three Broadway stage attractions next fall, imparted the following news nuggets:
Two members of the Harlem Redwings, a juvenile gang, were sentenced to twenty years to life yesterday for the fatal shooting of a bystander in a teen-age gang war.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 24 -- The Princeton Shopping Center, owned by Clearview Associates, Inc., has been taken over in a foreclosure action by the Property Credit Corporation of New York, holder of the second mortgage. Announcement of the action was made by George W. Warnecke, president of the Property Credit Corporation.

PARIS, June 24 -- Dr. Luther Evans, Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, may contest the right of an international tribunal to interfere with "loyalty" dismissals.
WHITE PLAINS, June 24 -The Westchester Republican County Committee, as expected, designated four candidates for county office at its annual convention in the county center today.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 24 (AP) -- Young Billy Maxwell of Odessa, Tex., came in late today with 34, 33 -- 67 to take the lead in the second round of the Western open golf championship.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 24 -- The State Bar Association was warned today that if lawyers did not cooperate with a moderate program of modernizing the courts now they might face unwelcome radical revisions in the entire legal profession later.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -There was no doubt tonight that the nineteen Latin - American countries were in general agreement on major points of United Nations policy.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A witness told the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today that thirty-four foreign-language newspapers in the United States consistently followed the Communist line. Eighteen of the papers are published in New York.

Today's new film is a Soviet import, "The Dragonfly," at the Stanley. Produced at the Toilisi studios in south Russia, the color film is described as "a musical comedy of errors." Lina Abashidze stars and the feature was directed by S. Dolidze. The Artkino release has English titles.

The futility of outsiders expressing their distaste for the racism of the Government in South Africa has been demonstrated clearly in recent years. At the same time it is necessary on occasion to call attention to the fact that enlightened opinion in the United States is bound to feel as much distaste for the Afrikaner philosophy of "apartheid," or legal segregation, as it did for the similar glorification by Hitler of the "Aryan."
Recent editorializing about the Argentine situation tends to overlook one important fact -- namely, that the Roman Catholic Church helped put Peron into power in 1943.
MAHWAH, N. J., June 24 -- A housewarming under a fortyacre roof was held today at the automobile assembly plant of the Ford division of the Ford Motor Company.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 24 -- Yugoslavia again sought to reassure the West today that her sentiments were more with the West than with the Soviet East.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., June 24 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair retained the fifty-four-hole medal play championship of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Rock Spring Club today.

STEPHEN VINCENT BENET once wrote a popular story and motion picture called "The Devil and Daniel Webster." In Benet's cheerful fantasy the Devil was outwitted by Webster, who saved a New Hampshire farmer from the provisions of a contract he had unwisely made.
The New York State Commission Against Discrimination was upheld yesterday in ruling that a Bronx swimming pool and recreation park could not lawfully refuse to admit Negroes.

SOME of the mangoes now on fruit counters here were picked less than twenty-four hours earlier in Florida. This quick trip from grove to market for the luscious tropical fruit is an innovation this year. It is one gourmets will applaud.

ST. LOUIS, June 24 -- Tom Poholsky allowed the Giants only three hits tonight. One of them cost him the ball game. Whitey Lockman belted his ninth home run of the season atop the right-field pavilion roof in the fourth inning.
OSLO, Norway, June 24 -Britain's Queen Elizabeth II arrived in Oslo today on her first visit to a foreign country since her accession in February, 1952.

ROME, June 20 -- A clinic for old books is moving into a modern home. In its new $150,000 headquarters the Institute of the Pathology of the Book will step up research into why books and documents become "ill" and what can be done to prevent their decay.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The administrator of the lagging refugee relief program was able today to report some progress.
VASSAR, Mich., June 24 (UP) -- The community of Vassar will remain on the map because workers at the town's only factory were willing to take a 61-cent hourly pay cut, factory officials said today.

WASHINGTON, June 24--Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent over the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. A slight rise in average prices of industrial commodities accounted for the increase, as the index for farm products declined. No change was registered in the index for processed foods.
ABOARD THE FISHING BOAT VIKING VII, June 24 -- The marine radio telephone in the wheelhouse chattered incessantly today as this vessel drifted off the south shore of Long Island in search of fluke.

Three boys from an East Harlem street gang were arrested yesterday for the murder of a rival gang member. The police said they had drawn lots to pick a trigger man. A 14-year-old girl and another boy were also rounded up.

WASHINGTON June 24 (UP) -- House investigators disclosed today that two former Navy officers had been showered with jobs and expensive gifts after they bought $177,660 worth of a fruit-flavored drink that sailors didn't like.
Connecticut plans to call another $100,000,000 of GreenwichKillingly Expressway bonds in about sixty days, State Treasurer John Ottaviano announced yesterday.
The radio board of directors of the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters moved yesterday to overhaul and spell out more clearly radio's standards of practice.

Stockholders of the Cerro de Pasco Corporation, at a special meeting here yesterday, approved an increase in authorized common shares to 2,500,000 of $5 par value each from 2,000,000 of the same par value.
LONDON, June 24 -- The Trades Union Congress set up a special three-man tribunal today to try to end the dock strike which is now in its fifth week.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 24 -An attempt to restore film censorship in Ohio failed today in the waning hours of the Legislature.
A man whom a Senate subcommittee sought to link with Communist efforts to push the narcotics traffic wound up yesterday giving the Senators recommendations on how to halt the business.

Following are the texts of a speech by Secretary of State Dulles at the United Nations ceremonies in San Francisco and excerpts from addresses by Lester Pearson of Canada, Dr. Sudjarwo Tjondronegoro of Indonesia, Dr. Mahmoud Fawzi of Egypt, David Aguilar-Cornejo of Peru, Vaclav David of Czechoslovakia, Sardar Mohammed Naim of Afghanistan and V. K. Krishna Menon of India as recorded by the New York Times.
ROME, June 24 -- Arriving in Rome today, Mayor Wagner of New York and his wife found the city strangely quiet. The Mayor attributed this to the ban on automobile horns.
Reports that a Singapore company was bidding up rubber to meet June delivery commitments firmed rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange yesterday.
BOSTON, June 24 (AP) -- Chicago survived a hectic ninth inning to cool off the Boston Red Sox, 3 -- 2, tonight. Nellie Fox' single in the seventh was the decisive blow.
A three-vehicle collision in Harlem yesterday afternoon sent fifteen persons to the hospital.
An 83-year-old man, nearly blind and on public assistance, has lost his seeing-eye dog and City Hall is out to help him find it.

Our biographical sketch yesterday of a noteworthy Texan, Amon G. Carter, said that with his colorful personality, his showmanship and his open-handed generosity he could have posed for a portrait of "Mr. Texas" himself. With this we think most Texans would agree.
Max Shachtman, said yesterday that he would press his fight for a passport so that he could promote socialism in Europe.

In its first change of ownership since 1920 the three-story carriage house on lot 25 by 102 feet at 113 East Seventy-seventh Street has been sold by the United States Trust Company of New York, trustees under the will of Lewis Cass Ledyard Jr.

Cadbury Bros., Ltd., English producer of chocolate and cocoa products since 1861, reported yesterday that its gross sales last year reached a record $203,000,000. This is about 20 per cent above the $170,000,000 volume for 1953.
ERIE, Pa., June 24 (AP) -- Hammermill Paper Company has increased paper prices $10 a ton.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board called today for stricter Federal controls over bank mergers.

WHITEFIELD, N. H., June 24 -- The White House announced today that Soviet planes had made art "inexplicable and unwarranted" attack on a United States naval patrol aircraft over international waters in the Bering Strait area.
MADRID, June 24 -- Don Juan of Bourbon, pretender to the Spanish throne, came out today in support of the Spanish regime and of Generalissimo Francisco Franco personally.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., June 24 -- Mr. and Mrs. Saul Weinsier captured the second annual Charles Stillman Memorial Husband-and-Wife alternate-stroke golf tournament today. The victors posted a 75, four strokes over par figures.
LONDON, June 24 -- Qualified Britons agree with almost everything Secretary of State Dulles said today in San Francisco. But they are not sure that this was the time to say it.

Henkind-Walsey Company, realty investors, has purchased two apartment buildings in the Bronx. The sixty-eight-family house with three stores at 624-34 Bergen Avenue was bought from the Conron Realty Company, owner for forty years, for all cash. Edward Muhlfield was the broker.
Following is a list of major incidents involving Soviet and other Communist planes on one side and Western aircraft on the other since World War II:
"Wasn't that a wonderful game?" inquired Casey Stengel rhetorically after the Yankees had beaten the Indians last night.
Business pilots, who fly corporate executives around in company airplanes, are getting their own special ground training device.

A three-car accident on the West Side Highway at Thirtythird Street last night resulted in injuries to seven persons and forced a detour of northbound traffic for seventy-five minutes. Four of the victims, two of them unconscious, were taken to St. Vincent's Hospital.
A man who said he was a member of the Communist party invaded the United Nations headquarters of the Soviet Union here yesterday, demanding a passport "to get out of this lousy country."
MOSCOW, June 24 -- A new law defining the duties and obligations of procurators, the chief law enforcement officers of the Soviet Union, has been enacted here.
ROME, June 24 -- Antonio Segni, father of Italian land reform, was considered tonight to have the best chance of becoming Italy's next Premier.
MILWAUKEE, June 24 -- The Dodgers' gay dash through the West came to an abrupt end tonight amid the thunderous cheers of 43,068, Milwaukee's second largest crowd of the year.
Sol Boyce Johnson, a deputy commissioner in the New York City office of the State Liquor Authority, resigned under fire on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday.

Today is Election Day for the nation's 950,000 wheat farmers. They will vote on whether to put their 1956 crop under Government marketing quotas. Polling booths will be open from 7 A. M. to 5 P. M., local time, in thirty-six states, with the balloting supervised by county agricultural committees.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -This was Harry Truman's day at the United Nations. Other men made better speeches than he did today, but the little man from Independence got the longest and loudest standing ovation of the week.
CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- Granny Hamner of the Philadelphia Phils today captured the second base lead in the National League voting of the All-Star game.

IF any reader happens to be looking for an antidote -- or, put it more emphatically, for an absolute diametrical antithesis -- to Louisa May Alcott's "Little Women," he can now locate it easily in this account of the fortunes and misfortunes of the sisters Dubochet, daughters of an unemployed Swiss watchmaker who flourished in London in the time of Lord Byron, Beau Brummell and other worthies of the Regency period.

THE public mind rates novels in two chief kinds, the formal work of art and the slice of life. Henry James is compared with Wolfe or Dos Passos. And the slice of life is somehow regarded as more true, more unaffected and sincere.
Buyers' hearts were in the Highlands last week, as Black Watch and "Brown Watch" plaids continued to draw heavy orders in ready-to-wear.

IF New York is the American city least like my Paris, the one most like it, of the American cities I have seen, is Washington. The resemblance is not merely physical -- the broad boulevards, the trees, parks, monuments, public buildings and squares. It is also a matter of mood. People in Washington behave more as people in Paris do.

We are living at the end of an ice age. It began 25,000 or more years ago and reached a maximum between 20,000 and 18,000 years ago. The ice has been retreating for about 13,000 years. How do the scientists know? By the radio-carbon method which has been mentioned in this department over and over again.
Nineteen faculty members at Columbia University have been promoted to full professorships, it was announced yesterday.

The House Committee on Appropriations has recommended for the fiscal year 1956 the expenditure of $22,328,000 by the National Cancer Institute; the corresponding Senate committee has increased the sum to $26,400,000. The difference of $4,072,000 means little in these days of military expenditures that run into the billions, but it means much in terms of cancer research.
GUATEMALA, June 25 -- Violence was narrowly averted in front of the National Palace this afternoon as rightist and leftist student organizations held nearly simultaneous demonstrations.

The lives and achievements of Soviet military leaders are apparently to be publicized extensively. Contrasting sharply with the policy followed while Stalin was alive, such procedure might give further evidence of the increased influence of military leaders in post-Stalinist Russia.

SURFACE scratches on a walnut table can be easily and quickly obliterated. Rub the meat of a walnut or a brazil nut over the marred surface until the scratches disappear. The nut meats stain them to match the original finish. Apply a coat of paste wax and polish.

AMERICAN carriers got a belated opportunity last week to tell the Civil Aeronautics Board how they felt about some unexpected terms of the projected air pact with Germany. Kernel of the controversy was the provision granting Germany's revived airline, Lufthansa, permission to fly beyond New York to any Caribbean or South American country willing to grant it landing rights.

V. I. Lenin and Mahatma Gandhi were contemporary revolutionaries, but of a vastly different stamp. The Russian was ruthless, a master planner, his vision fixed on the materialistic goals of communism. The Indian was a man of peace, an ascetic who sought to influence by example, his vision fixed on emancipation from the material no less than from the British Raj.

Norris R. Crump, new president of the Canadian Pacific Railway, happily combines two industrial traditions. He reached his present post last month in the almost feudal British manner. The chairman retires, the president becomes chairman, the senior vice president becomes president and so on until the most remote division hires a new call boy.

OUR hat is off to Gilbert W. Chapman, the chairman of the National Book Committee and by the way, the president of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company Mr. Chapman delivered an address which was printed up by the National Book Committee and which they have properly called "The Mission of Books."
Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's speeches today in New Hampshire as reported by The Associated Press:
MISGUIDED fertilizing can be harmful to flowers and vegetables, just as proper feeding can be beneficial. This is particularly true of chemical fertilizers.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., June 25 (AP) -- Seventh-seeded Jose (Pepe) Aguero, a Brazilian Davis Cup player from Tulane University, won the seventy-first National Collegiate tennis tournament today.
BEETHOVEN: Symphony No.6; Detroit Symphony Orchestra. Paul Paray conducting (Mercury). Cleanly recorded, well paced performance.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations called today for an extension of "quiet diplomacy" within the framework of the United Nations to resolve world problems.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission today awarded $400,000 to four nuclear scientists in return for all rights to plutonium separation processes they had developed.

THE Arctic of the fur trader, explorer and mounted policeman on his lonely sledge patrol is passing swiftly. The mining engineer, radar station and military base are transforming it, while the nomad Eskimo stands wondering at the hubbub, unsure of his place in the new North.

BEDFORD, Pa. -- When plans for the Pennsylvania Turnpike, the nation's first long-distance toll road, were announced in the late Nineteen Thirties, the howls that went up from merchants and townspeople along the historic Lincoln Highway (U. S. 30), which traversed approximately the same region, were louder than the Indian warwhoops which greeted Gen. John Forbes' first roadbuilders thereabouts in 1758.
SEOUL, Korea, June 17 -- When the North Korean Communists were driven out of Seoul in the fall of 1950, they did more than loot or wreck much of the property.
Barnard College has received a grant of $9,995 from the Rockefeller Foundation to enable the composers Otto Luening and Vladimir Ussachevsky to evaluate recent developments in electronic music.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., June 25 -- The ancient saltbox-type farmhouse of old Fish Hook Mulford has joined the growing list of landmarks that help make up Americana.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, June 26 -- Farmers voted in a referendum yesterday to give the Federal Government authority to restrict marketings of wheat in 1956 as a means of preventing production of additional surpluses.

PITTSBURGH, June 25 (UP) -- The United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., told the United States Steel Corporation today that it must make a substantial increase in its wage settlement offer to head off a possible industry strike at midnight next Thursday.

GRACE and a quiet depth of perception mark these unpretentious stories about life on a Navy transport. They say as much for the company of men in wartime as most brawling and boisterous war novels. Yet the book is slight -- composed of ten stories that are integral parts of one narrative.

The week that has just passed in Argentina came as an anticlimax to the dramatic days of revolt and repression that preceded it. The air is gradually clearing, although there is much to be learned and one should still avoid any firm conclusions.
The offshore oil leases to be auctioned by the Federal Government on July 12 are expected to command record prices.

THE review by Henry Steele Commager of Louis B. Wright's "Culture on the Moving Frontier" lists the Presbyterian, Methodist and Baptist as among "the really effective churches" in spreading education and culture on the frontier, Mr. Commager errs in not including the Congregational Church.

JIMMY DURANTE will be more active than ever on television next season. He will do thirty half-hour shows which will be on the N. B. C. network three weeks out of every four weeks. The "Schnozzola" is skipping his usual summer vacation.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Cut flowers for bouquets in the early morning or evening and put in water immediately. But also once a week cut faded flowers from roses, perennials and annuals before seed pods can form. This prolongs bloom, even on such perennials as columbine. Shear perennial aster and 'mum plants back to a height of eight inches.
City officials have accused Queens Borough President James A. Lundy of greatly exaggerating the need for repair of the Kissena Corridor sewer in his borough.
Barbara Payne of El Centro, Calif., may not be able to pronounce the word, but at the age of 9 she already is an established numismatist.

IS the economy approaching a period that can be closely compared to the fall of 1929? If so, does this portend a drastic decline such as followed the speculative orgy of twenty-five years ago? These questions are uppermost in the minds of many people, now that the level of stock market prices has about pierced the ceiling established prior to Black Tuesday in October of 1929.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 25 -- Seventy-four starters skipped around flat triangles smartly today in a brisk sou'wester after beginning in a faint easterly that promised only a long, dull afternoon.

CHRYSANTHEMUMS are one perennial certain to bloom, if the plants are growing in full sun. But the quality and the amount of bloom depends on the care given them during the summer. It is frequently recommended that the plants be lifted, divided and replanted every spring. Sometimes it is advisable to move the location, if there is room to do so, as pests and disease may be carried over in the soil.
PARIS, June 25 -- Jean Monnet has begun his campaign for the federal union of West Europe, in contradistinction to various looser forms of union with which federal union is often confused.

Intruders in the Booker T. Washington Junior High School Tuesday night carried off a slide projector and record player after doing "senseless" damage to offices on the first floor, it was learned yesterday.

ATWIN to "Here Come the Bears!" so far as illustrations, approach and quality are concerned, Alice Goudey's new book describes the lives of three deer families in the Rocky Mountain wilderness. Just as in the earlier book she caught the bristling belligerency of the bears, now she shows us the gentle, timid yet resourceful nature of the deer.

The State Education Department will soon come to the rescue of pupils who do not know how to study. The department is preparing a guide to held pupils master the fundamental techniques of studying that will enable them to get more out of their education.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 25 -- The fifty-seven-room Russian-owned mansion, Killenworth, and its forty-three acres of land went on the auction block today for $15,605 in back taxes. Joseph Harris of Baldwin, L. I., a real estate dealer, took up the liens at 12 per cent interest. Of the amount $8,133 was for city taxes and $7,472 for school levies. Mr. Harris was the only bidder.

LAWNS in the Northeast, Midwest and similar climatic regions are about to enter their annual "trial by fire" season, for turf probably has no greater enemy than the July and August sun. And when that sun beats down for seemingly endless days, many facts about old and new lawns will be seen in a clearer light.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 25 -- The Boy Scouts of America dedicated a $3,000,000 headquarters on a forty-acre site in near-by North Brunswick today. The structure is on Route 130, about thirty-five miles southwest of New York City.
LONDON, June 24 -- An elaborate program has been arranged for a group of Russian church leaders who are due in Britain July 4.
An agency of the Congregational Christian Churches has received a grant from the Fund for the Republic to conduct a nation-wide study of Christianity's relation to civil liberties.

LONDON, June 25 (Reuters) -- South Africa needed 166 runs with eight second-innings wickets in hand to beat England in the second cricket test when play ended today, the third day of the five-day match at Lords Ground. England won the first test.

EVERYONE knows that plants need water. Not everyone knows when or how to water, or what kind of plants need irrigation. Indiscriminate watering is often harmful to plants. Daily light sprinkling encourages foliage fungus diseases and shallow rooting. Excessive watering of new plants can suffocate the roots, or wash away the fertility of the soil.
Greater credit availability for New York State's small but growing business concerns moved a step nearer to realization last week.

PARMACHENEE LAKE, Me., June 25 -- President Eisenhower cast his flies today for trout and land-locked salmon. He also dropped a hint he might not run for re-election. He motored into this remote, heavily wooded section of Maine after four days of speech-making and public appearances across neighboring Vermont and New Hampshire.

The drive-in theatre, once scorned as odd, even disreputable -- the movies were always very old and very bad, the audiences not always solely interested in the movies -- has become solid and respectable. Today it is, in fact, big business. From an insignificant 300 in 1946, drive-ins have multiplied startlingly to the present 4,062.
THERE has been a surge of philatelic interest in Washington, with a number of Congressmen introducing measures involving stamps.
A tonnage record in intercity freight was established by trucks during the first quarter this year.

ONE of the disks from London-Editions de l'Oiseau-Lyre is of special interest among the week's new releases. On this disk a baritone named Bruce Boyce is heard singing Brahms' Four Sacred Songs and other Brahms favorites such as Wie bist du meine Koenigin, Die Mainacht, Wie Melodien zieht es, Wir wandelten.
Gifts to the Russian Orthodox Church in exile will be auctioned for its benefit Thursday noon at the Plaza Art Galleries, 22 East Forty-sixth Street.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 25 -- The question who is to succeed Finland's 85-year-old President, Dr. Juho Paasikivi, when his term ends next March, now looks as if it would be solved in a very simple manner.
SEOUL, Korea, June 25 -- South Koreans paraded today and held demonstrations in observing the fifth anniversary of the outbreak of war with the North.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., June 25 -- The Progressive Education Association, a controversial group known for its influence in shaping teaching methods since its founding in 1919, took a first step toward dissolution here today.

PLANS for the long weekend which starts next Friday indicate that record crowds will leave the city for beach, lakes and mountains. Additional crowds are expected to arrive in town, attracted by the opening of New York's Summer Festival.

THE old saying, "good fences make good neighbors," could be rewritten to read, "good fences help make good gardens." There are few structural additions to the home property that will bring as much lasting beauty and serve so many purposes as a well-designed and well-constructed garden fence.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 25 -- Cornell announced this week plans for the university's first "student scholarship hall" for men. About $250,000 has been granted from a charitable trust with the hope that the building will "strengthen the bonds of friendship between future generations of American students and German youth."
MOSCOW, June 20 -- Not since the Moscow foreign ministers conference of 1947 have there been so many foreign news correspondents in the Soviet Union as there will be this summer.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -- Following is a transcript of Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov's news conference here today. The questions were translated from English into Russian.

BOULDER, Colo., June 25 -- Arnie Sowell of the University of Pittsburgh today became the second American to better unofficially the listed world record when he won the National Amateur Athletic Union 880-yard run in 1:47.6.

RECENTLY, one of the students at our school reached his twelfth birthday. His mother arranged a small, home party for him. The evening went happily and after his friends left, son and mother sat at ease discussing the evening. Now the twelfth birthday is a "big" birthday, as are the sixteenth and twenty-first, and, after a successful party, the immediate future should look rosy to a 12-year-old.

A survey of history textbooks in fifty-eight countries outside the Iron Curtain has been undertaken by the World Brotherhood, an organization devoted to reducing frictions created by national, religious and cultural differences.

THE time is the present, the setting Arizona and California. An Apache boy, fresh out of the agency scnool, accidentally acquires a pure-bred 2-year-old filly with a broken leg. The leg is mended under the supervision of a remarkable old medicine man, steeped in the magic and obduracy of his race.

WHEN a fellow sits down to figure out his ballot for the All-Star teams, he comes face to face with frustration. The voting, of course, is for the starting line-ups at the midsummer classic in Milwaukee on July 12, with the polls closing this Friday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- Clark M. Eichelberger, who helped formulate the original proposals for a United Nations Charter for President Roosevelt, agreed today that the anniversary conference here had achieved positive results.

IT was the Polish chemist, Casimir Funk, long a resident of this country, who coined the word "vitamins." He began his researches half a century ago when there was no such distinctive discipline as bio-chemistry.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Senate subcommittee on juvenile delinquency is looking into the "black market" in baby adoptions with a view to possible Federal legislation.

RILEY WILSON, a West Virginia raconteur of national repute in the bygone years, loved to recall with both profundity and profanity his early years as an Indian fighter. On one excursion against the redskins, it seems, he and his men ran out of ammunition and were forced to hotfooted flight to save their own skins.
FOLKLORE of New York will replace recollections of Indiana Saturday night on the Columbia Broadcasting System show "Two for the Money."
KITIMAT, B. C., June 25 -- This thriving new town on a wilderness fiord 100 miles below the Alaskan border is the scene of the largest aluminum expansion project under way in the free world.
What do you think ails baseball?

DETROIT, June 25 -- Bill Cantrell drove his Gale IV to victory today in the unlimited class of the Detroit Memorial speed boat regatta. Five boats crashed in the blinding spray of the first heat and a driver in a smaller class was killed in a second collision.

OSLO, Norway, June 25 (UP) -- Thor Heyerdahl, explorer, today gave Queen Elizabeth II a model of his famed Kon-Tiki raft for her children to float in their Buckingham Palace bathtub. The model was made from the balsa wood of the original raft on which Mr. Heyerdahl and his companions drifted across the Pacific to learn whether the South Pacific islanders could have come from South America centuries ago.

THE organization called AWARE, Inc., which describes its purpose as combating "the Communist conspiracy in the entertainment world," is the center of a bitter controversy among performers in radio and television.
The Fund for the Republic has granted $32,500 to the Common Council for American Unity for case studies of the legal rights of aliens in the United States.

OURS has often been called a "business civilization." The United States long ago emerged from the state of a rural-agricultural society into that of an urban-industrial society and the American industrial system is one of the wonders of the world.

I HAVE just finished reading Jack Gould's article of last Sunday about subscription television, and I would like to congratulate him for having done a clear and comprehensive job of presenting a complex subject.

BERLIN, June 25 -- Dr. Heinrich von Brentano said today Bonn would not make the repatriation of German captives in the Soviet Union a condition for negotiations between Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Soviet leaders.

WHEN his friends reflect upon years of personal association with John Golden, such a procession of anecdotes crowd into their memories that a tape recorder would be required to preserve them. Perhaps it might be a good idea for some of his friends and cronies to gather together periodically with such a device. While these memories are fresh, they should be taped for the tale of a life well lived.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 25 -- The conference of Asian countries of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization unanimously agreed today that Asia offered considerable opportunities for cooperation and economic and agricultural expansion.
Re the page devoted to "Girl Scouts in Search of Leaders" (June 5), by Dorothy Barclay, may I say that I and many of my leader friends do an excellent job for the Camp Fire Girls.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 25 (AP) -- Joe Campbell of Purdue and Johnny Garrett of Rice Institute finished even at the end of the first half of their thirty-six-hole National Collegiate golf championship final today.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 25 (UP) -- Andy Crevolin's Determine carried top weight of 124 pounds to victory by less than a neck today in the $27.550 Inglewood Handicap at Hollywood Park.
The wheels of production in New York's women's apparel industry will begin turning at a faster pace this week.
Great Britain is about to overtake the United States as the world's leading tanker operator.
A $400,000 jewel robbery with aspects of the bizarre and the ironic occurred yesterday in daylight at Madison Avenue and East Fifty-fifth Street.

THE last time I saw Babel, some twenty-five years ago, in Paris, critics spoke of him as a Russian Maupassant, Gorky called him "a great writer and a loyal Bolshevik," and it was rumored that Stalin enjoyed his writings.

TRENTON, June 25 -- The Garden State Parkway will be open to traffic along its entire 165-mile length for the first time on Friday. The superhighway will then stretch from Paramus in Bergen County to within one mile of the southern tip of the Cape May peninsula.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Officials and members of Congress viewed tonight with restraint, but some satisfaction, the Russians' admission that they might have been partly at fault in the plane incident.

BONN, June 25 -- The rights and duties of the future German soldier were outlined in a 110-page booklet published by the West German Defense Ministry today. Several hundred thousand copies will be distributed freely to make young Germans familiar with life in the future German army.

SUGGESTIONS are being sought by the Photographers' Association of America for the names of candidates, persons or organizations, for honors for their contributions to the advancement of professional photography.

ON two occasions in one household recently, a high pitch of aggravation was reached by inability to read the fine print a manufacturer had put on his product. In each case, a special paint was involved -- one for canvas, the other metallic. In each case the cautious householder assumed that special paint might call for special procedure.

CARLOS CHAVEZ, who conducted eight concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony in the spring of 1937, is returning to the orchestra next season. He will lead it three times, but in only one work: his Sinfonia No. 3. This work won the Mexican composer a $5,000 prize at the festival of Latin American music in Caracas last year. The first New York performance will be the North American premiere.
ROME, June 25 -- Mayor Wagner of New York drew barbed comment today in the left-wing press.
Some managers live by the "book," which is another way of saying they play percentage baseball.
BONN, Germany, June 25 -- The Bundestag debate on armament legislation will commence Monday with a Government statement on methods to be employed in creating a democratic military establishment.

LIKE the classic gangster film, "Scarface," Benjamin Appel's latest novel is no sensational cops-and-robbers melodrama, but the tragedy of a hero-villain which any Elizabethan dramatist would have understood and approved.
WEATHER has much to do with the prevalence of certain pests. Therefore, gardeners would be wise to be on the lookout for unwelcome visitors.
CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm's Mark-Ye-Well gained a nose victory in the $28.025 Laurance Armour Memorial Handicap at Arlington Park today.

IN its chief role as a boring tool the bitbrace is an essential component of every workshop, even the very small toolbox with a minimum of equipment. Because the brace is used quite frequently in many household chores, and serves several important functions in addition to cutting holes through wood, it pays to have one of very good quality, and also to utilize the special bits and accessories with the brace.

SAN DIEGO, Calif.--The first West Coast steamship service in many a moon has just been inaugurated, linking California with popular resorts on the west coast of Mexico. It runs from San Diego to Mazatlan, 1,000 miles southeast as the crow flies, and thence to Acapulco, 600 miles further down the coast.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Smiles crossed the faces of thousands here this week as Congress finally approved the pay-rise bill for the Government's white collar workers. But there were groans too.

HONG KONG, June 25 (Reuters) -- Nine "Chiang Kai-shek secret agents" have been sentenced to death for spying and sagotage in Communist China, the Peiping People's Daily, official Communist government organ, said today.
VIENNA, June 25 -- One hundred ninety detained Austrians, including forty-five women and two children, returned to Austria from the Soviet Union today.
