PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 25 -- In his first major competition since his return from the Navy, Rudy Jezek of the New York A. C. won the senior singles sculls quarter-mile 150-pound dash today on the Orchard Beach lagoon course off Travers Island.

ABOUT $1,500 in photographic equipment and concert tickets is offered the winners in the Stadium Concerts' annual Camera Night contest to be held Wednesday, July 6. Amateurs will have an opportunity to shoot freely such subjects as the performers, the crowds and phases of the Stadium's concert operations.

ELIZABETH HAMILTON was interested in birds. She used to take notes about them and someone said: "Why don't you keep a diary about the birds you see from your window?" That was how she started writing, and the story of the birds and other things in nature was published in a book, "The Year Returns."
LONDON, June 25 -- The unofficial seamen's strike ended today. Strike leaders said that "the thing that has beaten us" is the draft of strikers for military service.

HAVING reached the age of 90, which he did today, Bernard Berenson, the art historian, art connoisseur and premier authority on the art of the Italian Renaissance, is still engaged in what he makes appear as a kind of grumpy frontal assault on time.

WHEN he died in 1951, Walter Tower Rosen, banker and patron of the arts, left his beautiful estate, Caramoor, in Katonah, N. Y., to the public. His will gave to his widow, Lucie Bigelow Rosen, a musician in her own right, life use of the place. The entire residuary estate was vested in the Walter and Lucie Rosen Foundation to make Caramoor "a cultural, artistic and educational center" of permanent benefit to the public.

THE recurring question of technique versus content came up again, and repeatedly, in two competitions held last week. The neglect of craftsmanship has become so prevalent and technical inadequacy so generally condoned as unimportant that one might describe the situation as almost a current trend.
Skippers of pleasure boats are doing commendable things for safety's sake. On fresh water as well as salt they are tightening the regulations to make their sport free from accidents.
Another attempt, the newest in a long series, is now being made to modernize New York's complicated court structure in the interest of improving the administration of justice.

NEXT season will find one of the oldest of our dance landmarks missing, for the Students Dance Recitals series has been discontinued, at least for the time being. That old villain, rising costs, is the reason, and though the price of the subscriptions could be raised accordingly, the sponsors are unwilling to do this without further consideration.

BUENOS AIRES, June 25 -- The Soviet Trade Exposition reopened its doors today and two big races were among the nine run at Palermo Race Track. To all outward appearances this capital has returned to normality.
ALTHOUGH the off-shore fishing season is just getting started complaints have been flowing in from anglers who insist they were "victimized" by charter boat captains.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 25 -- Camp Kilmer, which processed 5,000,000 service men during and after World War II, will close next week for the second time in six years.
Hollywood versions of biblical stories take a thorough beating in the current issues of two religious magazines.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 25 -- By an ironic twist of history, the Peace Bridge, built in 1925 as a monument to a century of friendship between Canada and the United States, is stirring up trouble between the two neighbors.

TOLD in the first person, this is the story of a little girl's excursion to the seaside, a theme reminiscent of Alvin Tresselt's "I Saw the Sea Come In." Mrs. Koch's book is more everyday in mood, less poetic, but it has a robust quality of enjoyment.

WHEN I was a boy at school, reading my Latin texts with one finger on the word and one finger in the Notes, I did not get much fun out of it. Anyway they made us read the wrong sorts of authors, respectable authors like Cicero and Livy and the dull parts of Virgil.

IN his newspaper and magazine pieces, Samuel Grafton, a columnist turned free-lance writer, sets down the facts as clearly and draws conclusions as cogently as any reader could wish. But in "A Most Contagious Game," his first novel, the characters he creates are a little thin and their motivations are a little difficult to believe in.
A husky Iowa feed merchant, whose flat midwestern speech is spiced with a Dutch accent, left here last week for a five-week trip in Europe.
PROF. EDWARD TELLER, one of the leading architects of the hydrogen bomb, has just taken the fateful step that sometimes leads to television stardom.

On the second day of the tenth anniversary meeting of the United Nations in San Francisco, Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., delegate of the United States, rose to propose an international conference which would supplement the one to be held at Geneva in August to discuss the peaceful uses of atomic energy.

WARREN, R. I., June 25 -- A sixty-four foot trailer-ferry and a sixty-foot party fishing boat are under construction at the Blount Marine Corporation here. The welded-steel vessels are scheduled for launching next month.

VIENNA, June 25 (Reuters) -- The returning prisoners named two Americans who, they said, had died in the Soviet camp of Verkhne-Uralsk. They were Johnny Willart (or Wilmer) who went insane and died in Room 32 of the camp in the summer of 1953, and Charles Brown, who died in 1953.
Another effort to have Congress enact legislation to help professional and other self-employed persons establish retirement plans will be made in Washington, starting tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -- Admiral Hyman G. Rickover, the Navy's top atomic expert, warned in testimony released today that building President Eisenhower's proposed around-the-world atomic peace ship would delay the Navy's own nuclear ship program.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 25 -- Negro spokesmen today saluted the United Nations on its tenth anniversary, but they expressed regret over the "lack of progress" in implementing the human rights provision of its Charter.
NEW HAVEN, June 25 -- A year ago the city dog pound was branded by the American Humane Association as the "worst" in the entire country.

In 1946 Mrs. Hirsch Jacobs' good old Stymie won Aqueduct's Edgemere Handicap in 1:50 2/5. Yesterday the nine - furlong Edgemere had its thirty-sixth running. The winner was Mrs. Jacobs' Paper Tiger, one of Stymie's sons.
HENLEY, England, June 25 (AP) -- Russia's boatless oarsmen today sailed into more difficulties in their bid to win the Henley regatta for the second straight year.

THERE lies before me a "World Historical Atlas" published in Germany in 1953. Its maps display the territorial changes which have taken place as a result of historical development, and especially of wars. It is is an interesting book and shows far more directly than written history what tensions have arisen at different periods on this globe -- tensions which led to catastrophes.

THE international edition of Edward Steichen's "The Family of Man" show will be displayed from Thursday to July 31 at the Corcoran Gallery of art in Washington, D. C., after which it will be sent abroad for a European tour under the auspices of the United States Information Agency.

AS gallery activities slow down with the coming of summer the international aspect of local attractions is still in evidence. Four of the newly opened group exhibitions include displays of seventeenth century Chinese prints, Japanese master color prints of three centuries, seventeenth century Dutch painting and contemporary Yugoslav paintings and prints.

The facetious doggerel by Helen Bevington is all very clever, but I do wish people who refer to "Sumer is icumen in" would not so persistently assume (by ear) that "icumen" is merely a droll manner of spelling "a-coming."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, the Soviet Foreign Minister, said today the Soviet Union favored an all-German government that would not be an extension of either the East German or the West German regime.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 25 -- Henry Filter Jr. of Ridgewood, N. J., captured four firsts during the third day of the Fairfield County Hunt Club Horse Show today.
HARRISBURG, Pa., June 25 (UP) -- Gov. George M. Leader today threw his support behind a proposal in Congress that may lead to Federal control of the boxing profession.
HARTFORD, June 25 -- Tolls on the Merritt Parkway will be doubled in the next three weeks. Motorists will pay 20 cents instead of 10.

Optimistic predictions that business this year would set a new peak in activity, and another huge expansion program unveiled by General Motors, gave impetus to a further rise in stock prices last week. Although profit-taking at times slowed the upward movement, the market finally pierced the 1929 high.
OCEANPORT, N. J., June 25 -- Mrs. Irving Gushen's Star Rover showed unexpected staying ability to win the $25,600 Lamplighter Handicap at Monmouth Park today.

Teaching is essentially an expression of personality, Dr. Percival M. Symonds, Professor of Education, Teachers College, Columbia University, says in a study made public recently. This interpretation suggests a change in emphasis in teacher training from purely intellectual coures to experiences for the better personal adjustment of teachers.
The Russian Collection of the New York Public Library, long housed in the branch at 224 East 125th Street, will be closed on Thursday pending transfer.

THE value of an autobiography, not less than that of a novel, depends on its truth. The characters, central or subsidiary, must always feel and behave as they would and did, never as they might have or should.
The writers are partners in Scribe Productions. Mr. Shavelson directed "The Seven Little Foys," which Mr. Rose produced from a screen play by Shavelson and Rose.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Roger Lewis, Assistant Secretary of the Air Force, will return to private life in September.
DAVENPORT, Iowa, June 25 (AP) -- Jack Fleck, the young municipal course professional, has joined the parade of United States Open golf champions, but can he prove his place?

THE price of being a bridge editor (to borrow from a popular misquotation) is eternal vigilance. Readers lie in wait to catch the slightest slip. Bridge editors learn to eschew such flat statements as "the contract can be beaten" or "can be made." They learn to say "may" and "might" and "would probably."

GLYNDEBOURNE OPERA has made its high reputation by a zealous and unsparing search for perfection in performance. It began the search in 1934 when John Christie, member of a famous family of organ builders, opened this unique little theatre in the garden of his Sussex home, fifty-odd miles from London. He began with a performance of "The Marriage of Figaro" that linked music and drama "like Juno's swans, coupled and inseparable."
TULSA, Okla., June 25 (AP) -- Crude oil, plummeting nearly three miles down the Andes, may soon turn turbines generating electricity for a South American city of 30,000.

FLORENCE, Italy, June 25 -- Christians should rejoice in the progress of science, which lightens human suffering, the fourth International Congress for Peace and Christian Civilization declared today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- The United States is considering Europe-wide security system based on an exchange of guarantees and limitation of forces between the North Atlantic Pact countries and the Communist bloc.
The nickel cup of coffee -- at least for New Yorkers -- appears to be far away, despite declining prices of raw coffee.

THE travel lines and tourist agencies should shower medals on Ilya Lopert and David Lean for their film "Summertime," with Katharine Hepburn, now on the Astor's screen. For this strictly romantic contemplation of what happens to an American old maid while on a visit in Venice should increase the flow of tourist trade to that already popular city by an untold percentage in the next few years.

This summer will mark the eightieth year that the Universal Postal Union has been in active operation. Every day mail entering and leaving the United States is regulated, directly or indirectly, by this organization.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- The private diplomatic talks here this week have been extremely useful. They have clarified what the Russians are after, brought the Western officials closer together on how to deal with the current Communist diplomatic offensive, and provided both sides with a more realistic approach to next month's Big Four meeting at Geneva.
A multi-million-dollar expansion program at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Sparrows Point, Md., shipyard is equipping that plant to construct tankers even larger than the present giants.
Two men with experience in the railroad industry are being considered for the chairmanship of the new three-man Transit Authority.
SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 25 -- New York lawyers were urged today to get behind a proposal to reform state laws governing automobile accident damage suits.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives defended today the continuation of United States aid to Yugoslavia and India. Both countries have been criticized for not cooperating sufficiently with the West.

A REMARKABLY large number of Americans assume that all Russians are Communists. At the same time, many of these people believe that Russia is seething with revolt and may rise against the Communists at any moment.

Casey Stengel's desire to keep Jim Konstanty in the game allowed Bob Cerv to capitalize on the chance to be the hero of yesterday's Yankee triumph over the Indians. Casey let Cerv hit in a bunt situation in the eighth inning. Bob belted a single that scored Andy Carey with the winning run.

GOOSE BAY, Labrador -- Embarking from this obscure port (which came into real existence only with World War II's needs for an airbase and radio station here) a vacationist with a solid urge for the unusual, the rugged and the spectacular this summer can enjoy one of the most pioneering of all possible holidays.
The Chief Federal narcotics expert in New York sharply disputed yesterday the view of State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits that narcotics addiction was "at a record high."

HAVANA -- To this city, bursting at the seams with a steadily rising population, the tunnel to be dug under the channel to the Bay of Havana holds all the fascinating promise of the magic carpet of the Arabian Nights.
Trans-Caribbean Airways, Inc., which runs a six-planet passenger operation, has bought four planes for all-cargo service.

THE Spewacks, Bella and Samuel, appear to be developing a strong affection for French rascaldom. Not so long ago they turned the rogues of Albert Husson's "La Cuisine des Anges" into "My 3 Angels" with considerable success and now they will attempt to do the same with the characters of Jean Dutourd's novel which recently appeared here as "The Best Butter."
MOSCOW, June 25 -- What with one thing and another, it certainly has been a busy week for the international disciples of Dale Carnegie.

MORE film companies are taking to television to show that movies are better than ever. The National Broadcasting Company has purchased the Sir Alexander Korda production of Shakespeare's "Richard III" for a one-showing American premiere next January.

MOSCOW, June 25 (AP) -- Mikhail Krivonosov of Russia got off a heave of 209 feet 1.9 inches -- the second best hammer throw ever in a twelve-nation track and field meet before a crowd of 30,000 today at Dynamo Stadium.

Communist airplanes have again attacked a United States craft in an international area. The situation is not new. There have been many such incidents. The timing of this one, in the midst of the talk of better relationships at San Francisco, is ironic, but, we believe, accidental.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- When the House takes up, possibly some time this week, the revived bill to reorganize the Reserve program, it is likely to find itself confronted again with the question of racial integration, which stalled the measure when it was first debated three weeks ago.
NONSAN, Korea, June 14 -- A machine gun chattered at irregular intervals. Occasionally there was the explosion of a charge of TNT -- bright red flame at its center, then a cloud of dust drafting.

Priests of the Pious Order of St. Charles, like prison chaplains, count themselves successful when their congregations shrink. Their mission is to help the Italian immigrant make a new life in a new country.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., June 25 -- Camp Drum's annual summer training program opens with the arrival today and tomorrow of 12,300 National Guardsmen and Army Reservists, mostly from New England.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 2 -- Yugoslavia's conference with the Western powers will take longer than originally contemplated. The participants had hoped to conclude an exchange of views this afternoon but the closing meeting is now set for Monday.
EDGEMONT, S. D., June 25 (AP) -- Climbing aboard a bucket loader, Gov. Joe Foss yesterday broke ground for a $2,500,000 uranium processing mill here.

THE next to the youngest of the seven Larsson children (those happy Swedish adventures of "The Saucepan Journey") now stars in a book of his own. At 5. Pysen has a talent for living dangerously, due largely to his remarkable intensity of purpose.

HONOLULU, June 25 (UP) -- Australia's John Henricks continued to dominate the Keo Nakama swimming meet last night by shattering the America record for the 100-meter free-style race by three-tenths of second.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif. -- My wife and I have motored across the country quite a number of times. Two years ago we did it during the summer, and after experiencing the impressive heat of the Southwest desert region, we determined never to attempt it again during the hot season.
ASHEVILLE, N. C., June 25 -- The Supreme Court should be filled by promotions from lower Federal courts under a career merit system, a North Carolina lawyer told a judicial conference here today.

Ten years ago today fifty nations signed in San Francisco a United Nations Charter pledging them to act together to "save succeeding generations from the scourge of war." But the ten years since have been a decade of fear that the scourge might return.
MOSCOW, June 25 -- A new campaign against "eyewashing" (false reporting) by Soviet officials has been launched by the Communist party and Government.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 19 -- Thailand and neighboring Burma want to become close friends, their Government say. But after centuries of hostility, obstacles still block friendship's path.

DURING the occupation of Japan some Allied authorities considered the Japanese womenfolk their most enthusiastic agents in pushing the program of social reforms designed to strip the nation of its feudal, military character.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 25 -- Mike Souchak carded a 67 for an 11-under par 54-hole total of 205 today to lead the field into tomorrow's final round of the Western open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -- The National Petroleum Association, big refiners' group, again has filed suit to force the Internal Revenue Service to collect a 6-cents-a-gallon excise tax from oil reclaimers.
MADISON, Wis., June 25 (AP) -- Patty Berg, St. Andrews, Ill., pro, cracked par by two strokes today to take a stroke lead at the 54-hole mark in the women's Western open golf tournament.

Last week the first New York City regional meeting for the White House Conference on Education was held at Teachers College, Columbia University. Some 400 educators, community leaders and civic-minded laymen attended the all-day session, at which the many problems confronting American schools and colleges were considered.
HARTFORD, June 25 -- Reform of legislative practices that have existed for more than a hundred years in Connecticut has been started by the General Assembly.

IN the ardent regions where all the rest are excited and vehement, Mozart alone is completely self-possessed: where they are clutching their bars with a grip of iron and forging them with Cyclopean blows, his gentleness of touch never deserts him: he is considerate, economical practical under the same pressure of inspiration that throws your Titan into convulsions.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- The United Nations birthday celebration this week was so overshadowed by the impending meeting of the Big Four heads of government that the original purpose in returning here was almost forgotten.

WITH PRESIDENT EISENHOWER IN NEW ENGLAND, June 25 -- President Eisenhower was a smiling, calm, confident, crowd-pleasing "campaigner" as he moved across the northern tier of New England this week, dropping cryptic hints he might be a candidate for re-election in 1956.

THERE is (and long has been) some question whether Cape Cod is a location, a condition of mind, a collection of legends carefully preserved and possibly made to order by doting folklorists or a commercial product given an "antiqued" finish.

CELILO FALLS, Ore., June 25 -- Within the next few weeks, six Indian families will begin moving from their ancient fishing grounds on the Columbia River's rocks. The Dalles Dam railroad relocation work will start then.

Whether the mattress is hard or soft, it's a bulky thing to ship. So the mattress manufacturer with a national market has a problem in production -- and also in promotion and advertising -- of which the maker of a smaller product is happily ignorant.
CLEVELAND, June 25 (AP) -- Favored Traffic Judge, with Eddie Arcaro up, won the $46,675 Ohio Derby at Thistle Down Park today, a neck in front of long-shot Selinsgrove.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 25 -- Incredibly, Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas are still in the All-England doubles tournament tonight.
KODIAK, Alaska, June 25 (AP) -- Whether the Navy patrol plane downed in the Bering Strait was attacked by one or more Soviet planes remained unclear today.

THE Professor of Political Science at the University of Alberta, H. B. Mayo, has written a demanding book. It demands the reader's concentrated attention to follow the author's closely knit "survey and assessment of Marxism."

TO Scotsmen, the Highland Games are the World Series, Indianapolis 500 and Circus Day all rolled into one. The games consist of a variety of traditional competitions ranging from bagpipe playing to the tossing of the caber, a sort of junior-size telephone pole which, to make things difficult, must be tossed in such a way as to go gyrating down the field end over end like a twirler's baton gone astray.
Like the Hatfields and McCoys, private and public power interests are getting together more these days.

Thomas M. Pryor's "Hollywood's Search for Stars" (June 12) in my opinion points out Hollywood's lack of faith in itself. So what if there are ten years to a decade? So what if middle age, chronologically, is catching up with Hollywood's stars?

TO identify the contents of a party filled paint can without opening it, try color coding. When ready to seal the can, paint the lid with a little of the paint. This allows immediate identification of the contents when selecting paints for another job. The paint dries true to color on the lid, where painting it on the label may disguise the exact tone.

JACOB'S PILLOW opens its annual dance festival near Lee, Mass., next Friday and Saturday, under the direction of Ted Shawn, with matinees and evening performances off both days. The program will be given by Maria Karnilova and David Nillo representing the ballet, the John Butler Dance Theatre representing the modern dance, and Carola Goya and Matteo in the ethnological field.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -- Steve Gromek shut out the Washington Senators with four hits today. The Detroit Tigers made it two in a row over the Nats, 4 -- 0.

Profits of the nation's manufacturing industries in the first quarter this year far outstripped those of any similar period in American corporate history. To make the performance more remarkable, the result was achieved in the face of declining defense expenditures.
Three young hoodlums, brandishing a toy pistol, invaded a Brooklyn real estate office yesterday, slugged the elderly manager and fled with $400 in cash.

BOSTON, June 25 -- The Chicago White Sox backed Millard (Dixie) Howell's relief pitching with home runs by Jim Busby, Sherm Lollar and Walt Dropo today to win their fifth straight game. They beat the Boston Red Sox, 8 to 3.

Telluride Association has granted scholarships to seventeen high school juniors to attend its 1955 summer program at Cornell University during six weeks starting July 5. The central theme of the summer program will be the theories and practices of government in the United States.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 25 (AP) -- Top-seeded Crawford Henry of Atlanta defeated Norman Perry of Los Angeles, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1 today to win the national scholastic tennis championship.

BALTIMORE, June 25 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles and Kansas City Athletics tied, 3 -- 3, today in a drawn-out contest finally called off because of rain with no one out in the first half of the eleventh inning.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -- Representative Carl Vinson confidently predicted today that the House would pass a compromise version of President Eisenhower's compulsory military reserve bill despite threats of a new dispute over racial segregation.

Eighteen boys and eight girls, sons and daughters of members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A. F. L., received six-year college scholarships yesterday. They were provided by the Joint Industry Board of the Electrical Industry of New York.

Boston, June 25 (AP) -- Jimmy Carter, undismayed by statements he's been ducking Wallace (Bud) Smith for five years, will be favored Wednesday when he puts his world lightweight boxing title on the line against the Cincinnati man.

Some of the most beautiful yellows to be found anywhere are now to be found in the evening primroses, the primrose itself and the lesser members of the family called sundrops. They are hot-weather flowers, and they are so adaptable that they grow almost anywhere, in fields and at roadsides, east of the Rocky Mountains.

At the beginning of last week it was impossible to foresee whether the United Nations tenth anniversary celebration in San Francisco would turn out well or not. Some observers foolishly thought there was not much to celebrate -- as though ten years without a major war, in a world torn by gigantic differences of policy, interest and faith, were not in themselves a triumph.

MARGARET MILLAR always poses a problem in classification. If she sets out to write a straight novel, it may well (like "The Cannibal heart") have overtones of suspense: if she writes a detective story, it is certain (like "Rose's Last Summer") to be of interest to the connoisseur of serious fiction.

AT the time of the persecution of the Quakers in England, many brave men and courageous women endured untold hardships to follow their faith. The fortunate ones reached America, and in her latest novel Helen Corse Barney tells of a young boatswain's conversion to the faith and the trials and tortures he suffers before he, too, reaches the New World and marries the girl he loves.

CURRENT filming of "The Beast of Hollow Mountain," Hollywood's first science - fiction Western, has aroused interest in the history of imparting movement to inanimate objects for the purposes of motion picture entertainment. The picture, which has as its human stars, Guy Madison and Patricia Medina, introduces the Regiscope process, an animation-in-depth system developed after eighteen years of experimentation by Edward Nassour, the producer-director.

SAN SALVADOR, June 14 -- El Salvador, smallest and most thickly populated republic on the American continents, is searching for a solution to a problem plaguing many larger countries: a surplus of cash export crops and a shortage of basic good-stuffs.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 25 -- A nine-man New Zealand expedition has abandoned its eight-week attempt to scale Mount Masherbrum, 25,660-foot peak in the Karakoram Range of Kashmir.

The timing of Mr. Truman's address in San Francisco was almost startingly appropriate. Give or take a few hours and it was almost exactly five years from the time that Mr. Truman ordered our forces into action in defense of South Korea and called upon the United Nations to make good its pledge of defense against aggression.
GAZA, June 8 -- The Gaza strip is an artificial political island created by the Palestine War, which still smoulders around its edge.
PARIS, June 25 -- Premier Edgar Faure declared today that the French market must be enlarged by merger with "the European market and the African market."
The leader of the East Harlem street gang that murdered a boy in a rival gang last Thursday was seized early yesterday.
LONG BEACH, L. I., June 25 -- Rufus Wilson, National Commander of Amvets, said tonight that an anti-segregation rider to the military reserve bill threatened national security.

The National Physical Laboratory at New Delhi is experimenting with solar cookers. The one that has been most widely tested on farms is of the paraboloid type. In other words, it resembles a big concave searchlight mirror. It focuses the rays of the sun on a cooking utensil.

Dr. Bostwick G. Ketchum, senior oceanographer at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute, Woods Hole, Mass., told the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in Boston, Mass., last week that "the quantity of atomic power that may be developed within our lifetime would produce enough radioactive waste products within a year to make a detectable change in the ocean, even though they were uniformly distributed from shore to shore."

WHEN Josephine Revington was born, her father Joseph was prepared to hate her. Her birth cost her mother's life, and Joseph, handsome, imperious and selfish, had expected a son. But as the young Josephine grew in the image of her striking father, a close bond was knit between them that became a threat to the girl's fulfillment.
Said a shrewd politician years ago: "A campaign isn't meant to change votes. Ninety per cent of the purpose is to convince the converted and inspire the convinced."
JERUSALEM, June 25 -- Indications are growing that Defense Minister David Ben-Gurion will become Premier again.

I feel that Mr. Pryor's article fails to get at the root of the problem. New stars are not the panacea for the American motion picture industry. The fact is that the industry has lost touch with the great American public.
The Eastern women's clay court tennis starts at Bayside, Queens, tomorrow.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 25 -- Four new federally built multi-purpose dams in the Pacific Northwest were dedicated this week.

PARIS, June 25 -- Capitalism in the United States is a thing of the past, according to an official document circulated in France by the United States Information Service: The document, an eighty-page illustrated booklet in French, is titled "The American Economy, Beyond Capitalism."

STANTON, Del., June 25 -- Clear Dawn, a filly whose only victory this year had been scored in an allowance race last April, came out of the mist today to $39,800 New Castle win the Stakes at Delaware Park.

WHEN his former subordinates arrest Leslie Rob. Hungary's Number Two Communist, he seemed at the peak of his career as a dedicated revolutionary. Born on an estate where the serfs worked eighty-four hours a week for a handful of food, he soon discovered the meaning of despair.
HONG KONG, June 25 -- Ho Chi Minh, President of Communist North Vietnam, arrived in Peiping today for talks with Communist China's leaders.
Fire Island Light, homing beacon for North Atlantic passenger liners and cargo ships, now gleams almost as brightly by day as it does by night.

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., June 25 -- A Down East yachtsman, R. Perry Collins, made the New York skippers look bad today. His power cruiser, Permar II from the Boston Yacht Club, won the Huckins Memorial Trophy race.
The changing Navy is developing new designations for its new and converted ships.
The women's United States open golf championship will start Thursday at the Wichita Country Club, Wichita, Kan.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., June 25 -- Harland Meistrell's Frederick v. d. Isar, from Great Neck, won the best-of-breed award in the Dachshund Association of Long Island specialty show on the J. S. Phipps estate today.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 25 Prof. Walter T. Stace and Prof. Robert M. Scoon of Princeton University's Department of Philosophy will be the only university professors retiring at the end of the academic year next Friday. Both are authors of notable works in their special fields.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., June 25 -- Eight Suffolk County Garden Clubs are cooperating with the Long Island Branch of the National Association of Gardeners in sponsoring the First Annual Eastern Long Island Flower Show on July 23, 24, as a benefit for the emergency fund for East ern Long Island hospitals. Cecil F. Carter of Southampton is chairman and Mrs. John C. Stark, honorary chairman.

AT a time when most of the more acclaimed historical novels are the product of a meticulous research that would do credit to a Ph. D., there must be many a devotee of cloak and dagger who feels a nostalgia for the days of Rafael Sabatini.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov of the Soviet Union expressed "regret" today for the shooting down of a United States Navy Neptune patrol plane Wednesday over the Bering Strait between Alaska and Siberia. He offered in the name of the Soviet Government to pay 50 per cent of the damages.

IT was midsummer. The family was driving home from a church supper and bazaar. No lamps lit the country road; no lights shone from the infrequent houses passed. Only the white pin points of stars above and the yellow glow of the car's head lamps on the road kept the family in touch with their surroundings.
Nation-wide department store sales in the week ended June 18 were 2 per cent higher than volume in the comparable week last year.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Efforts to amend the Reciprocal Trade Act to curb the President's powers in rejecting recommendations of the Tariff Commission are in formulation.

WAUWATOSA, Wis., June 25 (UP) -- Representative Henry S. Reuss today accused Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, of fostering a "reckless trend of giveaways" in connection with the nation's natural resources. The Wisconsin Democrat said the Interior Department was "subverting fifty years of good conservation practices for our soil, forests, national parks, water and wildlife."
Fifteen hundred residents of Tudor City have raised their voices against "unnecessary, unlawful, disturbing, nerve-wracking and inexcusable" noise.
PITTSBURGH, June 25 (AP) -- An auto smashed into the rear of an oil tank truck on the Pennsylvania Turnpike today and killed a New York family of five.

The municipally owned sub-way, elevated, bus and trolley lines go under new management this Friday. A new Transit Authority inherits the task of nursing New York's most persistent community headache -- a task that killed its predecessor two years after it was set up to take the subway system out of politics and put it on a business-like basis.

LONDON, June 25 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov has done the West a favor. His speech at San Francisco has reinforced the conviction of diplomats abroad that the coming conference at Geneva will be a severe test of Western diplomacy and unity, whatever efforts are made to keep the discussion to noncommittal exploration of the problems.
MILWAUKEE, June 25 -- Don Newcombe simply had too many weapons for the Braves today. As a result Charlie Grimm's Milwaukeeans bowed to the Dodgers, 5 to 3, before 39,153 disappointed fans.
The recent statement by the President on the need for careful selection of Vice Presidential nominees brings into focus some changes in the concept of the second highest office in the nation.
ST. LOUIS, June 25 -- "That guy has beaten us too often with home runs," Leo Durocher said this afternoon of Stan (The Man) Musial.

LACK of uniform traffic laws throughout the country is a serious hazard to national defense in case of a sudden emergency, according to Earl B. Smith, director of transportation and communications, Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense.
PARIS, June 24 -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem of Vietnam is interested in obtaining assurances that French forces will fight the Vietminh in case of hostilities between north and south.

Successively in medical meetings over the last year, reports have been given of the dramatic results obtained in the treatment of certain mental illness with two new drugs -- chlorpromazine and reserpine.

QUEEN BOADICEA'S tragic uprising against the Romans is the framework of this colorful novel of ancient Britain. Young Quintus Tullius, newly recruited from Rome to the Ninth Legion, witnesses the betrayal of Boadicea by the Roman procurator.

BOOKS on gardening for children are not common, and Mr. Kinney has done a straight-forward, workmanlike job of suggesting innumerable outlets for the common urge to "plant something and watch it grow." He covers simply yet adequately the planting and maintaining of a plot out of doors, suggests how to hold a show at the end of the season and to discover by-product activities, such as flower arranging.

A thinking person is taken aback to see mediocrity extolled and crowned with prestige in The New York Times Magazine. I refer to Robert Hawkins' article "On the Left Bank -- of Rome" (June 5), especially to the choice of illustrations.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- The week's events have showed that the Russians, from Mr. Molotov down, came to the tenth anniversary conference of the United Nations for two purposes. First, they did not mean to weaken their position in any essential respect.

THE trend to outdoor cooking has made the old - fashioned "packed picnic" an almost forgotten thing. That excursion, for which food and drink are assembled at home, might appropriately be revived next week-end.

The end of much of the secrecy surrounding Soviet atomic research appears in sight. Large-scale publication of Soviet research results is apparently scheduled for the near future to aid the Soviet bid for world leadership in peaceful applications of nuclear physics.

MORE and more psychiatrists are discovering that the mystery of the human psyche and faith in a personal God are not incompatible. On the contrary, they complement each other. Dr. W. Earl Biddle's book is one of several recent attempts to demonstrate just that.

THE fine fire of English pride glows all through this long and populous novel, the best Clemence Dane has written since "Broome Stages." Like that well-remembered story, it is bathed in the wealth and continuity of English tradition.

There is impressive evidence of the continued good health of our economy in the latest data on cost of living and manufacturing workers' earnings published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Last month the Consumer Price Index was unchanged from the previous month and almost 1 per cent below the corresponding figure a month ago.
JERUSALEM, June 25 -- Israel and Egypt have agreed to send representatives Tuesday to a conference on the Gaza border situation.
SHIHMEN, Formosa, June 15 -- The age-old Formosan problem of what to do about too little and too much water is approaching solution here with the planned construction of a great, multi-purpose dam.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- For former President Herbert Hoover the last public service is done.

MILWAUKEE, June 25 -- Right now the biggest man in baseball is Donald Newcombe. And that isn't because he weighs about 235 pounds and stands 6 feet 4 inches minus his No. 14 shoes. Even were he half the size, the accolade would fit him.

CHICAGO, June 25 (UP) -- The hitting of Eddie Miksis, Dee Fondy and Walker Cooper powered the Chicago Cubs to their second straight victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6 -- 4, today before a crowd of 12,181.
The bewildering thesis developed by William R. Mathews, in your June 19 issue, for successfully negotiating with Russia might mislead public opinion if a stand were not taken on this matter.
The city's plan to smooth the way for travelers at its main passenger liner piers from West Forty-fourth to West Fifty-seventh Streets will take effect at 8 A. M. tomorrow.

When the conditions are right a shout can be heard several hundred yards away. With a loudspeaker the distance can be increased to half a mile or so. This is not good enough for the Signal Corps of the United States Army. Accordingly it has commissioned the Stanford Research Institute, Menlo Park, Calif., to produce something better.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) The Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report disclosed today that President Eisenhower had ordered "early and vigorous" action to carry out most of the Hoover Commission recommendations for improving the Government.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- Rural electric cooperatives in New York, Pennsylvania and Ohio protested today plans to sell half the output of the St. Lawrence power project to big industries in the area.

Last week there appeared here the first of two pieces (of which this is the second) that owe their inspiration (or instigation) to the fact that on June 13 last the present bull market in stocks had reached its sixth birthday, thus surpassing in longevity the Great Bull Market of 1923-29 by approximately two months.

BENNINGTON, Vt., June 26 -Bennington College, an experiment in education for women, will start this fall a drive to raise $2,000,000 by 1957. In that year the college will celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Americans for Democratic Action charged the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare today with "fantastic fumbling" of the poliomyelitis vaccine program. It called on President Eisenhower to dismiss Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the period June 1 through June 23:

Unbelievable as it may seem to those who know her well, Helen Keller is 75 years old today. One of the great and most widely known citizens of the world, Miss Keller has at the same time many of those qualities of youthfulness, such as a sort of radiant innocence, that are most endearing.

This week the bill appropriating funds for the Mutual Security Program comes up for debate in the House of Representatives. Present indications are that some Representatives will make bitter attacks on the proposed continuation of economic and military aid to Yugoslavia and of economic aid to India.

The Military Reserve Plan is in jeopardy, the School Construction Program has been jeopardized, and possibly the Public Housing Programs will be jeopardized because riders containing anti-segregation clauses were attached to them.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 26 -- Betty Boseley's The Clown defeated Mr. and Mrs. Albert Merkel's Bellaire in a jump-off for the green jumper title at the Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show today.
Revised rates for physical damage insurance that will save New York motorists $3,500,000 will go into effect today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- Syria became yesterday the fiftieth nation to deposit ratification of the United Nations convention against genocide. Arrangements to do so here during the United Nations' tenth anniversary meeting were made by Dr. Raphael Lemkin of Yale University, who has campaigned for the convention for more than a quarter of a century.
Even though an "observation play" was involved, Al Lopez, the manager of the Indians, definitely will go through with his protest of the second game of yesterday's double-header with the Yankees.
The millennium would be a great bore to most Americans. What we like is evidence of movement in the right direction.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -The Government, for the last month or so, has been making it easier for individual Indians to sell their land.

ROME, June 26 -- Pope Pius XII said this evening he believed Italian workers were moving away from communism. He added that the day might not be far distant when it would be possible to "inaugurate a true return of the ranks of labor to the Christ Jesus, the only master and Saviour."
LONDON, June 26 -- With occasional pauses for breath and to absorb modest bouts of profit-taking, the London stock markets last week again were marked by boom conditions.
A one-ounce hearing aid the size of a book of matches was announced yesterday by the Sonotone Corporation, the manufacturer.
MOSCOW, June 26 (AP) -- Russia, with an overwhelming list of entrants, dominated the second session of a two-day, twelve-nation track and field meet today.

The American News Company has a new president and director. He is Henry Garfinkle, who headed a dissident stockholders' group at the annual meeting last March. Mr. Garfinkle is a veteran in the magazine distributing business and is a director both of the United Board and Carton Corporation and of the Greater Boston Finance Corporation.

The charter market was on the quiet side last week, but there was no lessening of the solid position of vessel owners that has marked past weeks. Consecutive voyages in coal continued to indicate an abundance of future business.
COLUMBIA, Mo., June 26 (AP) Missouri Republicans agreed today to let a special seven-member committee settle patronage disputes.
LONDON, June 26 -- Prime Minister Eden told Britain tonight that there was a prospect of "some measure of success" in international negotiation at the Geneva conference.

Man's unwillingness to seek redemption often leads God to employ shock therapy in wrenching him from his familiar securities, the Rev. Dr. John M. Krumm declared yesterday at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).
The Jewish Theological Seminary of America has established an Institute for Ethical Studies in the Atomic Age.

The Rev. Charles Howard Graf, rector of St. John's in the Village Protestant Episcopal Church, 218 West Eleventh Street, announced yesterday that he had severed all connection with the American Church Union.

Champion Barrage of Quality Hill, the 2-year-old boxer owned by Mr. and Mrs. Jouett Shouse of Washington, became best in show yesterday in the sixteenth event of the Staten Island Kennel Club. There were 699 dogs, a hundred more than a year ago, in the Cromwell Center Pier at Tompkinsville.
LONDON, June 21 -- A male ring - necked duck, a species found only in Canada and the United States, has landed in Britain, apparently after a 3,000-mile journey across the Atlantic.
Jack Fleck, the new United States open golf champion, arrived in New York yesterday with one complaint. "I'd like to get back to golf," he said after landing at La Guardia Airport.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A project long cherished by the American Bar Association will get a hearing before Congress this week. But the outlook for favorable action is not good.
AMSTERDAM, June 26 -- The Netherlands Government has submitted to the lower chamber a revised bill to raise house rents and lower taxes.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- The sixty members of the United Nations ended their tenth anniversary celebration here this afternoon with a reaffirmation of their determination to settle their disputes by peaceful means.

MOSCOW, June 26 -- Zhumabai Shayakhmetov, a member of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party and former party chief in the Union's second largest republic, Kazakhstan, has been ousted from another party job.
The Committee for Modern Courts, a lay organization, called yesterday for public support of a proposal to overhaul and simplify the state's court system.

Mrs. Nancy Phillips of Bedminster, Pa., set a meet record for the 80-meter hurdles during her trial heat in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union Senior Women's track and field championships at Victory Field, Woodhaven, Queens, yesterday.
The "Latin American Fiesta," which was rained out on Saturday night, was presented last night at Lewisohn Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- The National Planning Association said today that technical aid programs strengthened the resistance of underdeveloped nations to communism and provided unusually large returns at small cost.
AMONG the gifts that will come today under Helen Keller's sensitive fingers as she marks her seventy-fifth birthday will be a lovely volume in dark red morocco.

Having stubbed its toe with "The King and the Duke," the newly reorganized Circle in the Square hopes its second offering, "La Ronde," will prove more durable. The Eric Bentley adaptation of Arthur Schnitzler's comedy will be evaluated at 8 o'clock tonight in the group's headquarters, 5 Sheridan Square.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- The candles burned today on the United Nations' tenth anniversary birthday cake. They burned in the form of spotlights and the lights of television cameras directed at the stage of the Memorial Opera House.
A large congregation, many of Italian descent, filled the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Pompei, at Carmine and Bleecker Streets, yesterday to honor the memory of an Italian Bishop.
Four teen-agers were under arrest last night in the killing of a 16-year-old boy in the Stephen Foster Housing Project.

Newspaper space is being bought by national advertisers at a record rate of $650,000,000 a year, it is reported by Harold S. Barnes, director of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association. At the same time, he finds, retail newspaper advertising also is setting new highs.
BALBOA, C. Z., June 26 -- The Panama Canal Company is offering for sale the veteran 250-ton floating crane Ajax.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- Harold E. Stassen, special assistant to the President on disarmament, said tonight that international disarmament depended on an inspection system "you can trust."

MADISON, Wis., June 26 (UP) -- Patty Berg, a pro golfer for fifteen years, won a fifth women's Western Open championship today. She registered a par 73 to gain the title by two strokes with a seventy-two-hole total of 292, even par for the distance.
Recommendations for improving the administration of justice for youthful violators and for attacking the narcotics traffic highlight a report made public today by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -Congress is faced with the problem of keeping alive at least seven important laws. The laws will expire next Thursday or Friday.

One of the city's last remaining Colonial homes met its end yesterday morning. Fire ravaged the 200-year-old, three-story house at 982 Anderson Avenue in the Bronx. It reputedly was used as a hunting lodge by Aaron Burr.

Violent temblors of emotion about the merits of city life vs. the allurements of the country have been recorded on our Bronx seismograph in recent weeks. Country dwellers never have been more disdainful of the hordes "suffering" in town.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Senator John F. Kennedy proposed today establishment of "a bipartisan, blue-ribbon commission" to review the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 26 -- The world economic picture looks increasingly bright, according to the United Nations. International trade in the last year showed a 7 per cent increase over the 1953 record. Countries long bothered by dollar shortages made some gains.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, June 26 -- A meeting of Egyptian and Israeli representatives of the mixed armistice commission scheduled for Tuesday is one in a long series of attempts to stop trouble along the Gaza strip.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- "The new Molotov" was explained today by Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo as the offspring of a "breathing spell that they [the Russians] need to consolidate themselves."

HONG KONG, June 26 -- The Chinese Communist Premier, Chou En-lai, and the Vietminh leader, Ho Chi Minh, teamed up tonight in accusing the United States of trying to "sabotage" the Geneva agreements on Indo-china.
Both employers and the unemployed benefit under an insurance program announced by the state yesterday.
OSLO, Norway, June 26 -- Queen Elizabeth II and her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, left Oslo in the Royal yacht Britannia tonight after a three-day state visit to Norway.
A discouraging picture of the city's traffic future was painted yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations will be in Geneva during the meeting of the Big Four heads of government next month, it was disclosed here today.
Four new films are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
A ground-gaining split was the Yankees' reward for beating the Cleveland Indians, 2 -- 0, in the second game of the double-header before 66,511 payng customers at the Stadium yesterday.

The Port of New York Authority said yesterday it would ask the Interstate Commerce Commission to end "a rate disadvantage ranging up to 16 cents a hundred pounds" on commodities moving by truck between the port area and Middle Atlantic points.

NEWARK, June 26 (AP) -- A study commission recommended tonight that the Federal Government turn over to the states some of its tax sources along with the entire financial responsibility for certain welfare and educational functions.
From Borneo to Basutoland, from the Arctic to the Antarctic the Cats are on the prowl.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -Mickey McDermott put an end to the Washington Senators' nine-game losing streak today. The Senators' southpaw pitched a 12-4 victory in the second game of a double-header after the Detroit Tigers had won the opener, 6 -- 4, in ten innings.
ROME, June 26 -- President Giovanni Gronchi asked Prof. Antonio Segni tonight to explore the possibilities of setting up a left-of-center government.

U Nu, Burma's Prime Minister, is a guest in the United States. We are delighted to have him here. He has said that all he wants to do is to look and listen. We hope that he will also talk because we want to hear what he has to say.

PARIS, June 26 -- Reports that the United States was considering a European security pact led observers here today to remark that the Western powers all seemed to be moving toward an accepted and consolidated balance of power such as the French had suggested.
FARMVILLE, Va., June 26 -- Prince Edward County is girding for a fight on the question whether white and Negro children shall attend the same schools.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 26 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold acknowledged defeat today in his attempt to arrange a high-level discussion between Israel and Egypt on proposals to lessen friction along the Gaza strip.

AVIGNON, France, June 26 -- Disarmament is now receiving earnest attention in the world's principal capitals. Mr. Stassen is seeking to prepare a draft plan that may be submitted by President Eisenhower at Geneva. British experts are pondering the question. The French, who sought to establish a world police force during the Nineteen Thirties, are reviewing old projects.
A study of the law and practice that govern the employment of teachers in institutions of higher education in this country will be undertaken by Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that Soviet Russia was able to put supersonic jet aircraft into mass production faster than the United States.

A five-story building containing eight stores and thirty-eight apartments at 1946-48 Prospect Avenue, corner of Tremont Avenue, in the Bronx, was sold by J. J. Boneparth to Enkells-Rakoff Co., operators, for cash over mortgages amounting to $155,000. The property fronts seventy - two feet on Tremont Avenue.
Properties in upper Manhattan formed the bulk of realty in the borough figuring in deals reported over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, has asked Charles E. Bohlen, Ambassador to Russia, to remain in Washington for consultations until the Big Four meeting at Geneva rather than return to Moscow.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Besides giving America Steve Allen, "Peter Pan," and the light, fantastic cigarette pack, television has finally cleared the track to the politician's millennium.
ST. LOUIS, June 26 -- When the Giants winged homeward tonight they bore not even a faint resemblance to young Lochinvar riding out of the West.

The boards of the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo and the Bank of Clarence, N. Y., have ratified terms of a merger. The plan will be submitted for approval to stockholders and State Superintendent of Banks George A. Mooney.
FLORENCE, Italy, June 26 -- Bernard Berenson, recognized as probably the world's greatest authority on Italian Renaissance art, celebrated his ninetieth birthday today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- Following are the text of Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens' summation of the spirit of the United Nations' tenth anniversary meeting and excerpts from closing addresses by Lester B. Pearson of Canada, Dr. Luis Padilla-Nervo of Mexico, Nasrollah Entezam of Iran, Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines and Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium:

The Rev. Joseph D. Huntley said yesterday that he was disturbed over "the rigid thought patterns" evident in twentieth-century man. He believed there were more important causes than "a temperance crusade, or anti-bingo legislation, or a campaign against street walkers."

PITTSBURGH, June 26 -- Inland Steel Company offered the United Steelworkers, C. I. O., today an average 10 1/2-cent hourly wage increase. The union quickly rejected it. The offer by Inland roughly equaled the one made earlier by United States Steel Corporation, the industry's traditional pacesetter in wage and contract talks.
KIMBERLEY, South Africa, June 14 -- De Beers Consolidated Mines has evolved a new and cheaper method of mining diamonds.
Harris J. Klein, chronic dissenter of the outgoing Transit Authority, issued a minority report yesterday covering his two-year service. The report said:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 26 -- "Gertrude Lawrence As Mrs. A." the book of reminiscences about the late stage star written by her husband, Richard Aldrich, will be made into a motion picture by Paramount.
HELEN KELLER was the subject of an inspiring tribute yesterday in an hour-long television program on the eve of her seventy-fifth birthday.

PARIS, June 26 (AP) -- Phil Drake of France, winner of Britain's Epsom Derby, won the $57,000 Grand Prix de Paris -- Europe's richest race for 3-year-old colts and fillies -- in record time today. Bewitched was second and Beau Prince II third.
Alcoholism must he treated as sickness, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh declared yesterday. He called it a public health as well as a penal problem.
BEMENT, Ill., June 26 (AP) -Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader, suggested today that a series of debates in the LincolnDouglas manner, might be a good thing for the 1956 Presidential campaign.

PARIS, June 26 -- French farmers fear an overproduction of wheat. The forecast of the Ministry of Agriculture on June 1 was that the 1955 harvest would amount to nearly 4,700,000 tons (94 million quintals). Last year the forecast was for 4,200,000 tons but 5,200,000 tons were harvested.

Helen Keller, the blind and deaf teacher and author whose 75th birthday is celebrated today, has a new book on Doubleday's list. She is also the subject of a biography by her friend of many years, Van Wyck Brooks.
MILWAUKEE, June 26 -- The pennant road became unexpectedly bumpy today just as the Dodgers were bringing their second Western tour of the year to a close.

Mexico's economy, which last year rebounded from its mild 1953 recession, is continuing to move ahead this year, the Chase Manhattan Bank reported in its Latin-American Business Highlights released over the weekend.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial translation of the text of the memorandum on the Alaskan plane incident handed to Secretary of State Dulles by Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov in San Francisco yesterday:

The New York Times has purchased from the New York Central System a piece of property west of West End Avenue that extends from just below Sixtysecond Street to Sixty-fifth Street. The price was not disclosed.

SEYMOUR TROY, custom shoemaker, insists the human race is entitled to better fitting footwear. Females of the species who have worn too-tight pumps will agree. Shoes that fit comfortably can be as hard to find as uranium.

A plea to Americans to "rise above" their ideology at the forthcoming Big Four conference was made in a sermon yesterday by the Rev. John Walter Houck. He is pastor of Pilgrim Congregational Church at Grand Concourse and 175th Street, the Bronx.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 26 -- Women can do something now about the education problems of the future, Dr. Rosemary Park said at a recent meeting here. She is president of Connecticut College for Women.
Motorists took advantage of the sunshine and warmth yesterday to flock to countryside and shore resorts. Traffic was moderate to heavy throughout the day, reaching its peak in the evening.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 26 -- Argentine exiles here believe the Navy has not submitted to the Government of President Juan D. Peron. They say it is holding out for a settlement that will achieve some of the aims of the June 16 revolt.

LONDON, June 26 -- Cricket is a ritual and only secondarily a sport. This is the first lesson an American must learn about the game that is as much a part of English life as the weather and that probably has had an equal share in shaping national character.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 26 -- A good part of the fleet competing in the thirteenth regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island spent a long afternoon trying to cope with the indecision of the wind today.

British sterling capped an irregularly lower trend for most of last week by a precipitate decline on Friday. Heavy selling on a market virtually barren of buying orders caused a plunge to $2.78-7/32, lowest since late February, with the day's close of $2.78-13/32, a loss of 9/16 cent from the preceding week.

ALBANY, June 26 (AP) -- Governor Harriman said today that a Republican - dominated legislative committee had taken no steps to investigate year - old charges that some New York children's camps were operated by Communists or Red-front organizations.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The House is expected to act this week on the Administration's foreign-aid request. It faces another battle over the military Reserve program.

PARMACHENEE LAKE, Me., June 26 -- Two wily land-locked salmon and five good-sized trout were hooked today on the lures of President Eisenhower. He spent a quiet relaxing Sunday in a fisherman's paradise.
BONN, Germany, June 26 -- A new chapter in post-war German history will open tomorrow with the start of the arms debate in the Bundestag.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 26 -- Nineteen party lists will contest the third national parliamentary elections here on July 16.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 26 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that complete integration of the public schools was the country's most important civil rights objective.

The current controversy between Abraham D. Beame and Luther Gulick over the proper place in the organization structure of the city government of the "management improvement" function emphasizes a serious problem in public administration.

MARINARA, the sauce Italians lavish on all kinds of seafood, is a simple concoction of tomatoes, garlic, olive oil and herbs. It can be such an exquisite blend of flavors that every remaining drop must be cleaned from the plate with a piece of bread.

Word came the other day from South Africa that one of man's evolutionary forebears, Australopithecus prometheus, has been duly accredited as a toolmaker. The existence of Prometheus, who lived anywhere from 100,000 to 1,000,000 years ago, has been known for thirty years.

The series of articles on "Our Changing City" takes Times readers today into Manhattan's midtown. This is the New York of Times Square, of the theatres, of the great hotels, of the fine Fifth Avenue stores, of the mammoth railroad stations, of revered institutions, of the United Nations, of our tallest buildings, of our worst traffic jams.
Job-hunting is essentially a problem in merchandising. Yet, in this age of high-pressure selling, nothing is sold as archaically as a person's services.
Twenty-five years from the golden twenties to nuclear fifties have sculptured more deeply the man-made cordillera that is Manhattan's midtown.
MOSCOW, June 26 -- A Soviet acknowledgment of the desire of the American people for peace was published here today.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 26 (UP) -- Cary Middlecoff of Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., carded a 63 today to win the Western open golf championship with a 272, ten strokes under par
Fifteen tons of dirt fell on four boys in a play tunnel in Queens last night, snuffing out the lives of two and injuring the others.
BOSTON, June 26 (UP) -- The Boston Red Sox. snapped the Chicago White Sox's five-game winning streak by sweeping a doubleheader, 5 -- 2 and 8 -- 2, before 32,362 fans today.

ONE year and one week ago Daphne Du Maurier's historical novel about her great-great-grandmother, "Mary Anne," was published and many readers enjoyed their first close-up inspection of the scandalous habits of the Regency bucks and the fair and frail ladies with whom they whiled away their abundant leisure.

Cotton futures prices moved in a relatively narrow price range last week. At the end of trading on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ranged from 55 cents a bale lower to 95 cents higher from the close of the previous week. Only the three most distant months finished in the plus column.
The Columbia Broadcasting System has arranged for live television coverage of the dedication ceremonies of the new United States Air Force Academy on Monday, July 11.
BALTIMORE, June 26 (AP) -- Connie Mack today watched the Kansas City Athletics sweep a double-header from the last-place Baltimore Orioles, 1 -- 0 and 5 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- The national banks' assets totaled $108,000,000,000 on April 11, down 6.8 per cent from those of last December, the Controller of the Currency, Ray M. Gidney, reported today.

PARMACHENEE LAKE, Me., June 26 -- President Eisenhower will confer with Secretary of State Dulles on the shooting down of an American plane by Soviet fighters, directly after the President gets back to Washington late tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today he was gratified, although not satisfied, by the Soviet expression of regret over the shooting down of a Navy Neptune plane.
PITTSBURGH, June 26 -- Even though the steel industry has been straining its productive capacity, most mills have been getting further behind on delivery promises.

CHICAGO, June 26 (UP) -- Bob Rush hurled the Chicago Cubs to a 2-1 victory over Pittsburgh today. The Pirates won the opener, 5 -- 4. The split kept the Cubs in second place, a half game ahead of Milwaukee.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- West Coast shipowners called today for defeat of an alleged move by foreign shipping interests aimed at "scuttling a large part of the American merchant marine."

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Contrary to the usual price trend preceding the main harvest of winter wheat, the market has been comparatively strong, moving up on mill buying and commission support. Hedge pressure has been unusually light and growers appear to be dictating the market course more than they have in previous years.
Our attention has been called to inequities in the proposed beginning salaries for registered professional nurses in the New York City Department of Hospitals.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The creation of a fourth branch of the Defense Department to supply the Army, Navy and Air Force was recommended today by the Hoover Commission. It estimated possible savings, through improved operations, at $2,000,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -Wheat farmers have voted to continue present rigid controls on their crop next year rather than gamble on the possibility that Congress might enact a satisfactory substitute program.
The Urban League of Greater New York reported yesterday that "the slow but steady progress toward racial equality in industry was set back" last year when "New York felt the pinch of recession."

Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., delegate of the United States, suggested at San Francisco that all the information at present available on the effects of atomic radiation be collected and disseminated. The suggestion deserves the serious consideration of the General Assembly of the United Nations.

RODIN'S "Thinker" had nothing on Charles Dillon Stengel before the Yankees' double-header at the Stadium yesterday. Ol' Case was discovered in his office an hour before high noon, deep in concentration. Unlike the statue, though, there was nothing mute or motionless about the Bombers' pilot.

The Reader's Digest announced yesterday a new set-up for supervising advertising for its various editions. Reader's Digest International Editions, Inc., originally formed as an advertising and accounting organization for the foreign editions, which carried advertising from the outset, will be dissolved as a corporate entity as of July 1.

The Reader's Digest announced yesterday a new set-up for supervising advertising for its various editions. Reader's Digest International Editions, Inc., originally formed as an advertising and accounting organization for the foreign editions, which carried advertising from the outset, will be dissolved as a corporate entity as of July 1.
The Atlas Corporation and associates have agreed to buy about $1,254,375 of the treasury stock of the North Australian Uranium Corporation, Floyd B. Odlum, Atlas president, announced yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, June 27 -- A revised strike strategy intended to put a competitive "squeeze" on major steel producers was being considered by union leaders here tonight.
Four boxing managers were suspended indefinitely yesterday by the New York State Athletic Commission for refusing to answer questions about the New York chapter of the International Boxing Guild.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -- A defense-conscious House of Representatives approved today a $2,369,000,000 military basebuilding program. It also quickly passed a $267,709,000 atomic construction bill
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of a communique on the four-power ambassadors' meeting here, as broadcast today by the Belgrade radio:
" WIDE, Wide World," seen last night over Channel 4, showed the scope of television as it never has been seen before. It was superb entertainment.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, today attacked a pending bill to extend Government purchases of certain minerals as a $750,000,000 "raid on the Treasry."

Toots Shor's "Crumbums" and the Twenty-One Club "Gentlemen" clowned through thirty minutes and an inning and a half of a softball "contest" before the Mayor's Trophy game at the Stadium last night. The "Crumbums" won, 1 -- 0, on an unearned tally fashioned by Carl Hubbell and Joe DiMaggio.

GENEVA, June 27 -- For its seventy-fifth anniversary conference the ORT World Union is concentrating on the needs for vocational education among Jews in four regions. The areas are Israel, North Africa, Iran and Europe.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 27 -During the United Nations anniversary meeting here last week the Soviet Union suggested two alternative "package" deals for a solution of the East-West deadlock over the admission of new members to the organization.

EXPERTS on interior design are firm in insisting that room decoration begin with the floor. But most homemakers, who have to match rugs to other furnishings rather than the other way around, may find what they are looking for in recently introduced patterns.

Informed that "an airplane courier" was standing by to carry vital papers to Washington to beat a June 30 deadline, the Board of Estimate yesterday hastily and unanimously approved a new housing project for Queens.
With an entry of thirty-one players the women's Eastern clay court tennis championship started yesterday at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.
The head of a big oil company warned yesterday that advances in atomic energy and jet and turbo-prop engines have not canceled the need to find and develop new petroleum reserves for many years.

BELGRADE, June 27 -- Marshal Tito is being described as "Putnik's best customer," a reference to the Yugoslav travel agency. The announcement of his intended visit to Moscow recalled his past experiences in the Soviet Union as well as the many trips he has made lately and is planning to faraway places.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- In its preparations for the Geneva conference of the Big Four next month, the United States is looking for a formula that will do two things:
An investigator for the State Liquor Authority who was being questioned by the New York County District Attorney's office has offered his resignation.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Control of the Fox De Luxe Brewing Company of Chicago and the Kio Oil and Development Company, Fox' associated oil producing company, has been acquired by interests headed by Arthur J. Feicht, Fox announced today.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 27 -- Two strikes ended today and negotiations resumed in a third in this area.

Virtually the entire shipping industry joined yesterday in a protest to the House of Representatives against the amendment to the Mutual Security Act that would nullify the requirement that half of all foreign-aid cargoes be carried by American-flag ships.

The widespread building boom since the end of the war has put a new twist on the man-bites-dog story. It is no longer news when a golf course is taken for home sites. However, it is of considerable interest when land in a rapidly developing area is converted into a golf course.
Pan American World Airways, which strung the first airline route across the Atlantic in the spring of 1939, will make its 50,000th ocean crossing tonight.

Joseph (Joe Louis) Johnson, 16 years old, of 70 West 115th Street, accused of slaying another 16-year-old youth last Saturday night, was held without bail yesterday in Youth Term of Felony Court for a hearing July 11.
HAVANA, June 27 -- A court decree today ordered the arrest of former President Carlos Prio Socarras on a charge of conspiring against the Batista Government. Senor Prio Socarras is in exile in Miami.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- The Delaware River Port Authority complained to the Interstate Commerce Commission today that truck operators were charging "unjust and unreasonable" rates for hauling waterborne cargo to and from Philadelphia piers.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The Federal Government opened its case here this morning in the United States Tax Court against Joe Louis, the former heavyweight world boxing champion, to get from him $460,000 in income taxes for the period 1946-49.
LONDON, June 27 -- The recession in industrial shares noticeable toward the end of last week continued today, although few issues closed above their lowest.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board and the Securities and Exchange Commission today endorsed objectives of a bill by Senator J. William Fulbright to extend Federal policing to unlisted securities.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today the vote of wheat farmers for continued Federal controls was recognition that the Administration's route toward agricultural adjustment was "the best route."
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 27 -- An effort is being made to sow the seeds of communism among South Africa's 10,000,000 Negroes.
Market yields on United States Government securities stiffened yesterday on the announcement that the Treasury had decided to increase the sale of discount bills.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- After the three-day Operation Alert, in the course of which a hypothetical H-bomb attack on the United States wrecked sixty-one cities, killed 8,200,000 people and injured 6,550, 000 more, the President climaxed the imaginary calamity by "invoking" martial law throughout the nation. Since it is not in human nature

ROME, June 27 -- Mayor Wagner had an audience with Pope Pius XII today and received his blessing "for the entire people of New York City." The Mayor said after ward that the subject of juvenile delinquency had been brought up by the Pontiff during the twenty-minute audience.
Michael H. Prendergast of Rockland County appeared last night to be the leading candidate to succeed Richard H. Balch of Utica as Democratic state chairman.
EASTON, Conn., June 27 -With four long-time friends Helen Keller quietly observed her seventy-fifth birthday here today.

An 85-year-old New Jersey hardware store owner who sells little brass washers will stand trial tomorrow in Lower Manhattan Court on charges of trying to use the washers in a turnstile of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 117 pints of blood on Friday from employes of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation at Federal Hall, Wall and Nassau Streets. The day's total was 384 pints.
A spokesman for the American Church Union declared yesterday there had been "serious errors" in criticism of its program for raising funds with a puzzle contest.
PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP) -- Brahms and umbrellas were featured tonight as Rudolf Serkin, the pianist, performed before several thousand hardy concertgoers at Robin Hood Dell.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., June 27 (AP) -- Four National Guardsmen from Waterbury, Conn., were killed last night when their automobile crashed into a tree.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -The Senatte Banking Committee approved today a two-year extension of the Defense Production Act.
The Society of St. Tammany, enfeebled and living on its memories, held its 166th annual "big meeting" last night.

With a sense of gratitude we noted the recent arrival in the United States of the first of some 2,000 Arab refugees from the Near East who are to be settled here under the President's Refugee and Relief Act.

Christopher T. Chenery's Manotick won the $30,450 Gazelle at Aqueduct yesterday. Few in the crowd of 22,019 expected the gray daughter of Double Jay to be anywhere at all at the finish of the mile-and-a-sixteenth fixture. As a consequence, she paid $93.70 at the win betting windows.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 27 -- The latest step in audience participation in a motion picture -- literally a movie in the round -- was demonstrated today at the Walt Disney Studio. In Circarama, as the development is called, the audience is surrounded completely by a screen on which a continuous image is focused.
Thomas K. Finletter, former Secretary of the Air Force, declared yesterday that total disarmament, enforced by a peacekeeping international army, was the only way to obtain world peace.
Negro stagehands will be admitted for the first time to full membership in Theatrical Protective Union No. 1, International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, A. F. L.

TORRINGTON, Wyo., June 27 (AP) -- The upper North Platte River went on its worst flood rampage in twenty-five years today in the wake of tornadoes and cloudbursts that cut a swath of destruction across southeastern Wyoming last night.
