The Continental - Diamond Fibre Company announced yesterday the election of John H. Lux as president and a director, effective with the change of the corporate name to Haveg Industries, Inc., on Friday. Timothy F. Murphy, president of the company, will continue as a director and become vice chairman of the board on the same day.

The tenth anniversary celebration of the United Nations has come to an end with what might be called the "San Francisco Declaration," in which Chairman van Kleffens summarized the statements made on behalf of the sixty nations represented. The declaration concedes that continued differences between nations raise difficulties and dangers.
A subway conductor who got twenty-two parking summonses over twenty-two days spent an unhappy time yesterday in Vehicle Accident Court.

PIERRE MONTEUX, who had conducted the Concertgebouw Orchestra in Amsterdam on Sunday night, opened his Lewisohn Stadium engagement last night with the players of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra duly assembled.
The humble house dress bids fair to become a Cinderella of sorts in women's apparel shops next fall.

In a battle-scarred hut at a point called Kilometer 95 on the road from Gaza into Israel representatives of the Egyptian and Israeli Governments will meet today under United Nations auspices to try to put an end to the bloodshed and murder that have kept their border in a state of turmoil.
ROME, June 27 (AP) -- Jan Peerce, a leading tenor of the Metropolitan Opera, presented a rare record collection of church music to Pope Pius XII today.

ARMED with guide books, pocket dictionaries and an appetite for adventure, more Americans will be going to Europe this summer than ever before. For those who will also have an appetite for good food, some advice on restaurants has been graciously volunteered by two travelers recently returned from the continent and the British Isles.

One of the most radioactive pieces of material produced for peacetime use has been installed at a laboratory at Linden, N. J. The material -- cobalt metal in the form of a pipe thirteen inches long and two inches in diameter -- will be used by the Esso Research and Engineering Company, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), in petroleum research.
The Eighth Annual General Meeting of Gill Duffus Ltd. will be held on July 14 in London, England.
Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday increased earnings for the month of May and for the five months ended May 31.
Driver responses to traffic hazards were tested in Times Square yesterday.
ROME, June 27 (AP) -- Antonio Segni won the important approval of his own Christian Democrats today in his quest for a government to lead Italy out of another political crisis.

The New York Times has often given generously of its news column space to the serious local topic of out-door litter. Public education could help tremendously and I am an optimist. As a native-born. New Yorker who has not joined the flight to the suburbs, may I add my observations and suggestions?

PARIS, June 27--The three leading Western foreign ministers will meet with their counterparts on the North Atlantic Council here on July 16. The ministers will discuss the Geneva conference of Western and Soviet heads of governments, which will begin two days later.

Today's new film is "Not As a Stranger." It will have a kleiglighted premiere this evening at the Capitol. The drama, based on the novel by Morton Thompson, stars Olivia de Havilland, Robert Mitchum, Frank Sinatra, Gloria Grahame, Broderick Crawford and Charles Bickford.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., June 27 -- Announcement was made here today of the election of Dr. Walter H. Zinn as first president of the American Nuclear Society. The society is composed of scientists and engineers engaged in full-time work on atomic energy.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 27 -- Two charges against an elderly baby sitter whose driverless automobile rolled onto the New York Central Railroad tracks last Friday in near-by Eastchester were dismissed there today.

Shareholders of the Briggs Manufacturing Company at the annual meeting yesterday in Detroit approved expenditure of $3,130,411 for its common stock from the estates of Mr. and Mrs. W. O. Briggs and from James C. Briggs, as well as from five trusts created by W. O. Briggs in his lifetime.
Mary Martin, Noel Coward, Bing Crosby and other performers will appear on the monthly ninety-minute "Ford Star Jubilee'' programs that begin Sept. 24 on Columbia Broadcasting System television.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Public Housing Administration announced plans today for the sale by nineteen local authorities of $121,465,000 in housing bonds. Of this total $11,735,000 will be offered by the Housing Authority in New York City.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -- An attorney for four Puerto Ricans who shot five members of the House of Representatives last year today demanded a new trial for his clients.

New Yorkers, it seems, just will not "go" for an exhibition contest, regardless of how worthwhile the cause. Only 19,193 fans turned out to see the Yankees beat the Giants, 4 -- 1, at the Stadium in the tenth annual charity game for the Mayor's Trophy last night.
SCOTTSBLUFF, Neb., June 27 (AP)--Two persons were killed and a third was believed killed when a tornado slashed through the Hillerege Housing Development northeast of here late today.
When the soldiers cast lots for Jesus' garments what did they use for dice? Who were the four horsemen? Where did the thorns come from for the crown they put on Christ's head ?

Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson won his return bout with Jimmy Slade at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The Far Rockaway, Queens, heavyweight swarmed all over Slade the last eight of the ten-rounder to gain a unanimous decision.
A local ordinance banning airplane flights over Cedarhurst, L. I., at altitudes of less than 1,000 feet was ruled unconstitutional yesterday.
Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education, got a first-hand picture of the school system's seamy side yesterday.
A late rally in steel issues and sustained demand for selected oils put the stock market averages in the plus column yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -Senate Republican leader William F. Knowland demanded today that Communists in northern Laos comply with the Geneva agreement or be "forthwith" cited before the United Nations as a threat to world peace.

A police captain, cited for meritorious service several times during his twenty-nine years on the force, was suspended last night as "unfit for duty." He had been found by Deputy Chief Police Surgeon Joseph L. Mc-Goldrick suffering from "over-indulgence in some intoxicating agent or agents."

HAIFA, Israel, June 26 -- A laden cargo net swinging aboard a freighter in this port epitomizes historical change in Palestine. For thousands of years the land was a highway between the Euphrates and the Nile. Now it is the terminus of roads stretching across the seas.
IRV NOREN, who is good at arithmetic, was reciting facts and figures as he awaited his turn in the batting cage before Sunday's double-header with the Indians.

VIENNA, June 27 -- "There is no alternative to coexistence but war," Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, said today. Mr. Nehru came to Vienna yesterday after visits to Prague, Warsaw and Moscow and will go to Belgrade Thursday.

MacKinlay Kantor has turned over to World Publishing Company the manuscript of his 320,000 word novel, entitled "Andersonville." It is a story about the "infamous" prison that the Confederacy had planned and built to hold 10,000 Union soldiers and that at one time contained 36,000 men on its twenty-three acres.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 27 -Rapid progress was reported here today in the National Army's drive against the last stronghold of rebel Hoa Hao troops in West Cochin China.

Talks between the Yugoslav Foreign Office and the Ambassadors of the United States, Great Britain and France in Belgrade ended yesterday with the issuance of a communique. Shortly thereafter Marshal Tito announced that he has accepted a Soviet invitation to visit Moscow, a natural sequel to the recent Belgrade visit of the Khrushchev delegation.

One day in June sixteen years ago, when the World's Fair in Flushing Meadows was in full swing and ominous rumblings of war were sounding across the ocean, a big Pan American clipper rose into the air from Port Washington and headed seaward. It was the first commercial flight across the North Atlantic.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- (UP) -- Representative Victor Wickersham today proposed a total test evacuation of Washington, even though he said this was sure to involve accidents and even deaths.

Each summer many vacationers go through a familiar mental process and arrive at a familiar decision. It all starts because summer speaks of time off and time off is synonymous with pleasant pursuits, one of which is reading.

MADRID, June 27 -- The Motion Picture Association of America has dropped negotiations with Spanish officials for renewal of an agreement on the importation of United States films to Spain. Film distributors here called the demands of the Spanish Government "so onerous as to be unacceptable."

PALO ALTO, Calif., June 27 -- War missiles that will hurtle from continent to continent across oceans at speeds twenty times that of sound were viewed as possible today at the triennial inspection of the Ames Aeronautical Laboratory.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 -- Two Americans, an Australian and a Dane reached the men's semi-finals of the All-England tennis championships today.

Back from producing the Spanish-language version of "The Teahouse of the August Moon" in Mexico City, in conjunction with Jean Dalryrnple, Rita Allen is thinking now in terms of Broadway activity. She has acquired "The Feathered Fauna" for early fall presentation.
LONDON, June 27 -- Britain protested to Greece today against Greek broadcasts inciting the inhabitants of Cyprus to revolt.
MOSCOW, June 26 -- A demand for the extension of "creative boundaries" of Soviet art has touched off a public controversy in Moscow.

LOS ANGELES, June 27 -- The basic question of the times was said here tonight to be whether to believe that man has the power to order his life and determine his future. Such was the theme put before the biennial convention of the American Association of University Women.

An example of fragmentized jurisdiction is cited in the subcommittee report to the Temporary Commission on the Courts that vividly illustrates the need for reduction in the number of types of courts in New York State. This example was drawn from a recent study by the Community Service Society, and showed the complexities of multiple court jurisdiction in dealing with family problems.

Directors of United Funds, Inc., yesterday authorized a 100 per cent stock split on the United Income Fund shares, one of its funds. For each share outstanding, currently amounting to more than 6,500,000, there will be issued a like number to holders of record Aug. 4.

IT is not at all unlikely that there still are those who will find "La Ronde" indigestible. This should not be considered unusual. In fact, it would be socially and medically normal. It has been giving people trouble ever since Arthur Schnitzler wrote it under the title of "Reigen" at the turn of the century and had it published privately because it was considered so unsavory.

Luben Vichey, 42-year-old Metropolitan Opera basso, has purchased the National Concert and Artists Corporation. It is one of the two largest concert bureaus in the United States. The purchase included Civic Concert Service, Inc.

Saul Panish has sold the six-story apartment house accommodating forty-four families at 94-16 Thirty-fourth Road in Jackson Heights, Queens, to a client of Murray Zelig, attorney. Louis Landsman was the broker and Joseph Goldfein was attorney for the buyer.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 27 -- Richard McNeill of the Garden City Country Club and his son Dick won the Father and Son Golf Association tournament today. In the thirty-sixth annual event conducted by the organization at the Garden City Golf Club, the McNeills had a winning gross score of 73.
MONTREAL, June 27 (Canadian Press) -- A temporary 40 per cent reduction in freight rates on shipments to the Mediterranean area was announced today by the Canada-Mediterranean Freight Conference.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Tuesday, June 28 -- Communist MIG-15 jets yesterday shot down a Chinese Nationalist jet trainer and riddled a flying boat chartered by the United States Army. The flying boat was taking an American doctor on a mercy mission to the Matsu islands.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 27 (UP) -- The Indonesian Army defied the authority of President Sukarno today by refusing to accept Maj. Gen. Bambang Utoyo as Army Chief of Staff. All top army officers boycotted the installation ceremonies for General Utoyo.

At the end of last week the Department of Agriculture conducted a referendum among the nation's wheat farmers on the question of whether the latter would accept "marketing quotas" on the 1956 wheat crop. Wheat is one of the so-called "basic" crops on which support prices are mandatory.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Negroes pursued their campaign today to ban racial segregation from National Guard organizations in the South.

THE first school tuna reported in the area this season was taken Saturday morning by an angler fishing out of Freeport, L. I., which indicates that the vanguard of the migration is approaching these shores.

Consumption of man-made fibers rose 353 per cent from 1937 to 1954, according to a study prepared for The Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. The rate of increase was twice that of natural fiber consumption.
Six city motorcycle policemen and one formerly attached to the Long Island State Park Commission force were charged in Kings County Court yesterday with participating in the courtesy card racket.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- If Vyacheslav M. Molotov keeps a diary of his American transcontinental journey, entries under "Chicago" should provide diverting reading.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -The House of Representatives voted today to continue for another year the temporary $6,000,000,000 increase in the Federal dept limit. The vote was 226 to 56.
BUENOS AIRES, June 27 -- President Juan D. Peron appeared in public today for the first time in a week. Photographs in the newspaper showed him granting audiences.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles arrived here tonight by plane from Maine. During their two-hour flight they discussed the coming Big Four conference and the shooting down of a Navy plane by Soviet airmen.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -Senator Estes Kefauver and Rowland R. Hughes, Director of the Bureau of the Budget, exchanged softly spoken hot words today about the Dixon- Yates power contract.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., June 27 (AP) -- A tobacco industry spokesman said today that high taxes on cigarettes rather than concern about cancer was the primary cause of the drop in cigarette smoking.

Directors of the Danish Ford Motor Company have agreed to accept an offer of the Ford Motor Company, parent concern in the United States, to acquire the Danish company's 60 per cent holdings in the Ford Motor Company of Sweden.

WHITE PLAINS, June 27 -- Nicholas Sulick, 30 years old, pleaded guilty in Westchester County Court today to a misdemeanor indictment growing out of a widespread investiga tion into a courtesy card traffic scandal in the New York metropolitan area. Judge George M. Fanelli set no date for sentence.
TOKYO, June 27 -- The worsening relations between Japan and South Korea will be the subject of important talks in Seoul during the next few days.
Traffic along the upper West Side luxury liner piers was speeded up considerably yesterday by a new traffic control plan.

MIAMI, BEACH, June 27 -- A tiny portable phonograph that will play 3,000 records on power from four ordinary flashlight batteries was unveiled today by the Philco Corporation. The lunchbox-sized phonograph was shown to 1,200 distributors' executives convening here.

Prices of commodity futures on the New York exchanges were irregular yesterday in generally featureless trading. Rubber, hides, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, sugar and zinc were mixed. Wool and lead rose. Coffee, cocoa, potatoes and burlap declined.

LONDON, June 27 -- British excavations in Anatolian Turkey have brought to light further information about the Arzawas, a culturally advanced people that stood midway between the might of the ancient Hittites and the warrior kings of the Homeric world.

Brooklyn longshoremen voted yesterday in favor of the new working rules drawn up by the Waterfront Commission, employers and Local 1814 of the independent International Longshoremen's Association. The local is headed by Anthony Anastasia.

One way to get from Santiago, Chile, to West Fifty-first Street, New York, is to get into a twentyfive-year-old automobile and drive northward 12,849 miles. That is what four Chilean members of the Lions International have done.

The six-story apartment house at 269 Prospect Place in Brooklyn is under contract of sale to Leonard Winston, real estate operator and investor. The property has been owned for more than twenty years by the Fortuna Building Corporation.
The city moved yesterday to block a request of the New York Telephone Company for a $34,000,000 temporary rate increase.
A ROSE is a rose on the bush, but as a color it can be practically anything. It is the Textile Color Card Association of the United States, Inc., who decides what.
BONN, Germany, June 27 -Theodor Blank, Minister of Defense, outlined for the Bundestag today the Government's plans for a democratic defense force under civilian control.

Directors of the Rheem Manufacturing Company have elected William S. Rheem 2d as a vice president and a director, it was announced yesterday by R. S. Rheem, president and father of the new officer. Mr. Rheem II is a member of the third generation of a pioneering Western industrial family.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Wheat prices moved up rapidly yesterday following Saturday's vote of the wheat growers for the market-quota plan. However, free selling followed gains of up to 3 cents and much of the early gain was dissipated before midday.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 (AP) -- Bill Talbert said today Budge Patty had promised to "seriously consider returning home" to try for a place on the American Davis Cup team.

SKOWHEGAN, Me., June 27 -- President Eisenhower said today that the world was making a steady, if slow, march toward real, secure, permanent peace. At the end of his visit to Maine and northern New England he gave a special message to his comrades in arms from World War II. He told them the world was nearer the ideals for which they had fought.

The leasehold on the two-story garage at 539-45 West Forty-seventh Street has been purchased by the Ryder Truck Rental System, Inc., from the Samac Garage Corporation, of which Samuel Lapin is president.
SKOWHEGAN, Me., June 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's informal remarks here today:
WASHINGTON, June 27--The Senate unanimously approved today the establishment of a bipartisan commission to review the Federal security program as to its effectiveness and fairness.

The leasehold on the two-story garage at 539-45 West Forty-seventh Street has been purchased by the Ryder Truck Rental System, Inc., from the Samac Garage Corporation, of which Samuel Lapin is president.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Treasury announced plans today to borrow $100,000,000 more than usual next week to cover some of its seasonal needs.
SKOWHEGAN, Me., June 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's informal remarks here today:
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 27 -- President Tito has accepted an invitation to visit the Soviet Union. No date was given.
Prices of vinyl plastics resins were trimmed 9 to 18 per cent yesterday by one of the world's largest producers, the Bakelite Company Division of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee put off action today on the nomination of former Representative John S. Wood to be a member of the Subversive Activities Control Board.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 27 -- Petitions were circulated on three trains of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad this morning, calling upon commuters to protest the levying by the carrier of parking tolls at several of its stations.
NEW BEDFORD, Mass., June 27 (AP)--Berkshire Hathaway, Inc., announced today that it would give vacation pay to 10,000 employes in twelve New England plants on strike since April 15.
Detectives of the Narcotics Squad recovered $250,000 worth of pure heroin last night a few hours after it was smuggled into the city from a steamship.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 27--Judy Mintz of Glen Oaks, who hopes to be a Skidmore freshman in the fall, shot a 74 at the Piping Rock Golf Club today. The performance enabled the 17-year-old Great Neck golfer to lead the qualifiers in the twenty-fifth annual women's Long Island match-play championship.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 (AP) -- The results of today's matches in the All-England tennis championships:

LOS ANGELES, June 27 -- A San Diego housewife who spied for the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified at a Congressional hearing today that local Communist party activities had received guidance from Mao Tse-tung, the Chinese Communist leader.

OCCASIONALLY a book is published that is too solid, thorough and specialized to appeal widely to many readers, but that is so comprehensive in coverage, so incisive in its insights and so bold in its interpretations that it acquires a great reputation and is read by intellectual leaders for generations. Alexis de Tocqueville's "Democracy in America" was such a book.
LONDON, June 27 -- Fear that within five years Lancashire will become "a graveyard of cotton mills" was expressed in a report published today for the Trades Union Congress.

Strikes by warehouse employes of two major food chain stores serving New York and Long Island were averted by settlements just before the walkout deadline yesterday afternoon. Negotiators of Local 852, Teamsters Union, A. F. L., and the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company reached an agreement shortly before 5 P. M.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad had a net income, before sinking fund reserves, of $1,001,287 last month, as compared with $702,838 in May, 1954.

A suggestion for an organization to provide insurance producers with public relations and advertising information and material was suggested yesterday by John C. Stott of Norwich, N. Y., in an address before the Insurance Advertising Conference at Atlantic City.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -Paul M. Butler, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said tonight that some members of his party in the South were working for the Republicans and only "pose as Democrats."
Creative artists in all branches of the fashion industry will have a chance to show their talents in a national fine arts project sponsored by the Fashion Group, Inc.
ALBANY, June 27 -- The president of the American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., today called on the Justice Department to begin an antitrust investigation of the suspension of The Brooklyn Eagle.

The announcement last week was routine: the Export-Import Bank granted a credit of $3,920,000 to the Cia. Vale do Rio Doce of Brazil. It was to finance the purchase of American railway and ore-handling equipment.
BERLIN, June 27--West Berlin is girding itself to handle the largest influx of refugees since the massive immigrations of 1953.

NORWALK, Conn., June 27 -Battle lines were drawn today for a renewal of a conflict here. The issue: whether to dedicate choice acreage to residential development or convert it to meet the expanding needs of industry.
MOSCOW, June 27 -- At 3:30 o'clock this morning dozens of young Russian girls in their best summer dresses were strolling up the middle of Gorky Street, as if it were high noon and open country.

ALBANY, N. Y., June 27 (AP) -- Democratic legislative leaders called today on a Republicanruled committee to give "top priority" to an investigation of possible Communist influence in summer camps for children.

OCCASIONALLY a book is published that is too solid, thorough and specialized to appeal widely to many readers, but that is so comprehensive in coverage, so incisive in its insights and so bold in its interpretations that it acquires a great reputation and is read by intellectual leaders for generations. Alexis de Tocqueville's "Democracy in America" was such a book.
BERLIN, June 27--West Berlin is girding itself to handle the largest influx of refugees since the massive immigrations of 1953.

NORWALK, Conn., June 27 -Battle lines were drawn today for a renewal of a conflict here. The issue: whether to dedicate choice acreage to residential development or convert it to meet the expanding needs of industry.
MOSCOW, June 27 -- At 3:30 o'clock this morning dozens of young Russian girls in their best summer dresses were strolling up the middle of Gorky Street, as if it were high noon and open country.

ALBANY, N. Y., June 27 (AP) -- Democratic legislative leaders called today on a Republicanruled committee to give "top priority" to an investigation of possible Communist influence in summer camps for children.

A four-man slate of Republican candidates to run in the Sept. 13 primaries on Staten Island was approved last night by the 352-member Richmond County Republican Committee. The slate had been recommended by the committee's executive body.
It seems there is just no stopping the sizzling Dodgers.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Congress passed finally today a four-year continuation of the draft.
COLD SPRING, N. Y., June 28 -- Even when you are 77 years old, life can be a happy adventure.
The Mohawk Business Machines Corporation will seek Public Service Commission approval at Albany today for permission to install tariff-free its telephone answering devices throughout the state.

NEW ORLEANS, June 28 (AP) -- Willie Pastrano of New Orleans passed his first test as a top light-heavyweight contender tonight with a ten-round decision over the former world champion, Joey Maxim of Cleveland.
SUNNYVALE, Calif., June 28 (UP) -- An airliner that can take off and land vertically has reached the model stage at the Government's Ames Aeronautical Laboratory at Moffett Field.

The New York Community Trust, administrator of charitable funds, announced yesterday the appointment of Earle S. Thompson to its distribution committee. Mr. Thompson is president of the West Penn Electric Company and a director of the Potomac Edison Company, Monongahela Power Company, Yale and Towne Manufacturing Company, Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company and the City Bank Farmers Trust Company.

FLORENCE, Italy, June 28 -- One aim of Moscow's diplomatic maneuvering is to destroy the Balkan pact, which links Yugoslavia to the easternmost NATO allies, Greece and Turkey. This treaty, valid for twenty years, binds the countries on the Soviet bloc's southwestern flank to defend each other in case of aggression.

Irving Cohen, former manager of Billy Graham and Rocky Graziano, yesterday told the New York State Athletic Commission about a $500 fine he had to pay to the International Boxing Guild. He testified on the advice of his counsel, Martin Nadle, rejecting the advice of the Guild's attorney, Murray Frank.

GAZA ARMISTICE LINE, June 28 -- Egyptians and Israelis began negotiations here today in an effort to end the fighting along the truce line. Fifty-three Egyptians and twenty-five Israelis have been killed in the area this year. A communique issued after the four-hour session said:
OTTAWA, June 28 (Canadian Press) -- The Government has issued an export permit for the sale of surplus butter to Communist-controlled Czechoslovakia, it was learned today.

The one-story industrial building on plot 100 by 220 feet at 133-16 Thirty-fifth Avenue in Flushing, Queens, has been sold by the Frank Chase Industries to Challan Co., manufacturers of wire novelties. The Greiner-Maltz Company was the broker in the transaction.
MOSCOW, June 28 -- An American made a public speech in Moscow tonight -- and the Russians loved it.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 28 -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, predicted tonight that "self-interest" eventually would cause the South to eliminate segregation in industry.
WHEN Clipper Smith was coaching the Boston Yanks of the National Football League in 1947, he cast wistful eyes in the direction of a solidly built, black-haired youngster.
A wildcat strike of drivers that closed five of nine plants of the Coca-Cola Bottling Company in the city for two weeks ended yesterday, a company spokesman said.
The key to combatting world communism, Carmine G. DeSapio declared last night, is to maintain American ideological solidarity and traditions of liberty.
LOS ANGELES, June 28 -- The status of women in the academic world is slipping backward, delegates to the national convention of the Association of University Women were told today.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Representative Clarence Cannon, sidestepping legislative niceties, today attacked Senator Foghorn. This member he identified as a sort of composite figure of a Senator.

BONN, Germany, June 21 -- The Bundestag sent the Government's controversial volunteers bill to its principal committees tonight after a stormy debate. On the first reading, members of the Government coalition parties attacked the bill as badly conceived and hastily drafted.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 29 (AP) -- A United States Marine fighter plane, searching for two downed Marine fliers bobbing on life rafts in the Pacific, disappeared yesterday afternoon, the Navy reported.

The United States Government moved in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday to get back an alleged windfall profit of $3,158,000 realized by five corporations in the construction of Farragut Gardens, a large Brooklyn housing development.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 28 (AP) -- Members of the Forty Eight, fun-making organization of the American Legion, had the recommendation of their executive committee today that it break away from the Legion organization.
Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in operating revenues and net income for five and twelve months ended May 31.
CATSKILL, N. Y., June 28 (AP) -- A mule-drawn, wooden-wheeled covered wagon eased up to the toll gate at the western end of the Rip Van Winkle Bridge across the Hudson near here today.
LONDON, June 28 -- Forty-nine British seamen were found guilty today of having disobeyed orders and prevented the liner Queen Mary from sailing from Southampton June 16.
A police car pursued a stolen yellow convertible in Brooklyn yesterday with such success that when the fleeing machine rammed a traffic-light stanchion the police car almost telescoped it.

" The Seven Little Foys," with Bob Hope starred in the role of the famous vaudevillian, Eddie Foy Sr., will have its premiere this evening at the Criterion Theatre for the benefit of United Cerebral Palsy.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 28 (UP) -- President Joao Cafe Filho signed a ruling today that from now on all Brazilian Government imports will be paid for at the single foreign exchange rate of 43.82 cruzeiros to the dollar.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- It was incorrectly reported in yesterday's New York Times that the First Boston Corporation, investment bankers, had once been scheduled to receive a $150,000 fee for its services as financial agent on the Dixon-Yates power contract.
MILWAUKEE, June 28 (UP) -- Ernie Banks and Jim King each hit two homers tonight to give the second-place Chicago Cubs a 7-3 victory over the third- place Milwaukee Braves.

Cpl. Harold M. Dunn pleaded guilty yesterday to two charges of aiding and collaborating with the enemy during nearly three years as a prisoner of war in North Korea. He thus became the first former captive to admit the truth of such a charge, according to an Army official.
Stock prices, as measured by The New York Times composite average of fifty representative issues, reached a new top yesterday, and then backed away. The list closed irregularly lower on the day.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Senate handed President Eisenhower a legislative defeat tonight by voting, 42 -- 41, to scuttle his plans for an atoms-for-peace merchant ship.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Lattimore case came to the end of the long, long trail today.

LAST night's audience at the Lewisohn Stadium of City College gave Pierre Monteux a cordial welcome to the podium, and in return the veteran French conductor gave his hearers an evening of admirable music-making.
HAMDEN, Conn., June 28 (AP) -- Talon, Inc., announced today that it intended to close and sell its Hamden plant. It employs 350, of whom 80 per cent are women.
" The Reluctant Debutante," a newly established London hit, is to be exported to New York. Chiefly concerned with the future of the venture, due here in January, is Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.
A plan for the merger of the Penn-Texas Corporation and Niles-Bement Pont Company has been approved by directors of both companies.

The winners of five $6,000 college scholarships awarded annually by the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union were announced yesterday by Paul Hall, secretary-treasurer of the district. The awards, known as the Andrew Furuseth Memorial Scholarships, are named for the pioneer leader of seamen's unions.
Electronics workers at WOR and WOR-TV have chosen a video union, rather than an audio union, to represent them. The choice was made in an election conducted by the National Labor Relations Board.
A GREAT weight has been taken off a woman's intuition by a men's clothing concern that has set up rules for her to follow when helping her husband select a new suit.

The State of Maryland borrowed $25,000,000 yesterday to finance road building. The transaction consisted of the sale of serial bonds of the State Roads Commission maturing on July 1 from 1956 to 1970 at an interest cost of 2.5108 per cent.
Charges of widespread bribery and blackmail in the State Liquor Authority were made public yesterday at the office of J. Irwin Shapiro, State Commissioner of Investigation.
TRENTON, June 28 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner and Attorney General Grover C. Richman Jr. today hailed a decision yesterday by the New Jersey Supreme Court as a boon to the fight on bookmaking.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Charles S. Bridges, president of Libby, McNeill Libby, Chicago food canner, said today that proposals by a minority group of Eastern shareholders to assume management of the company would be resisted by every legitimate means.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 28 -- The chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission recommended today a Federally sponsored "passenger support" subsidy program for the nation's railroads.
A huge "beachhead" on the Brooklyn waterfront stretching for more than two miles and involving thirty-two piers is being acquired by the Port of New York Authority.

LAKE GEORGE. N. Y., June 28 -- The Republican State Chairman declared tonight that some persons in the state were being subjected to pressure for political contributions that is "sometimes closely akin to extortion."

Eddie Brannick, a member of the New York Giants official family for fifty years in August, will be honored at a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Aug. 28. The golden anniversary celebration for the secretary of the baseball club was announced yesterday at a luncheon in Toots Shor's Restaurant by Horace Stoneham, president of the Giants.

A playwright and a pianist, neighboring penthouse dwellers whose clashing artistic temperaments collaborated in a sky-set production that might be called "Fists in Fast Movement," received cool notices from the court yesterday.
The Waterfront Commission yesterday issued "permanent" licenses to five of the thirty-one contracting stevedoring concerns awaiting final approval of their applications.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Indonesian Embassy said today it would refuse an entry visa to a Washington attorney engaged to defend twenty-two Dutch nationals held for trial in Jakarta.
LONDON, June 28 -- A return to socialism's first principles is being urged on the Labor party by practical politicians and theoreticians.
Michael H. Prendergast of Rockland County was assured of election as Democratic state chairman yesterday. He will replace Richard H. Balch of Utica, who is resigning.
SAN SEBASTIAN, June 28 (AP) -- The American yacht Ticonderoga, apparent leader in the Havana-San Sebastian trans-oceanic race, had covered 2,435 miles of the 4,200-mile course yesterday.

This cry of the favorite player swept through the stands at Aqueduct yesterday as seven public choices stepped to victory. The chalk fanciers in the crowd of 18,166 were in an exultant mood as their selections came through with utopian regularity.
PITTSBURGH, June 28 -- The United States Steel Corporation warned tonight that a national steel strike appeared "imminent."

The American Machine and Foundry Company's recent offering to stockholders of 236,205 shares of common stock at $26 each has been 97.5 per cent subscribed through the exercise of warrants, Morehead Patterson, chairman and president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) -- A United Press dispatch of last Friday incorrectly identified Hal B. Grubbs Co. of Long Beach, Calif., as the manufacturer of two soft-drink mixes bought by the Navy in transactions that became a matter of Congressional investigation.
TAIPEI, Formosa, June 27 -- The average age of Chinese Nationalist Army soldiers has been scaled down to 25 years from the nearly 30 of little more than a year ago.
Motoring members of the Park Association of New York City, Inc., touring the parks of the East Bronx yesterday, studied the historical as well as the recreational aspects of the area.
Directors of the Camden Trust Company and the Oaklyn (N. J.) National Bank announced yesterday approval of a merger plan.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- President Eisenhower presented to Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway today the Distinguished Service Medal, third oak leaf cluster, for "exceptionally meritorious service" as Supreme Allied Commander in Euope and as Army Chief of Staff.

Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., formerly known as the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, announced yesterday the election of B. Brewster Jennings as chairman of the board to succeed George V. Holton, who retires Friday.

Support for the multi-million-dollar promotional campaign for the clothing industry planned by the American Institute of Men's and Boys' Wear, Inc., was pledge at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. The pledges came from 2,000 clothing industry executives who saw a preview of the industry's program.
The city's first solar furnace melted a bit of cold Manhattan granite in three seconds yesterday.

A new issue of $25,000,000 of twenty-year convertible debentures of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, heavy construction and shipbuilding business, will be placed on the market today by a syndicate of more than ninety investment houses headed by A. C. Allyn Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Senator Estes Kefauver accused President Eisenhower today of "apparently trying to cover up" facts about "a shocking piece of duplicity" in the Dixon-Yates power plant contract.

DETROIT, June 28 -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., announced today that 90 per cent of the union's membership in 111 General Motors plants throughout the nation had ratified the new three-year agreement reached with the company on June 13.
Four youths who pleaded guilty in two separate killings resulting from gang warfare were sentenced yesterday to prison terms of twenty years to life in General Sessions Court.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- A pay increase averaging 7.5 per cent for more than 1,000,000 Government employe was signed into law today by President Eisenhower. The increase is retroactive to March 1.
MOSCOW, June 28 -- The public debate over new styles and forms for Soviet art gained further momentum today.

MOSCOW, June 28 (AP) -- The United States has told the Soviet Union it will accept one permanent Soviet clergyman in return for permission to send a new United States priest to Moscow. The Russian will have the same privileges in the United States as those accorded the American in Moscow.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 28 -- A field of 180 competed in the Westchester Seniors Golf Association's twentieth annual spring tournament at the Quaker Ridge Club today.

A plaque citing its "progressive action in establishing and operating its group insurance program" was presented to The New York Times yesterday by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. The Times' program has been in effect for thirty-seven years.
Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov took in another museum yesterday and then drove eighteen miles to a luncheon date with Bernard M. Baruch. The museum visit was Mr. Molotov's...

Two investments trusts, the Pennroad Corporation and State Street Investment Corporation, and an investment banking concern prominent in railroad financing, Bear, Stearns Co., Inc., have acquired control of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Federal, state and local governments will have to continue taxing some of the same sources while the cost of government remains so high, a Federal commission concluded today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 28 -- A grenade was thrown from a speeding jeep tonight at a building housing the United States Information Service library and United States official personnel. No Americans were injured, but a Frenchman passing by on a bicycle was hurt.
WEST ISLIP, L. I., June 28 -- Governor Harriman visited Suffolk County today to try to do something about the tides -- oceanic and political.

Pinches of earth from thirty-four foreign countries and each of the forty-eight states and four territories of the United states were placed in a glass bowl yesterday on the base of the Statue of Liberty. After being stirred as a symbolic blending of the many peoples who became part of this nation, the earth was taken to the statue's torch and scattered over the island below.

The House of Representatives has voted to continue for another year the temporary increase of $6 billions in the Federal debt ceiling. It is expected that Senate action will have been completed on the same legislation by midnight tomorrow when, in the absence of such action, the debt limit would revert to its statutory figure of $275 billions.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 28 -- Claire H. Fellows, engineering and research director of the Detroit Edison Company, has been named president of the American Society for Testing Materials, it was announced today at the group's fifty-eighth annual meeting.

JERUSALEM, Wednesday, June 29 -- Premier Moshe Sharett will force the resignation of the Israeli Cabinet this morning. He will then report to President Izhak Ben-Zvi and attempt to form a new government.
Davy Crockett's cap became a burning issue yesterday.
A 7-year-old Brooklyn girl, who had been inoculated with the Salk anti-polio vaccine, has been stricken with non-paralytic poliomyelitis, the Health Department reported yesterday.

A half century of pioneer work in behalf of women workers came to a close when the New York Women's Trade Union League voted to terminate its activities. A special membership meeting accepted the recommendation of the league's officers and executive board to end educational and legislative programs immediately, it was announced yesterday.

Gross revenues and net income of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway for the first five months of the year increased 7 per cent and 35.8 per cent, respectively, above results for the corresponding months of 1954.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, in the fiscal year ended May 31, attained the highest sales and earnings in its history.

One of the most ambitious navigation projects in recent years will get under way here tomorrow. Joseph Havkins, 41 years old, an Israeli merchant mariner, will cast off from his Hudson River anchorage at West Forty-first Street and head the twenty-three-foot sloop Lamerhak II out to sea. Havana is the first scheduled stop on a round-the-world voyage that will cover 30,000 miles and take four years to complete.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 28 -- The Peiping Government has slowed a United Nations program to evacuate several thousand European refugees from Communist China.

BOISE, Idaho, June 28 (AP) -- The Idaho mass polio vaccination program -- already postponed indefinitely -- faced new delays today as state health authorities announced they had "lost confidence in the Salk vaccine."
WIMBLEDON, England, June 28 -- It's an all-American women's semi-final round as a tennis legend perpetuates itself.

The sixteen-story building occupied by Sears Roebuck at 362-70 Ninth Avenue and 358-72 West Thirty-first Street has been sold by Sidney M. Barton to Irving Brodsky in a deal negotiated by Helmsley-Spear, Inc., broker, and the George Comfort Company, co-broker.

The Public Works Department will receive bids today for the construction of a new Youth House, estimated to cost $3,500,000, to replace the outmoded "temporary" Youth House established eleven years ago at 331 East Twelfth Street.
I was amazed at the communication from eight citizens purporting to describe the policy of the New York City Board of Education in the June 24 issue of The Times.

There is no step that will catapult a man into neighborhood prominence more quickly than the purchase of a new automobile. One day he is a nonentity, a faceless figure that gravitates between home and office in a vehicle of ancient vintage.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 28 -- John Kerr, who scored on Broadway in "Tea and Sympathy" and was brought into movies by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in "The Cobweb," soon to be released, will do a second film for the studio.

MUENCHEN - GLADBACH, Germany, June 28 -- The North Atlantic alliance's atomic-bombing exercise that ended yesterday threw light on the essential military problem of the Western world: how to recover the initiative after an atomic attack.
The city is near an agreement with the Federal Government for acquiring Ellis Island for the treatment and care of aged and alcoholic men.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 28 -- A state-wide network of ten educational television stations was proposed today by State Controller Arthur Levitt. He urged also that four community colleges be established on Long Island. Because Mr. Levitt has been designated by Governor Harriman as educational liaison officer of the state, his recommendations took on added significance.
PITTSBURGH, June 28 (AP) -- Clifford F. Hood, president of the United States Steel Corporation, issued the following statement tonight:

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee said today that the Attorney General's list of subversive organizations was "widely misunderstood and misapplied." The subcommittee declared the list needed to be put in "proper perspective."

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Secretary John Foster Dulles said today that the State Department had not decided whether to appeal the Federal Court of Appeals' decision that denied the department's exclusive control over the issuance of passports.

BY means of television, a group of business men's wives got a chance last night to see what happens when their husbands go out of town to a convention. The repercussions may last for years in some households.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The State Department announced today that twelve Soviet agricultural experts would begin their United States visit at Des Moines, Iowa, on July 15.

AMERICANS traveling in West Germany this summer will do well to include Munich on their itineraries -- that is, if they like fine food. For reports of several recently returned travelers indicate that this upper Bavarian city is the center of good eating in Germany.

Two surprising and important steps have been taken in the last two days toward a fundamental improvement of the notoriously deficient and unrealistic employe security program of the Federal Government.

Futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges were generally lower yesterday. Trading was dull in most markets and involved evening of holdings for the long week-end. Potatoes, rubber, hides, silk, wool, burlap, cottonseed oil and soybean oil declined.
CHATHAM, June 28 (Canadian Press) -- David P. Rogers, president of the Union Gas Company of Canada, Ltd., said today that unforeseen delays had slowed up the expansion of its natural gas business.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Striking all mention of controversial Echo Park Dam, the House Interior Committee today approved a $760,000,000 authorization bill for the Upper Colorado River project.
LONDON, June 28 (AP) -- Britain's state-owned transport system finished 11,900,000 ($33,320,000) in the red last year, its annual report showed today.

The decision of Attorney General Brownell to drop the perjury charges against Owen Lattimore brings to a close a long and distasteful case that has never done the Government any credit. While this newspaper has disagreed with many of Mr. Lattimore's written and spoken views, we have felt that his prosecution first before a Senate committee and then, for two and a half years, in the Federal courts smacked strongly of persecution for his beliefs.
City ferry workers on the route between the Battery and St. George, S. I., were offered wage increases of 15 to 17 1/2 per cent yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- An official survey expressed deep concern today over the Government's lack of "adequate intelligence data" on the Soviet Union.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., June 28 -- Significant new developments in various phases of nuclear science were reported here today at the first annual meeting of the American Nuclear Society.

In the first stop on his pilgrimage to Moscow Ho Chi Minh, leader of the Communists in Indochina, has visited with the Red Chinese Premier, Chou En-lai. They are agreed that the friendship of the Chinese Communists and the Indochinese Communists is "everlasting" and cannot be "damaged by anyone."

MINEOLA, L. I. June 28 -- Swimming at fifty-five Nassau County beaches was approved here today by the County Department of Health. Permits were denied at two beaches and two others operating without permits have been ordered to close.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Boston splurged for eight runs in the ninth inning to defeat Washington, 8 -- 2, in the second game of a double-header tonight. The Red Sox captured the twilight first game, 4 -- 0, behind Frank Sullivan's three-hit pitching.

The Enright Corporation, an investment group headed by Nathan Sherman, has purchased the fifty - three - family apartment house at 1405-07 Shakespeare Avenue, the Bronx, from a client of Morris Greenberg, attorney. The property was held at $200,000 and was sold subject to mortgages totaling $147,375.

HACKENACK, N. J., June 28 -- John Been of the University of Houston upset sixth-seeded Bill Tully of Yonkers in the Eastern clay court tennis singles championship, 6 -- 3, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, today at the Oritani Field Club.
PURCHASE, N. Y., June 28 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association held a new kind of one-day tournament today over the Century Country Club course.

Bids for construction of a new Youth House for temporary detention of delinquent boys, at an estimated cost of $3,500,000, will be received by the city's Public Works Department at the Municipal Building today. This is the long-overdue replacement for the building on East Twelfth Street, of which there has been so much complaint by judges and others.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the Russians' readiness to discuss German unification would be a test of their sincerity about relaxing international tensions.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Administration's $3,285,800,000 foreign aid bill was started through the House of Representatives today with a warning that "the danger to the free world has not diminished in any way" despite recent Soviet Union gestures of cooperation with the West.
The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation yesterday junked three phases of pricing policy long practices by most makers of television and radio sets.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Secretary of State Dulles reasserted today the willingness of the United States to enter into direct conversations with Communist China.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has cleared the way for the proposed merger of the United States and International Securities Corporation, Devon Securities Corporation and Dunwalke Securities Corporation into the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation, it was learned yesterday.

BERLIN, June 28 -- Allocation of the assets of U. F. A., former Nazi-controlled German film combine, among three new successor concerns was announced today. Bavaria Film Kunst Studios of Munich, created under an earlier decision of the German Liquidation Board, has already inherited the largest share of UFA's former properties.

THE bass season opens in New York, Pennsylvania and Connecticut on Friday, which should insure a pleasant week-end for the anglers who put the largemouth and the smallmouth at the top of the freshwater game fish list.
Karl Spooner, who struck out fifteen Giants the first time he faced them last September, didn't do quite so well at Ebbets Field last night. But he won his game just the same.

The Commerce and Iudustry Association of New York yesterday registered its opposition to the Fulbright bill to subject all corporations with assets of more than $5,000,000 or more than 500 stockholders to the rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
LONDON, June 28 -- Four Scottish undergraduates emulated today for Queen Elizabeth II the chivalry of Sir Walter Raleigh, who spread his cloak for the first Queen Elizabeth to walk on.
PARIS, June 28 -- About the only thing you're certain is real after you've left the Exhibition of Fakes in Art and in History is your feet. They hurt.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Secretary of State Dulles blamed "trigger-happy" Soviet fighter pilots today for the attack last week on a United States Navy plane over the Bering Sea.

CAMDEN, N. J., June 28 -- The Camden Courier Post, an afternoon newspaper published by Camden Newspapers, Inc., will move into its $3,000,000 plant in near-by Delaware Township over the July 4 week-end. For the first time since 1875 a daily newspaper will not be published within the confines of this city.
NORWALK, Conn., June 28 -- A promise that Manresa Island in the harbor here would have "the best looking power plant in America" failed today to impress landowners.

TO the sophisticated grade-schooler now happily on the verge of leaving classroom routine behind, returning to the fold next fall will be old stuff. To a youngster entering "big school" for the first time, however, the occasion will probably he life's greatest adventure.

In your editorial of June 2 you drew attention to the sad state of the American merchant marine. Citing the rise in the seaman's basic monthly wage from $72.50 in 1940 to $314 today, you implied that this pay improvement has priced the seaman out of work and put the industry on the rocks.

DOVER, Del., June 28 (AP) -- The merger of General Dynamics Corporation and Stromberg-Carlson Company was approved today by stockholders of both concerns. Directors of both companies had approved the merger proposal on April 25.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Senate Democratic leader challenged President Eisenhower today on the record of the Eighty-fourth Congress and proclaimed the beginning of the end of its first session.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Following are the recommendations of the (Hoover) Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government for improving the Central Intelligence Agency:

CHICAGO, June 28 -- How Joe Louis incorporated himself and lived by borrowing from himself, the old Twentieth Century Sporting Club and other sources was described today in the United States tax court.
LONDON, June 28 -- "I Love Lucy" has been signed for British commercial television.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 28 (AP) -- Indonesia's Government faced a military and economic crisis tonight that threatened its life.
Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy expressed concern yesterday over the growing instability of family life and the lowering of traditional moral standards.

To speed Germany's contribution to Western defense under the Paris pacts Chancellor Adenauer has submitted to his Parliament a preliminary bill designed to get the organization of the new German Army under way. This bill calls for the recruiting and retraining of 6,000 officers and noncommissioned officers, so as to create a cadre for a future conscript force of 500,000 men.
BUENOS AIRES, June 28 -- The first casualty in President Juan D. Peron's Cabinet as a result of the revolt of June 16 appeared today to be Minister of the Interior Angel G. Borlenghi.
THE gentlemen in the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau keep talking, this year, of their "second annual New York Summer Festival," though it isn't that, by a full twenty years.
PARIS, June 28 -- Four notable figures in the American theatre combined their talents here tonight in a performance of Thornton Wilder's allegorical play, "The Skin of Our Teeth."

Directors of the Nuclear-Electronics Corporation, Olympic Radio and Television, Inc., and Victoreen Instrument Company voted yesterday for the merger and consolidation of the three companies, subject to approval of their stockholders at meetings to be held in August.
Two of five men on trial for alleged evasion of $17,400,000 in income taxes on wartime whisky deal profits were cleared in Federal Court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- A House committee today urged early consideration of legislation depriving the Federal Power Commission of price jurisdiction over natural gas at the producing wellhead.
Saskatchewan wheat growers are happy about the decision of i their counterparts south of theI border to accept marketing controls, according to The Canadian Press.

It is difficult to believe that America's leading newspaper could publish so misleading and distorted a picture of political issues in South Africa as is contained in the dispatch from your representative there published on June 24.

Carmen Lampe, the New Jersey state titleholder, advanced to the quarter-finals of the women's Eastern clay court tennis championships yesterday. The Forest Hills player defeated Margaret Niven of Rego Park, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 0, on the courts of the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club at Bayside, Queens.

Jacob K. Javits, State Attorney General, will lead state employes in giving blood today at the State Office Building, 80 Center Street, to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. Today bloodmobiles will also visit the New York Regional Office of the Veterans Administration, 252 Seventh Avenue, and Letchworth Village, Stony Point, N. Y.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Regardless of Federal subsidies, unstable labor conditions are making shipping a poor investment, the House Merchant Marine Committee was told today.

Chester Bowles, former United States Ambassador to India and Nepal and author of "Ambassador's Report," has a new work on Harper's list. Called "Waging the Peace," the book presents Mr. Bowles' observations and comments of world conditions based on a three months' visit to Asia and Africa.

Wherever it has gone in the Far East -- Japan, Formosa, the Philippines, Thailand, Malaya, Ceylon -- the Symphony of the Air, a ninety-two-piece American orchestra, has received a notably warm reception. Communists have been trying hard to sell the people of Asia the ides that the United States knows nothing of real culture.

DARIEN, Conn., June 28 -- James H. Griffin, a man who has lived with transit and traffic problems for forty-two years, believes the time fast approaching when New York streets will have reached the "saturation point" for automobile traffic.

STRATFORD, Ont., June 28 -- As a lithographic portrait of political revolution the "Julius Caesar" that opened here last evening is vivid and dramatic. As a portrait of some illustrious Romans it is sprawling and tame.
LONDON, June 28 (UP) -- The five United States entries drew their first opponents today when the draw was made for tomorrow's opening of the Royal Henley Regatta.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 29 -- Olivia de Havilland will star in "The Ambassador's Daughter," to be directed and produced by Norman Krasna from his own screen play. United Artists is financing the production, which will be filmed in France starting in October or November.

HENLEY, England, June 29 (UP) -- Three American eightoared crews won their opening heats today at the Royal Henley Regatta. Russia threw the first day of the classic into confusion by first withdrawing and then re-entering its powerful oarsmen.
President Eisenhower has urged Congress to authorize United States membership in the proposed companion institution of GATT, designated the Organization for Trade Cooperation.
Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, said yesterday in a farewell message he was certain the American people wished to live "in peace and amity."
Roy Campanella, ace catcher of the Dodgers, will be lost to the club until sometime after the All-Star game on July 12 because of an injured left knee.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Winston M. Burdett, now United Nations correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, testified today that he had been a Communist party member from 1937 to 1942 and had engaged in espionage for Russia overseas.
NEW DELHI, June 29 -- The Government announced today liberalization of imports of a large number of items from the dollar area.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 30 (AP) -- New radio signals from a downed airman's life raft renewed hope today that at least one of four marines lost in the Pacific off Japan might be found.
LONDON, June 29 -- A Royal Commission found today that monopolistic practices have encroached on a large sector of British trade the last generation.
LONDON, June 29 -- Viscount Woolton resigned today as chairman of the Conservative Party Organization. He will remain Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster and a member of the cabinet.
LONDON, June 29 -- The Fashion School of the Royal College of Art showed a dress collection today that indicates big changes for the better are slated for the future Miss Average Briton's wardrobe.
The Gerber Products Company and its subsidiary achieved record net sales in the year ended March 31.
Commodity prices were irregular in very dull trading yesterday on the New York futures markets.
Camilo Leyra, 55-year-old salesman, was convicted of firstdegree murder last night in Kings County Court in the killing of his father and mother. There was no recommendation for mercy.

The Arabian American Oil Company last year produced a record of 953,000 barrels a day of crude oil in Saudi Arabia, according to the company's report to the Saudi Arabian Government. The peak was in May, 1954, when production averaged more than 1,000,000 barrels a day. In 1953, output averaged 844,642 barrels a day.

ALBANY, June 29 -- The Public Service Commission will not rule on the New York Telephone Company's request for a stopgap rate increase until court action on an earlier rate case has advanced one more step.

Most concerns in New York City have done well in the first half of the year and expect to do as well or better in the second half, according to a survey by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -The new military Reserves bill cleared the House Rules Committee today, and may go to the floor tomorrow.
A Soviet Caucasian minority whose republic was wiped off the map by a Kremlin decree eleven years ago has made a dramatic reappearance.
THE small school stripers are showing in fair numbers in Long Island Sound between Rye and Stamford, but few trollers are taking advantage of the opportunities.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 -- Forty-five Federal judges of the Ninth Judicial Circuit today applauded a denunciation of Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania.
LONDON, June 29 -- A special panel of the Trades Union Congress declared today there was "no justification whatever" for continuation of the dock strike.
A 20-year-old youth defied a patrolman last night when ordered off a public school ground in Brooklyn, but he ran out of back talk in Night Court.

The nation is now faced with the imminent threat of a steel strike -- and that means a threat to the earnings of over half a million workers and to the union's treasury, to the profits of the steel companies and, indirectly but potently, to the nation as a whole.

HACKENSACK, N. J., June 29 -- A Bergen County judge angrily condemned today three Wallington men who continued to serve as members of the Board of Education after being convicted in his court of soliciting a bribe. Judge Arthur J. O'Dea told the men they had "acted like hoodlums."

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Those Republicans and Democrats who have been criticizing the President and the Senate Democratic leader for being "too nonpartisan" felt better today after the smooth relations between General Eisenhower and Senator Johnson were ruffled by a small public spat.
LOS ANGELES, June 29 (UP) -- Cal Eaton tonight offered a $1,250,000 guarantee to bring the Rocky Marciano - Archie Moore heavyweight championship fight to Los Angeles.
CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers, lashing five straight hits to open the game, including a three-run homer by Al Kaline, trimmed the Chicago White Sox, 8 -- 2, today.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 29 (AP) -- Christopher T. Chenery's Prince Hill staged a rally in the short stretch to win the second division of the Longfellow Handicap at Monmouth Park today. The mile race was held on the grass course.

The Yankees added a game and a half to their American League lead yesterday. By sweeping a double-header with the Orioles at the Stadium while the White Sox were losing to the Tigers, the Bombers increased their edge over the second-place Chicagoans to five full games.

The nation's inland waterways continue to move an ever larger share of traffic. According to a survey made by the American Waterways Operators, Inc., the tonnage carried during the first half of 1955 was "far ahead" of the 1954 pace.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House has authorized direct quotation of the President throughout:
ROCHELLE PARK, N. J., June 29 -- A move to restore control of the powerful Bergen County Republican organization to John J. Dickerson was begun here tonight by 1,400 party leaders.
The proposal to create public parks on two abandoned city-owned hospital sites, one in the Bronx and one in Queens, was approved unanimously by the City Planning Commission yesterday.
WASHINGTON -- The United States has one of the oldest populations of the world and we are rapidly growing older.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Congress is "making progress" 'in devising legislation fair to both producers and consumers of natural gas, President Eisenhower said today.
Eight years' imprisonment was imposed yesterday on Cpl. Harold M. Dunn for collaborating with the Communist enemy while he was a prisoner of war in North Korea.
Approval of subscription TV would "kill the goose that laid the golden egg" for radio-TV distributors and dealers, according to Benjamin Abrams, president of Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation.
Gifts and pledges to the Greater New York Fund to date total $6,020,000.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Jacob Stern Co., Inc., of New York and its president, Jacob Stern, were charged by the Department of Agriculture today with manipulating the price of March potato futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Eisenhower took a moderately optimistic view today of next month's Big Four meeting in Geneva.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., June 29 -- The election of Cyrus Collins of Hastings-on-Hudson as president of the Children's Village, a school for rehabilitation of delinquent boys, was announced today. He succeeds B. A. Tompkins, retiring executive vice president of the Bankers Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Navy said tonight that it was blacklisting Sol Schlesinger, a cap maker, and was moving to cancel his contract to manufacture 50,000 blue sailor caps.

A new plan of factoring which will enable manufacturers and distributors to obtain funds on retail accounts on a non-notification basis was announced yesterday by James Talcott, Inc., 101-year-old factoring and commercial finance firm.

The Republic of Indonesia is confronted with one more of its perennial army crises. The immediate issue is the appointment of a new Chief of Staff over the protest of senior officers. But the real question seems to be the fight in both army and Parliament against Defense Minister Kusumasumantri, who is accused of having made the appointment for political purposes in the interest of the Communists.

JERUSALEM June 23 -- Mr. Gruenwald, who lost fifty-two members of his family in Nazi gas chambers, had sought for many years to learn why the plight of Hungarian Jews had not been prevented or eased. His search led him to Dr. Kastner, whom he accused of treachery.

The five-story apartment house accommodating forty-six families at 311 Seventy-ninth Street in North Bergen, N. J., has been sold by the Broadrock Realty Company to Jack Frieman. The property, opposite the Hudson County Park, contains suites of two, three and four rooms.

LONDON, June 29 (UP) -- Britain said tonight she had warned the Chinese Nationalist Government that British warships would be used, if necessary, to protect British merchantmen trading with Communist China.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Eisenhower pledged his cooperation today to a bipartisan review of the Administration's loyalty-security program for Government employes.
In his letter appearing in The Times of June 14, relative to the Palace of Progress, Martin D. Jacobs makes certain statements which cannot go unchallenged.
PAUL RICHARDS is a man of vision, a farseeing operative. His main trouble at the moment concerns a matter of definition. How far is farseeing?
Civilian and Army personnel of the New York Military District will give blood today to the regional Red Cross at the New York Port of Embarkation, Fifty-eighth Street and First Avenue, Brooklyn.
GAZA, June 29 -- Negotiations between Egypt and Israel on ways to end the fighting on the truce line were suspended today. The two sides failed to agree on an agenda after two days of talks.

Pierre Monteux conducted the Stadium Symphony again last night in Lewisohn Stadium and again the result was happy music-making. In such works as Tchaikovsky's "Hamlet" Overture and Fourth symphony and the dances from de Falla's "Three-Cornered Hat" Mr. Monteux led the orchestra in pellucid, perfectly proportioned readings.
VANCOUVER, B. C., June 29 (AP) -- Bob Rosburg of San Francisco today shot a 7-under-par 65 to take the first-round lead in the 72-hole $15,000 British Columbia open golf tournament.
The Cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, one point lower to 10 points higher, with the far months showing the most strength.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 29 (AP) -- Greyhound bus drivers in ten states and the District of Columbia ended today their eighty-four-day strike against the Atlantic Greyhound Corporation.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 (AP) -- The summaries of the matches played in the All-England tennis championships today:
TAIPEI, Formosa, June 29 -The Chinese Nationalist press was nearly unanimous today in urging the bombing of Communist air bases in retaliation for Monday's attacks on Nationalist planes.

Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams will appoint 690 probationary patrolmen and seven women to the force this morning at Police Headquarters. The appointments will raise the department's strength to 22,237 members, which will be a record.
A Queens sewing machine company and three of its officers were convicted yesterday of fraudulent advertising over television.

On June 20 The New York Times published an article on Puerto Rico to the effect that the proposed minimum wage regulation for the island, contained in S. 2168, may cause greatly increased unemployment and curtail expansion of the Puerto Rican economy.

Officially, today is the end of the school season. But Johnny, who is all set to kick over the traces of education for the next two months, may be in for a rude surprise. In many homes across the land mother and dad have been eagerly awaiting this day to start a little educational project all their own, one to which they are prepared to give over a good portion of summer's vacation time.
LONG BEACH, L. I., June 29 -- Attorney General Jacob K. Javits proposed today that Republicans sponsor a three-point program to cut the highway accident toll.

The lowest bids submitted to the city yesterday for the construction of a multi-winged Youth House in the Bronx totaled $5,341,930. Engineers of the Public Works Department had estimated the cost at $3,500,000.

" JOHNNY BELINDA," as the stage and screen already have demonstrated, is a story that contains elements of great emotional force. In the television version, seen last night over Channel 2 on "Front Row Center," some of the script's quality of poignancy was retained and faithfully portrayed.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- United States naval air patrols in the Bering Sea have been suspended, according to authoritative sources.

The five-story dwelling containing nine apartments on lot 20 by 100 feet at 62 East Sixty-sixth Street, near Park Avenue, has been sold by Alfrieda P. Hobson to Joseph L. Ennis Co., realty operators. It is assessed at $62,000 and was altered recently.
A ten-year $85,000,000 improvement program for the Brooklyn waterfront was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.
A sharp difference of opinion broke out yesterday in top railroad management over a proposal that the nation's railway get a "passenger support" subsidy from the Federal Government.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) -- The Government is trying to collect $566.10 it contends Gov. Edmund S. Muskie of Maine owes in back income taxes, United States Tax Court records showed today.

LOS ANGELES, June 29 -Members of the American Association of University Women were urged to be more active and partisan in community politics. Three women politicians and a woman banker, members of the organization, spoke today to the delegates of their national convention here.
BUENOS AIRES, June 29 -- President Juan D. Peron decreed today that the country was no longer in a "state of siege." Normal constitutional guarantees had been suspended for thirteen days.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Thursday, June 30 (UP) -- Government troops have driven rebel Gen. Le-Quang Vinh and his rebellious Hoa Hao forces out of free Vietnam, the National Defense Ministry announced today.

The shipping industry yesterday welcomed the action taken Tuesday by House and Senate conferees in approving operating differential subsidy funds of $110,000,000 and up to 1,950 contract voyages a year by subsidized steamship lines.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 814,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, it was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline stocks at the week-end totaled 164,471,000 barrels, compared with 165,285,000 a week earlier and 168,147,000 a year ago.

The entire loft at 100 Metropolitan Avenue in Brooklyn, comprising 10,000 square feet of space, has been leased by the Dumont Lamp Company from the Imperial Plating Company. The lessee will use the space for general offices and for the manufacture of lamps rind lighting fixtures.
STONY BROOK, L. I., June 29 -- The Long Island Seniors Golf Association had a record entry of 123 players in its tournament at the St. George's Golf and Country Club today.
ALTHOUGH the Davy Crockett renaissance has moved the frontier a trifle farther eastward than usual this season, the men of the West continue to put out more flags.
CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- A July 4 week-end automobile traffic death toll of 380 was forecast today by the National Safety Council.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Eisenhower demanded even more backing from the Democratic Congress today in his first head-on partisan collision with that body.
CHICAGO, June 29 -- The W. A. Sheaffer Pen Company has cut 650 merchants from its shipping lists as a result of their violating fair trade laws, company officials said here today.

WASHINGTON, June 29 --The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended June 22:
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 28 -- By letting it be known that he has accepted an invitation to Moscow, Marshal Tito has called attention again to his parallel relations with the East and the West.

A recent Presbyterian declaration that the Church of Rome had "created a semi-divine female being" in the figure of Virgin Mary was criticized yesterday by the Catholic Theological Society of America as a distortion of Catholic devotion to Mary."
WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 -- It will be top-seeded Tony Trabert of Cincinnati against Kurt Nielsen of Denmark for the unofficial world tennis championship.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Eisenhower put on a political show for 186 reporters at his seventy-second press conference today.
A combination in restraint of trade in the manufacture and sale of dry colors, an $80,000,000a-year industry, was charged yesterday by the Government.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Furniture manufacturers' sales in 1955 may wind up 4 per cent higher than the record $2,127,036,000 volume of 1953, according to John M. Snow, executive secretary of the National Association of Furniture Manufacturers.

" The Invader," a forty-minute documentary on the fight against syphilis was shown for the first time yesterday at the Center for Mass Communication of the Columbia University Press. The center produced the film for the Georgia State Department of Public Health.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 29 -- The New York City Ballet opened its Holland Festival engagement here tonight with a conquest of its Municipal Theatre audience.

NEW DELHI, India, June 29 -- In the wake of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's visit to the Soviet Union, the Indian Communist party came out today in strong support of India's foreign policy. Heretofore the party has opposed Mr. Nehru's policies.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 29 (AP) -- The pilot and an aviation machinist mate were praised today by injured crew members of the United States Navy bomber attacked by Soviet MIG's over the Bering Sea last week.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Substantially higher rates for power produced by Federal agencies like the Tennessee Valley Authority were urged today by the Hoover Commission.
Robert Lewis, better known in the theatre for his accomplishments as a director, will step out as a Broadway producer this season.
Increased credit installment selling of this country's exports is essential to its long-range economic interests, Senator John Sparkman declared yesterday.
