Eddie Arcaro had his first ride on Christopher T. Chenery's Scansion yesterday. It was a highly enjoyable ride. Scansion won, and Arcaro cut in for the winning jockey's 10 per cent of the net of $9,800.
A special Queens County grand jury charged yesterday that Borough President James A. Lundy and his two principal aides "lacked a proper concept of public office."
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, June 29 -- Malaya is about to take an important step forward on the road to national independence.

The Port Authority's purchase of two miles of the Brooklyn waterfront for $13,750,000 and its plan to spend upward of $70,000,000 on terminal improvement there within a decade constitute a highly significant startling development. The program of modernization, which will replace dock facilities and storage quarters built in part for the horse-and-wagon days, cannot fail to make an immense contribution to the New York port's future.
The New York County American Legion was urged last night to put its Americanism program to work by helping Puerto Ricans to adjust themselves to a changed way of life here.

PARIS, June 29 -- Employes of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization adopted a motion today requesting the director general to reinstate seven American staff members dropped as loyalty cases.
" The lowest thing that has happened around here in a long time" -- that's the way the police put it -- occurred yesterday in the Ryer Avenue district of the Bronx.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 -A new chapter in the story of West Coast maritime labor-management relations opens tomorrow.

JERUSALEM, June 29 -- Premier Moshe Sharett purged the General Zionist party from his Government today, four weeks before the scheduled national Parliamentary elections. The removal of the right-of-center party, the second largest in the outgoing Knesset (Parliament) followed its abstention yesterday in a Parliamentary confidence vote.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 29 -- The eight-day Communist organized "World Assembly for Peace" ended tonight with the adoption of a so-called Helsinki Appeal for Peace. It reflects the Kremlin's position on foreign policy. The vote was 1,486 to 0.

The easy road to learning has ended for the city's school children. By the time summer vacation begins tomorrow 11,709 children in the first six grades will have learned that they have been left back. Although this is only 2.6 per cent of the 448,000 children in the elementary grades, it is more than double the number kept back in recent years.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 29 -- The vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad today urged the Government either to drop the 10 per cent tax on rail passenger tickets or else see that it is used to help rather than hurt passenger service.

The life of a prisoner with "the longest record of solitary confinement in the United States" is the subject of "Birdman of Alcatraz," by Thomas E. Gaddis. Twice sentenced to death, Robert Stroud has been in isolation for thirty-nine years.

BOSTON, June 29 -- Wallace (Bud) Smith, 26-year-old lightweight from Cincinnati, became the champion of his division tonight. He lifted the title from Jimmy Carter of New York in a fifteen-round bout in the Boston Garden.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) -- The House Ways and Means Committee changed signals again today on its Social Security bill and voted more liberal provisions for women.
MOSCOW, June 29 -- Law enforcement officers in the Soviet Union have just had new instructions from the Communist party leadership on their duties and obligations.

Following are the text of a statement issued yesterday by Sig Mickelson, vice president of the Columbia Broadcasting System; a letter from Senator James O. Eastland to C. B. S., a statement by The New York Newspaper Guild and a statement by national Guild officers in connection with the testimony of Winston Burdett; C. B. S. commentator, that he had been a Communist spy overseas:
Nassau County, L. I., borrowed $19,187,000 on serial bonds yesterday to finance sewage disposal and other improvements.
BEREA, Ky., June 29 -- Berea College, the Southern highlands institution of world renown as an educational pioneer, began its centennial celebration today.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- More than 20,000 men this week and last put on their most comfortable shoes each morning and took over a chore customarily confined to women. They went shopping. And they were paid to do it.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Eisenhower made it emphatic today that Senator Estes Kefauver would not be licensed to hunt the Executive files for traces of "corruption" in the Dixon-Yates power contract. At his news conference the President said, in effect, that there was no corruption to be found there anyhow.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- Hog prices staged a modest comeback on the livestock market today. Cattle action was even more vigorous. Vealers and sheep were steady. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
New issues of corporate securities valued at more than $14,000,000 will be offered to investors today by investment banking syndicates.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A one-year extension of the temporary $281,000,000,000 national debt limit was approved today by the Senate Finance Committee, 12 to 1.
LONDON, June 29 -- The slide from last week's high marks continued today, with both stock prices and business lower.

BEREA, Ky., June 29 -- Paul Green, noted American folklore dramatist and a native Southerner, boldly challenged the region tonight to view its race relations problem as part of the total democratic struggle to preserve free inquiry.

A 6-year-old drummer hardly tall enough to see over a bass drum made his debut with the Goldman Band, Edwin Franko Goldman conducting, on the Mall in Central Park last night. It was the eleventh of the season's Guggenheim Memorial Concerts presented in memory of Daniel and Florence Guggenheim.

Several leading New York banks announced yesterday that they were increasing the rate on loans to brokers and dealers to finance buying of non-Government securities for their own accounts. The present rate of 2 3/4 per cent will be raised to 3 per cent.
LONDON, June 29 -- The House of Commons approved today without dissent the bill sanctioning the Austrian state treaty.
MOSCOW, June 29 -- In an atmosphere of interest and excitement that probably couldn't be duplicated anywhere else, the United States and Soviet chess players started their eight-day match here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 29 -- Work has begun at Inchon in Southern Korea on a modern flat-glass plant capable of producing 6,000 tons of window glass a year, the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The United States will miss a great opportunity to reduce world tensions if it abandons his atomic "peace ship" project, President Eisenhower said today.

THE automatic refrigerator is a faithful handmaid of the American housewife at all times, but especially in summer. During the sultry season it turns out shimmering aspics, chilly soups, cold drinks and those delightful desserts that frequently go under the somewhat dated name of "icebox cakes."

Paper companies were highlighted in the merger news yesterday. Crown Zellerbach Corporation, one of the nation's largest papermakers, and Gaylord Container Corporation announced plans for consolidation. The St. Regis Paper Company also is negotiating to acquire the General Container Corporation, Cleveland.

FOURTH of July fare for the family, whether it is eaten in the woods, at the beach or at home, consists of a wide variety of thrifty choices. Smoked and ready-to-eat hams, ready-to-cook turkeys, fresh swordfish and fresh East Coast salmon are all to be found in good supply in the markets.
TORONTO, June 29 (Canadian Press) -- The Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd., had a net profit for the first three months this year of $908,326, it was announced today at the annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Senate and House conferees disagreed with the military judgment of President Eisenhower and his Defense Department today and called for maintaining the strength of the Marine Corps at 215,000 beach-head troops.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Government named today its first sales manager to move surplus farm products.
NEW YORK women will see the first big change in Bergdorf Goodman for more than a quarter of a century when the "Miss Bergdorf" department is opened this August.
TWELVE THOUSAND women spend a fortune in New York every year on clothes. But the money isn't theirs, and the clothes are worn by somebody else.
It was Willie Mays night at Ebbets Field last night. Its effects on the jaded spirits of Leo Durocher's Giants was electrifying, to say the least.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- John L. Lewis is reported to have opened wage talks informally with the northern soft coal operators.
LOS ANGELES, June 29 -- A retired Los Angeles fruit grower was threatened with deportation today for allegedly having said the United States had practiced "germ warfare" in the Korean war.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -Lewis A. Lapham, president of Grace Lines, New York, gave a top priority rating today to a common expiration date for all maritime labor contracts.

The organization and operations of the Central Intelligence Agency should profit greatly from the recommendations passed on to the President by the Hoover Commission and its special task force headed by Gen. Mark Clark.

The United States Court of Appeals upheld yesterday a union's right to maintain an "educational" picket line outside a plant in which a rival union held official certification as the sole bargaining agent.
Most of the programs produced by "Facts Forum" are being consolidated under the supervision of Hardy Burt Productions, which is planning to increase their dissemination by radio and television.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 28 -- Dutch officials are counseling against hopes of meaningful Soviet concessions or conciliation at the Big Four meeting in Geneva.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Navy said today it had withdrawn security clearance from Dr. Fritz Zwicky, a top expert in rocket and jet propulsion, because he had not declared his intention to become an American citizen.
The construction of a subway line to the Rockaway peninsula has brought a modest real estate windfall to the city.
GUATEMALA, June 29 -- The regime of President Carlos Castillo Armas is finishing its first year in power on a favorable note with regard to the nation's economy.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Eisenhower voiced anew today his faith in the foreign-aid program as an effective weapon in the "cold war."
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Highlights of President Eisenhower's news conference today were:

Magistrate Harry G. Andrews dismissed yesterday in Lower Manhattan Court a charge of using slugs instead of dimes in a Hudson and Manhattan Railroad turnstile. The defendant was Max Staloff, 85 years old, of 496 West 187th Street. He operates a hardware store in Jersey City.

The retail grocer has long been burdened with an increasing volume of a latter-day "currency,'' the coupon good for a reduced price on a host of items. Because the coupon represents time and trouble in handling and redemption, the manufacturers who issue them have been making a cash payment of 1 or 2 cents and in some cases as much as 5 cents.

As the murky situation in Argentina clears with painful slowness it may be well to call attention once more to a basic consideration. With it in mind we will be better prepared to interpret such new events as the forced resignations of Angel Borlenghi, Minister of the Interior, and Eduardo Vuletich, Secretary General of the General Confederation of Labor.
The possibility of work stoppages by a few unions in the building construction industry was acknowledged yesterday by a spokesman for the Building Trades Employers Association.
Isabel Troccole of New York reached the semi-final round of the women's Eastern clay court tennis championship yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, June 29 -- The United States Steel Corporation indicated today that it was ready to improve its 10-cent wage rise offer to ward off a national steel strike at midnight tomorrow.
Stock prices, as measured by The New York Times average, yesterday registered the highest closing level in history.

More than $110,000,000, or nearly half of the total net asset value of National Securities Seires, was concentrated in the railroad, iron and steel and nonferrous metals industries, the company announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Wheat futures today moved up from 1 to 1 1/4 cents over Tuesday and held the major portion of the recovery right up to the close. Early in the day the wheat market had to absorb a fair volume of hedge selling but after this was out of the way there was liberal buying.
The city school system was urged yesterday to strengthen its lines of communications, both within its ranks and with the community at large.
A man described as "the worst landlord in the city" failed to appear in court yesterday for sentencing because he had gone to Miami Beach on "urgent business."
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 29 (UP) -- An Air Force C-47 transport plane crashed on Sitkinak Island, ninety miles south of Kodiak today, the Air Force at Elmendorf Air Force Base here reported tonight.
Stockholders of Standard Factors Corporation and of Nathan Straus-Duparquet, Inc., approved yesterday a merger plan making Nathan Straus-Duparquet a subsidiary of Standard Factors.

PARIS, June 29 -- Severe Criticism of past French policy in Algeria and emphasis on the gravity of the uprising there were contained in a report today by members of the French National Assembly. The authors represent four parties.
Grand Central Terminal saw its gayest farewell party of the year yesterday as the annual movement of children to summer camps reached its peak.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 -- Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., was drubbed by Mrs. Beverly Baker Fleitz, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0, in less than forty minutes on the Center Court today in the All-England tennis championships.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 30 -- A discovery that makes it possible to grow polio virus for vaccine in large quantities without the use of expensive monkey kidneys was announced today by three University of California medical researchers.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The release of a quantity of Salk poliomyelitis vaccine under revised Federal safety standards will be considered tomorrow and Saturday by the Public Health Service's technical advisory committee on the vaccine.

Bob Grim, the rookie-of-the-year in the American League last season, was placed on the thirty-day disabled list by the New York Yankees yesterday. Ted Gray, a 30-year-old southpaw, was signed as a free agent to fill Grim's position on the pitching staff.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Lewis A. Lapham, president of the Grace Lines, said today that two new passenger-cargo liners would be built for the Latin-American Caribbean run.

Stanley Resor, long a leader in advertising, is leaving the position of president of J. Walter Thompson Company, the world's largest advertising agency. He will become chairman after forty-seven years with the agency, all but a half-dozen of them as president.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- An apartment house that has been the residential choice of several Soviet Union Embassy employes for more than ten years has suddenly lost favor.

Amid a heated controversy over its latest report, the life of the second Hoover Commission officially terminated yesterday after two years of inquiry into the organization and functioning of the Federal Government.

It seems to me that the editorial entitled "To End Fiscal Hangovers" in your issue of June 22 fails to contribute much to general understanding of Federal budget practices or to the proposals of the Hoover Commission on the subject.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Eisenhower took steps tonight toward possible cancellation of the controversial Dixon-Yates private power contract.
PARIS, June 30 -- Theatre critics here generally praised the cast of "The Skin of Our Teeth," which opened here Tuesday night, but some found fault with the play.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 799,472 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

American business men were urged yesterday to reach into their foreign organizations, as well as their domestic operations, for future managers. The advice came from George D. Bryson, vice president for international operations of the General Foods Corporation.
A committee of the Board of Higher Education picked provisional quarters yesterday for the new community college on Staten Island. It is slated to open in September, 1956.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- Congress made a start today toward propping up the Capitol dome. Former President Truman always feared it might topple over on the lawmakers.

New Jersey has just been discovering, or rediscovering, the truth that the Federal grant-in-aid is not necessarily a bargain. The state's Commission on Intergovernmental Relations figured out that New Jersey state and local governments would receive $53,000,000 of Federal grants-in-aid while paying in to Washington $123,000,000 of taxes to help finance the Federal grant program.
WICHITA, Kan., June 30 (AP) -- Fay Crocker of Montevideo, Uruguay, shot a two-over-par 74 today to take the first-round lead in the $7,500 women's National Open golf tournament.

Admiral C. Turner Joy, as chief of the United Nations delegation at the Korean armistice conference at Panmunjom, spent long months in 1951 and 1952 negotiating with the North Koreans and their Chinese allies. On the basis of his experiences. he has written an analysis of the strategy used by the Communists in negotiations with the "free world."
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The New York Stock Exchange and the National Association of Manufacturers took opposite sides today on proposed Federal policing of over - the - counter trading in stock.
CHICAGO, June 30 (UP) -- A new method eliminates the "guesswork" from diagnosing non-paralytic polio quickly and isolating it from similar diseases, a Yale University physician said today.
Despite a holiday forecast of thunder showers, a record 1,200,000 automobiles on highways in and near the city were predicted yesterday for this week-end.

PARIS, June 30 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle said today France's influence in the coming conferences with the Soviet Union would be greater if she had the atomic bomb and if she had delayed the arming of West Germany.
The Premier and Foreign Minister of Denmark said yesterday that the value of his country's export trade with the United States had increased fivefold in the last five years.
J. H. (Casey) Hayes, who does the training for the Christopher T. Chenery string, has a versatile band under his wing this season.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, with prices 10 points lower to 9 points higher than Wednesday.

LONDON, June 30 -- The British Government has invited Greece and Turkey to talks on the status of Cyprus. Bomb outrages by the pro-Greek underground have been directed against British troops on the island colony in the Mediterranean.
Detailed plans for an eighteen-month study of ways to improve the housing of minority groups in the United States were announced yesterday by the Commission on Race and Housing.
A deputy State Liquor Authority commissioner yesterday denounced allegations by the State Commissioner of Investigation that the authority was "rotten from top to bottom" with graft.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The House of Representatives tonight passed the Administration's $3,285,800,000 foreign-aid bill without important changes. The vote was 273 to 128.
Traffic conditions in the city are not getting proper treatment because the Police Department is still lacking in personnel, Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams declared yesterday.
MONTREAL, June 30 (Canadian Press) -- A merger of Dominion Stores and Thrift Stores into a $200,000,000 food chain was confirmed today.
How many building trades workers would report for work today on $600,000,000 worth of projects remained a question last night.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 30 -- Of all the recent visitors here Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India received today the heartfelt welcome.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 30 (AP) -- The possible merger of the Easy Washing Machine Corporation with the Murray Corporation of America, Detroit, was discussed at a directors' meeting here today. The Syracuse Herald-Journal reported.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- At midnight tonight an official group with a long name ends its appointed tenure, and soon thereafter its chairman and in every other respect its outstanding member will be 81 years old. The group under him, like its predecessor, is known by his name, despite its formal title of Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 30 (UP) -- Fernand Leger, French artist, won today the $4,000 grand international prize of the third biennial Modern Art Exposition here.
MOSCOW, June 30 -- Two titans of the chess world, Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union and Samuel Reshevsky of the United States, played to a draw in Moscow tonight.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 30 (AP) -- American and Russian oarsmen took charge of the Royal Henley Regatta today, turning the races into a carnival of foreigners painful for British spectators to behold.

May I congratulate Leonard Buder of your education staff and The New York Times for the lucid piece in the June 17 issue of The Times on the subject of Regents exams? For the first time, to my knowledge, a newspaper has done a complete and very objective job in explaining to the public what the examinations mean, how they origi nated, what their raison d'etre is, etc. Mr. Buder has done a real service.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- President Eisenhower issued a proclamation today limiting imports of rye to 186,000,000 pounds during each of the next two fiscal years, beginning July 1, 1955, and July 1, 1956.
PITTSBURGH, Friday, July 1 -- A strike of 600,000 steel workers shut down mills that produce nine-tenths of the country's steel at midnight last night.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 30 (AP) -- Bolivia will open its first international oil pipeline tomorrow, sending petroleum from the rich Camiri zone to Argentina at the rate of more than 660,000 gallons a day.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender said today he planned to introduce soon a bill to eliminate "manipulation" of wheat prices by speculators who also operate grain warehouses.
NEENAH, Wis., June 30 (AP) -- Cola G. Parker will retire tomorrow as chairman of the Kimberly - Clark Corporation, paper manufacturer, when he reaches mandatory retirement age of 65.
THIS week-end undoubtedly will find heavier fishing on salt and fresh water than any other three-day period of the year, and prospects are generally bright.

The stock market in the first half of this year did the largest business since 1930 and The New York Times combined and industrial averages reached the highest point since the inception of the index in 1911.

MOSCOW, June 30 -- President Eisenhower's statement that there could be no real peace in the world until the satellite states of East Europe were free to choose their own governments, was distributed to Soviet newspapers tonight. Presumably it will be widely published tomorrow.

About three months ago, in the business areas from Fifty-ninth Street to the Battery, river to river, we started the replacement of the small hanging letter boxes by large combination boxes that you now see on the street.
Motorists traveling to and from New York this week-end may expect delays or detours because of repairs, new construction or congestion, on the following routes:
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Premier U Nu of Burma demonstrated today that he did not like to be kept waiting.

MARSTRAND, Sweden, June 30 (Reuters) -- The leading yacht in the first "King of Sweden" trans-Atlantic yacht race in twenty years tonight was tacking up the west coast of Sweden toward its goal at Marstrand.
Acreage tracts in Suffolk and Nassau Counties have been purchased by builders for improvement with housing colonies.
James J. Moran was sentenced yesterday to an additional two years in a Federal Penitentiary and was fined $22,500 in Brooklyn Federal Court.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Army inducted its new Chief of Staff today and the Air Force swore in its incumbent chief for another two-year hitch.
PUSAN, Korea, June 11 -- The most curious visitor at the Automotive Rebuild Shop of the South Korean Army at Pusan was Charles E. Wilson, the briefing officer said.
CHARLES W. HAVENER, has the comfortable proportions of a man who enjoys eating, speaks of the Cranshaw as "the sweetheart of all melons" and says that "a honeydew should feel like a kid glove."
KODIAK, Alaska, June 30 (AP) -- Ten persons were reported today to have been killed in the crash Wednesday of an Air Force C-47 transport on Sitkinak Island.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The weekly average of member bank reserve balances for the week ending June 29 decreased $345,000,000 to $18,653,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff have ordered resumption of the naval air patrol of the Bering Sea that was suspended a week ago.

Representatives of 100,000 maritime workers in the American Federation of Labor yesterday pledged "full physical, financial and moral support" to the drive to unseat the independent International Longshoremen's Association.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Federal Judge Edward M. Curran ordered the Civil Service Commission today to expunge from its records a finding of "reasonable doubt" of the loyalty of John Stewart Service.

A 28-year-old dress buyer started suit in Supreme Court yesterday to recover $425 of vacation money that she lost betting last Monday at the Aqueduct Race Track. She charged that the pari-mutuel laws were discriminatory and in violation of a section of the Penal Law.

Retirement of two large issues of public utility and turnpike bonds lifted the total of bonds called for redemption in June before maturity to $87,496,000 from $74,486,000 in May. The total was the largest since March, but well below the $147,258,000 for June, 1954.

VANCOUVER, B. C., June 30 (AP) -- Bob Rosburg of San Francisco moved three strokes ahead of the field today at the halfway point of the seventy-two-hole $15,000 British Columbia open golf tournament with a twelve-under-par 132.

ROME, June 30 -- Antonio Segni asked President Giovanni Gronchi tonight for more time to assess his chances of forming a new Italian Cabinet. Signor Gronchi consented to extending the deadline to Saturday.
Net earnings of the Parker Rust-Proof Company and its subsidiary increased in the six and eight months through May, the company announced yesterday.
Following were the basic positions taken by industry and union negotiators in the steel dispute:
BUENOS AIRES, June 30 -- The Minister of the Army, Gen. Franklin Lucero, named today a "Special Tribunal of Qualifications" to investigate Argentina's armed forces.
A ten-member citizens committee has been created to study and report on fiscal relations between the state and the city. This was announced yesterday from Governor Harriman's office in Albany.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 29 -- A state of mind that many a woman is acquainted with, though she rarely confesses it to other women, to her husband or to her children, was mentioned out loud at meetings here today. It was boredom.
Recent Soviet press comment three times. As a result much indicates growing concern with of the cotton crop is behind, agriculture.

FAIRFIELD, Calif., June 30 -- Forty - two members of the Symphony of the Air arrived at Travis Air Force Base today, "tired and very disappointed" over a breakdown in travel arrangements after a tour of the Far East.

STRATFORD, Ont., June 30 -- As a professional iconoclast, Tyrone Guthrie is just the man to rescue "The Merchant of Venice" from respectability. His production of the Shakespeare comedy, which opened in the festival tent last evening, is beautiful, humorous, tumultuous and melodramatic.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Eisenhower has invited Democratic and Republican Congressional leaders to a White House meeting July 12 on the position the United States will take at the Big Four conference in Geneva.
TAIPEI, Formosa, June 30 -- Although Britain and Nationalist China have no formal diplomatic relations, they observe an unwritten agreement of live and let live.
WASHINGTON, Friday, July 1 (AP) -- A city-wide transit strike began here early today when last-ditch negotiations to avert a walkout failed.
TRENTON, June 30 -- Federal Judge Phillip Forman moved today to prevent any windfall profits from the sale of two Delaware River bridges in 1948.

The Union Pacific Railroad announced yesterday a $4,607,702 increase in net income for the first five months of 1955 over the like period last year. The company attributed the gain chiefly to a $7,975,563 advance in total operating revenues.

IT was late morning at Ebbets Field and none of the varsity operatives had yet put in an appearance. O nthe diamond were the Dodger Jayvees, extra pitchers and a batch of kids getting tryouts. Al Campanis, a Brooklyn scout, had a fatherly arm draped around a baby-faced youngster.
The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo will make its first Stadium appearance in five years on Saturday evening, July 9, as a highlight of the third week of concerts at Lewisohn Stadium.
Stock prices continued their upward thrust through unexplored territory yesterday. About half of the issues traded finished higher on the day and seventy-two rose to new highs for the year.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Senate passed and President Eisenhower signed today a bill continuing the national debt limit at $281,000,000,000 for another year.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Eisenhower signed tonight a bill to continue the general military draft for four years and the induction of doctors for two years more.

CHICAGO, June 30 (UP) -- Ray Boone knocked in three runs with his eighth homer and a single today to spark the fourth-place Detroit Tigers to a 4-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox. Detroit thus scored a sweep of the three-game series.
BOSTON, June 30 -- Wallace (Bud) Smith, the new lightweight champion of the world, planned for a bright future today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Federal Court of Appeals ruled today that Enrico Soccodato of New York had not lost his American citizenship by serving in the Italian army and voting in Italian elections. It reversed a judgment of Judge Edward M. Curran in United States District Court here.

The United States Department of Labor announced yesterday the appointment of Frank A. Cardillo as chairman of the New York-New Jersey Region II field staff committee. He is now deputy commissioner in charge of the department's bureau of employes compensation.
You published letters on June 9 and 17 dealing with the Palestine situation. Both letters contained gross twisting of facts and call for correction.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 -- "Carousel," the Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical stage success, will be brought to the screen by Twentieth Century-Fox. Reports that rights to the property had been acquired by the studio had been denied consistently over a period of months.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 30 -- Elimination of racial discrimination in the field of recreation was described today as being fully as important as integration in housing, education and other social areas.
X-rays of the injury that Rube Walker of the Dodgers suffered in the eighth inning against the Giants at Ebbets Field yesterday proved negative at Long Island College Hospital last night.

President Eisenhower has resolved the one problem left unsettled at the Big Four foreign ministers' meeting in San Francisco -- namely, the duration of the heads-of-government conference in Geneva later this month. The Soviets, who like to drag out conferences in the hope that the pressure of time will force the other side into otherwise unlikely concessions, have refused to accept a definite time limit on the Geneva meeting, as proposed by the West.

Anna Ehrlich, individually and as executrix of the estate of Benjamin Ehrlich, has sold the two-story dwelling at 1574 Seventy-sixth Street in Brooklyn to Raffaele Bonelli. The sale was negotiated by the Paramount Realty Service as broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Everything isn't serene at "Seventh Heaven." A closing notice, bearing Wednesday's date, was posted on the back-stage bulletin board of the ANTA Theatre. The attraction opened May 24 with Gloria De Haven, Ricardo Montalban, Kurt Kasznar and Robert Clary in the leading roles.

An unusual number of Americans have been in Moscow recently. A few days ago a team of our topnotch weight lifters performed feats of strength to win the plaudits of the Soviet man in the street. Now our chess players, under dogs but undismayed, are displaying American skill at the other end of the competitive spectrum.

GENEVA, June 30 -- Belgium and Luxembourg, supported by the Netherlands, have asked for a waiver of the international trade rules that prohibit discriminatory application of import controls on agricultural products. The rules are those incorporated in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
MADRID, June 30 -- The Spanish police are holding up the visas of two leading Protestant pastors who are planning to attend the Baptist World Alliance meeting in London July 16.

BERLIN, June 30 -- Willi Stoph, architect of East Germany's embryonic armed forces, resigned unexpectedly tonight as Minister of the Interior. Allied observers here interpreted the move as a prelude to his becoming the first East German Defense Minister.

ALBANY, June 30 (AP) -- In other developments today the Guild asked Jacob K. Javits, State Attorney General, to investigate "new, secret strike insurance as a possible conspiracy in violation of the insurance and other laws of the State of New York."

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 30 -- Gov. George M. Leader today signed a bill authorizing an increase in truck weights and sharply raising the fees and penalties for overloading. The signing ended a years-long battle between the railroads and truckers over the so-called "big truck" issue.
LOS ANGELES, June 30 -- Dr. Anna L. Rose Hawkes of Oakland, Calif., was elected president of the American Association of University Women today. She will serve four years.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 30 -- Adios Boy, a 6-1 shot driven by Howard Camden, scored a one-length victory over Philip Scott in the tenth invitation National Pacing Derby for a purse of $25,000 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The winner raced the mile and a quarter in 2:32 2/5.
Governor Harriman has informed the State Power Authority unofficially that he will not approve the proposed Alcoa contract in its present form.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Following are a statement issued by the White House and two documents, all given out today by the White House Press Secretary, James C. Hagerty, on the Dixon-Yates project:

Helping keep families together is the task to which Jewish Family Service has dedicated its energies for eighty years. In the period when tens of thousands of Jewish immigrants were pouring into New York the mission of this affiliate of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies was to steer the new arrivals into the main stream of American life.

LOS ANGELES, June 30 -- William Kimple, 54 years old, a member of the Communist party for eleven years as a Los Angeles police undercover agent, named names of card-carrying local Communists today before the House Un-American Activities subcommittee hearing.
BONN, Germany, June 30 -- The West German Government accepted today the Soviet invitation to discuss the establishment of diplomatic, economic and cultural relations.

WHEN Harry Krehbiel was a boy of twelve in his native Grefrat near Duesseldorf in Germany in 1912, his father got him a $5 violin and set him to scraping on it. When the boy got out of Bridgeport High in Connecticut, in 1915, the father's gift to him was a $50 instrument bought at Friedrich's in Broadway.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Manufacturers' sales set a record in May, the Government disclosed today. At the same time, new business attained the best level since January, 1951.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 30 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Harry J. Lemley ruled for the Government today in its $3,000,000 foreclosure suit against the Westmoreland Manganese Corporation.
A "backward-nations sweepstakes" is taking place in Asia between democratic India and Communist China, T. S. Repplier, president of the Advertising Council, declared yesterday.
ALBANY, June 30 -- The American Newspaper Guild decided today not to defend the employment rights of any of its members who admitted Communist party membership or were convicted of it in court.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The nation's railroads would be permitted to increase their refrigeration charges by 12 per cent if the Interstate Commerce Commission adopts the recommendations of an examiner submitted today.

Directors of the Key Company accepted yesterday an offer of ACF Industries, Inc., to purchase the assets of Key, makers of oil refinery, chemical plant and power plant equipment. Stockholders of Key will vote on the purchase offer at a special meeting in August.

The city of Dayton, Ohio, raised $12,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance the construction of schools. Serial bonds maturing from 1956 to 1980 were sold at public bidding to a syndicate headed by First National City Bank of New York and Northern Trust Company.
GUATEMALA, June 30 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas has not had to worry about formal politics in the first year of his administration. Now it is preparing to move on to the national scene.
HACKENSACK, N. J., June 30 -- Ron Holmberg of Brooklyn and Jack Frost of Monterey, Calif., gained the semi-final round of the Eastern clay court singles championship at the Oritani Field Club today.
Adlai E. Stevenson was disclosed yesterday to have had separate meetings in New York this week with Governor Harriman of New York and Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Western Union Telegraph Company today filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an issue of 1,041,393 common shares of $2.50 par.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Hoover Commission went out of existence today and former President Hoover asserted that adoption of its proposals would save enough money to balance the Federal budget and cut taxes.

Concert versions of two Sigmund Romberg operettas, "New Moon" and "The Desert Song," were offered at Lewisohn Stadium last night by the Stadium Symphony Orchestra and soloists under the direction of Franz Allers.
THREE more art galleries have opened summer group shows with the coming of July.
EDMONTON, Alberta, June 30 (Canadian Press) -- The Social Credit Government was returned to office in yesterday's elections with a reduced but firm majority.

BUFFALO, June 30 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court justice today told the police he was fired upon last night by unknown assailants. He reluctantly suggested today that friends of juveniles he had sentenced to prison might have been responsible.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The foreign aid program, under which the United States has spent some $51,000,000,000 since the end of World War II, will be under new management beginning tomorrow.

Wreckers, diggers and builders have been making over the Middle and Upper East Side. But with their booming activity is coming heartbreak for residents being forced from one of the city's oldest communities -- solid Yorkville.
State rent controls were lifted last night from 272,500 housing units, all upstate, in accordance with a law enacted at the last session of the Legislature.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- After trading back and forth largely over a 1 1/2-cent range, wheat futures closed tonight with July showing only a fractional loss. On the other hand, the more deferred deliveries were up from 1/4 to 7/8 cent.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 30 -- The United States is facing increasing competition in Latin American markets from the Soviet Union and nations of the Soviet bloc, a United Nations agency reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson declined on security grounds today to make public answers to questions Senator Henry I. Jackson, Iemocrat of Washington, asked about United States-Russian air power.
An eleventh-inning pinch single by George Shuba gave the Dodgers a nerve-tingling 6-5 victory over the Giants at Ebbets Field yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Federal Court of Appeals upheld today a lower court ruling that Maj. Gen. P. T. Mow owed the Republic of China $6,368,503 plus interest and costs.

The profit on food is so short that food outlets are being pushed more and more into adding nonfood wares to sweeten their take. Drugs, small clothing items that lend themselves to packaging and unattended selling, hardware and such -- all have taken their places on the supermarket shelves.

Alberta, the westernmost of Canada's three prairie provinces, has gone Social Credit again. It is perennially fascinating to see the play of provincial politics in Canada with its attraction for the eccentric and regional parties. Some of the provinces, like Ontario and Quebec, vote one way in provincial elections and another in national polls.
TOKYO, Friday, July 1 (AP) -- Two faint radio signals flickering out of the Pacific fog sparked slight new hope in the concentrated hunt for four lost Marine airmen, in its fifth day today.

Charles Grutzner, who testified yesterday before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee in Washington, has been a reporter for The New York Times since December, 1941. He has been a newspaper man for more than thirty years.
NORWALK, Conn., June 30 -- Patrick B. McGinnis invaded this hotbed of commuter protest tonight and served notice that protest would get them nowhere.
The Ex-Cell-O Corporation and subsidiaries, producers of machine tools, precision parts and dairy equipment, yesterday reported a net profit of $5,303,078 for the six months ended May 31.

Two new films open today at first run theatres. At the Mayfair is "House of Bamboo," a Twentieth Century-Fox melodrama starring Shirley Yamaguchi and Robert Ryan. Other featured players are Robert Stack, Cameron Mitchell and Brad Dexter.
Norman Thomas, the nation's best-known Socialist, resigned yesterday from the Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Charles Grutzner, a reporter for The New York Times, was accused by Senate investigators today of having sent two dispatches from the Korean war front in 1950 that indirectly helped the Communists.
BALTIMORE, June 30 (AP) -- A Teamsters Union, A. F. L., official said tonight a strike had been called against the Railway Express Agency at 12:01 A. M (local time) Tuesday, July 5.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Congress sent to President Eisenhower today a $31,882,815,726 appropriations bill for the armed services for the fiscal year opening tomorrow.

Directors of Chesebrough-Pond's, Inc., yesterday elected Jerome A. Straka as president and chief executive officer. Arthur B. Richardson becomes chairman of the board. The merger of Chesebrough Manufacturing Company, Consolidated, and Pond's Extract Company was approved by stockholders last Monday.
An American Mozart Festival, commemorating the two-hundredth anniversary of the composer's birth, will be held at Columbia University next April.
Turner Catledge, managing editor of The New York Times, issued the following statement last night:
Public offerings of new securities here in June and in the first six months of 1955 were smaller than in the corresponding periods last year.

A leading observer of the economic scene has taken a look at the record level of consumer debt and concluded that there is no cause for alarm -- at least now. The First National City Bank of New York, in its July bank letter, says that while the more than $31,000,000,000 in consumer debt appears large, it should be placed in perspective against disposable income and liquid assets or savings.

Charles Munch, music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, will arrive here today by plane from his home in Paris. He will drive immediately to Lenox, Mass., to prepare for his fifth season as conductor of the Berkshire Music Festival.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- Lower prices for wholesale fresh pork and an oversupply of hogs sent prices 25 to 50 cents lower today. Cattle were steady to 25 cents higher and sheep steady. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
GAZA, June 30 -- According to an authoritative account, it was a disagreement between Egypt and the United Nations truce chief that led to suspension of the Egyptian-Israeli talks here yesterday.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 30 -- Pakistan decided today to join the military alliance formed in February by Turkey, Iraq and Britain.
Loans to business by leading New York City banks increased $11,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. This was the third straight weekly increase.
There is something new under the sun.
VALLEY STREAM, L. I., June 30 -- Ground was broken here this morning by three generations of the Gimbel family for a suburban branch of Gimbel Brothers, Inc.

The Civil Aeronautics Board has received airline interchange agreements and proposals that would provide one-plane service between the eastern United States and the Canal Zone via Miami. The agreements were filed in Washington yesterday by Pan American World Airways and National Airlines.

Futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges continued yesterday to drift in dull and featureless trading. Lead volume, however, was the second heaviest of the year. Wool, sugar, cottonseed oil and potatoes declined. Coffee and soybean oil were mixed. Hides, rubber, lead, zinc, copper and cocoa rose.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 30 -- Anti-Communist, pro-French elements in the western Cameroons appealed today to the Trusteeship Council. They seek help in combating the Union des Populations Camerounaise. A petition circulated today asserts that the organization, led by Ruben Um Nyobe, is Communist-dominated.
According to the calendar, summer began at 12:32 A. M. on June 22. But as far as the city's 900,000 public school pupils were concerned, the change did not occur until 3 P. M., yesterday
LONDON, June 30 -- Stock prices rallied today although the volume of trading declined further.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Perjury charges against Owen Lattimore were dismissed today in a quiet courtroom where some of the bitterest battles in the celebrated case had been fought.
SANTIAGO, Chile, June 30 -- Argentina today is a puzzled and uneasy country. But one thing is clear: President Juan D. Peron is still directing it.
DAMASCUS, Syria, June 30 (Reuters) -- The United States was accused today of having negotiated with a Syrian political group concerning a plot for the overthrow of the Syrian Government.

"The Theology of Jazz" will be one of the highlights of an experimental series announced yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System television network and the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The president of General Motors Corporation, Harlow H. Curtice, has declined an invitation to testify before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee on anti-trust and monopoly matters. He said he did not know enough about automobile company mergers to be helpful.

Plans for a new six-story apartment building opposite St. Gabriel's Park were announced yesterday as William Intner, realty operator, bought a plot 75 by 98.9 feet at 318 to 322 East Thirty-fifth Street, between First and Second Avenues.
A Navy program to acquire the use of urgently needed tankers built and financed by private concerns moved one more step toward fruition yesterday.
Michael J. Quill urged yesterday that Governor Harriman act to abolish the state-created City Transit Authority and restore control over city-owned facilities to local administration.
The coordinated Communist campaign to induce refugees from Communist-ruled countries to return home has been stepped up substantially in the last few weeks.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Democrats hailed as a major political victory today the apparent decision of the Eisenhower Administration to cancel the Dixon-Yates private power contract.
Armed men got away with a total of $7,000 in two Brooklyn holdups yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, July 1 -- The United States Steel Corporation announced tonight that its prices would go up an average of $7.50 a ton. The price rise came in the wake of a strike settlement that gave the company's 170,000 union employes a wage increase of 15 cents an hour.

The Consumer Power Company has decided to go under-ground. The decision of the big Michigan utility has nothing to do with any subversive movement. It means that, in an age of hydrogen bombs, the company's new power control center will be built where it could survive almost any disaster.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 1 -- The Federal Supreme Court's switch from the "separate but equal" doctrine to the nonsegregation ruling for public education was pictured today as a result of an evolution in social science thought.
A period of only moderate activity is ahead for distributors of new issues of investment securities.
Stepping out of its traditional Casper Milquetoast role, the Municipal Art Commission has vetoed the city's proposed $13,000,000 modernistic municipal courts building.
Residential fire insurance rates of the Allstate Insurance Company in this state must be 15 instead of 20 per cent below those charged by fire insurance companies generally.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 1 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali said today that unless India and Afganistan settled their disputes with Pakistan soon "there can be no basis for cooperation and friendship."
MARSTRAND, Sweden, Saturday, July 2 (Reuters) -- The fifty-four-foot American yawl Carina early today was first across the finish line in the 3,450-mile trans-Atlantic yacht race from Newport, R. I.
MOSCOW, July 1 -- Samuel Reshevsky of the United States scored a clean-cut victory today over the chess champion of the world, Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union.

The United States Court of Appeals reversed yesterday the conviction of Joseph P. Ryan, lifetime boss of the independent International Longshoremen's Association. His counsel, Louis Waldman, hailed the decision as a "landmark in the development of labor law."
Trading was very light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Many investors left the city early to start the long week-end. Most of the light volume involved evening of holdings.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Even if a television speaker appears to be looking you frankly in the eye, he may still be reading a script. The mechanical prompter patented this week by Luther G. Simjian for the Reflectone Corporation of Stamford, Conn., makes this possible. It's done with a transparent mirror.

Peace that seemed early yesterday to have been assured in the $600,000,000 building industry in the metropolitan area became doubtful last night. One of the many unions involved rejected a proposed settlement.

SUFFERN,, N. Y., July 1 -- A Route 17 traffic bottleneck that has delayed thousands of motorists many hours over the last twenty years apparently ended at 2 P. M. today. A one-mile stretch of the New York State Thruway was opened from Hill-burn to the New Jersey border.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The White House announced today the United States delegation to the Big Four meeting in Geneva July 18 would consist of ten persons. It will be headed by President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles.
WATSEKA, Ill., July 1 (AP) -- One man was killed and twenty-nine persons were reported injured today when a Chicago and Eastern Illinois train carrying 110 passengers was derailed at Papineau, Ill.

The big wave of spending and lending during the first half of 1955 has pushed up the cost of borrowing money. As a direct result, yields have also gone up for such investments as United States Government obligations, state and local bonds and fixed-income corporate securities.

PARAMUS, N. J., July 1 -- The 165-mile Garden State Parkway was opened in its entirety today. State officials predicted that it would be extended soon to connect with the New York State Thruway. Gov. Robert B. Meyner cut the traditional ribbon at noon to mark the completion of the final four-mile link from East Paterson northward to this community.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States today opposed a return to mandatory farm price supports at a fixed level.

PITTSBURGH, July 1 (AP) -- Statements on the steel settlement today by David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., and Clifford F. Hood, president of the United States Steel Corporation:

On May 11 The New York Times printed a letter from Councilmen Stein and Mirabile discussing New York City's traffic problems. On May 18 The Times printed a letter by Mrs. Emma Albert, who described herself as Safety Chairman of the Sixty-third Precinct Coordinating Council, Inc., among other titles, which criticized the Councilmen's letter.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- An Administration official said tonight he understood that Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby would resign in "a week or so, maybe sooner," as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 1 -- Train No. 351 from Norwalk to Grand Central was fifty-three minutes late here this morning, but even so, many commuters missed it in a confused scramble at the station.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Wheat futures lost 1 to 1 1/2 cents on the near-by deliveries in today's trading session, but the far March and May parted company with the others. The March was off only fractionally while the May showed a gain of 3/8 to 5/3 cent for the session.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A preliminary report on Operation Alert was discussed by President Eisenhower and members of his Cabinet today.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The House Interior Committee today approved a bill increasing quantities of strategic domestic minerals that may be purchased by the Government for the national stockpile.
Continuing their reign of terror against second-division opposition, the Yankees routed the Senators, 7 -- 2, before 5,037 sweltering spectators at the Stadium yesterday.
MOSCOW, July 1 -- Soviet aviation progress, which has aroused so much interest and concern in the United States, was extolled in the highest terms in the Moscow press today.

MADRID, July 1 -- Falange party leaders indicated today that they opposed the claim of Don Juan of Bourbon to the Spanish throne. They said that if Spain was to have a king he should be Juan Carlos, the 17-year-old son of the Pretender.

Health officials of New York City and Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties agreed yesterday that further inoculations of Salk anti-polio vaccine should be delayed until next fall. This course is to be followed even if supplies become available this summer.
LOS ANGELES, July 1 -- The American Association of University Women was awarded a citation tonight for its work in behalf of educational television.
Thousands of New Yorkers took to the not-so-open road yesterday in pursuit of fresh air, sunshine and recreation over the long Fourth of July week-end.

In June of 1939, William and Emilia Zweck were married, a short ten weeks before Hitler invaded their Polish homeland. An officer in the Polish army, William Zweck was soon captured and held prisoner in Bavaria until the Americans liberated him in 1945. But his wife and their infant daughter he had never seen were caught in Soviet-occupied Poland.

The state of New Mexico announced yesterday plans for borrowing $14,000,000 to finance the construction of institutional buildings. The borrowing will take two forms. An issue of $9,500,000 is to be secured by special taxes.

The Department of Parks, thus far unable to obtain money to restore the crumbling Soldiers and Sailors Monument, has done the next best thing. It has fenced off part to protect the public from possible injury.
NEW DELHI, India, July 1 -- All over India today workmen were taking down signs that read "Imperial Bank of India" and putting up new signs. The news ones read: "State Bank of India."

The American Civil Liberties Union released yesterday an exchange of correspondence with the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service. The letters of the civil liberties group denounced the jailing of persons facing deportation proceedings. The service rejected the protest.
Efforts to bring religious faith and ideals to bear upon political problems will be evident in churches this week-end.
Home furnishings departments were the leaders in New York department stores last month Retailers scored gains averaging 5 per cent over the volume for June of 1954.
The stock market soared yesterday after news of the steel strike settlement.
Edward R. Murrow's radio news broadcasts, heard Mondays through Fridays at 7:45 P. M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System, are being presented under new arrangements.

HONG KONG, July 1 -- The Chinese Communists asserted tonight that one of the three United States soldiers who changed their minds about living under communism had slashed his skin in a "bluff" at suicide.
FORT WORTH, Tex., July 1 (UP) -- The will of Amon G. Carter, newspaper publisher and oil man, filed for probate today, provides bequests of some $800,000 for friends and associates.
One of three State Liquor Authority employes concerned in contempt proceedings for declining to answer financial queries resigned yesterday as the cases went to court.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 1 (AP) -- Finland's Pentti Karvonen bettered the listed world record for the 3,000-meter steeplechase today in a track meet against a team of touring Americans. But his time of 8:47.8 was not the best ever run on the Olympic Stadium track.
The often postponed truck loading and unloading tariff of the Port of New York Waterfront Terminal Operators has been delayed once again.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 1 -- President Tito and Prime Minister Jahawarlal Nehru joined today in an optimistic appraisal of the world situation. They also claimed credit for contributing to the lessening of world tension through their espousal of a policy of active coexistence.

LONDON, July 1 -- Seven parish priests of the Church of England returned from a visit to Moscow today with the conviction that there was "peaceful coexistence" between the church and state in the Soviet Union. They said relations between high officials on both sides were "cordial."

" THE HUNTING WASP,"* by John Crompton, is a remarkable book of bold, ruthless adventure. There are safaris here to rank with the wildest out of Africa. There are tales of premeditated murder that would cause a certain amount of eyebrow raising in the coolest gangster societies. If you are venturing into the untamed country this week-end, take a copy along as a guide to what goes on in the busier insect circles.

Stephen Messana's Harlem Maid took the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. While a crowd of 16,461 looked on, the 6-year-old daughter of Grand Admiral contributed a front-running performance to win the mile - and - a - quarter event by a neck over Ogden Phipps' Bassanio.
ALBANY, July 1 (AP) -- Richard H. Balch, retiring Democratic state chairman, was sworn in today as a member of the State Public Service Commission for a full ten-year term.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that it had revoked the operating authority of the four non-scheduled airlines operating as North American Airlines.

The Sayville Airport property, comprising 122 acres on the west side of Broadway, south of Sunrise Highway, in Sayville, L. I., has been purchased by a syndicate represented by Henry David Epstein. The Seldein Organization and Robert A. Bernhard were the brokers in the transaction.
PARIS, July 1 -- Jacques Soustelle, Governor General of Algeria, reported today that the French drive against terrorists in Algeria had met with success and that the outlook had improved.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Lynn D. Poole, director of public relations for Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, was named president-elect of the American College Public Relations Association tonight at the association's convention.
Music becomes more and more complicated. Ferde Grofe's "Hudson River," which will receive its first performance Monday night at Lewisohn Stadium, calls for the noise of a bowling alley.

Governor Harriman and Mayor Wagner have now appointed a ten-member committee to examine the fiscal relations between state and city. The prime purpose is to determine the fairness or lack of fairness of state financial aid to New York.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The index of average primary prices declined 0.3 point over the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Declines in average prices for farm products and processed foods accounted for the decrease, as the index for industrial commodities remained unchanged.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had increased. Its latest offering of $1,600,000,000 in ninety-one day bills was sold at a price equal to an annual interest rate of 1.541 per cent.

Archie Moore, the world light-heavyweight boxing champion, attained his most elusive goal yesterday. He was matched to meet Rocky Marciano for the world heavyweight championship in a bout that he had been seeking for more than a year.
Net sales and profits of the Champion Paper and Fibre Company increased in the year ended March 31.

The Estate Securities Company, realty operators, bought the seven-story apartment house on plot 150 by 150 feet at 122 West 114th Street, at St. Nicholas Avenue, from the Rutley Realty Corporation and immediately resold it to Tom Maloof.
ALBANY, July 1 -- The State Education Department named Dr. Walter B. Emery of Washington today to head a study of the value of educational television and New York's progress in the field.

ROME, July 1 -- The paradox of the cold war is that both ideological blocs use the same words to express contradictory ideas. "Peace," "freedom" and "democracy" are terms as commonly employed in the Soviet Union as in the United States. But in semantics, the meaning of meaning, they are poles apart. The resulting confusion of abstract concepts is even more dangerous when practically applied.
BUENOS AIRES, July 1 -- President Juan D. Peron partly solved his Cabinet crisis today by swearing in four new ministers.
DENVER, July 1 (AP) -- Three of the nation's largest copper producers were shut down by a strike today. However, a union spokesman said that there were "some real prospects of settlement soon."
ALBANY, July 1 -- Joseph F. Collis of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., was re-elected today to a second term as president of the American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O.
The two members of the new three-man Transit Authority announced yesterday, as they assumed office, that they had arrived at their choice of a chairman.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 1 -- The Town Board of Assessors has assessed the interest of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation in a Navy jet plane assembly plant here at $742,800 for this year and $496,000 for last year.
CHICAGO, July 1 (UP) -- Joe Louis, former heavyweight boxing champion, testified in an income tax case today that he had ended up owing more taxes in 1946 than he had made from boxing.
TOKYO, July 1 -- Japan celebrated today the first anniversary of the establishment of her postwar defense forces.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 1 -- Westchester County's experimental barring of out-of-county residents from its Saxon Woods Golf Course this year has produced one clear-cut result: The golfers who still crowd the first tee each dawn are all Westchesterites.
A movie theatre's advertising was called "lewd" yesterday, and several complainants urged that its license to operate be terminated.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- A Government labor official predicted today that unions negotiating new contracts this year would "raise their sights" now that steel workers have won a 15-cent-an-hour wage increase.

Nicaragua has replaced its system of multiple exchange rates for imports with a single buying rate of seven cordobas to one United States dollar, according to advices yesterday from Managua, the country's capital. The new rate is effective immediately.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower set up tonight an emergency board to investigate a dispute between the Railway Express Agency, Inc., and the Teamsters Union, A. F. L., in nine cities across the nation.

Not only the steel industry and its thousands of workers, but the country as a whole, should find it possible to enjoy this long Fourth of July week-end in a spirit of greater relaxation now that a prolonged nation-wide strike in the steel industry has been averted.
The 24-year-old woman driver who struck a fire engine and caused a series of crashes at Fifty-second Street and Seventh Avenue on June 24 was found guilty yesterday.
June's total of donations to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program amounted to 11,827 pints. Included were 378 pints given last Thursday.
William De Koning Jr., who was convicted with his father last year in a shakedown racket among Long Island contractors and union members, was named yesterday in an unfair-labor- practices complaint.

Six letters addressed to employed persons 50 to 60 years old to help them with problems of their approaching retirement have been published by the National Association for Mental Health. The series is entitled "Notes After Fifty."
Besides conducting the affairs of his theatre tour venture for peripatetic theatregoers, Alexander H. Cohen is busy drawing the blueprints for two forthcoming productions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 1 -- Fess Parker, who died nobly at the Alamo as "Davy Crockett," will die again for Walt Disney but perhaps not quite as heroically -- at least not in the eyes of audiences below the Mason-Dixon Line -- in "The Great Locomotive Chase."
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Jefferson School of Social Sciences in New York was ordered today to register as a Communist front by the Subversive Activities Control Board.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 1 (AP) -- The Nebraska Supreme Court ruled today that the amendment to the state constitution prohibiting union shop agreements took precedence over the Federal Railway Labor Act permitting them.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Live hog prices varied from steady to 50 cents lower today as receipts over night again were around 500 head higher than the trade had expected. Cattle and vealers were steady to weak Sheep were steady. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 -- Tony Trabert is the Wimbledon tennis champion. In a crushing display of power worthy of the best players of bygone eras, the American routed Kurt Nielsen of Denmark, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 1, in the men's singles final of the all-England championships today.
DETROIT, July 1 -- United States car and truck manufacturers completed yesterday their biggest half-year of production in the history of the industry.
CHAUDOC, Vietnam, July 1 -- The Vietnamese National Army has begun mopping-up operations in the rugged Thatson (Seven Mountains) region near here.
MOSCOW, July 1 -- A group of United States Quakers handed to the Soviet Government today a proposal for modifying the control and inspection provisions of its world disarmament plan.
The Dodgers, following their three exciting games with the Giants, seemed to suffer a pardonable letdown at Ebbets Field last night.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson asked secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson today to give him information on relative United States-Soviet military strength in secret if Mr. Wilson will not do so publicly.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, asked Congress today to pass a law that would permit the Justice Department to compel the production of documents required in civil antitrust investigations.
High Government officials joined representatives of the Free Europe Committee and the Downtown Manhattan Association yesterday in celebrating the first anniversary of Freedom Day.
WICHITA, Kan., July 1 (AP) -- Fay Crocker of Montevideo, Uruguay, today fired an even-par 72 to increase her lead at the halfway point in the women's national open golf tournament to eight strokes.
Ten thousand claims for pay increases for city laborers were filed yesterday with Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa.
FLORENCE, Italy, June 24 -- The goldsmiths and jewelers whose shops have stood for six centuries on the Ponte Vecchio are facing ruin.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -- Pope Talbot, Inc., is suspending its steamship freight service between West Coast ports and Puerto Rico after operating in that trade for thirty years.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Senate Democrats stepped up their assault on the Dixon-Yates power contract today and moved to turn it into a weapon against the Administration.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Bills involving several billion dollars in Government spending were acted on in Congress today.

WESTCHESTER not only has beautiful parkways to entice motorists, but good restaurants that extend an irresistible invitation over a long week-end such as this. The county's eating establishments are so numerous that only some in the west part may be put up for discussion today. At all of them, reservations are recommended on any summer week-end.

The news that the British Government has invited Greece and Turkey to talks on the status of Cyprus will be received with widespread relief. This was not one of the major headaches of the world today, but it was a gnawing, exasperating ill that had serious potentialities.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Eisenhower's public housing program failed today to win Rules Committee clearance for consideration by the House of Representatives.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A bus and trolley strike brought a jam of private cars to downtown Washington today. No settlement of the dispute was in sight.

The recently completed elections in Pakistan have served several important purposes. First of all, eight months of "Governor's Rule" have been brought to a close. The new Constituent Assembly is the symbol of representative government. This Assembly is charged, at this time, not merely with legislative functions but also with the drafting and adoption of the permanent Constitution for Pakistan which has been thus far delayed.
Defeated in one suicide attempt, a woman plunged to her death minuts later in the financial district yesterday as policemen ran forward to deter her.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The late Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, then Chief of Staff of the Air Force, was identified today as the Pentagon official who had cleared for publication a New York Times dispatch on the introduction of the F-86 Sabre Jet fighter plane in the Korean fighting in December, 1950.

PITTSBURGH, June 30 -- In the inflationary period after World War II the statisticians who charted the stratospheric flight of the wage-price spiral evolved the maxim that "as steel goes so goes the economy."

A prediction that "Not As a Stranger" would "gross at least eight to ten million dollars in the United States and Canada" was made yesterday by George J. Schaefer, general representative of Stanley Kramer Pictures.

CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ind., July 1 (UP) -- Bob Lawson. a 20-year-old freshman from Southern California, forged into the lead at the half-way mark of the National Amateur Athletic Union decathlon championship with 3,886 points today.

FORT LEE, N. J., July 1 -- About 8,000 orphaned and crippled children had their day today at Palisades Amusement Park at the nineteenth annual outing of the Police Anchor Club of New York. From the peals of laughter from the 500 policmen and women and the 300 Roman Catholic sisters who accompanied the children, it was difficult to tell whether young or old had the best time.
DEDHAM, Mass., July 1 -- A Norfolk probate judge ordered today the arrest of a couple who had failed to comply with his decision that they give up a 4-year-old girl.
The transport Upshur will sail from the New York Port of Embarkation today with some 2,200 soldiers and their dependents, the first major move in Operation Gyroscope.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 1 -- That currently popular topic of dinner-table conversation, dieting, was discussed at meetings here this week. They were attended by some of the 3,000 home economists participating in the annual conference of the American Home Economics Association.

An analysis of the role of the middle class in the development of human culture will be issued in September by Rinehart, entitled "The Crisis of the Middle Class." The author is Henry Grayson, associate professor of economics at the University of Maryland.
LOS ANGELES, July 1 -- The Ford Motor Company plans a major expansion in the Los Angeles area, it was learned today.
KIEL, Germany, July 1 (UP) -- Fourteen small United States war vessels lend-leased to the Soviet Union during World War II docked here tonight to be returned to the United States Navy.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Government approval of a sale of 100 passenger cars to Bulgaria has touched off a considerable volume of inquiries on possible sales of autos and other goods behind the Iron Curtain.

One of the four king penguins at the Bronx Zoo has laid an egg -- the first time a captive king penguin has done so in the United States. In addition to this phenomenon, family trouble has arisen among the penguins. And still further, zoo officials know now that there is at least a queen among the kings -- but which one?
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, July 1 (AP) -- Four main financial advisers to Prince Rainier III, ruler of this gambling casino realm, have been suspended after a panic at Monaco's principal bank.
MOSCOW, July 1 -- An international gathering to discuss peaceful uses of nuclear energy opened here today under Soviet auspices.
GUATEMALA, July 1 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas is facing an opposition that is growing in strength and vociferousness.
The police have started to crack down on taxicabs with fast meters that cause passengers to be overcharged.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The long-blocked bill to build trained and ready military Reserves from 700,000 to 2,900,000 by 1960 was passed by the House of Representatives today.
THE school tuna fishing has improved considerably during the past three days. A number of boats at Long Island ports have brought in from five to fourteen fish, some scaling almost fifty pounds.
In your editorial of June 25 on Puerto Rican wages you suggest that Congress should not act on the bill passed by the Senate "before they are sure what the results will be."

Two newly ordained Roman Catholic priests flew yesterday to Puerto Rico to serve a year's apprenticeship before taking up the problems of Puerto Ricans in New York parishes. An undergraduate of New York Seminary accompanied the priests to the Caribbean island. Another seminarian will leave July 17.

LONDON, July 1 -- Anxiety over any change in the defense arrangements for northwest Europe that might result from the Big Four meeting in Geneva has been expressed by members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The State Department eased visa regulations today to encourage more persons to visit the United States.
Tony Trabert, now the world's foremost tennis amateur after his triumph at Wimbledon, looks more like a football player than a tennis star.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The president of the American Stock Exchange said today that a bill to extend Government regulations to many stocks not now listed on major exchanges was in the public interest and should be adopted by Congress.
PITTSBURGH, July 1 -- The shortest steel strike in the country's history ended today with a pay increase of 15 cents an hour.
A swarm of 5,000 French bees visiting here has demonstrated an uncanny ability to tell time without the aid of the sun.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -- The nation's biggest bank is growing bigger. New highs in resources, deposits and loans were reported today in a mid-year statement of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 1 (AP) -- Russian rowers today lost the Grand Challenge Cup, the Royal Henley Regatta's top trophy, when they were defeated by a virtually unheralded Canadian crew.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Premier U Nu of Burma, who never wears a tie, got a 4-H Club tie clasp today. At the same time the Department of Agriculture, which has no use for striped pants, acquired a protocol officer.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 2 (AP) -- One of four missing United States Marine airmen was found dead yesterday in the wreckage of his jet plane. The jet had crashed on a volcanic island normally avoided by fliers because of the tricky winds that swirl above it.
COIMBRA, Portugal, July 1 -- Eight Portuguese jet fighter pilots rode to death in formation today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 -- Manager Leo Durocher and Whitey Lockman were thrown out of the game in the seventh inning and the Giants were thrown out of contention in the eighth at Connie Mack Stadium tonight.
The Coast Guard believes it has as big a traffic problem as the City of New York, albeit a watery one.

LOS ANGELES, July 1 (AP) -- Isabel Bonner, New York actress, died on stage tonight playing the lead in "The Shrike," the 1952 Pulitzer Prize play written by her husband, Joseph Kramm. The actress who was 47 years old, was playing opposite Dane Clark.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 1 -- The Mayor of Memphis said tonight that his city already was "definitely committed" to the construction of its own power plant, and had been for more than a week.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 1 -- Martial law was declared in six provinces of Chile today as a transport and communications strike virtually paralyzed the country. Thirty-seven thousand workers were reported out.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, July 2 (AP) -- Prince Rainier III created a new Cabinet post and put an elder statesman in it today in an apparent effort to bolster confidence in the Monaco Government after a run on the principal bank. No official would talk about the duties of the new minister.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 2 -- The Moslem League party took the first step today toward relinquishing its eight-year control of the Government to a three-party coalition.
How long can it last?

DUESSELDORF, Germany, July 2 (AP) -- A touring United States track team won six events today in an international track meet before a crowd of 15,000. The Americans swept all except one event in which they started and in that race placed second.
MOSCOW, July 2 -- Your Moscow correspondent is not lonesome any more. In fact he has developed an acute case of professional ochlophobia.
CLEVELAND, July 2 -- The Ford Motor Company has joined other Cleveland concerns in recruiting skilled craftsmen in Canada, but on a much larger scale, company spokesmen said today.
