THE momentum of increased sales and greater production has carried the economy along at a much faster pace than even the most optimistic predictions. At the halfway mark, 1955 is far and away the best year for business and now there are very few who can see any heavy clouds on the horizon for at least another six months.
UNKNOWN to most concertgoers, and to most professional musicians also, is the Symphony No. 3 by Borodin. The Russian composer left the score unfinished -- only two movements were completed.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 2 -- Doubledogdare of the Claiborne Farm won the $27,950 Colleen Stakes at Monmouth Park today. Under a determined ride by Jimmy Nichols, the daughter of Double Jay came through on the outside to win by three lengths over Helen W. Kellogg's Dark charger.

The threat of a steel strike, which became a reality for a short period on Friday, cast a shadow over the stock market for a while last week. When a settlement was reached, however, stocks turned strong and active to end the week at the highest level in history.

THRILLING performances by the Philadelphia Orchestra under the direction of Eugene Ormandy climaxed the series of nine concerts comprising the fifth annual Sibelius Festival. The festival was held in the middle of June in this "white city of the North."

BUENOS AIRES, July 2 -- Leonide Massine scored a critical and popular triumph last night with the premiere of his new ballet, "Usher." The audience, which completely filled the Teatro Colon, reserved its greatest ovation for the ballet based on Edgar Allan Poe's story "The Fall of the House of Usher."

IN "The Raiders," William E. Wilson, novelist, college professor, magazine contributor and quondam newspaper reporter, has built a thinly plotted story out of the sparse fragments of a Civil War cavalry incident. Background of the action was a raid in July, 1863, when Confederate forces under Gen. John Hunt Morgan crossed the river from Kentucky for a strike into Ohio and Indiana.

IT was with understandable shock that Fray Juan, youthful Spanish priest of the Discalced Reform founded by St. Teresa, found himself before the austere Pope Clement VIII, sometime during the first years of the seventeenth century.
TOKYO, July 2 -- Residents of a near-by town have forcibly prevented surveys of land for expansion of the Tachikawa air base.

THE higher - speed Ektachrome color film which was introduced in the 35mm and 828 sizes in January was made available by Eastman Kodak last week in the 120-620 rollfilm sizes as well. Offered in 32 A. S. A. Daylight and 16 A. S. A. Type F (flash) emulsions, the new size costs $1.25 a roll of twelve 2 1/4x2 1/4-inch or eight 2 1/4x3 1/4-inch transparencies.

In the very interesting and informative article about song-writers Richard Adler and Jerry Ross -- "Upbeat for a Song Writing Duo" (June 19) -- Gilbert Millstein states that Adler's first lyric, written at the age of 7, was "set to music by a pupil of Aaron Copland."

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 4 -- 3, today for the seventh straight time. Randy Jackson and Walker Cooper hit home runs during the Cubs' three-run eighth inning before 15,623.

SINCE Jose Ferrer is not the man to rusticate, it should be noted that the actor-director, who is currently involved in two movie projects and is preparing to start a third in October, has just acquired two additional properties.

The New York Tow Boat Exchange has re-elected its present officers, headed by James P. McAllister, president, according to William E. Cleary, executive vice president. The election was held at the annual meeting last week.

AS a direct result of a letter that appeared in The Drama Mailbag, written by Mrs. Ida Martus, chairman of the School and Theatre Committee, I was privileged to escort a group of boys and girls to their first contact with the theatre, thanks to the generosity of Charles Bloomfield of National Theatre Tickets, who arranged for them to see "Anastasia" for 25 cents apiece.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 30 -A district court judgment asserting a Hungarian Zionist leader made "a secret front with the Nazis" in Budapest in 1944 has become the most heated issue in Israeli political life. Israel will hold parliamentary elections July 26.

MOSCOW, July 2 -- A lone pair of players faced each other across the chessboard in the match between the United States and the Soviet Union tonight. They were the lowest ranking members of the two teams -- Herman Steiner of the United States and Alexander Kotov.

THE American Broadcasting Company states its coverage of the Disneyland Amusement Park dedication July 17 will bring together the greatest concentration of television equipment and operating personnel ever assembled in one place.

ALDERSHOT, England, July 2 (UP) -- Chris Chataway, one of the world's five trackmen to have run the mile in less than four minutes, failed in his attempt to achieve a second Miracle Mile today when he won the event at an Army meet in 4:00.8.
MINEOLA, L. I. July 2 -- A simple plan for keeping an accurate finger on the pulse of Nassau County's population has been developed by the Nassau County Planning Department.
For more than five years the deadlock over the admission of new members has probably done more to discredit the United Nations than any other single factor.
President Eisenhower, Adlai E. Stevenson and other dignitaries will send messages to the people of five Soviet satellites tomorrow on the fifth anniversary of Radio Free Europe.

The steel industry is basic to the nation's current boom in industrial production -- up a record 138 per cent over the 1947-49 average. Steel is also a bellwether to long-term economic stability. On the one hand, steel prices affect the cost of almost every other commodity -- from automobiles to bobby pins.

NEW HAVEN, July 2 -- The memory of the fifty-six men who signed the Declaration of Independence will be honored in graveside ceremonies Monday in a national expansion of a project started in Connecticut three years ago.

BACK on page one the reader will find what is to our mind an intelligent celebration of Walt Whitman. The occasion is, of course, the 100th anniversary of the appearance of a volume of poems called "Leaves of Grass," and the question is, When did that monumental little book appear? No one seems quite to know.

RICHMOND, July 2 -- Fifth Reserve District retailers are expecting a big shot-in-the-arm from the new Civil Service pay raise. Not only does the Washington metropolitan area house an army of Government emloyes, but thousands more are to be found in the district, Richmond alone having 3,600.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- Representative James P. Richards, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said today his group would investigate whether United States troops abroad were being jailed unjustly for violations of foreign laws.

LONDON, June 21 -- An apparently successful method of overcoming some of the dangerous side-effects of drugs now used in the treatment of tuberculosis has been suggested by a group of Irish medical scientists. They are working under the direction of Dr. Vincent Barry of Dublin.
Two Queens men on their way to deposit a total of $4,900 in cash in neighborhood banks turned it over instead to robbers yesterday in separate hold-ups.

THE familiar saying that the French Revolution has led to the writing of more books than any other subject in human history may not be one of the eternal verities. A generation ago studies in the American Revolution seemed to have become the pastime of a few secluded scholars.

THE on-again, off-again picketing of six Miami Beach ocean-front hotels is off again as the result of a decision by the Florida Supreme Court in Tallahassee. The court has reinstated a temporary order banning pickets at the six hotels, part of twenty that have been hit during the seventy-three-day-old strike.
Australia's Davis Cup tennis squad, fresh from its doubles triumphs at Wimbledon, is due here early this week to open its quest for the international trophy.

Your editorial of June 24 on the National Reserve Plan Bill confirms a feeling that there is a great deal of misconception about this measure. It is at least difficult to accept either your suggestion that the matter of U. M. T. was merely "dragged into the background of debate" or the President's contention that the Powell anti-segregation amendment was "extraneous" to the subject.

WHEN the townspeople of Ronchamp, France, set about building a new church -- their old one had been destroyed by World War II -- a prominent industrialist of the town, Alfred Canet, persuaded them to take a daring course. He convinced them the best architect for the job would be Le Corbusier, the very modern, often controversial figure of international fame.

The Pirates defeated the Dodgers for the second straight time at Ebbets Field yesterday. An error by Carl Furillo, his first of the season, opened the gates for the run that enabled Pittsburgh to win in the tenth inning, 7 -- 6.

PARIS, July 2 (Reuters) -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin, France's top soldier and one of her leading experts on North African affairs, today disavowed French settlers in Morocco who refused to follow Government policy.
DETROIT, July 2 (AP) -- The 1956 new car market may be as big as any in automotive history, in the view of industry experts.

LOS ANGELES, July 2 -- The inroads of the automobile on public transportation are being underscored here. Half the city's transit facilities have been strike-bound for nearly two weeks. The effects are nearly imperceptible.
HARTFORD, July 2 -Connecticut's adult probation system is in for a big change soon.

HANG onto your slide-rules, folks. The pending public presentation of "Oklahoma" in Todd-AO, latest of the big-screen innovations, isn't going to mark the end of the technical evolution that started three years ago with Cinerama and the short-lived 3-D fad.

Independence Day, which marks the fifty-first anniversary of the ice-cream cone, promises soon to be the big day too for Tastee-Freeze. These soft ice creams have spread all over since World War II. In many areas they have supplanted the venerable "cone."

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 -- Louise Brough entered the hall of Wimbledon fame today. She drew on every shot in her memory book and improvised a few more on the spur of the moment to defeat Mrs. Beverly Baker Fleitz of Long Beach, Calif., 7 -- 5, 8 -- 6, for the all-England women's tennis championship.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Senate leaders predicted today that the Senate would soon follow the House of Representatives in approving an Administration bill to establish a new military Reserve program.
CHICAGO, July 2 -- The American school teacher is reported to be finding it more difficult than ever to control her classroom.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 2 -- The building boom in the Ninth Federal Reserve District continues. Valuation of building permits issued this year through May in eighty-eight cities of the district totaled $149,612,380, compared with $109,394,150 for a similar period last year.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The new chief of the Passport Division thinks her office has outgrown the 1848 Winder Building with a Civil War dungeon in its depths.
LIEGE, Belgium, July 2 -Street fighting broke out tonight after a demonstration by about 10,000 Roman Catholics against the Government's bill to cut aid to parochial schools.

Russia's much-publicized drive to make a strong showing in the men's track and field section of the 1956 Olympic Games apparently poses only a small threat to the traditional supremacy of the United States in those events.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., July 2 -- Robert B. Meyner, Democratic Governor of New Jersey, believes President Eisenhower would carry New Jersey if an election were held today.

Of recent years Dr. Harold Urey has been lecturing on his conception of the earth's origin. According to him, the infant earth had an atmosphere made up of methane. (marsh gas), ammonia and hydrogen. In the course of time this atmosphere changed into the one we have -- one composed largely of nitrogen and oxygen mixed with carbon dioxide, a little hydrogen and minute amounts of other gases.

THE best non-theatrical news in some time is the availability of five "See It Now" programs in Edward R. Murrow's extraordinary television series. It can only be hoped that such circulation, initiated several months ago when Associated Films released Mr. Murrow's interview with Dr. Robert J. Oppenheimer, represents a trend on the part of other television producers and alert 16mm distributors for private or group viewing.
CHICAGO, July 2 (UP) -- Two more changes were recorded today in the All-Star baseball poll as tabulators neared the end of the count.
TRENTON, July 2 -- The New Jersey Legislature will be asked this fall to establish a permanent State Juvenile Protection Commission.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Nonagricultural employment in Illinois rose about 31,000 persons to 3,283,500 during April, the State Department of Labor reported. The gain over a year ago in April was 11,100 persons. Excluding Government employes, there were 2,941,000 persons employed in nonfarm jobs at the end of April.
TEHERAN, July 2 (AP) -- A touring team of American weight lifters beat an Iranian team, 6 -- 0, last night before several thousand spectators, including the Shah.

Said James E. Fitzsimmons, the great horse-trainer, to Eddie Arcaro before the Dwyer Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday: "You've got the best horse. Put him in front and let that other one come and try to get you."

LILACS have started to make seed and if the old blossom heads have not been removed, action should be taken at once. Further delay may impair next year's bloom and cause the lilac fancier much disappointment in May.

EARLY one cold morning last January, when the new state administration was only a few days old, the telephone rang in the Albany hotel suite of Eugene F. Bannigan. Democratic leader of the New York State Assembly.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Secret Service, which has been tracking down counterfeiters since the Civil War and protecting President since the turn of the century, will unfurl its first official flag to celebrate its ninetieth birthday Tuesday.

The Treasury face to face again with the jigsaw puzzle of managing the public debt, has just made a move that emphasizes the significant shifts that have taken place in national money matters since the end of World War II.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -More men are re-enlisting in the armed forces, the result of a pay increase and bonus voted by Congress.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Senator Walter F. George called today for "a great and continuous effort" by colonial powers to prepare dependent territories for self-government.
Q. What is the fiscal year?

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) -- L. Quincy Mumford, Librarian of Congress, said today that 27,000,000 Americans had no access whatever to a local public library. The American Library Association, which he heads, opens its week-long seventy-fourth annual conference tomorrow.

IN the absence of official information at Washington, observers of the philatelic scene are making what they consider a logical surmise that the next stamp in the new regular series inaugurated last year will be the 6-cent with portrait of Theodore Roosevelt.
The first major phase of a vast peacetime troop movement began yesterday with the sailing of the transport Upshur from the New York Port of Embarkation, Brooklyn.

" EACH man," declares Meyer Berger in the preface to this collection of tributes to our city. "reads his own meaning into New York." It is true that New York is complex, and if this anthology fails to bring the metropolis into sharp focus, the fault may not be entirely that of the compiler.
MOSCOW, July 2 -- Soviet opinion about the United States attitude toward the coming Big Four conference has undergone a change.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 2 -- The Fourth of July has traditionally marked the formal opening of the season here.
NORWALK, Conn., July 2 -- Their dander up, Fairfield County commuters spent part of the Independence Day week-end mapping ways to get even with the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

TEANECK, N. J., July 2 -- "Not for sale" signs, some adding "because we like our neighborhood," are appearing on more and more houses in northeastern Teaneck. They are the result of an organized campaign by residents to integrate the fifty-seven Negro families that have moved in among them and to prevent "panic" selling.
Governor Harriman said last night that despite New York State's progress against discrimination, continuous effort was necessary to maintain it.
Retailers look back with satisfaction at the business of their stores during the last six months and they see no reason for gloom in the months ahead.
PARIS, July 2 -- The most popular entertainment to appear on the Paris stage in a long time is being provided here nightly by the Peiping Opera Company.

TALKING about the year's good pictures, as we sometimes incline to do on this Sunday, which falls right in the middle of the measurable twelve-month stretch, we discover a happy coincidence that should gratify and inspire those visitors with cinematic cravings who are in the city this holiday week-end.

THE most effective cooler in hot weather is plenty of liquid, physicians say. But to their recommendation of several glasses of water from the faucet, epicures turn their backs, preferring to concoct more imaginative summer beverages.

TRAVELERS to foreign lands do hunt souvenirs while they roam but when a gardener gets this wanderlust a little advice is in order. Woe to him who travels across the seas and brings back slips of beautiful plants seen hither and yon.

SEOUL, Korea, July 2 -- Foreign Minister Y. T. Pyun of South Korea asked today that the United States clarify its aims in Korea during the Big Four conference unless it was willing to employ force to settle the Korean issue. The Foreign Minister was critical of Secretary of State Dulles for saying last week that anything leading to an early realization of Korean unification at the Geneva conference was doubtful.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I. -Boats and horses will undoubtedly dominate the 1955 vacation picture for eastern Long Island, for although the trend in this direction has been gradual during the past few years, recent months have seen a terrific upsurge in interest in matters marine and equestrian.

GUATEMALA, July 2 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas observed the first anniversary of his accession to power today by declaring his Government would continue to deal with subversive elements through democratic processes.

BALTIMORE, July 2 (AP) -- George Susce pitched a four-hitter tonight as the Boston Red Sox racked up victory No. 21 in their last twenty-six games and toppled the Baltimore Orioles to their eleventh loss in a row, 5 -- 1.
The four - power "summit" meeting at Geneva convenes this month against the background of an uneasy balance of power maintained in part by United States air-nuclear superiority.

THE National Broadcasting Company has received a story idea from James Jones, author of "From Here to Eternity." Mr. Jones' first venture into television writing is a result of the network's quest for new talent in its program development plans.
When a team is as far in front as the Dodgers are in the National League, it can indulge in the luxury of kicking away a ball game without great damage.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Hoover Commission passed out of existence this week, leaving behind it political controversies that are likely to persist for months and even years.

" FAREWELL rewards and fairies" lamented Bishop Corbet as the Puritan influence strengthened during the reign of James I. His regret for a lost sense of magic was, however, premature. Three centuries later, despite juke-boxes and jet planes and even the promise of a rocket to the moon, the folk tale still has an audience.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 2 -- Form held up well today in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound Regatta conducted by the Huguenot Yacht Club. The winners included Bus Mosbacher with Susan in the International class, Henry Boschen with the S boat Sirius, Fred Hibbard with the Lightning, Flash, and Bill Corwin with the 210, Harpoon.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- Willie Hartack spurred the Brookfield Farm's Impromptu past the favored Doggoon to win the $29,700 Warren Wright Memorial Stakes at Arlington Park today. The 8-1 shot triumphed in 1:22, equaling the track record for seven furlongs.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Spray shade trees with nicotine sulfate or summer oil to control aphids. This prevents sticky drip from marring objects and blackening foliage of shrubs under trees. The first Japanese beetles have emerged, so protect favorite plants with DDT or lead arsenate. Hand pick from roses and drop into a can of oily water.

A HISTORY not of American city planning, or architecture, or of social and economic development in America, this book is something of all three. Christopher Tunnard is director of the graduate program in city planning at Yale: Henry Hope Reed has written extensively on architectural subjects.

Because of necessary delays in modifying the regulations that must now be followed in making certain that no live polio virus has found its way into vials of Salk vaccine it will be impossible to carry out this year's vaccination program on the scale planned in the spring.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of the letter from the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, to Senator Frank Carlson, Republican of Kansas, announcing his decision of Wolf Ladejinsky:

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- One of the stoutest pillars of the Government's security program developed a crack this week. The Attorney General's list of subversive organizations, which has served as basic documentation in thousands of findings of "derogatory information" against Federal employes, was denounced by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee as "misunderstood and misapplied."
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 2 -- The Irish News, the only Roman Catholic and Nationalist daily newspaper published in Northern Island, celebrated today the centenary of its first issue.
The antics of collegians, young and old, have provided Miss Madeline F. Scully with full-time amusement over the last twenty-nine years.

THE Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, reactivated last season after a period of disbandment, will make its first appearance in New York on Saturday night at the Lewisohn Stadium. Already it has lost its ballerina of the season, Maria Tallchief, who has rejoined her own company (the New York City Ballet, now nearing the end of its European tour) after a year's leave of absence.

GARRISON - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., July 2 -- Glory, a 9-year-old chestnut mare owned and ridden by Mrs. William Morin and her son James, won the championship of the twenty-first annual Garrison Horse Show today.
BEAR MOUNTAIN -- Palisades Interstate Park, long a favorite playground of New Yorkers, has made an addition to its many attractions with the opening of the Anthony Wayne Recreation Area.
LEGISLATIVE predation, one of the most persistent enemies of wildlife, is more difficult to control than such natural predators as wolves, mountain lions, foxes, wildcats and skunks.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 2 -Hydrangea Week, which opens here tomorrow, is the result of a beautification idea that just grew and grew and grew.

MARSTRAND, Sweden, July 2 (Reuters) -- The navigator of the American yacht Carina today told how the fifty-three-foot craft battered her way through twenty-five-foot waves on her 3,450-mile trip here from the United States. She ended her journey at 2:16:40 A. M. to win the Lipton Cup for finishing first.
Once again, in Carlos P. Romulo's "What the Asians Expect of Us" (June 19), the United States has received the energetic admonishment of a kindly elder.

The New York Athletic Club's Block Island predicted-log race is the banner event next weekend. The annual test started fifty years ago and it has been responsible for all the subsequent predicted-log races that have been springing up elsewhere.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 -Hollywood, once so fearful of television, today is riding the crest of a video-inspired boom. The prosperity of the nation's glamour town surpasses the hey-day of the film capital in 1945.

The first full day of operation of a new Police Department order on violations in this city's bars brought the arrest of two persons for serving persons under 18 years of age and the issuance of one summons for serving an intoxicated person.

ROME, July 2 -- The weaknesses now being revealed within the ranks of the Christian Democratic party have always been inherent in its make-up. Their seriousness is not lessened by the fact that Antonio Segni now seems likely to reconstitute a government along the same lines as before.

When the New York State Thruway bridge over the Hudson is completed this autumn it will permit more than automobiles to cross the river. It will open the way also for business and industry to flow between Westchester and Rockland Counties.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson has held a dude rancher's effort to gain control of an access road in a national forest area was against the public interest.
The long Fourth of July week-end opened yesterday with the summer's hottest day so far and with the season's biggest crowds at the near-by beaches.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., July 2 (AP) -- Ben Green's Swift Steve, an $8,000 claim in April, today won the $27,325 Governor's Day Handicap, the feature event of the last day of Narragansett Park's summer meeting.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 2 (UP) -- President Eisenhower, wearing a pink visor hat, golfed in 92-degree heat today and then went to Camp David in the cool Catoctin Mountains of Maryland for the Fourth of July week-end.
VANCOUVER, B. C., July 2 (AP) -- Dow Finsterwald of Bedford Heights, Ohio, won the 72-hole, $15,000 British Columbia open golf tournament with an 18-under-par 270 today.

THE astonishing batting feats of large Don Newcombe have given added emphasis this season to the inescapable fact that pitchers are normally atrocious hitters. Most of them couldn't even hit the water if they fell out of a canoe. They just can't hit nuthin' from nohow. But why?

WHEN the heads of government of the Big Four sit down together this summer for their momentous meeting at the summit the conversation, in whatever relaxed moments may occur, will be apt to fall into two languages.

Amos Landman, publicity director of the National Municipal League, said yesterday his resignation had been demanded after he had refused to tell a Senate subcommittee whether he used to be a communist.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 2 (UP) -- The Australian Lawn Tennis Association will invite two leading American players to compete in the national championships next January, the association's new president announced today.

THERE have been thousands of detective stories, but few stories about detectives. "The Man Who Paid His Way" records the adventures and problems of an ordinary, honest employe in the Detective Bureau of Pacific City -- a fictional community that has more than a surface resemblance to Sergeant Friday's Los Angeles.

BACK about the year 20 B. A. (before atoms), the loneliest regions in all America were in a strip sixty miles wide on either side of the Green and Colorado Rivers. Today, from the San Rafael Swell to Lee's Ferry, one couldn't shoot a rifle in any direction, including up, without winging at least one prospector.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 2 -- The Government named Vietnamese officers today as Deputy Chiefs of Staff for the fledgling Navy and Air branches of the armed forces. The two French officers who are being replaced will remain as members of the joint French-American training mission in Free Vietnam.

Washington in July ordinarily is a town of dank heat, tourists, and irritable politicians. This time the heat, the tourists and the politicians are there but the irritability is missing. Last week, as Congress entered what may be the final month of its 1955 session, the atmosphere was tranquil.
NORFOLK, Va., July 2 (AP) -- Virginia's previously solid front against racial integration in public schools has been cracked by the school board of Norfolk, the state's largest city.

LOS ANGELES. July 2 (AP) -- The C. H. Jones Sons Stable has purchased Imbros, who set a world record for seven furlongs in 1954. Imbros' time of 1:20 3/5 was bettered recently by El Drag who was clocked in 1:20.
The American business man likes to give things away. Every year he buys great quantities of calendars, huge numbers of pens and pencils, vast stores of blotters and thousands of other items.

THE Orient, and Japan in particular, has served as the locale of several recent American film productions. In each case the authenticity of the scenery lured the directors all the way across the Pacific.

Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, announces that the United States has agreed to sell to the French Government thirty tons of heavy water to be used in two research reactors. The sale is to be made during the years 1956-58 to the French Commission for Atomic Energy.

THE late Heinrich Zimmer was primarily a student of myth and symbol, and this is the fourth volume that has been edited from the mass of unpublished lectures and writings which he left behind when he died in 1943.

MORE effective with her statistics than her sentiment, Virginia Pasley presents here an indictment of those of us who sent young soldiers to the Korean war untrained, unarmed, undedicated. They got their guns all right, and their military hardening, but they were in tragically short supply of that moral ammunition.
LONDON, July 2 -- The situation in Britain's dock strike became chaotic today, with strike leaders in the north defying the orders of the union's officials to return to work on Monday.
Twenty-five prized possessions of the New York Public Library are on exhibition for the summer in the main lobby of the Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street building.

FARGO, N. D., July 2 -- The State Board of Higher Education voted 5 to 2 this week to discharge four professors at the North Dakota Agricultural College in Fargo. Three of them immediately announced intentions to appeal to the District Court.
R. Stanley Dollar, one of the pioneers of American-flag shipping, will be 75 years old Wednesday.
The aerosol "bug bomb" of World War II has now push-buttoned its way into millions of American homes and an increasing number of industrial uses.

There will be scores of exhibits at Geneva, Switzerland, when the International Conference on Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy meets there from Aug. 8 to Aug. 20. In fact, there will be so many exhibits that it will be necessary to install them in several buildings.

Dr. Louis J. van der Meulen, commander of the Leyden District of the Netherlands National Police, says in the Journal of Criminal Law, Criminology and Police Science that it would be no trick to deceive the police by what looks like a thumbprint but is really a big-toe print.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -United States policy at the Geneva conference will assume that the Soviet Union wants to reduce its arms burden.

RECOGNIZING the advantage of showing sculpture in the open air the Sculptors Guild is holding its seventeenth annual exhibition in the space made available by the adjacent and hospitable Guggenheim Museum where the Giacometti retrospective is being held.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia has found that lenders in this area are under pressure to make their terms more lenient. Those who are holding the line on terms believe they are losing business.
LONDON, July 2 -- The hundredth birthday parties of some of Britain's most august newspapers have developed into a family row.

We are in entire agreement with the contention of an eminent military critic, whose letter appears elsewhere on this page, that the presentation of the legislation to provide for a pre-trained reserve has left much to be desired. We do not agree, however, that the introduction of a non-segregation amendment did anything to clarify the basic issue.

" WHY did my fruit tree die? It looked all right last year, and came into leaf this spring. I can't see any obvious injury. What shall I do?" These questions and comments paint a picture of a problem that many home fruit growers have faced or will probably have to face some day.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -Congress will soon extend the life of the Interstate Oil Compact Commission for four years, but there may be a spate of trouble before final approval.
HAMPTON, Va., July 2 -- A young Baltimore pilot emerged as the only double winner in today's regatta here that started a two week-end festival of speed boat race meets.

As the owner of one of the best-known employment agencies in New York City. I take issue with Mrs. Roche's statement that there are fewer jobs for domestics available now than before. Of course, if the author bases her information only on the New York State Employment Office experience, she cannot get a true picture of the domestic employment situation.

THE Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival near Lee, Mass., under the direction of Ted Shawn, will house its most celebrated attraction to date this week, when ten members of the Royal Danish Ballet in Copenhagen open a series of fifteen performances on Wednesday evening.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, took back today his charge that Wolf Ladejinsky was a "security risk."

IN these critical times things are done at the international level which would be inexcusable at the personal level. In our own land we seem helpless, frustrated witnesses of a procession of crimes, of breaches of trust and of simple dishonesty. But we are not really so helpless.
Congress, as was expected, voted last week to extend the controversial "doctor draft" for an additional two years.
CINCINNATI, July 2 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs defeated the Milwaukee Braves, 10 -- 5, tonight on a seven-run second inning and Ted Kluszewski's twenty-fifth home run.

THERE is an art to harvesting fruit to get the maximum size, color and flavor. Timing is the key and it depends on the way the fruit is to be used. Some ripen to a good flavor if they are harvested somewhat immature. Other fruits will shrivel and rot before ripening if they are harvested when immature.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Chicago area supporters of the proposed $181,000,000 Calumet-Sag Channel project came to its defense today. A Hoover commission task force report on Thursday had blasted the project as "unessential."

WICHITA, Kan., July 2 -- Fay Crocker of Montevideo, Uruguay, staved off sharp challenges by Mary Lena Faulk and Louise Suggs to win the $7,500 women's National Open golf championship today. She carded 299 and Miss Faulk and Miss Suggs finished with 303's.
TWENTY-FIVE years ago this week (on July 7, 1930) Sir Arthur Conan Doyle died; and with him, some think, died the glory of the detective story.

ATHOUGH Tuesday will mark the twentieth anniversary of the receipt of its Congressional charter, the American National Theatre and Academy apparently is going to permit the day to pass without pomp or ceremony.

A GREATLY expanded system of highways and especially farm-to-market roads throughout many regions of Latin-America, already under way in some places and planned for others, not only will produce great economic benefits but also will have a still wider effect in raising general social standards, a group of international experts recently concluded.
Isabel Troccole of New York successfully defended her Eastern clay court tennis championship yesterday.

Russia's Foreign Minister Molotov was in San Francisco, 7,500 miles from Moscow, when he was informed of the recent plane "incident" over the Bering Sea. In San Francisco Mr. Molotov was much nearer the "scene of action" than if he had stayed at home.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Eisenhower and the Premier of Burma, U Nu, said in a joint statement today that they had reviewed together the problem of the eleven United States fliers imprisoned in Communist China. The two leaders also had a "frank discussion" of the major point of difference between Rangoon and Washington, the fact that the United States had been shipping surplus rice to countries in Asia that normally imported it from Burma.
KIAMBU, Kenya, June 18 -- A major job of rehabilitation is being done in Kenya among the Mau Mau-infected Kikuyu tribe.

WHEN gluing wood for cabinet or furniture work, remember that dampened wood expands more across the grain than with it. Be sure that both pieces of wood meet with their grain at the same angle, or the joint may crock while drying.

The week-end, when more Americans are away from their homes than at perhaps any other time of the year, it is appropriate that there is much news about travel problems, particularly international travel. In Moscow, a visiting group of American Quakers reports that it found among the Soviet people "widespread ignorance and misinformation about contemporary American life" and urged increased travel between this country and the Soviet Union.

THE San Francisco Opera season opens on Sept. 15. The details of its repertory have already been announced, but thanks to its prospectus and a little investigation one can now give more news of its personnel.
DETROIT, July 2 (UP) -- Lieut. Col. James. A. Poston of Columbus, Ohio, won the second annual cross-country Ricks Memorial Trophy Race today.

SUMMER, librarians tell me, is the leisure-reading season. It is also the season in which publishers bring out as few new mysteries as possible -and you may gnaw at that puzzle in the absence of any recommended new whodunits.
NEW DELHI, July 2 (AP) -India, in a move to boost its foreign exchange position, has opened a comprehensive program to sell its goods in every part of the world.

The National Maritime Union of America, C. I. O., will publish on July 20 a 144-page history of its birth, growth and achievements. It is entitled "This is the N. M. U." The first printing of 75,000 copies will be distributed to schools, libraries and the union's members.

NOW that the season for outdoor living is with us, it is interesting to note the different settings in which city dwellers and suburbanites enjoy their summertime leisure. In the city, the setting is apt to be a somewhat formal one confined to small gardens and penthouses. Surrounding these green retreats, the city skyline rises in a craggy, architectural landscape, as dramatic as it is incongruous.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Republican leadership today blamed a change in circumstances rather than any reversal in Administration policy for the White House decision Thursday to reconsider the Dixon-Yates power project.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 2 (UP) -- Countess Fleet stamped herself as one of America's great racing fillies today. She picked up top weight of 126 pounds and raced to a new track record for a mile and an eighth as she easily won the $28,000 Vanity Handicap at Hollywood Park.
New York's lighterage network is a keystone of the port's success rather than a fallen arch of cargo traffic, according to George D. McDonald.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A bitter contest over the role business executives will have in planning defense mobilization is expected to erupt next week on Capitol Hill.
CLEVELAND, July 2 -- Jack Harshman hit a game-winning homer, gave three hits and struck out ten tonight as the Chicago White Sox beat the Cleveland Indians, 2 -- 1.

Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore revealed yesterday in his annual report that a total of $700,000,000 was being spent on a public works' program in the borough. The Federal and State Governments have contributed to many of the projects.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. July 2 -- A marked improvement has taken place in the economies of Middle-East countries, United Nations experts reported today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 2 -The Government intensified precautions today against possible disorder arising from the current wave of strikes. There were fears such disorder could overthrow the Government.
BUENOS AIRES, July 2 -- The city's cathedral was jammed today with Roman Catholics attending the first mass in the building since the revolt June 16.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 2 -- Sweltering in 90-degree heat, 6,000 participants and spectators gathered atop Round Hill today for the annual Highland Games. Pipers, dancers, athletes and bands came from such far points as Detroit and Canada.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 1 -A group of experts on problems of the aged agreed here this week that preparations for old age and retirement should begin in the middle years.
With approach of the Big Four conference, the possibility of increased East-West trade is again working its illusory magic on Western minds.
Hibiscus (H. rosa-sinensis) was brought from tropical islands of the Pacific to England and then to the United States. It is widely grown as a shrub outdoors in Florida and southern California.

On the sides of his delivery truck one of the local merchants advertises his wares as follows: "John McConnell. Everything in glass. Stratford. Canada. Home of the world-famous Shakespeare Festival.''

STANTON, Del., July 2 -- The leading claimant for queen of the turf in 1955 is Parlo. The Foxcatcher Farms' speedy 4-year-old miss made a move toward the throne today by win ning the $151,500 Delaware Handicap before 23,305 persons at Delaware Park.

DALLAS, July 2 -- Department store sales in the Southwest through May and the first three weeks of June continued above sales for the same period last year, the Eleventh Federal Reserve Bank reported in its monthly business summary for July 1.

Four Massachusetts school systems and ten colleges have joined the Harvard Graduate School of Education in a bid to obtain able liberal arts and science graduates as public school teachers on both the elementary and high school levels. Their program is supported by a three-year grant of $150,000 from the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Advancement of Education.

THE two most recent volumes the brilliant "Library of American Biography" series, edited by Oscar Handlin, help define and focus the familiar contrast between conservative and radical strains in American thought. Russel B. Nye's William Lloyd Garrison and the Humanitarian Reformers" neatly balances Richard N. Current's "Daniel Webster and the Rise of National Conservatism."

IN these trying times when democracy is being fiercely attacked from both the right and the left, we rush to defend it blindly without actually knowing what we believe "the democratic way" to be. Americans of today owe no greater obligation to themselves than a fundamental rethinking of what constitutes democracy and which elements in it are essential and which are not.

Rubber prices have soared during the last two months. The spot price of natural rubber is at about the highest level since the Korean War and futures on the Commodity Exchange of New York are the highest since trading was suspended on April 2, 1951.

IN the century since the first, slim, privately printed volume of "Leaves of Grass" appeared, Walt Whitman has become throughout the world America's most widely read, most deeply discussed poet. But the hundred years have not removed the ambiguities of his place in his own country.

The Navy's heavy cruiser Newport News attracted 1,000 visitors yesterday when it held open house at Pier 88 at West Forty-eighth Street. The ship may be visited today and tomorrow from 1 to 4 P. M. On Tuesday morning it will leave for its namesake port, Newport News, Va.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- A familiar record has been playing in the courtroom of Federal Judge Louis E. Goodman.

THE primary conservation issue of the year, the fate of Dinosaur National Monument, is still hanging in the balance in Congress. In the billion-dollar bill authorizing the Upper Colorado Basin Storage Project (a complex system of water, power and irrigation works in Utah, western Colorado, Wyoming and New Mexico) the Senate included provision for Echo Park Dam.

The chairman of the 1956 finance campaign of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, will be Harry J. Delaney. He is vice president of J. P. Maguire Co., Inc., factor. The campaign will begin on Jan. 12. Its goals will be $921,000 for operating expenses and $400,000 for capital developments.

LONDON, July 2 (AP) -- Jean Conan Doyle, daughter of the late Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, famed creator of Sherlock Holmes, said she had arranged the exhumation before dawn today of her parents' bodies from their graves in Sussex.

HAPPY is the householder who has some storage space for his tools and working materials. Not everyone does have -- apartment dwellers and those in the smaller suburban developments. But for the lucky ones who can accumulate a little stock there are some suggestions for saving time, money and work.

Better and moderate priced dress markets showed unusually good activity last week, resident buying offices reported. Coat and suit orders were definitely slow, particularly in the popular-priced category.
GENEVA, July 1 -- The visa officers of United States consulates in Central Europe believe they can make the somewhat slow starting refugee relief program work.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 2 -- War is out of the question in this age, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today in an address before the Yugoslav Parliament.
Department store sales showed modest gains last week, compared with volume of a year ago. Hot weather was the big factor.

The principle that is making the nation's factories completely automatic -- a machine that controls another machine -- is being applied to an increasing degree to homes. In fact, it started there in the first place with the introduction of the thermostat many years ago.

CRAWFORDVILLE, Ind., July 2 -- Bob Richards of Long Beach, Calif., called on the pole vault, his "ace in the hole," today to win his third National Amateur Athletic Union decathlon championship. Richards scored 6,873 points.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- From a Republican Administration point of view, this is the perfect year for a national election. With issues so scarce, the prosperity theme is more valuable than ever. We have just come through the most prosperous half-year in our history.
LONDON, July 2 (AP) -- A member of Parliament protested today that subjecting young military recruits to the traditional close-crop army haircut was "an invasion of man's liberty."

A MATERIALLY valueless but psychologically important part of the booty which fell into Allied hands as a result of the victory of 1945 were the archives of the German Foreign Ministry. In it were the private papers of Friedrich von Holstein (1837-1909), who served in the German Foreign Office for many years and from 1890 until 1906 was believed to be chiefly responsible for directing German foreign policy.

No formal poll has been taken and none will be, but Representative Herbert C. Bonner, Democrat of North Carolina, was unofficially hailed last week as the national character most loved by the maritime industry.
PARIS, July 2 -- The French Government has agreed that, for the time being, the Vietnamese National Army and the French Expeditionary Force in Indo-China should have completely independent commands.

A PLASTIC finish, bonded to a hardboard backing, is available in either 16-inch blocks or 16-inch by 8-foot planks. The plastic surfaces are said to resist moisture, grease, heat, acids, stains, wear and marring. They can be wiped clean with a damp cloth.

I was fascinated by the picture of the flying pelicans shown with other fantastic effects achieved in aerial photography in "Aerial Abstractions" (June 19). But may I suggest that the pelican "abstrac tion" shows the shadows of the birds on the lake and the bottom of the lake, rather than, as your caption put it, "white pelicans reflected in black on the surface of a California lake and on the lake's bottom."

CLEVELAND, July 2 -- Sales of used automobiles soared to 2,532, highest weekly total in more than three years, as the motor vehicle boom continued in the greater Cleveland area. New car sales increased from 1,701 to 2,024 as June business continued brisk.
Sixty special play streets and playgrounds, to accommodate thousands of boys and girls who stay in the city during the summer, will be operated by the Police Athletic League.

Of the many nineteenth century myths about business men and their influence in world affairs one of the most pernicious was that of Machiavellian "international bankers" and "merchants of death," who supposedly promoted war and rebellion for profit.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- This Eighty-fourth Congress, now in what will probably be its final month, is ending in a substantially unbreached coalition with the Republican White House.
YONKERS, N. Y., July 2 -- This city is learning that you cannot keep everybody happy.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Preparations for a four-power conference, whether at the summit or on a lesser peak of authority, are about as detailed and painstaking as the planning that went into the conquest of Mount Everest.

GEORGE STURGIS COFFIN is a native and resident American, but his bridge books are expatriates. He writes them in Waltham, Mass., and has them published in London. To reach American readers they have to cross the Atlantic.
Tommy Byrne had it last night at the Stadium. The Yankees' sometimes-wild left-hander blanked the Washington Senators with three hits, 12 -- 0, walking two and nicking two batsmen with pitched balls.

AS set forth in her autobiography, the philosophy of Ethel Merman, a woman with large eyes, good legs and an incredible voice, who is probably the finest musical-comedy performer of the last quarter century, is a homely one and considerably less complicated than the lyrics of Cole Porter, which she has often rendered with absolute felicity.

WHEN I first read "Frankreichs Uhren gehen anders," I put it down as the best book about France since D. W. Brogan's "France Under the Republic." The English version has lost none of the original sparkle; and the new Epilogue alters the perspective by a good many degrees.
PAUL WHITEMAN thinks something should be done about encouraging the youth of America to concentrate on dancing.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A spokesman for the Forest Service says that there is no official Department of Agriculture position on the Taos Indian claims to national forest lands. The lands lie in the Sangre de Cristo mountains in north central New Mexico.

Most of Mary Roche's brilliant and entertaining piece on the servantless life I find sound -- "The New 'Servants': Machines and Husbands" (June 5). But as one who was once an eager beaver for every new domestic labor-saver.
JAMES PLUNKETT is a young Dubliner of 35, who has worked as a clerk in the Dublin Gas Company, played the viola professionally, served on the staff of a funny magazine, and written three radio plays.
Louise Brough is a champion who came back. Five years after her third victory at Wimbledon she has won the crown a fourth time.

SOMETHING new, and perhaps vital, has been added to the American musical scene. Luben Vichey, a basso at the Metropolitan Opera, has purchased the National Concert and Artists Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary, Civic Concert Service. Inc.
A record number of foreign students came to this country in the 1954-55 academic year, the Institute of International Education reported last week.

BETHESDA, Md., July 2 -- Locker No. 85 at the Burning Tree Club has a small American flag hanging inside it, and the nameplate is marked, "Mr. President." Even among his best friends, Eisenhower is called "Mr. President" at that beautiful golf course.

KANSAS CITY, July 2 -- The closing week of the first six months of 1955 saw a good movement of merchandise in retail and wholesale channels in the Southwest. Modest gains were the rule over last year, although there was a narrowing compared with earlier months of this year.
SAN SALVADOR, June 28 -Four outstanding candidates are jockeying for position in next year's Presidential election campaign.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- So great is the power of the President to make news and such is the charm of the Eisenhower personality that his mood greatly influences and sometimes even dominates the national attitude toward great events.

Competitions for United States Government scholarships for graduate study abroad for 1956-57 are now open, it was announced by Kenneth Holland, president of the Institute of International Education, 1 East Sixty-seventh Street, New York City.

TAOS, N. M., July 2 -- Indians of Taos Pueblo are petitioning Congress for the return of lands north and east of their present boundary. The lands in question include Blue Lake, an important Indian religious shrine. For the last half century, these lands have been under the jurisdiction of the Carson National Forest.
GREENVILLE, S. C., July 2 (AP) -- Advance planes took off today for the biggest troop airlift in military history.

IN a fury of activity worthy of any Shakespearean tempest, a project of great promise for the American cultural scene rushes toward its debut. The project is the American Shakespeare Festival, which, with a sound of fanfare, will open July 12 at Stratford, Conn. The dream is that one day this Stratford may rival, even surpass, the one in England as a magnet for millions and a center where Shakespearean acting approaches perfection.

Sailplanes (motorless gliders) equipped with oxygen tanks (some with about 180 pounds of other equipment) have climbed to 40,000 feet and more. Greater heights could have been attained on some occasions if the pilot had been housed in a pressure cabin.
Gordon Smith has been named director of sales promotion for International Business Machines Corporation.

When "Leaves of Grass" was first published a hundred years ago it was, to those who read it, a strange and striking book. For both in form and content it offended all the poetic conventions of its time. And the succeeding editions, which caused the book to grow eightfold, only deepened the sense of novelty and even of contradiction.

VANCOUVER, B. C., June 25 -- The only ship to sail the Northwest Passage in both directions, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police craft St. Roch, will be set up in Kitsilano Park here as a marine museum.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, today issued subpoenas to force Louis Wolfson, financier, to testify Thursday on the Capital Transit Company strike. The dispute has halted public transportation here.
TELEVISION took a major step forward last week when the National Broadcasting Company presented "Wide Wide World," an exciting panorama of life in North America.
TOKYO, Sunday, July 3 (AP) -Long-range B-29 search planes, searchlights and powerful illumination rockets were pressed today into the spreading hunt for three Marine airmen missing in the Pacific.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- The Giants, poised on the brink of sixth place today, were saved from the tumble by Sal Maglie and three well-propelled home run balls at Connie Mack Stadium. Sid Gordon, Willie Mays and Ray Katt accounted for all runs with their homers, the Giants beating the Phils and Curt Simmons, 6 to 1.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- Republicans made plans today to offer a compromise plan to pay for President Eisenhower's proposed nation - wide highway building program.
Harold W. Scott, vice president of the Pennsylvania Company for Banking and Trusts since 1934, has been elected a senior vice president.
PARIS, July 2 -- The United States cultural "Salute to France," which has drawn wide attention and some criticism in the French press, will close here tomorrow.
VIENNA, July 2 -- The Austrian Government has run into trouble with the Russians in carrying out its state treaty.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 2 -- United States rowers captured Britain's two top trophies for eights in spectacular races today.
JERUSALEM, July 2 -- The tragedy of the 500,000 Jews of Hungary who were murdered by the Nazis in 1944 is haunting the Parliamentary election campaign in Israel.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- Eight youths were charged tonight with murder in the slaying of a high school senior in a West Side gang war.

IT is virtually impossible to go from other major Southeast Asian cities to Bangkok -- Thailand's capital and the new headquarters site of the Manila Pact powers -- without a lifting of the spirit. In many ways, this reaction is unreasonable. Other places are cooler, cleaner and prettier.
ROME, July 2 -- President Giovanni Gronchi formally charged Antonio Segni tonight with the task of forming a new Government.

ONE of the United States most important cultural ambassadors is a petite woman with gray. symmetrically parted hair and a gentle, well-bred voice. She is Alice Trowbridge Strong, wife of L. Corrin Strong, United States Ambassador to Norway.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- Following is the text of a joint statement by President Eisenhower and Burmese Premier U Nu:

A BOOK version of "The Family of Man" exhibition, which is now on tour throughout the United States and soon will be in Europe, has just been published in two editions (New York, Simon Schuster, de luxe, $10; Maco Magazine Corporation, paper, $1).

THE community-level campaign to legislate airplanes away from living rooms received a severe setback last week. A Federal judge ruled unconstitutional a Cedarhurst L. I., local ordinance banning flights over town at less than 1,000 feet.
SIENA, Italy, July 2 (AP) -- The Lowly Grub, cheered by thousands around the city square, today won Siena's historic Palio, the world's roughest horse race.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Majority Leader of the Senate, suffered a moderately severe heart attack today. He will be unable to return to active duty at this Congress session.

Last week New York City prepared to expand its educational facilities for those seeking higher education. Plans were begun that will lead to the creation of three community colleges in three different boroughs. This is the first time that the city has seriously considered the need of those students who want to go beyond high school, but who do not seek a traditional four-year college program.
VICTORVILLE, Calif., July 2 -- The Air Force's first supersonic fighter group is operating under severe handicaps because of a manpower shortage.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The new display of Soviet air power over Moscow proves that the United States has lost a degree of air supremacy Americans felt they had in the past, Senator Stuart Symington said today.
A partial civil rights "victory" was claimed yesterday by Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat of Manhattan, in the new Reserve program voted by the House Friday.

Proposed Congressional legislation that would permit commercial banks to underwrite certain municipal bonds not secured by a full pledge of the issuer's tax power has caused a smoldering trade dispute to break into flame. The legislation is known as the Bricker bill.
PANAMA, July 3 -- Two thousand delegates to the National Patriotic Coalition convention today nominated Ernesto de la Guardia Jr., as 1956 Presidential candidate.

In his long fight for a sound American farm policy, Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson has often shown high standards of personal integrity and political courage. These same qualities are demonstrated again now in his public announcement that he has reversed his decision of last year with regard to agricultural specialist Wolf Ladejinsky.
HASTINGS - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., July 3 -- Dr. Reina Albagli Hutner, a research scientist, was found dead of cyanide poisoning this morning at her home, 7 Ridgedell Avenue.
HAMPTON, Va., July 3 -- A local contractor, W. Curtis Martens, makes a specialty of winning speed-boat regatta trophies known as gold cups.

There was some disagreement among charter brokers on the status of last week's market. The field was "brisk," or it "slipped a little," or was "definitely bullish," depending upon which broker was speaking.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 3 (AP) -- As nasty a brew of weather as old Scotland can muster prevailed at St. Andrews today on the eve of the British open golf championship.
HONG KONG, July 3 -- Communist China's leading newspaper re-emphasized today the theme of a purge of the "revolutionary ranks."

HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 3 -- Irving Suntag, seeded fourteenth, and unrated Winton Charlop, both of Brooklyn, moved a round ahead of the field as the New York State men's tennis championships began at the County Tennis Club today.

MADISON, Wis., July 3 (AP) -- Leroy Gore, former weekly newspaper editor who last year started an unsuccessful movement to recall Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, says he is quitting the Republican party. He also said he might be a candidate against Mr. McCarthy in 1958.

ON Friday of last week this space was devoted to a review of a book by one of the most introspective and deliberately intellectual of contemporary Scotsmen, "An Autobiography," by Edwin Muir. Today we have with us an autobiography by one of the most extroverted and furiously active of contemporary Scotsmen, "No Escape From
CHICAGO, July 3 -- The Federal Government has been asked to bail the public schools out of their serious financial crisis.

SALONIKA, Greece, June 26 -- Sitting here on the balcony of a small hotel, with the breeze blowing softly off the Aegean Sea below, the college world of New Haven, with its classrooms, its football week-ends and its fraternities, seems eons away.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 (AP) -- Bill Talbert, the United States Davis Cup captain, looked back on the Wimbledon lawn tennis championships today and said: "Now we have got several problems to work out before the Davis Cup challenge round."
Of the various taxes included in the revenue laws today, the one that at times approaches closest to the metaphysical in concept is the capital gains tax.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- Dr. Ralph R. Shaw, 48 years old, a professor in the Graduate School of Library Service at Rutgers University, has been elected first vice president and presidentelect of the American Library Association.
CHICAGO, July 3 -- The wheat market showed strength early last week, following the vote ratifying marketing quotas. But futures prices did not hold their gains.

EACH June, while the RitzCarlton Hotel was in existence, Chef Louis Diat created at least one new hot-weather dish for the annual opening of the summer garden restaurant. His most famous innovation was, of course, vichy soisse, actually a chilled adaptation of the French leek and potato soup.
MOSCOW, July 3 -- Pravda welcomed today the "sensible statement" of The New York Times recommending more cultural exchanges between the United States and the Soviet Union.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3 -- The Tavern on the Green in Central Park is scheduled for a face-lifting operation with a reverse twist. Columbia Pictures has obtained permission to redesign the exterior of the restaurant so it will resemble the old Central Park Casino.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 3 -- Wolf Ladejinsky said today that he was "extremely gratified" that the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, had cleared him as a "security risk." Mr. Ladejinsky said in a prepared statement that Secretary Benson's action was "a belated but happy vindication of the principles of justice and fair play on which American democracy rests."

MOSCOW, July 3 -- At the end of play tonight in the Russian-American chess match, Samuel Reshevsky of the United States led the champion of the world, Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union, by 2 points to 1.

BUFFALO, N. Y., July 3 (AP) -- A University of Chicago Track Club team today lowered the Amateur Athletic Union championship 1 7/8 mile medley relay mark from 7:41.5 to 7:21.1. The old mark was set here by the New York Pioneer Club last year.
NEW MILFORD, Conn., July 3 -- Like the theatre, music keeps spreading through the green and pleasant country-side in the summer.

TORONTO, June 20 -- Within a few months this city will complete a $16,000,000 project by which a downtown slum has been transformed into a park-like community and thousands of its residents exposed to a new way of life on the site of the old.

The Yankees reached the halfway mark yesterday at the Stadium, where they played their seventy-seventh game of the season. They lost the contest, 5 -- 0, to Johnny Schmitz and the Washington Senators, but there was no gloom in the clubhouse afterwards.
Traffic in the Port of New York, as measured in arrival and departure of seagoing vessels, increased in the first six months of 1955 over the same period last year.
PARIS, July 3 -- The national congress of the Socialist party called today for electoral reform in Algeria "to give the population means of political expression."
SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 -- West Coast shipowners were taking a good look this weekend at a proposed new type of contract for their seagoing unlicensed personnel.
BERLIN, July 3 -- West Berlin's revival as a major European fashion center will enter a new phase with the creation of a downtown garment center similar to Manhattan's.

VIENNA, July 3--An agreement has been reached in part between the World Committee for Jewish Claims Against Austria and the Austrian Government. It covers a method by which Jewish victims of nazism will be indemnified but not the amount.

Arthur Feldman of 154 East Ninety-first Street became champion chess player of Washington Square Park yesterday. His opponent, Harry Fajans of 30 Magaw Place resigned from the "knockout" tournament after one hour forty-five minutes of play in the broiling sun.

" Seventh Heaven" closed after its forty-fourth performance Saturday night at the ANTA Theatre. The decision to pull up stakes was no surprise. A closing notice had been posted hastily on Wednesday to take effect at the end of the week.
Governor Harriman announced yesterday his approval of a modified contract for the sale of state-generated St. Lawrence River hydroelectric power to the Aluminum Company of America.

LONDON, July 3 -- The midsummer boom in the stock markets has faded out and given place to much quieter conditions in the last few days. There has not been much selling but a widespread decline in prices has occurred, with industrial shares the principal sufferers.
Some new household aids, well designed and functional, also add decorative notes to the housewife's domain, the kitchen.
ZURICH, Switzerland, July 3 -- The European Payments Union multilateral settlement last Thursday was made on the old basis for the last time.
PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (UP) -- U Nu, Prime Minister of Burma, said today that the ideals of the American Revolution were more explosive in their capacity to change the world than atomic bombs.

Now that H. R. 1 (the new Trade Agreements Act) has become law, there is a widespread tendency on the part of the press, as well as of the Administration, to stress the importance of what Congress gave the Administration and to overlook the vital concessions which the Administration made in order to get what it did.

MOSCOW, July 3 -- The Soviet Union has put into the air a four-engine jet transport plane apparently suitable for both military and civilian use. The big, trim airliner unexpectedly made its public debut today at the annual air parade over Tushino Airport on the outskirts of Moscow. Also shown were a turboprop intercontinental bomber, a twin-jet all-weather fighter, a supersonic single-jet fighter and a twin-rotor troop-carrying helicopter.
MALMOE, Sweden, July 3 (AP) -- Group Capt. Peter Townsend rode the winner today in an international horse race for amateur riders. Prince Aly Khan finished fourth.

Crew members and guests aboard a heavy cruiser, dedicated at its launching "to universal peace," yesterday heard one prescription for preserving that peace. Preaching in a general Protestant service on the afterdeck of the Newport News, Capt. Maurice M. Witherspoon, retired Navy chaplain, told of the role of "Sailors for a New Day."

LONDON, July 3--Dock workers in Manchester, Liverpool and Hull voted today to return to work. This would speed the end of the most costly of the three strikes that have combined to cripple Britain's export trade.

A note of alarm is clearly evident in much recent Soviet comment on agricultural progress this year. After the frenzied effort this spring which resulted in 50,000,000 additional acres being planted, it is charged that the farmers are not cultivating the fields in many cases. There is obviously not enough farm machinery so that "the most advanced agriculture in the world" must use every horse, ox or buffalo available for draft power.
THURMONT, Md., July 3 (UP) -- President Eisenhower took it easy at his Catoctin Mountain retreat near here today as his contribution to a safe and sane Fourth of July week-end.

The origins of our democracy may be found in the Judeo-Christian religions, the Rev. Dr. William B. McAlpin said yesterday. He preached at the West-Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth street.

The tenth birthday of the United Nations was the occasion for deserved tributes to the late Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg's labors on behalf of the Charter in San Francisco and in Washington. The Senator believed that the Assembly would be "tomorrow's Town Meeting of the World."

Almost 100,000,000 people live in captive Eastern Europe today, subjects of the Kremlin as much as persons living in Moscow or Vladivostok. Whether in Prague or in Budapest, in Warsaw or in Bucharest, the Communist gauleiters in control seek to win their subjects' loyalty by a monopoly of internal information.
A visiting British vicar said yesterday that the American evangelist Billy Graham, by his appearances in the British Isles, had encouraged thousand to "take down their Bibles from the shelves."
Producers of "Inherit the Wind," a Broadway play, have decided against participating in a telecast for fear that a showing on home screens might cut receipts.
SANDY HOOK, N. J., July 3 -- A retired oil company executive and two women were badly burned today when a gasoline explosion and fire destroyed a thirty-seven-foot yacht.

MARSTRAND, Sweden, July 3 (Reuters)--A 54-year-old former Norwegian lifeboat skippered by a wartime resistance hero tonight stood between the American yacht Carina and victory in the trans-Atlantic yacht race.

On Saturday evening, July 6, 1776, Philadelphians who paid "only two coppers" read for the first time in a newspaper the document by which the thirteen colonies broke their allegiance to Great Britian.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., July 3 (AP) -- A partner in the Chicago architectural firm that designed the Air Force Academy says the controversial model of the cadet chapel had been abandoned.

The death of Leopold Prince in the fall of 1951 was a blow to the City Symphony Orchestra, which he founded and led for more than thirty years. The group, however, has survived the winter seasons and on Saturday night it came back into the summer picture.
For a long time at Ebbets Field yesterday a steaming crowd of 15,000 must have been convinced the National League had suddenly turned itself upside down.

HACKENSACK, N. J., July 3 -- Eddie Moylan of Trenton won the Eastern clay court tennis championship for the second straight year with a 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0 victory over Ron Holmberg of Brooklyn today.

WASHINGTON, July 3--The "art collection" started by Thomas Stephens, former appointments secretary to the President, finally has been put up for exhibition in, appropriately, a corridor of the White House.

Joseph Sager Sons, builders and realty investors, have sold the one-story building with nine stores at 2053-59 Morris Avenue, also fronting at 67-81 East Burnside Avenue, the Bronx. Sylvia Garfinkel and Elaine Blankstein were the buyers.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Carmine G. DeSapio said here today he was confident New York's delegation would support Governor Harriman for the Democratic Presidential nomination at the national convention next year.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -- The Weather Bureau is installing a powerful radar set at Cape Hatteras, N. C., as part of the hurricane warning system on the Eastern seaboard.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 3 -- The crews of about 130 racing yachts were blistered by relentless sun today and then headed for home ports with nothing to show for the afternoon except sunburn.
Prayers for the Roman Catholic clergy and laity of Argentina and for "all the other persecuted peoples of the world" were offered yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
WASHINGTON, July 3--The serious illness of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, the Senate Democratic leader, is throwing shadows across the whole polito-governmental scene.

A new theme for Independence Day: "One's deepest loyalties cannot any longer be attached exclusively to one's own homeland, "but must be based on the understanding and needs of men everywhere, was suggested yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John Paul Jones.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Eisenhower Administration is now consciously cutting its losses on programs under severe attack for many months.
An audience of 7,500 braved the threat of rain Saturday evening and went to Lewisohn Stadium to hear a program of music conducted by Andre Kostelanetz.

ATHENS, July 3 -- About 200 fine vases dating from the late Helladic period (1250-1200 B. C.) have been found in four chamber tombs opened at Glyfada, a seaside resort on the West Coast of Attica, near Athens.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 3 -- The Right Rev. Dr. Horace W. B. Donegan, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, preaching here today, said all freedom-loving nations would endure if humility and patience were brought too bear on the relationship between nations and individuals.

THERE has been a fable that has gained so much popularity in baseball circles down through the years that it now has come to be accepted as a tradition. It is, viz., namely and to wit: The teams that lead the pennant races on the Fourth of July are the ones who will meet in the world series in October. Oh, yeah?
WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -- Edward F. Howrey, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today the F. T. C. planned to issue more anti-merger complaints.
Members of the radio and television artists union have voted by a margin of nearly two to one to support a resolution condemning AWARE, Inc.
CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs gained their eighth split of twelve double-headers by beating St. Louis, 10 -- 5, after the Cardinals captured the opener, 8 -- 2, before 35,176 today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 3 (Reuters) -- More than 100 men and women were arrested here today for having staged a demonstration calling for elections to unite South Vietnam with the Communist northern part of the country.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, called today for prompt Senate passage of a resolution asking President Eisenhower to take the lead in creating an international commission to study the full effects of atomic fall-out on the world's populations.

If our observation of Independence Day has gradually become more and more of a picnic festival and less and less of a patriotic celebration, there may be good reason. After a century and three-quarters we are naturally inclined to take our "independence" for granted.
The beaches and picnic areas of the metropolitan area could not accommodate all the people who sought relief yesterday on the hottest day of the year.

ROME, July 3 -- The strategic and political picture in the Eastern Mediterranean is gradually shifting and Britain's reluctant decision to discuss the future of Cyprus with Greece and Turkey indicates the changing pattern. Already in Iran, Iraq, Egypt and the Sudan London has had to recognize the new force of nationalism.
WALDEN, N. Y., July 3 (AP) -- A Brooklyn girl was killed and her fiance injured in a two-car collision last night.

GUATEMALA, July 3 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas assured his people today that his second year in office would bring higher living standards and "the most advanced constitution in Guatemalan history."

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -- The Democratic - controlled Eighty-fourth Congress is runnings far ahead of its Republican - dominated predecessor in the number of bills approved to date, official records showed today.
ALBANY, July 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of Governor Harriman's statement on the contract to supply St. Lawrence River power to the Aluminum Company of America:

Admiral Ben Moreell, retired, chairman of the task force on water resources of the Hoover Commission, has challenged one of the four dissents to the commission's report on water resources made public last Wednesday.
PHILADELPHIA, July 3--Working in the kind of hot weather he likes so well, Ruben Gomez today pitched the Giants to a 4-3 triumph over the Phillies before 8,259 at Connie Mack Stadium.

CINCINNATI, July 3 (UP) -- The Milwaukee Braves snapped Joe Nuxhall's string of consecutive shutout innings at twenty-eight today. The Braves went on to defeat the Cincinnati Redlegs, 7 -- 3, as Warren Spahn scattered ten hits.
Chester R. Green has been appointed sales manager of the Kraft Foods Company. He formerly was national cheese products sales manager.

One hundred years ago today -- give or take a day or so -- an unknown author, who had set the type and paid the cost of printing, published "Leaves of Grass" in a small shop in Brooklyn. Today a small group of Walt Whitman devotees will walk to the corner of Cranberry and Fulton Streets to stand for a moment in front of a bronze tablet commemorating that event.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Senator Earle C. Clements, who will act as Senate majority leader for the rest of the session, is a 58-year-old "moderate" Democrat generally acceptable to both the Northern and Southern factions of his party.

The Hoover Commission's published recommendations for improving this country's intelligence service are inadequate to solve the problem of intelligence from behind the Iron Curtain, some sources close to the problem believe.
Neal Goldman Associates Inc, industrial designers, in 34 E 51st St -- Joseph P. Gavron, broker.

A business that got its start on a garlic press nearly three years ago has now accounted for the import of 4,000,000 gift items from more than thirty countries. The Italian gadget was taken on as an interesting addition to the line of household and kitchen ware sold by Damar Products, Inc., a direct mail order house.
CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- The starting American and National League line-ups for the twenty-second All-Star game in Milwaukee, July 12, were announced tonight.

AS years go on, great historical figures assume superhuman proportions. Any warmth, personality or humanity their names might have once conjured up grows progressively dimmer. But a visit to Mount Vernon or Monticello, and the sight of a favorite bed or chair, serves as a reminder that Founding Fathers were once young bridegrooms furnishing homes.
The Pelham Bay Little League controversy is not an excellent example of the "departmentalized thinking" of modern Americans, as Mary T. Maiellaro in her letter published June 25 thinks it is.
