SANTIAGO, Chile, July 3 -- A powerful bomb wrecked the offices of the anti-administration newspaper El Debate just after 1 A. M. today. There were no casualties.
The city will rush the construction of a Youth House in the Bronx even if the job costs nearly $2,000,000 more than was originally estimated, City Council President Abe Stark predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- -- Senator Harry F. Byrd said today the Eisenhower Administration was "lessening its efforts for economy." He said it had better get busy cutting expenses if it wanted to reduce taxes next year.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 3 -- In a midyear report President Tito's Government said today the nation's economy was still in difficulties. This is particularly true of the balance of payments in foreign commerce, a Government spokesman declared before Parliament.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Ten statuettes, named Ernies in memory of the late war correspondent, Ernie Pyle, were presented tonight by the Airborne Association in recognition of outstanding journalistic contributions to national defense during the year.

New York's pioneer Law Against Discrimination has now been in effect for a full decade, and the commission charged with its administration has published an illustrated booklet in celebration of progress and in furtherance of its mission of equality of opportunity for all.
Cotton prices here rose last week on future deliveries. There was a high volume of trading in the October, 1956, contract.
BALTIMORE, July 3 (UP) -- Frank Sullivan gained his eleventh victory of the season and his seventh in a row today as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 7 to 2.
It is with regret that I have realized that some Americans have not clearly understood the nature of Peron's attacks against the Catholic Church in Argentina.
PARIS, July 3 -- The French Government is studying Premier Ngo Dinh Diem's complaints about a franc shortage in South Vietnam. Direct fund aid by the United States is one proposed remedy.

Four buildings occupying the blockfront on the west side of Nostrand Avenue between St. Marks Avenue and Bergen Street in Brooklyn have been sold by the Cord Helmer Realty Corporation to the Bergnos Realty Corporation. The deal was negotiated by the Bulkley Horton Company.

The Empire Trust Company's statement of condition at the end of June showed reductions during the second quarter of this year of $13,890,132 in deposits and $13,285,893 in holdings of United States Government securities.

PITTSBURGH, July 3 -- Steel procurement is now the tightest it has been since early 1953. The wage agreements reached last week ended production slowdowns but heavy backlogs give promise of keeping the industry operating at a high rate for the foreseeable future.
The city is appealing from a Supreme Court decision forbidding it to pay a $20,000 claim filed last May by Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 3 (AP) -- In cheerful spirits, despite wounds, burns and bandages, seven United States fliers whose Navy patrol plane was shot down June 22 by Soviet jet fighters over the Bering Sea arrived here today from Anchorage, Alaska.

A FRIDAY sign in a cafeteria in Broadway between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets told check-payers: "Happy Holiday. Please Drive Carefully." Under that, with neat commercial candor, it added: "We can't afford to lose customers."

Prime Minister Nu of Burma, on tour of the United States after an official visit in Washington, arrived here last night for a three-day round of sight-seeing and public appearances. Attired in characteristic Burmese costume -- a green sarong, long-sleeved yellow jacket and a tight yellow headdress -- U Nu stepped briskly into the Pierre Hotel lobby at 7:10 P. M.
BUENOS AIRES, July 3 (AP) -- The Roman Catholic Church and President Juan D. Peron's Government gave evidence today that they were eager to settle their bitter dispute.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- With Washington's acquiescence, the South Vietnamese Government has shelved a United States-sponsored plan to trim the Vietnamese Army down to an elite force of 100,000.

KANSAS CITY, July 3 (AP) -- Vic Power's second home run of the game in the fourteenth inning gave the Kansas City Athletics a 9-8 victory over the Detroit Tigers today and a sweep of their four-game series. The game lasted 3 hours and 58 minutes.

Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of West Germany, has recorded the essence of his political philosophy in his book, "World Indivisible," which Harper will publish on Aug. 10. Dr. Adenauer discusses many practical aspects of a revived Germany, its re

AMRITSAR, India, July 3 -- About 6,000 garlanded Sikhs have danced off to jail in the Indian Punjab with great determination and a considerable amount of good nature. With just as much determination and pleasantness the police are giving assurances that there is room for many more in their spacious prisons.

JERUSALEM, July 3 -- Egypt's reported intention to ask for replacement of Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns as United Nations truce chief was deplored in foreign diplomatic circles here today as harmful to his effort to quiet the Gaza border.
SETAUKET, L. I., July 3 -- With a program in the old-fashioned Fourth of July tradition, this North Shore village of 2,500 is observing its 300th anniversary.

I have been writing for years on the matter of abolishing the Regents exam in American history. We do not need this kind of examination. And now we have the outcry from the schools that this June exam was too difficult, resulting in too many failures. Let's obviate this situation by having the school itself act as the best judge of what its students can do and should do.

The rate of installation of heavy equipment and new plant facilities -- summarized in the term "capital goods" -- is not slowing at all, but is continuing to rise. The post-war boom in such expansion apparently has not overreached itself and a rising level "should be sustainable" in the months ahead, according to the Machinery and Allied Products Institute.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Senator James O. Eastland said today that the late Harry Dexter White, a former Treasury Department official who has been called a Soviet spy, "had a world - wide commercial espionage system reporting to him."
Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, former chairman of the Transit Authority, said yesterday he saw no need for a fare increase.

In 1872 the Government of China sent a group of thirty teen-age boys to the United States for training. That, it is believed, was the first organized visit of foreign students to our shores. Since then, with the exception of periods of war, the number of foreign students and scholars coming to this country has increased with each year.
NEW HAVEN, July 3 (AP) -- Ninety years ago New Yorkers and other Americans considered apartment houses a threat to morality.
There have been many changes on the West Side of Manhattan in the last twenty-five years, but, to paraphrase an old saying, the more it changes the more it remains the West Side.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, July 3 (UP) -- Prince Rainier III asked for and accepted tonight the resignations of his entire Cabinet in the aftermath of last week's run on a leading Monte Carlo bank.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3 -- Television has brought to Hollywood an economic philosophy that goes a step further than the guaranteed annual wage. In addition to receiving their initial compensation, the creative craftsmen of the Film City are moving successfully toward winning a continuing annuity from their labors.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 3 (AP) -- A mother and her three children were killed at a picnic ground today when lightning struck a tree under which they had retreated in a thunderstorm. Three others, including the father, were injured.

Count Philippe de la Lafayette and Count Jean de Rochambeau arrived yesterday. Descendants of the French Generals Lafayette and Rochambeau, who aided in the Ameridan Revolution, they will take part in the 175th anniversary celebration of the arrival of French forces at Newport, R. I., in 1780.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The idea of getting rid of the Electoral College in the choice of President is an old one. Andrew Jackson when President devoted several paragraphs of each of his eight annual messages to the subject, but without result. Now Senator Humphrey is going to try his hand at the job.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (UP) -- A Census Bureau survey indicated today that 80 per cent of all married women between 15 and 59 years old were still wed to their first husbands.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Congress has put the "still in business" sign on an advisory committee that has saved $300,000,000 in military physicians' salaries during the last few years.

United States investments in Europe are the counterpart of European investments in the United States. Before the rise of exchange controls and economic planning, capital and know-how flowed freely both ways between the continents.
CHICAGO, July 4 -- An aggressive program of political action is being charted by the nation's school officials.

CLEVELAND, July 4 (AP) -- Larry Doby singled home a run in the first game, then pounded out two one-run homers in the second contest today as the Cleveland Indians downed the Detroit Tigers, 6 -- 5 and 8 -- 5. The double-header was played in sweltering 96-degree heat.
MOSCOW, July 4 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan has accepted an invitation to dine on Fifty-second Street -- that is, the next time he is in New York.
Textron American, Inc., has arranged to buy the international cable system of Western Union Telegraph Company for $18,000,000.
ROME, July 4 (AP) -- Premier-designate Antonio Segni has been promised the support of all four Center parties for a new Italian coalition Government, it was announced tonight.

GOTHENBURG, Sweden, July 4 (UP) -- Bengt Nilsson, Sweden's European high-jump champion, defeated Ernie Shelton of Southern California today in a Scandinavian - American track and field meet at Slottsskogsvallen. However, United States athletes won five other events.
Eartha Kitt, the singer, reporter last night the theft of $32,400 in furs and pearls from her thirteenth-floor penthouse apartment at 270 Riverside Drive, near Ninety-ninth Street.
Milo Savage, 161, Salt Lake City, outpointed Sammy Walker, 156 1/2, Springfield, Mass., in the ten-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
PITTSBURGH, July 4 -- Forbes Fields became Rhubarb Field today as the Giants and Pirates split a double-header. Many of the 16,902 Pittsburgh fans threatened to split the umpires' skulls.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York sees favorable prospects for dollar earnings abroad, the lowering of international trade barriers and steps toward convertibility of the free world's major currencies.
A nineteen-passenger helicopter is being built for airline use.
THE angling visitor to this country might wonder whether our anglers are interested in fishing for fun and fish or whether their interest lies in competing with other anglers.
The American Cargo War Risk Reinsurance Exchange of 99 John Street reports that ten years after World War II shipping still continues to be plagued by floating mines.
The weather went on a Fourth of July spree yesterday, setting a 1955 record for the third day in a row -- 95.8 degrees at 4:05 P. M.

NEW DELHI, India, July 4 -- The Communist party disclosed today new tactics based on trying to work within Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's own Congress party and his Government's mass development projects.
LONDON, July 4 -- The fifth International Student Conference opened today at Birmingham University to consider the problems of students of the free world.
BUENOS AIRES, July 4 -- Tension in this city mounted today to its highest pitch since the revolt of June 16.

TAIPEI, Formosa, June 29 -- Nationalist China's military establishment is slowly being fashioned by the United States into a modern fighting force faithfully following the American model in doctrine as well as organization.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson remained in "serious" condition today at the Navy Medical Center in Bethesda, Md.
"BAKING" potatoes in melted rosin, the gummy substance from pine trees, may sound a bit bizarre. But spuds done in this way are delicious, according to those who have tasted them.

A New York City fireman who answered eight alarms Saturday night and who was due back on duty last night, took time out yesterday afternoon to paddle to victory in three of the six senior events of the Metropolitan canoeing championships.
Governor Harriman issued a enw defense last night of his approval of the controversial Aluminum Company of America contract for St. Lawrence River hydro-electric power.

A test pilot who made the initial flights of the country's first vertical take-off (V. T. O.) fighter plane and a Navy flier who kept a dirigible aloft for eight days won the 1955 Harmon International Aviation Trophies.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- While keeping a close watch for White House developments, Senate Democrats stand ready to renew their fight on the Dixon-Yates power contract when Congress returns tomorrow from its holiday week-end.
MOSCOW, July 4 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev put the Western powers on notice today that if they did not want to talk seriously at Geneva the Soviet Union "can wait and hold on."
VIENTIANE, Laos, July 4 -- The armed Laotian Communists continue to pose a serious threat to this elongated Buddhist kingdom, landlocked in the upper reaches of the Indochina peninsula.

POZNAN, Poland, July 3 -- Josef Cyrankiewicz, Polish Premier, opened the Poznan Trade Fair today. President Boleslaw Bierut attended a brief ceremony and later accompanied the Premier on a tour of the pavilions.

Casey Stengel's blueprint for the big week-end was ripped to shreds yesterday at the Stadium. The manager of the pacesetting Yankees had figured upon a sweep of the three games with the Senators and a split with the red hot Red Sox. He was only slightly wrong about Washington, which won one of three, but he was all wrong about Boston.

The Fifth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, so far as is indicated by reports of the Independence Day celebrations, did not get any special attention from the orators. But nothing could have been more fitting, and, regrettably, more necessary. Because the Fifth Amendment has recently acquired a bad name it does not deserve, being one of the great repositories and protectors of liberty in this country.
LONDON, July 4 -- The six-week-old strike of dockworkers in seven British ports ended today.
ROME, July 4 -- The two Roman Catholic prelates who were expelled from Argentina three weeks ago indicated today they would be allowed to return.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 4 -- The largest Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta of the season was distinguished by the most hectic mass finish of them all today. The 144-boat event of the Larchmont Yacht Club also produced the first Y. R. A. appearance of the majestic twelve-meters, which sailed a too-long twenty-mile course.

"MY dad taught me that loyalty come first," said Eddie Brannick, the boy philosopher. The secretary of the Giants has so many engaging and admirable qualities that they almost defy cataloguing. But if there is a more intensely loyal man than Brannick in this village of ours, he's been hiding.

TORONTO, July 4 (Canadian Press) -- Tom Patterson, founder of the Shakespeare festival at Stratford, Ont., said today negotiations were "nearing completion" for presentation of "Oedipus Rex," one of the festival plays, on Broadway next winter.
E. J. Garvey has been named merchandise coordinator for six departments within the cotton apparel fabrics division of Pacific Mills, a member organization of Burlington Industries.

DUBLIN, July 4 (UP) -- Hugh Stewart, the defending champion in the Irish dawn tennis title tourney, began his bid to retain the singles title today with a 7-5, 6-2 victory over Julian Drury-Byrne of Dublin.
MEXICO CITY, July 4 (AP) -- The dominant Party of Revolutionary Institutions said today it had won a one-sided victory from the quietest general election in Mexico's history.

LONDON, July 4 -- Britain has pledged cession to the Union of South Africa of a naval base that she has held for almost 150 years, in return for an agreement on the naval defense of South African waters.

The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor is encouraged but "far from satisfied" by the progress achieved in two fiscal years. This is made clear in its annual report, issued for publication today. The report expressed the belief that a "vacuum" would exist if the bi-state agency were to be abolished at this time.

LONDON, July 4 -- The Western Big Three powers, with the cooperation of West Germany, are trying to adjust Sir Anthony Eden's plan for German reunification so that it will be more palatable to the Soviet Union.
A pedestrian was mysteriously shot in East Harlem last night despite a heavy concentration of police sent into the area on a tip that a youth gang war was brewing.
JAKARTA, Indonesia. A town not so very different from a suburb in the United States is flourishing in the Sumatra jungle.

A new book by Richard Hofstadter, author of "The American Political Tradition," will be issued in October by Knopf. "The Age of Reform" examines "the passion for progress and reform" that "colored" the period from 1890 to 1940.
The first group of mid-year statements, issued over the weekend by leadnig New York City banks, shows a rise in net operating earnings for the first six months of the year.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- The National Park Service is planning bigger and better things for visitors to the nation's scenic and historic areas.
GENEVA, July 4 -- Western Germany has reached new tariff agreements with Norway and Sweden. Negotiations are continuing here between the German and Danish delegations.

In one of its first actions since winning a treaty of independence the Austrian Government is taking steps to liquidate one of the saddest legacies left to it by the Hitler regime. It has reached agreement with the World Committee for Jewish Claims on the methods by which it proposes to indemnify Jewish victims of nazism in Austria.

The Anthem's New Spangles That ever-popular organization, the Goldman Band, just on its thirty-eighth season of summer performances at the Mall in Central Park, has produced a novelty which will be heard in every concert of the series, a new arrangement, by Robert Russell Bennett, of "The Star-Spangled Banner."
Lillian Roth confirmed a report yesterday that she had withdrawn as the chief performer for "Pleasure Dome," the revue that Jack Segasture plans to produce.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (UP) -- The Defense Department again is studying plans for burial of an unknown soldier of World War II in Arlington National Cemetery alongside the unknown soldier of World War I.

GENEVA, July 4 -- The chief impact here of United States preparation for the Big Four conference has been the introduction of the special kind of administrative confusion that is native to the lower reaches of the Potomac.

VIEWERS who spent much time before their television screens over the holiday week-end saw a conglomeration of programs that should help to make the outdoors more popular than ever during the rest of the summer.
TAIPEI, Formosa, July 4 -- The Chinese National Air Force claimed last night the possible destruction of a Communist MIG-15 jet fighter in a dogfight in the vicinity of the Matsus.

Net sales of the General Tire and Rubber Company and its consolidated subsidiaries in the six months ended May 31 were $130,342,661. That was the largest six-month record in the company's history and represented an increase of 40.1 per cent over the $96,619,965 registered in the first half of 1954.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm's Mark-Ye-Well, supposedly an over-the-hill racer after only one victory in twelve starts this season, today withstood a stretch challenge by Ruhe to score a neck victory in the $28,225 Stars and Stripes Handicap at Arlington Park.
Some New Yorkers looked a bit startled when they came back yesterday from the long week-end and found girls with cardboard ears of corn in their hair wandering around Pennsylvania Station.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 4 -- Santiago has begun to feel the pinch of the national transport strike. A growing shortage of gasoline and kerosene has resulted and a food shortage is imminent if the strikes go on.

More than 2,000 United States corporations control and operate business enterprises abroad with a book value of $16,200,000,000. Through these oil fields, mines, factories and mills the companies are bringing the democratic values and the material advantages of American civilization to less developed areas.

STRASBOURG, France, July 4 (UP) -- Fifteen Western European nations called on the Allied Big Three today to try to end the "cold war" through a mutual system of collective security and a unified Germany.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4 -- The making of motion pictures without the use of film was said today to be perhaps only a year away from commercial introduction.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The United States has entered the second half of 1955 with every prospect of achieving new production and sales records, Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, declared today.
Although some showcases played to excellent business, the holiday heat wave put a damper on attendance at a majority of Broadway's first-run houses, the various managements reported yesterday.
MARSTRAND, Sweden, July 4 (Reuters) -- The fifty-four-foot American yawl Carina II of Greenwich, Conn., was declared the official winner of the trans-Atlantic yacht race tonight.

The contract for sale of about a fourth of the state-generated power to come from the St. Lawrence hydroelectric project to the Aluminum Company of America has been modified somewhat and approved by Governor Harriman. Robert Moses, chairman of the State Power Authority, says its members are "well satisfied" with the contract.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 4 -- A program of graduate study leading to a doctorate in religion has been planned by Princeton University's Department of Religion, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, announced today.

President Eisenhower sent Fourth of July greetings yesterday to the people of five Soviet satellite countries. He was joined by other prominent Americans in a program sponsored by Radio Free Europe, which is celebrating its fifth anniversary.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 4 -- Someone new has been added to the rosters of specialists at this year's conference of the American Home Economics Association, which met here last week. It is the woman who qualifies as an expert in that she holds down a twenty-four-hour job in a laboratory called home.
BOMBAY, India. For twenty-five years, half his life, Gopal Pandu has been an employe of the United States pharmaceutical concern, Parke, Davis Co.
The 179th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence was celebrated throughout the nation yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today it had issued a complaint charging the Paint Dealers Institute of New York City and six affiliated associations with a conspiracy in restraint of trade.

WASHINGTON July 4 -- After more than four months, the nomination of Newell Brown of New Hampshire to be Wage and Hour Administrator has been taken off the shelf by the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare. But it may be headed for a worse fate.

CALGARY, Alberta, July 1 -- In 1933 the University of Alberta, in western Canada, received a grant of $10,000 from the Carnegie Fund for the advancement of fine arts. Rather hesitantly the governors of the school agreed to establish a course in drama in the Canadian mountain resort of Banff.

LONDON, July 4 -- The stock markets resumed their rally today after a rather quiet start. The end of the dock strike served to offset Chancellor R. A. Butler's warning about the rising cost of British products and measures to curb home consumption.
In all Asia and the Far East, there is no more colorful story of American enterprise in far-off places than the career of Herman Fred Scholtz in Thailand.

During the last quarter-century there has been a significant change in the position of Latin America among United States foreign investment interests. In 1929 about half of all direct investments of United States citizens were in near-by countries -- Canada, Mexico, the West Indies.

JERUSALEM. Jacob Lampner, a refugee from a Nazi slave labor camp, was a furrier when he came to Israel in 1950. Like other refugees, he answered a "help-wanted" advertisement of a plant erected by the partnership of two men and a United States corporation.

A religious center is planned on the east side of Hendrix Street, between Stanley Avenue and Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn. Nine lots there comprising a plot 180 by 100 feet have been purchased by the Congregation B'nai Israel from the City of New York.

MANILA, July 4 -- Two respected statesmen at an Independence Day celebration here reaffirmed Philippine - United States friendship in rebuke to its persistent detractors among Filipino politicians and neutralists.

This past holiday week-end must have convinced many citizens, including lawmakers, that the automobile has come to stay and that it must be accommodated. Congress is still wrestling with the question of how the Federal Government will meet its share of financing highway modernization and expansion.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I offer a few comments with reference to the Administration's highway building program, referred to in your columns?

John B. Schlossberg has been elected president of the Max Schlossberg Company, Chicago, to succeed Max Schlossberg, who has been named chairman of the board. John Schlossberg was formerly vice president. Paul Becker, former vice president, has been elected executive vice president, and Edwin A. Superfine vice president.

MILWAUKEE, July 4 (UP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Milwaukee Braves, 4 -- 2 and 5 -- 4, today as the Braves passed the million mark in home attendance. The setbacks marked the first time this season the Braves had dropped a twin bill.

EPIDAVROS, Greece, July 4 (UP) -- Judith Anderson, who has starred in classical dramas in the United States, announced today she is going to play "Hamlet" dressed as a man and wearing slacks. Work on the production is expected to start after her four-month tour of Australia in "Medea" beginning Oct. 6.
NEW DELHI, India, July 4 -- Three United States former prisoners of the Korean war who have had enough of living in Communist China will be released at the Hong Kong border on Saturday.

Tony Trabert returned from Europe yesterday with the British and French tennis championships, an armful of racquets and no immediate plans for turning professional. He came back, too, with the belief that the United States has better than a 50-50 chance of keeping the Davis cup.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 4 -- Intergroup relations agencies were advised today to devote as much effort to ensuring enforcement of civil rights legislation as to achieving its enactment.

Aldo Villani reckons he is the luckiest man in Milan. His luck began nine years ago when, at the age of 29, he was hired as an electrician by the general sales agency in Italy of the National Cash Register Company of Dayton, Ohio.

Today's issue of this newspaper carries a broad survey of American business operations in a number of countries in all parts of the world. It was the possible expansion of such activities that formed the original "Point Four" concept. What is offered here is a glimpse of what is being done now to translate the concept into action.

The five-story building containing seven stores and twenty-four apartments at 1491 Brook Avenue in the Bronx has been purchased by the Goodman-Herman Company, real estate operator. The property, assessed at $54,000, occupies a corner plot 50 by 100 feet at 171st Street.
One of the most feted persons in New York yesterday was a white-bearded Italian priest attending the eighth annual convention of the American Ex-Prisoners of War.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- A leading champion of freedom of information said tonight the Department of Welfare had been too secretive about the Salk anti-polio vaccine. He said that as a result when defects appeared there was "a great shock to the public opinion."
Admirers of Walt Whitman, who were to have dedicated a park named for the poet, met instead yesterday at the site where his "Leaves of Grass" was printed one hundred years ago.

With an unusually good first-half volume of business loans tucked away, major New York City banks are looking forward to an even greater increase in the next six months. Normally, business loans decline during the first half of the year as fall borrowers pay off heavy indebtedness. This year, new loans more than offset such repayments.
POINT O'WOODS, FIRE ISLAND, L. I., July 4 -- This island's famed "sunken forest" has finally been saved for posterity.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 4 -- Eddie Moylan made his debut as the top-seeded player in the New York State tennis championships today at the County Tennis Club. The Trenton player, who won the Eastern clay court title yesterday for his twelfth 1955 tournament victory, entered the third round here without trouble.
Horazio Fresno, 42-year-old mechanic, thinks that the Americans are "wonderful people."

BABYLON, L. I., July 4 -- Fred Scopinich's Starfire took the Star Class honors as the Babylon Yacht Club's three-day invitation regatta ended today. Starfire had two firsts and a second, scoring her second triumph on the final program.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- A $1,000 reward was offered today to anyone locating the Monitor, the famous Union ironclad ship of the Civil War.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The farmer as in the past is being ground between the millstones of high cost and low prices until such a time as calamity strikes and the entire world is in the depths of one of the greatest depressions.
Prime Minister Nu of Burma, a smiling statesman with a tourist's gleam in his eye, looked over a large slice of New York life yesterday.

MILLVILLE, N. J., July 4 -- John Wehrle, the Hackensack youngster who was hospitalized briefly by a regatta accident on Saturday at Hampton, Va., made a good recovery today. In the American Power Boat Association Region 3 championships on Laurel Lake for outboard stock runabouts and stock hydroplanes, he carried off two titles. Region 3 comprises New Jersey, Delaware and eastern Pennsylvania.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 4 -- A grant of $100,000 to the Stanford University School of Medicine by the John and Mary R. Markle Foundation of New York was announced today. The money is to be used to help move the school from San Francisco to the university's main campus near here.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (UP) -- Key House Republicans will begin tomorrow a last-ditch effort to salvage President Eisenhower's plans for a $101,000,000,000 interstate highway program.

CHICAGO, July 4 (UP) -- Warren Hacker knocked in two runs with a single and pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 4-3 victory in the second game of a double-header today. The Cincinnati Redlegs won the opener, 6 -- 3, before 21,759 fans.
Between the Middle East, cul-ural center of the Moslem world, and the Union of South Africa, where a part of Europe has been reconstructed on the veldt, lies one of man's last frontiers.
TIMMINS, Ont., July 4 (AP) -- Cyrus S. Eaton of Cleveland said today he was not involved in any internal dispute for control of the McIntyre Porcupine gold mine.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- The Dodgers roared up to the halfway mark in the National League flag race today with two spectacular triumphs over the Phillies before 33,707, the largest crowd of the year at Connie Mack Stadium.
In Matanzas Province fifty miles east of Havana is a village of workers who live like the country club set of any small United States town.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4 -- Shirley Jones is Twentieth Century-Fox' choice for the co-starring role of Julie Jordan in "Carousel." She will play opposite Frank Sinatra as Billy Bigelow.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 4 (AP) -- Arvilla Hanover, a Hambletonian eligible driven by co-owner Bill Haughton, today won the $15,503.02 Coaching Club Oaks trot as the Grand Circuit opened a five-day stand at Historic Track.

Guatemala has been celebrating the first anniversary of President Castillo Armas' term in office. It is a time for congratulations and good wishes -- and the President will need all the wishes and the help that he can get.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is true, as one reader has noted, that Benjamin Franklin, long after the event, regretted that he had failed to inoculate a 4-year-old son who died of smallpox in 1736. However, Franklin was not entirely at fault.
In the three months since the state Legislature adjourned last April 2, Governor Harriman has been a very busy Democrat.
LONDON, July 4 (Reuters) -- The sterling area's gold and dollar reserves fell by $6,000,000 during June, the Treasury announced today. At June 30 they stood at $2,680,000,000.

BONN, Germany, July 4 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer agreed today to have his controversial bill on military volunteers rewritten in exchange for an undertaking by the coalition leaders to railroad the new version through the Bundestag by July 16.
TOKYO, June 29 -- Fabulous caves constructed by the Japanese armed forces during World War II are serving as atomic bomb shelters for United States units based in Japan.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 4 (AP) -- A virtually unknown English professional, Frank Jowle, shot a 63, the lowest score ever made in the 95-year-old British Open golf championship, today. This overshadowed the feats of a strong American delegation in the qualifying round of the tournament.

PITY the poor New York customer in July. She wants to buy summer clothes in the summertime, and finds nothing but sadly wilted leftovers. As the mercury soars into the nineties, scratchy tweeds and satin evening gowns for fall go on show in store windows.
PARIS, July 4 (Reuters) -- Changing concepts and economic standards have increased the demand for women's ready-to-wear clothes in France.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., July 4 (UP) -- Senator William F. Knowland said today there could be no "real release of tensions" in Eastern Europe until Soviet satellites could pick their governments in free elections.

The Naumburg Orchestra gave its annual Independence Day concert last night on the Mall in Central Park. The program was the second of the four free summer concerts that are the annual donation of the brothers, Walter W. and George W. Naumburg.

Henry E. Abt, president of the Brand Names Foundation, Inc., has sold his home at 5 Vermont Avenue in the Prospect Park section of White Plains to Eugene J. Rosen, head of Columbia Technical Translations, a scientific publication. In the Mediterranean style of architecture, the house has nine rooms and three and one-half baths.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 4 (AP) -- Unbeaten Decathlon, the pride of New England, scored a front-running victory in the $21,900 Tyro Stakes before 26,600 racegoers at Monmouth Park today.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Free world exports to the Soviet Union reached a post-war peak last year, while exports to the entire Communist bloc rose 24 per cent over 1953.
WEST POINT, July 4 -- The first group of approximately 700 plebes will detrain at the United States Military Academy tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- The State Department said today that Soviet Russia had paid $7,692,766 to the United States shortly before last Friday. The payment represented interest and principal due on its wartime 'pipeline" lend-lease account.

Bobby Brocato slipped through on the inside to win the $61,100 Carter Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. With Ray Broussard doing the riding, the 4-year-old son of Natchez -- Dorothy Brown performed in flawless style to carry the colors of Joe W. Brown to a one-length victory in the seven-furlong test.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 4 (AP) -- Jacques Charland of the Three Rivers Ski Club of Quebec today won the eighth annual Fourth of July ski jump with leaps of 109 and 110 feet.
The Republican state chairman urged all Republicans in Congress from New York yesterday to support President Eisenhower's highway construction program in preference to a Democratic substitute.

The abiding affection and esteem in which the late Senator Robert A. Taft was held by his colleagues and by many millions of other Americans have prompted a movement to erect to his memory a bell tower 100 feet high on the grounds of the National Capitol in Washington.

CAIRO. On the bank of the Nile here, at a place where the traveler can watch the sun go down behind a row of palm trees and a minaret across the river, foundations are being dug. They are for the 400-room Nile-Hilton Hotel, planned as one of the most luxurious in the world.

The Salvation Army's demonstration of emergency feeding problems in the atom bomb defense drill on June 15 brought yesterday additional grants of $17,180. The funds will be used to continue and improve such disaster relief techniques.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The District of Columbia Bar Association has called "fantastic" a Hoover Commission suggestion that all Civil Aeronautics Board cases be decided within six months from the date of the final hearing.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 4 -- The most striking of many changes that economic difficulties have wrought in Pakistan is said to be the effort of rural women to have somewhat fewer children.

The General Foods Corporation is going after the dog business in a big way, Madison Avenue style. Through its Gaines division it is introducing in several states a package containing dog biscuits in six flavors -- liver, cheese, meat, vegetable, chicken and milk -- each with its own distinctive shape and color.

Brazil today is hungry for electric power. Her growing industries need it. But more than that, the ordinary Brazilian has learned how much electricity can do to make his life easier and more pleasant.

Lena Horne has been signed for a prefabricated TV "spectacular" musical to be produced by Walter Fried and Henry Newman. The producers are starting their novel venture into big-show packages with an adaptation of Offenbach's "La Belle Helene" by Howard Richardson and William Bernie.

The Jeffrey Garden Apartment property in Bayside, Queens, has passed to new ownership. The Kensington Terrace Apartments, Inc., of which Jerome Lorber is president, bought from the Purkan Jewel Corporation all of the stock of Jeffrey Garden Apartments, Inc., and Jeffrey Garden Apartment, Section II, Inc.

The Irgitand Company has sold the nine-story apartment house on plot 112 by 102 feet at 203 West Eighty-first Street. Max Klachkin was attorney for the buyer and Max J. Fink acted for the seller. The sale was negotiated by the Wood, Dolson Company as broker.

The memoirs of Harry S. Truman, a 500,000-word manuscript on which the former President had been working for more than two years, have been completed. They will be published serially by The New York Times, Life Magazine and The St. Louis Post-Dispatch beginning in the fall.

LAST night's concert at Lewisohn Stadium had a new sound effect. In addition to the customary drone of airplanes passing overhead, there was the sound of firecrackers outside as the neighborhood celebrated the Fourth of July.
DETROIT, July 4 -- Neither side is showing any great concern about integrating newly negotiated supplemental unemployment benefit plans with state unemployment compensation programs.
LONDON, July 4 -- Kafiristan tribesmen of the Northwest Frontier of India are still playing harps that closely resemble those made by the ancient Sumerians of Iraq at least 5,000 years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The Republican National Committee claimed today for the Eisenhower Administration a record for appointing women to high public office.

LOS ANGELES, July 4 (AP) -- An internal dispute broke into the open today among members of the A. F. L. International Association of Machinists who have been on strike against the Flying Tiger Air Line since June 14.

BALTIMORE, July 4 (UP) -- Little Willie Miranda doubled home two mates in a four-run eighth inning to break a 2-2 tie as Baltimore defeated Washington today, 6 to 2, to snap the Orioles' twelve - game losing streak.

VANCOUVER, July 4 (Canadian Press) -- The Queen Charlotte Islands and a number of small northern British Columbia ports were without regular shipping service today as the Seafarers International Union (A. F. L.-T. L. C.) struck Union Steamships, Ltd.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 4 (UP) -- The Kansas City Athletics split a double-header with the White Sox today. They won the second game, 4 -- 3, on a play that touched off a dispute. Chicago, took the opener, 8 -- 3.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP) -- Thousands turned out today in 90-degree heat to celebrate the 179th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence in this birthplace of American liberty.

The election of Albert B. Richardson as vice president in charge of advertising of Chesebrough-Pond's, Inc., was announced yesterday. This concern was formed recently by merger of Chesebrough Manufacturing Company, maker of the Vaseline brand of products, and Pond's Extract Company, cosmetic manufacturer.
Fort Dix in New Jersey, home of the Sixty-ninth Infantry Division, is training almost 44,000 men annually in the basic, and applied, school of the soldier.
MOSCOW, July 5 -- Samuel Reshevsky of the United States was the uncrowned king of the chess world tonight.
A 49-year-old Pittsburgh railroad executive was sworn in yesterday as chairman of the New York City Transit Authority.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Senate Democrats failed to enter the ring today for a showdown fight on the Dixon-Yates power contract.

LONDON, July 5 (AP) -- The International Sugar Council reduced today the export quotas of member countries by a flat 5 per cent. A council communique said the executive committee, meeting in special session, had decided to cut the total world export quota from 4,133,500 to 3,925,750 metric tons.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Wheat, corn and rye futures developed considerable strength today, but not before a recession early in the day, when there was some hedge pressure on wheat. Commission demand broadened on the declines, with more aggressive buying by local bull leaders in wheat and corn.
An investigation of nearly two months has disclosed no evidence of criminal negligence in the collapse of a section of the main floor of the New York Coliseum last May 9.
The Association of Catholic Trade Unionists is planning to celebrate on a nation-wide scale next year the silver jubilee of the Papal encyclical, "Quadragesimo Anno."
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange climbed to new highs yesterday, with General Motors and du Pont in the vanguard.
MOSCOW, July 5 (AP) -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda said today San Francisco was a wonderful town.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4 -- The quick changes in the Hollywood scene occasioned by the rapid growth of the Television industry are leading the National Legion of Decency and the Motion Picture Association of America into a paradoxical position on censorship.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., July 5 -- The police said today that a $100,000 jewel theft had been reported by a New York couple who stayed at the BerkeleyCarteret Hotel over the holiday week-end.

Brooklyn as a borough of industries, of public improvements and of all-around civic health had, a good year last year, and Borough President John Cashmore has told Mayor Wagner about it in his annual report as the Brooklyn borough head. During 1954 sixty-four factory or loft buildings were put up in Brooklyn, an average rate of better than one a week.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) --The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., one of the nation's biggest labor unions, moved its headquarters today into a new white marble building adjacent to the Capitol grounds.

ROME, July 5 -- A new force is now evident in the complicated Italian political picture. This is the personality of Giovanni Gronchi, second President of the young republic. For Signor Gronchi clearly intends to use his constitutional powers more fully than did his predecessor, the retiring economist Luigi Einaudi, and to assert a positive influence in the evolution of Italy's policy.

The City Planning Commission has come through promptly and unanimously with a verdict in favor of making park land out of two plots being surrendered by the Hospitals Department. One of these would extend Jacob Riis Park in Queens, adding needed beach.

Dr. Benjamin Fine's story in your issue of June 28, reporting Charles Silver's visit to Public School No. 611 at Youth House, omitted to mention its program. Despite the handicap of the physical structure, the teachers and staff at Youth House have performed their duties admirably.
CLEVELAND, July 5 (UP) -- Mayor Anthony J. Celebrezze today ordered taller American flag staffs in downtown Public Square so Old Glory would fly above flags of the United Nations.

ST. LOUIS, July 5 (AP) -- Realignment of the board of directors of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas (Katy) Railroad Company to give representation to a new stockholder group is expected at a special meeting of the board here July 14.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Government's chief "trust-buster" said today that the Justice Department was investigating the recent merger of New York's Chase and Manhattan Banks to determine whether an anti-trust suit should be filed against them.

The present state of the weather being what it is -- and Washington is in even worse condition than New York -- no one could blame Congress for wanting to close up shop by the end of the month. But while temperature in the nineties may give some excuse for deferring less urgent matters, there are a few major items that need to be passed, and now.

The opening of this year's session of the Council of Europe in Strasbourg has been marked by the initiation of a unique experiment in supranational jurisdiction. The experiment was launched when Germany and Belgium followed the example of Denmark, Ireland, Iceland and Sweden in accepting all provisions of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, signed in Rome in 1950.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Support of proposals to award medals to civilians who have earned distinction in social betterment, science, letters and sports was apparent in Congress today.
ALBANY, July 5 -- State Health Department experts reported today that the death rate from lung cancer had shown an "alarming increase" in men in the upstate area in the last twenty years.

May I suggest that your column headed "A Surprise for Johnny" in the Topics of The Times of June 30 rendered your readers no useful service. There may be need for more attention to phonetics in the teaching of reading in our schools.
They are hardly new, but the protests have been mounting recently. The protesters? The nations' railroads. The target? Taxes levied on the carriers by states, cities and other municipalities.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- A Navy selection board will be encouraged to favor brilliant young line officers and specialists for promotion from captain to rear admiral.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 5 (AP) -- Dr. Gilbert F. White has resigned as president of Haverford College and will become Professor of Geography at the University of Chicago. The resignation will be effective the first of next year.

TRENTON, July 5 -- Attorney General Grover C. Richman instituted legal proceedings today to remove from office four members of the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council and the State Rent Control Director.

Perhaps lately you have been hearing less noise created by aircraft. The fact is, a campaign started three years ago by the aircraft industry to reduce the airplane's din in populated areas has met with considerable success.

PARIS, July 5 -- Neither semi-official nor private commentators saw anything of great significance in the remarks by Mr. Khrushchev. It was considered one more sign that Moscow had decided it would get further by relaxing tension than by maintaining it.

THE fans did inordinately well this season in voting on candidates for the All-Star teams. Their choices for the starting line-ups are reasonably sound. The same cannot be said of the managers -- or of one manager, anyway. The culprit is Leo Durocher, the skipper of the National Leaguers. Leo the Lip could never be elected mayor of Philadelphia or even as a keeper in the dog pound.

Four floors in the twenty-seven-story building going up at 20 Broad Street, next to the New York Stock Exchange, have been leased by White Weld Co., brokers and dealers in investment securities and one of the country's biggest underwriters of stock issues.
New Yorkers sweltered in temperatures above 90 degrees yesterday for the third successive day. At 12:35 P. M. the mercury reached the day's official Weather Bureau high of 95.
ALBANY, July 5 -- The State Education Commisioner said today that boards of education did not have the power to force teachers to testify about Communistparty membership...

CINCINNATI, July 5 (AP) -- Manager Birdie Tebbetts of the Cincinnati Redlegs and Harry (The Hat) Walker of the St. Louis Cardinals battled with their fists tonight in the ninth inning as the Redlegs rallied with four hits and two runs to beat the Cards 5 -- 4.
MOSCOW, July 5 -- The United States' Independence Day was front-page news in Moscow this morning.

Eleven wholesalers of decorative fabrics believe it is not only the single gentleman, needing curtains or draperies, who should hire an interior decorator to tell him which he should get. They hold that the complete family needs a decorator fully as much.

Subject to confirmation today at a meeting of Tyrone Power's advisers in the office of the Music Corporation of America, it seems virtually certain that the Playwrights Company will sponsor the star's next stage appearance in "A Quiet Place."
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Treasury moved today to borrow $2,750,000,000 without exerting significant pressure on the tight supply of commercial bank credit.

A plot adjoining its one-story plant on Peterson Lane in Secaucus, N. J., has been purchased by the Union Textile Printers, Inc., for future expansion. The site, about one and three-fourths acres, was acquired from the B. E. Holding Corporation in a transaction negotiated by the Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization as broker.
The National Broadcasting Company yesterday unveiled more than seventy-five big guns with which it will try to dominate the television airwaves next season.

WALLA WALLA, Wash., July 5 (AP) -- Several score tough prisoners seized nine hostages and control of half the sprawling state prison today. They then set a twenty-four-hour deadline for improvement of treatment by custodial personnel.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 3 -- A forecast of what may be appearing in supermarkets and equipment stores was given at the recent American Home Economics Association conference here. Some of the items listed are at the point of being introduced now, others are in the process of development.

CHINESE AIR FORCE BASE, Formosa, June 20 -- An F-86 Sabre Jet rolled down the runway here this morning, gathered speed and took off a bit hesitantly. The pilot steadied it in the air but the ascent was somewhat wobbbly as the sleek fighter roared into the sun.
SYRACUSE, July 5 -- County and local law enforcement officials were told here today that too many communities were relying on "transparent dodges" in coping with juvenile delinquency.

The General Motors Corporation plans to split its stock 3 for 1. The world's largest industrial enterprise, with assets of more than $5,000,000,000, has called a special meeting in Wilmington, Del., for Sept. 23 to act on the proposal.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- The House approved without dissent today a bill providing stiffer penalties for seditious conspiracy and advocacy of violent overthrow of the Government.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- President Eisenhower called on his Republican Congressional lieutenants today for fresh exertions on his program. The controlling Democrats, meanwhile, prepared to end this session in twenty-five strenuous days.
SAN PEDRO, Calif., July 5 (UP) -- The fleet of sailing craft engaged in the race to Honolulu was reduced to fifty-one boats today.
TOKYO, July 5 -- Japan's House of Representatives began debate today on a bill that would pave the way for large-scale revision of the nation's Constitution.

PARIS, July 5 -- A conference to coordinate man's greatest international effort to discover the secrets of the Antarctic is to begin here tomorrow. About a dozen powers, including the Soviet Union, are due to attend.

When Charles H. Sampson acknowledges that he is "no more of an economist than a retired college professor has to be in order to live," he gives away no secret. In his letter printed in the June 26 issue Mr. Sampson apparently takes the position that a guaranteed annual wage is fine for a college professor but a crime for factory workers.

HERZLIYA, Israel, July 5 -- Defense Minister David Ben-Gurion described the "growing friendship" between Israel and the United States tonight as a "guarantee" for fulfillment of what he called Israel's historic role in this region.

COMMONPLACE though they may be, sandwiches are still the most practical fare for picnic baskets and box lunches. And they can be delicious. The trick is to keep them at the peak of freshness from the time they are made until served.

IF GIUSEPPE VIRZI and his professional friends are not misguided, Giuseppe has made the first important contribution to violin construction in 200 years. He is quietly certain of his achievement. His friends are enthusiastically voluble.

We would have fewer governmental departments and agencies, perhaps, if each were required by law to justify each year its continued existence. The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, required by the bi-state compact between New York and New Jersey to do just that, makes a clear-cut case for itself with the internal evidence in the report for its second fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today reported that the "agreed system plan" for reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company had been favored by an overwhelming majority of creditors and security holders.
PHILADELPHIA, July 5 -- The Dodgers set out on the second half of their National League pennant chase tonight only to trip over Robin Roberts and the Phillies.

One of the most important and far-reaching domestic issues ever to arise in the United States is now before Congress -- the question of whether we are to have adequate highway legislation to meet the needs of our forty-eight states. The keystone of these needs, by general. agreement, is the construction of a 40,000-mile interstate highway system.

The wave of new financing by local governments is having a direct impact on the market in tax-exempt bonds. Yesterday saw dissolution of a syndicate formed to market big recent issues of revenue bonds to finance turnpikes in Florida and Texas.

I have recently returned from Europe. While there, driving one day through a residential part of Paris, my brother-in-law asked our guide: "If I should come over here to spend six months or so, how much would I have to pay for a five-room apartment in one of these buildings ?"

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, July 5 -- The Navy has ordered three barges in the Puerto Rico area to carry water to St. Thomas. It was acting on an appeal for help from this Caribbean territory that has been suffering an acute drought.

Competent authorities claim there are some 500,000 different species of insects. These authorities must be competent, since they are encyclopedists, although an average gardener would have set the figure perhaps 250,000 higher.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- A Senate subcommittee, and apparently a lot of stranded bus and trolley riders, were looking today for Louis E. Wolfson.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- The House of Representatives voted unanimously today to pay a reward of up to $500,000 to anyone who uncovers an effort to smuggle atomic bombs or nuclear material into the United States.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- The House of Representatives voted today to vest in the Federal Government ownership of all the official papers of the nation's Presidents. The documents are now scattered and no one knows where a lot of them are.
It never stops raining these days for the clerical workers in University Hall Annex on the Columbia University campus.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 5 -- Miss Isabel Troccole of New York began her quest of the women's New York State tennis championship today with a 6-0, 6-0 victory over Jeanne FitzGerald of New Rochelle at the Pelham Country Club.
NARRAGANSETT, R. I., July 5 -- The holiday surfcasters found the striped bass cooperative along the Rhode Island beaches. A number of big stripers were harvested before the migration moved on.

ROME, July 5 -- Antonio Segni, a left-of-center Christian Democrat, announced tonight that he had formed a left-of-center coalition government. It will replace the government of Premier Mario Scelba, which resigned June 22.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The entire Senate stood today in silent prayer for the Senate Democratic leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, who is gravely ill of a heart condition.
Fort Dix, N. J., home of the Sixty-ninth Infantry Division, and center of basic Army training in the northeast, is now processing an almost equal number of volunteers and draftees.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 5 -- Two high-ranking officers of the National Revolutionary Council accused most of the members of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem's government today of being "traitors" and "enemies."
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 5 (UP) -- The will of Silliman Evans, publisher of The Nashville Tennessean who died recently, was filed today for probate in Davidson County.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 5 -- Copa Productions, the Tyrone Power-Ted Richmond producing company, is preparing a film version of the novel "Nightfall," written by David Goodis and published in 1949.
BIRMINGHAM, England, July 5 (AP) -- Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., and Jaroslav Drobny of Egypt led the favorites today into the second round of the Midland Counties lawn tennis tournament.
The International Longshoremen's Association is planning to set up a coast-wide bargaining system in future contract dealings with employers.
Cotton futures here closed 5 points up to 9 off yesterday with only the old July advancing Trading continued slow on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Walter F. O'Malley, president of the Brooklyn Dodgers Baseball Club, was charged with slander yesterday in an affidavit filed in Supreme Court.
Lloyd's Register of Shipping, the "bible" of the world maritime industry, will appear in a new and more attractive format.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 5 -- Community leadership today was termed the key to desegregating public schools.
TRENTON, July 5 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner announced today his nomination of New Jersey's five representatives on the bi-state Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission.
To the winds that blew hot across Battery Park yesterday were added "cool" blasts from the big horns of the Cities Service Band of America.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 5 -- Three more seeded players were eliminated from the New York State tennis championships today at the County Tennis Club of Westchester. Several other favorites were extended.
STRASBOURG, France, July 5 (AP) -- Greece and Turkey agreed officially today to join Britain in a discussion on the future of Cyprus, British crown colony isle in the Eastern Mediterranean.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- A settlement between officials of the Chicago Transit Authority and two major operating unions was reached tonight in the face of a threatened strike. The authority, a public agency, owns and operates the surface and elevated lines and the motor buses.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Lewis Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today that the United States' contribution to the United Nations meeting in Geneva on the peaceful uses of atomic discoveries would be "outstanding."

The conciliatory broadcast by President Peron yesterday may mark an end to the period of tension and uncertainty in Argentina since the revolt of June 16. Then, again, it may not. There are a lot of loose ends to be picked up and some puzzling features to the picture we get from Buenos Aires today.
FORT SUMNER, N. M., July 5 (AP) -- Five crewmen were killed in a flaming collision of two freight trains thirty-six miles west of here early today.
Dry cargo ship deck officers of the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., are expected to sign a three-year labor contract with East Coast and Gulf ship owners today.

PITTSBURGH, July 5 (AP) -- The United States Steel Corporation posted new list prices on its products today, to become effective at 12:01 A. M. tomorrow. The average price increase is approximately $7.35 a ton.
CHICAGO, July 5 -- The United States is endangering its economy through a reckless waste of gifted students, the nation's school teachers were told today.

Leo Durocher and Al Lopez, as managers of the rival All-Star teams, yesterday exercised their prerogatives and selected the pitchers and other players needed to round out the two twenty-five-man squads. With one exception neither pilot is likely to be criticized for his personal choices for the twenty-second annual classic to be played at Milwaukee's County Stadium on Tuesday.

DETROIT, July 5 -- Emil Mazey, secretary-treasurer of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., testified here today before a Federal grand jury reported to be investigating possible violation of the Federal Corrupt Practices Act.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Government and railroad representatives will meet in Chicago July 22 to discuss dates and places for further hearings into the General Services Administration's complaint against rail rates on freight for Alaska.

First National City Bank of New York, the nation's third largest, reported yesterday net current operating earnings for the first six months this year amounted to $20,109,027, or $2.01 a share, up from $16,560,515, or $1.66 a share, in the like months of last year on the basis of 10,000,000 shares now outstanding.
LONDON, July 5--Prime Minister Eden told the House of Commons today that about 2,000,000 working days had been lost by the men who participated in the recent railway, dock and coal-mining strikes.
LONDON, July 5 -- A report to the International Students Conference at Birmingham criticized the Union of South Africa today for refusing visas to a students' investigating committee.

How the United States overcame its reluctance to world leadership and how it filled the gap to Soviet expansion is the subject of "The Fifteen Weeks," by Joseph M. Jones. The author was a member of the State Department staff in 1947, when the change took place.

The highway madness that takes over the wheel on our three-day holiday week-ends took a ghastly, extraordinary toll on the Glorious Fourth. Between 6 P. M. Friday and midnight Monday more than 400 people were killed in traffic accidents.
Borough President James A. Lundry of Queens lashed back yesterday at a special grand jury that accused him of concocting a false story of collapsing sewers during his election campaign in 1953.

ROME, July 5 -- One day five[ years ago, Prof. Antonio Segni,I now Premier of Italy's seven-I teenth Government since the] fall of Fascism, gave his wife aI bottle of perfume. This ws his I way of making amends for hav-I ing expropriated 250 acres of their own olive groves and vineyards in northern Sardinia.

Nikita S. Khrushchev may deride Western speculation about Soviet weakness, but it is from his own speeches in the last two years that much of the West's evidence of Soviet economic difficulties has come.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Wholesalers in May sold about 2 per cent more than in April, and 13 per cent more than in May last year, the Bureau of the Census said today.

A new delight for pavement-bound city youngsters was activated yesterday by Deputy Police Commissioner James B. Nolan, president of the Police Athletic League. It was just a fire hydrant in a new play street, but when Mr. Nolan turned it on at 10:30 A. M. -- the temperature was then nearing 90 degrees -- 200 boys and girls rushed joyfully into its shower of cool, clear water.
CROTON FALLS, N. Y., July 5 -- A father and his son died early today when their car was hit by a stolen sedan. Two teenage boys were fleeing in the stolen car from pursuing state troopers.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 5 -- Mayor Nicholas S. LaCorte announced today that Nat Gershen and Gerard E. Duffy, members of the Board of Police Commissioners, would be continued in office. They were indicted last week on conspiracy and other charges resulting from a gambling inquiry.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- It appeared today that East-West trade would be a prime topic for discussion at the Big Four meeting in Geneva.
BUENOS AIRES, July 5 -- President Juan D. Peron offered an "open hand" to his political opponents today. His opponents declined to grasp it.

G. T. Baker, president of National Airlines, announced yesterday a $95,000,000 expansion program. A large part of the money will be spent for airliners of new types, and it appears certain they will be turbine-powered planes of United States manufacture.

WEST POINT, N. Y., July 5 -- Seven hundred young men representing every state in the nation, the Territory of Hawaii and three foreign countries were sworn in here today as members of the United States Corps of Cadets. They became members of the academy's Class of 1959.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 5 (UP) -- Frank Jowle, an unheralded English week-end golfer, won the medal in the British Open Golf Championship today with 135. Lieut. Joe Conrad, an amateur, led five United States survivors with a 139.

GARDEN CITY PARK, L. I., July 5 -- It is bad enough to be buried by tons of cascading sand when the temperature is in the humid nineties. But it is even worse when a doctor comes along and will not let a man have a cigar while he is being dug out of the sweltering trap.

BERLIN, July 5 (AP) -- The traditional audience vote announced at the end of the ten-day International Film Festival in West Berlin tonight gave three prizes to the United States, three to West Germany and one each to Italy, France and Spain.
The United States weightlifting team, which competed twice in Russia last month, returned yesterday with Clarence H. Johnson, its manager.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 5 -- President Carlos Ibanez del Campo was reported preparing tonight to ask Congress for emergency powers to deal with labor troubles and keep order.
The following have been elected to three-year terms as new members on the board of trustees of the Committee for Economic Development:

A special garden for the blind, featuring braille-written posters saying "Please Do Pick the Flowers," will be constructed in Central Park near East Seventieth Street and Fifth Avenue, the Department of Parks announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- United States officials are frankly skeptical of Nikita S. Khrushchev's denial yesterday that the Soviet Union will be negotiating from weakness in Geneva.
PITTSBURGH, July 5 -- The Giants and Willie Mays were back on the beam tonight as they plastered the Pirates, 11 -- 1, before 7,245 fans at Forbes Field.

Two West Side properties have figured in quick resales. They are the nine-story and penthouse building containing thirty-seven apartments at 158 West Eighty-first Street and the six-story apartment house for forty-four families at 1825. Riverside Drive, corner of Seaman Avenue.
Governor Harriman is scheduled to announce today the appointment of a Negro to the State Supreme Court for the first time in New York's history.

Illusionist of the Greentree Stable served a good purpose in capturing the Elmhurst Handicap, the classified test that occupied the main spot on the program at Aqueduct yesterday. The 3-year-old son of Devil Diver provided the means for returning Teddy Atkinson to the winner's circle.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 5 -- The United Nations Command accused the Communists today of continued violation of Korean armistice agreement.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- A Presidential order freeing enough copper from the Government stockpile to meet defense production needs will be asked if the current strike in the copper mining and smelting industry continues beyond a week.

MADRID, July 5 -- The Spanish Government has accepted a verdict issued by the Madrid Court of Appeals granting Spaniards who are baptized Roman Catholics the right to contract civil marriage with non-Catholics.
STRASBOURG, France, July 5 (UP) -- Guy Mollet, French Socialist leader was unanimously re-elected president of the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe today.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Soviet Union and Rumania are invading the free-world market in petroleum products, United States officials said today.

Events tonight: Stadium Symphony Orchestra, Andre Kostelanetz conducting; Vera Franceschi, pianist, Lewisohn Stadium, 8:30; Goldman Band, Central Park, 8:30, and "Norma," Public School 6, 45 East Eighty-first Street, 7:45.
The National Association of Manufacturers pressed vigorously yesterday for removal of tax blocks to release incentives and funds for the country's economic growth.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today support rates for the 1955 wheat crop would average $2.08 a bushel.
Rubber prices soared yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Futures here followed sharply higher prices in London and Singapore.
Prime Minister Nu of Burma was saluted yesterday by the city as a founding father of his young nation and stanch defender of democracy in Asia.
The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, one of the nation's largest department store groups, will soon add to its holdings the J. W. Robinson Company of Los Angeles, a major West Coast store.
BUENOS AIRES, July 5 (UP) -- The following is the text of President Juan D. Peron's radio speech to the nation today:

HONG KONG, Wednesday, July 6 -- Communist China's revised Five-Year Plan was projected by its chief architect today in terms of a reduced grain target, somewhat slower agricultural collectivization and continued stress on heavy industry.

HOW to make a single small room function well twenty-four hours a day is a problem that faces many New Yorkers. That this can be achieved -- and attractively -- is demonstrated by a series of furnished one-room apartments just completed at 415 East Sixty-fourth Street.

ALBANY, July 5 -- The State Health Department said today that fifteen new cases of poliomyelitis has been reported in the state outside New York City in the week ending July 2, as compared with five in the week before.

THE all-Tchaikovsky program by the Stadium Symphony Orchestra that Andre Kostelanetz conducted at Lewisohn Stadium last night began with relativly unfamiliar Tchaikovsky, the orchestral suite from "Pique-Dame."
The Symphony of the Air is assured of enough engagements to keep it in existence for another full season.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Secretary of State Dulles conferred today with the French Ambassador, Maurice Couve de Murville, and the British Ambassador, Sir Roger Makins, on Western policy at the Geneva conference opening July 18.
Washington Water Power Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for five and twelve months ended May 31.
Assistant Fire Marshal Irving Rothenberg will face departmental charges on six counts involving alleged sale by him of fire insurance to a Queens furniture company.
BROOKLINE, Mass., July 5 (UP) -- The brother of Harry Dexter White said today it was "nothing short of ridiculous" to accuse the late Treasury official of operating a world-wide spy ring.
Domestic steel operations dropped last week to the lowest level of the year to date as a result of the strike that closed many steel-making plants for several hours on Friday.

LONDON, July 5---Dr. DonaldI Soper, leading British Methodist;[ said today that a fifteen-dayl visit to the Soviet Union had[ convinced him Christians thereI were living in "relaxed condi-[ tions" since the death of Stalin.
MOSCOW, July 6 -- United States chess players ended their Moscow match in a crushing defeat tonight.

Zev Style Handbags Inc, 562 W 31st St; Somerset Craftsmen Ltd, furniture manufacturing and showroom, in 155 E 23d St; Pocket Brassiere, Kerr Chodes and 74th Street Broadway Food Market Inc, in 2121 Broadway -- Walter Scott Co, brokers.

MILWAUKEE will be host to the All-Star game for the first time on Tuesday and the good burghers out there are excited by the prospect. As part of a week-long festival they intend to put on public display thirteen living members of Wisconsin's Athletic Hall of Fame. Among them is Pat O'Dea.
LONDON, July 6 -- The Church of England extended a cautious hand today toward the Methodist Church, looking toward an eventual union.
A militant convention of East Coast longshoremen yesterday condemned the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor as "a modified form of fascism -- state control of labor."
The new Transit Authority will seek a long-term peace past with Michael J. Quill, whose strike threats have kept the subway system in turmoil for years.

Bell Telephone Laboratories announced yesterday the development of a tiny electronic device of large potential value to industry and consumers. The product: a silicon power rectifier, about the size of a pea, which will convert alternating into direct current.
Two Columbia Broadcasting System camera men left Czechoslovakia yesterday after shooting the first films made there by American newsmen in ten years.
LONDON, July 6 (AP) -- Government made public today a bill to end its monopoly over the importation of sugar and to restore the pre-war competitive market.

Futures on the New York commodity exchanges rose irregularly yesterday on light volume. Coffee, cocoa, potatoes, hides, lead and copper were stronger. Rubber, soybean oil and zinc eased. Sugar, burlap, wool and cottonseed oil ended mixed.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Administration opened its case for its customs simplification bill today. At once, however, it ran into searching questions from key members of the Senate Finance Committee.

PARIS, July 6 -- The United States Navy is planning to fly six or eight planes non-stop from New Zealand to McMurdo Sound in Antarctica in December. It will be the first flight in history to link that continent with other land areas.

The General Motors Corporation, now the world's largest industrial enterprise, has long been identified in the public mind as an outstanding exponent of equity capitalization. It has financed its growth almost entirely through common stock; it has a well-deserved reputation for sharing its prosperity with its stockholders; and it has successfully employed stock ownership as an incentive to its management executives.
BROOKLINE, Mass., July 6 (AP) -- A Jewish couple, ordered under threat of arrest to give up a 4-year-old foster daughter whose mother is a Roman Catholic, gained a two-week delay today.
The superliner United States -- fastest merchant vessel in the world -- has just passed her third birthday. Her owners yesterday issued a "well done" report.
The cotton futures market closed steady yesterday, 5 points lower to 13 points higher than on Tuesday, with moderate trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.

JERSEY CITY, July 6 -- An eighteen - month - old indictment was reinstated today charging Jersey City's Director of Revenue and Finance and three nurserymen with conspiring to defraud the city and to violate the public bidding laws.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- In an effort to spur foreign sales of surplus farm products, the Senate Agriculture Committee voted today to drop a longtime requirement that half of all such exports must be transported in United States ships.
PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (AP) -- Andrew Taylor, 11-year-old tourist from England, made his concert debut as a conductor today with the Robin Hood Dell Orchestra.

WARSAW, July 6 -- Elaborate celebrations took place here today to mark the fifth anniversary of the agreement by which the East German and Polish Governments recognized the Oder-Neisse line as their common frontier.
ALBANY, July 6 (AP) -- Governor Harriman will leave by airliner from New York tomorrow on a four-week vacation trip that will take him to England, Israel, Italy, France and Ireland.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 6 -- State Senator Edward P. Larkin of Floral Park has scheduled a meeting of his joint legislative committee investigating communism in summer camps for next Friday. He was criticized recently by Governor Harriman.
ALBANY, July 6 -- The State Rent Administrator said today he saw "little hope" of removing rent controls throughout the state when the present law expires in 1957.
BOSTON, July 6 -- The strict motion picture censorship law in Massachusetts was declared unconstitutional today by the State Supreme Judicial Court. The statute is part of a Sunday law 300 years old.

OTTAWA, July 6 (AP) -- A deal for the sale of $19,000,000 worth of Canadian wheat to Poland, partly financed by a Government-guaranteed bank loan, has plunged Canada's Parliament into bitter controversy.

Michael H. Prendergast of Haverstraw was unanimously elected Democratic State Chairman yesterday. He replaces Richard H. Balch of Utica, who became a member of the Public Service Commission last week.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Rev. Aniceto M. Sparagna, a former Roman Catholic priest from Italy now preaching at the West Collingswood, N. J., (Protestant) Church of Christ, received permanent residence status in the United States today without President Eisenhower's approval.

So much has been said against horn blowing that I hope some utterance in mitigation will be tolerated. I concede there is much reckless, unnecessary use of horns in New York City that should be stopped. So also must one avoid going to extremes, typical of American life, legislating unenforceable self-denying ordinances.

Changes in the subway signal system at Coney Island have made impossible a recurrence of the head-on collision that injured forty-two persons June 19, Edward T. McNally, general superintendent of the Transit Authority, said yesterday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 6 (AP) -- South Vietnam's Foreign Minister Vu Van Mau said today his Government accepted the principle of an election next year to unify Vietnam, but only through a free ballot, supervised by the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Eisenhower made it clear today that he would be glad to have Congress adjourn as planned on July 30.

The new Transit Authority is now completed at last, the search for a chairman having ended with the choice of a Pittsburgh man of long railroad experience, Charles L. Patterson. Working with him as members appointed by Governor Harriman and Mayor Wagner are E. Vincent Curtayne, formerly of the Manufacturers Trust Company, and Joseph E. O'Grady, who had been the city's Labor Commissioner.
