TOKYO, July 6 -- John M. Allison, United States Ambassador, called on Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japanese Foreign Minister, this afternoon in behalf of Robert F. Buda, American trader who is under a six-year sentence here on a charge of attempted murder.
LONDON, July 6 -- Britain will hold an all-party conference to consider admitting members from Malta to the Mother of Parliaments, Prime Minister Eden announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities, as announced today by the Federal Reserve Board, shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 29:
SHEBOYGAN, Wis., July 6 -- Mayor Rudolph J. Ploetz listed today Kohler Company terms for settlement of the fifteen-month-old strike at the company's plant in near-by Kohler Village.
LONDON, July 6 -- Selwyn Lloyd, Minister of Defense, cautioned today that great efforts would be required from Britain if she was to keep pace with armaments developments in Communist countries.
CINCINNATI, July 6 (AP) -- Three more seeded players were knocked out of the running today in the combined Tri-State and Western tennis tournament.

General Motors stock rose $1,335,358,437 in value yesterday as investors rushed to buy on news of the proposed 3-for-1 stock split. The shares closed at $127.75, up $14.37 1/2 from Tuesday's final figure.
A Bronx area of 344 square blocks will be added to alternate-side parking program tomorrow to facilitate the cleaning of streets.
The new executive team at J. Walter Thompson Company, the world's largest advertising agency, believes that advertising is gaining in importance and as an essential of living.

JAMESTOWN, N. Y., July 6 (AP) -- Tommy Goodwin of Rye, four-time champion of the state's amateur golfers, defeated Ward Wettlaufer of Buffalo in the first round of the New York state amateur championship today.
Congress and the Maritime Administration have created an atmosphere of confidence for the American Merchant Marine, a West Coast shipping executive said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (UP) -- A casual acquaintance was identified today as the heir to virtually all the estate of Mrs. Lulubel Hagar Rossman, slain widow of an accounting concern executive. The value of the estate is estimated at $500,000.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The State Department, after eight years of refusal, has decided to issue a passport to Dr. Martin D. Kamen, the atomic-bomb scientist the department had once linked to communism.

TOKYO, July 6 -- The belief that the recent visit to South Korea of the United States Ambassador to Japan may have helped ease tensions between Seoul and Tokyo was expressed today by two Japanese Government spokesmen.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- A large-scale program of Federal aid to public education was proposed this evening by Adlai E. Stevenson. Under the formula outlined by the 1952 Democratic Presidential candidate, the schools would receive $800,000,000 a year from the Federal Government.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- A Government advisory committee recommended today a broad expansion of the Federal Food and Drug Administration.

JUST about a half-hour before the start of last night's concert at Lewisohn Stadium it started to rain. It was a weak shower, but it had enough strength to wash away most of the audience. Only a few hardy music-lovers showed up, and a good number of those appeared with cameras, meters and other mysterious paraphernalia slung around them.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Eisenhower said today that the Washington bus and trolley strike was interfering with public business.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 6 (UP) -- Roger W. Babson, business analyst, observed his eightieth birthday today and wished he were "8 years old instead."
MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 6 -- Mayor Frank T. Tobey announced tonight that within the next thirty days Memphis would make a "definit commitment" on a $5,000,000 survey for a new power plant.
LISBON, Portugal, July 6 (AP) -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar shuffled his Cabinet and appointed five new Ministers today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 6 -- Prime Minister Nu of Burma expressed the belief today that United States policymakers were not opposed to the admission of Communist China to the United Nations. The issue is rather one of "timing," he said.
Harold A. Stevens became yesterday the first Negro in New York's history to hold the position of justice of the State Supreme Court.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 6 -- A Los Angeles art critic testified today that five paintings offered for sale by Roy J. Goldenberg as works of modern French masters were not authentic. Mr. Goldenberg, an auctioneer and buyer and seller of the effects of movie stars, went on trial on five charges of misdemeanor fraud and five counts of misleading advertising before a jury in Beverly Hills Municipal Court.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Eisenhower began defining today the principles that would guide United States policy on disarmament in the forthcoming conversations with Soviet leaders.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Jersey Joe Walcott, former world heavyweight boxing champion, gave Senators today a preventive for juvenile delinquency.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives approved tonight a Democratic bill for new Social Security benefits and broader coverage. The bill also provided for higher Social Security taxes.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Army disclosed today that more than 100 "former German" scientists and specialists were developing guided missiles at the Redstone Arsenal in Huntsville, Ala.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Spokesmen for Federal bank regulating agencies today generally endorsed a bill to prevent bank mergers that might tend to lessen competition and create monopoly. But they disagreed over plans to place the policing power in the hands of the Attorney General.

BALTIMORE, July 6 -- Thirty-three-year-old Jim Wilson, named to the American League All-Star team yesterday -- he's the only Oriole on the squad -- made Al Lopez look good tonight. The right-hander blanked the league-leading Yankees, 4 -- 0, holding them to four singles and permitting none to reach second base.

BUENOS AIRES, July 6 (UP) -- Interior Minister Oscar Albrieu said today Opposition parties would have access to the radio and the press provided they "place themselves within the bounds of pacification and harmony."

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (AP) -- John A. Stephens, vice president of United States Steel Corporation, said tonight America's economy had developed to the point where "we can afford both books and bathtubs and libraries and license plates."
PARIS, July 6 -- A three-day debate on the conventions providing Tunisian home rule began in the French National Assembly today.

STRASBOURG, France, July 6 -- Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, and Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, outlined today a formula for European coexistence that would bring the Communist states and a reunified Germany into a revamped Council of Europe.

EVELYN WAUGH, who served with Britain's Commandos and the Royal Marines in World War II, is about the only first-class military satirist now writing about those singularly restless years. Others have started out promisingly and then got themselves hopelessly mired in the tedious pleasures of righteous indignation. Or lapsed into far too predictable slapstick.
BOSTON, July 6 (AP) -- Ted Williams slammed a two-run homer, a double and a single to pace the Boston Red Sox to a 7-5 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.
THINGS may change when fall rolls 'round, but as of today probably the most stable thing in fashion is the length of the hemline.
Harry Hopman flew in from England yesterday, brimming with confidence that Australia would win back the Davis Cup and that Lewis Hoad would stand as the best tennis player in the world.

INDIA and the sari dress burst upon the fashion world fairly recently. To the Whiting India Guilds, Inc., a pleasantly do-good sort of organization, the exotic subcontinent is old stuff. Through church and club bazaars, the Guilds has been selling Indian bangles, earrings, hand-carved ivory necklaces, dolls, brass candlesticks, sandalwood elephants and any number of similar articles to avid buyers for some time now.

There are many ways to take a vacation and a fabulous number of places to which one can go. One learns in time, after some unhappy if not disastrous experiments in holiday living, what sort of vacation is best for one and for the most part one strays not too far from whatever has been found to be most pleasant -- beach, lake or mountain; luxury hotel, lodge or tent.

It has been rather warm hereabouts for several days, fine growing weather, they used to say. But there has been the normal amount of complaining about the abnormal, because New York City is not accustomed to an unbroken succession of days up in the nineties.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House authorized direct quotation of the President throughout:

Distribution of free subway timetables began yesterday at the transit stations. Riders put them in pockets and pocketbooks as rapidly as change booth attendants filled the orange-painted containers for the schedules.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The thermometer on the wall read only 84. But the humidity, and the bright lights for the motion picture cameras made it seem at least twice as hot in President Eisenhower's crowded news conference room today.

The Italian Government has purchased the six-story dwelling at 690 Park Avenue, which had been occupied under lease as te Italian Consulate. Assessed at $375,000, the property occupies a plot about 62 by 86 feet at the southwest corner of Sixty- ninth Street.
Three New York City men scheduled to be executed at Sing Sing Prison tonight for the 1950 slaying of a Reader's Digest messenger received a reprieve late yesterday.
MOSCOW, July 6 -- Permission to work as resident news correspondent in the Soviet Union was granted today to Welles Hangen.
Governor Harriman has talked to the major television networks with a view to assuring that New York State will not lose out to California as a producing center.
A majority of stocks traded yesterday declined, despite spectacular advances for General Motors, du Pont and a handful of oils and chemicals.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Active mill buying against flour sales was a major factor in lifting wheat prices today. But the fact that recent buying has absorbed hedging also impressed the trade, leading to good outside buying.
Four hot days in a row have touched off the summer's first big buying boom in room air conditioners here.

BIRMINGHAM, England, July 6 (UP) -- Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., and the defending champion, Jaroslav Drobny of Egypt, led the way today into the quarter-finals of the Midland Counties lawn tennis tournament.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 6 -- Top-seeded Eddie Moylan of Trenton and Second-ranked William Tully of Yonkers advanced to the quarter-final round of the New York State men's tennis championships on the courts of the County Club today.

A store center in planned in the Flushing section of Queens by Lawrence M. Lyons, builder and real estate operator. He has acquired a plot on Sixty-ninth Avenue, between 164th and 165th Streets, on which he plans a a building to contain a supermarket and fourteen other stores.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., is offering 200,000 shares of common stock of California Water and Telephone Company at $18.75 a share. Money raised by the sale will be used by the company to finance additions and improvements to properties.
SYRACUSE, July 6 -- The country's adult population was blamed here today for confusing understanding with "coddling" in its approach to juvenile delinquency.
Prime Minister Nu of Burma accused the American people last night of an exaggerated fear of communism. He saw this as damaging to United States prestige in Asia.
BONN, Germany, July 6 -- The Chancellor's Christian Democratic Union proposed today an electoral reform that would result in a two-party system in West Germany.

The Brooklyn Appellate Division dismissed yesterday a $1,050,000 suit brought against the city by Max Schuster, the father of Arnold L. Schuster, who was mysteriously murdered after he had informed the police of the whereabouts of Willie Sutton, the bank robber.
DANBURY, Conn., July 6 -- The eighty-five-year-old Danbury News Times, this city's only newspaper, is being sold, it was disclosed today.

May I express the appreciation of the National Probation and Parole Association for your editorial of June 24 supporting Governor Harriman's position in behalf of improved probation services for New York courts. The Governor's position is a sound one, recognizing the importance of early and effective treatment of offenders in any program designed to cope with delinquency and crime.
SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, July 6 (AP) -- The Mare Nostrum, a Spanish yacht that had not reported her position in more than a week, today sailed into port to win the 4,200-mile race from Havana.
NEW DELHI, India, July 6 -- It has been a long time in coming, but on the legal horizon is a sign of help for that most harried of Indians, the father of the bride.
HONG KONG, July 6 -- A 1955 state budget with expenditures amounting to the equivalent of $12,563,000,000 was submitted to Communist China's Congress in Peiping today.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The illness and hospitalization for months of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas are most unhappy reminders of the many recent entries on the casualty lists of party leaders in Congress. They are reminders, too, of the dominant reason for this situation -- the heavy toll of mental and physical pressure on these leaders.
BRIONI ISLAND, Yugoslavia, July 6 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru predicted tonight good results from the forthcoming Big Four conference in Geneva.
Don Mueller, who rarely swings for the seats, lashed savagely at a high fast ball by Curt Simmons in the sixth inning at the Polo Grounds last night.

"Nine Men," a political history of the Supreme Court by Fred Rodell, will be issued Aug. 12 by Random House. The author discusses the court's place in our scheme of government, past and present, interpreting its ceremony and secrecy, its robes and ritual.
The Hooker Electrochemical Company reported yesterday a net income of $4,085,100 for the six months ended May 31. This compares with $3,215,800 for the similar period of the preceding fiscal year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 6 -- Paramount is planning a motion picture about the tragic life of Ira Hayes, one of the Marines who raised the Stars and Stripes on Mount Surabachi during World War II.
ALBANY, July 6 -- Benjamin J. Buttenwieser of New York, former assistant United States High Commissioner to Germany, was elected chairman of the new committee on city-state fiscal relations today.

"The melodious wail of the steam locomotive whistle -- nostalgic music to the ear of rail fans -- won't become the lost chord on Long Island after all." That's what the Long Island Rail Road said yesterday.

Something of the delight of our parks will soon become a reality for a group of men, women and children who rarely can fully appreciate them -- the blind. A gift of $125,000 from the Ray and Charles Newman Memorial Foundation will make it possible for the Park Department to transform a special section of Central Park near Fifth Avenue and East Seventieth Street into "Fragrance-Touch Garden for the Blind."
It appears to me that the letter of W. Stanley Rycroft on the church in Argentina oversimplifies a complex problem.

In a few years Randalls Island will be bigger by forty-six acres. To accomplish this, the city will cut off the northern end of near-by Wards Island by rerouting Little Hell Gate, the water passage between the islands. It will also fill in part of that waterway's bed.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated net income of the major segment of Class I carriers during May at $86,000,000. This was more than double the earnings of $40,000,000 reported by the same railroads in May, 1954.
Three teen-age slayers of a 30-year-old television salesman received sentences of sixty-five years to life yesterday in Bronx County Court.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- After four years of executive delay the Senate voted today unanimous approval of the revised Geneva conventions setting new standards of treatment for prisoners of war and civilian captives. The vote was 77 -- 0.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Post Office Department announced today that the forthcoming three-cent stamp commemorating President Eisenhower's "Atoms-for-Peace" plan would go on sale here July 28.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Caryl Chessman, scheduled to die in the gas chamber of San Quentin prison July 15, won a reprieve for the seventh time today.
TAIPEI, Formosa, July 1 -- A lively little Navy is growing in the Formosa Strait under the wing of the United States Seventh Fleet.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland. July 6 (UP) -- American tempers flared on the ancient St. Andrews course today as the former United States Open champion, Ed Furgol, shot a 71 in the first round of the Britsh Open golf tournament. This put him two strokes behind three deadlocked British leaders.
Two Broadway producers, foregoing thoughts of vacation for business matters, completed arrangements yesterday for the use of the Lyceum Theatre as a showplace for their respective stage offerings.
CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP) -- Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steel producer, announced that effective today it was advancing prices of many of its steel products.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Administration's countrywide highways-building program remained in deadlock in a House of Representatives committee today.
Directors of the Koppers Company, Inc., have elected Walter C. Rueckel as vice president and general manager of the engineering and construction division.
BOSTON, July 6 -- The spire of the Old North Church lifted once more over Boston's North End today.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "The Shrike," a Universal-International version of Joseph Kramm's Pulitzer Prize-winning drama co-starring Jose Ferret and June Allyson, is at the Victoria.

WALLA WALLA, Wash., July (AP) -- Rebelling convicts at the Washington State Prison today ended their twenty-six-hour revolt and released unharmed nine hostages after winning promises of major concessions that may not be kept.

The Italian ministerial crisis has not only been settled in the relatively short time of two weeks but the outcome is most heartening. The Government that the new Premier, Antonio Segni, has brought together is stronger than the previous one of Mario Scelba, and it offers the hope of progress and stability.

Floyd Patterson, a Brooklyn light heavyweight, invaded the heavyweight ranks with success at Madison Square Garden last night. He knocked out Archie McBride of Trenton in 1 minute 46 seconds of the seventh round of the scheduled ten-round feature contest.

The American people generally have come to believe that Western proposals for disarmament inspection and control are "fool-proof" and that the Soviet Union would not accept them in the foreseeable future.

AMSTERDAM, N. Y., July 6 (AP) -- S. G. Cramer Company has closed its wholesale grocery house here and the five supermarkets operated by a subsidiary. The Cramer Company and Supreme Food Stores, Inc., filed bankruptcy petitions yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 6 -- A Federal judge said here tonight one of the first duties of the nation's lawyers "is to bring the administration of justice in the courts into harmony with the tempo of the age of the radio and the airplane."

NEW HAVEN, July 6 -- Yale University, seeking a site for new undergraduate dormitories, has offered the city $3,000,000 for the land and buildings of the James Hillhouse and Wilbur L. Cross High Schools and the Boardman Trade School.
Five men, three of whom displayed pistols, had the good fortune yestermday to choose as a hold-up victim a man unable to call loudly for help. As a result they escaped easily with $5,000 in cash.
CAIRO, July 6 -- Egyptian and Israeli representatives reached swift agreement today on an agenda and began negotiating ways to end armed border clashes.

The Chase Manhattan Bank's net operating earnings after taxes for the first six months of 1955 amounted to $21,051,000, or $1.75 a share, on the 12,000,000 shares of capital stock outstanding, it reported yesterday. For comparison only, the combined net operating earnings for the first half of 1954 amounted to $18,012,000, or $1.50 a share, on the same number of shares.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- Gene Conley, selected for the National League All-Star team, today became the first Milwaukee pitcher to win ten games this season. He hurled the Braves to a 5-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs before a Ladies' Day crowd of 40,985.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation was drawn today into the swirling controversy over the Dixon-Yates power contract.
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 6 -- The military advisers of the Southeast Asia Collective Defense Treaty held their first formal meeting here today under a tight security blackout.

The twelve-story Bryce Building at 387-393 Fourth Avenue has been sold by the Edith C. Bryce estate to an investing customer of Boyd E. Wilson Co., brokers in the transaction. The property, on plot about 98 by 166 feet at the northeast corner of Twenty-seventh Street, was formerly part of the Peter Cooper estate.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Application of martial law in a nuclear war is being studied with the view of minimizing its effect upon the American system of government President Eisenhower said today.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 6 (AP) -- The Easy Washing Machine Corporation today announced its directors had approved a proposed merger with the Union Chemical and Materials Corporation of Pittsburgh.

WISE shoppers this week-end will take advantage of the attractive values offered in frying chickens and pork. Market experts cite the unusually good supplies of pork as the reason for the sharply lower prices. Other good bargains may be found in fresh, local greens abundantly available for the vegetable basket.

GAZA ARMISTICE LINE, July 6 -- Egyptian-Israeli talks on quieting the Gaza border moved forward today after representatives of the two nations had agreed to an agenda proposed by Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 6 -- Security measures were reinforced tonight as Chile awaited a twenty-four-hour nation-wide general strike due to begin at midnight.

The city of Tulsa, Okla., borrowed $5,437,000 yesterday on issues of serial bonds to finance improvements. Issues of airport sewer and road bonds totaling $5,152,000 and due from 1958 to 1980 were sold to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates at interest costs ranging from 2.62 per cent to 2.67 per cent.

GAZA ARMISTICE LINE, July 6 -- Israeli officials contend that as a result of the geographical situation here, a one-sided version of the Gaza talks goes to the outside world. A visit to the border during today's meeting showed why they think so.
ON hot days, when the cook wants to spend as little time as possible in the kitchen, canned meats are an expedient for quick, hearty main dishes.
Harvey E. Lamcke, 27-year-old former Government egg grader, received a suspended sentence yesterday after pleading guilty to false grading.
CINCINNATI, July 6 (UP) -- Warren Giles, the National League president, today fined Birdie Tebbetts and Harry Walker $100 each for their part in an "unprecedented" baseball fist fight last night.
Following is the text of Adlai E. Stevenson's speech to the National Education Association in Chicago last night, as recorded by The New York Times:
THE next two weeks should provide ideal conditions for the varmint hunters. Most fields of alfalfa, timothy and clover seem to be sufficiently open to permit easy spotting of woodchucks.
MOSCOW, July 6 -- A large group of scientists from foreign countries, including non-Communist states, inspected the Soviet Union atomic energy power plant today.
Trans World Airlines tried a new tack yesterday in its plan to help form a second United States global air service.
The New York Central Railroad in the first six months this year turned in a net income of $26,513,491, in contrast to a deficit of $6,701,856 in the corresponding period of 1954.
MURREE, Pakistan, July 6 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali was rebuffed today by his colleagues in the Moslem League.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 6 (UP) -- The Pennsylvania State Athletic Commission today placed a six-months suspension on Harold Johnson for his "blackout" loss to Julio Mederos May 6 in Philadelphia. The commission also directed that the light heavyweight's $4,113 purse for the fight be forfeited.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) -- The Government announced today it had lost $643,987,964 on farm price support operations for the first eleven months of the last fiscal year. It said this compared with losses of $419,477,074 during the previous full fiscal year.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- Butcher hogs' broke 50 to 75 cents as demand tell of U sharlolv today, partly because of continued hot weather. Steers and heifers met active demand, selling steady to 25 cents higher. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
Continued hot and muggy weather through Saturday, and possibly Sunday, was all the Weather Bureau could foresee last night.

Hoffman Electronics Corporation has announced the purchase of all outstanding shares of Nation Fabricated Products, Inc., Chicago maker of electronic components, and will operate it as a division. The Chicago concern employs about 400 and has a net worth of about $2,000,000. Purchase price was not disclosed.
The agencies of the United Israel Appeal expended $46,000,000 for their immigration and resettlement programs in Israel during the first half of this year.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Public Housing Commissioner Charles E. Slusser announced today the sale of $192,558,000 in short-term loan notes by fifty-eight local housing authorities.
There's no doubt about it: The auctioneer at the Saratoga yearling sales next month will make mention of Getthere Jack in his pep talks to the customers.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Following are the main points made by President Eisenhower at his seventy-third news conference today:
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Eisenhower sent a message of goodwill to Prime Minister Nehru today by the hand of V. K. Krishna Menon.

ROME, July 6 -- A Cabinet differing little from its predecessor in composition or policy was announced today by Prof. Antonio Segni. The prominent left-wing member of the Christian Democratic party and leading advocate of land reform was sworn in with his Ministers by President Giovanni Gronchi.
DETROIT, July 6 (AP) -- Ferris Fain, a two-time American League batting champion, got his unconditional release from the Detroit Tigers today.

PITTSBURGH, July 6 -- Carl Erskine gained his ninth triumph of the year and first in nearly a month as the Dodgers flattened the Pirates tonight in the first game of a twilight-night double-header, 10 to 5. But that was as far as Walter Alston's Brooks were to go on this sultry evening.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- A Senate-House conference committee agreed on a $3,285,800,000 foreign aid authorization today. It also approved a House-sponsored amendment reaffirming Congress' opposition to a United Nations seat for Communist China.

Benefit committee members of the Women's Auxiliary Board and the Hospital Unit Associates of St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases have been meeting to plan their annual fashion show and card party.
LIKE other men of science before him, Robert Polk, 11 years old going on 12, knows what it's like to have contemporaries think him a trifle strange.
PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 6 -- Althea Gibson, the defending titleholder, reached the round of sixteen in the women's New York State championship today at the Pelham Country Club.
LONDON, July 6 -- Trading in the stock market expanded today with the start of a new bookkeeping account. A shortage of offerings accentuated the upward trend in prices.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Eisenhower criticized today a Congressional practice of legislating on specific tariff items without regard to the effect on the reciprocal trade agreements program.
PERTH AMBOY, N. J., July 6 -- Five Bronx lawyers spent the day here conferring with local officials and visiting recreational centers to learn how this community deals with juvenile delinquency.
ALBANY, July 7 -- Governor Harriman today appointed Aaron L. Jacoby of Brooklyn to the Public Service Commission. Mr. Jacoby is chief clerk of the Kings County Surrogate's Court.

FORT CAMPBELL, Ky., July 7 (AP)--A thin but steady stream of the nation's largest transport airplanes--a parade which at its westbound peak will be some 9,000 miles long--roared off toward Japan today.

DUBLIN, July 7 (UP) -- The defending champion, Hugh Stewart of San Marino, Calif, gained the final of the Irish lawn tennis singles championship today with a thrilling 6 -- 4, 6 -- 8, 8 -- 10, 6 -- 4, 11 -- 9 victory over Bob Perry of Los Angeles.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Consolidated sales of Libby, McNeill Libby in the fiscal year ended May 28 rose to a record high of $261,876,478, Charles S. Bridges, president, said today in the annual report to shareholders.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The economic boom still is rolling into new high ground, James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, reported today.
The Greater New York Racing Association, Inc., formed by The Jockey Club to rehabilitate the thoroughbred sport, went into business yesterday.
A television advertiser has put "giveaways" into the big money with sponsorship of a program offering $64,000 to the winner, who has nothing to do but answer a few questions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 7 -- A strike by the Screen Actors Guild that would cripple television film production by the major motion picture studios and other principal producers of movies for video here became a possibility today.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that the penalty rate for excess cotton grown under rigid marketing quotas this year will be 17.7 cents a pound, nearly 60 per cent of the current average market price.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Federal Court of Appeals ruled today that the adoption of a 6year-old white boy by his Negro stepfather would be in the best interests of the child.
One police sergeant was dismissed yesterday and eighteen patrolmen were fined or reprimanded in connection with towcar operations in Manhattan and the Bronx.

Two suggestions have been heard recently by way of proposals for the forthcoming Geneva conference of the Big Four heads of government. One is the project for an all-European security pact and the other one would have the United States formally renounce the goal of liberation for the captive peoples behind the Iron Curtain.
MANILA, July 7 -- President Ramon Magsaysay called the Philippine Congress into special session today for a showdown test of his political leadership.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 7 -- The first anniversary of Ngo Dinh Diem's Premiership was celebrated today with mass meetings, athletic events, fireworks and a parade of lantern-bearing soldiers.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- A Senate inquiry acted today to block Government payment of cancellation fees if the DixonYates power contract should be revoked.
TRENTON, July 7 -- New Jersey has instituted a new program to speed the immigration of refugees from Communistdominated lands.

The traditional "family management" of Tiffany Co. struck back yesterday at reported efforts of Irving Maidman, real estate operator and builder, to become a director or officer of the jewelry and silverware concern.
Sales and earnings of the Raytheon Manufacturing Company in the fiscal year ended May 31 were the highest in its history.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The State Department said today the United States Government's opposition to the seating of Communist China in the United Nations was unabated, despite a statement by Prime Minister Nu of Burma.

Robert Moses yesterday accused the president of Consolidated Edison Company of New York of indulging in "dexterously evasive" declarations in the company's bid for private development of the vast power resources of Niagara Falls.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 7 (Reuters)--The following is the text of a declaration issued today by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India and President Tito of Yugoslavia after Mr. Nehru's one-week visit to Yugoslavia: ...

BUENOS AIRES, July 7 -- Dr. Arturo Frondizi, president of the National Committee of the Radical party, disclosed today that the Ministry of Communications had refused to grant the party radio time to broadcast its political program.

Motorists traveling to and from New York this week-end can expect detours or delays, because of repairs, new construction or congestion, on the following routes (the numbers correspond to those on the map):
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Eisenhower received today a recommendation for a vast hydrogen war test in combination with Civil Defense and Government dispersal exercises in 1956.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 7 -- A private complaint of perjury was lodged today against Dr. Israel Kastner, a wartime Zionist leader in Budapest, Hungary, who was accused by a Jerusalem court of having been a Nazi collaborator.
The Coast Guard searched nearly 4,000 square miles of the Atlantic off New Jersey yesterday, looking for a fishing boat that may never have existed.

In endorsing a large-scale program of Federal aid to education Adlai Stevenson has nevertheless shown himself to be fully aware of the very real problems raised by this further expansion of Federal influence into an area traditionally reserved to local authority.
The New York Chamber of Commerce spoke out yesterday against a House of Representatives bill that would tighten Federal control over bank mergers.

DAVID UNWIN'S first novel, "The Governor's Wife,"* is a topical discussion of the crisis in race relations that for the last few years has convulsed much of Africa south of the Sahara. Few of the horrendous problems that torment our weary world are more complicated and difficult and few have had so many books written about them.
Intensive efforts are being made to continue "Ankles Aweigh" at the Mark Hellinger Theatre beyond tomorrow night.
PARIS, JULY 7 -- Premier Edgar Faure's government, still grappling with the problems of French North Africa, defended the conventions of Tunisian home rule in the National Assembly today.
HOUSTON, Tex., July 7 -- The Santa Fe Railway is spending "several million dollars" on a new passenger car which, it is hoped, will help recapture lost passenger traffic.

"Ole Miss," a small plane with a determined disposition, has earned a price in the Smithsonian Institution. Twenty-years ago the single-engined aircraft, piloted by brothers Al and Fred Key, established a world flight endurance record that still stands.

"The Tontine," Thomas B. Costain's new novel in two volumes, has been scheduled for Sept. 23 publication by Doubleday. Containing more than 950 page, the story, set in nineteenthcentury England and America, deals with four generations of three families.

BIRMINGHAM, England, July 7 (UP) -- Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., entered the semi-finals of the Midland Counties tennis championship today with a 2 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2 victory over Orlando Sirola of Italy.
Abolition of the National Labor Relations Board was "urged yesterday by Louis Waldman, former counsel for the International Longshoremen's Association.
Cotton futures closed strong on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, up 1 t 15 points (5 to 75 cents a bale).
At his press conference on Wednesday President Eisenhower said: "I just think that Congress, when it wants to, can do an awful lot in a very short time and I am hopeful that they will do so."
NORFOLK, Va., July 7 (AP) -Federal Judge Walter E. Hoffman ruled today that the Commonwealth of Virginia could not deny Negroes the use of Seashore State Park.
An ocean breeze and cloudiness combined yesterday to hold the day's maximum temperature below 90 degrees for the first time since Sunday.

Clare Boothe Luce, Ambassador to Italy, made a plea yesterday for "the young Italian Republic." She said that "misguided millions" of Italians who vote Communist wanted the wrong thing for the right reason.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -A Government security officer today parried questions whether he had had a liaison with a German "Miss X." He acknowledged that he had sponsored her entry into the United States.
TOKYO, July 7 -- The Communist party of Japan has ordered its members to come out of hiding and use "legal" tactics in promoting world revolution, according to Japanese security officials.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The United States accepted today the Soviet Union's offer to pay half the damages for the attack June 23 on a Navy patrol plane over the Bering Sea.

QUITE by accident the other day some file-worm stumbled onto a run of stories in The New York Times, written 100 years ago, that might Well have carried the same general caption as a current series-the pieces labeled, "Our Changing City."
Even before it began, market analysts were predicting that 1955 would be a year of stock splits. They were right.
Group Health Insurance, Inc., earned $350,000 -- 20 per cent -more in premiums last year than the year before, according to the annual report of its president, Arthur H. Harlow Jr.
WASHINGTON July 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of a United States note to the Soviet Union on the shooting down of the Navy patrol plane by Soviet jet fighters last June 23:
CAIRO, July 7 -- Egypt's representative said tonight that he hoped full agreement with Israel on measures to curb the truce line fighting would be drafted by the end of next week.

The directors of the Byron Jackson Company approved yesterday the proposed merger with the Borg-Warner Corporation. They set Aug. 23 as the date for a special meeting of the stockholders to act on the proposal.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The head of the New York City Youth Board and other juvenile authorities told a Senate Labor and Public Welfare subcommittee on juvenile delinquency today that local communities must take an active interest in youthful crime before it could be successfully combated.
HOBOKEN, N. J., July 7 -The Cunard Line freighter Andria was damaged early today by a general alarm fire while tied up at the Eighth Street pier here.
MOSCOW, July 7 -- Moscow rejects in advance any proposal that may be made at the Geneva conference for including a reunited Germany in the Atlantic alliance.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The State Department reversed previous rulings in two controversial passport cases today.

LONDON, July 7 -- The three Western powers are ready to agree at the Geneva conference to reasonable security arrangements meeting Soviet fears of a free and united Germany, Sir Anthony Eden declared tonight.
Adolf A. Berle Jr., state chairman of the Liberal party since 1947, resigned last night. New men should be enabled to take posts of responsibility, he said.
In the years between the start of World War I and the end of World War II, Harlem changed from a melting pot into the city's boiling pot.

Mayor Wagner returned to City Hall yesterday after a month away. He brought back with him from Europe some ideas and impressions. Housing, street cleanliness, transportation, city noise, municipal finances were among the problems he looked at.

The Homemaker Service of the Children's Aid Society will benefit from the Nov. 15 performance of the Enid Bagnold play, "The Chalk Garden," which opens here Oct. 24 with a cast headed by Gladys Cooper.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 7 (AP) -- The defending champion, Peter Thomson, stroked home a 20-foot putt on the eighteenth green today for a 68 and a place among the trio sharing the lead in the British open golf championship.
MURREE, Pakistan, July 7 -- A dispute over the designation of a temporary chairman disrupted the opening session of the new Pakistan National Assembly today.
WASHINGTON, July 7--Congress passed and sent to the White House today a bill authorizing $3,285,800,000 for foreign military and economic aid in the fiscal year 1956.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee announced today it was calling five newsmen to testify next Wednesday in a resumption of hearings on Communist infiltration of the press.
MELBOURNE, Australia, July 7 -- Australia closed the fiscal year on June 30 with a trade deficit of 68,000,000 Australian ($151,320,000), compared with a surplus of 46,700,000 in 1953-54.
The all-but-forgotten specter of horse theft reared its visage again in Brooklyn yesterday. But about as fast as it takes to say "Hi Ho, Silver," the purloined pony was recovered.

If you see yellow spots before your eyes as you start down the subway stairs it won't mean that a dizzy spell has struck you. The Transit Authority is installing yellow plastic disks in scores of subway stations to let riders know when they are at the top or bottom of a flight of stairs.

WALLA WALLA, Wash., July 7 (AP) -- Guards seized scores of weapons -- knives, axes, hammers and baseball bats -- today as they conducted a cell-by-cell shakedown of Washington State Prison after a two-day revolt.

MOSCOW, July 7 -- Samuel Reshevsky of the United States tonight challenged the chess champion of the world, Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union, to a twenty-game match. Ten games would be played in New York and ten in Moscow.

Commodity futures were irregular yesterday in dull trading on the New York exchanges. Coffee, sugar, wool and zinc were mixed; rubber, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, cocoa and tin eased. Potatoes, burlap, hides, lead and copper ended higher.
The total of polio cases in the city this year rose to ninety-one yesterday, with five new cases reported.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Frank Lloyd Wright said today that "half-baked" designs for ultra-modern buildings would turn the new Air Force academy into a "wayside market."
Earlier target dates for completion of subway construction and maintenance projects were called for yesterday by the new Transit Authority.

Alco Products, Inc., announced yesterday that it had named the Stone Webster Engineering Corporation as engineer-constructor for the so-called Army Package Power Reactor. This is a portable power plant whose components can be transported by air.
The market for foreign dollar bonds continued yesterday to appraise optimistically the chances that Russia and the West would reach a 'meeting of minds on financial issues at the Geneva Conference.

PITTSBURGH, July 7 -- Walter Alston did a great deal of perspiring today and it wasn't all caused by the sultry weather. A stirring ninth-inning uprising by Fred Haney's pesky young Pirates almost wrenched a well-earned game away from the Dodgers.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 7 -- Difficulties have developed for South Africans of British ancestry who travel on British passports.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Export-Import Bank today announced that it had granted three credits for a total of $15,500,000 for industrial projects in Spain and Italy.

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- Mrs. Titus Haffa, wife of an appliance manufacturer, was revealed today as the holder of the lone $100 ticket on the 140-to-1 winner of the fourth race at the Arlington Park race track yesterday.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System may have a comer in a young man named Johnny Carson, who now has his own show at 10 o'clock Thursday evenings. He is a humorist of the quiet, unhurried school and he has a most engaging smile and personality.
SYRACUSE, July 7 -- Attorney General Jacob K. Javits proposed today a "very much longer school day" for children from broker homes as one means of combating delinquency.
GAZA ARMISTICE LINE, July 7 -- Egyptian and Israeli representatives consented tentatively today to some proposed security arrangements for this area but there was disagreement on important points.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 7 -- Eddie Moylan of Trenton, favored to win the New York State tennis championship for his thirteenth victory of the campaign, and unseeded Phil Hanna of Jackson Heights reached the semi-finals in the only singles matches played at the County Tennis Club of Westchester today.
WESTON, Conn., July 7--Associate Justice John Marshall Harlan of the Supreme Court denied tonight an application for a new appeal by the three Reader's Digest killers.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UP) -Brig. Gen. W. W. White, who handles military oil needs, told House investigators today that he was drawing pay from a major oil corporation in addition to his Government salary.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 7 -- Chile's one-day general strike has passed without disorder, but with no progress toward settlement of the strikers' grievances.

New York's seven major daily newspapers are continuing to pile up impressive gains over 1954. In June the seven papers had 14,461,778 lines of advertising, against 13,256,308 for the 1954 month. This was a gain of 9.09 per cent.

TAIPEI, Formosa, July 7 -- Four United States Air Force generals arrived in Formosa today to appraise the air defense strength of the Chinese Nationalist island. At the same time the Nationalist Air Force again warned of the shifting of Communist air power to the southeast China coast opposite Formosa.
Three union officials were arraigned in General Sessions Court yesterday on charges of jamming the telephone lines of seven drugstores in a drive to organize the employes.
A new air-cooled Diesel engine -- probably the lightest of its type in the world -- was given its first public demonstration here yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, July 7 (AP) -- Argentine officials are planning to renegotiate an oil exploration contract recently signed with Standard Oil Company of California, according to well-informed sources here. The contract, which bears the signature of President Juan Peron has been under study in the Argentine Congress for nearly two months.

NORTH TARRYTOWN. N. Y., July 7 -- The General Motors Corporation offered today to buy from Westchester County seventy two acres, including part of the county's Kingsland Point Park here. The land, which lies close to the Hudson River, would be used for expansion of the corporation's Chevrolet and Fisher body division plants here.
STRASBOURG, France, July 7 (Reuters)--Yugoslavia is considering cooperating with the fifteen-nation Council of Europe, the unofficial parliament of Europe.

WASHINGTON, July 7--Secretary of State John Foster Dulles told Congress early in June that the economy of the Soviet Union "is on the point of collapsing." He gave no factual elaboration to support the statement.

Frank Dooley Adams, that sterling steerer of steeplechase and hurdle horses, did some "Johnny-on-the-spot" steering at Aqueduct yesterday. Deprived of his whip at the last hedge, Adams nevertheless piloted Sanford Stud Farm's Fulton to a rousing triumph.
Two West Coast shipping executives outlined their views yesterday on improved labor-management relations, increased shoreside productivity and operating economies.

Unwarranted interference with the operations of the United States Information Agency, plus appeasement on the part of that agency, have combined to deliver a severe blow to American principles and to the effort to give an honest picture of our country to the world at large.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Representative Robert H. Mollohan said today the nation's railroads had accepted $1,500,000,000 worth of Government tax help to build freight cars but had failed to keep the freight fleet up even to peace- time needs.

Camilo W. Leyra Jr., 55-yearold salesman, was sentenced yesterday to the electric chair by Kings County Judge Hyman Barshay. He had been convicted June 29 for the third time of killing his father and mother with a hammer.
BOSTON, July 7 -- A group of Massachusetts legislators and business leaders will visit New York tomorrow to study facilities of the Port of New York Authority.

Permit me to express agreement with your editorial objections to the proposed 100-foot-high monument to the late Senator Robert A. Taft on Capitol Hill. Particularly pertinent is your observation: "We find it difficult to imagine Mr. Taft, with his innate sense of the fitness of things, approving a memorial -- to anyone -- on the grounds of his beloved Capitol."
ALBANY, July 7 (AP) -- The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court upheld today an order of the State Education Commissioner removing five members from the Lindenhurst, L. I., school board.
CINCINNATI, July 7 (AP) -Johann Kupferburger of Johannesburg, South Africa, eliminated the top foreign threat today in a rain-interrupted TriState - Western tennis tournament.
PARIS, July 7 -- The Soviet Union has told the organizers of the International Geophysical Year that it hopes to occupy at least one outpost on the Antarctic Continent.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Controller General Joseph Campbell reported apparent "conflicts of interest" today in the activities of a St. Louis mining executive as an unpaid Federal official.

The arguments against a $1 minimum wage that he made in two appearances before the Senate Labor Committee in April and May are repeated in his letter in these columns June 7 by Emerson P. Schmidt, Director of the Economic Research Department of the United States Chamber of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said today that he would fight to prevent veterans from shouldering further Ready Reserve obligations.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The announcement by Mr. Tompkins aroused speculation here as to the union that would be cited. It has been known for some time in labor and other circles that several have been under investigation.

PARIS, July 7 -- Mark T. Shaw, United States consultant on marketing, distribution and productivity, has charged that French trade associations had nullified efforts to introduce competitive productivity into France.

IN PEPPER, the coarser the grind, the more pungent the flavor. Or at least that is how it seems to be. Actually, larger particles of the condiment are no more flavorful than the finely ground version, but they do retain their tang longer.

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- With the hot weather continuing unabated, hog prices declined further in the livestock market today. Steers and heifers again were in active demand Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
A new type of "moving sidewalk" that turns corners and moves up and down grades was demonstrated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Florida's new legal system for Presidential preference primaries cannot be tested until May 29 next year -- the fixed date for this state-wide poll. That is regrettable because the law is a great improvement over any other now in effect, including those of New Hampshire and South Dakota.

Miss Blanche Ring, whose merry songs still live in the memories of older theatregoers, gave an interview yesterday in her room at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, 218 Second Avenue at Thirteenth Street.
GENEVA, July 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower will live in a luxurious fifteen-room villa five miles north of Geneva during the forthcoming Big Four conference.
Mayor Wagner, back at City Hall yesterday after his tour of Europe and Israel, said that he still favored Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1956.
The new management of National Department Stores promised stockholders yesterday that it would take drastic action wherever necessary to reverse the trend of income losses.

ALTHOUGH Strauss '"Gypsy Baron," heard in concert performance at Lewisohn Stadium last evening, is not up to the level of "Die Fledermaus" (indeed, what other Strauss operetta is?), it contains many sprightly tunes.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Thirteen Soviet agricultural officials, expected in New York July 16, will see a cross-section of American farming during their month-long tour of the United States.

The thirteen-story and penthouse, building at 157 West Fifty-seventh Street, containing wo stores and fifty-two apartments, has been purchased by David Bergner and Abraham Hershson from a syndicate represented by Henry H. Held, attorney.

LEE, Mass., July 7 -- Ten dancers from the Royal Danish Ballet made their American debut near here last night at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, under the auspices of Ted Shawn. They bowed themselves into a new country in the liveliest and most charming manner.
HONG KONG, July 7 -- Communist China was reported today to be preparing to build a railway that would supply her military forces in Fukien province facing Nationalist-held Quemoy and Formosa.
HONG KONG, Friday, July 8 -- Communist China has agreed on an 800,000,000-yuan ($338,000,000) economic aid program for North Vietnam.
BEVERLY HILLS, July 7 -Mr. Wolfson tonight asserted that Senator Morse's tactics were so distasteful as to be compared to the type to be expected under nazism or communism.

CHARLIE DRESSEN was overjoyed at being back in the big leagues during spring training. He was popping off like a string of Chinese firecrackers. Little did he realize then that service as manager of the Washington Senators barely qualifies as a return to the majors. He's realizing it now, though.

Today's new film is "Crash-out," a melodrama, at the Palace. The cast is headed by William Bendix, Arthur Kennedy, Luther Adler and William Talman. Gene Evans and Marshall Thompson are seen in featured roles. Lewis R. Foster directed from a scenario he wrote with Hal E. Chester. Mr. Chester produced the Filmakers release.

The Bankers Trust Company has leased three floors in the thirty-story office building to be erected by Uris Brothers at 485 Lexington Avenue, the east blockfront between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 7 -- The Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation has agreed to buy a major interest in African Consolidated Theatres, which controls South Africa's entertainment industry.

In a Hyde-Jekyll show the Giants displayed their evil and good sides to 5,130 customers at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Virtue triumphed and they beat the Phillies, 8 -- 5, by crashing five homers in the late innings.

SALLY VICTOR has been spending the last two months boning up on Japan. After burning the midnight oil in museums and libraries, she has come up with a hat collection that is almost as good as a trip to the Land of the Rising Sun.

PULA, Yugoslavia, July 7 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India and President Tito of Yugoslavia called upon the Big Four today to initiate international cooperation for the peaceful use of nuclear energy.
GOSHEN, N. Y., July 7 (AP) -- Scott Frost failed in the first two heats, but took the last two and the $16,000 Historic-Dickerson Cup at Historic Track today.

After more than eighteen months of imprisonment some twenty-odd Dutch nationals have now been placed on trial by the Indonesian Government for alleged "seditious plotting." They are without counsel. The Dutch lawyer who was assigned to their case is reported to have fled the country in fear of his life.
New York's oldest active film studio will begin shooting a new television film feature next week, completely disregarding the furor over TV's next move or, for that matter, the movies' last move.
Cardinal Spellman sailed yesterday for South America, heading a list of 329 pilgrims going to the International Eucharistic Congress in Rio de Janeiro next month.

Gasoline stocks declined 4,861,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the report issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. This was the largest decline in supplies since the week ended Oct. 6, 1945, when gasoline stocks dipped 4,994,000 barrels.

Chile's twenty-four-hour general strike yesterday, which seems to have been effective and which came on top of a grave transport strike, is one more warning that the country simply cannot continue indefinitely along its precipitate path of inflation.
THE salt water front offers better prospects than the lakes or streams this weekend, although a few of the bass lakes within a hundredmile radius of the city are giving up some nice fish.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The United-States and West Germany signed today a controversial air agreement despite the objections of major domestic airlines.

JAMESTOWN, N. Y., July 7 (AP) -- Billy Shields of Albany, a top favorite, and John Quinzi of Rochester, a long shot, advanced through two rounds of the New York State amateur golf championship today. They will meet tomorrow in what could be the best match of the tourney.

The Council of Europe, now meeting in Strasbourg, has before it proposals for revision of its basic statute to open its doors for the admission of additional European countries, including the Soviet satellites. The proposals were met with immediate protests from some delegations who saw in them a watering down of the ideals of freedom for which the Council and its statute stand.
BRIXHAM, England, July 7 (Reuters) -- A shipyard here has signed a contract to build a reproduction of the 183-ton Mayflower, which carried the Pilgrim Fathers to America in 1620.

Percy E. Champion, former head auditor of the Lafayette National Bank, Brooklyn, was sentenced yesterday to a year in Federal penitentiary by Judge Robert A. Inch in the Brooklyn Federal Court. Champion had pleaded guilty on June 21 to a charge of embezzling $4,985 of the bank's funds.

LONDON, July 7 (Reuters)--An innings of 155 not out by Denis Compton helped after England made a poor start in the third test cricket match against South Africa at Manchester today. England won the first two matches in the five-match series.

DETROIT, July 7 (AP) -- Prime Minister Nu said today his earlier comment that top United States officials favored admitting Red China into the United Nations was an impression gained under the assumption the Reds would "behave."

Current economic trends indicate that in twenty years labor and pension funds "will own 35 per cent of all big business," Adolf A. Berle Jr., chairman of the Board of the Twentieth Century Fund, reported last night.
LONDON, July 7 -- Britain sharply informed Czechoslovakia tonight of her displeasure at the continued detention of British-born wives of Czechoslovak citizens against their will.
The stock market underwent a general decline yesterday, with the recent favorites taking the biggest losses.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Folks are returning to Montgomery Ward Co. to work. The latest to rejoin the fold is Chester W. Anderson, who on Aug. 1 is to become mail order manager. He is expected to be elected a vice president at the next meeting of the board of directors.
LONDON, July 7 -- Prime Minister Eden sidestepped today a Laborite suggestion that Sir Winston Churchill be included in the British delegation to the Big Four conference in Geneva.

BOSTON, July 7 (UP) -- Grady Hatton's bases-loaded single highlighted a three-run seventhinning that enabled the Red Sox to beat the Washington Senators, 6 -- 5, tonight. It was the seventh victory in a row and the twelfth in the last thirteen games for Boston.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The weekly average of member bank reserve balances for the week ended July 6 decreased $44,000,000 to $18,609,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
LONDON, July 7 -- A Royal Air Force jet fighter pilot was killed today moments after flashing past Princess Margaret and a gala crowd at a flying display at Farnborough, Hampshire.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 7 (AP) -- American touring athletes broke six West Indian records last night in a track and field meet which was part of the celebration of Jamaica's 300-year link with Great Britain.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Impatient Senators looking for Louis E. Wolfson got an impatient telegram from their man today.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 7 -- The Justice Department soon will start filing petitions aimed at denying Communist-dominated labor unions their rights under the National Labor Relations Act, an Assistant Attorney General said here today.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Less activity was noted in the grain markets today, and buyers were cautious in following recent gains in wheat futures. There was some mill buying. Hedge pressure was light, and profit taking sales by local longs were absorbed on fractional setbacks.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Egypt's Foreign Minister, Dr. Mahoud Fawzi, told Secretary of State Dulles today that Egypt wanted to avoid war with Israel.
MORRISTOWN, AT. J., July 7 -- A 40-year-old amateur golfer, Martin Stanovich, led the field in the opening round of the New Jersey open championship today.
LONDON, July 7 -- Most industrial and Government issues scored gains today, although the latter opened dull and industrials suffered a late fall.
FORT WORTH, Tex., July 7 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted Safeway Stores, Inc., and two of its officials today on three criminal counts charging antitrust law violations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 7 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has the inside track on motion-picture rights to the story of Dr. Jonas Salk and his discovery of the polio vaccine. Arthur Jones is writing the screen treatment.

Loans to business by major New York City banks declined $126,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This was the largest weekly decline since June, 1954, and the first decrease in four weeks.
It is generally believed that the walkouts that have idled major copper mines and smelters in the past week will end shortly. But the shutdowns have aggravated an already serious supply shortage.
Birmingham, Ala., borrowed $4,000,000 on serial bonds yesterday to finance new school construction.

Five buildings containing 105 apartments at 354 to 370 Cypress Avenue, the Bronx, have been sold by the 354 Cypress Avenue Realty Corporation to an investor represented by Max Benegls, attorney. The property is assessed at $165,000. Stanley Russell Associates, Inc., were the brokers.

PARIS, July 7 -- Experts of the Western Big Three powers will meet here tomorrow in another stage of what officials believe will be the best coordinated negotiation that has yet taken place between the West and the Soviet Union.
CHICAGO, July 7 -- The nation's educators were urged today to improve the teaching of science and mathematics in high schools.
PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 7 -- Althea Gibson reached the semi-final round of the women's New York State tennis championship today at the Pelham Country Club.
Elimination of seven railroad grade crossings in Hicksville, L. I., was ordered yesterday by the Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A new plan to exempt all veterans from compulsory obligation to train as Ready Reserves brought fresh controversy today into the Administration's program to build up a 2,900,000 "minuteman" force in four years.

"THE GREAT STORY OF WHALES," by Georges Blond, French novelist and newspaper man, has kept me dodging icebergs in Antarctic waters for the last two days and nights. A fine thing, too. Particularly when most of the bystanders around us were being as ruthlessly eloquent about the heat wave as bomb-haunted raconteurs in wartime London.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The White House press office sought today to reconcile apparently conflicting statements by the President and his Secretary of State on the internal strength or weakness of the Soviet Union.
ALBANY, July 8 -- Two appointments to $12,500-a-year posts on the Workmen's Compensation Board were announced today by the Governor's office. The appointees are:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 8 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that the forthcoming United Nations atoms-for-peace parley might open the way for removing "the threat of the atomic bomb."
ST. PAUL, July 8 (UP) -- Jerry Barber, the Tiny Man of the links, shattered the thirty-six-hole record in the $15,000 St. Paul open touranment today with a fifteen-under-par 129.

TOKYO, July 8 (Reuters) -- Trade Minister Tanzan Ishibashi said today the Japanese Cabinet had approved his policy of expanding trade with the sterling area, mainly through increased Japanese imports. Mr. Ishibashi said he reported to a Cabinet meeting today on the progress of Anglo-Japanese trade and payments talks which opened here June 23.

Anthony Anastasia, Brooklyn dock boss, was soundly whipped yesterday in a test of strength at the quadrennial convention of the Atlantic Coast District of the Independent International Longshoremen's Association.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Tax increases on gasoline, large tires and heavy vehicles were recommended by a House of Representatives subcommittee today to help finance a new road-building program.
PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 8 -- June Kroeger of Louisville, Ky., an unseeded player, sprang two surprises today to reach the final of the New York State tennis championship at the Pelham Country Club.
A new police station, built on a park strip adjoining the northbound lane of the Bronx River Parkway near Sagamore Street, the Bronx, was put into use yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 8 (UP) -- Bob Lemon became the first American League pitcher to win twelve games this season tonight. He hurled the Cleveland Indians to a 1-0 victory over the Chicago White Sox, though he needed relief from Ray Narleski in the ninth inning after working eight frames in 96-degree temperature.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 8 -- Stan Mosel assumed a three-stroke lead in the New Jersey open golf championship today. With a crackling 64, six under par, the 23-year-old professional brought his thirty-six-hole total to 135.
LONDON, July 8 -- Gov. Averell Harriman of New York said today he hoped the Big Four conference in Geneva would discuss "the freer interchange of people and ideas between the two blocs."
PARIS, July 8 -- The transport ministers of eight countries approved here today the statutes of a new inter-European organization for the purchase and distribution of railroad equipment.
VERNON, N. Y., July 8 -- Adios Harry, a 4-year-old pacer owned by J. Howard Lyons of Freenwood, Del., set a world record for a mile race with a time of 1:55 2/5 at Vernon Downs tonight.
Two toll projects came to the horizon of the municipal bond market yesterday.
SEGUIN, Tex., July 8 (UP) -- Representative John J. Bell, Democrat of Texas, and two other men have been indicted on charges that they conspired to steal more than $154,000 of state money.

CHANGING the winter decor of an East River apartment required more ingenuity than cash for interior decorator Bess Bernard. Since the owner of the flat asked her to keep the cost low, Miss Bernard accomplished her mission with paint, fabric and rearrangement of furniture.
Leo Durocher and his Giants threw everything they had at the Dodgers in the opener of their three-game series at the Polo Grounds last night.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A possibility of ending Washington's transit strike turned up today, but it was no more than an outside chance. The strike entered its second week.
ALBANY, July 8 -- The New York Telephone Comppany's attempt to win a $68,500,000 rate increase ran into another setback today.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- Attorneys for Cpl. Claude J. Batchelor asked the Army today to set aside his conviction on charges of collaborating with the Communists in Korea.
SEVEN hundred and forty-nine conventions were held in New York City last year, and 2,500,000 persons attended them.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 8 -- About 2,500 striking Antwerp longshoremen went to a meeting today half intending to call off the strike. They were dissuaded by a Communist former member of Parliament, who was the last to speak.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 8 -- Mayor Frank Tobey said today that the Eisenhower Administration's suggestion that Memphis city officials "vote" their intention to provide the municipality with its own electric power resources was "so much Republican hogwash."
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Port of New York Authority today urged Congress to authorize $200,000 for a study of silting and shoaling in the Hudson River.
The heat wave nearly blacked out western Brooklyn yesterday.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced yesterday that it had granted two loans totaling $7,500,000 to Nicaragua for the development of electric power. The loans will help finance construction of a 30,000 kilowatt thermal power plant in Managua and transmission lines to fifteen outlying towns.

School is out these days, but the summer vacation does not mean a cessation of school activities. In fact, more than half of the school buildings are still open, in line with the Board of Education's summer recreation program. In addition, the board is operating forty-two swimming pools, 401 playgrounds, twenty-eight athletic fields, thirtyfive evening centers and twentynine play schools, with the cooperation of various organizations and city agencies.
Stocks started firm yesterday, eased most of the day and then staged a modest rally in the final thirty minutes to close irregular and only slightly lower.
Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation, one of the nation's top diversified organizations, has added another company to its long list of acquisitions -- the Brown Paper Mill Company, Inc.
AUSTIN, Tex., July 8 (UP) -- The Board of Regents abolished segregation today in the Graduate School of the University of Texas and at Texas Western College, effective this fall.

ON Nov. 9, 1895, one Mrs. Charles S. Brown won the first women's golf tournament ever sponsored by the United States Golf Association. Her score for eighteen holes was 132. She wore shoes with pointed toes, an ankle-length, long sleeved dress and a tiny cap atop her pompadour.
OTTAWA, July 8 -- Despite vigorous protests from the Conservative Opposition, the Canadian Government intends to go ahead with its proposal to sell wheat to Poland on a credit basis.

Stockholders of the Ferro Corporation yesterday authorized the issuance of $6,000.000 of twenty-year convertible subordinated debentures at a special meeting in Cleveland. Robert A. Weaver, chairman, said the board of directors planned to pay cash dividends each year instead of the combination of stock and cash dividends previously distributed.
BERLIN, July 4 -- West Berlin is better prepared today to withstand a renewed blockade than at any time in the last six years, responsible officials said.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, July 8 (AP) -- The United States yacht Ticonderoga today crossed the finish line of the 4,200-mile race from Havana, almost two days after the winning Spanish yacht Mare Nostrum.

TORONTO, July 8 (Canadian Press) -- Automobiles equipped with telephones have been used in some stock-selling schemes, O. E. Lennox, chairman of the Ontario Securities Commission, said in the current issue of the commission's bulletin.

LENOX, Mass., July 8 -- The Boston Symphony Orchestra, at least a substantial section of it, and its conductor, Charles Munch, began their annual task of adding the ministry of music to the generously endowed Berkshire countryside at Tanglewood here tonight.
New York's department and specialty stores have succeedd this summer in postponing the start of large-scale clearances of women's apparel, thereby prolonging ready-to-wear sales at full mark-up.
The Port of New York Authority welcomed an eager competitor yesterday with advice, open arms and a cooling tour of the harbor.

When Secretary of the Treasury Humphrey appeared before the House Ways and Means Committee for the third year to discuss the lack of elbow room posed by the present limit on the national debt it is significant to note that he did not reiterate his earlier request for permanent relief from this annually recurring and highly vexing problem.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 8 -- The Philippines announced its candidacy today for the Security Council seat to be vacated when Turkey's term expires at the end of this year.

Searching and Old Baasket waged a rousing duel in the mile-and-a-sixteenth race that topped yesterday's card at Aqueduct with the former winning by a head. There were six interests in the test, a classified event for fillies and mares, called the Canarsie Handicap, but the attention of the 17,691 fans was centered on the first two to finish.
Nineteen Arctic research teams will poke into Alaskan and Canadian water, air and surface phenomena this summer. Two other teams are preparing for winter studies.

"The Man Who Loved Redheads," a British-made Technicolor comedy written by Terence Rattigan and starring Moira Shearer, John Justin and Roland Culver, has been scheduled to open on Monday, July 18, at the Paris Theatre.
Actors Equity Association approved yesterday a salary reduction for all cast members of "Ankles Aweigh," thereby assuring its continuance at the Mark Hellinger Theatre.
VIENNA, July 8 (AP) -- Austria and the Soviet Union have agreed on the goods to be delivered by Austria as compensation for the Russian-administrated enterprises in this country.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The University of Rhode Island at Kingston received a patent this week on a cure for the highly destructive Dutch elm disease. The inventors -- two members of the faculty and an industrial chemist -- were surprised and gratified at the remarkable effectiveness of their discovery, but did not pretend to understand it completely.
LONDON, July 8 -- The National Coal Board announced today it was increasing the price of coal by 18 per cent beginning July 18.
The Columbia Broadcasting System confirmed yesterday a report that it had signed Orson Welles to direct and star in a series of elaborate color television shows, beginning this autumn.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- A below-average cotton crop of between ten and eleven million bales was indicated by a Department of Agriculture report today. The report said growers had reduced planting 14 per cent from last year under a rigid crop control program.

TART, fresh currants, available here for only two weeks each year, are now on the market. The quality of the fruit is excellent and supplies are ample for the brief season that continues for just about one week. more.

A hearing on whether the license of the Times Theatre at 302 West Forty-second Street should be renewed was adjourned yesterday until July 18. The license of the motion picture house expired June 30, but the theatre has been permitted to operate until a decision has been made on complaints against it.

DETROIT, July 8 (AP) -- The nation's auto makers maintained a high level of production this week, despite the Independence Day holiday and heat-inspired work stoppages, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

Employes of the American Bosch Arma Corporation, Roosevelt Field, Mineola, L. I., gave 278 pints of blood on Thursday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. On Wednesday, they had given 243 pints.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged at 110 per cent of the 1947-49 average in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the U. S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. Lower average prices for farm products were balanced by a rise in the index for processed foods, led by higher prices for meats.
The steel in the abandoned Third Avenue Elevated turned to gold -- $330,665 worth of it -- for the city yesterday.
PARIS, July 8 -- The Kingdom of Laos charged tonight that Communist forces had defied the year-old Geneva truce and attacked positions held by Laotian troops.
Indigestion in the market for state and local Government bonds is a major concern of the underwriting community.
ANAHEIM, Calif., July 8 -- The final fantastic touches are being put on Disneyland.
LONDON, July 8 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India arrived in London this evening for talks with British leaders on the East-West conference in Geneva this month.

Charity was not enough, decided the late William R. George in the Eighteen Nineties, after he had taken a number of underprivileged, maladjusted slum children to the country for the summer. From this beginning grew the George "Junior Republic" at Freeville, N. Y., near Ithaca, with its two cardinal principles: "Nothing Without Labor" and "Self-Government."
WATERTOWN, N. Y., July 8 (AP) -- An estimated 16,800 National Guardsmen and Army Reservists move into Camp Drum this week-end for the second two-week period of summer maneuvers.
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 8 -- The three-day meeting of the military advisers of the Southeast Asia Collective Defense Treaty ended here today.

Davy Crockett, who of late has been somewhat ubiquitous, thundered down the West Side trail yesterday and shot a bear on West Sixtieth Street. Of course it was all make-believe, through the courtesy of the Police Athletic League.
The Longines - Wittnauer Watch Company, Inc., a leading producer of high-quality watches, completed its fiscal year on March 31 in a strong financial position.

Motorists who used the 165-mile Garden State Parkway on the recent holiday week-end experienced conditions that usually beset pioneers. As on other superhighways in or near the metropolitan area, traffic was jammed and delays were, to state it mildly, annoying.
PARIS, Saturday, July 9 -- The French National Assembly approved Tunisian home rule early today by a vote of 540 to 43.
PEORIA, Ill., July 8 -- Ownership of the Toledo, Peoria and Western Railroad will be shared equally by the Santa Fe Railway and the Pennsylvania Railroad, it was announced today.

BUENOS AIRES, July 8 -- The Ministries of Navy and Air announced late last night the dismissal of 106 officers. The officers were described as leaders in the revolt against the Peron Government June 16.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 8 (AP) -- Peter Thomson of Australia won the British Open golf championship today with a seventy-two-hole score of 281. He thus became the fifth golfer since 1900 to capture the title two years in succession.
PARIS, July 8 -- The Soviet Union revealed plans today for a major expedition to cross about 1,600 miles of unknown terrain in the heart of Antarctica and establish three bases.

A plot at 310 to 320 East Seventy-first Street has been assembled for a syndicate controlled by Max Steinberg for development with an apartment building. The sellers were the Engel estate, represented by Joseph Kleiner, attorney, and Levine, Amsterdam Oxenham, represented by Albert Levine, attorney.
Some issues that do not regularly make the headlines remain on the list of "unfinished business" at this session of Congress.
CHICAGO, July 8 -- Wheat futures continued to show a steady undertone today. Local buying caused rallies at times. Other grains tended to be easier and soybeans declined.

ROME, July 8 -- During almost a decade the Italian political scene has shown a certain resemblance to world geography of the Ice Age. Extending from opposite poles two huge glaciers have embraced much of the body politic. And now, as they commence to withdraw gradually from the central spaces, there is to be noted a straining and cracking.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 8 -- New York City's Chief Magisrate, John M. Murtagh, made known here today plans for reorganizing the city's Adolescent Court system this fall.
