GENEVA, July 8 -- The Soviet Union will resume active participation in the World Health Organization and will become a member of the International Bureau of Education.
HARTFORD, July 8 -- Connecticut legislators may not get those free rides on the state's toll facilities that they voted themselves, after all.

Negotiations between the shipbuilding division of the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., opened yesterday in accordance with a wage reopening clause in the present two-year agreement.
LONDON, July 8 (UP) -- Pravda, Soviet Communist party newspaper, advised Soviet scientists today to quit bumbling and copy some capitalist ideas.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 8 -- Roy J. Goldenberg took the witness stand to deny today that he offered as authentic five paintings that allegedly are fake French masterpieces.
Rare campaign maps used by the Marshal de Rochambeau in charting France's contribution to victory in the American Revolution have been returned to this country.
Three armed men robbed a contracting company official of a $4,585 payroll yesterday. The money was intended for steam-fitters at a housing project under construction in Queens.

A burglary suspect who, the police said, tried to get too much mileage out of his loot, was returned here yesterday from Florida. He was charged with stealing a plane ticket and $4,000 in jewelry from an apartment here and then using the ticket to fly to Miami.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 8 (UP) -- Violence flared in the third and fourth innings of an International League game between Toronto and Columbus tonight. It sent Toronto's manager, Nick Cullop, and Spook Jacobs off the field and Toronto's first baseman, Lou Limmer, to the hospital.

BIRMINGHAM, England, July 8 (UP) -- Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., defeated Abe Segal of South Africa, 6 -- 4, 13 -- 11, today and reached the final of the Midland Counties lawn tennis singles tournament.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 8 -- Yugoslavia would "consider" an invitation to join the Council of Europe if it were extended, the government's spokesman declared today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 8 -- "Porgy and Bess" had its premiere at the Municipal Theatre last night. Brazil thus had the privilege of being the first country in South America to see the George Gershwin-Du Bose Hayward-Ira Gershwin operetta on its current tour.
VICTORIA, B. C., July 8 (AP) -- Bert Thomas, 29-year-old former frogman with the United States Marines, became the first swimmer to conquer icy Juan de Fuca Strait.
ATLANTA, July 8 (UP) -- Georgia threatened today to close the State University Law School to preserve racial segregation in defiance of Supreme Court decrees.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- With much of the nation in the midst of a sizzling heat wave, the House Ways and Means Committee voted today to cut taxes on air conditioners and coal.

LONDON, July 8 -- Industrial shares closed the week firm after reacting slightly to the fall on Wall Street. The Financial Times index for industrial shares was 220.4, compared with yesterday's record high of 220.6.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Army launched a new training program today for warfare in the atomic age that calls for maneuvers from Louisiana to Alaska.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The State Department urged today the passage of a bill to permit American citizens to settle claims against five nations from foreign assets frozen by this Government. The countries are Russia, Italy, Bulgaria, Rumania and Hungary.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 8 -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem's personal envoy to France, Nguyen Huu Chau, returned from Paris today with an optimistic attitude on future French-Vietnamese relations.
HONG KONG, July 8 -- Ho Chi Minh, the Vietminh leader, arrived in Ulan Bator, capital of Outer Mongolia, by plane from Peiping this morning, according to Hsinhua (New China) News Agency.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and closed 4 points higher to 11 points (55 cents a bale) lower. The March contract, with its 20 cents a bale rise, was the only month to advance.
DETROIT, July 8 (AP) -- The General Motors Corporation reported today its car divisions had sold a record total of 1,947,906 new and 2,510,980 used autos in the first six months of 1955.

TOKYO, June 29 -- Training of Asian technicians under the United States foreign aid program is now being concentrated in Japan. Experts have found that facilities in the United States are often too far advanced for quick application in Asian countries, whereas conditions in Japan are more like those the trainees must face when they go home.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee, after a quick and brief investigation, voted unanimously today to seek new curbs on the peacetime employment of "dollar-a-year" men in the Government.
Yesterday was one of those days that give meaning to the saying: "It isn't the heat; it's the humidity."
If firecrackers cannot be legally sold in New York City they are obviously sold illegally or brought in from other states.

DUBLIN, July 8 (UP) -- Bob Howe of Australia beat George Druliner of Los Angeles 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2, today in the Irish open lawn tennis singles championship. Howe will meet Hugh Stewart of San Marino, Calif., in the final tomorrow.
PELHAM, N. Y., July 8 -- A dozen sailing yachts started toward Block Island tonight as the forerunner of the New York Athletic Club's annual regatta eastward on Long Island Sound.
Assistant Fire Marshal Irving Rothenberg pleaded guilty yesterday to six departmental charges based on his outside activities as a fire insurance salesman.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Rain and the Yankees -- or vice versa -- resulted in the Senators' fifteenth shutout of the season tonight. The league-leading Bombers were credited with a 3 -- 0 victory over Manager Chuck Dressen's Nats after a downpour in the seventh inning had caused a wait of 1 hour 15 minutes.
THE big bluefin tuna have arrived in Nova Scotia waters, and there is reason to believe that a few fish are now swimming around in the waters at the eastern end of Long Island Sound.

CINCINNATI, July 8 (AP) -- The Wimbledon champion, Tony Trabert, who had not lost a set since the French championships early last month, lost a set today and came close to defeat in the quarter-finals of the Western Tri-state Tennis tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 8 -- In a rare show of hospitality, the Soviet delegation to the United Nations flung wide its doors yesterday to a group of curious teen-agers, eager to learn more about the Russians.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A "fairly big" meeting that the Administration failed to mention in its report on events leading up to the Dixon-Yates power contract was revealed today.

ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., July 8 -- A New York City Negro judge declared today here that real progress in desegregation in public schools had been made in some areas, notably Baltimore and Washington, and in Kentucky, Oklahoma and New Mexico.

An easy automobile drive to the hither reaches of Long Island is Jones Beach. For more than a quarter of a century a mecca for New York pleasure-seekers, this popular seaside playground, now in its twenty-sixth year of operation, promises in 1955 to be more popular than ever.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today issued temporary rules to speed the movement of empty freight cars to help overcome an "acute" freight car shortage.

Futures were generally lower yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Rubber, wool, cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, potatoes, hides, lead and tin declined; coffee was higher and sugar and copper moved mixed.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 8 -- A new general strike, without time limit, threatens Chile unless a solution for labor's financial demands is found within ten days.

At this season of the year, when people go on vacation and the sun shines at its warmest, the cows give more milk and the dairy industry puts on a big promotion to dispose of it. Helping in this drive is a new branch of the industry that has sprung up in the last few years -- selling milk by automatic vendors at times and in places where stores are closed or non-existent.

HONG KONG, July 8 -- The Peiping Government announced a delay this morning in the scheduled exit from Communist China of the three former United States soldiers who changed their minds about living under communism.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- Brig. Gen. W. W. White is within his rights in drawing pay from an oil company of which he was vice president before his recall to active duty, Representative F. Edward Hebert, Democrat of Louisiana said today.

The organization of a real estate investment combine with the purchasing power of more than $250,000,000 has been announced by Louis Sachar, president of the Marshall Management Corporation, real estate investment concern of 244 Madison Avenue.
CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- An American Medical Association committee says aspirin and other salicylate compounds should bear a warning: "keep out of the reach of children."
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Allen Whitfield, Des Moines lawyer and Republican leader, asked President Eisenhower today to withdraw his nomination as a member of the Atomic Energy Commission.
CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- Department of of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
OTTAWA, July 8 -- Canada and the United States advanced plans today for Civil Defense on a continental basis.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Two Supreme Court Justices in turn today denied a stay of execution for three men in the death house at Sing Sing, N. Y. Defense attorneys then indicated they had given up.

There is nothing so rare as a day in July when a baby king cobra slits its eggshell with an eye tooth and pokes its head out into a world of bright lights and grinding cameras. That is what happened yesterday at the Bronx Zoo.

Arrangements are being made for the annual bridge party for the benefit of the Willoughby House Settlement at 228 York Street, Brooklyn. Mrs. Harold L. Ostergren, benefit committee chairman, has announced that it will take place in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, on Nov. 15. Mrs. Olney M. Raymond will assist her as vice chairman.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Former Judge Willam Clark of Princeton, N. J., accused the State Department today of treating him shabbily.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Civilian employment reached 64,000,000 for the first time in history during June.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., July 8 (UP) -- The Indiana Bar Association will investigate the case of Mrs. Charles Evans, who spent seven hours in jail because she owed $3.70 in school book rental for one of her children.
The contract recently signed by Argentine President Peron and the Standard Oil Company of California, reported in The Times of June 12, is worth some comment.

Don Zimmer was holding gleeful court in the Dodger dressing room at the Polo Grounds last night. At least half a dozen newspaper men were gathered around the Brooks' hitting, base-running and fielding hero of the 12-8 victory over the Giants.
BAASTAD, Sweden, July 8 (UP) -- Mervyn Rose of Australia and Ham Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., scored semi-final triumphs in the international tennis tournament today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 8 (AP) -- Governor General Ghulam Mohammed today ordered tribal areas along the Afghan frontier in Pakistan merged with Pakistan's North-West Frontier Province.

WOODMERE, L. I., July 9 -- Two men were being questioned here early today by investigators of the Federal Communications Commission in connection with the false report of the sinking of the fishing boat Blue Star near Ambrose Lightship.

The twelve-story loft building at 148 Lafayette Street has been sold by Samuel Derfner Sons to the Mac Post Building, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Post Manufacturing Company, Inc. The buyer intends to occupy a number of floors for its own use.

Sam Bereson, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the four-story apartment building at 1569 Prospect Place in Brooklyn from Prospect Estates, Inc. The property, on plot 147 by 120 feet, contains fifty-eight apartments and is assessed at $140,000.
TOKYO, July 8 (AP) -- The world featherweight champion, Sandy Saddler of the United States, scored a technical knockout over Shigeji Kaneko of Japan in their ten-round non-title fight last night.
Comment appears appropriate on two letters published in recent issues of The Times.

July seems to be the Month of the Overnight Hike, a highly interesting operation, as one views a youthful hiker's departure and his return. One supposes, off-hand, the Overnight Hike seems to be especially popular in July because July is traditionally a month of flowers, sunshine and clear nights.
Two State Liquor Authority investigators complied yesterday with a State Supreme Court order to supply information about their finances or face arrest.
The city sold 203 vacant parcels in the Bronx and Brooklyn yesterday for a total of $1,387,825. This was $535,890 above the upset, or minimum price, of $851,935.
NAIROBI, Kenya, June 18 -- Only a few strands of barbed wire separate the lions from the people in Nairobi.
The Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies urged the city this week to expand foster home service for infants. The Department of Welfare said the service would be increased at once.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8 -- Success of the Screen Actors Guild bid to increase the scale of additional payments to performers for the re-use of film television shows may be determined by a small percentage of the union's 8,000 members.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Small Business Administration had dismissed Clarence C. Clarke, the former investigator whose complaints touched off a Senate investigation of the agency's security program.

A new edition of the works of Samuel Johnson, of about fifteen volumes, is planned by Yale University Press. The work will include writings identified during the last twenty-five years as Dr. Johnson's and not printed in any previous collection of his works.

The Wall Street rumor mart has been working overtime of late, predicting stock splits. In many cases, the talk would appear to be based more on guess-work than on facts. Nevertheless, market operators are aware that fifty-one splits have already been effected or announced this year in New York Stock Exchange issues.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 -- The Pacific Gas and Electric Company is planning to import an additional 225,000,000 cubic feet of natural gas a day into California. It has applied to the California Public Utilities Commission for authorization to add 189.8 miles of pipeline at a cost of $24,000,000 to bring more gas from Texas and New Mexico into its fast-growing consumer area.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The House Appropriations Committee expressed Congressional anger today at the Defense Department for its handling of military foreign aid funds.
BOSTON, July 8 (UP) -- A state-wide police search was ordered today for 4-year-old Hildy McCoy, central figure in a case involving adoption of a Roman Catholic child by a Jewish couple.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Public Health Service set up new research and plant inspection programs today in moves to improve the Salk poliomyelitis vaccine and further to assure its safety.
Foremost Dairies, Inc., disclosed in Jacksonville, Fla., yesterday plans to retire several services of preferred stock through rationale of debentures.
Former President Herbert Hoover declared yesterday that "an endurable peace for years to come" could result from the forthcoming Geneva Conference.

ROME, July 8 -- Indian Prime Minister Nehru had an audience with Pope Pius XII today. Before leaving for London he disclosed in a press conference that the question of Goa, the Portuguese enclave in India, was "briefly mentioned" in his talk with the Pope.
Prospective jurors in the city must now pass a loyalty test.

JAMESTOWN, N. Y., July 8 (AP) -- Bobby Hill of Rochester gained the semi-finals of the thirty-third New York State amateur golf tournament today. He defeated Lyn Wilson of Buffalo in the quarter-finals, 5 and 4.
CHICAGO, July 8 -- Harold E. Stassen, Special Assistant to the President on Disarmament, denounced Adlai E. Stevenson today.
THE story of a group of French refugees who fled to America at the time of the French Revolution will be dramatized in a new pageant to be presented outdoors near Towanda, Pa., on Aug. 18, 19 and 20.

THIS two-fisted novel purports to take the hide off the unethical practitioners in the used-car business. It may be likened in some quarters to the job Frederic Wakeman once did on the high-pressure tactics of radio and advertising.

EACH summer thousands of vacationing Americans turn their backs on the hedged-in luxury of resort life, and for the first time seek the free and easy pleasures of camping. Naturally, one of the first questions they ask is, "How and what do campers cook?"
WASHINGTON, July 9--Congress has discovered that it can legislate control over almost everything but its own work load.
DES MOINES, July 9--Iowa and the rest of the upper Midwest will be in fullest bloom next Sunday when a Russian farm delegation arrives in Des Moines.

THE late man-about-resorts, Alexander Phillips, bemoaning the decline of moneyed society in the United States, once complained: "The '400' has been marked down to $3.98." Now the Internal Revenue Service has come along with a further markdown-- to 148.

HONG KONG, July 9--An intensified campaign against alleged "counter-revolutionaries," "spies," "economic saboteurs," "habitual criminals" and "delinquents" has been developing for some time in Communist China.

IF plants and flowers have not been properly staked, one heavy storm or a brief thundershower can take a heavy toll. This is especially true of tall plants like delphinium, in particular the Pacific Hybrids, and dahlias and plants like peonies or double petunias with heavy flowers.
PORTLAND, Ore., July 9 -- A confused political situation on the Klamath Indian Reservation was eased considerably last week.

Work is being speeded on the Brevoort apartment building on the east side of Fifth Avenue between Eighth and Ninth Streets. Myron Minskoff, vice president of Sam Minskoff Sons, Inc., owner-builders, said completion is now scheduled for the last week in August.

WASHINGTON, July 9--Visitors to the capital found something new here this week. Thousands of automobiles were parked astride the street car tracks in downtown Washington. Traffic problems were monumental. A bus and trolley strike was the cause of it all.
OSSINING, N.Y., July 9-- Three men convicted of the murder of a Reader's Digest truck helper in a 1950 hold-up were executed tonight in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison.

FESTIVAL is a much-abused word. Not all of the musical undertakings that use it here and abroad have a right to it. But there is no law to prevent an ambitious committee from dressing up its venture with this attractive appellation.

Built-in air-conditioning is seen as a major factor in new apartment renting, according to A.L. Simon, the president of Simon Brothers, builders. He said the installation of air-conditioning facilities now is rated by prospective tenants on a par with neighborhood character, room size, apartment layout and building services.
A Fifth Avenue bus went out of control last night at Broadway and West 168th Street, jumping a curb and killing a man and a woman. Five other persons on the sidewalk were treated for shock.
MOSCOW. SIBERIA. The very name has a sinister sound. The word is as cold as the latitudes in which the land itself lies. The thought of it chills men's minds.
PARIS--Under French legislation public roads are made for moving traffic not for parking cars, but in April of this year 25,000 Parisians were fined for illegal parking.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)-- The head of the Justic Department's year-old internal security division today reported that "major strides" had been made in the fight against subversioin in the first six months of 1955.

AMSTERDAM--The parking problems in the Netherlands are serious and are expected to become more serious. The automobile density at three per 100 inhabitants is very low compared with many other countries and will in the near future rise substantially, probably to some seven or eight per 100 inhabitants by 1970.

WITH the unveiling during the last fortnight of "Not As a Stranger" at the Capitol and "The Shrike" at the Victoria, the uncontrollable wheel of film fortune came up with two dramas that dealt with aspects of medicine and, even more important, its impact on the weak and the strong.

Prices of fine antiques continued to rise in the recent auction season, according to William H. O'Reilly, president of the Plaza Art Galleries. He predicted that with public institutions receiving large quantities of fine objects, the resulting scarcity at sales will raise prices further.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 9 (UP)--Paul W. White, founder of the Columbia Broadcasting System's news bureau and news director of KFMB-TV, San Diego, died at his home today after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

THE friendly Soviet attitude toward Zea Mays, a distinctly American invention of some 2,000 years ago, is more than a genial manifestation of the new look in Communist international relations. Zea Mays is botanical for corn, and in the past year a substantial segment of Soviet agriculture has been switched to growing it.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UP)-- Representative Jere Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, will introduce next week a bill that would levy more than $1,500,000,000 a year in higher taxes on employers and 55,000,000 holders of jobs.

IN the spring of 1954 death touched Justice Jackson on the sleeve, giving him certain notice that the time ahead was brief. Quietly he resolved to render an account of his constitutional faith, which it was hoped he would deliver at Harvard as the 1955 Godkin lectures.
Jim Hearn, the Giants' big right-hander who has had a checkered baseball career, performed strictly on the up beat at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Prelude to Geneva A kind of international "dialogue" took place last week between the President of the United States, speaking in Washington, and the Communist boss of Russia, Nikita S. Khrushchev, speaking in Moscow.

TO THE EDITOR: Robert L. Lamborn's article, "Must They Be 'Crazy, Mixedup Kids'?" (June 26) speaks wisely in holding that "there are serious defects in an approach that assumes that the way to make someone better is to show him continuously how bad he can be."

Two sharply different evaluations of Russia's current position were given last week. Secretary of State Dulles was revealed to have told Congress that the Soviet system "is on the point of collapsing," a statement later modified by the White House.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 9 --At the end of the first six months of 1955, home building and public improvements are under way at a record high level in this metropolitan area.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 9 -- In a Mbulu village, Iraqw tribesmen gathered one September day for a look and a hand-shake with a surprise visitor to that remote corner of northern Tanganyika.
This country's current surge of prosperity has been vigorously duplicated in its foreign trade.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 9--With the Big Four conference a little more than a week away, the activities of certain non-participants have attracted attention.
The shipping industry and some members of Congress are organizing another fight to retain the right of United Statesflag ships to carry half of all foreign-aid cargoes.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Jan Karszo-Siedlewski, former Polish diplomat, died yesterday at the National Institutes of Health Clinical Center. He was 63 years old.

State and municipal longterm financing during June totaled $623,059,039, compared with $854,717,712 for June, 1954, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. For the first six months of this year the total of such financing was $2,810,480,509, about 25 per cent less than the financing for the first half of 1954.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 5 -- More governments pledged a greater total of contributions to the United Nations' technical assistance program in 1954 than ever before.

HOLLYWOOD. WARNER BROTHERS television operation now is in full swing. The studio's series of thirty-nine hourlength shows, divided into three story categories, each with thirteen self-contained episodes, is being turned out at the rate of one completed show a week.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is heartening to learn that the Senate has voted approval of a bill to create a nonpartisan commission to revamp the loyalty and security program despite the negative attitude of President Eisenhower and Attorney General Brownell.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 7-- The state officials charged with leasing California's offshore lands for oil exploration and development are looking forward to busy times.

Paul S. Tenen, an attorney with the American Law Institute, died Friday in Bispebjerg Hospital, Copenhagen, Denmark, of injuries received in an automobile accident in Copenhagen, according to word received by relatives here. His age was 29.
It was a case of mutual admiration between U Nu and New York City last week. The Prime Minister of Burma, in the United States on an official visit, arrived here Sunday for four days.
Many a woman today may envy her fur coat. While she suffers through the hot weather, the coat that kept her warm all winter is spending the season in cold storage.

The Port of New York and its extensive system of waterways in 1953 carried 50,538,382 net tons of inland waterway freight, according to a tabulation made public yesterday by the American Waterways Operators, Inc.
Stamp Tax History Addison's Spectator No. 445 of August, 1712, sounded a note of doom. "This is the day," said the Spectator, "on which many eminent Authors will probably publish their Last Words.
SYRACUSE, July 9--Policemen and prosecutors must try to prevent crime as well as punish it, some of them agreed today.
LONDON, July 9--Nine eminent scientists, including the late Albert Einstein, have appealed to the nations to forswear war because the hydrogen bomb threatens "the continued existence of mankind."

BRUSSELS--Like most other countries, Belgium has a parking problem, but the situation is well within manageable limits. Moreover, on instructions from the city authorities, motorists from abroad have priority right to the large free parking space in front of Brussels' magnificent medieval City Hall, which is itself a tourist attraction and is centrally situated.

Today, according to the Weather Bureau, will be hot and humid again, but tomorrow-- A cooler air mass from Canada is pushing eastward from the Northern Plains, the upper Mississippi Valley and the western Great Lakes, where it was centered yesterday.

MR. BAKER'S new novel is crowded with sharp observations of our time. Husbands like pretty girls, he tells us. Business men like pretty secretaries and dislike trade union leaders. Almost everyone (he reminds us) follows the mirage of a beautiful life and beautiful people.

A CONTROVERSIAL occupant of San Quentin's condemned men's wing. Caryl Chessman built up a tremendous reader-audience with his provocative best-selling book, "Cell 2455, Death Row." Seldom more than a legal inch away from the lethal gas chamber during seven harrowing years, Chessman has written a blistering sequel in "Trial by Ordeal," a far more disciplined example of objective writing.

The French National Assembly has acted in a vigorous and statesmanlike way in approving, by an overwhelming vote, the conventions that will establish home rule for Tunisia, M. Mendes-France was defeated and taken out of the premiership ostensibly on this issue, but he has now been vindicated.

WASHINGTON, July 9--Carter L. Burgess, Assistant Secretary of Defense, voiced doubt today that a voluntary Reserve training program, even with cash bonus inducements, would insure the type and size of reserves needed for national defense.

More than two months have passed since President Eisenhower made his dramatic proposal for "an atomic-powered merchant ship" as part of the "program for peaceful uses of atomic energy." With next month's Geneva conference on the peaceful uses of the atom coming up, the proposal is more than ever pertinent.
A record $700,000,000 is being spent this year on churches going up throughout the country and wood is being used in many of them to preserve traditional effects in contemporary architecture.
HAMBURG, Germany, July 9 (AP)--The University of Pennsylvania eight-oared crew defeated one English and two German shells in the first day of Hamburg's international rowing regatta today.

WASHINGTON, July 9--Following is the text of the conclusions and recommendations of a report on the Tennessee Valley Authority compiled by Adolphe Wenzell during 1953 as a consultant to the Bureau of the Budget:
HOLLYWOOD. THE stepped-up production pace that has marked the first half of the year for the nine Hollywood producing studios is expected to become even faster in the month's ahead.

CONCRETE is familiar to everyone as a finished product, but to many people the idea of mixing it and using it properly is forbidding. Actually, it is easy to handle for simple purposes and susceptible of shaping, by means of homemade forms, for curved sidewalks, free-form swimming pools, goldfish ponds and flower boxes.

HOME owners with "twoby-four" garden plots are scheduled to benefit from the work of daylily hybridizers. Thanks to the dwarf and midget varieties, it is no longer necessary to devote half a flower bed to one clump of daylilies that will grow four feet tall and throw the entire garden scheme out of scale.

To THE EDITOR: Alfred Harbage's piece about Calvin Hoffman's book, "The Murder of the Man Who Was Shakespeare," is not so much a review as a fulmination against all unbelievers.* * * The antiStratfordians, after demonstrating conclusively the case against him, nominated many candidates for the vacancy.

THIS is the first of a planned series of regional guides to the United States, to be known as "Golden Regional Guides." Few projects could have a more auspicious beginning The book is delightful throughout and a bargain.
WHEN Josephine McCarthy was a little girl she used to make unusual mud pies, using grains of rice and coffee beans to provide decorative touches.

CHICAGO, July 9--President Eisenhower's plea for Congressional action at this session on his education program and Adlai E. Stevenson's sharp attack on that program focused new attention this week on the question of Federal aid to education.
WHETHER a television showing of a play or film increases or decreases the production's box-office receipts is a question under debate in entertainment circles.

SALT LAKE CITY--Motorists vacationing in the mountain and desert regions of the West this summer will find highways to major resort areas in unusually good condition and remarkably free of tedious detours.

STRASBOURG, France, July 9 (AP)--An extraordinary luncheon meeting of French Cabinet ministers with Ales Bebler, Yugoslav envoy to France, today oiled the hinges of the Council of Europe for Belgrade's entry into Western European organizations.

It is accepted that the meat of animals that have been exposed to gamma rays, which always accompany the explosion of an atomic bomb, is not a fit food. Hence the fish that were irradiated by fallout on the Japanese boat Fortunate Dragon that happened to be within eighty miles of Bikini after the big hydrogen-bomb explosion of March 1, 1954, were thrown away.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Captivity has proved too much for the five emperor penguins at the National Zoological Park here. All have died of a fungus infection.

IN some sort of defiant gesture, and in sharp contrast to the conservative activities of most other leading record companies, Columbia has devoted its entire June list to that debatable commodity known as "modern music."
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)-- The White House announced today that Everett Frederic Morrow, a Negro, had been named to a top job in President Eisenhower's executive office.
WASHINGTON, July 9--President Eisenhower will address the nation Friday night two hours before he leaves for the Big Four conference in Geneva.

TECHNIQUE and content in photography are parts of a whole, according to Lloyd E. Varden, and any attempt to separate the two defeats the goals of worthwhile photographic effort. Mr. Varden, a leading technical consultant who has been long concerned with this problem, is an associate professor of graphics in the Engineering School at Columbia University.

MILWAUKEE, July 9 (AP)-- Early Wynn, Cleveland's powerful right-hander, and Brooklyn's Don Newcombe, who also throws from the right side, appear to be the likely choices to gain the starting assignments in the twenty-second annual major league All-Star game here Tuesday.
Harold Reade Barnes and his wife, Lillian, departed Friday for a vacation in Maine. Tucked away in the woods some seventyfive miles northwest of Portland, they will relax for a month.

LOW-PRICED sanders are making hand sanding large surfaces a thing of the past. A line of three sizes of small, electric back-andforth sanders has just been announced. Model 404 delivers 14,400 strokes per minute with a straightline action that permits rapid cross-grain cutting, or fine with-the-grain finishing.

ST. PAUL, July 9--Jerry Barber of Log Angeles clung to his St. Paul open golf tournament lead today. Tommy Bolt of Chattanooga moved into the runner-up spot and Arnold Palmer of Latrobe, Pa., fell to third at the 54-hole mark.

The stock market, propelled chiefly by the General Motors announcement of plans for a 3-for-1 stock split, soared to new highs early last week. Favored issues scored sharp gains. Then a downtrend developed under heavy profit-taking and the market showed a tiny loss for the week.

CUCUMBERS on a trellis? Why not? Space is at a premium in many home gardens and the trellis method, according to my figures, means at least four times as many fruits from a given soil area as does the conventional method of permitting the vines to run over the ground.

ROME, July 9--An American missionary received today a tenday suspended sentence and was fined 3,000 lire ($14.83). Cline R. Paden of Springfield, Tex., was found guilty of putting a sign in front of his church without police permission.

MEXICO CITY, July 9 (AP)-- Adolfo de la Huerta, Provisional President of Mexico in 1920, died today of a heart ailment. He was 72 years old. He was a former Governor of Sonora State and one-time Secretary of the Treasury.

CLEVELAND, July 9--Bituminous coal shipments from Lake Erie ports are staging a comback this season. Shipments up to July 1 ran more than 3,500,000 tons ahead of the corresponding 1954 period, according to the Ore and Coal Exchange.

BONN. THE Federal Republic of Germany, whose red-black-and-gold flag now flies at SHAPE headquarters in Paris, alongside the banners of fourteen other NATO nations, is (like Iceland) an ally without an army. As yet, not a single German tank, plane or uniformed soldier is at the disposal of SHAPE'S commander.

IN World War II John Gwyther was a young British naval officer. Passing below Torres Strait, through the narrow Endeavour Strait, discovered and named by Captain Cook, Gwyther noticed that most of the navigational instructions were those which Cook had supplied nearly two hundred years earlier.

BIRMINGHAM, England, July 9--Jaroslav Drobny of Egypt steadied his game in the final set today and made a successful defense of his men's singles title in the Midland Counties lawn tennis tournament. He defeated Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., 7--5, 4--6, 6--4.

Cornell University plans to expand its graduate division of extension education to help promote extension service abroad. The Ford Foundation has granted the university $500,000 for the special program, which will start this fall.

THE youngsters have been at camp just over a week. Mother and dad have been out to dinner three times visited friends twice and purchased four sets of theatre tickets for use in the next six weeks. This evening the quiet that pervades the half-empty house though long awaited, is suddenly no longer blissful.

CAIRO, July 9--Formal peace in the Middle East is still a long way off. But Egypt and Israel are closer to it now than at any time this year and possibly closer than they have been since the Arab-Israeli armistice was signed nearly six years ago.

Jim Hearn starred at bat and on the mound as the Giants routed the Dodgers, 10 to 2, at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The right-hander hit two home runs and a run-scoring single. In Washington, the Yankees shut out the Senators, 4 to 0, on Bob Turley's two-hitter.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 9-- A defense-studies program will be introduced by Harvard University next fall.

There was political logic in these statements last week by New York Democratic leaders. Mr. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall and national committeeman, runs the show in New York Democratic politics. If he could get the Presidential nomination for Mr. Harriman he would assume a leading role in national politics.

TOKYO, July 9--The rainy season in Japan is nearing an end. It has been a relatively dry one. In most Asian countries that would be bad. In Japan it may be good. That is, if the weather stays hot. The longrange forecast is that it will.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)-- The Government is planning to curb uranium penny stock deals.

OUR American Shakespeare Festival Theatre, which opens Tuesday with "Julius Caesar," is truly a people's theatre. Begun by a small band of enthusiasts, it has been built only as a result of the efforts of hundreds of theatre lovers.
Public awareness of the need for community support of education in large cities is increasing and paying dividends, the superintendents of schools in New York and Chicago said yesterday.
BOSTON, July 9 -- John C.S. Andrew, Professor Emeritus of Sociology and Economics at Boston University, died today in Roslindale General Hospital. He was 84 years old.

THE dividing line between science fiction and the suspense story is often hard to draw. Many science fiction writers have experimented with stories of pure detection in the future; and now appears a straight espionage thriller which ends with the successful launching of an armed satellite into an orbit around the earth on July 4, 1955.

Increased demands by large national furniture and food chains will require parking space at a ratio of ten to one at the new Gateway regional shopping center at Vails Gate in New Windsor, N.Y. The usual ratio is four or five to one.
HARTFORD, July 9--A statewide special election will be held July 26, but few persons in the state are interested.

IN comparison to the vast number of dog books, stories about cats occupy a minor place in juvenile literature. Nevertheless they have a devoted -- and demanding -- audience, one which ought to be gratified by the larger-thanusual assortment this season.

WHAT century--the nineteenth or twentieth? Although this novel is set in the Philippines during World War II, it bears a strong family resemblance to an earlier age when the good guys whipped the bad guys and brought justice to Cactus Gulch.

THE best poetry of every age is always unpredictable. Even as late as 1919 only the few were aware that the novelist Thomas Hardy was the author of many memorable short poems, and fewer still were able to predict the lyrical strength, the endurance of the elder Yeats.

Little by little the Argentine situation is beginning to clear up. There is much that we still do not know, but all signs point to a period of outward calm that will permit a breathing spell and that gives us a chance to look back and even to look a short distance ahead.
CHICAGO, July 9 (UP)--Judy Rullah, unbeaten 2-year-old daughter of Nasrullah, racked up her fourth straight triumph today with a stretch rally in the $96,505 Arlington Lassie.
FOR the first time since the inception of the West German Film Festival five years ago, a German picture has scored on its home field.

A consolidation of its processing department has been completed by the Northern New Jersey Mortgages Associates of Teaneck, N.J. This was made possible by the finishing of about 1,000 square feet of space in the basement of the two-story structure at 133 Cedar Lane.
NEW DELHI, July 9--For India, Jawharlal Nehru's triumphal European trip has been as gratifying an experience as it must have been for the Prime Minister.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 9-- The largest social event in many years took place here tonight when more than 700 guests attended the Breakers Ball. It marked a high spot of the 175th anniversary observance this week-end of the landing of Count de Rochambeau and the French fleet.

LONDON--Since Britain holds the world record for traffic density, the parking problem in London, Edinburgh, Manchester and all the larger cities of the United Kingdom has become of paramount importance.
MORRISTOWN, N.J. July 9 --A record score of 273 by Stan Mosel won the New Jersey Open golf championship today.
One of the least understood jobs in the stock market seems to be that of the specialist.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UP)-- The Federation of American Scientists congratulated the State Department today for finally granting a passport to a St. Louis radiobiologist.

HONG KONG, Sunday, July 10 (AP)--The three former United States soldiers who changed their minds about staying in Red China wore broad smiles and appeared in good condition and good spirits as they walked across the bridge over the Shum Chun River into Hong Kong.

TORONTO, July 9--Allan J. Rush, Mayor of London, Ont., from 1951 until March of this year, died today in the Southwestern Ontario city. He was 47 years old. Death was attributed to a virus liver infection.

ROBERT WHITNEY and the Louisville Orchestra have earned the gratitude of music-lovers for their liberality in handing out commissions for original works to contemporary composers. That the commissioned works have turned out to be somewhat uneven in quality is not the orchestra's fault; indeed it is in the nature of such an undertaking that only a few works will be outstanding, and most will be pretty bad.
DETROIT, July 9 (AP)--The Kansas City Athletics, blanked for seven innings by Frank Lary, scored two runs in the eighth inning today to defeat the Detroit Tigers, 2--1.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)-- Senator Russell lined up some
Competition among Brooklyn savings banks is providing many depositors in that community with the best return on their money in twenty-five years.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 9 --National Guardsmen and reservists from the New York City area began moving into Camp Drum today for two weeks of extensive training in the field.

Aside from the 2 1/2-1 1/2 victory of Samuel Reshevsky over Mikhail Botvinnik in the chess matches against Russia last week, the best showings for the United States were made by Larry Evans of New York and Isaac I. Kashdan of Los Angeles.
The fate of the International Coffee Bureau's plan to stabilize world coffee prices is in the hands of Brazil. At present those hands appear to be pointing thumbs down.
Some 3,000,000 "war babies" will shave proudly for the first time in a couple of years--and that will swell the coffers of the American Safety Razor Corporation.

PORT - OF - SPAIN, Trinidad, July 6 (Reuters)--With the impending birth of a new nation through the federation of the British West Indies, Trinidad and Barbados are advancing strong claims to house the Federal capital.
THE Realist "45," the lowcost version of the original Stereo Realist stereo camera, was made available to dealers last week, according to announcement by David White Company of Milwaukee, the makers.

JERUSALEM, July 9--A week ago Egyptian authorities were reported to be so bitter against Maj. Gen. E.L.M. Burns that they planned to ask for his replacement as chief of staff of the United Nations truce supervision organization.
PARIS, July 9--The head of the Government of Laos, Premier Katay Sahorith, said today that the local Communist attacks on Laotian forces were made possible by intervention from outside the country.
MOSCOW, July 9--From a study of the calendar it appears that the peoples of the world most frequently declare their independence or change their forms of government in the summertime.

TO characterize Midway as "the battle that doomed Japan" may seem to be overdoing it a little from the American point of view. The old Japan wrought her own doom by allowing herself to fall under the domination of a crassly blind military oligarchy which initiated an unnecessary war which she could never, by the wildest stretch of imagination, have won.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 9 (AP)--Billy Shields of Albany and Tommy Goodwin of Rye today advanced to the final of the thirty-third New York State Amateur golf tournament.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Neither you nor Walter Millis in his letter of July 3 appear to have hit to the heart of the military reserves plan.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 9--The King's College, Protestant and coeducational, will reopen this fall on a new campus--the former site of storied Briarcliff Lodge, a resort hotel that catered to the wealthy and famous for many seasons during the first half of this century.
HARRISBURG, Pa., July 9-- Truckers approaching Pennsylvania no longer face the invisible wall that had barred loads permitted in other states.

THE pageant of new daylilies has so far lived up to all advance predictions; this year it has been gayer and more inviting than ever. This is good news for gardeners, particularly those who seek longlasting perennials of high quality to enhance their gardens for years to come.

Three new vice presidents have been elected by Pease Elliman, Inc., to direct the realty brokerage company's expanded investment and commercial departments. They are William M. Lese, Robert I. Randall and Albert Sarnoff.
LONDON, June 27--The British have a half-pint-sized mechanical "cow" that they say turns grass and other vegetable matter into high-grade protein faster and more efficiently than any animal.

At Urbana-Champaign, Ill., Ambrose C. Richardson, Professor of Architecture in the University of Illinois, and Maj. George M. McCauley, who is taking his master's degree in architecture there, have built a dome three feet high and six feet in diameter.
BUENOS AIRES, July 9-- Catholic Action leaders took advantage of the 139th anniversary of Argentina's declaration of independence today to stage a demonstration.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 9-- Laotian Government troops struck back today at attacking Communist-supported Laotian forces in mountainous northern Laos. The Laotian Government said violent fighting had developed.

MOSCOW, July 9--Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin called tonight for frank talk at the Big Four heads-of-government conference that will begin July 18 in Geneva. Referring to subjects that might be on the conference agenda, he said the Soviet Union's views on the question of Germany's reunification would be made known "within the next few days."

AT Jacob's Pillow this week the little unit of dancers from the Royal Danish Ballet in Copenhagen will present its second program on Wednesday, Friday and Saturday evenings at 9 and Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons at 4.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., July 9--The United States Air Force Academy, symbol of a new age of power in the skies, opens Monday afternoon. The first class of the academy, 306 cadets from all over the nation, will be sworn in at the academy's temporary site at Lowry Air Force Base, Denver.

BERLIN--This city's traffic problem was "solved" for many years to come when Allied bombers rained destruction on it during World War II. The present isolation and economic stagnation of West Berlin have prevented any rebirth of the problem.

Scientists know a great deal about the diseases of agricultural animals and household pets, but they know little about the maladies of laboratory animals. This is true in spite of the fact that experimental animals are essential in the investigation of diseases such as cancer, heart disease and poliomyleitis.

SUMMER smote the country in earnest last week and produced standout business in two fields. Travel and resort volume boomed as vacationers took to the land, sea and air lanes. Stayat-homes stormed stores for room air conditioners to beat the heat.
Department store sales across the country in the week ended July 2 were 4 per cent above volume in the like week last year.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 9-- Misty Morn of the Wheatley Stable finished in first place in the $30,700 Molly Pitcher Handicap today, but the daughter of Princequillo had to survive an objection before her victory was official.

The suspicion is growing that top New York Democrats are trying to confuse next year's contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination. It is based chiefly on recent apparent contradictions in the positions taken by state leaders.

ROME. "THE SWINDLERS," one of those off-beat items that haunt press agents' nightmares with their unconventional, hard-to-publicize ingredients is, paradoxically, the most interesting picture now on the boards in Rome.
Four New Jersey communities made "perfect" scores in property tax collections in 1954.

PARIS, July 9--While experts of the three Western powers were drafting recommendations for a common policy for the Geneva talks, Premier Edgar Faure and Foreign Minister Antoine Pinay began today to weld together their ideas on France's own attitude.

GENEVA--As a tourist attraction, the forthcoming Big Four conference is not regarded by the Genevese as an unmixed blessing. To have the heads of government of the United States. Russia, France and Britain assemble in your town helps, to say the least, to put it on the map, as the saying goes.

BADEN-BADEN. THE International Society for Contemporary Music has made a remarkable recovery since its crisis three years ago. Each of its recent annual festivals has had a character of its own, even if we concede that only a few of the works actually performed at the festivals have been discoveries.
A housing development will replace a ten-acre site in the Rego Park section of Queens, formerly operated as a race track by the late Arnold Rothstein, New York gambler and real estate investor.

PARIS. RARELY has a Paris art season been as brilliant as this year and it is finishing in a blaze of glory with two exhibitions devoted to Picasso--that of fifty years of his painting at the Musce des Arts Decoratifs and that of his prints at the Bibliotheque Nationale.

LONDON, July 9--Following are the texts of a statement to the press by Bertrand Russell and of a statement on nuclear warfare signed by leading scientists (Albert Einstein signed just before his death): Russell Statement The accompanying statement, which has been signed by some of the most eminent scientific authorities in different parts of the world, deals with the perils of a nuclear war.

Eight Indonesians are undergoing training in the offices and other installations of the Isthmian Steamship Company. The object is to foster discussion and exchange of ideas and information relating to steamship practices.
SHORT rail trips out of New York at reduced rates are being offered by several railroads, and with the arrival of warm weather they are becoming increasingly popular.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A Congressional investigation of the extent to which the Business Advisory Council has influenced Government economic policies has begun.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 9-- Fifty-one yachts started tonight in the twenty-fourth Stratford Shoal race of the Riverside Yacht Club. The fleet was within a half dozen or so of being the largest ever.
HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 9 --Bill Tully of Yonkers and Ed Moylan of Trenton reached the final of the New York State singles championship at the County Tennis Club of Westchester today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UP)-- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, said today an atomic merchant ship some day would be built toy the United States, but it would not be President Eisenhower's "peace ship."
BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 9--A motor cruiser that was delivered only four days ago became the winner of the New York Athletic Club's fortysecond annual predicted-log race to Block Island tonight.

Twenty-four houses in ranch and split-level design are planned for a colony in Tenafly, N.J., which was formally opened yesterday with the display of a model home. Known as Blueberry Hill, the development is on Mackay Drive and Ivy Lane, west of Knickerbocker Road.
HARTFORD, July 9--The biennial Connecticut budget is only nine days old, but Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff already expects an $8,000,000 deficit when it expires on June 30, 1957.

ROME--The average Italian automobile is, by American standards, a midget, and only about every sixty-seventh Italian owns one. This figure disregards buses and trucks which are, conversely, king-size. But parking space is, in the center of this country's ancient cities, as precious as anywhere, especially during the tourist season.

If the State of New York is ever going to cut its mental health bill--it's now $160,000,000 or about one-third of the entire operating budget--research will be the answer, one expert predicted last week.

THESE are times that try men's tempers and pocketbooks. They try them in a number of ways, but the ones that came under discussion in a certain group last week-end centered on the topic: "things are not what they seem" or, "be sure you're right, then go ahead."

THE voluntary junking of motor vehicles rendered unsafe for operation through old age or other causes is a country-wide problem for which the National Automobile Dealers Association is seeking a solution. That organization is considering plans for disposing of these vehicles so as to put them out of circulation permanently.

Bees have been buzzing in the news of late--French bees that came from the Laboratoire d'Evolution des Etres Organisers of the University of Paris. Five thousand of them were flown over to the American Museum of Natural History in New York City on June 13.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 9 --European integration was spurred here today at a meeting of experts from the six countries of the European Coal and Steel Community. The community pools the coal and steel production of France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 9-- Chile's transport and communications strikes continued through their ninth day today while the Government and the unions wrangled over terms of a settlement.

THE Louisiana iris, denizen of muck bogs and cypress swamps, has become a garden aristocrat unsurpassed in grace and beauty. Because of its adaptability to a wide variety of growing conditions, this beardless iris flower now flourishes in lands far away from its native bayous.

The fact that the House Appropriations Committee has in apparent resentment at Defense Department procedure, suddenly started slashing at the foreign aid bill, already authorized in both houses, does not deny the validity of the foreign aid concept.

IN the opinion of a number of veteran observers of the stamps' world, many American philatelists, including some dealers as well as individual collectors, are not being altogether realistic about certain types of stamps that are issued periodically by the governments of the European satellites of the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UP)-- Thousands of would-be home buyers, flush in the 1955 business boom, will have to wait many extra weeks to move in.

SHOOTING is an American heritage and several thousand practitioners will assemble at Camp Perry, Ohio; next month to compete in the National Rifle and Pistol Matches. The program will be the most varied since the beginning of World War II.

Accommodations for about fifty-eight families are to be provided on a tract of fifty-eight acres in Huntington, L.I., which is being converted to a housing colony known as Wolf Hill Estates. The development is on Caledonia Road, about one-fourth of a mile north of Wolf Hill Road.

Children ask more questions about science than about any other subject, according to a nation-wide survey conducted by the University of Illinois. The survey covered 6,313 pupils in grades four through eight, 4,531 parents, 212 teachers and 169 librarians.

The American Cancer Society announces that Dr. Mary Alexander Fink of the University of Colorado's School of Medicine has vaccinated mice successfully against transplanted cancers which otherwise would have killed them. She finds that the animals produce antibodies against the tumors--a startling discovery.

IT is estimated that American bridge games account for some three billion deals each year, and in such a vast quantity almost nothing is improbable. Four or five times a year someone somewhere should hold all thirteen cards of a suit, not stacked by pranksters but honestly dealt.
NORFOLK, Va., July 9--Two veteran Marine Corps divers are preparing to prove they have located the sunken hull of the old Union iron-clad ship Monitor.

MILWAUKEE, July 9 (UP)-- Ray Crone pitched the fifth straight complete game for Milwaukee as the Braves defeated the Cincinnati Redlegs, 5--2, today. The triumph was the fifth in a row for the home club.
SO far the weatherman has been quite generous with rain. This sometimes means trouble for some plants, as many pests and diseases thrive in damp, sunless weather.

THE major summer art attraction in New York, which is the final even in the Museum of Modern Art twenty-fifth anniversary celebration, is proving to be one of the most successful exhibitions in the history of the museum.

At the last meeting of the American Geophysical Union Dr. Roger R. Revelle, director of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography (University of California), announced that in August, Canada, Japan and the United States will jointly conduct a great oceanographic survey of the North Pacific Ocean.

In an essay-review of Calvin Hoffman's "The Murder of the Man Who Was Shakespeare," Alfred Harbage discussed the controversy over the authorship of Shakespeare's works, and dismissed the claims of various candidates to be the "real" Shakespeare.

HOLLYWOOD. IF statistics mean anything, Hollywood is caught in the hypnotic spell of a major TV boom. The volume of film production for video is absolutely awesome; the facilities for doing live shows border on the fabulous, and overall range of television activity is somewhat breathtaking.

VIENNA--One of the symptoms of increasing prosperity in Austria has been increasing motorization. Vienna's registered motor vehicles, for instance, leaped from 98,000 last October to 115,000 this spring. This, plus an ever-increasing tourist traffic, is facing Vienna, Salzburg and Innsbruck, and the tourist who visits them by car, with the parking problem so familiar to the American motorist.

COLLEGE BOARD--Tests The College Entrance Examination Board has developed a program of twelve advanced placement tests which will enable colleges to grant advanced-course standing and credit to students admitted with superior high school training.

ST. LOUIS, July 9 (AP)--The St. Louis Cardinals rode into fifth place tonight on Stan Musial's grand-slam homer in the sixth inning and Tom Poholsky's six-hit pitching. The Redbirds defeated the Chicago Cubs, 4--2.

EVER since its founding fifteen years ago, the National Music Council has been active in promoting Government interest in music. Now it has taken a step that it hopes will improve its standing with the Government.

BONN, Germany, July 9--The question of preparing a successor to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, who will be 80 next Jan. 5, was raised today by the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, West Germany's leading newspaper.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Make succession sowings as soon as early spring planted vegetables such as peas, lettuce and beans, have been harvested. Sow a root crop such as carrots to replace the top crop such as peas. It soil is dry, soak the furrow with water after it has been opened but before seeds are sown.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)-- Six members of the House Interior and Insular Affairs Committee today attacked the upper Colorado River storage project as an "unwarranted and unconscionable" Federal subsidy to Colorado, Wyoming, Utah and New Mexico.
CAPE ELIZABETH, Me. THE Queen was in the parlor, smoking. Outside, her husband piloted a lawn mower with her 8-yearold daughter in his wake, as Bette Davis talked about "roots."
TO THE EDITOR: Mr. Lamborn's position is well taken. Extensive anthropological data suggest that what we regard as "typical" adolescence is primarily a function of our own anxietyridden society.

ALMOST everyone knows, and reveres, the great marble statue of Abraham Lincoln in the Lincoln Memorial in Washington. That shrine, second only to Mount Vernon in the vast numbers of visitors it attracts, symbolizes to the world our nation's capital perhaps as much as the White House itself.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 9 (AP) --Philip Scott won the $7,500 Flanders Pace by a length over Brooke's Honor tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Diamond Hal was third. The time for the mile and one-sixteenth race was 2:09.

ABOARD U.S.S. GRESHAM AT SEA July 9 (UP)--It was the time-honored West Coast rivalry all over again, San Francisco versus Los Angeles, in the transPacific yacht race to Honolulu today. Sailing yachts from those cities were staging a neck-andneck battle passing the halfway point.

PITTSBURGH, July 9 (UP)-- Robin Roberts, limping from a bruised left toe, breezed to his 150th major league triumph today. He hurled a three-hitter to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to a 7-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

FOR October, both The Literary Guild and the Book-ofthe-Month Club have chosen books whose authors have had corners on the clubs. The Literary Guild selection will be Thomas B. Costain's "The Tontine," the first two-volume edition ever selected by The Guild Mr. Costain becomes a four-time winner.

THAT new Arthur Laurents play "A Clearing in the Woods" will fly the joint pennant of Roger Stevens (or the Playwrights Company) and Oliver Smith. When it will sail into the mainstream called Broadway, however, is a matter still to be determined.

Home foreclosures continue at a low rate, according to J. Howard Edgerton, president of the United States Savings and Loan League. He said that in 1954, for the tenth consecutive year, the ratio of foreclosures to the number of new home mortgage recordings ran below 1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 9-- Among the Government offices that still lack the comfortable benefits of air-conditioning are those of the Weather Bureau, located in part in an old red brick building that housed horses back in the Eighteen-eighties.
When the late Frank A. Vanderlip decided in 1904 that the National City Bank should put out a small circular about Treasury securities, he little knew what he was starting.

WASHINGTON, July 9--Three of the four Yankees who have been honored with the All-Star designations showed why today, as if reasons were necessary. Bob Turley blanked the Senators with two hits, 4--0. Mickey Mantle clicked with a 5-for-5 performance at the plate and Yogi Berra, with a triple, homer and double, drove in all the runs.

Four hundred and ten cities throughout the country annexed about 325 square miles of land last year for public purposes. The acreage surpassed by nearly 16 per cent that absorbed in the two previous years.
TRENTON, July 9--New Jersey's Democratic legislative candidates have agreed on six major issues that they feel will carry them to victory in the fall elections.

EVERYONE has in his library a few books that he would not lend to anyone. They are the irreplaceable books that were issued for a small public and then went out of print. I have a score of such--strange works, some of them, and all redolent of the place and season when I first read them and the accumulated pleasure they have given me through the years.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UP)-- Hungry herds of deer are blocking efforts to reforest thousands of acres across the nation, an Agriculture Department expert says.
Jim Hearn paid a heavy price in poundage for his valiant labors on the pitching mound, in the batters' box and on the bases in the broiling heat at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

IS the A-bomb just another weapon of war? Will it take its place alongside the gladius, crossbow, bayonet and machine gun? Or will the bomb usher in a new age of weapon war? Will the foot soldier become obsolete?

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 9--Joint efforts by white and Negro home owners to effect orderly and peaceful integration of Negro families in previously allwhite residential neighborhoods have produced hopeful results, the New Rochelle Council for Unity announced today. A majority of the council's 300 members are white.

GENEVA. TALLEYRAND is alleged to have said, "There are five continents --Europe, Asia, Africa, America and Geneva." A true Genevese might be defined as a person who is incapable of ever getting the real point of that remark.

MASTIC BEACH, L.I., July 9--An unusual ground-breaking ceremony will take place here next Saturday. Several thousand local residents, each equipped with a spade, will break ground for the proposed Smith's Point bridge, which is expected to be ready in two years.

CROTCHED MOUNTAIN, N.H. To other children throughout the nation, Davy Crockett may be the "King of the Pioneers." Here in the mountains of rural southern New Hampshire, however, there are 200 handicapped children who should reserve this title for a citizen, Harry A. Gregg, whose Crockett-like courage, determination and vision have resulted in an unusual center in which these children have received rehabilitation.
CHICAGO, July 9--Big Connie Johnson struck out twelve and allowed six hits today as he hurled the Chicago White Sox to a 6-0 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

WHEN replacing screens in last year's frames, try stapling the mesh down, instead of using tacks. It's not only faster, but the job will be stronger, since staples spread the strain over a larger area than a tack, and will not pull through the mesh as easily.

THE whale is the largest creature that has ever existed on the face of the earth. The brachiosaurus, which was only a little more than half the size of the whale, has long since become extinct, presumably because it was simply too big.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 9 (AP)-- A bartender, a plasterer and a certified public accountant won the Harding Cup for Miami today. The trio took the city team competition, a preliminary to the United States Golf Association's public links championship next week.

The elderberry bushes are in bloom, and seeing them from the roadside one thinks that they deserve a better fate than to be regarded as weeds and grubbed out. Many a cherished lawn shrub isn't much prettier than an elderberry bush in full bloom.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 9--Rex C. Ellsworth's Swaps coasted to his eighth straight victory today to strengthen his claim as the top 3-year-old in the nation. He won the $57,750 Westerner at Hollywood Park by some half-dozen lengths.

VOLUME forty-nine of the Rivers of America series deals with a picturesque and beautiful stream in western North Carolina and east Tennessee. Rising and flowing among the oldest mountains in North America and the highest east of the Mississippi, it receives the waters of many picturesque tributaries, flows over Douglas Dam, and merges with the Holston to form the Tennessee River at Knoxville.

WASHINGTON, July 9--Some of the American turncoats of the Korean war are seeking now to walk the hard road back. As one of them has put it, he would rather hang in the United States than live in Communist China. Unless they collaborated with the enemy, or did something that harmed the welfare of their fellow American prisoners, they may face nothing more than the problem of trying to hold their heads high.

WASHINGTON, July 9--There are two principal reasons for the public indifference to the President's announcement that he would proclaim "martial law" in the United States if a comparable measure of the hypothetical damages inflicted by the "enemy" in Operation Alert should actually be visited on the nation in similar circumstances--Congress dispersed and a number of State Legislatures out of session.

SOMEWHAT quieter in tone, though certainly not in pace, than his "The Day of the Triffids" or "Out of the Deeps," John Wyndham's third novel will nevertheless exert an even more lasting effect on the imagination. Beginning with life on earth long after a total atomic war, Mr. Wyndham's story offers the conception that the posterity of nuclear madmen huddled on Labrador may well have evolved into extreme religious conservatives.
Three cities in the eastern part of the country have stepped up their drives to keep housing safe, sanitary and healthy.

DUBLIN, July 9--With more than 2,000 barmen on strike here, this will be a dry week-end in neighborhoods where all the saloons have closed. The Dublin bartenders sought a 25-shilling ($3.50) weekly increase in wages and more time off, but the saloon owners' highest offer was an increase of 12s 6d ($1.75), which was rejected.

THE latest in lilies will go on view this week at Boston's Horticultural Hall, when the North American Lily Society opens its Eighth Annual Lily Show and annual meeting there on Tuesday. Thousands of new varieties, some being shown for the first time, others already on the market but not familiar to enthusiasts, will be included in the exhibits.

A FEW summers ago a charming American student staying at a Swiss hotel was asked to dance by a young Italian. The language barrier impeded conversation but when the boy led her back to her table, he bowed and said haltingly: "Thank you for Marshall Plan."

OTTAWA, July 9 (Canadian Press)--A Royal Commission inquiry into Canada's coastal shipping trade is shaping up largely as a fight over restricting the operations of non-Canadian vessels in this 35,000,000-tons-ayear traffic.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Gov. Wiliam G. Stratton has flashed the go-ahead signal for the construction on Chicago's lakefront of what its sponsors predict will be the "world's greatest" exposition and convention hall center. The estimated cost of the project is $34,000,000.

NEW HOPE, Pa.--After nearly twenty years, the pleasures of excursioning in a mule-drawn barge are available once more along a few miles of the venerable and scenic Delaware Canal, which parallels the eastern border of Pennsylvania between Easton and Bristol.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Congressional foes of the DixonYates power contract declared today that what they termed the "improper" role of Adolphe H. Wenzell, the former investment banker, had been the vital straw that "broke the Administration's back."

GENEVA, July 10 (Reuters) -- Newspaper reporters and photographers today made their first visit to the lakeside villa where President Eisenhower will stay, under the guard of the "Swiss Navy," during the coming East-West conference here.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 10 -- President Eisenhower bowed his head in prayer today for the success of the Big Four conference. His son and grandson joined him. The President attended the service at the ivy-covered 215-year-old Gettysburg Presbyterian Church with his son, Maj. John Eisenhower, and his grandson, David, 7.

BOSTON, July 10 (AP) -- Faye Throneberry of the Boston Red Sox scored the tie-breaking run on a bases-filled walk to Jackie Jensen and Norm Zauchin followed with a two-run single in the eighth inning today for a 10-7 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

THE Museum of the City of New York has turned up a curious document about Braddock's defeat on the Monongahela, which happened just 200 years ago last Saturday. Albert K. Baragwanath, museum librarian, found it in a collection of papers that had belonged to the De Lanceys of New York.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- A former Atomic Energy Commission official said today that cheap nuclear power might be within reach in twelve years if early financial obstacles could be overcome.

A recent letter by Ethel H. Wise, vice president, board of directors, and chairman, executive committee, Youth House, makes note of the fact that Dr. Benjamin Fine's story of my visit to Youth House omitted to mention the educational program conducted at Public School 611 at that institution.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -"Colorless" is the adjective Washington pundits are fondest of applying to politicians like Senator Earle C. Clements, the Senate's acting majority leader.
Carelessness in smoking was responsible for more deaths in fires here last year than any other cause, according to the annual Fire Department report, issued today.
Fugitives from the heat and humidity made a mass turnabout at beaches and parks yesterday when thunderstorms brought a sudden -- and welcome -- break in the nine-day heat wave.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission alleged today a three-way conspiracy to fix prices in the Puget Sound salmon industry.

THE overwhelming decision of television and radio artists to condemn AWARE, Inc., is a forward steep in liberating the broadcasting industry from the influence of outside pressure groups. AWARE is the privately constituted organization that has been applying its own standards as to whether a performer is a Communist or Communist sympathizer.

HONG KONG, July 10 -- "Death is better than communism," according to three former United States soldiers who changed their minds about living in Communist China. The three, who came out of Communist China in the rain today, said many Chinese hated and feared the Red regime.

Sharply increased net earnings and sales for six months through May were reported yesterday by the Eagle-Picher Company. Eagle-Picher mines and smelts lead and zinc, and manufactures pigments, rubber goods, insulation, packaging materials and other products.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- State legislators this year found little to laugh at in some of the millions of comic books produced annually in the United States.
The state's new Democratic chairman said yesterday he aimed to "restore the two-party system" upstate.
MURREE, Pakistan, July 10 -- Hopes for a united Pakistan were set back today when East Pakistan's representatives in the National Assembly won their demand for regional autonomy.

The one-story industrial building at 36-41 Thirty-sixth Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Cellu-Craft Building Corporation, of which Sam Levy is president. The buyer is the Long Wear Stamper Corporation, manufacturer of recording equipment.
There is "a living church" in East Germany, the Rev. Christian R. Berg, director of relief work of the Evangelical Church in Berlin, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- There are those who insist any time a team like the Yankees loses to a team like the Senators it's an accident. If that is so, a horrible mishap befell the league-leading Bombers in the first game at Griffith Stadium today.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- The Federal Prison Bureau said today that not one of the local jails it had inspected in the 1954 fiscal year that ended June 30 had merited an "excellent" rating.
The charter market last week held on to its recently gained strength, refusing to succomb to the customary summer lull.

Three Americans who were prisoners of the Chinese Communists and first chose to remain with the Reds have changed their minds and are on their way back to the United States. They face trial and possible punishment. They know that this is the case, but state that even this is better than life under the Communists.

The five-story store and apartment building at 1376 Third Avenue has been sold by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company to Benjamin Litowitch. Charles Siegel was attorney for the buyer, and Reuben Tally acted for the seller.

Leo Durocher spent a long, steaming afternoon at the Polo Grounds yesterday trying to catch lightning in a bottle. Then, in the last half of the ninth, with his Giants trailing the Dodgers, 2 -- 1, he caught it.
Whitehouse Hardy, retail shoes, corner store in the Singer Building at 149 Broadway -- Tankoos Co, brokers.
Three duplex garden apartments at 30 East Thirty-seventh Street were ransacked Saturday night or early yesterday morning.

PARIS, July 10 -- It was reported tonight that among the proposals under consideration here was one calling for an all-around reduction of armament expenditures. The amounts thus saved would go into an inter national fund to finance economic development.
VALPARAISO, Chile, July 10 -- Chile's transport and communications workers returned to their jobs today. Substantial gains were assured them after a nine-day strike.

NAIROBI, Kenya, July 10 (Reuters) -- Mau Mau "General" Kofia Mbaya (Bad Hat) and twenty-five of his followers were among the last terrorists to give themselves up as the Kenya Government's amnesty offer ran out at midnight tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Administration appears to be in for a rough time on both sides of the Capitol this week.

In the Senate the plan to create a pre-trained reserve force is again running into difficulty. There are more amendments and more controversial suggestions. These serve to complicate rather than to clarify the issues.

PITTSBURGH, July 10 -- Now that steel product prices have been advanced, steel producers and their customers are working out schedules and delivery details. The delivery situation was described by a normally cautious source as "rather uncertain."
NEW DELHI, India, July 10 -This is the time of the mango. It is the time to eat the mango, time to put mango in a pudding, to pit mango against mango and, best of all, time to talk about mango.

IN ONE respect at least, this month and next are the best of the year. For this is the season of the truly fresh tomato, a juicy, full-flavored bit of goodness of which New Yorkers get only a mediocre approximation during the other ten months.
George Murphy has been named host and director of a new Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures television program that takes to the air this autumn.
HAMBURG, Germany, July10 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania crew today won one of Germany's oldest races -- the Hamburg Senate -- against keen German and English competition.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 10 (Reuters) -- Dr. Arthur H. Compton said today he approved the "general objectives" of an appeal to ban war signed by the late Albert Einstein but could not support it in detail.

SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, July 11 (Reuters) -- A composite newspaper carrying four titles was published in Sydney today after company executives and non-union staff members joined in an emergency printing staff.

"An appalling erosion of our human resources" is the way Dr. Francis J. Daly, director of pupil personnel services for the New York State Education Department, recently described the alarmingly high rate of school drop-outs. He was referring to the fact that one out of every two pupils who enters high school nationally does not remain long enough to complete his studies.
BUENOS AIRES, July 10 -Scores of Argentines were arrested today in a resurgence of anti-Peronist demonstrations. It was the second such demonstration within twenty-four hours.
