The Holy Eucharist was instituted because "Christ wished to prolong the Incarnation," the Rev. Harry J. Wolff declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. He is a member of the clergy staff.

THE Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, which played its last season in New York in 1950, returned Saturday night for a single appearance at the Lewisohn Stadium. It attracted a record audience for the season of 17,000.

ABOARD THE U. S. S. GRESHAM AT SEA, July 10 (UP) -- The schooner Ramona of San Francisco and the Los Angeles ketch, Morning Star, tonight were reported "nearing a record" in the trans-Pacific yacht race.
DENVER, July 10 -- A new model of the cadet chapel was shown today to guests who inspected the temporary site of the Air Force Academy here.
A stormy three-day session is in prospect as the quadrennial convention of the International Longshoremen's Association opens this morning at the Commodore Hotel.
CHICAGO, July 10 -- Wheat futures registered substantial gains last week, but there was free selling in corn and deferred soybean futures, the latter making new lows on the crop.

From Washington on Saturday came the overdue news of where the Federal Government seems to have got its new Tennessee Valley Authority policy. It got it, presumably, from a report drawn up for the Budget Bureau in 1953 by Adolphe H. Wenzell, an investment banker, who had been called in as consultant.
MILWAUKEE, July 10 (AP) -Baseball-mad Milwaukee gets its first All-Star game Tuesday when the Braves and their National League playmates are favored to close the gap on the American League.

First-quarter department and specialty store profits continued the rising pattern begun in the final quarter of last year, according to a survey by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
TOBA, Japan, June 29 -- Japan's virtual monopoly of cultured pearls is providing her with an increasingly important source of foreign earnings, especially dollars.

PITTSBURGH, July 10 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4 -- 1, today behind the six-hit pitching of Curt Simmons. In the second game the Pirates downed the Phils, 3 -- 1, on a six-hit hurling job by Vernon Law.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 10 The match between Eddie Moylan of Trenton and Bill Tully of Yonkers for the New York State tennis championship at the County Tennis Club of Westchester was suspended today by a violent rainstorm.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 10 (UP) -- The Yugoslav Government decreed sizable price increases today for wheat, bread, fats, tobacco and railway passenger fares.

MILWAUKEE, July 10 (UP) -Wally Post hit a two-run, ninthinning homer for a 7-6 Cincinnati Redlegs victory today. The Milwaukee Braves extended their winning streak to six straight by taking the first game of a double-header, 7 -- 4.
BALTIMORE, July 10 (AP) -- The Rev. Vincent F. Beatty, S. J., assistant professor of chemistry, today was appointed president and rector of Loyola College.

William S. Kies Jr., George H. Walker Jr., and R. James Foster have been elected directors of Chemical Enterprises, Inc. Mr. Kies is a partner in W. S. Kies Co., Mr. Walker is managing partner of G. H. Walker Co. and Mr. Foster is a partner in Rand Co.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 10 -- Variable weather conditions marked the Western Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association's eighteenth regatta of the season today. The event attracted 141 entries and was conducted by the Port Washington Yacht Club.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 8 -Ceylon rubber producers and shippers were gravely perturbed today when rubber prices dropped 7 1/4 strait cents (about 2.3 United States cents) a pound on the Singapore market. The reason for the anxiety is that prices for Ceylon rubber sold to Communist China under a trade agreement are based on Singapore rates.
A 12-year-old Brooklyn boy who tried to slither under the exit gate in a B. M. T. station yesterday became stuck and had to be rescued by a police emergency squad.

Frank Loesser's musical version of Sidney Howard's Pulitzer Prize drama, "They Knew What They Wanted," is gradually starting to roll. Mr. Loesser's wife, Lynn, finally has found a Broadway producer to join hands with her in putting on the show.

Charles P. Taft, brother of the late Senator and president of the Committee for a National Trade Policy, recently delivered an address at Southern Methodist University in Dallas. It has been reproduced in a small volume called "Trade Barriers and the National Interest."*

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 10 -G. K. Bennett's Hurrying Angel from the City Island Yacht Club and George C. Thompson's Corinthia III of Indian Harbor were the winners today in the twenty-fourth overnight race of the Riverside Yacht Club.
BAASTAD, Sweden, July 10 (AP) -- Ham Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., today won the men's singles title in the Swedish international tennis tournament before 3,000 spectators.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 10 -- A cabin cruiser exploded, burned and sank off Montauk Point today, fatally injuring the owner and hurting three passengers.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., July 10 -- The Houston brothers, Robert and Bill, paced the New York Athletic Club to team laurels today in the mid-Hudson regatta staged by the Poughkeepsie Rowing Club. The Winged Foot team won ten of the thirteen events for 167 points.

CHEROKEE, N. C., July 10 (AP) -- A wall of water caused by heavy rains high in the Great Smoky Mountains flashed down the Oconalufty River yesterday. It washed out several bridges and swamped highways and farm lands. No deaths or injuries were reported.

ALHAMBRA, Calif., July 9 (UP) -- Des Koch, national collegiate discus champion from the University of Southern California, today upset Brayton Norton, world pentathlon record ho1der, to win the national A. A. U. pentathlon title.

ALTHOUGH we live in an airconditioned age, with offices, automobiles and some private dwellings comfortably cool, and more than a million units expected to be installed this year, not all of us have this comfort in our own homes.
BERLIN, July 10 (UP) -- East Germany and Poland reaffirmed today their determination to hold the Oder-Neisse line as the "final" frontier between the two countries.
More than 100 persons of Hungarian extraction took part yesterday in a demonstration against soviet domination of Hungary.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 11 -- Very happy over the box-office returns from "Blackboard Jungle," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is contemplating the production of another film about juvenile terrorists.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Democrats promised a "quiet burial" for Dixon-Yates when they won control of Congress last fall. But they celebrated today more in the free-swinging style of a Dixieland band playing "When the Saints Go Marching In."
SAN JUAN, P. R., July 11 (AP) -- Puerto Rico is fighting its worst polio outbreak in ten years.

FREEHOLD, N. J., July 11 -- Detectives from the prosecutor's office said today that James Wynn, 27 years old, of Asbury Park, had confessed the murder of Raymond Hagerman, 66, an Asbury Park taxi driver, early yesterday.
Deputy Mayor Henry Epstein posed some hard questions yesterday to a group of school superintendents.

ATLANTA, July 11 -- In honor of Bitsy Grant, the little giant killer, who beat the Budges and Vines and played on the Davis Cup team, they built a tennis stadium here in his home town and brought the national clay court championship to Atlanta.

DENVER, July 11 -- The past looked to the future today as a dream of three decades was realized. Three hundred and six young men, awkwardly earnest in their new khaki uni forms with blue caps and blue shoulderboards, swore to "support and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic," and became the first cadets at the new Air Force Academy.

Oil Painting, Mrs. Joe Goodwin's consistent sprinter, won the six-furlong Champlain Handicap easily yesterday. The handicap, worth $16,925, was the opening feature of the Saratoga-at-Jamaica meeting, and Oil Painting's victory was eminently popular with the crowd of 22,715. She paid $6.90 for $2.
CHICAGO, July 11 -- The Shriners will stage a sever-hour parade tomorrow through Chicago on Michigan Avenue. A colorful array of Oriental bands and camels will augment the line of 25,000 marchers.

HOW long, O Lord, how long will this mental aberration to abolish everything that is difficult plague our local educators? Martin Wolfson in his recent letter urges the discontinuance of the Regents' examination in American history because too many high school students failed the subject this last June. It was too difficult.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 11 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey accused the Eisenhower Administration today of being "weak, confused and at times petty" in its foreign policy toward new and underdeveloped nations.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 -- Harry Bridges said today many efforts had been made to recruit him into the Communist party. But, he declared, all had failed and he never became a party member.
The Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, Inc., will be the beneficiary of a theatre party to be held at the Nov. 1 performance of "No Time for Sergeants."
HANOI, Vietnam, July 11 -- In this capital of Communist North Vietnam everything, including the daily lives of its residents, seems to be going according to plan.
Election of J. E. Goodwin as executive vice president of the Chicago and North Western Railway system, was announced yesterday by Paul E. Feucht, president.

The Kidde Manufacturing Company has sold the former Sipp-Eastwood Company industrial plant at 39 Keen Street in Paterson, N. J., to the J. Calendrillo Motor Express. The buyer is a local concern that will use the property for an expansion of its warehousing and trucking facilities.
The Grace Line invited bids yesterday for two 15,000-gross-ton passenger liners for the company's Caribbean service.

SELDOM is a book more accurately titled than is "One Man's India."* by Arthur Stratton. Many books about India have been unsuccessful efforts to fit many men's Indias into one volume -- the India of the peasant villagers, the India of Jawaharlal Nehru, the Congress party and world politics, the India of Mohandas Gandhi and the India of the Bhagavad-Gita.

WHITE PLAINS, July 11 -- Westchester took preliminary steps today to restrict the use of its world-famous park system to county residents. It did so with a wary eye toward Park Commissioner Robert Moses of New York.
MILWAUKEE, July 11 (AP) -- Facts and figures of tomorrow's All-Star baseball game:
Four separate forest fires raged out of control in the West yesterday, ravaging thousands of acres of timberlands in Colorado, Wyoming and Arizona.

Robert Mary of Coral Gables, Fla., a co-holder of the National intercholastic doubles crown, yesterday scored a first-round upset in the junior play of the Eastern junior and boys' tennis championships at the West Side Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 11 (AP) -- Chattanooga will build its own power generating facilities if the "threat of a TVA dominated by the private power monopoly should become a reality," the chairman of the Electric Power Board said today.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today President Eisenhower's nominations of J. Edward Lumbard of New York and Sterry R. Waterman of Vermont to be United States Court of Appeals judges for the Second Circuit.

Retailers will increase their dollar volume in lower-priced and medium-priced women's sportswear next fall by trading up in price lines, buyers reported yesterday at the semi-annual Women's Sportswear Show at the Hotel New Yorker.
THE white marlin arrived off eastern Long Island in good numbers over the weekend, and although many were hooked, few were brought alongside the boats.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Fifty-four first-term and second-term Republican House members urged President Eisenhower to seek a second term for himself today. But the President laughed and remained noncommittal on the third anniversary of his nomination for the Presidency by the Republican National Convention in Chicago.
Lewis S. Rosenstiel, chairman of Schenley Industries, Inc., one of the big four distillers, threw the trade into more than a mild turmoil over the week-end.

JONES BEACH, L. I., July 11 -- "What this world needs is a conference at 'the summit' held on an ocean beach and with a common enemy to fight, such as the green fly." This was the unanimous opinion today of sixty-six consuls general stationed in New York.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) -- Net working capital of corporations rose by $2,300,000,000 during the first three months of 1955 the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. This was the best quarterly gain since 1950.
Patrolman John F. Delaney, 33 years old, of 39 Hemlock Street, Brooklyn, who was accused of breaking into a Long Island tavern last year, was dismissed yesterday.

LONDON, July 11 -- The British Government recently has discussed offering the Soviet Union an Allied guarantee of its western frontiers in return for an agreement to reunification of Germany in freedom.
Longshoremen of this port were taken to the woodshed yesterday by an old and valued friend.
LONDON, July 11 -- The 18 per cent increase in the price of coal announced last week by the National Coal Board was bitterly assailed in the House of Commons today.

NEW DELHI, India, July 11 -- Sometime this week a British Admiral will be piped aboard the cruiser New Delhi in the harbor of Bombay and will take command of the Indian Navy. It will be the last time a British officer will command India's fleet.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 11 -- Global production in manufacturing and mining reached a new peak in the first quarter of 1955, the July issue of the United Nations Bulletin of Statistics reported today. Exclusive of mainland China and the Soviet bloc states, world output exceeded by more than 1 per cent the previous high, registered in the last quarter of 1954.
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

" The Private War of Major Benson," a Universal-International comedy-drama in Technicolor, with Charlton Heston and Julie Adams, has been scheduled to open on Tuesday, Aug. 2, at the Plaza Theatre. William Demarest, Tim Hovey, Tim Considine and Sal Mineo head the supporting cast.
LONDON, July 11 -- The rise in British coal prices brought a fresh current of uncertainty in financial circles today resulting in lower prices in the stock markets.
Althea Gibson, seeded No. 1, reached the third round of the Rose Taubele Memorial tennis tournament at the New York Tennis Club in the Bronx yesterday.
Newspapers continue to be the top ad medium used by the 100 leading national advertisers in this country despite the "phenomenal" growth of network television.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that farm crop production this year promises to be the second highest on record.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved contempt citations against turnabout witness Harvey Matusow, Harry Sacher, New York attorney, and Joseph Starobin, New York writer.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 11 (AP) -- Mrs. Marian duPont Scott's Nahodah, prepping for a probable clash with unbeaten Polly's Jet and Decathlon in the Sapling Stakes Aug. 8, turned in a sparkling performance while winning the Speedster Purse before 19,600 at Monmouth Park today.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) -- The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to a compromise $2,360,530,300 military construction bill.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Harry Lundeberg, president of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., attacked today a proposal to set up a new Federal board on maritime labor disputes as "socialistic."

The Standard Oil Company of California announced plans yesterday for a multi-million dollar expansion of its West Texas pipeline facilities. T. S. Petersen, president, said the first stage of the project would consist of substituting twenty-inch pipe on seventy miles of the existing 195-mile system from Wink to El Paso.

Rubber futures registered one of the sharpest rises of the year yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Most options went to new highs for the life of the contracts. Trading was influenced by strength in London and Singapore.
Tony Puleo, 136 1/4, Brooklyn, gained the unanimous decision over Libby Manzo, 134, Elmhurst, L. I., in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
LONDON, Tuesday, July 12 (AP) -- Sir Jacob Epstein, the sculptor, has secretly married his 50-year-old secretary and model, Mrs. Kathless Garman, it was reported today.

Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation has appointed William C. Foster as an executive vice president, Thomas S. Nichols, president of the diversified industrial and chemical company, announced yesterday.
Brisk breezes from Canada yesterday brought considerable relief from New York's nine-day hot spell. Today will be even cooler, the Weather Bureau said.
SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., July 11 -- The 25-to-7 victory by the Russian chess team over the Americans in Moscow proved once more that professionals can beat amateurs.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) -- Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California, today named three staff members to his special House subcommittee to investigate charges that Government agencies were withholding public information.
The Jewish Labor Committee asked yesterday that the Big Four conference at Geneva next week discuss the fate of an estimated total of 2,000,000 Jews behind the Iron Curtain.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Wilber M. Brucker was confirmed by the Senate today to be Secretary of the Army. Meanwhile, the White House announced the resignation of Robert B. Anderson, Deputy Secretary of Defense, effective about Aug. 15.
BUENOS AIRES, July 11 -- Overruling objections by clerical authorities, the Government is beginning to repair the principal churches destroyed by fire on the night of June 16.

The Bell System -- American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal telephone subsidiaries -- reported yesterday increases in operating revenues and net income for three and twelve months ended May 31. A. T. T., including earnings of subsidiaries received as dividends, also reported gains in operating revenues and net income for three and twelve months ended June 30.

A family ownership of fifty years have been terminated in the sale by the estate of Louis Gelb of the three buildings at 1098-1102 Second Avenue. The buyer is the Sheppard-Fifty-eighth Street Apartments, Inc., which plans to improve the site with a nineteen-story apartment house.
PARIS, July 11 -- Premier Edgar Faure is considering proposals to link arms reduction on both sides of the Iron Curtain with a kind of Point Four program for aiding economically backward regions.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 10 -- The Southeast Asia Collective Defense Treaty is experiencing troublesome days. Only a slow start has been made toward forging an effective defense alliance in this part of the world.

THE impresarios of Hollywood and Broadway had better thing twice about the free advertising rides offered by television. A few more of the dreary TV trailers for stage and screen attractions and the viewer is apt to give up all entertainment.
OTTAWA, July 11 -- Lester B. Pearson, Secretary of State for External Affairs, told the House of Commons today that he might go to Moscow in the autumn.

CHEESE bread, the tangy loaf that has been a specialty found only in a few outlets here, for the first time now is being mass produced. The baker is Levy's, the Brooklyn concern best known for its rye and pumpernickle.

In formal ceremonies the new Air Force Academy has been opened at Lowry Air Force Base in Colorado. This is not its permanent home, but buildings at the base have been made available until the new structures at Colorado Springs are completed, in about two years. Meanwhile, the new service school has begun its function at the temporary site.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Justice Department today opposed legislation proposing full return of more than $485,000,000 in war-seized assets to German and Japanese individuals and corporations.

CAMBRIDGE, England, July 11 -- A group of internationally famous psychic investigators are trying to make scientific sense out of the evidence in favor of the existence of ghosts, poltergeists and other supernatural manifestations of the living and the dead.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company lost another round today in its efforts to block construction by a rival company of a Louisiana-to-Michigan natural gas pipeline.
MANILA, July 11 -- Two Philippine Government investigators said today they thought United States Navy officials were treating Filipinos badly on a naval reservation on Subic Bay.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Ranking military spokesmen told Congress today that they would rather have no new program for building up trained and Ready Reserves than the one adopted by the House of Representatives July 1.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Senate leaders of both parties arranged today to put that body on record as sympathetic to peoples now "subjected to the captivity of alien despotisms."

President Eisenhower has made a happy gesture in gathering at the White House thirty-odd leading figures in the sports world to talk about sports and young America. There has been talk about using this approach to "reduce juvenile delinquency," but this is too narrow a view.

Philipp H. Lohman in his letter published June 20 suggests that Jules Verne may have derived at least some of his ideas from the work of Edgar Allan Poe. Mr. Lohman will be pleased to learn that he is entirely correct in his surmise that Poe provided stimulation for the young Verne.
LONDON, July 11 (Reuters) -- England struggled to avoid defeat against South Africa on the fourth day of the third test cricket match at Manchester today despite a 117 by Captain Peter May.

In your issue of June 27 the A. P. correspondent, under the heading "Indian Land Sale Is Eased by U. S.," obviously tried to present fairly both sides of an argument which is extremely difficult for outsiders to understand.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 11 -- President Eisenhower's order terminating the Dixon - Yates contract was reported here today in the midst of a bitter area fight over the power supply issue involved.
MILWAUKEE, July 11 -- This seething metropolis, still patiently waiting for its first world series, was all adither tonight as it prepared to play host to baseball's next-best show.

LOS ANGELES, July 11 (AP) -- The Monterey Oil Company reported today net income for the nine months ended last May 31 of $829,136, or 52 cents a capital share. This compares with $552,948, or 43 cents a share, for the same period a year ago.

Stockholders of the New Haven Clock and Watch Company, at a special meeting on July 26, will vote on a new plan of recapitalization, according to the proxy statement. The plan involves the conversion of the 4 1/2 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock into one share of new 50-cent cumulative convertible preferred and one share of common stock.
Fun outdoors can "lead to tragedy because of needless eye accidents," according to Franklin M. Foote, executive director of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness.
BONN, Germany, July 11 -- Two Cabinet ministers representing the All-German Bloc submitted their resignations to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today after having lost control of their party.
Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, honored the late Elkan Naumburg yesterday in observing the fiftieth anniversary of his founding of the Naumburg Concerts on the Mall in Central Park.

A former Chinese Nationalist leader said yesterday that Chinese Communists would invade the Quemoy and Matsu Islands before September unless the United States asserted in Geneva its willingness to negotiate the Formosa problem.

TORONTO, July 11 (AP) -- O. E. Lennox, chairman of the Ontario Securities Commission, has announced that the right to certain exemptions under the Securities Act has been withdrawn from five companies.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs have increased.
The cable from Melbourne read: "Sir Norman Brookes, president of the Lawn Tennis Association of Australia for twenty-nine years, retired today."
NEWARK, July 11 -- The need for more rail transportation into mid-Manhattan, preferably via an intercepting underground rapid transit system, was urged here today.
CAIRO, July 11 -- The Prime Minister of India and the Premier of Egypt dined tonight in Al Tahra, the palace of former King Farouk.
TOURISTS who visit Belgium usually go home with lace. A recent Belgian visitor to the United States, Mme. Paul van der Hofstadt-Storie, hopes it will be with genuine hand-made lace.
OTTAWA, July 11 (AP) -- Canada's two largest railways advocated today closer regulation of coastwise vessels in submissions at the opening hearing of the Royal Commission on Coastal Shipping.

By rail and superhighway, theatre lovers will speed tonight to the pre-Revolutionary War town of Stratford, Conn. There, at 8:30 P. M., on the banks of the sleepy Housatonic, the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre will raise the curtain on its inaugural season.

GENEVA, July 11 -- The Economic Commission for Europe reported today that the present tightness in the coal market was likely to be prolonged and even intensified in some respects in the July-September quarter.
A Congressional hearing on tolls charged on commercial traffic through the Panama Canal has been requested by three leading shipping groups.

MRS. Charles S. Guggenheimer, for thirty-seven years chairman of the Stadium concerts, received a citation for her work in connection with the summer series at last night's concert at Lewisohn Stadium.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 11 (UP) -- The rebellious Indonesian Army demanded today that its new Chief of Staff be dismissed or resign. The Army has refused to recognize his authority.

Pencils wielded by manufacturers and their representatives flew busily over order books yesterday as thousands of store owners and buyers flocked to openings of local summer wholesale furniture, floor covering and lamp markets.

PURCHASE, N. Y., July 11 -- Two 22-year-old golfers shared honors in the Westchester County qualifying round for the metropolitan amateur championship today. They were Ernest Arend of Deal and Clarence Fogal of Mahopac, who scored 75's at the Century Country Club.
Slightly higher prices will prevail in most types of linens and domestics in the fall selling season, manufacturers reported yesterday at the trade's semi-annual market showing.

JERUSALEM, July 11 -- The Egyptian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission found today that an Israeli observation post had been shelled by mortar fire from Egyptian-controlled territory at noon on May 30.

Two Long Island youths, accused of the radio hoax that had Coast Guard ships and planes searching for two days last week for a "sinking ship" that never existed, will be arraigned in Brooklyn Federal Court today.
Frank Luther, the vocalist who is to tots what Eddie Fisher is to teen-agers, will make the test run of a new children's telecast tomorrow at the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Portable oil heaters would be banned in all buildings in New York under legislation drafted by the Wagner Administration. A local law incorporating the ban will be introduced into the City Council today.

PITTSBURGH, July 11 (AP) -- The United Steelworkers of America (C. I. O.) and the Aluminum Workers International Union, A. F. L., said today they would use "joint bargaining strategy" in negotiating for a wage increase from the Aluminum Company of America.
A brief revolt of the Municipal Art Commission against the proposed site of the modernistic $13,000,000 building for the Municipal and City Courts was quelled yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Mr. Dixon said today he presumed his company would halt excavation activities at West Memphis immediately.

ATLANTA, July 11 (AP) -- The Georgia State Board of Education today placed a lifetime ban on any teacher who instructs racially mixed classes. It also created a super-secret committee, apparently to deal with segregation.

Two members of a three-man House subcommittee on minerals and metals issued in Washington yesterday a joint statement taking issue with public statements of the chairman, Representative Sidney R. Yates, Democrat of Illinois.
CARTERET, N. J., July 11 (AP) -- A new contract covering 1,450 production workers at the United States Metals Refining Company was ratified tonight by the union.
Evgeni Vladimirovich Litoshko, New York correspondent for Pravda, will attend the Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Conn., this evening.
Has the fast tax write-off outlived the emergency for which it was created; and should it be abandoned, or its use be substantially restricted?

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, told the Senate today a report by the Controller General indicated "collusion" in the stockpiling program for critical metals during the Korean conflict.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A Senate committee with jurisdiction over broadcasting is trying to get privately endowed foundations to do some research for it.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) -- The Government will start a survey on Wednesday to see if the program of fast tax write-offs for defense production expansion should be change or possibly junked.

Foresters in separate areas of Arizona, Wyoming and Colorado were trying yesterday to check forest fires on 23,000 acres of forest. One man, a prospector, was trapped in a canyon, and died. The value of the lost timber cannot be reckoned. The burned-over lands were parts of national forests.
A meeting of the Tammany executive committee has been called for next Monday to designate candidates for vacancies on the General Sessions and City Court benches.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 11 -- Officials are seeking ways to avert strikes and at the same time to halt the inflationary spiral.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 11 (AP) -- Jerry Hoyt, nationally known racing car driver, died in an Oklahoma City hospital today from injuries received last night in big car races here.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 502 pints of blood Friday. Army personnel at Fort Monmouth, N. J., contributed 341 pints. The rest was received at the New York and Brooklyn donor centers and the Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn.

ROME, July 11 -- Universal peace brought about by fear of nuclear weapons would not be an unmixed blessing unless based also on Christian teaching, said the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano today.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, July 11 (Reuters) -- Nine Spanish delegates to the world Baptist Alliance Congress in London this week have beeu unable to obtain visas to come to Britain.
Do something about the weather? Of course you can, according to this area's meteorologists in Government and university employ and those in commercial practice.
PARIS, July 10 -- The French Government intends, before the end of July to ask Parliament to vote a bill under which the 1955 estimates will be accepted as the basis for the 1956 budget.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The State Department announced today that Secretary of State Dulles would leave Washington Wednesday for the Big Four conference in Geneva.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 11 (AP) -- Gene Andrews of Pacific. Palisades (Calif.), the defending champion, scrambled back from a three-hole deficit today to defeat Wallace Smith, Pontiac (Mich.) policeman, in nineteen holes at the national public links tournament of the United States Golf Association at Coffin Municipal Course.
To the folklore of delays on the Long Island Rail Road there was added yesterday the fainting spell of 21-year-old Miss Roslyn Geldman, of 319 Beach Street, Arverne, Queens.
The Fire Department's uniformed force will be increased by 425 men on July 28, bringing the roster to 11,541 out of an authorized strength of 11,637.
Firemen massed hoselines yesterday to throw up a wall of water to protect two ten-story gas tanks from heat and sparks during a five-alarm Brooklyn fire.
LONDON, July 11 -- The damaging economic effects of the railway and dock strikes that beset Britain recently were indicated in export figures for June made public by the Board of Trade today.

The business boom in the United States is lagging far behind the economic performance in Western Europe. So says Dr. Robert S. Aries, president of R. S. Aries and Associates, engineering consulting concern in the international field. Dr. Aries has just returned from an extensive tour abroad and has a glowing report to make.

The eyes of the world are turning toward Geneva, where the conference of heads of government proposed by former Prime Minister Churchill more than two years ago will at last take place beginning next Monday. It will be the first such meeting since the Potsdam conference in 1945, and it will assemble in a different world and a different atmosphere.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today the 1954 recession had been only half so severe as it previously reported. Recovery this year, it added, was carrying the economy to peaks higher than previously suspected.

BALTIMORE, July 11 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles today signed three more youngsters in a continuing youth movement and optioned Duane Pillette, a pitcher, to Oakland of the Pacific Coast League on twenty-four-hour recall.
Plans for speeding traffic around the perimeter of Manhattan were announced yesterday by Borough President Hulan E. Jack.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., July 11 -- The country's top newspaper advertising executives were told today that they were using outmoded selling methods in marketing their product. They were urged to make sweeping changes to become "partners" with advertisers and with agencies, rather than "solicitors" of space.

Instead of the customary official pleasantries of welcome the International Longshoremen's Association convening here yesterday heard some stern, straight-from-the-shoulder advice from Vincent A. G. O'Connor, the city's Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.
LONDON, July 11 (UP) -- The Indochina International Armistice Commission demanded today an immediate cease-fire in the fighting between Communist forces and Government troops in Laos.

Russia, with her accustomed adroitness, has now made an about-face and to all intents and purposes is holding out temptingly the olive branch. The great question at the conference in Geneva at the summit is to determine whether or not this is sincere, or whether it is merely a Trojan horse which will cause us to lower our own defenses.
HONG KONG, July 11 -- The three American "returncoats" who arrived here yesterday from Communist China sailed for home -- and possible trials -- immediately after midnight.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. Prices at the close were 8 points lower to 6 points higher than on last Friday, with the near months showing the most weakness.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 11 -- The president of the National Housewares Manufacturers Association said here today that 1955 will produce the highest dollar sales volume in the history of the nation's $2,000,000,000 housewares industry.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- President Eisenhower today ordered cancellation of the Dixon-Yates power contract.

BREMERHAVEN, Germany, July 11 (UP) -- A United States naval spokesman said today the Russians had ripped all instruments out of United States lend-lease vessels before returning the ships to the Americans.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., July 11 -- A shipment of seventeen diesel locomotives, destined for the Northwestern Railway of Pakistan, was inspected today by Pakistani Government representatives aboard the Norwegian motor vessel Bellis.

MILWAUKEE, July 11 -- A learned mathematician once proclaimed that there are no odds on a single throw of the dice. If that theory be correct, it may be a mistake to name the National League as betting favorite over the Americans in the annual All-Star game on the morrow in this baseball-mad city.

The Lehman Corporation reported yesterday total net assets reached a new high of $224,250,663, equal to $48.47 a share on the 4,626,856 shares outstanding on June 30, the end of the company's fiscal year. The net asset value gives effect to deductions of dividends of $2.01 a share.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- Reported large flour sales in the Southwest turned a weak wheat market stronger today and, incidentally, helped a modest recovery in coarse grains from the low points of the day. Kansas City was relatively strong, and, while no figures were available, it was intimated that the flour business was of substantial volume.
HONG KONG, July 11 -- A bill has been introduced in Communist China's National Congress calling for punishment of Hu Feng, the Marxist writer-critic who opposed Chinese Communist literary controls.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Treasury and State Department officials urged today approval of a proposed $100,000,000 International Finance Corporation to spur commercial development in the free world.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- President Eisenhower took up with thirty-two sports leaders today plans to encourage youngsters to become more active on the playing fields.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 11 -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization is ready to make a study of the world-wide peril of radioactivity as soon as the United Nations calls for one.
The nation's steel-making furnaces poured more steel in the April-June quarter this year than in any previous quarterly period. Output last month was a record high for any June, too.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- An independent banker told a Senate Banking Subcommittee today he favors reasonable supervision of bank holding companies.

MILWAUKEE, July 11 -- Major league players want all restrictions lifted on playing winter baseball in the Latin-American area. They also want the present March 1 deadline on reporting for spring training revised.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- There are two mysteries connected with the July 7 release by a House subcommittee of Secretary of State Dulles' June 10 testimony on the foreign aid appropriation bill, and diligent inquiry today failed to solve them. They are:
AS the farmer prepares his fields for the crops, so the provident homemaker readies her storage arrangements for his harvest.
SAN MARINO, July 11 (AP) -- Councilors of this tiny Communist-governed Republic swung their fists today during a heated debate on forthcoming general elections. No one was seriously hurt.
Prices jumped at the opening of the stock market yesterday, managed to hold most of their gains through a day of cross-currents and closed with a good general advance.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 11 -- The New York Times, in a news item published July 3, identified Charles F. Spear erroneously as a lawyer representing Alan U. Parsell in real estate matters. Mr. Spear, now Town Judge here, is a member of the zoning board that decided in Mr. Parsell's favor when he sought to remove topsoil and gravel from land over the objections of Mrs. Eugene W. Moore, who lives on near-by property.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate today a $2,638,741,750 foreign-aid appropriation for the fiscal year of 1956.
Recent advices from Portsmouth that parakeets outnumbered warplanes on the British aircraft carrier Centaur is not surprising in light of the history of the parrot-like little birds.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation is considering new financing expected to amount to more than $80,000,000. The funds would be used for development of fabricating facilities and certain other capital improvements.

Chandler Brossard, author of 5two novels, has a work of non-fiction on Rinehart's list for Oct. 27, entitled "The Scene Before You; A New Approach to American Culture." He has assembled twenty-four essays on influential aspects, among them sex and science; movies, TV, comics and Greenwich Village; painting, music and politics.
FALLSBURG, N. Y., July 11 -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, criticized today "persons who preach brotherhood but do not practice it."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 11 -- There were scenes in Belgrade today reminiscent of wartime food shortages. Long lines of agitated people formed outside food shops to obtain sugar.

Plans to merge Miller Hart, Inc., former Chicago meat packing concern now engaged in the cold storage business, and the Mount Vernon Bridge Company, Ohio steel fabricator, were announced yesterday. Combined assets would approximate $6,500,000.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today praised Allen Whitfield's "respect for the ethics" of the legal profession and agreed to withdraw the nomination of Mr. Whitfield to be a member of the Atomic Energy Commission.

The recent statement by several scientists concerning the dangers of atomic warfare may be useful as a warning. As a call for the "abolition of war," however, it may prove unfortunate. Its general tendency is to frustrate and confuse -- frustrate, because it points to no practical solutions; confuse, because it takes no note of the significance of past efforts.
ST. LOUIS, July 12 (AP) -- The American Zinc, Lead and Smelting Company announced the purchase today of two pieces of mining property and a concentration plant in southern Wisconsin.

Any passenger who rode the Long Island Rail Road's first electric train on the morning of July 26, 1905, and is of a mind to take another ride can do it on the house July 21. The trip is guaranteed to be one part sentimental and one part comfortable.
LONDON, July 12 -- Despite a late rally, stock market prices were lower today. The drop was largely influenced by the growth of last month's adverse trade balance.

While Geneva prepares for next week's meeting of the heads of government and next month's conference on "Atoms for Peace," another United Nations session in the same city is dealing with what Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, in a speech prepared for delivery there, yesterday called "the major long-term economic problem facing our generation * * * the major task of the United Nations."
HANOI, Vietnam, July 12 -- Newspapers and radio programs here have given maximum acclaim to the treaty of aid and friendship signed in Peiping Thursday between Communist China and North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Senate Subcommittee on Juvenile Delinquency voted unanimously today to cite for contempt of the Senate three New York witnesses who refused to answer questions on alleged dealings in pornographic materials.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- Miss Frances G. Knight, head of the State Department's Passport Division, told members of Congress today it would be easier on them, and her, if she could gear her operations to the jet age.

BONN, West Germany, July 12 -- The first hot strip mill installed in West Germany since World War II, theoretically capable of processing 2,000,000 tons of steel a year, was put into operation today at the August Thyssen Steel Works in Duisburg in the Ruhr.

AMERICA'S oldest trade school, run by the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen of the City of New York, operates quietly in the six-story Indiana limestone and Roman brick building (originally the Berkeley Preparatory, School) at 16-24 West Forty-fourth Street.

BOLZANO, Italy, July 12 -- The last American President to visit Europe in peacetime was Woodrow Wilson and his political ghost is again stirring on the eve of General Eisenhower's journey to Geneva. Wilson is remembered by Europeans primarily as the exponent of ethnic frontiers drawn to include, when possible, only members of the same linguistic groups.

BUFFALO, N. Y., July 12 (AP) --Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, said today he would feel more confident about the nation's prosperity if small business men did not "find themselves at the end of the banquet table scrambling for crumbs."

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The presidents of two independent California banks spoke out today against proposed legislation to tighten Federal curbs on bank holding companies. They said it would hurt a powerful rival, Transamerica Corporation.
The New York Giants will launch the 1955 National Football League campaign when they meet the Philadelphia Eagles in Connie Mack Stadium on the night of Sept. 24, a Saturday.

Two new features arrive in town this morning. "Foxfire," a Universal-International drama in color, with Jane Russell, Jeff Chandler, Dan Duryea and Mara Corday, is at the Globe. Aaron Rosenberg produced and Joseph Pevney directed, from Ketti Frings' adaptation of a story by Anya Seton. . . . .
LONDON, July 12 -- A plea for a fortifying drop of brandy for nervous first-time air passengers was heard today in the House of Lords.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- Representatives of the Philco Corporation have been notified that recent increases in the price of steel and other raw materials will result in higher prices for appliances. In notifying Philco distributors and field personnel, James H. Carmine, president of the corporation, said yesterday:
Ivy Cover-Ramsey, a student at A. and I. State University, Nashville, Tenn., led the way into the semi-final round of the Rose Taubele Memorial tennis tournament yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- President Eisenhower and Congressional leaders agreed today that firm national unity in support of his position was a necessity for the coming Big Four conference at Geneva.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The International Business Machines Corporation, in the first six months of this year, achieved record earnings after taxes and all charges.
Budget estimates awaiting action by the new Transit Authority indicate that the city-owned subway and bus lines may slip back into the red this year.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Administration carried to the Senate today its fight to restore $627,900,000 slashed from this year's foreign-aid appropriation by an angry House.
CHICAGO, July 12 -- The Shriners staged their traditional parade here today. The line of 25,000 marchers in bright Oriental costumes made it the "biggest" parade in the history of the order.

Governor Harriman's appointment of Dr. Paul H. Hoch as State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene represented an adventurous departure in policy. For it places in an administrative position -- one of the most important in New York's government, with a departmental budget of about $160,000,000 -- a man whose life has been spent in research.
DENVER, July 12 -- The new cadets at the Air Force Academy, which was dedicated here yesterday, were too busy today to be worried about the architectural style of their future home.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- A Senate hearing starring Louis E. Wolfson, a series of private meetings and truce proposals failed to restore the capital's transit service today.

MANCHESTER, England, July 12 (Reuters) -- South Africa won an exciting race against time to score a thrilling victory over England in their third cricket match today. The visitors won by three wickets, with only five minutes to spare.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The House Antitrust Subcommittee today approved a bill to forbid bank mergers through acquisition of assets if the merger would substantially lessen competition or create a monopoly.
Trans World Airlines was founded thirty years ago today. The airline is confining its celebration of the anniversary to pointing to the extent of its present domestic and overseas operations.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., July 12 -- A two-point plan by which this country's advertising men might play a major role in fashioning a world of peace and plenty was advanced today by Senator Clinton P. Anderson, chairman of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy.

STRATFORD, Conn., Wednesday, July 13 -- Since many people have been laboring industriously to build a new Shakespeare Festival Theatre on the Housatonic, this review is going to be a disappointing one.

STRATFORD, Conn., July 12 -- The American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy, dedicated to perpetuating the works of the playwright who "was not of an age but for all time," was opened formally here tonight.

Graduation exercises at New York University's College of Engineering last night were largely a family affair. Ninety of the 125 evening division graduates, all men, received degrees in the presence of their wives and children.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- President Eisenhower proclaimed today a belief that the peoples of the world did not want conflict. He maintained that it was only their "mistaken leaders that grow too belligerent."

CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Heavy selling overwhelmed the storage-egg futures market on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange again today, setting a new volume record for the second straight session. Eggs for future delivery closed 0.6 to 1.45 cents a dozen lower, September 38.45 cents.

The announcement last week by the Sales Executives Club that two of the leading exponents of the relatively new art of "motivational research" would speak at this week's luncheon moved about 900 ad and sales executives to attend the affair yesterday in the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Senate-House Defense Production Committee announced today it would question Howard I. Young, a St. Louis mining executive, about his conduct as a dollar-a-year man for the Government.

We have never shared the opinion of the more ardent critics of the Dixon-Yates contract that this longdisputed project constituted "a national scandal," something akin to Teapot Dome. Teapot Dome was a giveaway to private interests of rights to exploit a valuable piece of public property.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Government released today 720,000 more shots of Salk poliomyelitis vaccine.

MILWAUKEE, July 12 -- "I knew it was gone when I hit it," said Stan (The Man) Musial. The great Cardinal player was talking, of course, about his home run, which ended the All-Star game on one pitch today.

The Brighton Beach Baths property in Brooklyn has been leased for ninety-nine years from Joseph P. Day, Inc., by the Oxford Manor Corporation, headed by Alexander Muss, real estate investor. Involving an aggregate rental in excess of $20,000,000, the deal is reported to be one of the largest in the sixty-year history of the Day organization.
The Alabama Highway Authority borrowed $15,000,000 in the public market yesterday on revenue-secured bonds maturing serially on Aug. 1 from 1957 to 1975.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 12 -- It was announced today that Dr. Roy Blough had resigned from the secretariat of the United Nations to join the faculty of Columbia University as professor of international business. The announce

BOSTON, July 12 (UP) -- Two Massachusetts Democrats filed a bill today in the State Legislature under which a Jewish couple would be exempt from a law that requires them to surrender a Roman Catholic-born girl they had adopted.
Stocks opened firm yesterday, advanced the first hour and drooped the rest of the day. Both losses and gains were highly selective.

Mr. Al L. had a pleasant trip of a mile and a sixteenth in winning the Susquehanna Handicap at Saratoga-at-Jamaica yesterday. The 3-year-old colt, a son of Stymie, was kept in front all the way by Jimmy DelVecchio, who was looking over his shoulder at the end.
THE big bluefin tuna are present in the waters between Montauk and Watch Hill, R. I. Although none have been reported taken an angler had one almost in his boat yesterday.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 12 (AP) -- Dismissal of Fabian Sevitzky, musical director and conductor of the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra since 1937, was announced today.

The crucial issue that will determine the outcome of the Geneva conference is the problem of Germany, which involves the unification of that country and the creation of an all-German Government capable of joining in a final peace settlement.
Thank you for the interest you have shown in Puerto Rican wages by your editorial of June 25 and editorial note of July 2 following David Dubinsky's letter.

LA GRANGE, Ky., July 12 (UP) -- Carl Braden, newspaperman who was convicted on a sedition charge, was freed at the state reformatory here today after his attorney posted $40,000 appeal bond. He is still under a fifteen-year sentence.

JERUSALEM, July 12 (AP) -- Premier Moshe Sharett disclosed today details of a wartime Nazi offer to trade the lives of a million Hungarian Jews for 10,000 trucks to bolster Hitler's crumbling defenses.
The price of highways is a key issue as Congress strives for adjournment.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- With adjournment just around the corner, the Senate interrupted its program today to hear a series of commercials.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday. Prices moved 17 points (85 cents a bale) lower on July but 1 point lower to 6 points higher on the other months.
ALBANY, N. Y., July 12 (AP) -- New York State Controller Arthur Levitt today rejected the only bid on a 125-million-dollar issue of state-guaranteed Thruway Authority bonds.
MOSCOW, July 12 -- The Soviet Union called tonight for step-by-step reunification of Germany within the framework of an all-European collective agreement.
ATLANTA, July 12 -- Tony Trabert flew here from Washington and Hamilton Richardson arrived from Sweden today to begin their quest for the National clay court tennis championship.

Arthur J. Conte, a 26-year-old concrete worker, filed suit in Supreme Court yesterday for $1,000,000 for injuries he said he received when a floor collapsed last May 9 in the new Coliseum at Columbus Circle.
The first atomic reactor designed specifically for medical uses, including treatment and research, will be built for the new medical center of the University of California at Los Angeles.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 12 -- Memphis city officials went ahead today with their plans to construct a municipally owned steam generating plant.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 12 -- Gordon Stott of Nassau and Stanley Harte of Inwood shared honors today among qualifiers for the Metropolitan amateur golf championship. Each equalled the par 72 of the Wheatley Hills Golf Club counsel as forty-six Long Island entrants took part in the trials.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 12 -- State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits called on the Eisenhower Administration today to invest $100,000,000,000 in a program of peaceful economic competition with the Communists.
NEW ORLEANS, July 12 (AP) -- Louisiana suffered another blow today in its battle with the Federal Government over ownership of submerged lands in the Gulf of Mexico.
LONDON, July 12 (AP) -- Following is the text of a Tass statement, broadcast by the Moscow radio, on the German question:

JUST about every kind of food is sold somewhere in this city -- from live eels in Italian fish stores to 1,000-year-old eggs in Chinese groceries. But certain unusual foods must be hunted out, and often the search involves considerable time and effort.

A general reduction in the wholesale price of regular and premium grades of gasoline ranging up to one-half cent a gallon will be put into effect today by the Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., throughout New England, New York and the Middle Atlantic states. The company announced also the elimination of voluntary discounts previously given to dealers in so-called price-war areas.
The independent International Longshoremen's Association resumed yesterday its attacks on the Waterfront Commission, ignoring urgings to end "name-calling."
LONDON, July 12 -- There must be concessions on both sides if the West is to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the thaw in the "cold war," Clement R. Attlee declared today.

Civic, religious and social leaders in Suffolk and Nassau Counties will be introduced to the work of Greer, a children's community at Hope Farm, N. Y., at tea to be given on Saturday by Mrs. Ward Melville at Wide Waters, her home in Stony Brook, L. I.
THE veteran conductor Alexander Smallens led the Stadium Symphony Orchestra in last night's concert at Lewisohn Stadium of the City College.

MANY novelists seem to fall neatly into one of two classifications: the inward lookers and the outward lookers. Members of the first group look into their hearts and write about their fellow creatures according to some private and often passionately emotional view of life peculiarly their own. Notable examples are Emily Bronte, Herman Melville, Dostoevsky and William Faulkner.

The first volume of Hudson Strode's biography of Jefferson Davis is planned for September by Harcourt, Brace. Titled "Jefferson Davis, American Patriot, 1808-1861," the book covers Davis's years in the service of the United States as West Point Cadet, fighter in the Black Hawk and Mexican Wars, Representative, Senator and Cabinet member.
Two five-story store and apartment buildings at 931-33 Eighth Avenue have been sold by the estates of Marx and Moses Ottinger to an investing customer of Walter Samuels, brokers in the transaction.
In recent years the United States has become the center of the world's student exchange program. More foreign students attend colleges and universities in this country now than ever before.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- A study group from the insurance industry said today the possibility of a serious catastrophe arising from private operation of atomic energy plants "seems very remote."
Twenty-five tons of musty city records became waste paper yesterday.
Olga Tritt Inc, jeweler, store in the new building at 430 Park Ave -- William A. White Sons, brokers.
A $50,000,000 expansion of the West Side Highway was envisioned yesterday by Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan.

LONDON, July 12 -- A major crisis in Britain's yet unfledged commercial television industry came into the open today. The Independent Television Authority withdrew a contract offer from one of the four chosen broadcasting companies.
RAHWAY, N. J., July 12 -- Frank J. Moreau of Freehold, a member of the Monmouth County Shade Tree Commission, is a man who can't keep his eyes from a good-looking tree even when he's driving.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- A group of American Agricultural representatives left today for a visit to Russia, where they hope to plant "seeds of goodwill" with Soviet Union farmers.
MOSCOW, July 12 -- The Soviet Union reached agreement today with Austria on the payment for former German assets in the Soviet zone of Austria. The sum involved is the equivalent of $150,000,000.

Powerful streams of water from the Hudson River were shot 200 feet up in the air yesterday noon from the city's most modern fireboat. The display, held at Battery Park, was part of a musical program and exhibition of old and new fire-fighting equipment arranged for the benefit of several hundred persons on their lunch hour.

The Advertising Council reported yesterday measurable success in many of the seventeen campaigns in the public interest it carried on in the year ended March 1. The council is a nonprofit organization set up by advertisers, agencies and media.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Plans to set up a free world atomic energy agency outside the United Nations nearly have been completed by the United States working with seven Allied nations.

BONN, Germany, July 12 -- Conservative opponents of West German armament have begun a powerful campaign to arouse public opinion against the plans of the Federal Government and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
MOSCOW, July 12 -- "He" arrived in Moscow today.

HAWORTH, N. J., July 12 -- Harold Pembrook of Braidburn and Philip D. Ammirato of North Jersey shared the honors in the New Jersey section of the metropolitan amateur golf qualifying round today. Each had a one-over-par 73 at White Beeches.
For the first time in thirty years, the Port of New York has handled less than 30 per cent of the country's annual volume of foreign trade general cargoes.

Total crop production by American farmers for 1955 may be the second largest on record, according to the July 1 survey of the situation by the Department of Agriculture. Acreage planted was slightly less than in 1954, the department explains, but this has been just about offset by a smaller amount of insect and weather damage.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today it has received over $10,500,000,000 in subscriptions to its offering last week to sell $2,000,000,000 worth of tax anticipation certificates.

BANFF, Alta., July 12 -- Seven American teen - agers were killed yesterday by an avalanche on the slopes of Mount Temple in the Canadian Rockies. Two others were injured and only two escaped unharmed.
New York was warned yesterday that racketeers were trying to take over its trucking industry.
MILWAUKEE, July 12 -- As Stan Musial strode to the plate in the twelfth inning today, Harry Walker, his manager on the St. Louis Cardinals, called out to him from a box alongside the dugout.
A loan of $5,900,000 to Panama to aid in financing a four-year highway rehabilitation program was announced yesterday by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank).

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- Owen Clarke, a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, said today that elimination of rapid tax amortization for railroad car construction could result in a substantial reduction in new orders.
Antonio Sirianni, 59-year-old doorman and timekeeper for the Metropolitan Opera Company, was critically stabbed yesterday when he tried to capture one of two thugs who robbed his apartment.

FALLSBURG, N. Y., July 12 -- The Rabbinical Council of America has made a formal application with the Soviet Embassy in Washington to send an official delegation of rabbis to visit Jews in the Soviet Union.
BUENOS AIRES, July 12 -- Ten United States prelates headed by Most Rev. Robert E. Lucey, Archbishop of San Antonio and sixteen priests entered Argentina as "sight-seers" today.

The Sheltering Arms Children's Service will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Small War on Murray Hill," a new play by Robert Sherwood, on the night of Nov. 16 at a theatre yet to be announced. Mrs. Devereux C. Josephs heads the benefit committee. Serving with her as co-chairman is Mrs. Madison H. Lewis.
Louise Brough, who won the All-England women's singles tennis crown at Wimbledon eleven days ago, has no intention of resting on her laurels. She will take part in a tournament today.
ABOARD S. S. AMERICA, July 12 -- United States policy at the Big Four conference in Geneva next week will rest on certain principles, including the following:
GENEVA, July 12 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations stressed today the necessity of aid to underdeveloped countries.
RYE, N. Y., July 12 -- Alexandra (Sandy) Widman of the Noroton (Conn.) Yacht Club gained a quarter-point lead today in the competition for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound.
TAIPEI, Formosa, July 2 -- Nationalist China is fighting a tough, uphill battle to make Formosa's economy a showcase of anti-Communist Asia.
An ambitious plan to bring off-Broadway theatre to off-Broadway audiences has been worked out by the Phoenix Theatre and the Du Mont Television Network station WABD.

ANOTHER Hollywood film series wherein a Miss Fix-It keeps a family in a continuous storm has made its bow under the title "The Whiting Girls" (9 P. M. Mondays over Channel 2). As with so many of its predecessors, too much hokum spoils the program's fun.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The resignation of Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare will be announced tomorrow, barring some quite unexpected overnight changes in White House plans.

Women volunteers are urgently needed for daytime assignments with Red Cross bloodmobiles and donor centers. Mrs. E. Roland Harriman, vice chairman of the New York Chapter and chairman of volunteers, said the volunteer ranks had been reduced "more than expected" by summer vacations, illness and other factors.

An old-fashioned ice cream parlor is planned for the ground floor store of the five-story office building being reconstructed at 24 West Fifty-eighth Street. The space has been leased by Max Gorden operator of the Blue Angel and Village Vanguard night clubs, and Michael Field, concert pianist.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 12 (AP) -- The defending champion, Gene Andrews, Pacific Palisades, Calif., scored a 6-and-5 victory over Charles Afong of Honolulu in the second round of the United States Golf Association's public links tournament.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 12 -- The New York Yacht Club's tenth annual junior regatta attracted a starting fleet of 119 today.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Dixon-Yates power controversy struck the Securities and Exchange Commission today. It involved all its commissioners in a threatened contempt action.
Relocation of the Nantucket Shoals Lightship, one of the most important navigational aids for European ship traffic, has been proposed by the Coast Guard.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 12 -- Barbara Bel Geddes will take four weeks off from the Broadway stage hit, "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," to make her first movie appearance in five years. She will co-star with Frank Sinatra in Otto Preminger's independent production of "The Man With the Golden Arm."

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Active mill buying was again in evidence in the wheat pit this morning against sales of flour estimated as high as 12,000,000 sacks the last two days. There was enough hedge pressure to balance the mill buying, so prices failed to show much strength.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, accepted today a use-tax increase sponsored by Democrats as a second-best but satisfactory way to finance a highway construction program.
Twelve hundred quiet people yesterday watched the Statue of Liberty rise out of the early morning haze.

Charles L. Patterson, the city's new Transit Authority chairman, went on a tour of the I. R. T. yesterday with some of his subordinates. Like other underground travelers before them, the subway officials felt the heat, and even lost their way briefly at Grand Central.

CLEVELAND, July 12 (AP) -- Three judges denied today an appeal by Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard for a new trial. They held that the 31-year-old osteopath's conviction for the murder of his wife had ended "a fair trial" and that "there was sufficient evidence to support" the jury verdict.
Deaths in the city during last week's heat wave were 39.7 per cent above the figure for the corresponding -- but much cooler -- week last year.
JONES BEACH, L. I., July 12 -- Thanks to a shift in the wind, 200 members of the United Nations staff enjoyed an outing here today under ideal conditions.
ASCOT, England, July 12 (Reuters) -- Queen Elizabeth II today discarded the horse-drawn landau that traditionally takes British rulers to the Ascot race track and rode in a modern limousine instead.

An automobile operated by a man who had never driven before went on a rampage in the Bronx yesterday. The zig-zagging car cost the life of a 5-year-old girl, injured two of her playmates, struck a building and damaged another vehicle.
A Bible-reading grandmother from Camp Hill, Pa., walked out of a Manhattan television studio last night clutching a check for $32,000.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The House Appropriations Committee recommended today that all funds for the construction of the new Air Force Academy be withheld indefinitely.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Revival of emergency powers to allocate copper and establish priorities for use of the red metal are under study by the Office of Defense Mobilization.

PARIS, July 12 -- The report of the experts of the Western Big Three preparatory to the Geneva conference was completed today. Its cornerstone is a modification of Prime Minister Eden's plan for uniting Germany on the basis of free elections.

LONDON, July 12 -- The British Empire Cancer Campaign reported today that intensive tests had failed to prove a connection between cigarette smoking and cancer. The report said that one set of experiments was started in 1953 at Leeds University, using a machine capable of smoking thirty-six cigarettes at a time. Extracts from the tars produced have been injected into mice, so far without result.

There are those who say that the stock market's recent strong showing is largely a "private affair." What they mean is that activity has been dominated by the fifty major companies which constitute, in terms of market value, 54 per cent of the worth of all shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

STRATFORD, Ont., July 12 -- Eventually, the Stratford Shakespearean Festival hopes to add opera and ballet to its activities. Last night the music festival, the new wing it added this year, presented a work that verged on both the other arts.
MOSCOW, July 12 -- Two new men have joined the Soviet leadership.

The Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation of Pascagoula, Miss., is the apparent low bidder for construction of two big new passenger liners. They are to be used by the Moore-McCormack Lines in its New York-Buenos Aires luxury trade.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it would purchase grain storage bins with a capacity up to 100,000,000 bushels if needed to house the predicted 1955 bumper crop.

Potato prices tumbled as much as the 1/4-cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Trading was influenced by the Government crop estimate released after trading closed on Monday. The report estimated 400,000,000 bushels this year compared with 355,000,000 in 1954.

Two Long Island youths seized in the recent ship radio hoax were ordered held for grand jury action when arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court. They are accused of perpetrating the hoax that cost the Coast Guard more than $50,000 in searching for a phantom sinking ship off the New Jersey coast.
MILWAUKEE, July 12 -- Short of winning a world championship, which it some day hopes to achieve, this seething baseball metropolis of the Midwest experienced its greatest baseball thrill today.

It was a "consummation devoutly to be wished" last night when a dream long dreamed came true with the opening of the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre in Stratford, Conn. The play was "Julius Caesar," and later will come "The Tempest."

FURNITURE with a dual purpose is one way of stretching the interior decoration budget that has an ancient ancestry. Back in the eighteenth century the "deception bed," which simulated a chest of drawers, was a forerunner of the contemporary sofa-bed.

Now that school has closed its doors for a while there is this to be said: it may be possible, when one is downtown or otherwise away from home, to phone the house in late afternoons or evenings without getting a "busy" signal quite so many times.
The Illinois Bell Telephone Company borrowed $30,000,000 on forty-year mortgage bonds yesterday at an interest cost of 3.198 per cent.
NEW DELHI, July 12 -- The old Indian political technique of marching off to jail won a major victory tonight for the Sikhs of the Punjab.

In speech and in writing on various occasions I vigorously protested an article called "How to Spot a Communist" in the "Air Intelligence Training Bulletin." I acknowledged that it was legitimate for the Government to explain to members of the armed forces the nature of communism, but I felt that the article itself was bad in principle and in substance.
Many business executives, confident that good business will last for the rest of the year, plan to enlarge their inventories and raise prices, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
NEW DELHI, July 12 -- The Prime Ministers of India and Egypt joined today in denouncing military alliances as hindrances to peace.

A Chatham Square cigar store owner was charged yesterday with selling bottles of bay rum -- after-shave lotion -- to unshaven Bowery habitues who sought the 50-proof product as a thirst quencher before the bars opened on Sunday.

"With One Hand," a new drama by Joseph Kramm, has been quietly wedged into the jam-packed schedule of the Playwrights' Company. Dealing with a man who was afraid of success, the play is to be presented under Mr. Kramm's direction. As soon as a male star is engaged, production activities will swing into high gear.
The Wagner Administration has relaxed considerably its plans to compel owners of tenements to provide central heating and hot water.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 12 -- Revival of the powers of internment without trial was threatened by the Government today. The move was indicated as tension gripped Northern Ireland during the annual celebration of Orangemen's Day.
A Pan American World Airways flight to London yesterday had Capt. Charles R. Titus as pilot and John L. Titus, his son, as co-pilot.
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -Nashua tuned up today for Saturday's $155,000 Arlington Classic with a five-furlong workout that was two-fifths of a second faster than the world record for that distance.

A former high school teacher is compiling one of the most effective "books" in baseball. Although the material will never make a best seller, it could be a potent factor in the Dodgers' pennant drive.

While recipes may seem old-fashioned in millions of homes where mixes have released the cook from the kitchen, the directions for preparing mixes, simple as they are, cannot be ignored if the results are to be good.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission warned all export trade associations today that they face anti-trust prosecution unless they cease price-fixing practices at once.

The Hunterdon, N. J. School District borrowed $2,060,000 yesterday on an issue of serial bonds maturing on Nov. 1 from 1955 to 1979. The bonds were sold to a banking syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. at a bid of 100.151 for obligations bearing 2 7/8 per cent interest.
GENEVA, July 13 (UP) -- Soviet security officers declined tonight Switzerland's offer to ring Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin's Geneva villa with barbed wire.
JULY is the month for blueberry desserts. Supplies of the fruit now are at their peak, coming mostly from near-by New Jersey. And the quality, as shoppers already are aware, is good.
NEW DELHI, India, July 13 -Prime Minister Jawaharial Nehru returned to his capital today and got a welcome home that made a crowd happy and protocol officers miserable.

A decline of 304,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute for the week ended last Saturday. At the week-end supplies were 159,307,000 barrels, compared with 159,611,000 a week earlier and 163,712,000 a year ago.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 13 -- The world population passed the 2,528,000,000 mark in 1954, United Nations statisticians reported today.
The Citizens Budget Commission called on the Transit Authority yesterday to scale down the city's subway construction program.

Among the twenty-odd issues expected to be raised at Geneva there will be one problem of overriding importance. This is the problem of disarmament, which involves the question of how to lift from mankind the fear of total annihilation in an atomic war.

A small ring-tailed monkey, a happy fugitive from a pet shop, has taken over the grounds of an old folks' home on the upper West Side and is delighting bench and window audiences with his free-leaping antics.
The first polio death among New York State children inoculated with the Salk vaccine was reported yesterday by the city Health Department.

The seven-story apartment house at 128-130 West Forty-seventh Street has been sold by the Tulman Realty Corporation to a client of Joseph Howard Kitz, attorney. The property, on plot 37 by 100 feet, contains twenty-eight apartments and is assessed at $165,000.
BUYING something for somebody else for most of us is a trying chore confined mercifully to Christmas, birthdays and weddings. Personal shoppers do it cheerfully five or six days a week.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's massage to Congress today on signing the $31,882,815,726 defense appropriation bill:
BONN, Germany, July 13 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was assured today that his Government and armament program would be unaffected by the split in the All-German Bloc.

LONDON, July 13 -- Harold Macmillan, Foreign Secretary, informed the House of Commons today that the Greek Government had told him it was in no way responsible "for the aggravation of the situation in Cyprus."
A helicopter somersaulted and crashed in flames yesterday afternoon on the sixteenth and fifteenth-floor setbacks of the Port Authority Building.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, walked out of a Senate Banking subcommittee hearing today after accusing Chairman Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, of handling the session like a "100 per cent dictator."
New or reconstructed advertising signs in the vicinity of Brooklyn Bridge were banned yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

A 71-year-old man was released without bail on a fugitive charge yesterday when he told Kings County Judge Nathan R. Sobel he wanted to clear himself of two grand jury indictments so he could live in peace in his declining years.

WATERBURY, Conn., July 13 (AP) -- Union negotiators from three plants of the American Brass Company today accepted the company's wage offer and ended their strike The strike by the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, independent, started last Thursday night in Ansonia, Torrington and Buffalo.

OTTAWA, July 13 (Canadian Press) -- Sharply diverging views on whether Canada's own ships should have all of the country's coastwise shipping business were placed today before the Royal Commission on the coasting trade.

The resignation of Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare has been foreshadowed in the news dispatches for some time, and, as her letter to the President says, has been brought about by personal reasons which cannot be questioned.
CHICAGO, July 13 (UP) -- Former President Truman said tonight that world peace depended upon the United Nations, Americans and the United States President.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., July 13 -- The country's top newspaper advertising executives defended today the industry's practice of running special sections, an important source of revenue.

CAMBRIDGE, England, July 13 -- Statistical studies are said to have disclosed some of the group characteristics of ghosts and thereby to have offered some indication that human personality survives beyond death.
BANFF, Alta., July 13 (Canadian Press) -- An investigation into the deaths Monday of seven young mountaineers from the United States on Mount Temple will begin Friday.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Protests against an air route agreement between the United States and West Germany erupted today into a full-scale Senate investigation. The agreement was signed last Thursday.
MERCED, Calif., July 13 -- A flying tanker loaded with jet fuel crashed and exploded in a barley field near here, killing all ten aboard.
