THE average American will consume about 160 pounds of meat this year, according to a report from the United States Department of Agriculture. This is seven pounds more a person than last year. The thrifty housewife, it seems, is taking advantage of the attractive

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 13 -- John Foster Dulles declared today that world peace would be achieved when moral and spiritual values triumphed over "the creeds of materialism and the cults of raw power."
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Opponents went before the United States District Court here today in a new attempt to block New York City's Washington Square southeast redevelopment program.

Tri-Continental Corporation's net investment assets passed the quarter billion mark on June 30, Francis F. Randolph, chairman and president, reported yesterday. On that date net investment assets stood at $263,097,000, compared with $236,164,000 at the start of the year and $204,891,000 on June 30, 1954.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Documents showing how the Pentagon had rejected a recommendation by the Air Force in Korea in December, 1950, that a New York Times correspondent be disaccredited were spread on the record of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today.

The Public Service Commission reserved decision yesterday on the application of the Long Island Lighting Company for a determination on whether an overhead power line in an area in the Town of Islip, Suffolk County, was unsafe.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby resigned today as the nation's first Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, at an emotion-packed White House ceremony. President Eisenhower nominated Marion B. Folsom of Rochester, N. Y., to succeed her.
GENEVA, July 13 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council heard today that Britain hoped nuclear power would provide a quarter of the annual expansion in electric capacity by 1965.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- White House intervention stopped Congress from learning of Adolphe H. Wenzell's role in the Dixon-Yates power project on the day it faced a critical test in the House of Representatives.

" SORRY TO BE SO CHEERFUL," by Hildegarde Dolson, is a breezy album of intrepid adventures on the wild Manhattan frontier. A number of these sketches first appeared in The New Yorker, Good Housekeeping and Mademoiselle -- a fact that the editors of The National Geographic and Yachting may resent bitterly. Particularly Miss Dolson's terse log called "Shipwrecked in Central Park."

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -The House of Representatives Public Works Committee approved today a new highway construction program. However, it defeated President Eisenhower's plan to pay for it with bond issues.

ABOARD S. S. PRESIDENT CLEVELAND, July 13 (UP) -- One of three American turn-coats heading home from Red China said today Chinese students and technicians who returned to their Communist-ruled homeland were walking into a trap.
CHICAGO, July 13 -- Wheat trade was much quieter today following the great activity incident to the splurge of flour buying the last two days. Mill buying was of no more than usual volume.

A warning system of one million civilian aircraft spotters is the ultimate goal of the Ground Observer Corps, which marks today the third anniversary of Operation Skywatch, its 'round-the-clock program of surveillance on the northern, eastern and western perimeters of the United States.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -- The Defense Department said today the plan for its last-minute, year-end obligation of $614,000,000 in foreign aid funds was explained to Congress weeks ago.
LONDON, July 13 -- The Soviet Union's statement last night on the reunification of Germany is regarded here simply as a reaffirmation of the position it had already taken.
MOSCOW, July 13 -- The twentieth Congress of the Soviet Communist party will convene here next Feb. 14 to elect the party leadership and approve the next five-year plan.
The latest changes in the high command of the Soviet Communist party appear to give new clues on the distribution of power in the Soviet Union.
BUENOS AIRES, July 13 -The hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church in Argentina rejected tonight all association with any political party that might attempt to protect its interests.
New issues of corporate securities totaling more than $27,900,000 will be offered to investors today by investment banking syndicates.
It will take one to two months to complete the procedure required to ban the blowing of automobile horns on the city's streets, Mayor Wagner said yesterday.
BRATTLEBORO, Vt., July 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Lucille S. Miller was convicted today by a Federal jury on eighteen counts of advising young men to evade military service.

OSLO, Norway, July 13 (AP) -- A Norwegian archaeological expedition headed by Thor Heyerdahl of Kon-Tiki fame will sail for the Pacific in September in an attempt to solve the riddle of Easter Island.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -Asgeir Asgeirsson, President of Iceland, and other top Icelandic officials will be host to President and Mrs. Eisenhower at a luncheon Saturday. The Presidential party will be en route to the Big Four conference in Geneva.
ATLANTA, July 13 -- Tony Trabert and Hamilton Richardson each lost a set and Sam Giammalva was close to defeat today in the National clay court tennis championship.
A preview of Christmas toys was held yesterday at the Toy Guidance Exhibit, Inc.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Secretary of State Dulles declared today that "the three Western powers see eye to eye" on matters likely to come up in negotiations with the Soviet Union in Geneva.

Second lieutenants are a much-maligned species of man to begin with, and the recent comment of a Senator didn't help their cause a bit. In a partisan dispute over the Administration's program this Senator said the Democrats would give "just, fair and reasonable consideration" to President Eisenhower's requests, but would not "carry out instructions like a bunch of second lieutenants."
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 13 -- Roy J. Goldenberg, auctioneer, was convicted today of falsely advertising five paintings as the work of celebrated French artists.

The 35,000-ton battleship Jean Bart, France's largest naval unit, arrived yesterday from Newport, R. I., for a five-day visit. The huge battlewagon is named for a seventeenth century French naval hero.

The Langdon Realty Company, headed by Phillip P. Zipes, operator, sold the building containing seventy-one apartments and fourteen stores at 1186 East 180th Street, the Bronx, to 1186 East 180th Street, Inc., represented by Irving Kulick, attorney.

Two soloists shared last night's concert by the Stadium Symphony at Lewisohn Stadium. With Alexander Smallens on the podium, Jeanne Mitchell was heard in Bruch's G minor Violin Concerto and Robert Goldsand was the pianist in Rachmaninoff's Concerto No. 2 in C minor. An audience of about 6,000 was on hand.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -- The Air Force reversed itself today and gave the Boeing Airplane Company a go-ahead to build passenger jet airliners side-by-side with jet-propelled tanker planes.

Roy Campanella, the Brooklyn Dodgers' star catcher who has been sidelined with an injured left knee since June 28, worked out with the team at Ebbets Field yesterday. Roy declared himself fit to play again.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 13 -- William Faulkner's novel "Soldiers' Pay" will be turned into a movie by Columbia Pictures.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Democrats led by Senators Anderson and Kefauver, with Senator Gore, Governor Clement and California's Representative Holifield not far behind, must find a scandal in the Dixon-Yates contract if it is to figure as a major campaign issue against the Eisenhower Administration.
TAIPEI, Formosa, July 3 -- United States economic aid to Formosa appears to be the condition for the continued survival of this insular refuge of the Chinese Nationalists.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 13 -- The winter-book favorite for Goshen's Hambletonian, on Aug. 3, Saul A. Camp's Scott Frost from Shafter, Calif., set a track record of 2:03 4/5 for a 3-year-old trotter at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Driven by Joe O'Brien, Scott Frost won the $15,000 Old Country Trot by a length and a half from Galophone.

Gen. Thomas Jonathan "Stonewall" Jackson has been nominated for this year's election to the Hall of Fame of the New York University. Americans of renown have laid aside pressing duties to express devoted admiration for General Jackson and to cite his superb achievements and sterling character as the reasons for their desire to request favorable consideration of his memorialization.
Sales volume of the nation's chain and mail-order houses in the first six months of 1955 were 8.1 per cent higher than in the first half of 1954, according to a survey by The New York Times.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 -- Harry Bridges testified today that it had not bothered him if a Communist party member got into his union or ran for office, because neither the Communist party "nor any one else can control our union."

ASCOT, England, July 13 (UP) -- Botticelli, a 9-to-4 shot owned by Marchese Incisa Della Rochetta of Italy, defeated the American-owned Blue Prince II by three lengths today in the Gold Cup race at the Royal Ascot meeting.
Almost every leading issue gave ground yesterday when are attack of selling hit the stock market in its final hour.
ROME, July 13 -- Premier Antonio Segni and his coalition cabinet received only a lukewarm reception today on their first appearance in Parliament.
" Mister Roberts," a Cinema-Scope and color adaptation of the Joshua Logan-Thomas Heggen stage success, adapted from the late Mr. Heggen's novel, opens today at the Radio City Music Hall.

Directors of the State Bank of Albany and the First National Bank and Trust Company of Hudson have agreed to a merger. It would be subject to the approval of stockholders of each bank and of bank supervisory officials.
ABOARD S. S. AMERICA, July 13 -- When the Big Four meet in Geneva Monday, each of the Western heads of government will have a specific task.

LONG BEACH, L. I., July 13 -- Razor-sharp clam shells have become a menace to surf bathers at this South Shore resort. Tons of Mactra soldissima (commonly known as surf clams) have been ripped from "sets" on offshore sand bars in the last month and deposited on the beach here and along Atlantic Beach, Point Lookout, Lido Beach and Jones Beach.
Two longshore labor disputes involving four North River piers were settled yesterday.
The New York Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it would start proceedings tomorrow in the first of two actions concerning loyalty oaths by tenants in Federally aided housing projects.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Two New York newspaper men today refused to tell the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee whether they had ever been Communists. Both invoked the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution, which guarantees a witness against self-incrimination.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -Walter Barry, a former international officer of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers Union, refused to tell a House Un-American Activities subcommittee today whether he was or ever has been a member of the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -The House Foreign Affairs Committee called today for a full report on agreements that give foreign courts jurisdiction over some crimes committed by United States service men overseas.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 13 -- Austria has complained to Yugoslavia over the reported "dumping" of Hungarian, Rumanian and Bulgarian refugees.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -Following are the texts of an exchange of letters today between President Eisenhower and Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby on her resignation as Secretary of Health Education and Welfare:

The attack upon Laos by the Communist-led and Communist-sustained Pathet Lao group is a direct and overt violation of the Geneva Agreements. It is a disruption of an uneasy truce at a critical time. It is a little Korea all over again.

Three residents of the metropolitan area were among six cousins who were chosen yesterday as heirs to a million-dollar tax-free estate in Portland, Ore. They included a 74-year-old governess and a special guard for a cemetery.
Moving diorama displays, long found in many airports, as well as railroad and bus terminals, are invading supermarkets as permanent point-of-purchase material.
PARIS, July 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement made by Premier Edgar Faure at his news conference today:
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -Bendix Home Appliances, Inc., of South Bend, Ind., has settled for $295,708 a tax claim by the Internal Revenue Service that originally totaled $637,976.
Representatives of the three major TV networks and five unions will meet tomorrow afternoon in an effort to avert a strike that could close down live presentations from New York studios.

GAZA ARMISTICE LINE, Israeli Side, July 13 -- Egyptian and Israeli representatives added two more items of agreement today to a draft undertaking called "Arrangements for Reduction of Tension Along the Demarcation Line."

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture officials and members of the agency's cotton export advisory committee conferred at length today on possible changes in Government cotton export policy for the new marketing year beginning Aug. 1.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The economy set another mark in prosperity in May. Personal income reached an annual rate of $301,000,000,000.

Announcement that Joseph Clark, Daily Worker foreign editor, will get his passport for the Geneva talks is welcome news. But what should have been routine disposition of a reporter's request became an internationally publicized incident. It perhaps served to focus attention on the problem of those who dissent from the powers that be in our land today.

The B. F. Goodrich Company reported yesterday that it had tested large truck tires made of synthetically duplicated "natural" rubber and found they compared favorably with those made of tree-grown rubber.
Robert Bowditch Jr. of Worcester, Mass., scored an upset yesterday in the quarter-final round of junior competition in the Eastern junior and boys' tennis championships.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 13 -- The establishment of a foundation to study the interrelationship of the free press and American life was announced here today by the Providence Journal Company, publishers of The Providence Journal and Evening Bulletin.

BONN, Germany, July 13 -- West German officials expressed fear today that the West might be maneuvered in Geneva into agreeing to a relaxation of the East-West tensions on the basis of the permanent partition of Germany.
Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens moved yesterday to quash aspecial grand jury presentment that accused him of issuing a false report on a sewer to further his political ends.

ONCE upon a time there was a would-be story telling mother whose small flesh-and-blood fidgeted and squirmed as she tried in vain to weave a fanciful tale. Had she heard the advice offered recently by a specialist in this art, she might have been by now a successful nursery raconteur.
TRENTON, July 13 -- New Jersey's Democratic Governor today appointed a Republican prosecutor to a $16,000 county judgeship, but Republican jubilation was short-lived.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A military Reserves plan relying heavily on voluntary participation in the next two years was approved today by the Senate Armed Services Committee. It greatly diluted the original Pentagon program.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -The House of Representatives voted today for a sweeping overhaul of Government payments to survivors of service men.
Italy and the United States are proving that it's feasible -- and beneficial -- to exchange technical know-how in the same industrial field.

In France this is Bastille Day, the French equivalent of our Fourth of July. The Bastille was a formidable political prison. Its fall in the revolution was the signal that the type of misrule that it represented could be brought to an end by the popular will.
The Newspaper Guild of New York, C. I. 0., said yesterday it would "do its utmost" to have Melvin Barnet reinstated in his job as a copy editor of The New York Times.

MILWAUKEE, July 13 -- Ordinarily hardly anything vanishes from the sports scene more quickly than an All-Star game. The contest interrupts the pennant races for a few hours, provides a little excitement and the next day it is gone and forgotten.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -- President Eisenhower urged Republican leaders in Congress anew today to push for action on his atomic "peace ship" bill. Instead, the House Merchant Marine Committee voted to go ahead with an experimental version of a true atom-powered merchantman.
Two policemen encountered unexpected trouble last night while enforcing the law in different sections of Brooklyn.

THE dishwasher may still be regarded as a luxury by some women who, though tempted to buy one, wonder whether this piece of equipment is worth the investment. Of aid to the prospective purchaser is an appraisal of the machine by the staff

The action of the justices of the Appellate Division establishing a Family Part in the Supreme Court, New York County, in which all matrimonial matters and matters relating to children will be centralized, represents a very substantial contribution in the handling of families and children in our courts.

HONG KONG, July 13 -- Communist China's state radio declared in a domestic broadcast today that seven battalions of royal Laotian troops had been "massed" in the vicinity of Samneua in northeast Laos and that the situation there had become "explosive."
Harvey M. Matusow, turn-about witness in Communist trials, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on six counts of perjury.
A ten-year search for the "Mad Dane" of the Royal Canadian Air Force will come to a happy end today in a Park Avenue apartment.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., July 13 (AP) -- The United States will begin selling atomic-produced electric power shortly.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 13 -- A lawsuit filed in the United States District Court here, contesting rights to ten "Big Buck" uranium mining claims in Utah's San Juan County, was viewed today as a precedent-setting action foreshadowing a major round of litigation in the domestic uranium mining industry.
MOSCOW, Thursday, July 14 -- The Soviet regime has again accorded top priority to the expansion of heavy industry with emphasis on machine-tool construction.

NEWARK, July 13--A witness called by Bergen and Rockland County towns charged today that abandonment of passenger service on the New York Central's West Shore Division would cause more trouble for New York City commuters generally.

TOKYO, July 13 -- A record post-war total of $887,712,000 in exports for the first six months of 1955 was reported today by the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry. This was an increase of 23.2 per cent over the level for the like period of 1954.
The third anniversary of Operation Skywatch will be celebrated nationally today.

DETROIT, Mich., July 13 (UP) -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., won a major victory today when Michigan's Attorney General ruled that the union's new wage plan did not conflict with the state's unemployment compensation laws.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 13 -The former chairman of the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee predicted tonight that half the nation's electrical power would be generated by atomic fuel before the end of the century.

CHICAGO, July 13 (UPI)--Ezzard Charles, a former heavyweight champion, got off the canvas after a second round knockdown to gain a ten-round split decision over Paul Andrews in the Chicago Stadium tonight.

Two young Americans with experiences in far places have books on the fall list of the John Day Company. Marvine Howe has been working for the Government radio in Morocco for four years. In her book, "The Prince and I," she presents the lighter side of Moroccan life.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- President Eisenhower sharply rebuked Congress today as he approved with reservations the $31,882,815,726 Defense Department appropriation bill.
President Eisenhower yesterday nominated Robert H. Schaffer to be Postmaster of New York. The post is subject to Senate confirmation. Mr. Schaffer will succeed Albert Goldman, who retired in 1952.
Half-year record sales and earnings were achieved by the National Tea Company in the twenty-four weeks ended June 18, H. V. McNamara, president, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Joseph Curran, maritime labor leader, proposed today the hiring of a full-time arbitrator so that labor-management disputes would not cause ship delays.
ALBANY, July 13 (AP) -- Margaret (Sis) Cramer shot an 81 to lead the field today in the first round of the New York State women's golf championship.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad announced yesterday that the opening date of its new policy to charge $5.50 a month for parking at the Norwalk (Conn.) station was now indefinite.
NORFOLK, Va., July 13 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has awarded Capital Airlines a franchise for non-stop flight service between Norfolk and Atlanta, airline officials reported here yesterday.
Earnings of the South American Gold and Plantinum Company in the first half of this year were estimated at more than $800,000 by Lewis B. Harder, president.
The policy committee of the Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., accepted last night the terms of an agreement to end the thirteen-week-old strike of 15,000 New England cotton and rayon textile workers.

LONDON, July 13 -- The House of Commons approved today a report by a royal commission as a basis for dealing with discriminatory trade practices. The house endorsed, by a vote of 316 to 255, a Government motion welcoming the report.
LONDON, July 13 -- The British Colonial Office and the Maltese political parties have agreed that a long-term plan for the development of Malta should be prepared.
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

It's just a middling-long flat piece of stuff rubbing rubber off tires and soaking up leaked oil. It's not Brooklyn Bridge or Rockefeller Center, but it's good. It squeezes meanly into two lanes and spreads generously into five. It ushers with, a high-winding munificence into the treasures of the Cloisters and stopgoes into pillar-planted, liner-lined Twelfth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -Marion B. Folsom wondered aloud today how it will be to be a "front runner."
GAZA ARMISTICE LINE, Egyptian Side, July 13 -Egyptian, Israeli and United Nations representatives agreed today to admit correspondents to the site of the armistice line negotiations here next week.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Thursday, July 14 (UP) -- The Communists agreed today to a reduction in the number of neutral nations inspection teams in Korea in the first major armistice change since the truce was signed two years ago.
RYE, N. Y., July 13 -- Mrs. James M. Mertz, the defending champion, gained a 1 1/4-point lead today in the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound. Four races were on the program.

ELMIRA, N. Y., July 13 (AP) -- Kemp Trager, a Detroit tool and die executive, today won the United States soaring title although he finished second in the standings of the twenty-second National Soaring Contests.
Opposition to a bill that would reduce the quota on United States imports of sugar was registered yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously rejected today a resolution by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy proposing that this country break off relations with the Soviet satellites.

FALLSBURG, N. Y., July 13 -- A resolution to establish a world confederation of Orthodox rabbis was unanimously adopted here today by the Rabbinical Council of America. The confederation's headquarters would be in Jerusalem.
The unique flair of Parisian haute couture, restless at its conquest of feminine fashion, is now turning to revolutionize American men's wear.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -- The House Banking and Currency Committee was informed today the Administration was willing to accept some restrictions on its use of officials borrowed from private industry. But the Defense Mobilizer, Arthur S. Flemming, said the restrictions proposed by the Senate committee would go too far and interfere with defense programs.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Congress completed action today on a compromise bill appropriating $1,365,613,500 to finance the Atomic Energy Commission, the Tennessee Valley Authority and public works programs in the current fiscal year.

LEO DUROCHER was in good voice during the plane trip back from Milwaukee and the All-Star game. But Leo the Lip always is in good voice and it matters not whether he's on the ground, up in the air or under water.

PARIS, July 13 -- Premier Edgar Faure proposed today that armament reductions in Europe should be guaranteed by both physical inspection and budgetary checks. He thought agreed cuts in military budgets would prove the more effective means of control.
The Playwrights Company is tying to sign Joan Fontaine for the leading feminine role in one of three productions it will produce on Broadway later this season.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -Governor Harriman and other key New York Democrats united today in support of a single bill for state development of power resources at Niagara Falls.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 13 -- Innovations and improvements in design and color are the highlights of the twenty-third summer exhibit of the National Housewares Manufacturers Association, in Convention Hall here.

First money of $8,950 went to the Woodley Lane Farm's Reneged, the favorite, in the Troy Stakes at the Jamaica track yesterday. But the colt's backers had an anxious wait of ten minutes or so before the current was fed to the "official" sign.
A remote-control battle over Puerto Rican wages put Mayor Wagner on a political hot spot yesterday.
Greece, the cradle of western culture and civilization, will dedicate tomorrow its first nation-wide electric power system.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 13 (AP) -- The Carolyn K Stable's Hi-Sag, a supplementary entrant, won the $24,110 New Jersey Futurity before 23,498 fans at Monmouth Park today.

The deadly portable kerosene heater would be forbidden in New York City, and tenements with ten or more apartment units would be required to have central furnace heating, under legislation sponsored by the Wagner administration. This is a forward step in the general policy of improving living conditions in the old cold-water flats.
Paul M. Butler, Democratic national chairman, pictured the Eisenhower Administration yesterday as "backtracking" to "get things squared away" for the 1956 Presidential race.
LONDON, July 13 -- The stock markets have staged a recovery today under the lead of Government stocks, despite -- or because of -- a fall in activity.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Two Japanese industrialists and a Japanese trade union leader agreed today that the biggest secret of United States productivity was "smooth relations between labor and management."
United Parcel Service celebrates its twenty-fifth anniversary in the New York metropolitan area today with delivery of its 750,000,000th package.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 13 -Truck shipments of potatoes from Suffolk County remained blocked today. Pickets from two locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., attempting to organize employes of potato shipping concerns, prevented the movement of trucks manned by fellow unionists.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities, as announced today by the Federal Reserve Board, shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 6:

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Vacant housing for sale or for rent in the three months ended last June 30 amounted to only 2.2 per cent of all dwelling units in the country, Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks said today.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -- Two House Democrats accused the Eisenhower Administration today of "ducking its responsibilities" and "lowering a Jim Crow curtain" on civil rights bills in Congress.
THE fluke season is now approaching its peak. While this flatfish lacks some of the delicate flavor of the small winter flounder, there is more meat in one fish and more action in the fishing.

HAMILTON, AIR FORCE BASE, Calif, July 14 (AP) -- A Strategic Air Command Globe-master that had flown more than 700 miles over the Pacific Ocean with two of its engines dead and eighty - seven men aboard, landed safely here tonight.

State Supreme Court Justice Martin M. Frank reserved decision yesterday on the plea of Chris Christensen, a welter-weight boxer from Denmark, to compel the New York State Athletic Commission to lift its ban on his scheduled ten-round bout with Gene Poirer at St. Nicholas Arena on July 25.

STAY-AT-HOME New Yorkers often extol the quiet charm of their city on a summer Sunday when the more restless residents are week-ending elsewhere. Only one bad feature mars that picture of urban serenity -- the scarcity of good restaurants open on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 --There were sharp isolated Democratic retorts today to President Eisenhower's defiance of a Congressional decision in one section of the $31,882,815,726 defense appropriation bill. Congress generally, however, did not appear perturbed.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 14 -- Defense Minister Iwa Kusumasumantri resigned today in the crisis that arose two weeks ago over the appointment of a new Army Chief of Staff.
ALBANY, July 14 (AP) -- The New York State Thruway Authority announced today a preliminary route for the Berkshire section of the toll road.
David A. Gordon, a reporter on The New York Daily News who refused Wednesday to tell a Senate subcommittee whether he had ever been a Communist, was discharged yesterday by The Daily News.

ALEXANDER SMALLENS conducted the Stadium Symphony in works of Handel, Mozart and Wagner last night at Lewisohn Stadium. Erica Morini was the soloist in the performance of the Wieniawski D minor violin concerto.
Forty-four years ago, almost to the day, the same New Haven train -- the Federal -- plunged off an embankment in Bridgeport at almost the same spot as yesterday's wreck and at almost the same hour.

It is nice of the Acting Postmaster to explain that letters may now be deposited in the large mail boxes which we have been taught were for packages only. But what the Acting Postmaster does not tell us is why, in so many cases, the new large boxes have not been placed where the old ones have stood for years.

Although only four members of the Art Commission of New York have approved of locating the new courthouse for the City Court of New York and Municipal Courts on the old Tombs and Criminal Courts Building site, and six members of the Art Commission have voted against the submission, the city is now, it seems, to be saddled with the Zurmuhlen-Lescaze-Del Gaudio project.

Two of the most important statistics series on the state of the economy have made their appearance this week. They are the latest quarterly estimate of the annual rate of production and services (technically referred to as the Gross National Product) and the monthly statement on employment issued jointly by the Departments of Commerce and Labor.

The twelve-story loft building at the northeast corner of Fourth Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street has been sold by John Sergeant Cram and others, as trustees, to the 387 Fourth Realty Corporation. The Harlem Savings Bank made a mortgage loan of $1,000,000 in connection with the transaction.
At next week's Geneva meeting the highest Western leaders will have their first opportunity in ten years to judge for themselves who rules the Soviet Union.
Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman announced his retirement from regular, active service yesterday. The 62-year-old jurist gave ill health as the reason.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission filed a three-count antitrust complaint today against the nation's two oldest paper manufacturers -- Union Bag and Paper Company of New York and the Hankins Container Company of Cleveland.

MILWAUKEE, July 14 (UP) -- Cary Middlecoff played the back nine in 29 strokes today to tie the course record with a 64 for eighteen holes and take the lead in the $35,000 Milwaukee open golf tournament.
QUANTICO, Va., July 14 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, tonight impounded $46,000,000 voted by the Democratic Congress to increase the Marine Corps pending a new study of its proper size.

ATLANTA, July 14 -- Tony Trabert, Hamilton Richardson, Edward Moylan and Bernard Bartzen gained their allotted brackets in the semi-finals of the national clay court tennis championship today. Of the four, only Bartzen, the defending champion from San Angelo, Tex., gave up a set.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The President's refusal to enforce Section 638 of the Defense Appropriation Act "unless otherwise determined [that it is valid] by a court of competent jurisdiction" is not likely to be reversed by any judicial ruling.
PARIS, July 14 (UP) -- Secretary of State Dulles said "great hopes are in the air," as he arrived here by plane today.
A solution to the controversial issue of truck loading and unloading at New York piers appears to have been reached.
TAIPEI, Formosa, July 4 -- Formosa's land reform may be the most significant social and economic revolution ever to come to Asia without bloodshed.
Aaron L. Jacoby of Brooklyn was sworn in yesterday as a member of the Public Service Commission by Secretary of State Carmine G. DeSapio.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 14 -- The North Korean and Chinese Communists agreed today in principle to the withdrawal of two North Korean and two South Korean cities from designation as ports of entry under the Korean armistice.
HAMILTON, N. Y., July 14 -- Former United States Senator William Benton called today for a redoubled American propaganda program abroad as an instrument of an aggressive foreign policy.

Acting Postmaster Robert H. Schaffer of New York yesterday promised the Wall Street district a new air-conditioned post office by next May. He made the pledge at ground-breaking ceremonies at the site for the new building at Pine and Pearl Streets.

BONN, Germany, July 14 -- A mission of the East German Communist Government departed today for Geneva where it will remain in contact with the Soviet delegation to the four-power conference. The mission was headed by Georg Handke, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs in East Germany.
LOOK for bigger hats this season. The trend is toward bulk, to counterbalance the slim-as-a-shaft silhouette American designers are turning out for fall.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 14 -- The engineer was killed and twenty-four persons were injured today when the Federal, crack New Haven Railroad train, jumped the rails on a sharp curve just south of the Bridgeport station.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 14 -- Plans to construct in Nashville a multi-million dollar plant capable of producing 50,000 tons of automobile safety glass annually were announced today by the Ford Motor Company.
CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- A renewed break in storage egg futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange today found reflection in the wholesale cash egg market.
TRENTON, July 14 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today modified an earlier prediction he made on President Eisenhower's chances for re-election.

BONN, Germany, July 14 (AP) -- West Germany and Britain will sign an international air routes agreement in London next week, Dr. Christian Seebohm, Minister of Transport, announced in the Bundestag today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 14 -- Yugoslav business leaders apparently expect a substantial increase of trade with the Soviet Union and its satellites. The diplomatic reconciliation of Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union has had a swift impact on the local currency exchanges.

"LOOK AT THE U. S. A.,"* a lavish photorama built by the knowledgeable editors of Look Magazine, is a wonderful incitement to travel in the United States. As introductions to the pictures, which are grouped by regions -- the Southwest, New England, the South, and so on -- there are talks by Paul Horgan, Mary Ellen Chase, David L. Cohn, Joseph Henry Jackson, the late great Frederick Lewis Allen, Gerald W. Johnson and others.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 14 -Stanley Dancer drove Pat Tuccio's Gene Mac to victory tonight in the ninth annual $35,000 Roosevelt Trot, a mile-and-a-half race, at Roosevelt Raceway.

The charge made last year that the Army was "coddling Communists" was answered yesterday in a report made by the Senate Investigations subcommittee, now under the chairmanship of Senator McClellan of Arkansas, on the case of Maj. Irving Peress.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The weekly average of member bank reserve balances for the week ended July 13 increased $170,000,000 to $18,799,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

THE brothers Morris and Julius Lipsett, who won the bid the other day to take down the Third Avenue El, got into that line in a small way, twenty-eight years ago, when they bought the old Columbia Inn at Bemus Point, not far from their home town, Jamestown, N. Y.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Titus Haffa, Chicago industrialist who, with his family, recently obtained control of the WebsterChicago Corporation, disclosed today that it was he who ordered the dismissal of four company vice presidents. He said the company had become top heavy with executives and had ordered the dismissals "for the good of the company" without waiting for action by the board of directors.
Six hundred employers from all parts of the metropolitan area applauded yesterday calls for a finish fight against union efforts to win unemployment wage guarantees.

A dispatch from our Washington Bureau reveals the extent of what it calls "the gathering crisis" in local passenger transportation throughout the nation. The number of riders falls steadily, the wages of bus drivers are on the rise, more people take to the private automobile.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Appointment of nine-member advisory committee to represent production, finance, commerce, agriculture and labor was announced today by the ExportImport Bank of Washington. The new committee will meet at the call of the bank's president to advise on the governmental lending agency's program.
Apropos Mr. Hartnett's letter, I should like to offer the following points:
Gifts from New Yorkers, ranging from $2 to $15,000, have brought the annual drive for funds by the New York Public Library to its first successful conclusion in six years.
DETROIT, July 14 (AP) -- The American Motors Corporation and the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., broke off contract negotiations today until Aug. 8, four days before their current pact expires.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Department store sales over the country the week ended July 9 were 13 per cent above the figures in the same 1954 period, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Former Pilot Officer Christian Marius Nielsen, the "Mad Dane" of the Royal Canadian Air Force whose whereabouts for ten years were a mystery to the Canadian Government, received his Distinguished Flying Cross yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 14 -- Robert Stack will head the cast of Edmund Grainger's "Great Day in the Morning," playing a professional gambler who wins control of a silver mine in Colorado.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Justice Department has opened an investigation involving "dollar-a-year" men who advise on Federal contracts granted under the Defense Production Act.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 14 (AP) -- Gerald Yeutter was badly hurt in a spill, and a 2-year-old colt, Bold Bazooka, equaled a world record for five and one-half furlongs at Hollywood Park today.

The Crowell-Collier Publishing Company has shifted from red ink to black and is planning its first long-term financing for growth and expansion. This was announced yesterday by Paul C. Smith, president of the company and editor of its three national magazines.
The Colgate-Palmolive Company has a new president. William Lee Sims 2d, who was elected to that post yesterday, began his service with the company in 1924 as a salesman.
PARIS, July 14 -- The final stage of the Western preparations for the Geneva conference began here today in an atmosphere tinged with more optimism than leading officials believed justified.

Fifteen hundred union members rallied in what was called the city's first meeting of Puerto Rican garment workers last night. Enthusiastically they demanded passage of a bill to raise Puerto Rican and mainland minimum wages by the same margin.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The celebrated case of "Who Promoted Maj. Irving Peress?" was closed today with a Senate committee blast at the Army for bungling and secrecy.

July, in these latitudes, means an end to those cool mornings and cool evenings, when the air is fresh and all the world sparkles -- an end, at least, until down from the north comes the first hint of October.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Two new compromise proposals, both involving large-scale United States purchases of domestic sugar, were placed today before the House Agriculture Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today subscriptions to its offering last week to sell an additional $750,000,000 worth of the forty-year bond floated earlier this year amounted to $1,720,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Ira Henry Freeman, a reporter on The New York Times since 1928, told Senate investigators today that he had been a member of the Communist party for "approximately one year," starting in 1938 and ending in 1939.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Capital Transit Company turned down today a union counter-proposal for a truce in the strike of Washington bus and street car operators. The strike is in its fourteenth day.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 14 -- Gordon Stott of the Nassau Country Club took the qualifying medal in the Long Island amateur golf championship today.
STRASBOURG, France, July 14 (UP) -- Dr. Albert Schweitzer, 80-year-old Nobel Peace Prize winner for 1952, has been slowly going blind for three years, Mme Adele Woytt, his sister, said today.

RYE, N. Y., July 14 -- Toni Monetti of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club won the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound today. The 18-year-old Skidmore College sophomore captured the nine-race Syce Cup series by three-quarters of a point with a total of 57 1/4.

GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 14 (UP) -- Art Larsen, a former United States singles champion from San Leandro, Calif., gained the men's singles semi-finals of the Swiss tennis championships today by downing Antonio Maggi of Italy, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2.
Paul Bailey of Buffalo, Ky., received the decision over David Stevenson of Toronto for the second day in a row at the Saratoga-at-Jamaica program yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- A Congress of Industrial Organizations spokesman said today Congress no longer should postpone its decision on public development of new power plants at Niagara Falls.
Stocks improved in late dealings yesterday, a day which saw the narrowest market and the lightest trading since the end of May.

A proposal to breach the Iron Curtain with religious radio programs was put forward yesterday by the Rev. Paul M. Stevens, director of the radio and television commission of the Southern Baptist Convention.

American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., and subsidiaries expect the currency depreciation situation in Chile will be alleviated as a result of improved rates granted its subsidiary in that country. W. S. Robertson, hairman, told stockholders in a quarterly letter mailed yesterday that applications for rate decreases are being pressed by Mexican and Brazilian subsidiaries and "we are hopeful that satisfactory action will soon be taken."
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Senate Permanent Investigations subcommittee has directed a full-fledged inquiry into the business affairs of Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force.
LONDON, July 14 -- Foreign Secretary Harold Macmillan cautioned today against any expectation that the four-power talks at Geneva would produce solutions of world problems.

A TOURING typewriter-pounder returned from the All-Star game in Milwaukee to discover that the postman had rung more than twice. There was a considerable batch of mail commenting on a condemnatory column about Preacher Roe's confession that he'd used the outlawed spitball as his money pitch.

GAZA ARMISTICE LINE, Israeli side, July 14 -- Talks between Egypt and Israel proceeded today to a point of which the two parties approved a preamble of an arrangement for maintaining security along the demarcation line.
A forlorn little island in Lower New York Bay, which has been a pretty lonesome spot the last few years, received two boat loads of inquisitive visitors yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- For the second time in two months a majority of the United States Tariff Commission today urged President Eisenhower to increase the duties on imported bicycles.

The search by advertisers for new and better premiums has brought a wider range of merchandise into the premium market, Gorden C. Bowen, president of the Premium Advertising Association of America, Inc., said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Individuals saved $1,700,000,000 in the first quarter of this year, sharply down from the $2,800,000,000 of a year ago, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
Southern opponents of desegregation lost another battle yesterday as the traditional practice of separating the white and Negro races came under heavy fire on several fronts.
LONDON, July 14 -- Queen Elizabeth II entertained 7,500 guests this afternoon at a garden party at Buckingham Palace.

ST. LOUIS, July 14 (AP) -- A group of Eastern investment firms which last month acquired a large block of stock in the Missouri-Kansas-Texas (Katy) Railroad was given representation on the line's board of directors today.
Capt. William V. Bradley was re-elected yesterday as president of the International Longshoremen's Association.
The well-known Lewis Morris Apartments at 1749 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, have been sold by Kimmelman Zauderer to 1749, Inc., headed by Samuel Kesselman.

LONDON, July 14 -- Business slackened further in the stock markets here today and some irregularity developed in prices. Oil shares remained active and moved higher while British Government stocks held their early gains of up to 2 shillings 6 pence (35 cents).

Jack Gould's TV column in The Times of July 11 had to do with AWARE, anti-Communist organization in the theatre and with me. Since I am only one of fifteen directors of AWARE, I cannot presume to speak for the organization. I do speak for myself and for the facts.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Sagging prices were the rule in the Board of Trade grain pits today. Rallies were small and hard to hold. There was scattered long liquidation in all pits, with pressure accentuated by some hedge selling in wheat and oats.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UP) -- The House Administration Committee voted today to raise the pay of most House employes and to give Representatives an additional $10,600 a year for office help and stationery.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway seriously questioned the soundness of United States military policy just before he retired as Army Chief of Staff on June 30.

Irene Mayer 'Selznick's office said yesterday that Mrs. Selznick's next presentation, "The Chalk Garden," would open at the Barrymore on Oct. 26. The first two plays she did on Broadway, "A Streetcar Named Desire" and "Bell, Book and Candle," were tremendous hits at that house.
ALBANY, July 14 (AP) -- Margaret Cramer of Amsterdam, N. Y., toured the tricky Schuyler Meadows course in 81 again today to hold the lead in the New York State women's amateur golf tournament.

"Adventure Unlimited," a personal narrative of the Coast Guard in war and peace, is planned for Aug. 1 publication by Prentice-Hall. The author is Harold Waters, a retired Coast Guardsman, who came to this country from Australia, then served in the Guards for more than twenty-five years.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 14 -- The threat of a strike by the Screen Actors Guild against producers of television films grew stronger today.
GAZA ARMISTICE LINE, Egyptian Side, July 14 -- The Egyptian - Israeli armistice line negotiations appeared today to be headed for a deadlock over basic divergences in principle.

The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steel producer, realized a 65.9 per cent increase in earnings for the first half of this year, compared with the 1954 period. Sales were up 31.9 per cent.

All other means having proved futile through the first half of the National League race, it may be that the Giants are going to turn to larceny in an effort to improve their position in the second half.
Two persons were questioned Wednesday in the Serge Rubinstein murder and a third will be questioned on Monday, it was disclosed yesterday.
The Berkshire Music Center's annual scholarship to a student of conducting has been awarded to Kenneth D. Schermerhorn, 25 years old, of Schenectady, N. Y.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Eisenhower's stated reason for killing the Dixon-Yates power project was disclosed today as having been rejected earlier by the Atomic Energy Commission.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 14 -- Eyewitnesses to the crash of the Federal here this morning told of a fantastic flaring and crackling as overhead power lines crumpled and crossed under the destructive impact.
CLEVELAND, July 14 -- The Yanks belted Cleveland's redoubtable Bob Lemon off the mound tonight as they launched their third Western tour of the campaign.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The House supported its Appropriations Committee today and refused to approve construction funds for the Air Force Academy at Colorado Springs.

Motorists traveling to and from New York this week-end may expect detours or delays because of repairs, new construction or congestion on the following routes (the numbers correspond to those on the maps):
SHORTLY after daybreak this morning seventy-five boats will cast off from the Atlantic City Marina for the opening of the three-day marlin tournament.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Senate issued today, in precisely the language that had been cleared by President Eisenhower, a declaration of interest in the ultimate liberation of captive peoples.

ALBANY, July 14 (AP) -- A New York Telephone Company engineer testified today that it would cost $13,000,000 to install equipment that would distinguish calls within New York City from those into Nassau and Westchester Counties.
Don Budge, the national singles champion in 1937 and 1938, yesterday was named to coach the United States' junior Davis Cup team, succeeding Jack Kramer.

MOSCOW, July 14 -- The Soviet Union announced today that Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, and Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, Minister of Defense, would go to the Geneva conference.
A bill to provide for a pretrained military Reserve force has now been passed by the Senate. The House of Representatives had already adopted a measure in this field.
PARIS, July 14 (UP) -- Byron Nelson celebrated France's greatest holiday today by becoming the first American to win the French open golf championship since Walter Hagen in 1920.

NEW CITY, N. Y., July 14 -- A Supreme Court Justice ruled today that it was no crime to induce, entice or procure a female to live a life of prostitution -- but that it was against the law to attempt to do so.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 14 -- Official sources say Premier Ngo Dinh Diem will make a statement in the next few days on elections for the unification of Vietnam. Secrecy is being maintained about the contents of the statement.

Today's new film is "Finger Man," an Allied Artists melodrama with Frank Lovejoy, Forrest Tucker and Peggie Castle in the leading roles, at the Palace. Lindsley Parsons produced and Harold Schuster directed from a scenario Warren Douglas based on a story by Morris Lipsius and John Lardner.
The chairman of the new Transit Authority warned New York straphangers yesterday not to expect a "gilt-edged chariot" for their 15-cent subway tokens.
LONDON, July 14 -- Lightning flashed through the crowd at the Royal Ascot race meeting this afternoon, killing a woman and sending forty-three spectators to the hospital with injuries.

A banking syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. will place on the market today $9,690,000 of preferred and common stock of McLean Industries, Inc., a holding company just organized, whose principal operating subsidiaries are Waterman Steamship Corporation and Pan-Atlantic Steamship Corporation.
NORFOLK, Va., July 14 -Some 233 Negro parents petitioned the Norfolk School Board yesterday to put an "immediate end" to racial segregation in public schools. Today the board rejected the request.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Senate approved tonight legislation to build the present ready military Reserves from 800,000 to 2,900,000 in four years.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Public Works Committee of the House of Representatives tentatively approved today Federal tax increases on gasoline and other highway-user items. The additional levies would raise about $11,800,000,000 in the next fourteen years for a vast road-building program.
Homebound commuters on the New Haven Railroad were subjected last night to minor delays as a result of the Bridgeport wreck.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UP) -- Frank N. Belgrano Jr., president of Transamerica Corporation, told Congress today that legislation to curtail bank holding companies is unfair and would "break up" Transamerica.
The Association of Catholic Trade Unionists has condemned "the unjustifiable blacklisting" that has been practiced by AWARE, Inc.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active and lower yesterday. The close was 20 to 67 points ($1 to $3.35 a bale) below that one Wednesday.

GENEVA, July 14 -- Pavel N. Kumykin, Soviet Deputy Minister for Foreign Trade, announced today that his Government was prepared to join the international trade organization proposed in the Havana Charter.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The National Lawyers Guild lost another court fight today in its challenge of the Administration's efforts to list the guild as subversive.
Ship traffic at the Port of New York during the first half of this year increased by 6.8 per cent over the volume in the 1954 period.
OTTAWA, July 14 -- All ships but those registered in Canada, and the United States should be barred from Canada's inland coastal trade, a royal commission was told today.

The American Express Company has acquired all the common stock of William H. Banks, Inc., Chicago, the nation's oldest field warehousing concern. The company did not disclose the purchase price or the terms of the transaction.

BABYLON, L. I., July 14 -- A patrolman of the Long Island State Park Commission, suspended for refusing to void three summonses he had given a news photographer taking pictures on Southern State Parkway, is scheduled for a departmental hearing here July 21.
SUMMERTON, S. C., July 14 -- No one knows for sure when school days will come again in Summerton, but everyone will tell you that when they do, white and Negro children will go to separate schools.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 14 -- In the cause of brotherhood, Lin Yutang, author and philosopher, gave a gentle scolding tonight to both the Orient and the West.
Additional leases on office space that will take up entire floors in two buildings going up in the Wall Street area were reported by brokers yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, July 14 -- The United States received today a first-hand report from Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru on his views on the coming Geneva conference of the Big Four heads of government.
LONDON, July 14 -- A 32-year-old mother gained a breathing spell today in her fight to educate her four children her own way.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Eisenhower has named his son, Maj. John S. D. Eisenhower, as a personal aide for the Big Four conference in Geneva.

All rubber options on the Commodity Exchange climbed to new highs for the life of the contracts yesterday. The volume, 4,250 tons, was the second largest of the year. The spot price of No. 1 smoked rubber sheets rose 1/4 cent a pound to 40 5/6 cents, the year's high.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 -- Prime Minister Nu of Burma called tonight for a spirit of compromise at the Geneva conference. There is a world of difference, he said, between compromise and appeasement.

Plans are being made for the annual Thanksgiving tea dance for the benefit of the Judson Health Center. It will be held on Nov. 17 in the main ballroom of the Ambassador. Mrs. George H. Pride is chairman and Mrs. Edward A. Gorman, vice chairman of the benefit committee.

The "feast or famine" business of freight car builders apparently has once again swung back to the plus side. For the first time since 1953, the nation's railroads are purchasing new equipment in volume. The orders, of course, are directly the result of the high level of carloadings and the prospect that this happy state will continue in the foreseeable future.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -- Shipping interests here expressed concern today over the recent announcement that the Defense Department had asked Congress for authority to sell three Delaware River piers in South Philadelphia.
MEMPHIS, July 14 (AP) -- Representatives of West Memphis, Ark., charged today that the only reason Memphis decided to build its own power plant was to force cancellation of the Dixon-Yates contract.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway strongly deplored in his final report as Army Chief of Staff efforts made to involve him in political support of Administration military policies against which he had registered strong objections.

GENEVA, July 14 -- Directly above the conference table where the Big Four will sit down Monday, there is an overpowering painting by Jose Maria Sert. The room was formerly the Chamber of the Council of the League of Nations and the fresco shows five giants grasping each other's powerful wrists in a gesture of unity and strength.
The upper Bronx is suffering from a split personality.
The Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday began investigating Wednesday's crash of a Port of New York Authority helicopter.

HALMSTAD, Sweden, July 14 (UP) -- Don Vick of U. C. L. A. won the discus and shot-put events in an international track and field meet today, while three other United States collegiate stars also posted victories.

Loans to business by leading New York City banks moved upward $10,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the fourth weekly rise in five weeks, according to data released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Deliveries of refined copper to fabricators in this country rose to a two-year high last month, reflecting a thriving industrial demand. Copper stocks in the hands of producers dropped to the lowest level since last November.
Johnny Podres' sore left arm didn't last and the St. Louis Cardinals easily defeated the Dodgers at Ebbets Field last night, 6 -- 1, behind the four-hit pitching of Larry Jackson.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Simon E. Sobeloff, the Solicitor General, was nominated today to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Judicial Circuit.
PITTSBURGH, July 14 (AP) -The head of the nation's fourth largest steel company said today an increase in the price of steel "in itself cannot trigger a new inflationary spiral."
Blood will be collected today from 100 uniformed members of the Police Department at the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, Thirty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue (Murray Hill 9-1000).

PITTSBURGH, July 14 (UP) -- The Aluminum Workers Union, A. F. L., asked the Aluminum Company of America today for a substantial pay increase in addition to a 5-cents-an-hour rise that is due July 1 under an escalator cause in the present contract.
Politics made strange bat-fellows yesterday.

PARIS, July 14 -- The French commissioner of productivity has replied to charges by an American expert that France's trade associations oppose competitive productivity while accepting United States funds aimed to foster productivity.
LENOX, Mass., July 15 -- The second week-end of Berkshire Festival concerts got under way tonight with an all-Mozart program played by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Leonard Bernstein conducting.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Eisenhower flew off to the Big Four meeting in Geneva tonight with the expressed hope that the men in the Kremlin truly believe in conciliation, tolerance and understanding.
Court decision was reserved yesterday in the case of a Queens couple who face eviction from a city housing project for refusing to sign an affidavit of loyalty.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Congressional sources said today that a revised design for the new Air Force Academy would be presented Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- President Eisenhower made still another plea for his atomic "peace ship" today. He said the reasons for building the craft "are no less impelling" than when he first proposed it many weeks ago.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- The Belair Stud's mighty 3-year-old, Nashua, will face six rivals in tomorrow's twenty-seventh running of the Arlington Classic. If all start the race will gross $148,174 and the winner will earn $91,350.

PARIS, July 15 -- The Western Big Three foreign ministers appeared to have agreed today that German unification and a European security accord must be dealt with as a single problem in negotiations with the Soviet Union.

A happy -- and gregarious -- commuter with whom this column is acquainted is never annoyed when the train he is riding breaks down or is otherwise held up. These are the only times, he reports, that social restraint dissolves and riders converse with one another indiscriminately.
MANILA, July 14 -- President Ramon Magsaysay is confident that agreement will be reached to grant the United States badly needed new military bases in the Philippines.

First National Stores, Inc., has leased 48,000 square feet of space for a supermarket in the Mid-Island Shopping Plaza under construction in Hicksville, L. I. The supermarket will be the largest of the 700 stores operated by First National in New York and New England.

OTTAWA, July 15 -- The impassable nature of Canada's rugged north is protection enough for the families of whooping cranes and their four young in their recently discovered nesting places. Canadian wildlife officials said today.
An off-duty patrolman was seriously injured in Maspeth, Queens, yesterday when he was struck by a car that swerved onto a sidewalk after its driver "blacked out" and lost control.

LONDON, July 15 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today that 5,000,000 ($14,000,000) worth of stocks and bonds in American companies bought by the Government to underwrite a World War II dollar loan would be sold back to private British investors.

Stock prices yesterday extended the gains made late in the previous session. The list closed near the best levels of the day. Much of the improved demand centered in a selected group of steel, tobacco, motor, mail order, oil and railroad issues.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Eisenhower deplored today a $140,404,000 cut in Atomic Energy Commission funds. He said it would jeopardize work on atomic weapons and hinder development of nuclear propulsion and peaceful uses of atomic energy.

SAMUEL ELIOT MORISON of Harvard is probably the greatest and certainly the liveliest naval historian we have had in this country. He has written the maritime history of Massachusetts. He is writing the story of the United States Navy's part in World War II. And from time to time he likes to publish a book about a celebrated sailor he has been studying and admiring for more than fifty years, Christopher Columbus.

LONDON, July 15 -- British medical authorities consider the Salk poliomyelitis vaccine still too dangerous to be used even for voluntary testing. Therefore, the Government-backed test program has been canceled, it was announced today.
PARIS, July 15 -- A curfew was imposed in Casablanca tonight as hastily reinforced security units acted to halt a wave of rioting.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, has been called to a closed meeting early next week with the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee. The subcommittee is inquiring into his business affairs.
A truck driver for a linen supply company was accused yesterday of having carried off $40,000 worth of coffee in three years along with the dirty aprons from the grocery stores he served.
QUANTICO, Va., July 15 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, stripped away today the secrecy he previously had imposed on Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's criticism of United States military policy.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 15 -- Bob Sweeny, of Sands Point, a finalist in the 1954 national amateur tournament, was among those who reached the quarter-final of the Long Island amateur golf championship today.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today an agreement providing through-plane service between New York and points in South America for the first time.

Four striking employes of a housing development in Flushing, Queens, were held on charges of arson last night after two early-morning fires were discovered in the storage basement and a garage behind the 3,600-family project.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 15 -- A four-horse entry in the Aug. 3 Hambletonian -- that's the exciting prospect Joe O'Brien is contemplating these days at Roosevelt Raceway.
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Ken Rosewall and Rex Hartwig swept Australia to two expected singles victories over Mexico in the opening play of the American zone Davis Cup tennis competition today.
ALBANY, July 15 (AP) -- Plans for a program to develop executive talent among state employes were announced today.

While critical floor tests still must be met, Congress is driving toward completion of a highway construction bill that would recognize at last the neglect of the past and the challenge of the future. The Senate has already passed one measure. The House Public Works Committee yesterday gave its approval to another.

A New Haven Railroad official said yesterday that the wreck of the line's Federal Express on Thursday was caused by "excessive speed" on the sharp curve a quarter-mile from the Bridgeport, Conn., station.
LEXINGTON, Ky., July 15 (UP) -- A special Federal grand jury investigating the Louisville and Nashville Railroad strike last spring returned today twelve indictments against strikers.

BONN, Germany, July 15 -- Eighteen Nobel Prize winners issued a declaration today urging all countries to renounce force as an instrument of policy under the pain of destroying themselves in a nuclear war.
The following books of a religious and an inspirational nature have been issued recently:
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams promoted fourteen members of the force and appointed three more policewomen yesterday in a ceremony at Police Headquarters.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 15 -- The civil authorities of Rio de Janeiro formally handed over to the Roman Catholic Church today the site on which many thousands of pilgrims will attend the thirty - sixth International Eucharistic Congress during the coming week.
The United States Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers, C. I. O., signed a five-year contract last night covering pensions, insurance and severance pay.

A tract of forty-five acres fronting 550 feet on Horseblock Road in the East Patchogue-Medford area of Long Island has been purchased by a syndicate headed by Leon D. Lazer and Herbert M. Citron. The new owners plan to improve the parcel with 200 one-family dwellings in the $10,000 price class.

A concert version of Verdi's "La Traviata" will open the fifth week of concerts at City College's Lewisohn Stadium on Monday night. It will be the first of four programs Thomas Scherman will conduct during the week.

Rubber prices tumbled yesterday on the Commodity Exchange following strength earlier in the week. The market had been strong for about a month. The decline was attributed to profit taking and speculator short selling.

The New York Times has contributed a $2,500 scholarship to the Inter-American Press Association Scholarship Fund, Inc., the fund announced yesterday. It is the third full scholarship of $2,500 to be administered by the agency.
On June 30 you published a letter in the form of a reply written by Senator Paul H. Douglas on the effect of the proposed minimum wage legislation on the Puerto Rican economy.

OTTAWA, July 15 (Canadian Press) -- The United States continued to increase its lead over Canada as the world's top wheat exporter in the first ten months of the current crop year. Expanding markets absorbed increased shipments from all major exporters, except Canada.
BUENOS AIRES, July 15 -- Gen. Juan D. Peron promised the nation today that he would no longer be Argentina's dictator. He said he would confine his activities to those of a constitutional president.
Seventeen-year-old Frank Santana was sentenced to twenty-five years to life yesterday in Bronx County Court for the killing of 15-year-old William Blankenship.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 15 -- Rod Serling has sold his third television play for motion-picture production. Republic has bought "Taps on a Bugle," a human-interest drama about a tough Army sergeant who becomes headmaster of a boys' military school.
BONN, Germany, July 15 -- The Bundestag rushed through two basic pieces of armament legislation today in a race against the beginning of the conference in Geneva Monday.

Cinerama Productions Corp, in 34 E 51st St through Bing Bing Inc; Chapman, Walsh O'Connell, lawyers; Publicidad Badillo, advertising agency, in 122 E 42d St; Iron Steel Board of Trade, in 100 E 42d St . . . Cushman Wakefield Inc, brokers.

In your editorial of July 8 headed "Indonesia's Prisoners" you refer to the trial of a number of Dutch nationals who are charged with subversion Specifically, they are accused of lending material assistance and, in some cases, of providing personal leadership for armed bands in open rebellion against the established Government of Indonesia. Like all trials of this nature, theI story as it emerges in piecemeal testimony is inherently confusing.

KOBE, Japan, July 15 (UP) -- One of the three American turncoats en route home predicted today all eighteen others still in Red China would be returning to the United States "in the very near future."
GAZA ARMISTICE LINE, Israeli Side, July 15 -- Egyptian and Israeli conferees, meeting for the seventh day at the border point known as Kilometer 95, issued a joint communique today.

Styles and fabrics from the Far East, Middle East and Europe will dominate the $6,000,000,000-a-year men's apparel industry in this country next spring, according to William Doniger, vice president of David D. Doniger Co., producer of McGregor sportswear.
MOSCOW, July 15 -- Beginning Wednesday the gates of Moscow's historic Kremlin will be opened to the public.

OSLO, July 15 (AP) -- Pentti Karvonen of Finland tonight bettered the world record for the 3,000-meter steeplechase during the Oslo games. He was timed in 8:45.4. The accepted world mark of 8:49.6 was set by Sandor Roseenoy of Hungary last year.

Lumber production in the week ended June 9 was 57.8 per cent above that in the comparable week last year, according to reports telegraphed to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 79.1 per cent and orders 67 per cent.

New Jersey's Governor Meyner and a twenty-seven-member Refugee Relief Committee have formulated a program designed to enlist community support in their state for speeding the immigration of refugees from Communist-controlled countries.
MADRID, July 15 -- The Government has increased the sentences of twenty-one Spaniards convicted last November of having attempted to organize a Masonic lodge.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement-issued by President Eisenhower today in connection with the signing of an appropriation bill:

The non-comic comic book is often cited as a phenomenon of these troubled times. Printed by the millions, these garish publications are marked by horror, violence and practically everything but humor. They have evoked nation-wide condemnation.

Ballet stars will appear next week on television in an effort to familiarize viewers with dance forms. Andre Eglevsky and Melissa Hayden of the New York City Center ballet company will be seen on "Television Workshop," which is part of the "Brokenshire Show," over WRCA-TV, Wednesday, from 1 to 2 P. M.
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) -- The defending champion, Mrs. Frances Vosters of Haverford, Pa., defeated Mrs. Connie Clifton Ball, Ormond, Fla., in a semi-final match of the Middle States women's grass court tennis tournament today.

LONDON, July 15 -- Oil shares took the honors in the stock markets here today with rises that carried prices to fresh peaks. Suggestions of a rising demand for oil at higher prices lifted British petroleum pounds 3 shillings 9 pense (52 1/2 cents) and Burmah 7 shillings 6 pence ($1.05) to record prices of 6 13/32 and 8 29/32 respectively. Shell and Canadian Eagle Bearer shares also advanced substantially.

The first ten titles in a new series of paperback books will be issued by Harcourt, Brace Aug. 4. To be called Harvest Books, the series will include titles from the concern's backlist of modern classics, as well as fresh compilations of material previously published in separate volumes.
CLEVELAND, July 15 -- For more than three and a half hours on this murky afternoon Gil McDougald was one of the most miserable young men in the world.

HOUSTON, Tax., July 15 -- The Texas Butadiene and Chemical Corporation has announced plans to begin construction immediately on a $26,000,000 aviation gasoline and butadiene plant near here. The announcement came from Godfrey L. Cabot, Inc., of Boston, principal stockholder in the corporation.
Big Don Newcombe pitched and batted the Dodgers to a 12-3 triumph over the Cardinals at Ebbets Field yesterday.
MOSCOW, July 15 (Reuters) -- Following is the official England translation of the statement delivered today by Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin:

CHICAGO, July 15 -- The $8,000,000 steamship Aquarama, with red stack, green hull and stainless steel superstructure, tied up at the east end of Navy Pier today for a summer run as Chicago's only floating entertainment house.

The Brown Company of Berlin, N. H., an important producer of wood pulp, paper, lumber and related products, announced yesterday the election of A. E. Harold Fair as president and chief executive officer.
NEWARK, July 15 (AP) -- The New York Central Railroad announced today that it would continue operating its West Shore division at least until Nov. 15.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture issued an order today denying trading privileges on futures commodity markets to several officers of Winn Lovett Grocery Company and its subsidiary, Potato Distributors, Inc., of Jacksonville, Fla.

MOSCOW, July 15 -- A twelve-member United States farm delegation arrived here tonight for an extensive inspection trip in the Soviet Union. The tour corresponds to a similar visit being made by a Soviet agricultural group to the United States corn belt.
ALBANY, July 15 (AP) -- Naomi Venable of Poughkeepsie edged two former champions today and won the New York State women's golf tournament at the Schuyler Meadows Country Club.

QUANTICO, Va., July 15 -- A daring athlete is Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense. Today he disclosed that he had been "pitched" and "ditched" and had gone "kerplunk" in various sports. Right now he is sore from three or four broken ribs from his latest venture -- aquaplaning.
Timely health and safety advice for vacationing families has been offered by the Institute for Safer Living of the American Mutual Liability Insurance Company.

In your frequently appearing articles concerning problems of modern education you have covered many aspects of the situation with excellent lucidity and comprehension. However, I do not believe that you have told of the agony and tribulation which the secondary school senior undergoes trying to get admitted to a good college.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Lower cost electricity for New York City dwellers would result from state development of Niagara River power, Gordon R. Clapp said today.

A touchy period appears to be ahead for distributors of new issues of securities. The bond market is bristling with question marks, of which the most formidable has to do with the continuing weakness of tax-exempt-interest bonds of local government.

MAURICE GONNEAU, the short, slender Frenchman in a tall white cap who is chef at the Biltmore Hotel, has a particularly savory way of preparing chicken breasts with butter, mushrooms, sherry, wine and herbs.
Following is the text of a radio and television address by President Eisenhower last night as recorded by The New York Times:
CHICAGO, July 15 -- Short profit-taking was active in all pits on the Board of Trade today, a condition that tended to steady the markets, but there was still little inclination to follow rallies.
NOT even the "good old days" provided better striped bass fishing than the present season at Cape Cod. Although the surfcasting has been only fair, boat fishermen have had exceptional returns.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Public Works Committee of the House of Representatives approved today a $48,500,000,000 highway program and $12,000,000,000 in new taxes to help finance it.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. The close was 3 points higher to 7 points lower than on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Two Congressional committees made public today testimony that the Government had lost $325,000 on a defense stockpile contract. The testimony said the contract was made in the face of an investigator's report that criticism would be a certainty if the identity of the head of the contracting concern came out.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Eisenhower agreed today to a postponement until next year of Congressional consideration of United States membership in the Organization for Trade Cooperation.

The twelve-story apartment house at 640 West End Avenue has been sold by the Investors Funding Corporation of New York to 640 Associates, Inc., of which Sidney Brenner and Irving Spiro are the principals. The property occupies a plot 58 by 100 feet at the corner of West Ninety-first Street.
LONDON, July 15 -- Non-Communist student organizations extended an invitation to groups from the Communist world to attend next year's International Student Conference session.

The Remington Rand division of Sperry-Rand Corporation announced yesterday an agreement under which it will take a leading part in establishing Turkey's first typewriter assembly and manufacturing plant.
