WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Eisenhower told Congress today that the Big Four conference could open "new vistas" for the world if the heads of Government reached "areas of agreement" on handling major problems.

The Protestant Council of the City of New York has proposed that special prayers be offered tomorrow in all churches for the success of the forthcoming Big Four Conference in Geneva. The heads of government will begin their parley on Monday.

MOSCOW, July 15 -- Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin declared today that the Big Four heads of government "can and must" resolve the major international disputes at their conference opening Monday in Geneva.
The Brattle Theatre at Cambridge, Mass., is planning to transport its successful production of Shakespeare's "Henry IV, Part I" to Broadway for a limited run this fall.
Ten years ago this morning, in the twilight of a New Mexican desert dawn, there occurred an event not then reported in any newspaper, yet with a news value that remains with us to this day.

ATLANTA, July 15 (UP) -- The Georgia Supreme Court refused today to "supinely surrender" its state jurisdiction to the United States Supreme Court. The case involved a Negro who said the jury panel for his murder trial was stacked with white persons.
Any New Yorkers who were disappointed yesterday because the temperature did not go up to 90 degrees may get their wish today.

NEW CITY, N. Y., July 15 -- Thomas Schimpf is wondering why two mares and a pony have been abandoned at his threshold in the last two days. And the Clarkstown police want to know why the animals were stolen in the first place.
THE can opener is a king not only of the kitchen but of the basement -- Macy's basement, that is.
Harold E. Pletcher has been elected a vice president of S. B. Penick Co., Lyndhurst, N. J., drug and chemical manufacturer.

A peaceable little shoe-repair man was murdered for a few dollars yesterday in one of a rash of hold-ups in the city. The unknown person who bludgeoned and stabbed Oscar Kerpel to death in his Brooklyn shop may not have netted even $10 in the crime.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Projected Social Security taxes "may eventually weaken or even destroy" public acceptance of the old-age and survivors' insurance system, Republicans charged today.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- President Eisenhower authorized today a $2,360,530,300 construction program at United States military bases around the world. Many of the projects are secret.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 15 -- W. A. Haight, president of the Creole Petroleum Corporation, announced that his company, in an effort to recapture certain European markets, would exposed facilities on its Amuay refinery by 100,000 barrels a day.

What will it be this week-end? A leisurely loll in the hammock until noon or guiding the mower over sun-scorched turf? A drive to the shore to gambol on the stretches of white sand and watch the dips and glides of gulls overhead or a trip into the country in search of the young, tender ears of corn?
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon may go to the United Nations atomic conference in Geneva next month to bolster President Eisenhower's atoms - for - peace proposals.
A 2-year-old boxer dog, trapped in a smoke-filled second-floor apartment in a burning building in Brooklyn, turned rescuer yesterday when its mistress came to save its life.
PARIS, July 15 -- The 1,000,000 inhabitants of the Saar territory will probably be able to vote on their future some time after Oct. 25 under an international compromise reached today.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Public Health Service released today 440,000 shots of Salk poliomyelitis vaccine produced by the Pitman-Moore Company of Zionsville, Ind.
YONKERS, July 15 -- The eighty - six - night harness race meeting listed for the Yonkers Raceway will be held as scheduled despite reports to the contrary. The dates are Aug. 8 through Nov. 15.

MILWAUKEE, July 15 (UP) -- Jim Turnesa, 42-year-old member of the famous golfing family, shattered the Blue Mound course record with a 63 today. He surged into the lead at the halfway point in the $35,000 Milwaukee open tournament with a thirty-six hole total of 130.

EDGEWATER, N. J., July 15 -- The 1,817,938th and final car was driven off the line today at the Ford Motor Company's assembly plant here. This ended twenty-five years of automotive production on that site.
One of the most ambitious projects to come out of the do-it-yourself program at a center of the City Department of Parks and Recreation will be launched this morning.
ALBANY, July 15 (AP) -- The Legislature's Republican leaders today called for "greater and more conscientious" efforts to produce legislation that would protect motorists against uninsured drivers.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., July 15 -- The Knollwood team of Joe Gonda and Frank Malara Jr., won the twenty-fifth annual British Victory best-ball tournament over the 6,464-yard, par-71 Briar Hall course today.

The Certain - Teed Products Corporation announced yesterday that its offer to purchase the outstanding stock of the Gold Seal Asphalt Roofing Company, Chicago Heights, Ill., had been accepted by holders of more than 95 per cent of such stock.

DETROIT, July 15 (AP) -- Motor vehicle output this week will consist of 168,056 cars and 28,355 trucks, the highest combined level in six weeks, Ward's Reports said today. The agency attributed the high volume to record-level assemblies by the Ford division and General Motors Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today authorized import of an additional 1,500,000 pounds of shelled filberts free of a special import fee between now and Sept. 30, the end of the quota year.

"The Scarlet Coat," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer adventure in CinemaScope and color with Cornel Wilde, Michael Wilding, Anne Francis and George Sanders, is scheduled to open Friday, July 29, at the Palace Theatre.
MEXICO CITY, July 14 -- Serious concern is being expressed here over Congressional discussion in Washington on a possible Government subsidy for cotton exports.
The Governments special tanker building program has run into a new snag.

There will be an increased ringing of city telephones until the end of August as the United Jewish Appeal continues its telephone solicitation to reach or surpass its 1955 fund-raising goal of $99,521,275. Most of the proceeds from this annual fund drive will be distributed to the United Israel Appeal, the Joint Distribution Committee and the New York Association for New Americans, all agencies of U. J. A.

ATLANTA, July 15 -- With play in the men's singles at a standstill, Barbara Breit of North Hollywood, Calif., led the women's division into the semi-finals of the national clay court tennis championships today.

TORONTO, July 15 (AP) -A new $1,000,000 laboratory for the production of Salk polio vaccine will be added immediately to the Connaught Medical Research Laboratories here, the board of governors of the University of Toronto announced tonight.

GENEVA, July 15 -- The Soviet Union has an admirable opportunity to win a propaganda advantage at the Geneva conference. All it needs is to carry to their logical conclusion adroit maneuvers already set in motion.

The Tacoma (Wash.) School District 10 yesterday sold an issue of $8,267,000 of bonds due serially on Aug. 1 from 1957 to 1975 to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates at a net interest cost of 2.58809 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at yields of 1.6 to 2.85 per cent.

LONDON, July 15 -- Prime Minister Eden said today he hoped the conferees at Geneva, by patience and perseverance, would make progress "toward reducing the troubles and easing the tensions which now beset the world."

Smiling faces, a rarity around Coogan's Bluff this season, were in evidence all over the Polo Grounds yesterday after the Giants had beaten the Chicago Cubs, 5 -- 3. The 5,028 fans, the players and virtually everyone in sight -- Chicagoans excluded -- were delighted with the victory that pushed the Giants into third place.

GENEVA, July 15 (AP) -- United Nations officials estimated today at least 1,500 newspaper men, radio and television reporters and photographers would be on hand to cover the Big Four summit conference.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 15 (Reuters) -- Thailand today called for a meeting of representatives of the Southeast Asian defense alliance to consider the outbreak of fighting between Communist and Government forces in Laos.
Substantial pay rises for most of the city's department and agency heads and their top aides will be voted soon by the Board of Estimate.

The convention of the International Longshoremen's Association here was embarrassed again yesterday by a work stoppage on the North River. It was the third time during the five-day meeting at the Commodore Hotel that high union officials were forced to be absent from the convention because of pier labor troubles.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 15 -- The Socialist-Liberal coalition Government conditionally agreed today to withdraw its bill curbing the privileges of Roman Catholic schools.

SEOUL, Korea, July 15 -- The Republic of Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff called today for a buildup of military power to equal that of North Korea. They also asked dissolution soon of the neutral nations' supervisory commission.

There's an old racing expression: "Chicken today, feathers tomorrow." Judy Johnson, a horse trainer, had had some feathery years in her profesion; now she's enjoying a fried-chicken week at the Jamaica track.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 15 -- A judge's illness today caused a delay in the trial of Leon Jungschlaeger, former Dutch intelligence chief in Indonesia who has been accused of leading rebels against the Indonesian Government.

COLUMBIA, S. C., July 15 -- A Federal circuit court today ordered the trustees of the Summerton schools to establish a school system not based on racial discrimination. The court said they could do it in their own time and in their own way.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 15 -- That jazz, the most proletarian of the arts, should be having a festival in Newport, the most exclusive of summer resorts, means less these days than it would have meant a generation or so ago.
OAXACA, July 15 (UP) -- The Americans on the wrecked plane were identified by Lineas Aereas Unidas officials as Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Weinbaum of 39 West Sixteenth Street, New York.

MOSCOW, July 15 -- Pravda's New York correspondent reported today that the opening of the Shakespeare Festival Theatre in Stratford, Conn., was a "great event in the cultural life of the United States."

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., July 15 -- Protests by Westchester Legionnaires against the repeat showing in near-by Katonah two months ago of Edward R. Murrow's television interview with Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, atomic scientist, were supported tonight by Thomas E. Paradine, former national vice commander of the legion.

The housewife got another hint yesterday that she may have to pay higher prices for appliances. Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported it might have to raise prices of its refrigerators and other home maker aids despite its "best efforts" to hold the price line.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 15 (AP) -- Eighty-seven grateful young paratroopers took off in a C-124 Globemaster transport for Fort Bragg, N. C., today after spending four and one-half suspenseful hours over the Pacific Ocean last night in the same kind of plane.

Earnings of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation for the quarter and six months ended June 30 were up 384 and 239 per cent, respectively, from the 1954 periods. The sales gains were not so striking.

Net assets of Chemical Fund, Inc., rose to a new high of $98,-i 891,893 at the end of the JuneI ;quarter, according to the quar-] terly report released yesterday.] This was equal to $15.80 a share. It compared with $65,398,960 or $11.57 a. share a year earlier,
LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 15 (UP) -- Wally Cox was dismissed today by the Dunes Hotel after three shows of his $44,000 engagement.

Several years ago the New York Public Library, despite its fine endowments, found that because of high costs and the need for improving salaries it would have to go to the public for funds. The alternative was unthinkable, deficit financing that would make inroads into endowment securities.

Fines of $1,500 each were levied on Bernard and Victor Colodney by the board of managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, it was announced yesterday. The two men, officers in Monitz, Wallack Colodney, members of the Exchange, received a vote of censure for conduct "contrary to the best interest of the Exchange and its membership."
CHICAGO, July 15 (UP) -- Bob Kennedy hit a pinch triple with two on in the ninth inning today to give the Chicago White Sox a 5-4 victory over the Washington Senators.

THE time when a toy was a toy, a truck or a doll seems all but forgotten in some circles today. Abstract, non-objective art has made its influence felt in the juvenile world as artists, industrial designers and architects have joined the ranks of toy developers.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Senate Internal Security Subcommittee's questioning of newspaper men was intended "to get leads to the present time" from those who admitted Communist affiliations some fifteen years ago, Senator James O. Eastland, its chairman, said today.
GENEVA, July 15 -- Germany will be an uninvited, unofficial but welcome guest at the Big Four conference dealing with her future.

NIAGARA FALLS, Ont., July 15 -- Robert Moses inspected the nearly completed $343,742,000 Ontario hydro-electric development today. The trip convinced him more than ever that the New York State Power Authority -- rather than private utilities -- should undertake the corresponding United States project.
The Geneva conference will begin ten years and one day after the opening of the Potsdam conference July 17, 1945. Potsdam, a suburb of Berlin, was then under Soviet control.
QUANTICO, Va., July 15 -- Two-star Admiral Arleigh A. Burke is sporting a contellation of four stars on each shoulder just for a few days.

QUANTICO, Va., July 15 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, the new Army Chief of Staff, forecast today further reductions of United States strength in the Far East as a result of the Eisenhower Administration's manpower cuts.
TOKYO, July 15 -- Japan's chief security officer reported to the Cabinet today that the Communists occupied positions in all important Government ministries.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (UP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today increased the minimum amount of liability insurance that interstate buses, trucks and freight forwarders must carry.
A union - employer combine that fixed princes, allocated customers and froze out independent truckmen in the theatrical hauling industry here was terminated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.3 per cent to 110.3 (1947-49 equals 100) in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices for all commodities other than farm and foods were primarily responsible for the increase, as the index for farm products declined again this week.

A new type of lock for fire exits is designed to give factories, stores and warehouses protection from pilferage through unguarded or unlocked emergency exit doors. Developed by the Exit Lock Company of Pacoima, Calif., the device rings a warning alarm for several minutes if an unauthorized person opens the exit.

The apartment building accommodating fifty-nine families at 1569 Prospect Place in Brooklyn has been sold by Prospect Estates, Inc., to the Gosam Realty Corporation. Henry Futterwert was the broker and title was insured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.
SPLIT, Yugoslavia, July 15 -- A five-day joint naval exercise involving British ships and vessels from Yugoslavia's small fleet began today in the Adriatic Sea.
NEW HAVEN, July 16 -- A couple of days ago Dr. Selden D. Bacon, Director of the Yale Center of Alcohol Studies, was approached by a man attending the thirteenth annual summer school.
The aluminum louver-styled window called the jalousie has done quite a bit more than keep the hot rays of the sun outside, where they belong.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 16 -- William Edgar John of Rye tonight won the Robert R. Martin Memorial Trophy predicted log race conducted by the Greenwich Power Squadron.

THE expert declarer's chief objective is to conceal the nature of his hand from his opponents. Nearly one-third of all successful contracts could be defeated by double-dummy defense -- that is, if the defenders knew the location of every card.
Melvin Lasky's piece on "A New German Army: Hopes and Fears" (July 10) pictures the proposed army in the eyes of the German people, their Chancellor and the officers who will eventually be in charge.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 15 -- The Federation of Malaya is entering a critical period on the road to independence.

" KNOW your adversary" may be the safest rule for negotiation, but as the Western heads of state sit down with the Soviet Prime Minister, they face the representative of a community which since the days of the Muscovite princes has been a byword for inscrutability and reserve.

ALL books contain persuasion. All books communicate a selection of judgments about life. All books try to teach. The differences are between those which teach well and those which teach badly, and between those which teach valuable things and those which teach bad or trivial things.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- The Chamber of Commerce of Greater Philadelphia has opened a cooperative program with six other large cities to improve the exchange of information on municipal operating costs.

JERUSALEM, July 16 -- Israel has purchased two British destroyers, the Defense Ministry said today. The announcement added that the two ships were superior in speed, firepower and range to anything in the possession of Arab states.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 16 (UP) -- A Brazilian official charged today that the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development was aggravating Brazil's financial problems by failing to live up to its loan commitments.

LEST the simple, the just thing get left unsaid, let me blurt out platantly that at least one reader of this latest biography of David Hume has spent some of the high moments of life reading it. The re-creation of the great Scottish skeptic is done with all the minutiae of scholarship and with all the devotion of a devotee.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 16 -- Monte Irvin, the "baby on the doorstep," is turning out to be more like a Christmas basket for the Minneapolis Millers in their fight for the American Association pennant.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The first hearing on the petition of an organization to be removed from the Attorney General's subversive list is about to get under way.
GENEVA, July 16 -- The Russians arrived in Geneva today fully prepared and empowered to do business with the West.

When President Eisenhower and the British and French Prime Ministers sit down around a table in Geneva tomorrow with the Soviet delegation they will face many complex problems. But beyond all the individual problems they will also face one central problem which their predecessors have faced before them and for which even the best Western statesmanship has as yet found no adequate or desirable solution.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- The body of a man washed up on the shores of the Chesapeake Bay today at Centreville, Md., was identified tonight as Dr. William C. Seifriz, 67 years old, botanist and professor at the University of Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Americans are buying, building, investing -- and borrowing -- as never before.

LAST week Postmaster General Arthur E. Summer-field announced further details about the rest of the stamp-issuing program for 1955. For local collectors perhaps the outstanding feature is that New York City is to be one of the first-day sales points.

The days are getting shorter -- there's twenty minutes less daylight today than there was a month ago -- but there's still time to puzzle out some kind of answers to those midsummer questions. Why don't fresh-water fish bite during hot weather? Do they go on a diet? If the fish ate more, the mosquitos would bite less because there would be fewer mosquitos.
LONDON, July 16 -- The golden jubilee congress of the Baptist World Alliance opened here today with an address by the Archbishop of Canterbury, head of the Church of England.

HONG KONG, July 16 -- Communist China's Defense Minister, Peng Teh-huai, told the National People's Congress in Peiping today the armed forces "must vigorously build up strength" for the "liberation of Taiwan [Formosa]."
DETROIT, July 16 -- An eleven-year dream of a beautiful and utilitarian civic center in downtown Detroit is close to reality.

IF such be his purpose this summer's tourist in Europe will find a rich fare of special exhibitions. Whichever way he turns he is bound to come across some exceptional concentration of works of art -- normally scattered far and wide -- assembled temporarily to celebrate an anniversary, to make an art historical point or merely to draw the crowd.

VERNAL, Utah -- If the idea of sailing a rubber boat down a remote Western River that cuts through some of the most strikingly beautiful canyon scenery in the world appeals to you, you had better make arrangements now.

MADRID, July 16 -- Spain's third national Workers' Congress ended today. About 700 delegates representing 8,000,000 workers approved resolutions recommending adequate legislation to improve their condition.

Seven homers, four by the visitors, added to the excitement at the Polo Grounds yesterday. A wild pitch ended it, as Ruben Gomez, a pinch-runner, carried across the "gift" run that resulted in an 8-7 Giants' victory over the Milwaukee Braves.

RAWLINS, Wyo., July 16 (AP) -- Two guards were dismissed on orders of state officials tonight as Gov. Milward Simpson and Warden Deane Miller sought to quell an uprising by about seventy-five armed prisoners of 277 at the Wyoming Penitentiary.

FOR those with a propensity for woodworking and sundry affiliations, four pamphlets, three of them at no cost, are available. For the young members of the household a six-teen-page booklet offers twelve different plans for a wide range of projects, from a boat to a sandpaper stick with step-by-step instructions.
DETROIT, July 16 (UP) -- The United Auto Workers, C. I. O., asked Congress today to investigate the recent steel price increase and an expected rise in automobile prices.

RICHARD VAUGHAN'S brand of gloom is Welsh. Those who have not read his first novel -- about an ancient feud between the Carmarthen-shire families of Ellis and Peele, a story to which "Son of Justin" is a direct sequel -- may find themselves confused as to what happened at the end of that book between two men and a bull in a barn.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 16 -- A Negro South African boy who has won a scholarship to Kent School at Kent, Conn., is having trouble obtaining official permission to leave South Africa.
MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., July 16 -- The Un-Americanism Committee of the Westchester County American Legion tonight assailed a series of six pamphlets being distributed by the League of Women Voters.
BONN, Germany, July 16 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer warned the Western powers today that the German people would never accept an East-West security system based on the partition of their country.

THE partition of India and the creation of the cleft state of Pakistan in 1947 was Jinnah's doing. The British Labor Government did not want it. Mahatma Gandhi considered it "blasphemy," but Mohammed Ali Jinnah insisted on a Moslem nation and he won.
Reorder activity was noted last week in the girls' and teen wear markets, with back-to-school selling at retail under way in some sections of the country.
M. Le Corbusier's new church ("A Church by Le Corbusier," July 3) prompts me to think of the future. And, frankly, I am worried.

KANSAS CITY, July 16 (UP) -- A pair of wild African elephants were reported on their way, in crates, to Kansas City today from Vero Beach, Fla., to become official mascots of the Kansas City Athletics Baseball team.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's personal interpreter at the Geneva conference, Lieut. Col. Vernon Walters, has a command of foreign tongues that the President put to use before he reaches the White House.
GENEVA, July 16 -- There is a shortage of new ideas, rooms and taxis at the summit, but otherwise everything has been arranged.

THIS is an inside story of the dark, early days of the Eisenhower Administration -- dark days illumined by the frightening flames of burning books. Martin Merson was the right-hand man to Robert L. Johnson, who left the serene position of president of Temple University to serve under Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in the bitterly disillusioning position of director of the State Department's International Information Administration.

MAHWAH, N. J., July 16 -- A new era for both the Ford Motor Company and this town just below the New York-New Jersey state line opened today.

President Juan D. Peron of Argentina, like most other modern dictators, has always taken the position that he did not like to dictate. Like the late Premier Mussolini and perhaps even the late Premier Stalin, his position has been that the dictating he did was in the public interest.
GENEVA, July 16 -- The stars of the Soviet Union's delegation to the Big Four conference in Geneva will be making a delayed entrance on the conference scene. scene.

Retail merchants, who have spent the last ten years pursuing their customers into the suburbs, now find they have a pressing problem back in the city. How are they going to hold onto business at their main downtown stores?

SOME film subjects are talked about, announced, canceled, postponed and resurrected so often that it comes as a surprise when signs appear to indicate that they are really going to be made. For years "Moby Dick," "War and Peace" and "Around the World in Eighty Days" were in that misty category, but all have now emerged into the clear light of production.

HONOLULU, July 16 (UP) -- Frank Hooykaas of Los Angeles, owner of the schooner Constellation, danced a Dutch jig of victory today when informed the sloop Nalu II would not better his boat's time in the annual trans-Pacific yacht race.

PARIS, July 16 -- The great port city of Casablanca, torn by race riots since Thursday evening, was declared a military region today. It was placed under martial law with Brig. Gen. Andre Franchi, a veteran of the Indochinese fighting, in command.
A series of thunderstorms skipped through scattered sections of New York City and its environs yesterday afternoon. One was blamed for a fatal automobile accident on the Manhattan Bridge.

AS calm And serene a garb as a man can wear is the standard gray flannel suit of commerce, a habiliment supposed to betoken solidity of character tastefully touched with quiet nonchalance. Calmness and serenity, however, frantically elude Tom Rath, the gray-flannel man of Sloan Wilson's book, and his inward solidity of character peeps forth, in quite pat fashion, only at the end of the narrative.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M., July 16 -- The public got a glimpse here today of the forbidden city of Los Alamos where the first atomic bomb was developed. It is here that Western supremacy in thermonuclear weapons has been maintained.
HARTFORD, Conn., July 16 -- Hartford soon will give up the municipal airport it has had for more than thirty years.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -- Senator Henry M. Jackson asserted today that production of United States atomic weapons and planes must be stepped up to nullify the threat of Russian air-atomic domination by 1960.

RETURNING after many years and other occupations to an old hobby, Bernard Gooch manages to exemplify in these essays the amateur naturalist very nearly at his best. His book is not unworthy to be put beside the first English classic of its genre, Gilbert White's "The Natural History of Selborne."
ELIZABETH, N. J., July 16 -- The Union County Park Commission has deferred final leasing arrangements with the Army on a Nike site in the Watchung Reservation near Summit.
ROME, July 16 -- Pope Pius XII informed by an aide today of the announcement made by the Budapest radio about Cardinal Mindszenty.
THOUGH many sportsmen are concerned over the fall hunting prospects, reports on big game, upland game and waterfowl indicate that hunters have reason to be optimistic.

IN any discussion among parents of adolescents, sooner or later one question is almost certain to arise: What shall we do when we know our children are doing things we don't approve of? Shall we voice our objections? Or shall we accept the behavior on the theory that in this way at least we avoid secrecy and deceit?
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 16 -- Drastic measures to control runaway inflation were announced today. They came as a climax to serious labor troubles that threatened to paralyze the nation's economy.
BERLIN, July 16 (AP) -- Soviet Premier Bulganin said tonight he hoped the Geneva conference would be an important step on the road to German unity.

THERE was a happy time, before the miracle of nylon, dacron and orlon had simplified that part of the packing problem, when the guide-book selection presented no difficulty. Baron Karl Baedeker was the inevitable choice.
VERNON, N. Y., July 16 (AP) Adios Harry paced the mile in a record 1:55 flat tonight at Vernon Downs and followed with a second heat in 1:57 to win the $26,000 American Pacing Derby.
CHICAGO, July 16 -- An unidentified New York woman, mother of an illegitimate child, testified today at the Senate judiciary subcommittee hearing into adoption practices.
BUENOS AIRES, July 16 -- The leaders of Opposition parties said today they were waiting to see whether President Juan D. Peron's speech yesterday was "straight talk or doubletalk."

AFTER years of making Broadway sit up and take notice, one of our most distinguished playwrights is seriously eying the screen. Very shortly, Arthur Miller expects to submit a general outline of a drama dealing with urban juvenile delinquency to a producer-distributor unit that already has expressed enthusiasm over the project.

One of the newest, most recondite and expensive of American pursuits is the collecting and cosseting of what are known as "classic cars." A classic car is difficult of definition, but it is usually taken to mean an automobile of outstanding beauty and engineering, produced between the years 1925 and 1942.
PIERRE, S. D., July 16 -- South Dakota's 22,000 public employes had something to sign this month beside their pay checks.
The Fabre Line has withdrawn from the Gulf Mediterranean Ports Conference.

The usually vexed issue of protocol is not likely to impede the work of the Geneva conference. The Big Four foreign ministers reached agreement on the form of the meeting when they discussed arrangements at San Francisco last month.
LIBREVILLE, French Equatorial Africa, July 16 (UP) -- Dr. Albert Schweitzer boarded the liner Foucald for France today.

CHANGES in daytime television are moving at a brisk pace. The National Broadcasting Company revealed plans last week for an evening-style dramatic series to be presented on a Monday-through-Friday basis, in color.

THE Samachsons, authors of "Let's Meet the Theatre," have now come up with a history of the liveliest of the arts -- and a good one, too. Starting with a performance of this decade's newer devices, "theatre-in-the-round," they briskly point out that the scheme goes straight back to antiquity.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- A grant of $59.326 has been awarded the University of Pennsylvania by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis for research to determine the chemical and biological reaction of a cell invaded by a virus.
MOSCOW, July 16 -- Premier Bulganin, Mr. Khrushchev and other members of the Soviet delegation left by air today without fanfare.

Three asteroids discovered by the Russian astronomer G. N. Neujmin nearly twenty years ago have been given Russian names, a privilege that is Neujmin's. The asteroid hitherto known as 1936 FC is to be called Lomonosowa, in honor of the Russian physicist and astronomer, Mikhail Vasilevich Lomonosov, who died in 1765.
GENEVA, July 16 -- President Eisenhower arrived here tonight in a hopeful mood for next week's conference with leaders of Britain, France and the Soviet Union.
The controversial Dixon-Yates contract came full circuit last week.

THIS unusual but rather wooden novel begins when Alvaro de Mendana, a seven-teenth-century Spanish nobleman, "after eighty-five days of voyaging where no men of Europe had sailed before" discovers a group of islands.
Russia will be represented for the first time in the biennial tournament for the junior chess championship of the world. The third in the series is scheduled to begin in Antwerp next Thursday.

TOKYO, July 15 -- Increasing opposition in Japan to the extension of United States air bases and to the continued presence of ground troops is forcing a policy statement on the matter by the Government.

Last October this department called attention to experiments that were being made at Brookhaven in the treatment of brain tumors by bombarding the patient's head with neutrons or gamma rays generated in a reactor. The work done at Brookhaven indicated that when borax is injected into a brain tumor the result is often remarkable.
VIENNA, July 16 -- Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty of Hungary has been "allowed to interrupt his term of imprisonment," according to an announcement tonight by the Budapest radio.

KANSAS CITY, July 16 (UP) -- Johnny Sain, former Yankee pitcher, received his unconditional release from the Kansas City Athletics today. He probably will retire from baseball as he wanted to do at the start of the season.

Security traders last week were reminded of the well-known fact that stocks can go down as well as up. Efforts to extend a modest rally met with a wave of profit-taking that toppled prices to new lows for the movement. But as the downward course of prices continued, activity began to wither.

EARLY last fall, WATV (Channel 13), yielding to the persuasive arguments of a group of video program promoters, introduced as one of its regular features a Jewish cultural program. The presentation was mostly in English, with only a smattering of Yiddish.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va. -- Colonial Williamsburg, that fabulous reincarnation of eighteenth-century America, has a motto: "That the future may learn from the past." It greets you almost everywhere you turn here, in leaflets given to tourists, in the guidebooks, and in the reports of the corporations set up by John D. Rockefeller Jr. to restore the setting and much of the daily activity of one of the most significant periods in American history.

The Western Bloc. One-third of the land areas of the globe and two-fifths of the world's population form the Western bloc of nations that will be represented at Geneva by the United States, Britain and France. Although they include members of all races, native to all the continents, they consist mainly of peoples who have been the heirs to or have come strongly under the influence of Western culture.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- The painting, "Deliverance of Leyden from the Siege of the Spaniards under Valdez, 1574," will be shipped next Wednesday to the museum of Rijksuni-versiteit in Leyden, Holland, as a gift of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts.

ALBANY -- New York State is producing a rich variety of historical celebrations this summer. Since the first spring week-end when the most optimistic chamber of commerce could hope for warm weather, the calendar has shown a festival of some kind somewhere almost every week, and the schedule will go on this way well into September.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The tourists who cram the vast Capitol building these days from early morning until the doors close at night may not know it, but when they see Representatives and Senators they are seeing men in the grip of a serious disease.

THERE was a time when the pruning of climbing roses was a fairly simple matter. Then most of the varieties had small and clustered flowers, typical of the ramblers. But first climbers with larger blooms on long stems and then the introduction of everblooming varieties complicated the pruning problem.
New York and Brooklyn department store sales last week continued to run ahead of year-ago volume levels.
The senior master of the Holland-America Line will bring his last command -- the passenger liner Noordam -- into New York tomorrow.
WHAT is the best way to make a pie crust? The answer to this question is important to home cooks, at this season, when fruits are abundant and at their peak of flavor for pies.

COMPILED by the editors of Look magazine, this photograph-and-caption tour of the United States is an example of pictorial journalism at its best -- as well as a living illustration of what Stephen Vincent Benet once called the "strong and diverse heart" of America.

NO man ever had a more fitting middle name than Jerome I. Case, the threshing machine king. The "I" stood for Increase, and the man's significance can be measured by the astonishing increases his bounteous farm machines and others like them have heaped up during the last hundred years -- increases in food production, in number of farms, in leisure and well-being for farm families, in population itself.

DANZIG, Poland, July 12 -- White pleasure steamers that run along the Polish Baltic coast leave for short cruises from Gdynia from the long and brightly painted pier at Zoppot (Sopot). In addition to the attraction of sea winds on a hot day, they give the passengers a chance to see a good stretch of the coast that the Poles obtained from the Germans.

EARLY summer is a busy time for anyone who grows gladiolus. The care given them during the growing period will in large measure determine not only the quality of the flower that will be harvested this season but the quality of the corm that will be dug in fall for next year's planting.
COLUMBIA, S. C., July 16 (UP) -- A South Carolina school district official said today that schools would operate on a segregated basis for at least another year.

A wild pitch with two out and the bases loaded in the ninth inning enabled the Giants to defeat the Milwaukee Braves, 8 to 7, yesterday. The New Yorkers extended their winning streak to five games. Duke Snider's second home run of the game gave the Dodgers a 5-4 triumph over the Cincinnati Redlegs.

NEPTUNE, N. J. -- To the list of new resort attractions along the Jersey shore add Storyland, a fifty-acre amusement area here in this small community adjoining Asbury Park. Laid out at a cost of more than $600,000, Storyland contains reproductions of scenes from popular fairy tales, Mother Goose rhymes, the Arabian nights, Biblical stories and American history.

Two appeals for the abolition of war were made by scientists last week. One was addressed by Bertrand Russell on behalf of nine distinguished scientists, including the late Albert Einstein and five other Nobel laureates; the other came from eighteen Nobel laureates who were attending a meeting of chemists at Mainau, Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia announces it is impressed by the optimistic predictions concerning the 1955 vacation season. At resort areas along the Delaware and New Jersey coasts and vacation spots in the Pennsylvania mountains, local bankers and business men say the hotels, cottages and apartments received many more inquiries than last season.

Accused of possessing a zip gun that assertedly killed a 14-year-old boy Thursday night, William Read, 16, of 462 East 144th Street, the Bronx, was held in $2,000 bail in Bronx Court yesterday. Magistrate Abraham Bloch set a hearing for tomorrow.

THE jacket blurb for "One Man's India" promises that Arthur Stratton's account of his peregrinations through India in the winter of 1952 is "not a matter of tiger hunts, glittering maharajahs, floods or famines'' but "is about ordinary Indian life * * * among the people and their monuments."

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- John B. Hollister, new foreign-aid chief, believes foreign-aid programs will be necessary "as long as there is no revolutionary change in the Soviet Union and the satellite countries."

Stephens College (Columbia, Mo.) is planning a new course for all entering students which will be taught over a closed television circuit. It will put to full-scale use a new teaching approach that may have important implications for education generally.
GENEVA, July 16 -- The neutral Swiss, who habitually hold themselves aloof from the affairs of the great powers, assumed responsibility today for the security of the Big Four chiefs of government.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 16 -- The New Haven Railroad said today that service was nearing normal on its lines here for the first time since the wreck of the Federal Express on Thursday.

THE freakish state of airline travel between this country and Mexico has created a nasty little diplomatic situation. Efforts to negotiate a bilateral over-all air pact between the two countries appear to be at a standstill, and tempers are beginning to wear.
ATHENS, July 16 -- Archbishop Makarios, Ethnarch of Cyprus, forecast today the failure of British-Greek-Turkish talks scheduled to follow the Geneva Big Four conference.
There are at present under consideration in the Senate three proposals to change the method of electing the President -- the Daniel-Humphrey, Kefauver and Mundt-Dirksen resolutions.
RALEIGH, N. C., July 16 (AP) -- Trustees of Saint Augustine's College have selected as president a man who was born on the campus.
AFTER five years of fanatical single - mindedness, Lawrence Langner has opened his Shakespeare Festival Theatre at Stratford, Conn. -- the third Stratford now dedicated to the Elizabethan tradition.

United Cerebral Palsy of New York City received $919,464 in contributions last year. This was the highest annual amount ever received by the organization, Robert I. Rogin, president of the group, said.

BOTH the quantity and quality of the art treasures to be seen in Florence make it a city of unquestionable distinction and superiority. Here, unique examples of fine painting, sculpture and architecture bear witness to a tradition of creativity and taste matched by few cities in the world.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- An attorney for Maynard F. Clough said today a Government report on zinc stockpiling apparently was prepared "for the deliberate purpose of misleading Congress."

He taught at Harvard Medical School and had a rich and rewarding life in his chosen profession. He was also a discerning nature student and his occasional essays in the Atlantic Monthly were warmly received.

A twelve-man Soviet agricultural delegation headed by Vladimir V. Matskevich arrived in New York yesterday. Mr. Matskevich is a close associate of Nikita S. Khrushchev, secretary of the Communist party in the Soviet Union.
More than a score of Protestant Episcopal Churches in and near the metropolitan area banded together yesterday to help a South African Anglican priest.

IN Connecticut, toll increases on the Merritt Parkway and Wilbur Cross Parkway have been in effect since the first of the month. A COMPLETE list of the open - air music festivals and concert series given each summer in America would be an imposing one. It would be typically American, perhaps, in nothing more than the varied character of these events, the publics they attract, and the various methods pursued in organizing them.

However, the poll will give an official stamp to the operation and perhaps make more folks pay attention.

THE Rt. Hon. Richard Gardiner Casey, C. H., D. S. O., M. C., will shortly be 65 years old. Born in Brisbane, he was educated at Melbourne University and Cambridge as an engineer. In World War I he enlisted in the ranks and rose to be a major.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A labor union has put an international "hot-cargo" label on an airline -- the first in aviation history, the union says.

AN automobile that will withstand a severe head-on accident so as to prevent injury to the occupants is the objective of a special research program under way at the Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory in Buffalo.

THIS is Elizabeth Bishop's second book, but over half of it is a complete reprinting of the thirty poems of her first book, "North and South," which appeared in 1946. There are eighteen new poems. A handsome number of these are as excellent as were some in her first book.
The struggle to save the American whisky industry from something approaching financial crisis resolved itself during the week into an effort to separate the sinners from the publicans.

A NEW "squeeze" between prices merchants pay for their goods and those they charge customers may confront the storekeepers of the land before the first fall frost strikes. Higher factory and distributor prices for household appliances are in the wind.
MASTIC BEACH, L. I., July 16 -- In the sweltering 86-degree heat this afternoon 3,000 residents took part in a mass ground-breaking ceremony.

NORFOLK, Va., July 16 -- The Norfolk division of the College of William and Mary, the Chamber of Commerce and the Supreme Allied Command Atlantic are developing joint plans for a North Atlantic Treaty Organization seminar as an experiment in better international understanding.

ASCOT, England, July 16 -- The French colt Vimy, a 10-to-1 chance, won the King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes by a head today. His victory ended a four-year English monopoly on this nation's richest horse race.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- William Woodward's Nashau, the 3-10 favorite, had to go all-out in the stretch today to win the $148,500 Arlington Classic. He scored by a half-length over Clifford Mooers' Traffic Judge.

OVER at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre the musical "Damn Yankees" is doing a lovely job of beating still another emissary of the devil, the one that is supposed to jab pitchforks into Broadway shows dealing with baseball. Indeed, according to the latest figures, "beating" could be stepped up to something stronger -- like "lacerating."

MANY people thought that David Ben-Gurion made a noble sacrifice when he retired as Israel's Premier at the end of 1953 and moved to Sde Boker, a dreary camp of cabins, fenced with barbed wire, on a scorched plain in the Negev. But when Ben-Gurion took over the Defense Ministry last February a friend found it was a mistake to congratulate him on his coming back to his Tel Aviv home.

THE new Linhof Super Technika Special 2 1/4x3 1/4 camera is becoming available in this country, according to announcement by Kling Photo Corporation, 235 Fourth Avenue, the importer. Features include a wider bellows and wider front opening than the regular model in order to accommodate the three new lenses designed for the camera by Carl Zeiss Optical Works.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 16 -- Bob Sweeny of Sands Point reached the final in the Long Island Amateur Golf championship today. Although he has won the British amateur and last year gained the final of the United States amateur and the New York State tournament, this marked the first time he moved into the title round of this event.

CLEVELAND, July 16 -- Art Houtteman allowed four scattered hits as he hurled the Cleveland Indians to a 4-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox today. He faced only thirty-one batters. Larry Doby and Gene Woodling hit homers for the Indians.

A NEW thing in the history of literature is happening in the U. S. Writers are everywhere in the universities, creating their own books and helping young talents create theirs. But many people suspect all this activity. Is it possible that the air of the campus is like a poisonous gas -- one whiff is tolerable, but prolonged breathing can kill?

Several recent events, especially in Asia, have again pointed up the problem of land reform and land use. Since this problem is directly related to what men eat, and whether they eat enough, it remains the most vital single consideration to more than half of the persons in this world.
MEXICO CITY, July 15 -- A combination of drought and a reduction in planting has had a serious effect on two main food items, corn and beans, for Mexico and virtually all Central America.

The Roman Catholic school system in New York City is suffering acute growing pains, according to the annual report made by Msgr. John Paul Haverty, Superintendent of Schools for the Archdiocese of New York. Elementary and high school enrollment in the Archdocese schools now totals approximately 200,000.
GENEVA, July 16 (AP) -- Following is the texe of President Eisenhower's statement on his arrival at Geneva:
A $6 million-a-year automotive maintenance chemical business that overflowed from a bathtub back in 1909 is headed today by a young man who has had to learn its ins and outs in four crowded years.

While the great powers' "summit" representatives are discussing political co-existence at Geneva this week, another international meeting in the Swiss city will be busied with concerns of the world's backward nations and how foreign private capital might help them.

BALBOA, C.Z., July 16 -- Commercial traffic through the Panama reached a record high during the fiscal year 1955, which just closed. A total of 7,997 sea-going commercial ships of 300 tons or more transited the waterway.

It was Italian Night at the Lewisohn Stadium on Saturday and an audience of 11,000 turned out for the program, which consisted chiefly of operatic arias. Alfredo Antonini, who is the customary conductor for this particular "night," was on the podium.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 17 -Thailand's move to have the Manila pact council at Bangkok discuss the Communist threat in Laos has caused resentment among Laotian officials.
ROME, July 17 -- Pope Pius XII is understood to have sent a special blessing today to Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty.
A. Schulman Inc of Akron, Ohio, dealer in rubber and plastics, executive offices in new Tishman building at 460 Park Ave -- Williams Co, brokers.
PITTSBURGH, July 17 (UP) -The St. Louis Cardinals, bolstered by Rip Repulski's two homers and a run-scoring single by Bob Stephenson, defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 9 -- 8, in twelve innings today.

The situation in Morocco, which has just led to the loss of many lives in a senseless outburst of rioting, is an inheritance from a belated nineteenth-century colonialism. It is none the less depressing because everybody, including the French Government, recognizes that colonialism is dead.
GENEVA, July 17 -- Forty men will sit down in the Palace of Nations tomorrow to begin the four-power conference.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia today reiterated his previously expressed determination to remain out of the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination next year. He was one of the strongest contenders at the convention in 1952.

Segregated housing is today's crucial issue" in the field of civil liberties, the Rev. Dr. Galen R. Weaver declared yesterday. He is race relations secretary of the Council for Social Action of the Congregational Christian Churches.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The management of Libby, McNeill Libby, nation-wide food concern, sent a letter to stockholders today urging them not to be deceived by "misleading" proxy material being distributed by an opposition group that has started a contest for control of the company.
KANSAS CITY, July 17 (UP) -- Frank (Spec) Shea of the Washington Senators, making his first start of the season, blanked the Kansas City Athletics, 4 -- 0, today with three-hit hurling.
Americans are incorrigible optimists. We recognize no insuperable obstacles in the way of our desires or ideals. Our nation was founded and built on faith.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- The Democratic National Chairman said today the Eisenhower Administration had served "certain selfish interests."

This ranting every holiday weekend about auto deaths is ridiculous. The plain truth is we all feel that these collective deaths are not too dear a price to pay for going about in cars; otherwise we'd take the obvious steps to cut them.
DISNEYLAND must be a facinating place to visit, but the trip must be easier for sightseers unburdened by twenty-nine television cameras and 10,000 feet of coaxial cable.
A Greenwich Village property at the northwest corner of Waverly Place and Gay Street has been bought for investment by the Lusol Realty Corporation. Harry Klein, real estate operator, was the seller.
How investments in common stock are helping to fatten labormanagement pension funds was indicated in a survey made public yesterday.

Susan Strasberg, a young newcomer to Broadway, has been entrusted with the title role in "Diary of Anne Frank." Getting such an assignment, especially in her first Broadway appearance, represents quite an achievement for the talented daughter of Lee Strasberg, director, who is one of the pillars of the Actors Studio, an organization dedicated to lacquering up and coming performers.

Young television followers who feel let down as their favorite cowboy, zoo, puppet or space program flickers off the air can now do something to amend such a state of affairs. They need only turn the pages of a new little leaflet to discover many suggestions for reading fare on the same TV subjects they enjoy.

IN the autumn of 1953 Tom and Betsy Rath were worried. Tom was 33. They had been married for twelve years with four years taken out for war. They had three small children, a shabby little house on Greentree Avenue in Westport and not enough money. They didn't have enough money to repair the house, to educate the children, to replace their old jalopy.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- James F. Byrnes said today the Big Four conference in Geneva this week "should result in lessening" East-West tensions.
ATLANTA, July 17 -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati and Mrs. Dorothy Head Knode of Forest Hills, Queens, are the new national clay court tennis champions.

The Treasury has finished its midsummer financing with results that are more than satisfactory. But perhaps the most interesting feature of this operation was not its comparative success, but the fact that it showed what can be done when the Treasury really sets its mind to shaping its program so it will fit into the policies of the Federal Reserve authorities.
Six pamphlets being distributed by the League of Women Voters that were criticized by the Un-Americanism Committee of the Westchester County American Legion were defended yesterday.
MINEOLA, L. I., July 17 -Two more men were arrested today in the investigation of a ring that reputedly supplied heroin to race track exercise boys.
MILWAUKEE, July 17 (UP) -Cary Middlecoff, Masters champion and former national open titleholder, won the $35,000 Miller open today.

GENEVA, July 17 (AP) -- After President Eisenhower and Secretary Dulles returned from church today they decided to relax a bit and strolled around the twenty-five-acre grounds of General Eisenhower's villa.
New York State's mental hospitals are 25 to 30 per cent overcrowded.

The Board of Estimate faces the decision this week whether to proceed, despite the cost, with construction of a new Youth House, to be situated in the South Bronx, for temporary detention of delinquent boys. The lowest bids submitted for this project, to house 250, were for a total cost of $5,341,930.
Domestic cotton prices finished sharply lower last week after an extended period of movement within a narrow range.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 17 -More than 300 sailing craft of assorted design, ranging from the tiny Penguins to the twelvemeter racing sloops, turned out for the second day of Larchmont Race Week this afternoon. But there was no wind. So there were no races.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17 -- United States scientists will get the major share of time at the United Nations atoms-for-peace conference that opens in Geneva Aug. 8.

THEY will be holding a "night" for Pee Wee Reese at Ebbets Field on Friday, the eve of the Little Colonel's thirtysixth birthday. But Pete Reiser won't be present. Pistol Pete will be off in the bushes somewhere, managing the Thomasville, Ga., team in the lowest of the minor leagues.
A 15-year-old girl was pulled to safety last night after threatening for forty-five minutes, the police said, to jump from the roof of her Manhattan home.
Commercial fishing, America's oldest industry, may get "its rightful share of attention" in the form of a National Fish Week.
Despite a large deficit last year, the 103-year-old Mount Sinai Hospital is planning a major expansion.

RAWLINS, Wyo., July 17 (AP) -- Two guards were dismissed and seventy-five rioting convicts won a promise of no reprisals today from Gov. Milward L. Simpson before abandoning a fifteen-hour rebellion at the Wyoming State Penitentiary.

LENOX, Mass., July 17 -- The concert by the Boston Symphony Orchestra that Charles Munch conducted at Tanglewood this afternoon demonstrated anew the conductor's affinity for French music and his great skill in bringing it to life.

The 3-year-old of today is no longer content with a summer drink of colored, flavored, cooled and sweetened water. The drink must be frozen into a cube, to be half-consumed before it slips and falls to the pavement. The ice-cream stick, too, must be enlivened with baseball ticket premiums and other inducements.
QUANTICO, Va., July 17 -The Marines have "landed" with Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson. He thinks they can do anything.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 17 -- Bob Sweeny of Sands Point, who was the British amateur champion in 1937, won the Long Island amateur golf title today.
PARIS, July 17 -- The vicious circle of Moslem terrorism and European counter-terrorism brought further killing and arson today to Casablanca, the commercial capital of French Morocco.

GENEVA, July 17 -- Billy Graham, American evangelist, who for five months has been exhorting Europeans to find God through Jesus Christ, directed the same appeal to the Big Four heads of government today. If they and the rest of mankind do not do so, he warned, the judgment of God will fall upon the world.

The Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Inc., has appointed Miss A. Bernice Quimby as executive director. The federation, central Protestant welfare organization for Greater New York, provides services for 203 agencies.
LONDON, July 17 -- Churchgoers over Great Britain prayed today for the success of the Four-Power meeting opening in Geneva tomorrow.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- A twin-engined Braniff Airways plane crashed today at Chicago's Midway Airport. Twentytwo persons were killed and twenty-one injured. Quick action by airfield attendants, the police and firemen kept the fatalities from being greater.
GENEVA, July 17 (AP) -- Following is a translation from the Russian of a statement made by Premier Bulganin today:

Although the problems of the Far East are not on the agenda of the Geneva meeting, they remain with us and are necessarily a part of the thinking with which we await the conference. The past week is one in which the disposition of our strength in the Far East has been under continuous and close scrutiny.

The State Probation Commission will re-examine its advisory opinion that the Children's Courts here are violating the state anti-discrimination law in appointing probation officers by separate Catholic, Protestant and Jewish lists.
HONOLULU, July 17 -- The Hawaii Department of the American Legion voted this week-end to disown the local Forty-and-Eight Society because of its racial policies.
The Soviet Communist party's Central Committee has published new information indicating the nature of domestic economic pressures being felt by the Soviet Government.

Union leaders will meet in Washington this week to try to pick a name for the merged labor movement that will be born this December. What to call the new group has become a point of strain between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
State Senator Alfred E. Santangelo, Democrat of Manhattan, urged yesterday an investigation to determine if there was any collusion or waste in the construction of the New York State Thruway.
Roger Craig and Don Bessent, who won for the Dodgers in their major-league pitching debuts yesterday, are Southerners who were born less than a month apart in the winter of 1931.
A special WRCA-TV broadcast spotlighting recent moves to encourage youngsters to participate more widely in sports will be presented on Saturday from 7 to 7:30 P. M.
The man who was the first choice of United States trade unionists to carry on a worldwide unionization drive has turned down the job.

JONES BEACH, L. I., July 17 -- Even the blase New Yorkers who have long since stopped noticing highway billboards had their attention drawn to the huge signs that were installed at strategic points along this state park beach yesterday.

The Albanian weekly, Dielli, the oldest Albanian publication in America, has been under my editorship for the last eleven years. It has a national and liberal tradition and as such is heartily disliked by the Communists.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox climbed to within a game and a half of the league-leading New York Yankees by sweeping a doubleheader from Baltimore, 3 -- 2 and 5 -- 4 today.
TORONTO, July 17 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian Oil Companies, Ltd., has offered to buy Anglo-Canadian Company, Ltd., in a transaction with an indicated current value of about $23,500,000.

AMMAN, Jordan, July 17 (AP) -- There are considerable development possibilities in Jordan, said Dr. Pieter Lieftinck, just before leaving here for Washington Friday afternoon. He headed the World Bank mission that has been conducting an economic survey in Jordan for four months at the Government's request.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 17 -- Henry Fonda and Reginald Rose have formed a partnership to produce a motion picture of the latter's television play, "Twelve Angry Men." Mr. Fonda will star in the drama about the deliberations of a jury in a murder trial.

GENEVA, July 17 -- Precisely ten years have elapsed since the chiefs of the victor Governments met in Potsdam to discuss the consequences of the Second World War. France has been admitted to the concert of Powers. Truman, Attlee and Churchill have been retired by politics and age.

PERCY GRIFFITH, a saltwater man with long sea duty behind him, does marine patrol now, on foot, landlubber fashion. He has served summonses to a Queen (the Mary), to the proud Ile de France, to fat-bellied ferryboats and to the harbor commoners, the tugboats. He has five-borough jurisdiction.
HONOLULU, July 17 (AP) -The thirty-nine-foot ketch Staghound sailed home today a virtual certainty to win its second straight victory in the 2,225mile Los Angeles-to-Hawaii yacht race.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 17 -- The Screen Actors Guild is weighing a call to its general membership for a strike vote against motion picture and television film producers for refusing to "negotiate an equitable, new, collective bargaining contract."
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 17 -The police are baffled by a series of bombings in Tel Aviv.
The Rev. Dr. Richard Allen Hildebrand yesterday attributed widespread crime in Harlem to "adult delinquency."

Commercial paper outstanding on the books of dealers at the end of June amounted to $572,000,000, unchanged from the end of May but down $107,000,000 from June 30 of last year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported over the week-end.
Millions of Americans bowed their heads in solemn supplication yesterday for the success of the Big Four conference in Geneva.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., July 17 (UP) -- Operation Gyroscope, the replacement by air of an Army unit overseas with fresh combatready troops, ended here today. The last plane returning troops of the 187th Airborne Regimental Combat Team landed at nearby Camp Mackall.

GENEVA, July 17 -- The Swiss Government is a superb host to the Big Four conference -- courteous, agreeable, careful about security and protocol -- but the Swiss people are not only neutral toward all major participants but almost indifferent.
The Standard-Vacuum Oil Company (Stanvac) announced yesterday that it had cleared a major hurdle in its efforts to search for crude petroleum in the Philippine Islands.
The recent history of downtown Brooklyn has been written by steam shovels and riveting guns.
Princess Astrid of Norway will smash the traditional bottle of champagne across the bow of the Norwegian America Line passenger vessel Bergensfjord today.
GENEVA, July 17 (AP) -- Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, Defense Minister, was under the control of a United States Air Force captain for three hours today.

GENEVA, July 17 -- Sir Anthony Eden will ask the Soviet Union tomorrow to consider a detailed plan for Germany's reunification in freedom under security arrangements intended to remove the Soviet's fear of new Teutonic aggression.
DETROIT, July 17 -- An electrifying steal of home by Earl Torgeson in the tenth inning gave the Tigers a 6 -- 5 victory over the Yankees today before a roaring crowd of 33,301.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -The Federal Trade Commission announced two actions today in the cordage industry.
It was the same story in each half of the double-header at Ebbets Field yesterday: the Dodgers won behind the pitching of a 24-year-old right-hander who was making his majorleague debut.
LONDON, July 17 -- In the past week the stock markets received two major shocks and one minor one.

ZURICH, July 17 -- What the Paris newspapers are calling "the French-Swiss cold war" is in reality a deadlock. It began when the trade agreement between the two countries expired on July 1 after the failure of negotiations that began on May 5 to draft a new agreement.

The four-story apartment house accommodating thirty-one families at 454 Riverdale Avenue, in Yonkers, has been sold by the Estate Securities Company, real estate operators, to Max B. Kane. Louis Nowikas was the broker in the transaction.
Meritorious service citations for 169 members of the Police Department are announced in general orders being issued today by Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams.

LONDON, July 17 -- Twentynine United States and European professors who have been discussing ghosts, hauntings, telepathic dreams, apparitions and similar phenomena have agreed on the need for a worldwide study of a large number of cases.

THE big, dark-red, juicy cherries here from the Northwest will continue in good supply until the middle of next month. The crop is unusually large this year and prices are lower than in most recent summers.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- In four months, the Hoover Commission said today, one of its study groups has cut enough red tape to save the Government and business $15,274,800 a year.

CLEVELAND, July 17 (AP) -A Boston Red Sox rally in the ninth inning fell short, and the Cleveland Indians took the second game of a double-header today, 6 -- 5. The Red Sox blanked the Indians in the opener, 6 -- 0, on Tom Brewer's three-hit pitching.

GENEVA, July 17 -- President Eisenhower, Prime Minister Eden of Britain and Premier Faure of France reached full agreement today on the broad strategy -- but not on all the tactics -- of their historic meeting with the leaders of the Soviet Union beginning tomorrow.
SHAVEI ZION, Israel, July 17 -- Gov. Averell Harriman of New York, who formerly directed Marshall Plan aid in Europe, looked today into ways in which the United States is helping Israel.

GENEVA, July 17 (UP) -- President Eisenhower attended church today on the eve of the Big Four conference. He listened with rapt attention to a sermon warning against "dogmatic absolution or flabby surrender."
BUENOS AIRES, July 17--President Juan D. Peron displayed impatience today with Opposition political leaders for not answering his call for internal peace on his terms.

Based on testimony before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, The New York Times of June 25, 1955, states that thirty-four foreign language publications with a total circulation of 137,000 are said to follow the Communist line.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -Confidential informants continue to be valuable in effective law enforcement, J. Edgar Hoover said today.

THE Geneva Conference of leaders of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union was the subject last night of special programs presented by the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company.

Summer-weight suits will account for 49 per cent of the initial springs, 1956, orders of men's wear retailers throughout the country, according to a survey by the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. In the 1955 season this group accounted for 44 per cent of the suits purchased by retail outlets.
Caretakers in two Queens cemeteries discovered yesterday that vandals had overturned twenty monuments. One monument was broken. The total damage was estimated at $1,000.

HUNTINGTON, L I., July 17 -- Mrs. H. H. Morris' bay gelding The Gigolo, from New Canaan, Conn., ridden by George Morris, scored 14 points to win the jumper championship in the annual Huntington Y. M. C. A. horse show at Rice Farms today.

Sales and earnings of the Continental Can Company in the six months ended June 30 again established new records for the period, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, board chairman, reported in the semi-annual statement, to be released today.
The reign of coal as king of the ship charter market was extended last week. Prospects now are for a continuance of this trend for at least the balance of the year.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today it has issued a false advertising complaint against "Kary-On," a new tonic concocted as a successor to "Hadacol."
Most American Christians are "muddled and confused" in their thinking about tolerance, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken declared yesterday.

Forty-two thousand persons are now covered by the welfare fund established January, 1949, under collective bargaining agreements between the New York Shipping Association and the independent International Longshoremen's Association.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -Preparations toward this country's bargaining for world tariff concessions are well under way.

Since the end of World War II many important persons have written accounts of their parts in it. In October, Viking Press will publish an American edition of the first volume of "The War Memoirs of General de Gaulle," which is said to speak for France.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Ken Rosewall and Rex Hartwig completely outclassed Esteban Reyes Jr. and Gustavo Palafox today for a 5-0 Australian sweep over Mexico in the first round of the American Zone Davis Cup tennis competition.

PITTSBURGH, July 17 -- Steel producers here and elsewhere foresee little relief in the tight order-delivery situation for the balance of this year, unless there is a break in the booming business picture. At the moment there is no sign of any significant let-down.
HARTFORD, July 14 -- After six months of Abraham A. Ribicoff as Governor, Connecticut is becoming convinced it elected a new type of politician last fall.
GENEVA, Monday, July 18 -Western insistence on linking German unification with security, was made clear to the Soviet leaders by French Premier Edgar Faure at a dinner that ended at 1 A. M. today.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Unusually favorable crop reports from nearly all sections of the country were the dominant factor in the grain futures trade last week. Other influences were felt for only short periods, and outside buying failed to follow the rallies.

Whatever happens at Geneva during this week's summit meeting of the Big Four cannot be called secret diplomacy. The signs yesterday were not only fairly encouraging but also outward and visible. Under a 90-degree sun, with Mont Blanc's snows exercising no perceptible cooling effect, the visiting heads of governments, with their attending assistants and advisers, were freely in the public eye.
Geneva, the scene of the abortive disarmament conferences of almost thirty years ago, is playing host to another meeting that will include a discussion of disarmament.

On June 25 The Times carried a special dispatch from Washington based on the testimony of a Civil Defense worker, Stella Andrassy, before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee. In her testimony she stated that thirty-four foreign language newspapers "consistently followed the Communist line"; that they "tell the most horrible things about America," and were a "defense leak."

ST. JOSEPH, Mich., July 17 (AP) -- Agreement in principle by directors of three corporations to merge their heavy appliance manufacturing businesses in a new multi-million dollar company under the name WhirlpoolSeeger Corporation was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed a new regulation today by which cash proceeds of the sale of certain stock would be set aside and refunded unless 85 per cent of the issue is sold within six months.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Did President Eisenhower and his researchers forget another President's journey nineteen years ago in his remarks opening his speech last Friday? Or is there no conflict between those remarks and the voyage of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt to the Inter-American Conference for Maintenance of Peace at Buenos Aires in December of 1936 ?

The Phillips Petroleum Company has installed a new 1,750 horsepower Diesel-electric drilling rig in its off-shore operation in the Gulf of Mexico. The announcement was made by the Electro-Motive division of the General Motors Corporation, builder of the engine-generator units.
DES MOINES, July 17 -Five thousand Iowans gave a twelve-man Soviet agricultural delegation a cheering welcome on its arrival in the world's corn capital late today.

This past week-end we of Gotham have had the pleasure of welcoming the Soviet officials sent to this country to study American agriculture, particularly corn-hog farming in Iowa and neighboring states. At the same time an American delegation, composed primarily of actual farmers, is now in the Soviet Union to study Soviet agriculture.

One of the reasons the Giants became champions last year was that they were the best doubleheader club in the National League. One of the reasons the Giants are where they are now -- sixteen-and-a-half lengths behind the pace-setting Dodgers -- is that they own one of the poorest twin-bill records in the loop.

The current week promises to be a big one for municipal bond dealers. A total of $230,648,005 of bonds and $61,617,000 of short-term notes, a total of $292,265,005, is scheduled for offering by state and local governments throughout the nation.
LONDON, July 17 -- An international conference on theatre history opened here today with delegates from eighteen countries and observers from fifteen present.
HONG KONG, July 17 -Shanghai's deputy mayor, a veteran Communist, has been arrested and booked for trial as a "counter-revolutionary."

QUANTICO, VA., July 17 -Charles E. Wilson said today that Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway had ignored the roles of reserves and of tactical or small atomic weapons in his attack upon national military policy.
An increase of 78.5 per cent in the last year in loft space vacancy in Manhattan is disclosed in the annual survey of the Real Estate Board of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies hit three late-inning home runs today and overcame a seven-run deficit to defeat the Chicago Cubs, 12 -- 11, in the tenth. The loss was the Cubs' sixth straight.

The average rate of interest charged on short-term business loans by New York City banks in the first half of June was 3.23 per cent, according to a regular quarterly survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Senator Richard B. Russell, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, predicted today that a Senate-House conference would produce a stronger Reserves bill but probably not an "adequate" one.
Whatever natural gas is, each day some 20,000,000 persons and 1,700,000 industrial and commercial customers in this country depend on it as a chief source of energy.
Cornell University has received $750,000 from the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation to establish an Institute of Hospital Administration.
RIO DE JANERO, July 17 -The thirty-sixth International Eucharistic Congress opened today with Roman Catholic pilgrims from at least thirty countries attending.

BONN, Germany, July 17 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer will take up residence tomorrow in Muerren, Switzerland, ninety miles from Geneva. He will remain there while the Big Four heads of government are in session on the German and other problems related to the "cold war."

NEWPORT, R. I., July 17 -It would provide a colorful touch to report that there was dancing in the streets here at the second annual Newport Jazz Festival. But -- truth to tell -- the large audiences, which totaled about 27,000 for the three evening concerts, were pretty nearly as well behaved as a Town Hall audience listening carefully to Bach's "Art of Fugue.
GENEVA, July 17 -- For the first time in his experience, Nikita S. Khrushchev got a glimpse today of the way of life and standard of living that are the products of Western democracy and capitalism.

A site 23,500 square feet at 1816 and 1822 Anthony Avenue in the Bronx has been assembled by Abraham Alkoff for improvement with an apartment house. The assemblage was negotiated by E. Osborne Smith, Inc., as broker.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 17 -- A four-day program will start here tomorrow for 442 American Field Service exchange students who have spent a year in this country.

Two hundred officers and enlisted men of the French battleship Jean Bart attended a solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. They were led by Rear Admiral J. C. F. Champion, assistant to the Chief of Staff of France's armed forces, and Capt. Henri Digard, commander of the Jean Bart.

A record volume of sales lifted half-year net earnings of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company 52.9 per cent to $20,003,633 from $13,082,796 earned in the first six months last year, it is disclosed in a report to be issued today.
LONDON, July 17 (AP) -- A lone voice out of Peiping sounded the only discordant note tonight on the eve of the Big Four summit conference in Geneva.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -Representative Olin E. Teague said today that 381 builders and lenders were under Veterans Administration suspension for violating G. I. housing regulations.
LAWRENCE PEABODY designs modern chairs, but he lives in a farmhouse that is 170 years old and he collects antiques.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Lard futures showed little change last week, the market fluctuating in a narrow range with no special feature. Not much stimulation to trade came from the action in vegetable oils. Continued liberal receipts of hogs, compared with last year, induced selling, as production is heavy.
The city probably will escape a poliomyelitis epidemic this year, Dr. Leona Baumgartner, City Health Commissioner, declared yesterday.
The temperature, which for a week had been trying to get up to 90 degrees, made it with a vengeance yesterday.
