Figures carry a hypnosis of their own. Any man who has ever worked with them knows how often some apparent relationship will lure him into digging data out of improbable sources, making estimates, drawing charts.
Two offerings from Hollywood, both due on Friday, compose the week's list of new film attractions. The programs follow:
PRINCETON, N. J., July 17 -- A Grecian city on the island of Sicily, forgotten for more than 2,000 years, will be unearthed by a team of Princeton University archaeologists.

THAT sometimes controversial matter of routine gets strong support over the decide-as-you-go method of Child-rearing in a collection of "admonitions for adults," prepared by the staff of the Rose Valley School, Moylan-Rose Valley, Pa.

Language at Geneva While they are meeting "at the summit" in Geneva the heads of the four great Powers Converse in three languages -- English, French and Russian. Each delegation has its own interpreters.
I read with interest your excellent editorial on "The Wenzell Report" in The Times of July 11. I feel that much more light is needed in this very important matter.
The Board of Health impounded a frisky, 12-year-old fox terrier last night after receiving an urgent request from a Cincinnati physician that the dog be checked for rabies.
It was on Dec. 31, 1946, that President Truman issued his proclamation declaring that the "hostilities" of World War II had ended.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 18 -- The Larchmont Yacht Club's fifty-seventh race week was resumed today with the skippers of 262 craft happy to get a streaky westerly after yesterday's dead calm. Because of northerly influences, the air was full of holes and spotty, but all except one of the boats finished. Guesswork played a big part in the results.
Negotiations are under way toward recovery of windfall profits made from Government funds in the construction of Farragut Houses, a large Brooklyn cooperative housing development.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Treasury Department announced today plans to refinance $8,477,000,000 of the public debt falling due on Aug. 15.

No recommendation of the Hoover Commission could deserve more general and unqualified approval than the one that has been made some two weeks after the commission has gone out of existence. A study group has devoted its attention to the "wilderness" of Government questionaires and reports and has suggested simplifications that could save the Government more than five million dollars a year and business more than ten.
An Indian village that existed in the lower Mississippi Valley at least 2,700 years ago was described yesterday by Dr. James A. Ford of the American Museum of Natural History.

Professional magicians will appear on a new television program that makes its debut Sunday, July 31, from 7 to 7:30 P. M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System network. Paul Tripp, who conducts "On the Carousel" each Saturday morning over Channel 2, will be the host.
GENEVA, July 18 -- The Soviet Union agreed today to contribute fissionable materials to the international "atoms for peace" pool proposed by President Eisenhower nineteen months ago.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 18 -- Columbia Pictures is contemplating going into television in association with the National Broadcasting Company.
GENEVA, July 18 -- Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, Soviet Minister of Defense, renewed today his wartime friendship with President Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- James M. Mead, outgoing member of the Federal Trade Commission, recommended today that chairmen of Government regulatory agencies be stripped of some of their power.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -Democrats are seeking to pin a "General Grant" label on the Eisenhower Administration.

The four-story business building at 207 West Thirty-eighth Street has been purchased by Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, from Harry Terker. The sale was negotiated by Victor Cohn, president of Williams Co., as broker. E. Louis Gothelf was attorney for the buyer.
GENEVA, July 18 (UP) -The women at the Big Four conference have had to take a back seat to the men. But they have managed to arrange a social program.
BUFFALO, July 18 -- George Meany told trade unionist today that their foes had opened "a new line of attack" through politics and legislation.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The House of Representatives passed today a bill to liberalize social security benefits for women and disabled persons. The bill also would admit more than 200,000 self-employed professional persons to the program.

The nation's steel-makers have scheduled their operations this week at 94.3 per cent of rated capacity, equal to production of 2,276,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute estimated yesterday.

DES MOINES, July 18 -- A twelve-man Russian agricultural delegation got its first glimpse of Iowa's tall corn and fat hogs today and immediately started popping questions about the profit side of successful corn-hog economy.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -The House of Representatives Rules Committee cleared the way today for House consideration of a bill to increase the Federal minimum wage from 75 cents to $1 an hour. The bill is expected to be acted on this week, possibly tomorrow.
LONDON, July 18 -- The striped hyena of North Africa has been saved from threatened extermination by a group of zoologists who took the trouble to find out whether its bad reputation was deserved.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 18 -- The Chief Minister of Northwest Frontier Province was dismissed today for opposing the Central Government's plan for a merger of the provinces, princely states and tribal areas of West Pakistan into single unit.
OTTAWA, July 18 (Reuters) -- While Canada's deep-sea merchant fleet has declined steadilyi since World War II, the fleet of boats plying the Great Lakes is increasing.

NEWARK, July 18 -- City officials, headed by Mayor Leo P. Carlin, civic leaders and company officials were on hand this morning at ground breaking ceremonies for the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company's $10,000,000 home at 520 Broad Street, opposite the Washington Park.

A breakdown in air conditioning almost cost the Bronx Zoo its pair of rare emperor penquins Saturday night. A quick shift to the chilly quarters of the neighboring king penguins saved the lives of the Anarctic birds.
A 15-year-old boy who admitted stabbing a teacher in night school on June 8 was sentenced yesterday to the Training School for Boys at Warwick, N. Y., for an indeterminate period.
LONDON, July 18 -- The House of Commons declared today one of the parliamentary seats won by a Sinn Fein member at last May's election was vacant.

The Caterpillar Tractor Company increased its net profit in the first six months this year to $15,446,994 from $12,627,907 earned in the corresponding half of 1954, it was reported yesterday by Harmon S. Eberhard, president, in the semi-annual statement to stockholders.

Following are the texts of the opening addresses at the Geneva conference yesterday by President Eisenhower, Premier Edgar Faure of France, Prime Minister Sir Anthony Eden of Britain and Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin of the Soviet Union, as reported by The United Press and The New York Times:
American textile merchants asserted yesterday that imports of Japanese cotton goods were a greater threat now than in the Nineteen Thirties.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The District of Columbia Board of Commissioners asked Congress today to oust the Louis E. Wolfson interests from control of the strike-bound Capital Transit Company.
A milk truck driver was robbed of $9,500 in Brooklyn yesterday by two armed men who held him up while he was making a regular trip to a bank. The hold-up occurred at 2:45 P. M.

The Arrow people and the Ford people have put their corporate heads together and come up with a promotion event linked to Christmas. Throughout the country in the week of Nov. 14 retailers will be displaying Arrow's new Thunderbird-in-spired sport shirts along with material on Ford's Thunderbird motor car for 1956.
PARIS, July 18 -- Casablanca was relatively quiet today after having been torn for almost four days by riot, pillage and arson.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -The White House reported today that congressional leaders had worked out a program to minimize difficulties over legislation while the President was out of the country.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 18 -- Voyager Productions, an independent company operated by Richard Sale, has acquired the motion picture rights to Elliott Paul's novel "Hugger Mugger in the Louvre."

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, called on Congress today to translate the proposals of the Hoover Commission into savings to the taxpayers and higher efficiency in Government.
The privately owned American merchant fleet is now at its highest rate of vessel employment since the Korean conflict, it was reported yesterday by the American Merchant Marine Institute.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -A Congressional subcommittee today began an inquiry into why the Justice Department did not ask the Supreme Court to review an anti-monopoly finding against the Firestone Rubber Company by the Federal Trade Commission, which a lower court reversed.
A correlated state-wide policy for all agencies concerned with correction is suggested in the annual report of the city Department of Correction.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 18 -- Howard Hughes today sold R. K. O.-Radio Pictures, Inc., and its assets to the General Tire and Rubber Company for $25,000,000 in cash.

A hand-operated automobile, specially built for handicapped persons, was presented yesterday to the Institute for Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The House of Representatives approved construction of an atomic-powered merchant ship today. However, it is not the type President Eisenhower has wanted.
New Yorkers sweltered yesterday through their sixth day this year of over-90-degree temperatures.
New York had a sudden influx of foreign students yesterday as 147 arrived under the sponsorship of three separate groups.
BLOOMSBURY, N. J., July 18 -- John Pickel's 100 years passed before him tonight as his fellow townspeople helped him to observe his centenary birthday anniversary.
A "full guaranteed annual wage" will be demanded by union negotiators at the opening this morning of contract talks with General Electric, the country's biggest electrical manufacturer.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The principal task to which the Democratic Digest is dedicated is to build the campaign issues for the party and project them in terms easy for the public to understand. In the current issue of this bright and well-edited organ of the Democratic National Committee the function is executed by an article which suggests similarity between the conduct of the Presidency by General Eisenhower and its conduct by General Grant.

True to the principles of do-it-yourself, Harvey H. Hecker, who will be 78 years old in October, built a sixteen - foot boat from a mail order kit. He then took unto himself a wife, aged 74, and put out with her from Florida aboard the small craft.

GENEVA, July 18 (UP) -- Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, delivered the following address of welcome today in his capacity as host to the Big Four meeting, which is being held in a United Nations building:
Norman Cousins, editor of The Saturday Review, yesterday demanded a "full investigation" of the operating record and policies of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 18 -- The South Vietnamese Army is fighting the most difficult battles of its young life in the marshlands of the southern province of Hatien. Deputy Defense Minister Iran Trung Dung said today, however, that the campaign should be ended successfully within two weeks.
CAIRO, July 18 -- The 4,700-year-old solar ship of the Pharoah Cheops, carrying a twentieth century cargo of DDT powder and rat poison, went into mothballs today for the summer.
Chester Mann, a suspended member of the police narcotics squad, pleaded guilty to first-degree perjury yesterday before Kings County Judge Hyman Barshay.
The New York State Supreme Court yesterday upheld the State Athletic Commission's refusal to sanction a fight involving a boxer whose manager is under suspension by the commission.
PURCHASE, N. Y., July 18 -- Construction of a $3,000,000 reserve troop - carrier squadron base at Westchester County Airport was proposed today by the air Force.

HONG KONG, July 18 -- The Peiping People's Daily, Red China's leading newspaper, welcomed the opening of the Big Four talks today. In an editorial it urged the Geneva conferees not to overlook the Far Eastern situation.

GENEVA, July 18 (AP) -- The first day of the Big Four meeting was all smiles, despite the sweltering heat. As the delegates gathered Geneva had its hottest day of the year -- 92 degrees Fahrenheit. But everybody looked happy.
Four mobile units will be in operation today for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.
Eight hundred New Yorkers from 60 to 90 years old took part yesterday in the annual boat ride of the Department of Welfare's sixteen centers for older persons.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Congress, with the Democrats in the van, on the whole backed President Eisenhower's approach today at the Big Four conference.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had increased. It announced that its latest offering of $1,600,000,000 in ninety-one day bills was sold at a price equal to an annual interest rate of 1.620 per cent. Last week, it was 1.606 per cent.

ROME, July 18 -- After only four days of debate the Chamber of Deputies gave its confidence this evening to Premier Antonio Segni and his center coalition government. The vote was 293 to 265, with 12 abstentions.
The General Dynamics Corporation has appointed Dr. Frederic de Hoffmann, atomic scientist, as vice president.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Rowland R. Hughes, Budget Director, denied today that President Eisenhower planned to impound extra funds voted by Congress for navigation, flood control and power projects.

Investment interests from Venezuela, the United States and Canada have formed a finance company to help dealers in automobiles and other motor vehicles in Venezuela to finance wholesale purchases and to handle installment sales.

THERE'S plenty of background material for homemakers to study in redecorated model rooms in New York City stores. New settings at Altman's, Stern's and Gimbels emphasize the decorative importance of floors, walls and windows, and the part that these areas play in setting off furniture to advantage.

GENEVA, July 18 -- President Eisenhower suggested today a new approach to disarmament, based on an "alarm system" of arms inspection. The system would be intended to prevent "frightful surprises" or sudden attack. The President made the proposal in his statement opening the Big Four conference, at which he pre sided.

Debtors who go hopefully to "adjuster" companies to organize their tangled affairs into a pay-off system satisfactory to creditors were warned yesterday that they may find themselves getting only deeper into debt.
JERUSALEM, July 18 -- Governor Harriman of New York saw from the air today the dredging operation by which Israel is reclaiming prehistoric Hula swamp and creating a rich farm area.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 18 -- This small island, designed by providence, for the surfcaster, has been plagued by bad weather for the last few days, and, although it has provided some fishing, the striped bass have been scarce.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -Harry Bridges, West Coast long-shoremen's leader, said today that relations between his union and employers had "in the main been mutually satisfactory" since 1948.
LONDON, July 18 -- A Labor party committee criticized today Britain's civil defense system as deficient in the manpower and equipment required to deal with a hydrogen bomb attack.
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Wheat was strong during most of the session in the face of big receipts and a fair amount of hedge sales. While wheat was showing a tendency to rally however, there was steady pressure on the coarse grains and new lows were registered.
GENEVA. July 18 -- Sir Anthony Eden presented today three security proposals intended to make German unity palatable to the Soviet Union.

SYOSSET, L. I., July 18 -- M. and Mrs. John Jo McDonald have offered Hunters Honie, their estate in the Woodbury section, for the Helping Hand Horse Show on Aug. 6. Proceeds of the event will go to the support of the Community Church.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Air Force dropped a lot of glass and the "accordion-like" chapel from designs for its new academy today. The revisions were warmly received by a Senate Appropriations subcommittee.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The House of Representatives today passed without a dissenting vote a bill to deny Federal employment to subversives or anyone who strikes against the Government.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Senate approved today a bill authorizing Federal grants to help states and communities provide free Salk poliomyelitis vaccine shots to children and pregnant women.

Ex-president Joe Ryan of the dockworkers' union was indicted and convicted of a criminal violation of the Taft-Hartley Act in accepting a "gratuity" from an employer of his dockworkers. He appealed, contending that the Taft-Hartley Act did not make it a criminal offense for a union official to accept money from an employer unless the official was an "exclusive bargaining agent" for the union.

Jottings: Guthrie McClintic arrived in New York from Paris yesterday and began work immediately on his production of "A Roomful of Roses." The play, starring Patricia Neal, is scheduled to go into rehearsal on Aug. 15. . .
THE modern summer brings a two-fold problem: the heat and vacation television. In neither case is relief certain. Take Saturday night for example.
LONDON, July 18 (AP) -- Four Baptist clergymen from the United States accepted today an invitation to visit the Soviet Union next month.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 18 -- It's a dog's life that cats are leading in this village now.
The Department of Defense and other Government agencies have decided to prod the steam-ship industry to build a new type of ocean carrier known as the roll-on-roll-off ship.
GENEVA, July 18 -- Moscow taught Washington a lesson in public relations this morning.
Plans to acquire control of the General Acceptance Corporation of Cincinnati were announced yesterday by the General Acceptance Corporation, Allentown, Pa.

[r. Chairman: On behalf of the Soviet Government, I am happy to greet 1%it. Dwight Eisenhower, the President of the United States, Ai. Edgar Faure, the Prime Minister of France, and Sir Anthony Eden, the Prime V[inister of Great Britain, and also the members of their delegations and to express a sincere vish that the work of our conference be a fruitful one.
Sugar Al Wilson of Englewood ended Pat Lowry's winning streak at five last night with a unanimous decision over the Toledo, Ohio, welterweight at St. Nicholas Arena.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- Speaker of the House Sam Rayburn, Democrat of Texas, said today that House action on a bill to exempt natural gas from direct Federal controls would depend on the outcome of a Democratic poll.

The Un-Americanism Committee of the Westchester County American Legion has lived up to its name by demonstrating a little un-Americanism of its own. If, as we believe, Americanism includes a deep reverence for the Bill of Rights and a desire that its principles be studied, discussed and understood, then this Legion group has indicated that it doesn't quite understand what Americanism is.

It was fitting that the Secretary General of the United Nations, Dag Hammarskjold, should welcome the Big Four heads of governments at their first meeting yesterday at the Palace of the Nations in Geneva. They needed U. N.'s blessing and they got it.
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- Jim Wilson of the Baltimore Orioles stopped the Chicago White Sox today, 3 -- 0, with a two-hit performance. It ended Chicago's winning streak at seven games.
Sales and earnings of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. for the first half of this year reached new records for such a period according to preliminary figures announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Justice Department has convened a Federal grand jury here to reopen the wartime murder case of Maj. William W. Holohan, the United States secret agent alleged to have been killed in Italy by two of his men.

WEST MILTON, N. Y., July 18 -- At 2:57 P. M. today the chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission threw a giant copper switch and sent atomic - generated electricity coursing into the lines of a private utility.
GENEVA, July 18 -- The Big Four heads of government met today and exchanged proposals for resolving the issues that for ten years have set the East against the West.
The nation's natural gas producers say their fight for new gas legislation is basically a fight for freedom.

Investors struggled yesterday with the task of interpreting Geneva developments in market terms. As a result, the so-called "atomic issues," steels and other stocks connected with armaments eased a bit and motors and other "peace issues" advanced.

Benjamin H. Schor and Joseph R. Pape, both Democrats, were appointed deputy commissioners of the State Liquor Authority yesterday by Thomas E. Rohan, chairman. They were sworn in for the $8,097-a-year jobs by Carmine G. DeSapio, Secretary of State, at his office, 270 Broadway.
I have followed with interest the attempt to liquidate the calendar congestion in our courts and enthusiastically favor the various committees appointed to study the problem.
A Third Avenue property and two other adjacent to the avenue are among parcels passing to new ownership on Manhattan's East Side.

The Big Four meeting at Geneva and Premier Faure's recent suggestion that the savings from a reduction in armaments be employed to help more needy peoples bring into sharp focus the urgency for a realistic solution of the German problem.

BONN, Germany, July 18 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was reported today to have sent a private message to Secretary of State Dulles ten days ago warning him of possible consequences to the Bonn Government and its foreign policy if the Geneva conference failed to advance Germany's reunification.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- A hitch developed today in proposals to import natural gas from Canada and to sell it in the Pacific Northwest and possibly California. The develop ment came as a Federal Power Commission examiner opened a hearing into an application by Pacific Northwest Pipeline Company to import 300,000,000 cubic feet of gas daily, which it would buy from Westcoast Transmission Company, Ltd.

The Big Four conference that could mark a turning point in postwar history has opened in Geneva in a spirit of general friendliness which has prompted President Eisenhower to declare that if this spirit is sustained the meeting will turn out to be a great success.
The Dodgers ended a four-game winning streak by losing to the Redlegs, 9 -- 5, at Ebbets Field last night before a crowd of 17,942.
RICHMOND, Va., July 18 -Three Federal judges refused today to order Prince Edward County to integrate its public schools by next September.

Jayne Mansfield of Hollywood, will make her Broadway debut in October as the "super-siren" in George Axelrod's satire about Hollywood, "Will Success Spoil Rock Hunter?" Since she was discovered by Warner Brothers at the Pasadena Playhouse two years ago, Miss Mansfield has appeared in such movies as "Pete Kelly's Blues" and "The Burglar"
MADRID, July 18 -- If Spain's top dress designer, Pedro Rodriguez, has his way, women will dress for fun and flattery this coming season.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Incident of the shooting down of a United States Navy patrol plane between Alaska and Siberia June 23 was a step nearer being closed tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The United States signed "atoms for peace" agreements today with Switzerland, the Netherlands the Republican of China and Lebanon.
Youth workers and enforcement officials were told yesterday to quit "arguing about the delinquency rate" and to "stop getting alarmed" by virtually useless statistics.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 18 -- John P. Kelly of Dunmore, president of the Pennsylvania Pharmaceutical Association, said today that pharmacists did not point out often enough or strongly enough that modern drugs were much cheaper than older remedies, since they cut the length of illnesses almost in half.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 18 (AP) -- Sammy Boulmetis set a track record for jockeys at Monmouth Park today by booting home his fifty-sixth winner in the seventh race.
CHICAGO, July 18 -- Earl Campbell, president of the National Association of Music Merchants, said here today that this year might be the biggest in history for the music retailing business.
MOSCOW, July 18 -- Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin has sharply criticized Soviet industrial leaders for failing to keep abreast of foreign, especially United States technological advances.
JERUSALEM, July 18 -- Palestinian refugees in the Gaza strip will recover money and valuables left in Israeli banks if negotiations now under way are successful.

John Botts of Bronxville, seeded third, and Ted Forstmann of Greenwich, Conn., seeded sixth, reached the quarter-finals in the Long Island junior and boys' tennis championships at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens, yesterday.

LONDON, July 18 -- Values of oil shares rose to new peaks today on a rush of buying. Other advances were on a smaller scale, with selected electrical, motor and engineering issues gaining between one and two shillings (14 to 28 cents).

A SPELL of scorching weather does not deter an Indian from sitting down with relish to his favorite dish: spicy, tongue-biting curry. In fact, it is a theory in India that hot foods on a hot day are more cooling than a glass of iced tea or a chilled salad.

Despite the heat yesterday, homeware buyers' attendance at the seventh annual National China, Glass and Pottery Show here was higher than last year. The show, which opened at the New Yorker Hotel on Sunday, had registered 1,508 buyers for department and other retail stores at the close of its second day.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- An official of the Department of the Interior said today that the proposed repeal of the Silver Purchase Act could have an adverse effect on the domestic production of copper, lead and zinc.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The House Public Works Committee decided today to reconsider its approval of a Democratic substitute for the President's highway program.
GENEVA, July 18 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's statement at the close of this afternoon's session of the Big Four conference:
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, was questioned for two hours in closed session today by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Eisenhower today nominated Paul W. Williams to be United States attorney for the Southern District of New York.

N. Richard Nash, whose comedy "The Rainmaker" received a fine welcome from the critics last season, is completing two new scripts. One is a play, the other the book and lyrics for a musical. It is likely that first option rights to both projects will go to Ethel Linder Reiner, who produced "The Rainmaker."

PARIS, July 18 -- The French balance of payments has improved markedly. This is reflected in the French position within the European Payments Union, where the French surplus in June -- $21,700,000 -- was the highest in three months.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Administration is considering negotiating a Dixon - Yates settlement outside cancellation provisions of the controversial private power contract.

Rubber prices soared into new high ground early yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Trading was influenced by higher prices in London and Singapore and reports that supplies were tight for immediate delivery. Stop-loss buying and commission-house purchasing here sent prices up about 1 1/2 cents a pound in initial trading.
DUBLIN, July 16 -- Three leading Irish fashion designers have dipped into the past for inspiration for their new collections.
VIENNA, July 18 -- Austria agreed today on a final settlement for indemnification of Jewish victims of Nazism.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (UP) -- Roy Smalley hit a two-run homer in the fifth inning tonight to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs. Earlier the Phils came from behind to win a suspended Sunday game, 8 -- 6, on Glen Gorbous' three-run homer.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., July 18 -- Justice lmrie was elected to the Supreme Court:'m 1941 and would have retired.In January, 1956. He served twice as city attorney of Glens Falls. In 19.44 hewas named to preside Over the grand jury investigating legislative spending.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration and local authorities opened an investigation today into the crash of a twin-engined Braniff Airways plane at Chicago's Midway Airport yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, July 18 (AP) -Washington pinned the seventh straight defeat on the Kansas City Athletics today, 6 -- 3, and swept a three-game series. Roy Sievers clubbed two home runs and a double for the Senators.

Commissioner Ford Frick met representatives of the Caribbean Baseball Federation yesterday to discuss a major league players' proposal to lift all restrictions on the number of players allowed to compete in Latin America next winter.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- The House of Representatives gave a final approval today to a resolution calling for the United States to help achieve independence for countries under foreign rule.

ST. LOUIS, July 18 (AP) -- Two more groups of holders of Missouri Pacific securities asked United States District Judge George H. Moore today to delay confirmation of the latest reorganization plan for the bankrupt railroad.

ROCKFORD, Ill., July 18 (AP) -- Two college students, Rex Baxter of Amarillo, Tex., and Bob Brue of Milwaukee, pinpointed three-under-par 68's today to share opening-round honors in qualifying trials of the Western Amateur.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- George M. Humphrey urged today a sharp cutback in special tax concessions to industries building defense facilities.
The Ohio Edison Company and its subsidiary, the Pennsylvania Power Company, reported yesterday new highs in operating revenues and net income for June and for six and twelve months ended June 30.

While the weather continues as an all-season topic of conversation, it captures talk most readily during the periods of extreme heat and cold, and especially at the outset of such periods, when the temperature takes off on its upward or downward journey.

SCARBOROUGH - ON - HUDSON, N.Y., July 18 -- Mrs. E. C. K. Finch, Country Club of New Canaan, posted a fine 75 for medal honors in the annual Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

A collection of personal stories of the strange characters, the adventurers and the victims who abounded in Europe after the flood of war receded will be published Aug. 24 by Lippincott under the title "After the Flood."

A broken key in one of four locks designed to keep out burglars nearly caused the death yesterday of Mrs. Patricia Clark Toriel. She was unable to escape from her barricaded apartment at 17 East Sixty-seventh Street when fire broke out early yesterday.

GENEVA, July 18 -- French officials were disturbed tonight by well-founded reports that members of the United States delegation had accused Premier Edgar Faure of going further in his speech to the four-power conference than he had indicated to them he would go.

MOSCOW, July 18 (AP) -- The United States farm delegation got its first look at Soviet agriculture today. It came back to town impressed, especially with the friendliness and hospitality of the people.

Westchester County has decided to limit the use of its public parks to the residents of Westchester County. As a basis for the decision the Westchester taxpayer feels he should not pay for the upkeep of parks that are used by people of another county, people who do not pay for them.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- The Treasury will net nearly $110,000,000 from bonus bids and first-year rentals on last week's sale of Tidelands oil and gas leases off Louisiana and Texas, it was announced today.

The C. V. Whitney entry of Full Steam and Brown Hackle contributed a highly pleasing performance at the Saratoga-at-Jamaica meeting yesterday. Established at odds of 7 to 10 by the crowd of 19,528, the Whitney colts finished one-two in the six-furlong feature.

In a game that was won and lost in center field and by center fielders, the Giants rallied to defeat the Milwaukee Braves, 6 -- 5, last night at the Polo Grounds. Willie Mays, who saved it with his reputation and his arm earlier, won it with his bat in the seventh, the same frame in which Bill Bruton lost it for the Braves.

Names of Pacific islands that were in the news during, the second World War, and in some cases afterward, crept into a report unanimously adopted yesterday by the United Nations Trusteeship Council. To the earlier period belong Saipan, Truk, Yap and others.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 18 -- With the start of the grass court season here at Merion, lawn tennis heads into the most interesting competition offered in this country since 1950.
John Calvin Siemer, who is under indictment for the 1954 theft of $82,143 from a Staten Island bank, was arrested in Ohio last night, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 18 -- The strongest array of talent to gather for a tennis tournament of the current season in this country began play today on the lawns of the Merion Cricket Club.

JONES BEACH, L. I., July 18 -- The State Power Authority decided today to put up to Governor Harriman the question of whether power from the St. Lawrence project should be carried to three customers over private or authority transmission lines.

ALBANY, July 18 (AP) -- The State Health Department said today that twenty-five new cases of polio had been reported in the fifty-seven counties outside New York City during the week that ended last Saturday.
MADRID, July 18 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco has assured both employers and workers that he will refrain from "absurd experiments" that might endanger the economy of the nation.

BUENOS AIRES, July 18 -President Juan D. Peron plans to establish a huge student organization to represent the interests of high school and college students, it was reported today. It will consist of both branches of the Union of Secondary Students and the General Confederation of University Students.

The City of Mobile, Ala., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Aug. 3 on an issue of $17,000,000 of Bankhead tunnel revenue refunding and improvement bonds. The new obligations will come due on May 1, 1995.

Events tonight: Stadium Symphony Orchestra, Thomas Scherman conducting, Philippa Schuyler, pianist, Lewisohn Stadium; Summer Choir, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, and Guggenheim Memorial Concert, Goldman Band, Central Park, all at 8:30.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- A panel of economists today urged keeping closer tabs on annual outlays for business plants and equipment. They told a Senate-House Economic subcommittee that earlier and more accurate checks "are a highly significant indicator of economic trends."

WASHINGTON, July 19 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee postponed action today on a proposal to bring Spain into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The delay was designed to avoid any embarrassment to the Big Four Conference in Geneva.

LONDON, July 19 -- An exchange of British and Russian theatrical companies was suggested today by the Russian delegation attending the International Conference on Theatre History. The suggestion came from Alexei Dmitrievich Popov, producer of the Soviet Army Theatre in Moscow and one of the Soviet Union's greatest Shakespearean scholars and producers.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The State Department gave permission today to Paul Robeson, the baritone, to travel to Canada. It said his application for a passport for European travel was getting "careful and prompt" attention.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Private dealers are buying surplus property from the Federal Government and selling it at a profit to state Civil Defense agencies, Texas' Civil Defense Director said today.

TAKE a gift, prettily packaged, to the week-end hostess or to the lucky traveler going on an ocean voyage this summer. Stores have assembled delicacies appropriate for giving, and have packaged them so handsomely that shoppers need do no more than decide which one to buy.
GENEVA, July 19 -- Following are sketches of the principal spokesmen of the four delegations to the Geneva conference:
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy agreed today on a bipartisan effort to restore $101.000,000 of the sum hacked by Congress from the budget for atomic work.
A union representing 80,000 General Electric employes announced yesterday that it had given formal notice of intention to terminate its contract with the company Sept. 15.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Most of the funds slashed by the House of Representatives were restored today as the Senate Appropriations Committee approved a $3,204,341,750 foreign-aid money bill.
GENEVA, July 19 -- President Eisenhower went toy shopping for his grandchildren this afternoon and created a traffic problem for the Geneva police.
TRENTON, July 19 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner announced today he would veto a measure increasing the salaries of New Jersey judges.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Edward F. Howrey, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today he never had done "an unethical thing." He made this point in saying he had leaned over backward in taking a position adverse to a former client of his, the Firestone Rubber Company.
A man who failed to cash a traveler's check in the Grand Central Terminal last night succeeded instead in getting himself booked for forgery and felonious assault.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- A long and at times emotional controversy in the House of Representatives this afternoon postponed until tomorrow the voting on an increase in the national legal minimum wage.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Deputy Under Secretary of State warned today that "one key element of most recent Soviet proposals is to eliminate United States bases in Europe and to get American troops out."

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., July 19 -- A successful revival of the old-fashioned summer evening band concerts has been accomplished here. The Tuesday evening free concerts of the seventy-five-piece Valley Stream Community Band at the new music shell in Memorial Park are the most popular summer activities in the village.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 19 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, declared today that the thousands of Roman Catholic pilgrims flocking to the thirty-sixth Eucharistic Congress here came to pray for peace in "this terrorized and terrified world."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 -- Four professors in different fields will join in a battle of ideas in the same classroom at Mills College next fall. They are to conduct a new course of three hours for seniors. He will be called "Patterns of American Thought."

The Allied Chemical Dye Corporation in the quarter and six months ended June 30 attained the highest sales and earnings for any similar periods in the company's history, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.
THE Lower East Side Neighhoods Association presented last evening the first of three orchestral concerts it will offer in the East River Park Amphitheatre.

CLEVELAND, July 19 (AP) -- Behind six-hit pitching by Lefty Dean Stone, Washington pounded four Cleveland hurlers for a dozen base hits tonight to thump the Indians, 8 -- 1. The victory was the fourth straight for the Senators.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 -- Three maritime officer unions on the West Coast asked the Pacific Maritime Association today to give them contract parity with their East Coast branches.
GENEVA, July 19 -- The Soviet Union asked for a delay in the reunification of Germany at the Big Four conference's second session today.

Two "firsts" were registered last night at the Polo Grounds as the Giants and the St. Louis Cardinals split a twilight-night double-header. The Redbirds captured the opener, 3 -- 1, with Willard Schmidt going all the way for the first time in his major league career.

A two-year agreement was reached yesterday between union truck drivers and cement, sand and gravel concerns in the metropolitan area. It provides for a pay rise of 35 cents an hour and other benefits.
The State Public Service Commission urged yesterday that the New York Central Railroad be required to continue operating the Weehawken Ferry for at least a year from this fall.

ROSH HAAYIN, Israel, July 19 -- One of the most fondly cherished dreams of Israel came true today. The constant springs of the Yarkon River began to feed into the giant pipeline that will carry the water sixty-five miles south to the rich but parched farmland of the Negev.

The will of a Greek-born bachelor, who remained true to the Ionian island of Lefkas, his boyhood home, even though he had spent many years in the United States, was approved yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

TOMKINS COVE, N. Y., July 19 -- The Rockland Light and Power Company expects to double its sales in the next five years, Charles L. Hulswit, president, said here today. This increase would come on the heels of a tripling of sales since 1945.

" Court Martial," a British-made drama co-starring David Niven and Margaret Leighton, is scheduled to open on Monday, Aug. 1, at the Fifty-second Street Trans-Lux Theatre, according to an announcement by the distributor, Edward Kingsley.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved continued collection of a 90-cent toll from train travelers passing through New York City by way of the Hell Gate Bridge over the East River.

Heavy experimental and development expenditures have contributed to sharply reduced earnings of the Douglas Aircraft Company this year. Donald W. Douglas, president, explained the change yesterday in the report for the first half of the fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, July 19--Two major legislative programs ran into difficulties that may shelve them as Congress pressed on today toward a scheduled July 30 adjournment.

Youth in Harlem will be aided as a result of a recital to be given by Marian Anderson at Carnegie Hall on Nov. 4 for the benefit of the Morning-side Community Center. Presented by S. Hurok, this will be the contralto's only New York recital this season.

Cocoa prices tumbled the 1-cent-a-pound limit in all positions yesterday except the spot July month which has no limit and was down 115 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Trading was influenced by lower prices for Brazilian and Dominican Republic cocoa and rumors that Brazil might remove all controls on cocoa export prices.

PITTSBURGH, Wednesday, July 20 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates scored two runs in the bottom of the nineteenth early today to gain a 4-3 decision over the Milwaukee Braves in the longest major league game of the season.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 19 -- Cornelius Shields squeezed his International Aileen as close to the committee boat as he safely could today for his first victory of Larchmont Race Week.

In the steaming, smoke-filled waiting room of the Long Island Rail Road at Pennsylvania Station yesterday afternoon thousands milled about uncertainly and, after the manner of Long Island commuters, philosophically.
GENEVA, July 19 (Reuters) -French Premier Edgar Faure acknowledged today that his speech at the opening session of the Big Four conference yesterday had been given a mixed reception.

Hearings on alleged Communist infiltration of the New York entertainment industry will be held here next month by the House Committee on Un-American Activities. Television and the legitimate theatre will be included.

CLEVELAND, July 19 -- John Calvin Siemer, who is under indictment for the theft of $93,000 from a Staten Island bank at which he had been employed, agreed today to return to New York to face embezzlement charges.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Another proxy fight for control of a midwestern company loomed today. Edward S. Reddig, Cleveland industrialist, is seeking to elect a new board of directors of the Minneapolis-Moline Company, Hopkins, Minn., of which he is a stockholder.
CARACAS, July 19 -- Venezuela had a record dollar income of $1,091,000,000 in 1954, according to a report issued today by Banco Central. A favorable balance trade amounted to about $800,000,000.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and its subsidiaries, steel producers, realized an increase of 98.5 per cent in its half-year earnings on a gain of 33.2 per cent in sales over the period a year ago.
Dark Charger scored a decisive victory yesterday in her first venture on a New York racing strip.

ELEVEN men who work for Pan American World Airways will soar out of Idlewild Airport on a company plane next Tuesday morning to fly to the Fourth International Paralympic Games at Avlesbury in Britain.

The United States press, radio and other media of information have been quite critical of Nehru's visit to the Soviet Union. Your own editorial was quite severe. Americans were not happy either to hear that Nehru had invited Premier Bulganin to visit India. Above all, they were quite annoyed that a joint statement was issued by Nehru and Bulganin.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 19 -The Screen Actors Guild announced today the calling of an "emergency" meeting of its Hollywood membership for Sunday night to vote authorization of a strike against producers of television entertainment films.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Tax allowances on payments to private retirement plans by professionals and other self-employed persons won approval today from the House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee.

The economy seems on the rise into 1956, according to at least one crystal ball. The National Securities and Research Corporation mingled rising personal consumption expenditures and increased construction into its refractives and reflectives and, in a report made public yesterday, found the prospect rosy.

Premier Bulganin's major speech on Soviet industry, published Monday in Pravda, unveils one of Moscow's chief current problems, the shortage of labor. That there should be such a shortage in a country with well over 200,000,000 persons may seem surprising, but the explanation is simple.

Dr. Benjamin Spock, one of the nation's best-known pediatricians, has signed a television contract with the National Broadcasting Company. He will conduct a weekly program on child care and development beginning Sunday, Oct. 9, from 3 to 3:30 P. M.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee turned over to the Internal Revenue Service today its transcript of testimony on Harry Lev, Chicago hat maker.

The 1956 line of RCA Victor television receivers will be introduced by Bruno-New York, Inc., metropolitan distributor, with a big advertising splash in newspapers in this area over the week-end. Two newspapers will have special color sections, usable by dealers later on for reference and for mailing pieces, and a list of papers will have large-space insertions.

Tammany leadership contests in about a third of thirty-four districts appeared in the making yesterday. The New York County Democratic organization is carrying out its first direct election of district leaders this year at the Sept. 13 primary.
LOS ANGELES, July 19 -- Michael Jeffers, actor, lost his $200,000 libel suit today against the Screen Extras Guild, after five years of litigation, including three lengthy trials.

The highly vocal advocates of the expansion of T. V. A. in the Democratic party are raising a mighty clamor that they have won a major victory as a result of the cancellation of the so-called Dixon-Yates contract.

BONN, Germany, July 19--Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, West German Foreign Minister and his secretary general, Prof. Walter Hallstein, departed for Muerren, Switzerland today to confer with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer on the serious situation caused by the Geneva deadlock on German reunification.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Income and spending increases, which carried the country's economy to record levels in the first half of 1955, are being maintained this summer, the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Senate voted today to bar from policy-making posts business executives who were serving the Government without pay.
NEW DELHI, India, July 19 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today an international conference on Far Eastern problems would have to be held some time after the Geneva Big Four talks.
Eugene Francis, a junior at Sea Cliff (L. I.) High School, and two other young golfers from the metropolitan area qualified for the United States Golf Association's junior championship yesterday.

The Theatre Guild and David Merrick, co-sponsor of "Fanny," are joining hands to introduce "The Matchmaker" to Broadway. Either Oct. 19 or 26 will usher in the Thornton Wilder farce, which entertained Londoners for eight months, to an undesignated Shubert house.

BALTIMORE, July 19 -- A damage suit of $1,000,000, charging breach of contract, was filed in Federal Court today by four strike-bound tugboat companies here against the International Longshoremen's Association and its Local 1337.
NEW DELHI, India, July 17 -- Indian agricultural planners have drawn up an ambitious program for reaping the wind.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., July 19 (AP) -- Vice Admiral Joel T. Boone, retired, White House physician in the Coolidge Administration, disputed today a colleague's statement that President Coolidge was "hysterical" at the death of his son, Calvin Jr., in 1924.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- A total of 1,166 loans involving credits amounting to $55,337,000 were approved by the Small Business Administration in the fiscal year ended June 30, that agency announced today.
Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn sought a $5,000,000 appropriation yesterday to build a downtown traffic link in the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.
BATON ROUGE, La., July 19 (UP) -Two Negro graduate students of Louisiana State University were peppered with buckshot on the campus today in what authorities called on act of racial violence.

Mayor Wagner made plain yesterday that he favored a blanket increase in minimum wages for Puerto Rican workers. But he side-stepped direct involvement in a controversy over the issue within the Mayor's Committee on Puerto Rican Affairs.

In 1952, seven men -- six Frenchmen and one Australian -- spent the winter at Terra Nova Glacier in Adelie Land, the French sector of Antarctica. The leader of the expedition, Mario Marret, has written an account of the lessons learned from this ordeal, entitled "Seven Men Among the Penguins: An Antarctic Venture." Harcourt, Brace will issue the book next month in an English translation by Edward Fitzgerald.
BLED, Yugoslavia, July 16 -- Yugoslav military authorities have turned back every recent effort by United States officials to increase their observation of the military aid program here.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -Sherman Adams, the assistant to the President, was asked today to testify before a Senate subcommittee about his role in the Dixon-Yates power controversy.
The delinquency "crisis" was dismissed yesterday as the creature of "alarmists" by Dr. Lauretta Bender, senior psychiatrist at Bellevue Hospital.
Christmas, minus some of the trimmings, came to the city yesterday.

Fred Jones, a 37-year-old narcotic peddler, whose testimony resulted in the conviction of a police narcotic squad detective for perjury, received a suspended one-year jail sentence yesterday in Kings County Court.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 19 -- Witnesses testifying before an investigating panel here today suggested that the wreck of a New Haven Railroad express train in Bridgeport early last Thursday was caused by excessive speed.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 19 -- Tony Trabert, Victor Seixas and Hamilton Richardson, the Big Three of the Pennsylvania state tennis championship, were in sharp form on the turf of the Merion Cricket Club today.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- A football, they say, by reason of its peculiar shape, takes some funny bounces. But take it from Charles Dillon Stengel, a baseball, though perfectly round, can go hopping off at even screwier angles. And that goes for almost anything remotely connected with it.
Thirty men from the Department of Sanitation received the department's award for heroism, the medal of valor, in ceremony in City Hall Plaza yesterday.
GENEVA, July 19 (Reuters) -The United States proposed today that a permanent United Nations specialized agency be established to advance peaceful uses of nuclear energy.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP) -- The railroads said today that continued Federal tax concessions were "essential" to help them build freight cars vitally needed for national defense. A. R. Seder, vice president of the Association of American Railroads, told a House of Representatives Government Operations subcommittee that halting the fast tax write-offs would cause a drop in freight-car building.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 19 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur has granted permission to Warner Brothers to have an actor portray him on the screen in "The Court-Martial of Billy Mitchell."
THE concert version of "La Traviata," which was postponed because of the brief rain on Monday night, was given last night at Lewisohn Stadium. It attracted an audience of 9,500.

GENEVA, July 19 -- What the Big Four are really trying to do is to arrange an armistice for the war that never happened because it was too dangerous to fight. The mere fact of this conference is tantamount to a cease-fire or its equivalent in invisible conflict. But drafting true peace cannot yet be started.

Two mobile units will function today for collections of blood for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. One unit will receive donations from employes of Remington Rand, Inc., at 315 Fourth Avenue; the other from employes of The New York Times, 229 West Forty-third Street.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday increases in operating revenues, net income and sales of electricity, gas and steam for six and twelve months ended June 30.
VICKSBURG, Miss., July 19 -- Vicksburg today became the first Mississippi city to test the issue of desegregation.
SCARBOROUGH - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., July 19 -- Mrs. Fred Wright of Leewood rallied to win an exciting first-round contest in the thirteenth annual women's Tri-County golf championship today.

The Atomic Energy Commission has made use of the excess power produced by a prototype of the reactor which the General Electric Company is building at West Milton, N. Y., for the submarine Sea Wolf. It was not the first time that atomic power had done useful work, but it was the first time that it had been poured into a public utility system to be used in the form of electricity.
New Yorkers and their neighbors may get slightly cooler weather today. But the emphasis will be very much on the "slightly," as the mercury is expected to rise into the upper 80's.
GENEVA, July 19 (Reuters) -British and Soviet leaders had a "very useful and serious" discussion tonight on the German problem and European security, a British delegation source said.
NORTHVILLE, Mich., July 19 (UP) -- A field of 134 will tee off tomorrow for the first of two qualifying rounds for the Professional Golfers Association championship.

ELGIN, Ill., July 19 -- The development of a battery smaller than a penny that will deliver virtually constant voltage for two years and will not leak, swell or emit gas was announced here today by Elgin National Watch Company.
GENEVA, July 19 -- President Eisenhower is playing a cautious role, in some ways the most conservative one, at the Big Four conference.

Charles Bauer, a suspended boxing manager, notified officials of the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday that he planned to sell his contract to handle Chris Christensen in order to permit the Danish welterweight to obtain some fights in this country.
A syndicate headed by J. J. Boneparth bought nine apartment houses in the Bronx from Jack Resnick and Peter Feinberg and immediately resold five of them.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- A two-run eighth inning homer by Elston Howard gave the Yankees a 4-3 victory over the White Sox tonight before a crowd of 46,711. It also increased the Bombers' hold on first place to three full games.
GENEVA, July 19 (AP) -- The Big Four leaders moved close together today -- for a photograph. They sat on the lawn, between two beds of roses, outside the Palace of Nations.

A new ship-stablizing device known as the "gyrofin" was introduced to the shipping world yesterday as a master boon for the ocean traveler. The Sperry-Gyroscope Company announced development of the stablizer at the Whitehall Club, 17 Battery Place.

A six-story industrial building at 22 Queens Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by Alex Lewyt, industrialist, for the consolidation of his three manufacturing concerns. The companies, now occupying three plants in Brooklyn, manufacture more than 200 articles, including vacuum cleaners, air conditioners and electronic equipment.
LONDON, July 17 -- British excavations in Anatolian Turkey have disclosed more details of a 3,000-year-old palace. It is said to be comparable in size and age to the mighty palace of Minos in Crete.

DETROIT, July 19 (UP) -- Babe Birrer, summoned from the bullpen in the sixth inning to quiet Baltimore bats, went on a hitting rampage of his own today with a pair of three-run homers that led the Detroit Tigers to a 12-4 triumph over the Orioles.
AMERICAN moppets are beginning to look more like midgets than children, according to those who design and sell clothes for the small set.
Power failure in two East River railroad tunnels halted all Long Island Rail Road service at Pennsylvania Station from 4:06 to 6:22 P. M. yesterday.
Hector Constance, Trinidad, B. W. I., and Ramon Fuentes, Los Angeles, tangle in the main bout listed for ten rounds tonight at Madison Square Garden.
The salary increases scheduled for top city officials and 118 judges will total $579,750, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.
MOSCOW, July 19 (AP) -- Newspapers here do not run society news. Westerners may know that Soviet Defense Minister Georgi K. Zhukov's daughter has just been married, but the Soviet people do not.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- A $1,500,000 libel suit has been filed in Federal District Court here against Charles S. Bridges, president of Libby, McNeil Libby, in connection with the proxy fight for control of the food products company, it was disclosed today.
BUFFALO, July 19 -- The head of the state's Labor Department called today for new economic protections for the state's wage earners.
Cotton futures were barely steady yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, and prices dipped 4 to 17 points (20 to 85 cents a bale).
Contracts have been signed between Flota Mercante Gran-colombiana, S. A., and two European shipyards for six new cargo ships on a barter basis.
A new playground that was transformed from a littered lot was officially opened yesterday on 106th Street, between Madison and Fifth Avenues, for the express benefit of the city's "good children."
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, July 19 -- The twelve-man Russian agricultural delegation got a good look today at rural life and hospitality in the Corn Belt.

Operating revenues of the Pennsylvania Railroad rose by $22,992,069 in the first half of this year and the company managed to carry more than 80 per cent of the gain down to net income. Net income was $20,884,608 against $2,319,315 in the corresponding 1954 period, an increase of 803 per cent.

ROCKFORD, Ill., July 19 (AP) -- Alex Welsh, the hometown favorite, toured his Rockford Country Club course in a 67 today to take the 36-hole lead of the Western amateur qualifying competition with a 138, four strokes under par.

Varying interpretations of developments and possible developments in Geneva buffeted the stock market yesterday. It opened reasonably strong, dropped sharply in mid-morning, climbed slowly until the final hour and ended with a brisk rally in which the aircrafts and Woolworth were the leaders.

THIS July and every July some good books and some books that look as if they might be good are being published. But there are not enough of them so that this space can be filled without considerable investigation of last spring's books and of books that would normally, in October for instance, be overlooked on purpose.

At Geneva yesterday the heads of the Big Four Governments got down to their real business sessions with a four-point agenda on which there was surprisingly quick agreement. Considering that only a few years ago a Big Four conference labored for months in Paris without being able to reach agreement on agenda, this speedy accord has increased the guarded optimism prevalent at Geneva.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Communist governments of Eastern Europe are stepping up propaganda urging anti-Communist refugees to "return to the homeland."

Eased world tensions, commercial and political, should work primarily to the advantage of the free world, Warren Lee Pierson, newly elected president of the International Chamber of Commerce, asserted yesterday.
PARIS, July 19 -- The Casablanca riots that cost more than sixty lives have been quelled.

Banking authorities here believe that unless the economy is beset by inflationary excesses the Federal Reserve System's credit policy of "mild restraint" is likely to continue during the seasonal business expansion common to the last half of the year.
Asiel Co, members of New York Stock Exchange, in the twenty-seven-story building going up at 20 Broad St -- Cushman Wakefield Inc, agents.

The congested booking situation, a bane to the managerial fraternity, is best illustrated by the following maneuver:
LONDON, July 19 -- R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, declined today to give any commitment on when Britain would make the pound sterling convertible.
GENEVA, July 19 -- The Geneva conference has made a strange beginning from which it will have difficulty in recovering.

TO refute the belief that men's fashions were dormant in the pre-pink shirt age (circa 1903 to 1953) Ephraem Witty, president of Witty Brothers clothing stores, has listed ten important style revisions that came about before the "renaissance."

CHICAGO, July 19--Narrow price fluctuations were the rule in the forepart of today's session on the Board of Trade. With the exception of July, soybean futures were not much changed. There was some hedge pressure in wheat, as receipts at primary points continue heavy. This, with a little local selling, weakened the market.

LONDON, July 19 -- Industrial shares closed firm today after early uncertainty on end-of-account influences. The net effect was that many early losses were eliminated and replaced by net gains, especially among the better-class issues.

CARSON CITY, Nev., July 19 (AP) -Weary, hungry convicts in Nevada State Prison gave up their twenty-six-hour bloodless rebellion tonight in the face of threats that patrolmen guarding the prison walls were "preparing for a showdown."

A borrowing of $4,900,000 on serial bonds was made yesterday by School District 219 of Cook County, Ill. The obligations, which will come due from 1958 to 1973, were sold to a syndicate headed by Harris Trust and Savings Bank at an interest cost of 2.944 per cent.

Francis T. Greene, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, told the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee yesterday that proposed legislation providing for mediation and a "cooling-off" period in maritime disputes "might be very helpful" to the industry.

Rhonda Fleming and Wendell Corey will share star billing with Joseph Cotten in "The Killer is Loose," to be made by Crown Productions for United Artists release. . . . John O'Hara will spend the summer here working on a new novel, "7 North Frederick," to be published by Random House.
HONG KONG, July 19 -- Liang Shu-ming, a Left-Wing Chinese scholar who has publicly rejected various aspects of the Communists' dogma while accepting their political leadership, is in trouble again.
HARTFORD, July 19 -- Raffles and bazaars became legal today in Connecticut.
The resurgence of American vessel construction will be the dominant feature of global shipbuilding in the next few years.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 (AP) -- A defense witness in the Harry Bridges citizenship revocation trial said today that in the thirty-three years he had known the longshore leader he had never heard him say he was a member of the Communist party.

MUERREN, Switzerland, July 19 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, looking at the Big Four conference from an eminence of 5,400 feet, predicted today that this conference would lead to another.

The American Enka Corporation, rayon producer, announced plans yesterday for raising about $11,000,000 through the sale of common shares. This would be the first financing by the company since it was formed in 1928 by Algemene Kuntzidge Unie, N. V., a Netherlands organization which still holds a majority of the 1,117,630 common shares outstanding.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Hog prices broke again today, with butchers down 50 to 75 cents and sows off 25 to 50 cents. The general market was at the lowest point for any July in nine years. Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

In commenting editorially on the 34,232 foreign students who are attending educational institutions this year in the United States you emphasize the pressing need for better communication between peoples all countries.
BUENOS AIRES, JULY 19 -- The first signs of a definite split have appeared within the anti-Peronist Roman Catholic forces.

The Fulton Manufacturing Company of Brooklyn has purchased a factory at 816-834 Clinton Street in Hoboken, N. J., from the Pfaudler Company of Rochester, N.Y. The structure, on a plot about 235 by 200 feet, contain approximately 48,000 square feet of space. It will be used for the manufacture of lamps and novelty items.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP) -- House Democratic leaders predicted today that legislation to exempt natural gas producers from direct control of the Federal Power Commission would be approved by the House Friday.

We heartily welcome the interest in the problem of the uninsured automobile owner expressed by the New York legislative leaders, Senator Walter J. Mahoney and Speaker Oswald D. Heck. As Republicans, in a Republican-controlled Legislature, they can be greatly influential.
Philippine imports of American textiles have been restricted sharply by cancellation of unused dollar quotas for the third quarter.

It would be good if someone could find a reasonable explanation for one of the major mysteries of motoring. It is that if a vote were taken among any carload of wanderers the winning place among pleasures of the trip would be given to the meals.
BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 19--This is proving to be a broadbill as well as a bluefish year, although the commercial fishermen rather than the sports anglers are harvesting the swordfish.

GENEVA, July 19 (UP) -- Following is the text of a letter dated July 18 and addressed to Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, from President Eisenhower on behalf of the heads of government:
KHARKOV, U. S. S. R., July 19 -- Twelve American agriculturists got a heroes' welcome today from several thousand Kharkov residents.

LONDON, July 20 -- Industrial shares greeted the new bookkeeping account on the stock exchange today by reaching a fresh peak. Buying was said to have been stimulated by consideration of the implications of a rise in the cost of living index and by good company statements.

Rayonier, Inc., producer of chemical cellulose, established three records in the first half of this year. Earnings, tonnage and dollar sales were the best in the country's history, Clyde B. Morgan, president, reported in the semi-annual statement issued yesterday.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 20 -- The Figueres Government has said the escaped convict, Jimenez, eluded the police and left the country without its knowledge.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities, as announced today by the Federal Reserve Board, shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 13:

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Two members of the House of Representatives said today that Administration officials should retract "misinformation" on foreign aid given to the Senate Appropriations Committee or be discharged.

LONDON, July 20 -- The Baptist World Alliance unanimously elected the Rev. Dr. Theodore F. Adams of Richmond, Va., today as its president for the next five years. He succeeds Dr. F. Townley Lord of London.
GENEVA, July 20 -- A new version of the old Soviet plan for an all-European security system was presented to the Big Four conference today.

PARIS, July 20 -- Persistent press reports to the effect that Gilbert Grandval, newly appointed Resident General in French Morocco, was about to accede to Moroccan Nationalist demands for the removal of Sultan Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa were denied today.

The F. W. Woolworth Company will be the major tenant in a building to be erected by the Webb Knapp Construction Corporation at the southeast corner of Main Street and Roosevelt Avenue in Flushing, Queens. The structure will contain three floors, a basement and a subbasement.

A MAJOR problem for the teen-ager is managing his money. The average ninth-grader expends about $92 a year, the twelfth-grader $166. By the time he is 18 he may earn nearly $600 a year and be contributing to the family's coffers.
LONDON, July 20 -- A wellknown Russian writer hailed today signs that "the stuffiness and tension in the atmosphere" among nations were coming to an end.
India's jute mills will seek to meet increased competition in the American market by developing new uses here for burlap and other jute products.
LOS ANGELES, July 20 (AP) -Don Harper of Palo Alto, Calif., gained an upset victory in the three-meter springboard dive today in the National Amateur Athletic Union swimming and diving championships.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A spokesman for the International Longshoremen's Association sharply attacked the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission today for "interfering" in relations between management and labor in the harbor area.

MANILA, Thursday, July 21 (AP) -- Flash Elorde of the Philippines gained a unanimous tenround decision last night over Sandy Saddler, the world featherweight champion, in a nontitle fight that ended in a near riot.

WASHINGTON, July 20--Senate investigators have correspondence and documents purporting to show that Harold E. Talbott actively promoted from his Pentagon office new business for a New York industrial engineering firm.
Twenty-five theatre and television personalities were reported yesterday to have been subpoenaed to testify about reported Communist infiltration in the New York entertainment field.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., July 20 -- Two Reserve divisions of the Army put on an impressive show today at near-by Camp Drum for twenty-five members of the Reserve Forces Policy Board and high Reserve officers.
LONDON, July 20 (Reuters) -- Britain's national dock strike in June cost the country about 90,000,000 ($252,000,000) in exports, a Government survey estimated today.

GENEVA, July 20 -- President Eisenhower operated an atomic research reactor today. He sat at the control panel of the reactor at United Nations European headquarters shortly before going to the Big Four conference.
The paraplegic, only ten years ago considered a hopeless cripple, can now in most cases achieve economic independence and lead a useful life, a United Nations expert declared last night.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UP) -- Chairman Harold D. Cooley, Democrat of North Carolina, said today a House Agriculture subcommittee has "made progress" in settling differences over new sugar legislation.

MASSAPEQUA, L. I., July 20 -- A jig danced to the tune of bullets peppering around the feet may be classified as side-splitting entertainment in western movies. But the Nassau County police called the stunt dangerous juvenile delinquency when they arrested four teen-age toughs here last night for trying it on two other boys.

May we comment on your July 15 editorial, "A Street Lane for Buses," together with the suggestion of banning private automobiles entirely from certain parts of New York City reported by Harrison Salisbury in the recent New York Times series, "Our Changing City."

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 20 -- Sixty persons were injured today when a throng of demonstrators against the 1954 truce accords split into small mobs that pillaged two hotels. A French military gendarme and a French woman were among the casualties, but no Americans were injured.

ICE cream straight out of a sizzling hot oven spells a baked Alaska to Americans, a Norwegian omelet to the French -- and an exciting dessert to both groups. In fine restaurants pastry chefs turn out this dressy version of old-fashioned ice cream and cake for several dollars an order.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 20 -The first solemn pontifical mass of the thirty-sixth international Eucharistic Congress was celebrated today by Francis Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York.
The State of New Jersey has made an official bid for Ellis Island, thus entering into competition with New York City.
In an echo of the train-robbery days of the old Wild West, two bandits staged a baggage car hold-up last night in Manhattan's West Side.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Senate completed Congressional action today on a bill authorizing a $500,000,000 civilian airport construction program throughout the nation.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- For the third time in ten days, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission today refused to tell Senate investigators of his talks with Sherman Adams about the Dixon-Yates power controversy.

Rubber prices continued to climb to new high ground yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. The volume was the fourth heaviest of the year. The close was up 100 to 190 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 3,870 tons. Trading was influenced by sharply higher prices in London and tight supplies for immediate delivery.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Federal Government ended the 1955 fiscal year a little better off, financially, than had been expected six months ago.
Three persons were wounded in a pistol battle yesterday when a guard thwarted an attempt by two armed men to seize a $5,000 payroll from a Bronx workshop for former tuberculous and cardiac patients.

New drafts totaling $41,800,000 were drawn by United States exporters on Latin American importers during June, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This was the largest amount in three months.

Having a job is a wholesome contribution to character-building for youngsters. The Police Athletic League, which has had a placement division since 1948, is making a concerted effort this summer to find jobs for boys who want to earn some money during the vacation.
American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries achieved new highs in earnings for six or twelve-month periods in the half just ended, according to the consolidated statement released yesterday.

Contemplating the state of business at midyear the Department of Commerce finds "the forward momentum" of the past few months continuing unabated. This momentum, according to "The Survey of Current Business," derives from "the interplay of rising income and expenditures," and its result has been to carry both industrial output and the aggregate production of the economy to new high ground.
GENEVA, July 20 -- There is a "Big Four" at Geneva and a "Little Four" -- the latter being the harassed spokesmen who have to pass on what the Big Four say without getting into trouble.
New issues of common and preferred stock of the Consumers Power Company valued at more than $25,800,000 will be offered to investors today.
Countries whose dollar shortages limit their ability to buy from the United States can find a growing supply of the goods they want in Israel, a trade group was told yesterday.

Guaranty Trust Company, one of the nation's ten largest banks, has put into operation a plan which will help officers and key employes of its correspondent banks to buy stock of the bank in which they are employed.
The New York Central Railroad, which has been one of the roads hardest hit by the nationwide freight car shortage, plans to spend $23,000,000 to correct the situation.
TOKYO, July 20 -- The United States Air Force is planning to release thirty of its forty air bases in Japan, the director of the Japan Procurement Board said today.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 9 points off to 3 points up yesterday.
The Consolidated Edison Company will increase its payments to the city for the use of under-street space for electrical transformer vaults.
DETROIT, July 20 -- A Federal grand jury indicted the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., today on charges of violating the Federal election laws.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis announced grants totaling $1,652,741 yesterday for polio research and the support of respiratory centers. "The fight against polio is not over," Basil O'Connor, president of the foundation, declared. He mentioned these important projects to be followed under the thirty-one grants:

Return trips from the beach or other vacation outings mean an increase in night driving. And while no motorist would think of driving after dark without turning on his lights, some do fail to notice when a light burns out.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Justice Department advised Congress today it had "strong doubts" that existing Federal law was adequate to deal with union welfare fund abuses.

Don Newcombe held the Cubs to two hits as the Dodgers won the first game of a twilightnight double-header, 10 -- 1, at Ebbets Field last night. The Cub run was unearned because of an error by Junior Gilliam.
GENEVA, July 20 -- Following are sketches of advisers to the delegations at the Big Four conference:

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. was knocked down today by a looping right-hand punch thrown by Representative Cleveland M. Bailey in a clash over public school segregation.
Net earnings of American Airlines, Inc. in the first half this year climbed 70.3 per cent to $8,537,000 from $5,014,000 reported for the initial six months of last year.
LONDON, July 20 -- The rectors and vice chancellors of universities in most of the countries of West Europe met today at Cambridge University to discuss their common problems.
