GENEVA, July 20 -- One of the most important questions that Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, will raise when he goes to Moscow this year is whether the Soviet Union is willing to proceed with the reunification of Germany.
MONTAUK, L. I., July 20 -This seems to be bluefish week at Montauk. The blues are running king size.

Your editorial "Light in Cyprus" on the British invitation to Greece for discussions on Cyprus is in line with your previous one, "Dispute Over Cyprus," which defended on Aug. 20, 1954, the islanders' right of self-determination. Words cannot adequately express my country's appreciation of The New York Times' invaluable assistance.

Volume ebbed on the stock market yesterday and little enthusiasm was in evidence, but the day passed with a generally firm tone and a modest rally near the close left more than half the list with net gains.

TRENTON, July 20 -- A special legislative committee on water supply will recommend to the Legislature that Chimney Rock in Somerset County be developed as the site of a new reservoir for metropolitan North Jersey.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy again turned down President Eisenhower's proposal for an atom-powered "peace ship."
The peaceful uses of nuclear energy will be explored in a series of radio broadcasts to be produced next month by the public affairs department of the Columbia Broadcasting System.
CHICAGO, July 20 (UP) -Swaps and Nashua, two of the standout 3-year-old race horses of the year, will meet in a $100,000 winner-take-all match race at Washington Park on Aug. 31.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- The Yankees virtually were left at the post tonight and though they made heroic efforts in the closing rounds it was no go. They dropped the second encounter of their torrid three-game series with the White Sox, 8 to 6, before 36,869 howling fans.

The Lifetime Cutlery Corporation has leased the one-story building at 12 Grattan Street in Brooklyn from Gottesman Brothers. It will use the property for the storage, warehousing and distribution of cutlery and kitchen novelties.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Senate and House conferees agreed tentatively today on a military Reserves program that would put no compulsory obligations for continued training on any man who is now seeing or who has seen active service.

CLEVELAND, July 20 (UP) -The Washington Senators scored four unearned runs off Early Wynn in the third inning tonight and went on to beat the Cleveland Indians. 6 -- 4, for their fifth consecutive triumph.

A PROGRAM of French music -- French except for the encores played by the soloists -- was presented last night in Lewisohn Stadium by the Stadium Symphony under Thomas Scherman. There even was a first Stadium performance of a work that has virtually dropped from the repertory: Charpentier's "Impressions d'Italie," a four-movement suite.
The quest for security and protection continues at a record pace, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday.
NORTHVILLE, Mich., July 20 -- Sam Snead set a sizzling pace with a 66 in the first qualifying round of the Professional Golfers Association national championship today.
LONDON, July 20 (AP) -- Soviet newspaper men today called President Eisenhower's anti-war remarks at the Big Four meeting "quite an important statement."
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 20--Although a nonpolitical event, the ninth annual Turf Charity Ball at the clubhouse of the Monmouth Park Race Track here will feature a "dark horse."

KHARKOV, U. S. S. R., July 20 -- The United States farm delegation temporarily abandoned its study of Soviet agriculture today to give lessons in American farm technique to inquisitive Ukrainian farmers.

Directors of James Talcott, Inc., factoring and commercial finance company, have authorized the registration and proposed public offering of 100,000 additional shares of common stock, it was announced yesterday by James Talcott, president.

Despite increased sales, earnings of Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company in the first half of this year dropped 6.9 per cent to $12,562,932 from the $13,490,505 earned in the corresponding period last year.

A Bronx sewing machine corporation and three of its officers pleaded not guilty yesterday in Brooklyn Special Sessions to charges of using the radio for false and misleading advertising. The officers were held in $1,000 bail each by Justice Peter Cawse Jr., for trial on Nov. 3.

This corner, always curious about what is happening to our town as the building trades replace the old look by a new one, has given respectful attention to the series of articles in which our colleagues on the news staff have summed up the transformations of the past few years.

THE $25,000,000 deal in which General Teleradio, Inc., is buying R. K. O.-Radio Pictures is another illustration of the unpredictable economics of television. The deal, which is certain to have wide repercussions throughout the entertainment world, had its genesis in a local do-or-die experiment over WOR-TV.
Three Brooklyn youths were arrested yesterday on charges of looting railway freight cars of goods worth $30,000 to $40,000 in the last two years.
Ramon Fuentes gained a split decision over Hector Constance of Trinidad, B. W. I., in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.
Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, Broadway's most illustrious acting couple, will share co-billing for the twenty-third time in January when they open in a new play by Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse.

Whatever the final outcome on the Federal highway building program, one must admire the dogged determination of the majority in the House Public Works Committee which insists that spending and taxing shall be voted at the same time. Once again, after a night's sleep and further reflection which probably included a forward look to the elections of November, 1956, the committee stood by its guns and approved the principle of pay-as-you-build.
Jean Baptiste, Mrs. Lloyd P. Tate's 2-year-old colt, won the fifty-third running of the $10,000 added Albany Stakes at the Saratoga-at-Jamaica race meeting yesterday.

GENEVA, July 20 -- Sir Anthony Eden offered the Soviet Union today the first Western concession on European security and German reunification. He made a modification of his specific proposals, the only ones thus far advanced by the West, on these cardinal issues of the Big Four conference.
A public official accused the city's private welfare agencies yesterday of getting more public funds and publicity than their
CAMDEN, N. J., July 20 -- The new $90,000,000 span that will link Gloucester City, N. J., and Philadelphia will be named the Walt Whitman Bridge. The span is scheduled to be opened next year.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UP) The United States Immigration Service is investigating 14,500 charges that aliens in this country are or have been engaged in subversive activities.
The nuclear-powered submarine Sea Wolf, second of her type, will be launched today at Groton, Conn.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Unity committees of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations have agreed to combine their names for their merged organization.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 20 -- Asian, Arab and African members of the United Nations sought today action to "bring an end to the bloodshed in Morocco."
Patrolman Harold J. Pogeweit's retentive memory for faces paid off yesterday. It returned an escaped murderer to custody and earned his captor a promotion.
BUFFALO, July 20 -- Delegates at the annual convention of the New York State Federation of Labor voted unanimously today to oppose the public development of hydroelectric power.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 20 -Kurt Nielsen of Copenhagen, runner-up to Tony Trabert at Wimbledon, was beaten in the Pennsylvania state grass court tennis championship today at the Merion Cricket Club.

VALHALLA, N. Y., July 20 -- Fourteen persons gathered at a graveside today to eulogize Mrs. Maud Glover Folsom and to protect their inheritances under the terms of her husband's will. The husband, Charles Stuart Folsom of New Rochelle, N. Y., a New York real estate operator, left a $2,700,000 estate when he died last Nov. 13 at the age of 77.
Record sales and earnings were achieved by the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation in the first six months this year.
WASHINGTON, July 20--The indictment of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., by a Federal court in Detroit today
AMES, Iowa, July 20 -- The Russian farm group today watched a modern American meat-packing plant make good the famous boast that "we use everything in the pig but the squeal."
A series of incidents over the last six weeks has led to a new crisis between Costa Rica and Nicaragua.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Corn and oats futures declined to new lows for the season today, with scattered long liquidation as well as local pressure. Trade in the feed grains was influenced by the favorable crop prospects.
GENEVA, July 20 (UP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's statement today at the opening of United States atomic exhibit here:

Stockholders of the FederalMogul Corporation and Bower Roller Bearing Company voted at separate meetings in Detroit yesterday to merge both companies into an organization called Federal-Mogul-Bower Bearings, Inc. The merger becomes effective July 29.

The delegation of Soviet agricultural officials now touring Iowa appears to have been having some eye-opening experiences in that state. Riding about in their airconditioned bus, they have seen, for example, a 160-acre farm operated by a farmer and his family without any hired help, yet producing a vast amount of food as well as a net income well above $10,000 last year.

PRINCEON, N. J., July 20 -The white frame house at 47 University Place bears no resemblance to the towering United Nations building in New York. But inside it is a working example of what the world organization is seeking -- peaceful international living.

A decline of 485,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 158,822,000 barrels, compared with 159,307,000 a week earlier and 161,786,000 a year ago.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 20 -- Facts about United States consumers -- what they eat, how much they spend, their health and savings -- were outlined by experts in consumer problems at a University of Minnesota Institute on the subject that opened here Monday.
ROME, July 20 -- Italian designers, in their fall and winter collections now being shown, allow women to choose their own waistline. But wherever it is, it must be slim.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 20 -- Cary Grant is the first of three co-stars to be signed by Stanley Kramer for his next United Artists production, "The Pride and the Passion."
A superseding indictment was returned yesterday by a Federal grand jury against Samuel Roth, 60-year-old publisher, for sending obscene articles and publications through the mails.

The Board of Estimate was urged yesterday by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa to reject proposals to make parks of the Seton Hospital site in the Bronx and the Neponsit Hospital tract in the Rockaways, Queens.
GENEVA, July 20 -- Four baffled heads of government handed over to their foreign ministers today the task of bridging apparently irreconcilable differences between the Soviet Union and the West.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
ROME, July 20 (AP) -- Italian courts ended today a sixteenmonth inquiry into the Wilma Montesi scandal and ordered Piero Piccioni, a jazz pianist, to trial on manslaughter charges.
Eight persons were hurt seriously in a four-alarm fire yesterday morning in two huge gasoline tanks at the Texas Company storage plant in Long Island City, Queens.

BONN, Germany, July 20 -The West German Government announced today the Cabinet had decided recently to take over the Gehlen Organization, a private intelligence agency in the service of a United States intelligence group.
GENEVA, July 20 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the proposal of Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Premier for an all-European security pact as issued by the Soviet delegation:
ROME, July 20 -- Gov. Averell Harriman arrived in Rome by air from Israel with Mrs. Harriman and two aides this afternoon.

In the ordinary tie-in promotion a coat manufacturer joins with a trousers producer to cry their wares together. In the next step the tea importers, the sugar refiners and the lemon shippers get together to tell of the virtues of iced tea.

The Geneva conference has now passed the halfway mark of the six days allotted to it, and while it would be premature to draw final conclusions it can be said that this long-projected meeting of the heads of government has already served at least one good purpose.

Second base at Yankee Stadium was transformed yesterday into a flower-banked pulpit. The pitcher's mound was a circular garden of red geraniums and caladium. Fountains played between first and second and between second and third.

Whatever chance the Giants had to beat Tom Poholsky and the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday at the Polo Grounds vanished in the first inning. After the first two Giants had hit safely, putting runners at third and first, the attack bogged down and the visitors proceeded to win, 9 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- There are no orchards anywhere near the Capitol, but members of the House from the West are daily hurling tree-borne fruit at one another from what appears to be an inexhaustible supply. And they are trampling out the vintage of the grapes of wrath.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., July 20 -- Mrs. E. C. K. Finch of the Country Club of New Canaan won on the eighteenth green today in the second round of the fifth women's TriCounty Golf Association championships.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Maritime Administration announced today a $750,000,000 shipbuilding and repair program. It is intended to raise the United States from its present tenth place among world merchant fleets.

The directorate of Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation at a meeting yesterday at Houston authorized a stock offering in exchange for shares of Texas Eastern Production Corporation stock. One share of the transmission company's common will be offered for each 2.6 shares of production company stock.

SINGAPORE, July 20--Pham Van Dong, Vice Premier of North Vietnam, addressed himself directly for the first time yesterday to Premier Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam on the question of elections for the reunification of their country.

Nineteen local public housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration borrowed $121,465,000 yesterday on bonds maturing over forty years at an average interest cost of 2.552 per cent.
MARIETTA, Ga., July 20 (AP) -- The Air Force showed off today its newest combat transport plane. It carries a load like a freight car and flies like a swift sports plane.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 20 -- An investigation of the New Haven Railroad train wreck at Bridgeport last Thursday was completed by the Interstate Commerce Commission, the Connecticut Public Utilities Commission and the railroad today.
KANSAS CITY, July 20 (AP)--Connie Mack accepted from the Athletics a plaque for his contributions to baseball in a brief ceremony prior to the Kansas City Athletics-Boston Red Sox game tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -Members of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today agreed to have their majority and minority reports on the natural gas bill ready next Monday. Chairman Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, who has opposed the bill, said this would clear the legislation for floor action next week "if somebody wants to take the dive."
Special Sessions Justice Gerald P. Culkin was designated yesterday as Democratic nominee for General Sessions judge. Municipal Court Justice Birdie Amsterdam was picked as City Court candidate.

Two teen-agers from this area were killed in a highway accident in Goshen, N. Y. yesterday. Another automobile accident at Morgantown, W. Va. took the life of a North Tarrytown, N. Y. resident and injured his wife.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption for the period of May 29 to July 2 averaged 34,659 bales for each working day. This compared with an average of 31,778 bales for the corresponding period a year ago, and with 35,162 for the May period this year.
The Welfare Department has doubled its hunt for rent-gouging landlords of relief clients in the last three months, State Rent Administrator Charles Abrams said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies made it nine in a row tonight when they swept a double-header with the Cincinnati Redlegs, 6 -- 0 and 4 -- 2. This set a modern record for consecutive victories by a Phillies' team.

ALBANY, July 20 (AP) -- Jacob K. Javits, Attorney General, said today the state would not appeal from a judgment awarding $112,290 in damages to Louis Hoffner for wrongful imprisonment on a first-degree murder charge.
BUENOS AIRES, July 20 -- A new wave of rumors swept through this city as the Argentine Navy put to sea.
GENEVA, July 20 -- President Eisenhower has adopted in Geneva precisely the technique he applies to the rough and tumble of politics in Washington.
The Owens-Illinois Glass Company will split its common stock two-for-one if shareholders approve at a special meeting in Toledo on Sept. 14.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -Representative Jack Westland, Republican of Washington, today accused military shippers of giving the port of Seattle "the short end" of its trans-Pacific cargo shipments.

An integrated team of giant and small electronic "brains" massed at 595 Madison Avenue, off Fifty-seventh Street, will begin today to solve, for a fee, office clerical problems fed to them by business men. The "brains" will perform on the main floor at world headquarters of International Business Machines Corporation.
Simon W. Gerson in his letter printed July 14 betrays a tortured understanding of our American "right to dissent when we wish."

The State of Ohio raised $52,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance highway construction. The borrowing was at an interest cost of 2.308 per cent on serial obligations maturing semi-annually on March 15 and Sept. 15 from 1956 to 1972.

PARIS, July 20 -- Nearly two hundred legislators of the fifteen countries of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization discussed plans today for forming themselves into a permanent parliamentary organization.

GAZA ARMISTICE LINE, Egyptian Side, July 20 -- Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns, United Nations truce chief, said today that nothing was likely to prevent conclusion of an agreement between Egypt and Israel on ways to curb fighting along the Gaza line.

QUEEN ELIZABETH II keeps her trim figure with lots of walking and willpower, reports The United Press from London. The young British monarch faces many temptations to go overboard on good food and drink simply because she is royalty. She never is without state banquets, official lunches and parties on her schedule. With them go elaborate foods, champagnes and other wines.

A property in the Beekman Place area of the East Side has passed to new control with the sale by Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, of the seven-story apartment house on lot 25 by 100 feet at 924 Second Avenue, northeast corner of Forty-ninth Street.
NEWARK, July 20 -- A Federal judge issued a temporary order today barring a striking union from trying to stop fuel deliveries by independent suppliers to Flying Tiger Lines, Inc.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 20 -- The largest turnout of youngsters ever to appear at one time for racing on Long Island Sound participated in the thirtieth anniversary celebration of Larchmont Yacht Club's open junior regatta today.
WASHINGTON, July 20--The Senate generally is viewing calmly and without pessimism the seeming hardening of the essential Soviet position at the Big Four conference in Geneva.

A year ago today, in Geneva, the accord was reached that was supposed to put an end to the fighting in Indochina. There was a temporary partition, at the Seventeenth Parallel, and a provision for a free election, one year from now, to determine the basis upon which divided Vietnam could be unified.
WASHINGTON, July 20--The House of Representatives approved today an increase in the national legal minimum wage from 75 cents to $1 an hour. The vote was 362-54.

Electric power production in the week ended last Saturday was 10,440,000,000 kilowatt hours, a record high. It compared with 9,759,000,000 in the preceding week and 8,951,000,000 in the corresponding week last year, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.
JEDDA, Saudi Arabia, July 20 (AP) -- It's a man's world in Saudi Arabia, so the captain's wife was locked away in a cabin when King Saud visited the world's biggest oil tanker last night.

GENEVA, July 20 -- President Eisenhower credited the Russians today with no less earnest a desire for peace than that of the West. He appealed for a common effort to bridge differences in viewpoint on the interlocked issues of the unification of Germany and the security of Europe.

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- The Hasty House Farms' Platan won the $61,600 Equipoise Mile before 19,647 fans at Arlington Park today. The Reverie Knoll Farms' Smokescreen was second and the Maine Chance Farm's Jet Action, the 5-2 favorite, ran third.

The Coast Guard's top experts on contracts between merchant seamen and ship masters and on laws concerning crew welfare, will retire in Washington at the end of the month. He is Comdr. Robert H. Farinholt, 57 years old, the service's recognized authority on personnel problems.

GENEVA, July 21--President Eisenhower proposed here today that the Soviet Union and the United States exchange complete blueprints of their military establishments and open both countries to unlimited aerial inspection by each other's planes.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UP) The Civil Defense Administration is trying to disperse its stockpile of life-saving supplies in case of an atomic attack on the nation's larger cities.
AMES, Iowa, July 21 -- Iowa's corn and hog farmers are proving better salesmen for the American way of life than Washington's "cold war" specialists.

Two new films, will open at first-run theatres this morning. "How to Be Very, Very Popular," a Twentieth Century-Fox comedy in CinemaScope and color, with Betty Grable, Sheree North, Robert Cummings, Charles Coburn and Tommy Noonan, is at the Roxy.

ALBANY, July 21 (AP) -- The State Tax Department reported today that tax revenue for the first three months of the current fiscal year was $79,997,507 higher than during the corresponding period last year. It said total revenue was $507,241,638, compared with $427,244,131 in the 1954 fiscal quarter.

GENEVA, July 21 -- Divergence between the sweeping United States objectives, outlined today by President Eisenhower, and the "more modest" plans of Prime Minister Eden emerged from today's session of the four-power conference.
Thirty thousand Jehovah's Witnesses were told yesterday that traditional methods of ordination to the ministry were scripturally unsound and "out of order."
ROME, July 21 -- Averell Harriman, Governor of New York, conferred today with religious and political leaders in Rome.

"Tanglewood on Parade," the annual benefit for the Berkshire Music Center in Lenox, Mass., will take place Thursday, Aug. 11. The day's activities, beginning at 4 P. M. and ending at 11, will include demonstrations by every department of the school, a lawn supper, an evening concert, drawing of door prizes and dancing on the lawn.

LONDON, July 21 -- The Baptist World Alliance unanimously resolved today that "we will not rest content until we witness the achievement of religious freedom and individual liberty throughout the world."
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company is undertaking today its first public financing in twenty-seven years.

LONDON, July 21 (Reuters) -- The Duke of Kent's third car crash in just more than a year was threatening today to develop into a minor storm involving the 19-year-old cousin of the Queen and the War Office.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Federal Court of Appeals upheld today a lower court ruling that a 1949 lease on valuable oil and gas lands in New Mexico violated the law. The lease had been granted by the then Secretary of the Interior, Oscar Chapman.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Government made the largest demand today since mid-1953 for aluminum to be set aside for defense uses. Stepped-up production of military planes was the major factor.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Two Senators today asked for an investigation of a proxy contest for control of Libby, McNeill Libby, food processing company. The request was made in a letter by Republican Senators John W. Bricker of Ohio and Wallace F. Bennett of Utah.

LONDON, July 21 -- J. P. L. Thomas, First Lord of the Admiralty, questioned today the wisdom of Britain's shipbuilding industry expanding its facilities simply because foreign yards had obtained orders that normally would have come to Britain.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The house voted today to require the Government to continue full-scale purchase of strategic minerals under a program to encourage their domestic discovery and production.
GENEVA, July 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower went yachting on Lake Geneva today -- together with a fleet of small boats filled with photographers.
Encouraging business news and an apparent easing of the uncertainty over changes to be wrought by the Geneva conference combined yesteday to bring a sharp advance in the stock market.

BONN, Germany, July 21 -- The press service of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's party reported last night that if Germany's reunification were sidetracked in Geneva, the Bonn Government would open bilateral discussions with the Soviet Union through diplomatic channels.
GENEVA, July 21 -- A new Soviet proposal for a nonaggression agreement between the North Atlantic and East European military blocs was presented today to the Big Four conference.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- This capital, which has seen the assassination of two Presidents, Lincoln and Garfield, was unmoved today by reports that the Swiss and Italian press had been critical of the tight security surrounding the movements of President Eisenhower in Geneva.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 21 -- Bill Corwin of the American Yacht Club sailed a large ring around the rest of the 210 Class at Larchmont Race Week today. He was so far ahead with Harpoon in time and distance that there was a question: Had he sailed a too-short course or had the others been wrong on one that was too long?

Motorists traveling to and from New York this week-end may expect detours or delays because of repairs, new construction, congestion or traffic checks on the following routes (the numbers correspond to those on the maps):
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The weekly average of member bank reserve balances for the week ending July 20 decreased $5,000,000 to $18,774,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

New York State's new Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, Dr. Paul H. Hoch, recently reported that the state's mental hospitals are now 25 to 30 per cent overcrowded. In the last year alone, state mental patients increased by 3,000 to reach an over-all total of 116,000.
WASHINGTON, July 21--The State Department insisted today that it was not considering cutting off aid to Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UP) -- A Senate committee took the unusual step today of publicly clearing two of its members of any blame for sponsoring a bill to let a narcotics law violator remain in the United States.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UP) -- The Democratic leader of the House of Representatives said today he still held some hope for a July 30 adjournment. But he added, "I don't see how we can make it."

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Reuben B. Robertson Jr. of Hamilton, Ohio, won the approval of the Senate Armed Services Committee today for appointment as Deputy Secretary of Defense after having divested himself of two stock holdings.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff, with the approval of Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, made the basic recommendations for President Eisenhower's proposal to exchange defense data with the Soviet Union.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., July 21 -- Engineers and technicians wielding 'cello bows play symphonies of "stress" and "natural frequency" every day in the engine division of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation.

A new apartment building accommodating forty-eight families at 41-40 Parsons Boulevard in Flushing, Queens, has passed to new ownership in a stock-sale transaction. The buyers, represented by Joseph G. Teichman, took over all the stock of the Barclay-Parsons Gardens Corporation from the owners and builders, George Rosen and George Rapoport.

A scheduled dance recital by Paul Draper at Pennsylvania State University, University Park, Pa., was canceled by university officials following American Legion protests against his appearance. The recital was to have been held Tuesday evening.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Pentagon underestimated its spending by about $1,472,000,000 in six months, an analysis of budget figures for the fiscal year 1955 disclosed today.
Edward R. Murrow's "See It Now" television program will not continue next fall in its usual time of 10:30 to 11 o'clock each Tuesday evening.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP) -- Gus Bell hit three homers in a losing cause tonight as Philadelphia rallied for three runs in the eighth inning to beat the Cincinnati Redlegs, 5 -- 3. The Phillies extended their winning streak to ten games.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The atomic powered submarine Seawolf, launched in Groton, Conn., today, carries on the name of two earlier underseas craft, both of which were lost.

Rubber prices continued to climb to new highs for the life of the contracts yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Futures were up 80 to 135 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 5,590 tons, the heaviest volume since September, 1949. The spot price on No. 1 smoked rubber sheets was up 1 1/4 cents a pound to 42 7/8 cents, the highest price since the Korean conflict.

BOSTON, July 21 (AP) -- Directors of the Gillette Company, parent of Gillette Safety Razor Company, have recommended a two-for-one split of common stock. A special stockholders' meeting will vote on the proposal Sept. 16.
BLED, Yugoslavia, July 21 -- The Yugoslavs have greeted with apparent calculated silence a proposal by the Soviet Communist party for a rapprochement on a party basis.

The General Electric Company had record net earnings of $101,892,000 in the first six months of 1955, Ralph J. Cordiner, president, reported yesterday. The earnings, equal to $1.18 a share of common stock, represent a 9 per cent increase over the previous peak of $93,856,000, or $1.08 a share, in the first half of 1954.

One of the most delicate problems involved in our foreign aid program, particularly in its military aspects, is raised by the Congressional requirement that recipient countries permit "continuous observation and review" by American representatives of how that aid is being employed.
Drabness and decline. This describes the last quarter of a century in North and Central Brooklyn -- the old Eastern District.
Samuel S. Multer and A. Edward Fiore, backed by the Bronx and Queens Democratic organizations, respectively, became deputy commissioners of the State Liquor Authority yesterday.

Brooklyn Republicans yesterday announced endorsements of Democrats for Surrogate and three Municipal Court posts for the November election. There were indications of a trade to retain one Supreme Court seat for the Republicans.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- A United States security board has found "reasonable doubt" of the loyalty of William Henry Taylor, an American official of the International Monetary Fund, his counsel said today.
Much of the loot taken in the West Side train robbery Wednesday night was discovered yesterday afternoon in a park in the Bronx.
BUENOS AIRES, July 21 -- A bomb explosion rocked this city's downtown section early today and shattered the peace called for by President Juan D. Peron.

BRANFORD, Conn., July 21 -- A long ribbon of welded rail was laid into the main line of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad here at noon today. Patrick B. McGinnis, president, formally tacked it into place with a gold-plated spike, thereby marking the beginning of the end for the old familiar click-clack.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Tension between Costa Rica and Nicaragua was eased today by a series of conciliatory moves by Nicaragua.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Marty Marion today signed a contract to manage the White Sox for two more years. A few hours later Marty's players put their stamp of approval on the document by flattening the Yankees in the series finale, 9 to 6, before 30,962 jubilant fans.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 21 -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem warned his countrymen today against "unbecoming gestures that can only cause misunderstanding and help our enemies, the Communists."

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Pan American World Airways proposed today to provide "integrated and through service" for international passengers if permitted to operate on the lucrative Boston-New York-Philadelphia - Washington - Miami route.

LOS ANGELES, July 21 (AP) -- Bill Woolsey of Honolulu scored a surprise victory over the defending champion, Ford Konno, also of Hawaii, in the 200-meter free-style final tonight in the National Amateur Athletic Union swimming and diving championships.

The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania borrowed $60,000,000 at short term yesterday on an issue of tax anticipation notes due on May 25, 1956. The issue was bought by a syndiate headed by Philadelphia National Bank and Mellon National Bank and Trust Company at a bid of 100 for notes bearing 1.5 per cent interest.
CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Wall Street saw something new yesterday -- the establishment of the first investment company controlled and managed by Negroes. It is Special Markets, Inc., at 92 Liberty Street. The president is Philip M. Jenkins, once manager of the mutual fund department of Baruch Brothers Co. and most recently with Bache Co.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- A stronger undertone developed in the grain markets today, with coarse grains showing a considerable price improvement, while wheat was quite firm at times.
ATHENS, July 21 -- Foreign Minister Stephan Stephanopoulos said today the Greek Government would appeal the Cyprus issue to the United Nations at once.

The American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., asked today for an opportunity to clear up by official testimony any impression created by the recent hearings of the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee that the Guild might be under Communist influence.
WASHINGTON, July 21--Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, made a conditional offer today to give up by Aug. 1 his lucrative partnership in a New York firm.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 21 -- Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New Haven Railroad, said here today that the pay-as-you-park policy for commuters would not be applied for at least a month and possibly longer.

Details of the $3,000,000 advertising program for the Florida Citrus Commission for 1955-56 were made public yesterday in Lakeland, Fla., the industry trade group's headquarters. Madison Avenue is considerably interested in the plans since Benton Bowles, Inc., has just taken the account over. J. Walter Thompson Company previously had handled it.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations has accused an American Federation of Labor affiliate of "unbridled piracy."
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 21 -- The coalition Government that has ruled Indonesia for the last two years was on the verge of collapse tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Following are excerpts from the official transcript of the testimony today of Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations:

Walt Disney deserves some sort of citation -- and probably will get one -- for creating the sixty-acre "Disneyland" near Anaheim, Calif. One may venture the prediction that "Adventureland," "Frontierland," "Fantasyland" and "Tomorrowland" will be so successful, visited by children (and their parents) in such throngs, that Mr. Disney will be petitioned to construct a similar wonderland in the East for the benefit of youngsters who are unable to make the trek to California.

The New York City Transit Authority established yesterday a new fiscal policy of putting idle funds to work. The result will be a $137,000 increase in income by the end of the fiscal year, June 30, 1956.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, July 21 (Reuters) -- Taxpayers in New Zealand today cheered a Government announcement of a 20 per cent income tax rebate, under which individual taxpayers will receive up to $210 each.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A South Korean economic delegation was preparing today to return to Korea after two months of inconclusive negotiations with the United States Government on the exchange rate of the Korean currency, the hwan.

PARIS, July 21 -- Violent Nationalist demonstrations broke out today in Marrakesh, Southern Morocco, on the occasion of the first official visit there of Gilbert Grandval, the new French Resident General.
A recent decision by the New York State Supreme Court served to "keep the New York State Athletic Commission in business." Too bad!

GENEVA, July 21 -- The Big Four conference is declining fast. What was advertised for weeks as a realistic private discussion of conflicting national interests, and started this week as a determined demonstration of international chumminess, developed today into a propaganda battle between the United States and the Soviet Union.
NEW DELHI, July 21 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and President Eisenhower have been exchanging cabled messages on the problem of relations between the United States and Communist China.
Champions of abstract art surrendered the ring yesterday to a famous veteran of battles in art -- Sir Jacob Epstein.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 21 (UP) -- A smouldering issue in the American Medical Association blazed into the open today. General practitioners made public an association report that asserted surgeons charged their patients too much.

PARIS, July 21 -- A committee of legislators representing the fifteen countries of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization drafted a resolution today to provide for a permanent organization of parliamentarians from the allied countries
Plans for a building in the downtown financial district representing an investment of $9,000,000 were announced yesterday as the Seamen's Bank for Savings sold its former quarters at 72 Wall Street.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 -- Armed with questions, two groups of teen-agers went off today to visit the headquarters of the Soviet and Polish delegations to the United Nations.

GROTON, Conn., July 21 -- The keel of the nation's third atomic submarine was laid here this morning. A few hours later the second one -- the Seawolf -- slipped down the ways into the Thames River. The placing of the keelplate was as unimpressive as the launching was ceremonious. it was not generally known to their hearers, the "past" in the atomic submarine cycle was near by, too.
Your extremely interesting and well-written editorial, "Commercial Atomic Power," appearing in the July 20 issue contains one incorrect statement about which I am sure you would want to be informed.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 799,040 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 21 -- Two youngsters were among the players who gained the semifinal round of the Garden State Women's Golf Association's I match-play championship today] at the Essex County Country Club.
ZURICH, Switzerland, July 21 -- Definite identification of the hormone that makes possible the nursing of all young mammals was reported here today.

An exchange of correspondence between the American Civil Liberties Union and Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times, concerning the dismissal of Melvin L. Barnet as a Times copyreader was made public yesterday.
BUFFALO, July 21 -- The ninety-second State Federation of Labor convention ended here today with an appeal to union men to vote as union men and not by "party label."

YONKERS, N. Y., July 21 -- James O'Neill, 75-year-old Supreme Court stenographer, had his first automobile accident in forty-two years of driving this afternoon. The accident caused serious injuries to his housekeeper and the death of a horse.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 21 -- Edward Moylan gave one of his finest performances on turf today in gaining the semi-finals of the Pennsylvania State tennis championship with Tony Trabert, Victor Seixas and Hamilton Richardson.

Players of the favorites were looking for co-makers, not bookmakers, after yesterday's Saratoga-at-Jamaica racing program. The favorites -- and their backers -- had a rough afternoon. None of the people's choices won.

KANSAS CITY, July 21 (UP) -- Frank Sullivan blanked the Kansas City Athletics for seven innings today and survived a late rally for his twelfth triumph, a 4-3 decision for the Boston Red Sox. The loss was the tenth in a row for the A's.

CLEVELAND, July 21 (UP)--Vic Wertz tied the score at 3--3 with a three-run pinch double in the ninth inning today. Then the Cleveland Indians went on to defeat the Washington Senators, 4--3, in the tenth when Al Smith raced home from first on a single.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 21 -- The Soviet Union has agreed to support the admission of seven Asian and African nations, including Japan, to the United Nations, according to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India.
A blistering, unrelenting sun beat down on the city yesterday as New Yorkers sweltered in tenements, factory lofts and offices.
ROME, July 21 -- Rome designers, in the third days of Italy's series of fashion openings, hewed to the natural body line with occasional digressions into below-hip fantasy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21--The Soviet Union rejected years ago the two points in President Eisenhower's proposal today for an exchange of information about Soviet and United States military establishments.
ALBANY, July 21 (AP) -- The Albany County Democratic organization endorsed Governor Harriman tonight as its choice for the party's Presidential nomination next year.

The Geneva conference, deadlocked over the two primary problems of German reunification and European security, has been stirred to new interest by President Eisenhower's startling proposal for quick action on what he regards as the overriding problem of disarmament.

The Kips Bay Boys Club, which has provided health, recreational and educational programs for underprivileged boys for forty years, will be the beneficiary of a theatre party on Oct. 25. The trustees and women's board of the organization have taken over the preview performance that evening at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre of "The Chalk Garden," a new comedy by Enid Bagnold.
The final week of concerts at Lewisohn Stadium will begin Monday evening with an all-Tchaikovsky program conducted by Efrem Kurtz. Isaac Stern will be soloist in the Violin Concerto.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., July 21 (AP) -- The steamship Mazatlan rested her hull in a drydock today after a thirty-day cruise that started as a luxury trip and ended with passengers subsisting on pancakes and rations from lifeboats.
Everyone knows what the American wife of today is like. But what about the wife of tomorrow?
The much-heralded "fair shake" for Brooklyn's longshoreman has been abandoned as inoperable -- at their union's request.

One month before the Geneva conference the Communists reintroduced a regime of terror in Hungary. The quotas of industrial workers were raised. The collectivization of farms was resumed and speeded up.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Approximately 970,000 more shots of Salk poliomyelitis vaccine were released today by the Public Health Service.
DAYTON, Ohio, July 21 (UP) -- The Government today ordered Jane Edith Thomas, 4-year-old daughter of a former soldier, out of the country.
The Monsanto Chemical Company plans to enter the oil business through a merger with the Lion Oil Company. The combination of the two companies would represent total assets of about $550,000,000.
MEXICO CITY, July 21 -- Texas highway authorities, observing a deadline set by the state Highway Department early this month, began turning back Mexican trucks at the border yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The House Rules Committee sent the $760,000,000 Upper Colorado project bill to the floor today for debate starting next Tuesday.
PORT HURON, Mich., July 21 (AP) -- Sale of Pressed Metals of America, Inc., automotive products manufacturer at nearby Marysville, for more than $7,000,000 was disclosed today.

PURCHASE, N. Y., July 21 -- Governor Harriman and "his Tammany and left-wing Liberal party string-pullers" are out to make Westchester and Rockland counties the "sixth and seventh boroughs" of New York City, Republican state chairman L. Judson Morhouse charged today.

The election of four vice presidents of Webb Knapp, Inc., was announced yesterday by the board of directors of the real estate development concern. They are Boylston A. Tompkins Jr., Robert M. Newman, William Zeckendorf Jr. and Allen C. Waller.
GENEVA, July 21 -- There is one subject on which the Big Four nave expressed no disagreement at Geneva; they are all in favor of more cultural exchanges between East and West.

A Federal court in a two-to-one decision restrained the Alleghany Corporation, holding company, yesterday from taking any action under an Interstate Commerce Commission ruling that it is in control of the New York Central Railroad.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits yesterday recommended "serious consideration" of a state youth authority to control the juvenile delinquency work of all public agencies.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., July 21 -- Robert Moses took issue today with Westchester County officials over the plan to bar non-residents from all Westchester Park Commission recreational facilities.

SCULPTURED lines and medium finishes for furniture, and explosively brilliant background and fabric colors, seem likely to be high fashion in home furnishings for fall. These trends are amply documented in two extensive new groups of room settings at Abraham Straus and Macy's.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., July 21 (UP) -- A Federal jury convicted Manuel Miller, former Bethel Selectman, of assault charges today for holding off United States marshals at gunpoint when they came to take his draft-hating wife to a mental hospital.
A garage mechanic demanded in Queens Supreme Court yesterday that he be cleared or indicted in the murder of his wife last Jan. 13.
GENEVA, July 21 -- Following is the text of the briefing by James C. Hagerty, White House press secretary, on today's Big Four conference.

HEADLINES in week-end market news are provided by fresh produce, seasonally abundant and at welcome low prices. Despite the prolonged heat wave, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday that most supplies were arriving in top condition, undamaged by high temperatures.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 21 -- Frank Strafaci of the Garden City Country Club, the defending titleholder, gained the third round of the fifty-third Metropolitan Golf Association's amateur championship at the Plainfield Country Club today.
Net sales of the General Foods Corporation for the quarter ended June 30 increased to $220,042,716 from $194,725,782 in the similar three months last year.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Senator Estes Kefauver charged today that evidence of "possible crime and corruption" in the Dixon-Yates power contract was being suppressed by refusals of Administration officials to testify before Congress.

GENEVA, July 21 -- French officials expressed admiration of President Eisenhower's proposal today for reciprocal reconnaissance of military installations between the Soviet Union and the United States.

The Association of Catholic Trade Unionists was upbraided yesterday for its condemnation of AWARE, Inc., an anti-Communist organization. Godfrey P. Schmidt, president of AWARE, deplored a resolution adopted by the Roman Catholic group at its recent convention.
NORTHVILLE, Mich., July 21 -- Doug Ford won the medal in the Professional Golfers Association championship today with a thirty-six-hole total of 135.
LONDON, July 21 (Reuters) -- England dismissed South Africa for 171 and then lost two first-innings wickets for 25 runs on the opening day of the fourth test cricket match at Leeds today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 21 (AP) -- Msgr. Manuel Tato, one of two prelates expelled from Argentina, presided tonight at a session of the thirty-sixth International Eucharistic Congress of the Roman Catholic Church.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Federal Court of Appeals ruled today that refusal to deny membership in a subversive organization was not ground for eviction from Government housing projects.

Another demonstration of Dictator Franco's hatred for democracy and all we stand for was in The Times dispatch reporting that twenty-one Spanish Masons had been sentenced to from twelve to twenty years' imprisonment.

Thousands of Long Island Rail Ebad commuters got a taste of steaming delays yesterday for the second time in three days. A train breakdown in the East River tunnel raised havoc with the line's rush-hour service.
BROOKLYN, that curiously vocal community, will lay offerings of its municipal affection at the feet of Harold Henry Reese tonight, on the eve of his thirty-sixth natal day.

GENEVA, July 21--(Reuters)--Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's address at the Big Four conference today, and of Soviet Premier Bulganin's proposal for an East-West nonaggression pact and his draft for a decision by the Big Four heads of Government on disarmament: ...
The paper industry, which has been rolling up successive monthly production records, announced yesterday that some peaks had been reached in the first half of 1955.

The America Fore Insurance Group reported yesterday total assets of the five companies reached $1,183,595,947 as of June 30. This was an increase of $72,482,015 over the figure for Dec. 31, 1954. Total surplus for policyholders was $805,008,873, a gain of $71,466,826 over the year-end figure.
A 17-year-old member of a Brooklyn teen-age gang, the "Gremlins," was held in $7,500 bail yesterday on a charge of attempting to extort $20 a month from another youth under threat of beatings.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Senate and House of Representatives conferees agreed finally today on a military Reserve training bill that Congress must accept or reject in full. The House was scheduled to make its decision Monday.
MONTAUK, L. I., July 21 -- -- The emphasis here is now on tuna of the school variety and some of the boats out of Tuma's Dock are bringing in up to eighty-five fish.
KHARKOV, Ukraine, July 21 (AP) -- Iowa voices were raised in "Home On the Range" here today and members of the visiting American farm delegation did a square dance with Soviet children at a hospital.
Loans to business by leading New York City banks declined $30,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
A revision of the basic Philippine Trade Act has now been adopted by Congress and awaits the signature of the President. This is a good job, done in the right way and at the right time.

In all of its expert planning for the various transportation needs of so complex an area as metropolitan New York the Port of New York Authority has on the whole done a magnificent job. Yet there remains one apparent blind spot when it comes to public mass transportation.
The private waste disposal industry in New York City is in the grip of a monopoly, Chief City Magistrate John M. Murtagh told the Board of Estimate yesterday.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., July 21 -- The Seventy-seventh (Statue of Liberty) Reserve Division and the Forty-second (Rainbow) Division, New York National Guard, ended their summer training cycle today at near-by Camp Drum.

The Board of Estimate, overruling the good judgment of Mayor Wagner and President of the Council Stark, has made the shocking decision not to turn the site of the city-owned Neponsit Beach Hospital in Queens into a park-and-beach addition to neighboring Jacob Riis Park.
A 450-foot stretch of Manhattan Beach will be opened on a limited basis to the public tomorrow, the Parks Department announced yesterday.
Three large acreage tracts in Westchester County have been purchased for development by New England Industries, Inc., of 120 Wall Street.
An injury to Wes Westrum removed much of the joy from the Giants' come-from-behind 6-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday at the Polo Grounds.

EL PASO, Tex., July 21 (AP) -- Flash floods that sent more than 10,000 persons scurrying for safety in El Paso and Juarez drained away late today as the victims dug their way back to debris-clogged homes.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- With the reading of a psalm and a prayer, Wilbur M. Brucker became today the sixty-first civilian Chief of the Army.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 21 -- The South African Government has refused to permit a 16-year-old Negro boy to be educated in the United States.

Warm weather and vacations are now with us in earnest. For those who have begun their annual summer holidays, as well as for those still to go, the automobile will, as ever, be a popular mode of transportation. But hot weather also is hard on the family automobile, so it is only an application of common sense that cars should be put in tip-top mechanical condition and kept that way for week-end and longer vacations.

A damage suit by Josephine Baker was dismissed yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox because she had failed to reopen the action before a June 30 deadline set by the court. The $400,000 suit was against Walter Winchell, columnist, the Hearst Corporation, and King Features Syndicate.
WILLIAMS BAY, Wis., July 21 (UP) -- A device that's expected to increase by a thousand times the number of stars scientists can study in detail has been developed at the Yerkes Laboratory here.
The Board of Estimate yesterday killed the proposal of Park Commissioner Robert Moses to convert the Rockaways site of the abandoned Neponsit Beach Hospital into a park.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Americans this spring made and spent more money, produced more goods and held more jobs than ever before.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The controlling Democratic leaders of Congress gave instant and enthusiastic support today to President Eisenhower's offer to exchange military information with the Russians.

Reflecting the sharp rise in sales, net profit of the Republic Aviation Corporation and its subsidiary amounted to $9,612,399 for the first half of this year, or more than double the $4,597,838 earned in the comparable six months of 1954.
Don Bessent, who had pitched and won his first major league game last Sunday, repeated even more brilliantly at Ebbets Field yesterday.

An eye witness account of the mass uprisings of June, 1953, in East Germany, by Rainer Hildebrandt, leader of the West Berlin anti-Communist resistance movement, will be published Aug. 25 by Duell, Sloan Pearce-Little, Brown.
The Board of Estimate took a 592,250 salary-increase pie out of the oven yesterday and put it in the showcase for public inspection.
Plans to create a community of 200,000 inhabitants on a 15,000-acre tract in New Jersey were announced yesterday by a Queens real estate syndicate.
The President's dramatic arms inspection suggestion to the Russians in Geneva yesterday dealt primarily with the effects -- not the cause -- of international tensions.

An emphatic answer was registered yesterday to questions as to which way the Government bond market would go after the announced oversubscription of $750,000,000 of new long-term Treasury bonds. The answer: down.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The House Agriculture Committee approved today a bill creating a new formula for setting up sugar marketing quotas in the United States in 1956. The vote was 24 to 7.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Democrats generally today showed a commendable disposition to weigh carefully what Secretary of the Air Force Talbott said to the McClellan subcommittee before passing judgment on publications of his activity in getting business for an engineering efficiency firm in which he is one of the two partners.
VIENNA, July 21 -- Austrian Government spokesmen stated at a press conference today that Austria would seek to become a member of the United Nations with a special status.
GENEVA, July 21 -- The United States and France have led the Big Four in issuing official clarifications at the summit.

David Wayne is eager to act in "The Ponder Heart." He said so yesterday in Beverly Hills, Calif. When an actor of his standing expresses a preference for a play, things begin to move with alacrity on the theatrical front.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, said today he would recommend that President Eisenhower sign a bill to raise the minimum wage to $1 an hour.

LONDON, July 21 -- Oil shares dominated the stock market today with prices rising further on announcement of the Government's program to convert more power stations from coal to oil. British Petroleum gained 2s 6d (35 cents), Burmah 3s 9d (52 1/2 cents) and Canadian Eagle Bearers 4s (56 cents).

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 21 -- Top-level motion picture industry management representatives are meeting to formulate policy in regard to forthcoming collective bargaining contract negotiations with the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Legislation designed to restrict bank holding companies was approved today by the Senate Banking Committee. The measure, although less stringent than legislation already passed by the House, would give the Federal Reserve Board far greater control over bank holding companies than it has now.
The New York Times of July 15 published an editorial entitled "A Street Lane for Buses."

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Representative B. Carroll Reece suggested today that the Ford Fund for the Republic was helping "Left Wingers" in a plan to attack "the whole security system of the United States Government."

The Wagner administration has made substantial progress toward modernizing the city government's relations with its employes. While many of the real tests lie ahead, and the neglect of years cannot be undone in a few months, some fundamentals to improvement of administration have been established and the results begin to show.

YORK, Pa., July 21 (AP)--The York County Selective Service Board ordered today the induction into the armed services on Aug. 1 of Edward Calvert Nixon, 25 years old. He is a brother of Vice President Nixon.

ROME, July 22 -- Rome's dress designers switched from guest lists to price lists today as United States buyers got down to the serious business of choosing models from the eleven collections of fall and winter fashions shown in Rome the last four days.
DETROIT, July 22 (AP) -- The American Motors Corporation reported yesterday its first quarterly profit since the Nash-Hudson merger on May 1 last year.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- There was no buoyancy in the wheat market today, and free selling of corn and oats wiped out much of the gain established on Thursday. Soybeans worked lower in the early trade, and rye was the only Board of Trade product to show any strength.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 22 -- An official explanation was given today of why the South African Government refused to permit a Negro boy to attend Kent School in Kent, Conn.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 22 -- Two hundred fifty thousand men and boys were to take communion tonight at a service presided over by Cardinal Spellman of New York.
The Mathematics Department of the University of Detroit will boast a new faculty member this fall. The appointment represents for him a long period of trial and error, but mostly trial.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Administration asked Congress today to appropriate $30,000,000 to assure "that every child and expectant mother has the opportunity" of being vaccinated against poliomyelitis.
All the loot carried away in the West Side train robbery Wednesday night was reported yesterday to have been recovered.

LANSING, Mich., July 22 (AP) -- The State Civil Service Commission today offered employes of the Mackinac Straits ferry fleet another $220,000-a-year pay concession and then warned them they would be discharged if they tied up the state auto ferries again.

A two-story business building on plot 175 by 148 feet at 160-78 West Twenty-third Street, southeast corner of Seventh Avenue, has been purchased for investment by Henry Leeds, president of the Tinnemar Realty Corporation.
Seven employes of a compressed-air-equipment plant were saved yesterday by fellow workmen when they were overcome by hydrogen sulphide fumes. The fumes had been discharged from a metal cylinder.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Average primary market prices decreased 0.3 per cent to 110.0 (1947-49 equals 100) in the week ended July 19, according to the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -- The Air Force announced today plans to produce a new, all-weather jet interceptor fighter. It also will step up production of another jet fighter, which can streak through the skies at twice the speed of sound.
The first units of the Arrny's famed First Division -- "The Big Red One" -- will arrive in Brooklyn Army base today after thirteen years of combat and occupation duty overseas.
GENEVA, July 22 -- The Western Big Three called on Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin today to help raise the Iron Curtain so that men, goods and ideas could move more freely between East and West.
The "Fighting First" is back, and this morning in Brooklyn the Army is rolling out a well-deserved red carpet at reception ceremonies in the division's honor.

On Thursday, Paul Bailey was a star of the Saratoga-at-Jamaica proceedings. He rode three winners and went to the top of the jockey standing. Yesterday, in the main event, Bailey's horse was the villain of the proceedings.

The estate of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Lewisohn at Barlow Lane and Milton Harbor in Rye, N. Y., has been sold by their heirs to Merritt Holby, builders, of Larchmont, who will build homes on part of the property.

WASHINGTON, July, 22 -- A new effort is under way by Senate Democrats handling atomic energy legislation to curb what they charge is "one-man rule" of the Atomic Energy Commission by its chairman, Lewis L. Strauss.

In recent weeks Governor Harriman and other state officials have interpreted the New York State Automobile Association's stand opposing the proposed $750,000,000 highway bond issue which will be submitted to the voters in the November elections as a move that can impede the state's highway program.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa fired another round yesterday in his battle with Parks Commissioner Robert Moses over extensions to the city's park system.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Eisenhower Administration was confronted today with farm troubles that, in more aggravated form, have proved the undoing of some of its predecessors. The current headache is compounded of declining prices and income, and mounting surpluses and costs for storage and subsidies.

This week's discussions in Geneva heighten the natural interest in the report on Russian production in the first half of this year, just issued by the Moscow Government. We now have enough experience with Soviet statistics to draw some important conclusions from this material, couched though it is in percentages.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter said today it would be "asinine" to believe that the Government would deport 4-year-old Jane Edith Thomas of Dayton, Ohio.

LOUISVILLE, July 22 (UP) -- Australia won both singles matches today in its Davis Cup tennis series with Brazil. Ken Rosewall defeated Jose Aguero, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 0, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, and Lew Hoad beat Bob Falkenburg, 3 -- 6, 8 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 1.
Five hundred European teenagers sailed for home yesterday, free from last year's notions that Americans were all rich or all gangsters.
LONDON, July 22 (Reuters) -- Britain and West Germany signed an air agreement today handing over some choice routes to Lufthansa, the revived German civil airline.

GENEVA, July 22 -- French Premier Edgar Faure submitted to the four-power conference today a memorandum elaborating his proposal that the savings resulting from armament reduction should go into an international fund to aid backward regions.
The United States Pipe and Foundry Company is proposing a four-for-one split of its common stock, subject to approval of shareholders at a special meeting to be held on Sept. 15.

MYSTERY fans perked up considerably three years ago over Georges Simenon's extraordinary, pint-size chiller, "A Matter of Life and Death." It all took place in a Parisian police station, where a huge wall map, lighted from a trail of set-off alarms, spelled an urgent cry for help.
LONDON, July 22 -- The youthful King of 1,000,000 tribesmen in Uganda was told today he might return from exile in a London apartment and rule over his people.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Observers in the capital regard President Eisenhower's proposal for a United States-Soviet exchange of defense blueprints as a bold stroke.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams will announce his resignation tomorrow.
BOONTON, N. J., July 22 -- Commuters in this area were battling along a divided front today against the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad.

LONDON, July 22 -- President Eisenhower's offer to exchange military data with the Soviet Union and allow reciprocal aerial reconnaissance was saluted here today as a dramatic challenge of Moscow's sincerity on the disarmament issue.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that the Tennessee Valley Authority had cost taxpayers $600,000,000 in Federal subsidies.
BAIREUTH, Germany, July 22 (Reuters) -- The fifth Richard Wagner Festival since World War II opened here today with a new production of "The Flying Dutchman."

LISBON, Portugal, July 22 -- The will of Calouste S. Gulbenkian was made public today. With the exception of certain unspecified sums left in trust to his descendants, most of his fortune and art treasures were willed to a Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation.
Nearly 1,400 Jehovah's Witnesses were baptized as ministers of the gospel yesterday in a Bronx swimming pool.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., July 22 (AP) -- A Chester County court ruling has upheld the right of Pennsylvania to press its claim to collect between $5,000,000 and $8,000,000 in inheritance taxes from the estate of Pierre S. du Pont.
ALBANY, July 22 -- The State Budget Director said today it was too early to tell what the state's financial picture would look like when tax time came around next year.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- One of the week's 518 patented inventions is especially appropriate to the current weather; a jacket with cross-ventilation. The front of the coat is orthodox, but the back has a vertical panel flanked by pleats. Under the two pleats are zippers that close a pair of long slits in the cloth.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The State Department, finding the demand for Russian interpreters too great for its own supply, answered a hurry call from the Midwest today by recruiting one from the Library of Congress and another from the Department of Agriculture.
ALBANY, July 22 -- A State Supreme Court justice cleared the way today for the appointment by the New York City Board of Education of 189 new assistant principals.

YONKERS, July 22 -- A three- car crash in which five persons were injured held up heavy northbound traffic on the Saw Mill River Parkway this afternoon for twenty minutes to half an hour. Autos carrying commuters and week-end vacationers backed up for three miles south of Tuckahoe Road here shortly after 2:30 P. M.

Premier Diem, in Vietnam, should have been more outspoken than he was in condemning the riots in Saigon. He deplored where he should have denounced. He lost a certain amount of international stature precisely at the time when he needed it most.

NEW DELHI, India, July 22 -- President Eisenhower has suggested that United States and Communist Chinese diplomats in Geneva discuss some of the problems between the two Governments. If the talks should be successful, he proposed, they could be raised to a higher level in Switzerland.

DNEPROPETROVSK, U. S. S. R., July 22 -- The arrival of the American farm delegation here tonight caused a near riot. Thousands of wildly cheering local residents broke police lines to get a close look at the visitors.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Eisenhower's principal political advisers held long conferences today on the future of Harold E. Talbott as Secretary of the Air Force.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Justice Department asked Congress today for $17,100,000 for a new prison and a reformatory.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Senate passed tonight a $3,205,841,750 foreign aid bill. It beat down all attempts to cut the figure back to the $2,638,741,750 approved ten days by the House.
The Rockefeller Institute announced yesterday the retirement after thirty-three years' service of Dr. Thomas M. Rivers, vice president and director of the institute and the institute's hospital.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 22 -- Casualties were high in the third and quarter-final rounds of the fifty-third Metropolitan Golf Association amateur championship at the Plainfield C. C. today.

DETROIT, July 22 (AP) -- Ward's Reports today forecast this week's automobile and truck output in United States plants would total 202,230 units, less than 7 per cent below the record of 216,629 for the week ended April 30.
NEWARK, July 22 -- The fully equipped Fiftieth Armored Division, consisting of 8,500 New Jersey National Guardsmen, prepared to move on Camp Drum, N. Y., tonight for a two-week encampment.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Small Business Administration is abolishing its personnel security division under fire by a Senate investigation.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Federal banking authorities have cautioned banks against "loosoned" credit terms on instalment buying, particularly on auto financing.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Three New England railroads have reached agreement on a freight interchange plan which apparently will satisfy the major opposition to Patrick B. McGinnis' ambition to head two of those railroads.
THE excitement on the salt water front brought on by the abundance of bluefish and school tuna has not swayed all the anglers, for the lakes and streams are still pulling their quota.
An expert on aerial mapping estimated yesterday that the Soviet Union's entire expanse could be photographed in one year by a fleet of thirty-four United States RB-47 reconnaissance planes.

THERE is enough lit'ry lore in Walter Hart Blumenthal's "Bookmen's Bedlam"* to keep anyone who is a dedicated collector, or simply interested in books in general, busy tracking down leads for a year and a day. You never saw such an orderly mass of bibliomania. Through this volume's portals pass the smallest, the largest, the strangest books in the world.

GENEVA, July 22 -- As the stalemated Berlin conference drew to a close in February, 1954, an expert on the United States delegation proposed that Secretary Dulles state in his final remarks: "The real differences expressed here are so profound that they cannot be resolved by foreign ministers but must be considered the direct and personal responsibility of individual citizens everywhere."
KANSAS CITY, July 22 -- Vic Raschi, who won 120 games for the Yankees over a span of eight seasons, turned on his former colleagues tonight.
LONDON, July 22 -- The Iron and Steel Board announced today increases in maximum prices for a wide range of iron and steel products.

The account in The Times of July 21 of a speech by Joseph A. Shelley, chief deputy probation officer of Kings County Court, presents a grossly unfair picture of the work of voluntary welfare agencies in the juvenile delinquency field. Mr. Shelley is, of course, entitled to his own opinions, and certainly neither the public nor the private agencies, separately or in combination, have yet satisfactorily met this problem.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Erection of memorials to the late President Roosevelt and the late Senatotr Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, won tentative Senate approval today after brief debate.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Thurman Arnold, former assistant attorney general and later a Federal judge, said today that the Government's loyalty-security system should be abolished.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Army Engineers announced today they would spend $2,355,000 to survey 176 flood control and navigation projects.

SAN FRANCISCO. July 22 (AP) -- The Government's suit to deprive Harry Bridges of United States citizenship was concluded today. Federal Judge Louis E. Goodman said he would announce the verdict July 29.
Stocks stood firm against a last-hour sell-off yesterday and closed with good gains in most sections of the list. Motors, rails, chemicals, oils and metals were especially strong.

Commodity futures were irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides, rubber and burlap were weaker; sugar, zinc, lead and copper closed mixed, and wool and potatoes rose.
The fifth annual Russian Mass for World Peace will be celebrated at Fordham University on Wednesday at 11:30 A.M.
DETROIT, July 22 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company announced today a liberalization of its retirement pay plan for its 45,000 salaried workers.
CAIRO, July 22 -- Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser pledged tonight that the Egyptian army would defend "the whole Arab world" against Israeli aggression.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 22 (AP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, recuperating in Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital from a heart attack, has received this letter from Adlai E. Stevenson, the 1952 Democratic Presidential candidate:

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Gasoline station owners told a Senate subcommittee today that they were the "expendable troops" in a New Jersey price war that has forced hundreds out of business in recent years.

LOS ANGELES, July 22 (AP) -- Aquatic stars continued their assault on American records tonight as the 1955 National Amateur Athletic Union swimming and diving championships ended. Marks were registered in two events, and the high platform diving crown was brought back to the United States.

They showered gifts and kind words on Harold Henry (Pee Wee) Reese at Ebbets Field last night. The gifts ranged from a portable typewriter from the writers, who instigated the "night," to a Chevrolet car. There were fifty different donors to the Little Colonel.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Eisenhower's proposal to lift the Iron Curtain was given a better chance of success in Washington than his plan for a mutual inspection of defenses.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Republican Senators provoked today a sharp partisan debate in an unsuccessful effort to force a quick decision in the Senate investigation of Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force.

In your July 16 issue you made an editorial appeal for contributions to the United Jewish Appeal, pointing out that a large portion of the funds collected would be used to promote immigration to Israel and to settle immigrants in that country, and giving the address to which contributions might be sent.

Underwriting commitments are slackening visibly as the calendar heads for midsummer. The diminished activity is attended by heaviness in the bond market, following the Treasury's recent borrowing of $750,000,000 of long-term bonds in an extended economy.

GENEVA, July 22 -- French officials said tonight that the three Western powers had agreed here to urge Premier Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam to respond to the invitation of Communist North Vietnam for talks on the elections provided for in the truce agreement.
TOKYO, July 22 -- The visit of Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japanese Foreign Minister, to Washington was on again today.
WOMEN willing to forego the gentle scolding and pampering given at Elizabeth Arden's pink-and-blue Fifth Avenue salon can follow her rejuvenating "day of beauty" at home.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today raised a question as to whether it should permit further acquisitions of broadcasting outlets by the National Broadcasting Company.

Two armed men escaped yesterday afternoon with a $4,277 payroll from the Roy Weaving Company, 71-07 Sixtieth Lane, Ridgewood, Queens. They entered the company's second-story office soon after the bookkeeper, Herman Chadicoff, returned from a nearby bank and deposited the cash in a safe.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22 -- Herbert K. Sorrell, who was a key figure in the 1945-46 studio strikes, lost a suit today in Superior Court, Los Angeles, for recovery of salary from the International Brotherhood of Painters, Paperhangers and Decorators of America, A. F. L.

MOSCOW, July 21 (UP) -- Soviet gross industrial output in the first half of 1955 topped government plans by 3 per cent and was 12 per cent higher than in the same period last year, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -- The American Trucking Association denied charges today that it was trying to kill a twelve-year $48,500,000,000 pay-as-you-build Federal highway program.

GENEVA, July 22 -- The foreign ministers' efforts to arrange the agenda for a four-power meeting in October broke down tonight. The cause was Soviet insistence that the Governments of East and West Germany be invited to the conference and that a directive on armament restrictions include a provision for a study of banning nuclear weapons.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 22 -- If Congress agrees, the United States delegation to the United Nations will get a new $3,300,000 home.

Northwest Nitro-Chemicals, Ltd., announced yesterday it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington a registration statement covering the proposed sale of $8,500,000 subordinate income debentures and 1,150,000 shares of common stock.
SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., July 22 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis won the fifth annual Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship over the Sleepy Hollow course today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 22 -- Several influential Cabinet ministers suggested today that Gov. Gen. Ghulam Mohammed would announce within a week a change in prime ministers.

GENEVA, July 22 -- The Eisenhower expedition to Geneva started to break camp today. With the President's plane alerted to fly him back to Washington tomorrow evening, a dozen-odd secret servicemen started home at noon by way of Paris.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 22 (AP) -- The Alabama Legislature moved today to preserve classroom segregation. It passed and sent to the Governor a House-approved bill giving local boards almost unlimited authority to determine where individual pupils must attend school. The vote was 32 -- 0.
