WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Voice of America deserves a case of laryngitis for broadcasting to the world that the country's dairy farmers are not particularly interested in getting rich, according to Representative T. James Tumulty.
Two months of painstaking police work paid off yesterday. Three men were charged with the robbery of $60,000 worth of furs in a hold-up of Bobby Brown Furs, Inc., 307 Seventh Avenue, last May 17.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- The American Medical Association today described a bill before Congress that would provide Social Security payments to the totally disabled as a "piecemeal approach to socialization of medicine."

LONDON, July 22 -- The stock markets ended the week today on very different note from that with which they began it. A decline in government stocks was sharply accentuated. Industrial shares turned downward, especially those likely be affected by any tightening of installment buying, such as automobile, radio and other durable consumer goods shares. Oil shares followed suit.

As home runs go, the one that Gail Harris hit to give a 6-3 victory to the Giants over the Cincinnati Redlegs last night at the Polo Grounds, was not one to write home about. It barely cleared the right-field wall about ten feet inside the foul line.

GENEVA, July 22 -- Moscow maintained an expressive silence tonight on the "legalized espionage" proposal that President Eisenhower presented to the Soviet delegation at the Big Four conference yesterday.
Husbands of the future may well have to blame the quality of their morning cup of "java" not on their wives but on their tape recorders.

" The Cobweb," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama in Cinema-Scope and color with Richard Widmark, Lauren Bacall, Charles Boyer, Gloria Grahame, Lillian Gish and John Kerr, has been scheduled as the next attraction at Loew's State.
MOSCOW, July 22 (AP) -- The Soviet press published today, without comment, President Eisenhower's proposal for an exchange of military information and aerial inspection.

The one-story building at 450 Johnson Avenue in Brooklyn has been leased by the Carnel Manufacturing Corporation from the Rebrah Realty Corporation. The transaction was negotiated by the Kalmon Dolgin Company as broker.

" The Literary and Philosophical Essays of Jean-Paul Sartre" is planned for American publication by Criterion Books in October. The volume will include studies of the work of Albert Camus, William Faulkner, John Dos Passos, Franz Kafka and Francois Mauriac.

Agreement on a wage increase was reached early this morning between representatives of the shipbuilding division of the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O.
HONG KONG, July 22 -- Almost one-fifth of China's peasant population must buy grain from the state because of natural calamities or individual shortages, according to Deputy Premier Chen Yun.
ZURICH, Switzerland, July 22 -- The total synthesis of the principal life-essential hormone of the adrenal glands was announced here today.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Capt. Raymond Wool, the Air Force officer involved in the Senate's investigation of alleged corruption in military procurement. resigned today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, predicted today the Administration would accept the new compromise military Reserve bill even though it was not all that President Eisenhower wanted.

GENEVA, July 22 -- There were two conferences proceeding in Geneva today: The summit conference of the heads of government dealing in the realm of proclamations and the foreign ministers conference just below the summit dealing in the harsher realm of negotiations.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 22 -- After two hours of play in 98 degree heat Victor Seixas was the winner over Edward Moylan of Trenton today in the Pennsylvania state grass court tennis championship.

When President Eisenhower heard about the approaching nuptials of Marshal Zhukov's daughter, he sent his aides to shop for wedding presents. The gifts were personal, for at Geneva there was no official exchange of presents.

The Eaton Manufacturing Company, Cleveland manufacturer of automobile and aircraft parts, in the first half of this year attained the highest sales for any six-month period in its record. Earnings climbed 42 per cent over the similar half of 1954.
NORTHVILLE, Mich., July 22 -- Jack Fleck, the United States Open champion, gained a place today among the sixteen players remaining in the Professional Golfers Association championship.
The sacred, if sometimes profane, domain of New York's longshoremen has been successfully invaded by the opposite sex. The harbor now has one longshorewoman.

A wage dispute between three major television networks and the United Scenic Artists Local Union No. 829, A. F. L., ended yesterday. Negotiators agreed on a new three-year contract, retroactive to April 1, which grants wage increases to 210 union members employed by the chains.

About Feb. 1 of next year representatives of the thirty-five nations that are signatories to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade are scheduled to meet at Geneva to negotiate the fourth round of reciprocal tariff concessions since the present system of multilateral agreements superseded in 1947 the bilateral pattern that had been employed prior to World War II.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 (UP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson got off the floor tonight to punch out a spilt decision over Rocky Castellani in a wild ten-round nationally televised bout at the Cow Palace.

The United States Court of Appeals denied yesterday a petition by the National Labor Relations Board for reargument of that court's reversal of a contempt conviction against the International Longshoremen's Association and three of the union's leaders.
Three Queens youths were held yesterday in the vicious beating of a partly blind war veteran.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., July 22 -- The heat meant nothing today to 72-year-old Joseph J. Mariniello of Newark. Mr. Mariniello, preserving a twenty-year-old tradition, bicycled fifty miles from Newark to Asbury Park to attend the annual summer outing of the Prudential Insurance Company.
ALBANY, July 22 (AP) -- The State Health Department reported today there had been "small outbreaks" in the state of a mild disease similar to non-paralytic polio.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A $1,600,000,000 Federal aid program of school construction was approved by the House Education and Labor Committee today. The vote was 21 to 9.
Earnings of The Texas Company and its subsidiaries for the quarter and six months ended in June were the highest for those periods in the history of the oil company.
BUENOS AIRES, July 22 -- Argentina's Vice President announced today his resignation as chairman of the executive board of the Peronist party.
Dense black smoke from a bake oven stack cost a Broadway restaurant owner $500 yesterday. It was reported to be the largest fine imposed since the Department of Air Pollution Control was established.

WITH raw cauliflower or cucumbers or radishes, all now abundantly available at the greengrocer's, the Chinese make a simple but delicious dish. It is one of the few Oriental creations that could be called a salad. The Chinese cut any one of these vegetables in very thin slices, then marinate the pieces for an hour or more in a mixture of soy sauce, vinegar and vegetable oil.

John C. Siemer, the Staten Island bank teller who disappeared with his family ten months ago, was held in $50,000 bail yesterday in Brookyn Federal Court on a charge of embezzling $93,780 of the bank's funds.
The Long Island Rail Road received permission yesterday to discontinue its Cedar Manor station. But the State Public Service Commission blocked the road's plan to dismantle the Higbie Avenue station.

New York City loses an excellent Police Commissioner in the resignation of Francis W. H. Adams. Except for a few transfers to other governmental posts, his will be the first major departure, we believe, from the official family originally chosen by Mayor Wagner.
BONN, Germany, July 22 -- Legislative action on the first West German armament bill was completed today. The law on volunteers was passed by the Bundesrat, or upper house.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 22 -- These were some of the main developments during today's fitful breezes at Larchmont Race Week:
The 10,000th Iron Curtain refugee to be resettled under the United States Escapee Program arrived here yesterday morning. He was Georgi Vasileff, a 32-year-old automobile mechanic.

Each month many of the oil-producing states fix the allowable or permissible production of crude oil within their borders for the succeeding month. This is done to hold production in line with market demand and prevent what is termed economic waste. The orders are issued through regulatory bodies, generally at mid-month.

GENEVA, July 22 (Reuters) -- Following are texts of President Eisenhower's address at the Big Four conference today; Prime Minister Eden's circularized speech on East-West contacts, and a British memorandum on disarmament and a French memorandum on disarmament proposals, submitted to a meeting of foreign ministers:

As the Geneva conference races toward its projected end today President Eisenhower has thrown down another challenge to the Soviets on what is the fundamental problem between East and West that overshadows all others and is the primary cause of both the cold war and the threat of an atomic war.
MILWAUKEE, July 22 -- Scorching spoiled today the dedication ceremonies for Milwaukee's new air terminal.

Reports of business done and goods shipped in the first half of this year continue to show that records are being made in almost every corner of the industrial map. Some of the more recent and impressive reports follow: ...
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 22 -- Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns has been asked to stay on for another year as the United Nations' Palestine truce chief.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Edward F. Howrey, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today that Congressional investigators should commend rather than criticize his actions in a 1953 antitrust case against tire and rubber companies.
Retailers want substantial stocks of higher-price fashion merchandise on their racks early in each selling season, according to a survey of 180 representative stores from coast to coast.
Ireland's dollar export drive has recorded a net gain for the latest fiscal year despite sharp decline in sales of beef and mutton, according to the report of the Irish Export Promotion Board.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 28 to 47 points ($1.40 to $2.35 a bale) yesterday.
LONDON, July 22 -- Nearly 50,000 persons gathered in a sports stadium here tonight to hear Billy Graham, American evangelist, preach at the closing session of the Baptist World Alliance.

PARIS, July 22 -- President Eisenhower's proposal for an exchange of military "blueprints" with the Soviet Union has aroused intense interest in France. The "U. S. bomb," as France-Soir called the proposal, received a tremendous play in today's press.

Pee Wee Reese Night at Ebbets Field was an unqualified success. The Little Colonel contributed two doubles to a twelve-hit attack that gave the Dodgers an 8-4 victory last night over the second-place Milwaukee Braves.

LENOX, Mass., July 22 -- Night had fallen and the green earth was giving back some coolness when Isaac Stern and the Boston Symphony under Charles Munch were playing the slow movement of Beethoven's Violin Concerto at Tanglewood tonight.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 22 -- The coalition Cabinet of Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo announced tonight it would resign as a result of the army's rejection of the Government's appointee as Army Chief of Staff.

AMES, Iowa, July 22 -- Twelve Russian farm officials seeking the key to the Midwest's great corn and livestock economy are having difficulty making a profitable comparison between what they are seeking and what they have at home.
Paddy Chayefsky, television's most celebrated playwright, is completing a drama that has been tentatively set for a December opening on Broadway.
School is out for the children, but it's only just beginning for their fathers.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 22 -- When Princeton University opens its 210th year in September it will have its first Negro member of the faculty. He is Dr. Charles T. Davis, who has been Assistant Professor of English at New York University for the last several years.
Yesterday was the hottest day of the year. There is no real relief in sight, although the weatherman says it will be "not quite so warm" tomorrow.

PUTNAM VALLEY, N. Y., July 22 -- It was pretty clear which group was more used to the great outdoors when thirteen Catholic Youth Organization board members joined several hundred youngsters here this week as "campers for a day."

TAIPEI, Formosa, July 22 -- Nationalist China's Minister of Economy, K. Y. Yin, acknowledged today it would not be possible to balance the Formosa Government's budget or balance of payments at the end of the current four-year development plan.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Saturday, July 23 -- Four electric transfomers were blown up in the European and American section of the city early this morning. The doors of the buildings looked as if bombs might have been used to blow them in.

IN this colorful novel, Jeramie Price has given readers a fast-paced story based on the lives of the Russian emperor and his beloved inamorata, Katrina. The book is much more, however, than a mere charting in terms of historical fiction of the careers of a ruler and his consort.

SINCE declarer has no partner to inform or mislead, he can take unlimited liberties with falsecards and deceptive plays. Some of these discards may be made for the purpose of concealing strength, others for the purpose of concealing weakness.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 23 -- The pattern of the South's struggle with the public school desegregation problem was etched more clearly this week. Local Federal court judges made initial rulings concerning school transition procedures in two embattled communities.

KANSAS CITY, July 23 -- The man with his ear to the radio was listening to the ball game and enjoying it immensely. Then, suddenly, he became a bit confused. A left-handed batsman slammed into first base with his right foot as he sped on to second. That called for something more than a pause for station identification.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- It is impossible for a passenger to do any work aboard a cruise ship.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The National Science Foundation warned today that a shortage of qualified research scientists and engineers was impeding development programs.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 23 -- Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo told the Indonesian Parliament tonight that his coalition Cabinet was resigning "to uphold the principles of parliamentary democracy and of the constitutional state."

REAL and impressive as have been many of television's accomplishments in the field of journalism, there still is a long way to go before the medium will realize its full potentialities. Of late there has been a distressing tendency, most marked in the case of last Sunday's special presentation on the Geneva summit conference, to substitute visual razzle-dazzle for sound reporting and editing.

About one hundred and sixty years ago Aaron Burr obtained a charter for a waterworks company. The charter specified that he was to run a waterworks -- and nothing else. But Aaron Burr, as history bears witness, was an ambitious man.

PORCHES and breezeways can be converted into yearround rooms with jalousie panels. Prefabricated jalousie walls are available for the home craftsman to install with a minimum of time and tools. The adjustable panels are 60 or 85 inches tall, in widths of 31, 37, 41 and 45 inches.
The 5-cent cup of coffee and subway ride have long been victims of inflation, but the nickel cigar is still here -- and gaining in popularity.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 23 -Helioscope had it all the way in his $83,550 "match race" with High Gun at Monmouth Park today.

TO a great many people of goodwill, Samuel Hopkins Adams' "Grandfather Stories" (see Page One) will offer the touchstone to a number of nostalgic hours. They will dream on the thought of how much better the world must have been when travel was by way of Clinton's Big Ditch and not by the New York State Thruway.

THE current battle between three United States airlines for a permit to fly non-stop between New York and Mexico City is one of the bitterest airline disputes on record. At the moment, it may seem somewhat academic. So

The Senate has acted wisely in restoring to the foreign aid bill a large part of the funds that were slashed by the House in a mood of irritation. The measure must now go into conference, and we earnestly hope that the Senators will be able to stand their ground.
Recently The New York Times published two interesting and contrasting reports dealing with the study of foreign languages.

IN death as in life, John Dewey is still very much part of the intellectual scene. His ideas continue to inspire, to excite and to provoke those who wish to make sense of human experience, and more especially of American experience.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -Democratic Senators forced today a continuing public investigation of the private business affairs of Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force.

KANSAS CITY, July 23 -- The Yankees had first place back in their grasp today. But then, in the blazing heat, they let it slip away as Lou Boudreau's amazing Athletics tripped the Bombers, 8 to 7, in an eleven-inning struggle.

IN her last novel, "The Web of Time," Josephine Lawrence dealt with the problems of the old with a depth of insight that evoked the quality of lasting folklore. In more than twenty previous books, among them "The Years Are So Long" and "If I Have Four Apples," Miss Lawrence has proved her ability to create characters that are absolutely real as individuals.
New York and twelve other states will receive new shipments of Salk polio vaccine by Wednesday, the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis said yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, July 19 -There appears to be a definite conviction here that Guatemalan political refugees in Mexico actively planned several weeks ago an overthrow of the one-yearold Guatemalan Government of President Carlos Castillo Armas.
PITTSBURGH, July 23 (UP) -The Pittsburgh Pirates combined the six-hit pitching of Bob Friend with poor Chicago fielding to beat the Cubs, 10 -- 2, today.

NUMEROUS wayside or native plants lead a double life. It matters little whether they are called wayward flowers or sophisticated weeds. The fact remains that the same plant may be taken into one garden to be cherished as a thing of beauty while in another garden it is considered a blight to be eradicated whenever it appears.

MOST writings about the brain, mind and psychiatry are couched in highly abstract concepts. It is refreshing to find a book reviewing the most recent orientations and scientific developments in the field that is based on an appreciation of the underlying structural and physiologic mechanisms.

At West Milton, N. Y., the General Electric Company has been experimenting with a prototype of an atomic reactor which is to be installed in the submarine Seawolf, sister of the Nautilus, now in service. Last week both the reactor and the Seawolf played their part in the news.

As Secretary of State, Cordell Hull carried out the foreign policies of the United States for nearly twelve years at a time of great international tensions. No other man had held this office for so long.
ALBUQUERQUE, July 23 -Racial friction, which is rarely extreme in New Mexico, is creating little stir as desegregation and anti-discrimination laws become increasingly effective here.

CLEVELAND, July 23 -- The Cleveland Indians, who had traded Bill Wight to Baltimore for Hoot Evers last week, beat the Orioles by 3 -- 2 today as Evers smashed a pinch two-run homer off Wight in the seventh inning.

MEMBERS of the Screen Actors Guild will meet tonight in the Hollywood Legion Stadium to vote on a strike recommendation by the board of directors against producers of film television entertainment. If the strike is approved (the only surprise would be a reversal, and that is regarded as extremely unlikely) it would be the second such action in the Guild's twenty-two-year history.

ZAPOROZHE, U. S. S. R., July 23 -- Twelve American agriculturists cruised the lower Dneiper River for more than three hours today to get a close look at the Soviet Union's largest river valley development program.

IN northern regions the popular house plant amaryllis is now basking in sheltered, sunny garden spots while the straplike leaves rebuild the bulb for next year's blooming. In mild regions, of course, amaryllis may spend all year in the garden blooming as well as maturing outdoors.
GENEVA, July 23 -- Delegates and observers from both sides of the Iron Curtain agreed tonight that the four-power conference had achieved its modest aims.

WILLIAM GROPPER, the noted artist, tells here -in brief text and many pictures -- of one man's discovery of America. Based on the experiences of a family, it is, in essence, the story of thousands of newcomers.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -A report criticizing Harold E. Stassen's activities in the investigation of a Pakistan grain storage project started a controversy today.
To most persons the word "shut-in" has long connoted dependency, despondency and despair. This, however, need not be the picture of the life of the physically handicapped homebound person.
A three-alarm fire swept through the upper two stories of a five-story tenement building in East Harlem early this morning, injuring one fireman. An 8-year-old child suffered smoke poisoning.

Last Tuesday morning Dale Vincent, owner of a 345-acre farm just outside Oskaloosa, Iowa, was operating a combine (harvester and thresher) in a field of oats along Highway 92. His 2 1/2-year-old son Philip was riding the tractor with him. A big blue and silver bus came bowling down the highway, followed by twenty-one cars. There was a squeal of brakes from the bus. The whole caravan came to a halt.

HOLLYWOOD. THE General Tire and Rubber Company will become a potentially important factor in the entertainment business when it delivers a check tomorrow for the sum of $25,000,000 to Howard Hughes and formally takes possession of R. K. O.-Radio Pictures, Inc.

In Britain, as in our own country, Government physicists have been assuring the world it has nothing to fear in the near future from the cumulative effect of radioactive fall-out if more hydrogen bombs are tested. In a communication published in the British scientific weekly Nature, Prof. J. B. S. Haldane, a distinguished geneticist and a first-rate mathematician, argues that the danger is greater than optimistic Government physicists or even pessimistic geneticists realize.

NEW DELHI, India, July 23 (Reuters) -- India is considering an agreement with the United States to allow American investors in India to insure with the American Government against risks of nationalization, an Indian Finance Ministry spokesman has announced. A decision on the agreement would be taken next month, he said.

JOHNNY CARSON and Jonathan Winters, now appearing regularly on the two major networks as seedling humorists with possibly big futures, came to their profession by a sleight-of-hand and sleight-of-mouth respectively.

GENEVA, July 23 -- French Premier Edgar Faure came here with the idea of breaking away from the "cold war" and getting the attention of statesmen and the public for constructive ideas that might help stabilize Europe and reduce its armaments.

ONE day a director I know was giving notes to the east after dress rehearsal These notes consisted of telling one actor to play his first scene a little more lightly. Another actor was corrected on a line reading.
The demise of the Third Avenue El will be observed Aug. 1 at a "wake" under the structure. Demolition will begin at noon.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The pattern of the general Democratic assault on the Republicans in the 1956 campaign is now plainly appearing, at the Capitol and the headquarters of the party's National Committee. It is the broad charge that the Administration and the Republicans who support its domestic programs put private and corporate rights above those of the people at large.

The Waterfront Commission has adopted all the recommendations of Jacob Grumet, hearing officer in recent proceedings against 141 longshoremen. The action was an outgrowth of a twenty-nine-day, port-wide strike that started March 4, 1954.

TRENTON, July 23 (AP) -- Samuel L. Bodine, chairman of the New Jersey Republican State Committee, said today that a Dr. Jekyll-Mr. Hyde label might fit Gov. Robert B. Meyner's statements on spending better than his own.
BLED, Yugoslavia, July 23 -The United States and Yugoslavia have again undertaken to settle the dispute over the interpretation of their military assistance agreement.
HONG KONG, July 23 -Prime Minister Nu of Burma declared today that President Eisenhower's dramatic proposal on exchanging military information with the Soviet Union was "a very good step."

THERE is always a great profusion of bloom from annual flowers in August and September, but July is often on the colorless side. It isn't necessary to rely on the perennial phlox, platycodon, bee balm and daylilies for flowers this month.

ENGLISH being the common language, the theatres of London and New York are always mindful of each other. Nothing that happens in one theatre is overlooked by the other. At the moment there are only two London productions on the stage in New York -- "The Boy Friend" and "Witness for the Prosecution." But fourteen New York productions are on London stages.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Cordell Hull, founder of the Reciprocal Trade Program and a key figure in laying the groundwork for the United Nations, died today at the age of 83.
The throbbing heat continued yesterday -- the tenth day this month with the temperatures in the 90's.

THOSE who have not purchased wallpaper recently may not know that a large variety of papers is being ing offered pre-trimmed. The selvages, which formerly had to be trimmed off both edges the whole length of each roll, are now precisely removed at the factory by electronically controlled machines.

While thumbing through the yellowed pages of an 1885 Puck, part of a vast collection of ancient magazines, I came across this prophecy on baseball players of the future. It struck me as bearing a remarkable resemblance to the players described by John Lardner in his "Mighty Robot at the Bat" (June 19), illustrated by Abner Dean, on the push-button era in baseball.

THE seventh stamp in the regular postage series inaugurated at Washington last year will be the 50cent with a photograph of Susan B. Anthony (1820-1906), woman suffrage leader. Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield, when making the design available last week, said that the likeness of Miss Anthony was "reproduced from an original photograph supplied by the Library of Congress."

NORTHVILLE, Mich., July 23 -- Tommy Bolt crushed the chances of Jack Fleck in the Professional Golfers Association championship today. Bolt, a former carpenter who registers from Chattanooga, stopped the United States Open champion by 3 and 1 in a scheduled thirty-six-hole match at the Meadowbrook Country Club course to reach the quarterfinal.

Carroll, a Harvard University linguist and psychologist, which may provide an answer to this question.

Jim Hearn was only four strikes, or two outs, away from a no-hit, no-run victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs yesterday at the Polo Grounds. The 32-yearold Atlantan achieved a 2-0 victory, but he failed in his bid to become the first Giant hurler to fashion a no-hitter since Carl Hubbell did it against the Pirates in 1929.

A military reserves bill has now emerged from Senate-House conference and will go to the floor of the two chambers for presumptive approval this week. On the ground that even a quarter of a loaf is better than no bread it will probably receive the reluctant signature of the President.

Signorina Miriam Michelotti, president of the San Marino League for Emancipation of Women, arrived at Idlewild Airport yesterday. She came to persuade natives of San Marino living in the United States to return to that smallest independent nation to try to overthrow the Communistcontrolled government.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 24 -- A smoldering forest fire leaped to life near Old Bridge this afternoon and in a half hour swept three miles through tinderdry pine woods. It destroyed two homes and a barn in its path.

THIS summer Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., is observing the centennial of its famous canal -- the Soo. With the opening of its locks in 1855, there was no longer the difficult portage around the rapids -- commercial vessels had a continuous water route between Lake Superior and the other lower Great Lakes.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -The Navy will run its biggest Arctic operations this summer. It will use 117 ships to send supplies to Far North bases and carry equipment for building the Dew Line or Distant Early Warning Line of Radar.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 23 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood completed the defense of her Garden State Women's Golf Association championship today, with a 5-and-4 triumph over Judy Frank of Aldecress.

TWO years ago N. Peter Rathvon, former president of R. K. O., bought the screen rights to the late George Orwell's book "1984." In that novel the astringent social analyst depicted a London of the not-so-distant future, a London known as "Airstrip One," heart of a country called Oceania, the complete totalitarian state, at perpetual war with the other world groups, Eurasia and Eastasia, and dominated by a creature known as Big Brother.

A REMINDER now at the end of July that the gladiolus season is fast coming up is the show scheduled for Wednesday by the New York Eastern Gladiolus Society. This year it will take place at the gymnasium of the Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute, Farmingdale, between the hours of 3 and 9 P. M.

THE fall of 1953 saw the start of two interesting developments in this country's musical life. At that time, the Louisville Symphony, aided by a $400,000 grant from the Rockefeller Foundation, began commissioning a new work every week. And the American Symphony Orchestra League began its workshops for music critics. This fall, the two developments are converging, for the league's third workshop for critics will be held in Louisville from Oct. 7 to 9.

Both in the United States and Britain research has been conducted for years on the possibility of sterilizing foods by bombarding them with electrons or X-rays and in this way killing micro-organisms. The results are promising, but sterilization by radiation is not yet a commercial success.

KANSAS CITY, July 23 -- Much of the 1955 wheat crop is coming to market and this has been graphically shown in the bulge in bank deposits and loans to mills and grain concerns. With the market price for protein wheat above the net price that would go to the farmer placing his wheat under Government loan, the farmer has been pouring his harvest into the terminal markets of the Southwest.

TOKYO, July 23 (AP) -- Japan's two conservative parties today released a blueprint for forming a new single party, opposed to socialism, communism and "monopolistic capitalism," but dedicated to "realizing a welfare state."

GENEVA, July 23 -- The Big Four pronounced the summit conference a success tonight. They instructed their foreign ministers to return here in October to start detailed negotiations on the future of Germany and European security.

SPARTA, N. J., July 23 (AP) -The defending champion, Mrs. Beth Olson of Beachwood Yacht Club, and Dick Torpey of Money Island Yacht Club were tied for first after two races today in the New Jersey State snipe championship at Lake Mohawk.

CANNES -- Everybody says the Riviera has changed, and it is true. The big estates are boarded up for sale, Scott Fitzgerald and Noel Coward left long ago, and there are ghosts of a livelier era which haunt Cap Martin and Cap d'Ail.

Though not in the same league with the Himalayas, these mountains in the border wilderness of Brazil and the Guianas have lately been the object of so many expeditions by adventurous parties and, subsequently, the subject of so many books by the same parties that the answer this morning would seem to be yes.

Players of the favorite had no worries in the run through the stretch in the $29,050 Saranac Handicap at the Jamaica track yesterday. Mrs. Marion duPont Scott's Saratoga, the people's choice at 13 to 10, hustled away from the opposition and won with three and a half lengths to spare.

DE WITT, N. Y., July 23 (AP) -- Lyall Evans of Camillus, N. Y., shattered 200 consecutive targets today to win the men's championship in the New York State amateur trapshoot. The championship was the fifth straight for Evans, who took the crown with a score of 194 last year.

THE undisputed climax of Ireland's summer tourist season is the Dublin Horse Show, scheduled this year for Aug. 3-6. This is jointly one of the major equestrian events on Europe's calendar and a big time for those who follow the doings of society and fashion.

GALVESTON, Tex., July 23 -The University of Texas medical branch here has had six years' experience in desegregation on the under-graduate level. Other branches of the university are slated to start desegregation.

CAIRO, July 23 -- The Egyptian armed forces displayed strength today in a five-hour parade celebrating the third anniversary of Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser's revolution against the monarchy.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Spray plants favored by Japanese beetles with lindane, malathion or DDT. Nicotine sulfate aimed at the undersides of leaves takes care of black or red aphids on nasturtium. Use DDT as soon as caterpillars are seen on buds of snapdragon. Apply lindane again to control lacebugs on evergreens, oak and sycamore trees.

Representatives of the Kohler Company of Kohler, Wis., and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., will sit down at Chicago Wednesday with Federal conciliators in an attempt to work out an agreement.

He was working in a tight corner in a basement, using an electric drill to cut a hole for a new pipe. To brace himself, he had one arm around an iron drain. It was hot and he was sweating aplenty.

RICHMOND, July 23 -- New industrial development in South Carolina for the first half of 1955 exceeds that of any full calendar year since 1951. In the six-month period new industries in the state were valued at $81,400,000.

Bears and bulls enjoyed themselves last week. They romped all over the New York commodity futures markets and paid little attention to anything but extremes. Few commodities were in middle ground. Most prices moved all the way up or all the way down.

CANBERRA, July 23 -- Utah (Australia), Ltd., and Concrete Constructions Proprietary, Ltd., have been given a joint contract by the Commonwealth Government to build a big ammunition filling and assembly plant at St. Mary's, near Sydney, at a fixed fee of 615,000 ($1,384,000) in excess of cost.

DETROIT, July 23 (UP) -- Rain forced the second game of a double-header between the Detroit Tigers and Washington Senators to be called off after three innings with the score tied at 2 -- 2 today. The Tigers wor the first, 10 -- 4, by rocking three pitchers for twelve safeties, four of them home runs.

IN this writer's experience almost everyone has an idea for a biography. Indeed, a large number of reader who, as they say, admire your work express their admiration by writing to beg you to undertake a subject they want to see done. Usually a subject different from anything you have attempted before and often to be written in a new method.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 -On the sixty-ninth anniversary of her first visit to this port, a three-masted iron ship, the Pacific Queen, with new paint and rigging, was berthed today near Aquatic Park to become a floating museum.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, July 23 (AP) -- Nearly 250,000 children attended the thirty-sixth International Eucharistic Congress today to take communion offered for the "salvation of the whole world."

A. M. Bakharev of Stalinabad Astronomical Observatory, Soviet Russia, is now credited with discovering the bright comet in the constellation of Pegasus on July 13. WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -President Eisenhower won a number of disputes with Congress over key defense and atomic funds today. The Senate Appropriations Committee voted to restore more than $1,000,000,000 that the House of Representatives had deleted from a money bill last week.

THE new issue of Aperture, just published, is devoted almost entirely to a kind of summation of fact and opinion on "The Family of Man" exhibition, Minor White, the editor, whose comments throughout the issue attempt to knit the various views together, places the show in historical perspective by including articles on the Photo Secessionist Show in Buffalo in 1910 and the Stuttgart 1929 exhibition.

THE lovely, brilliant Duchess of Aquitaine bowed to the fate of a tweifth-century heiress and married Louis VII of France. Save for the Second Crusade -- that tremendous adventure of her youth -- fifteen years of marriage passed uneventfully, to end in divorce on technical grounds.

GLUE is one of the oldest of the "do-it-yourself" mending and building media. Basically it is one of the easiest materials to use. This quality gives rise to the popular but erroneous notion that any glue will glue anything. Failure can be avoided by selecting the correct adhesive for the task.

WITH underwater photography apparently established as one of the most alluring hobby phases of the medium, the appearance of a popular manual on the subject is in order. A handbook on the hobby level, "A Guide to Underwater Photography" (New York: Greenberg, Publisher, $1.95) by Dimitri-Rebikoff, European authority on the subject and expert underwater photographer, and Paul Cherney, his American associate, will be published Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -- The Air Force disclosed today it had returned four United States fliers to full duty without taking action against them for "confessions" extorted by their Communist Chinese captors.

THE county fair season in these parts starts a little earlier this year, at least in Maine, where the celebrations get under way tomorrow, a week ahead of last year. Following are the places and dates of fairs announced for this year in eleven eastern seaboard states.

PARIS, July 23 -- For a few hours, a week ago yesterday, downtown Casablanca was in the hands of a frenzied European mob.
BARCELONA, Spain, July 23 (AP) -- Italy and Greece took gold medals today during the second Mediterranean Games. Until today, France had been dominating the action.

GAETANO SALVEMINI'S "La Rivoluzione Francese, 1788-1792" was first published in Milan in 1905 when the author was 32. Though long admired in Europe as one of the most succinct and intelligent volumes ever written on the early years of the French Revolution, it has remained almost unknown in the United States because of the long delay in providing a translation.

OTTAWA, July 19 -- Canada's 73-year-old Liberal Prime Minister, Louis St. Laurent, recently cheered his followers and dismayed his opponents by intimating that he expected to lead his party in the next election.
LONDON. SINCE the lamented departure of Brooks Atkinson for his own country the only important London production has been Orson Welles' dramatization of Herman Melville's "Moby Dick."

Cordell Hull's long fight for reciprocal trade agreements as instruments for world peace and prosperity has come to be regarded as the most characteristic feature of his public life. Mr. Hull's maiden speech in the House of Representatives in 1908 was a plea for the traditional low-tariff policies of the Democratic party.

BONN, July 23 -- The failure of the Geneva conference to advance the course of Germany's reunification on the pattern set by Washington, Bonn, London, and Paris did not surprise anyone. It did, however, cause a good deal of anguish among the devotees of "reunification through strength."

GROSSINGER, N. Y., July 23 -- Jean Murphy of Brooklyn won the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior women's 400-meter individual medley swimming championship today at the Grossinger Country Club's Olympic Pool.

IN the complex plan of the universe, flowers and insects are mutually interdependent. The insect is necessary to assure fertilization of the blossom. And since insects of all sizes come to the flowers, often it is here that the stronger insects destroy the weaker, this being one of the many mechanisms by which the insect population is controlled and kept in balance.

FIFTEEN years ago Harold J. Laski was a name to conjure with. A political scientist of eminence, a generous and influential teacher, a dominant intellectual in the British Labor party, he cast a spell on bright young men in at least four continents.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (UP) -- Del Ennis hit three home runs today to produce all the Philadelphia Phillies' tallies in a 7-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., July 23 -- Mrs. Henry Pomeroy Davison will open Peacock Point, her estate on Long Island Sound, on Sept. 10, for the annual benefit country fair of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown.

THE Kodak Pony 135 camera is available in a new model, Eastman Kodak Company has announced. At the same time the company offered a new Kodak Pony 135 camera outfit that includes the camera, a field case, flash holder and flash guard.

New Yorkers planning to take part in the open championship of the United States Chess Federation must again travel across the country to do so. Long Beach, Calif., is making elaborate preparations to extend hospitality to a large gathering.

NORMAN, Okla. -- Tourists who think of Oklahoma in terms of oil wells and sun-baked prairie should plan, on their trip through the state, to stop over at Quarry Isle State Park not far from the Arkansas border. They will be pleasantly surprised.

BUFFALO, July 23 -- A lively contest has developed among Western New York Republicans over the United States District Court bench vacancy. It was created by the death of Judge John Knight last month.

Within the last few years, however, this audience has been steadily widening and now it is of such proportions that it has become attractive to merchandisers who base their operations on a mass market.

The inauguration of Dr. Hollis L. Caswell as president of Teachers College, Columbia University, will take place on Nov. 22 at the Riverside Church in New York City. The theme of the inauguration is "Educational Leadership for a Free World." Dr. Caswell will be the first head of Teachers College to be inaugurated in twenty-seven years and the fifth president of the college since its founding in 1887.

ONE of the healthiest longrange careers in Hollywood right now belongs to Andy Devine, who, with the forthcoming release of "Pete Kelly's Blues," will be rounding out thirty years of moviemaking. "I've loved every minute of it," he croaked splendidly from the depths of his granite-lined tonsils.
HONOLULU, July 23 -- An ancient symbol of something hard to find in this atomic age is being set aside as part of a national park in Hawaii.

LIGHT-HEARTED as it is, this compact child's biography of Wolfgang Mozart manages to include almost every salient feature of the great composer's life. Helen Kaufmann knows her Mozart, and as she takes him romping through the glittering courts of eighteenthcentury Europe and England, we feel, as did his father, that the world cannot bestow too much upon the amazing infant.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The United States has warned the South Korean Government that it may have to curtail aid if President Syngman Rhee attempts to impose an "unrealistic" rate of exchange.

THE 28 - year - old author, Christopher Veiel, not only looks a little like a British F. Scott Fitzgerald -- he has also taken a lease on a Fitzgerald subject, expatriate life in France and Switzerland, to write his first novel.

ATLANTA, July 23 -- Construction contracts in the Southeast during the first half of the year were the second highest on record, totaling an estimated $1,384,000,000, it was reported this week. In June, awards for future construction were valued at about $257,000,000, some 35 per cent greater than those in the corresponding month of last year. Non-residential contracts in the first six nionths this year were up 28 per cent over the similar 1954 period.

The charter market continued "bullis" last week with coal still the most important single commodity in the field. A number of charters for coal shipments were made for next winter and later.

People who take pride in being good were chided by the Very Rev. James A. Pike in his sermon yesterday at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).

As a long-time student and consultant on urban mass transportation I agree with your editorial of July 15 "A Street Lane for Buses." It is indeed time to deal "head on" with the gathering crisis in local passenger transportation. The editorial presents excellently the extreme crisis conditions.

Coated nylon tarpaulin will replace standard cotton canvas tarpaulin in the next five years as completely as nylon stockings superseded silk hose, it was predicted over the week-end.

It is no depreciation of the stature of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt and the late Senator Robert A. Taft to suggest the time has not yet come to erect statues to them on Federal land in the District of Columbia. WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Members of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations predicted today that public hearings into the business activities of Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, would be brief.

A new world record for airline traffic in June was set by American Airlines. C. R. Speers, senior vice president directing sales, announced yesterday that American had flown 416,000,000 passenger miles in the month.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 24 -- Tony Trabert gave one of his most convincing performances of a year of notable achievement in winning the Pennsylvania State tennis championship today.

MONTAUK, L. I., July 24 -- An Air Force sergeant playing the role of a gunner who had bailed out of an enemy atom bomber tried to hide near here. He was flushed from a patch of scrub pine by a three-man team from an extraordinary Air Force outfit.

In his first sermon in the United States, the Rev. Kenneth D. Harvey declared yesterday that "all around the world America is held in honor, because President Eisenhower told his people to pray for peace."

The largest peacetime ship replacement program in the nation's history, involving the expenditure of $3,000,000,000 and the creation of 500,000 man-years of employment, is about to begin.

DETROIT, July 24 (AP)--Ted Abernathy, a Washington rookie pitcher, clamped down on the Detroit Tigers' home run surge today with a 3-0 victory in the second game of a double-header, ending the Senators' four-game losing streak.

About every major record in newspaper advertising has been smashed in the first half of 1955. This is the word from Media Records, Inc., and the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

One of the more joyful institutions of the summer season at Lewisohn Stadium, the Viennese Night, took place Saturday evening. BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 13 -- After journeying from Greece through Turkey and northern Syria, travelers are impressed by the bustle of activity in this cosmopolitan center of the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- The Government's one-mountainous supply of surplus butter has been reduced more than 50 per cent in the last year.

Marshal Tito's Government has applied some rather drastic medicine recently in an effort to solve Yugoslavia's present economic difficulties. Prices of key foods have been raised substantially, the increases being compensated for only partially by higher salaries. Yugoslavia's economic chief has acknowledged that not enough grain is being produced, and has ordered increased grain prices paid to farmers in the hope of spurring production.

As foreign trade expands and currency after currency gropes toward more complete convertibility, black markets are becoming fewer and blonder. The clearing deal, once extra-legal by the kindest interpretation, has been bleached by official sanction. Today almost all central banks and port officials cooperate.

NAZARETH, Israel, July 24 -- This ancient shrine of Christianity received today a dependable supply of water, a blessing it has lacked through all its recorded history.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Representative J. Percy Priest said today he thought a compromise on polio vaccine legislation could be reached.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 24 -- The first move to carry out the Geneva conference proposal for a renewal of disarmament talks will be made by the United Nations secretariat set up for the Big Four meetings.

MIAMI, Fla., July 24 -- Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, former President of Cuba, declared today he would return to Cuba in August for the purpose of uniting all those opposed to the Batista regime and bringing about a peaceful solution of the nation's problems.

Saved by Willie Mays' great play in the seventh inning of the second game, the Giants beat the Cincinnati Redlegs, 4 -- 1, yesterday at the Polo Grounds. The visitors had taken the opener, 6 -- 4, behind Art Fowler and Joe Black, ending a seven-game losing streak.
Jack Wilder has been named resident manager of the New Yorker Hotel at Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, effective Aug. 1.

NEW DELHI, India, July 24 (UP) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told Parliament today he believed the Geneva conference was at least a partial success. He added he did not think the time was yet ripe for similar talks on Asian problems.

The congregation at New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) had no idea, as it listened to the Very Rev. James A. Pike composedly deliver the 11 A. M. sermon yesterday, that only minutes earlier he had sat mopping television make-up off his face in a car speeding uptown.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Hundreds of persons paid their respects today to Cordell Hull, former Secretary of State and a founder of the United Nations-Organization. The 83-year-old statesman died yesterday after suffering several strokes and heart attacks.
Bishop Herbert C. Welch declared yesterday that by contrast with the nineteenth century, which was the century of nationalism, "the twentieth century will be called the century of internationalism."

THE television screen, once a medium of entertainment, again was used for sixty minutes last night to advertise a forthcoming motion picture. The commercial was presented from 8 to 9 o'clock on Channel 4.

ZURICH, July 24 -- Great nervousness prevailed all last week among business people in Switzerland. The news from Geneva had no perceptible effect on stock exchange busi ness whereas developments in Buenos Aires, showing that the Peron regime was nearing its end, had a stimulating effect on the market for all Argentine securities, in so many of which Swiss capital is heavily invested.

PARIS, July 24 -- The possibility of major war during the predictable future has been measurably reduced by the Geneva conference. The chances of conflict in the West had already disappeared before the summit meeting. But as a result of the mood now established among the Big Four it can be assumed every effort will be made to avoid serious trouble in Asia.

At two points in Southeast Asia, popular elections for a representative legislative body are important in the news. In one country, Malaya, the elections are scheduled for this week. In another, Indonesia, the elections are tentatively set for Sept. 29, and the current Cabinet crisis there has caused some fear that they may not be held as scheduled.
GENEVA, July 24 -- The Soviet delegates to the Geneva conference headed back to Moscow today to call off the "cold war." At least, that is what knowledgeable Russians here have said they will do.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 24 (UP) -- David Ben-Gurion offered tonight to meet Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser "or any Egyptian statesman" in a conference to pacify the Holy Land.
Fear of God should be inculcated in the young, the Rev. Olan Healy declared yesterday in a sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

New York and New Jersey officials continued yesterday to press their conflicting claims for Ellis Island. They were agreed, however, that it was time the Federal Government did something about the former immigrant station that has been declared "surplus."
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- Tobacco farmers in five Southern - states yesterday approved overwhelmingly marketing quotas for flue-cured tobacco for the 1956, 1957 and 1958 crops.
Much of the Flatbush-to-Coney Island region of Brooklyn, once staid and a bit frowzy at the edges, is growing up to be educated, alert and sophisticated.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The American Automobile Association expressed "vigorous support today for the Federal highway construction program approved by the House Public Works Committee.
Employers of waterfront labor in the Port of New York are casting about for new ways to intensify their safety education program.

That joint London mission of Roger L. Stevens and Robert L. Joseph has been accomplished. Tidings were flashed back here that the partners will be able to bring over "Tiger at the Gates" in September instead of holding off until January.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- Business and consumer credit has provided much of the steam behind this year's economic upsurge, Federal Reserve Bank figures showed today.

PITTSBURGH, July 24 (AP) -- Frank Thomas scored Jerry Lynch with a single in the last of the tenth inning today as the Pittsburgh Pirates downed the Chicago Cubs, 3 -- 2, in the second game of a double-header. The Pirates won the first contest, 12 -- 5, with a nineteen-hit attack.

As hundreds watched from the Brooklyn Bridge and other near-by vantage points, fire destroyed a 100-foot wood and steel pier next to the Fulton Fish Market early today. The blaze spread to the roof of a warehouse on one of the fish market's piers, but was quickly extinguished by city and Coast Guard fire boats.

JEFFERSON, Iowa, July 24 -- Diplomats from the Big Four Governments may eventually devise a plan for lifting the Iron Curtain. However, it is not likely to be any more successful than the one used here today by the Russian agricultural delegation and their hosts.

LONDON, July 24--The boom conditions have returned to the stock markets, with oil shares leading a fresh advance in industrial equities. With monotonous regularity the Financial Times industrial share index has been rising almost daily to new peaks.

A tuna-fish salad far from prosaic is one done in the Swedish manner, in combination with shrimp and hard-cooked eggs. The Scandinavians, with their fondness for fish, make many delectable salads such as this one:

This country's first importation of frozen shrimp from Pakistan will arrive here today. The 5,000-pound shipment will be unloaded from the S. S. President Monroe at Pier 9, Jersey City. Shipments are expected to reach 50,000 pounds a month by October.

The cargo ship Black Eagle will arrive here today on her maiden voyage, the Black Diamond Lines announced yesterday. The new motorship was launched from the Kockums Shipyard at Malmo, Sweden, on April 15.
LOS ANGELES, July 24 -- Los Angeles transit lines employes voted overwhelmingly today to end the thirty-five-day bus and street car strike.

The state does not feel employers should give workers the brush just because they grow beards. The Four Freedoms have just been expanded to include the freedom of workers to wear a Vandyke without losing their jobs.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Representative John W. McCormack, Democrat of Massachusetts, said today he "wouldn't be a bit surprised if somebody else" other than Adlai E. Stevenson won the Democratic nomination for President next year.
Following is the text of a radio talk by Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams yesterday afternoon, as recorded by The New York Times:

The Braves and the Dodgers struggled for nearly five hours at Ebbets Field yesterday and wound up right where they started. The Brooks won the opener, 9 -- 7, and the runner-up Milwaukeeans took the second game, 9 -- 2.

AMSTERDAM, July 24 -- Amterdam is gradually recapturing part of its pre-war position as an international financial center. This is reflected in next week's issue of 2,500,000 British sterling 4 1/2 per cent, fifteen-year bonds, at 98.25 per cent, of the Anglo-American Rhodesian Development Corporation.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Army observed the 180th anniversary of the Army chaplaincy today with a retreat parade at Fort Myer, Va.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 24 -- Three sailing classes held their annual long-distance events today under the direction of the Larchmont Yacht Club's regatta committee.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (AP) -- Saul Rogovin, a former American League pitcher, ran his string of scoreless innings to fifteen for the Philadelphia Phillies today. He shut out the St. Louis Cardinals, 3 -- 0, in the second game of a double-header called after six innings because of rain.

Sharply increased sales and higher lead and zinc prices enabled the St. Joseph Lead Company to report a consolidated net income of $6,741,906 for the first half of this year, equal to $2.48 a capital share. This compared with $2,749,192 or $1.01 a share for the like period last year.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Investigators of the House of Representatives swing back this week to a widening inquiry of alleged rackets in selling insurance policies to American servicemen.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 24 -- The Sixteenth International Conference of Surgery opened here today. Eleven hundred surgeons representing forty-two countries are attending the week-long conference, sponsored by the International Society of Surgery.

The Marine Band played "The Star-Spangled Banner" when President Eisenhower got out at the Washington airport yesterday morning, in the rain, his watch still on Eastern daylight time. This is a good song and it suited the occasion. Mr. Eisenhower had done even better than defeat an enemy in battle, as had been his assignment a decade ago.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- Senator Richard L. Neuberger, Democrat of Oregon, proposed today erection of a bird bath or small fountain as a memorial to the late Senator Charles L. McNary, Republican of Oregon, on the Capitol plaza.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox gained a 2-1 victory in the second game of a double-header today after losing the opener to the Chicago White Sox and Billy Pierce, 4 -- 0.

This morning, over in Jersey City, an important cargo will be unloaded. It is only 5,000 pounds -- not huge as ship tonnages go -- but it is the first tangible product of a new joint Pakistani-American enterprise. The cargo is frozen shrimp from the Arabian Sea off Karachi.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- The Senate Government Operations Committee will open hearings tomorrow on proposals to make Federal payments to state and local governments in lieu of taxes on Federal property.
LONDON, July 24 -- Prime Minister Eden said today that the Geneva conference had been more successful than he had expected.

PLAINFIELD; N. J., July 24 -- Bobby Kuntz of Bonnie Briar in Larchmont, N. Y., won the Metropolitan Golf Association amateur championship for the first time today over the Plainfield Country Club course.
A new kind of street sign, larger and a greater color visibility will be installed in Manhattan, starting today.
WASHINGTON, July 24--Senator Walter F. George renewed today his call for "face-to-face" negotiations between the United States and Communist China.
JAKARTA, July 24 -- The Army has emerged as a new and powerful political factor in the fledging Indonesian Republic.

A contract for the purchase of nine parcels in the Ruppert family realty holdings has been sold to Jack Resnick and Peter Feinberg by clients of Walter Scott Co. The deal revolves six parcels in Manhattan and three in the Bronx with a combined assessed valuation of $697,500. Helmsley-Spear, Inc., negotiated the sale of parcels, which had been in the family of Jacob Ruppert, the brewer, for fifty years.
Avco's Lycoming Division announced yesterday a new type of turbine engine designed by Dr. Anselm Franz of Milford, Conn. It will power a new helicopter in which the Army puts great stock.
GLASSBORO, N. J., July 24 -- Puerto Rican legislators came here today to learn first-hand the problems of migrant agricultural workers from their home-land.
The Estate Securities Company bought the four-story apartment houses occupying the blockfront at 238 to 268 Bay Ridge Parkway in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.
An early-morning rain, breezes and clouds broke New York's ultra-sultry weather wave yesterday.

If Venice has a Bridge of Sighs, then any tourist in Italy can identify a Bridge of Shops -- the Ponte Vecchio in Florence. Summer dispatches say that these shops of the goldsmiths and jewelers, floating above the River Arno, are facing ruin after six centuries of doing business at the same old stand.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 23 -- Snow fences and Christmas trees are "in season" here.
KANSAS CITY, July 24 -- The Yankees served notice today they were not yet ready to be counted out of the American League's pennant race. In fact, they are not even out of first place.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July -- The United States delegation to the conference on peaceful uses of atomic energy, opening Aug. 8 in Geneva, will num-number 324.

BONN, Germany, July 24 -- Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin of the Soviet Union reaffirmed today on his arrival in East Berlin that his government would "unflinchingly" uphold its policy on German reunification.

FLORENCE, July 24 -- Between them, Fabiani and Simonetta, Italian dress designers showing their collections today, take elegant care of the short plump woman and her long thin sister. This is not surprising because in domestic life Fabiani and Simonetta are man and wife, though they are completely "divorced'' in their work.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 24 -- The thirty-sixth International Eucharistic Congress, which has provided an impressive display of religious feeling here during the last week, closed tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Justice Department is scarcely overconfident about winning its case against the United Auto Workers, C. I. O. The union has been charged with spending union money for political broadcasts. The record gives good ground for pessimism.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., July 24 (AP) -- Local 6321 of the United Mine Workers yesterday re-elected two of its officers despite the fact that the union's international headquarters had suspended them for two years.

LENOX, Mass., July 24 -- Pierre Monteux is a remarkable octogenarian. His powers of concentration seem to become stronger as he gets older. Conducting the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood last night he led a diversified, demanding program with the kind of tension and control given only to the finest maestros.
The biggest union in the American Federation of Labor has bought its president's home for $160,000.

LOUISVILLE, July 24 (UP) -- Ronald Moreira, a 10-year-old native Chilean who plays for Brazil and attends college in the United States, upset Lew Hoad of Australia today, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, in one of the two concluding singles matches of the North American zone Davis Cup tennis series, already won by Australia.

Bargaining between East Coast shipyards and the International Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., shifts to the Maryland Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Baltimore today.

I have read with interest the splendid articles which appeared in The New York Times presenting a broad survey of American business operations in overseas areas, as well as your excellent editorial on this subject. By publishing these articles you have rendered an outstanding service to your readers and have given well-deserved recognition to the efforts and achievements of American business in overseas operations.

The Western Union Telegraph Company is offering its shareholders rights to subscribe to 1,036,052 shares of the company's new common stock at $20 a share on the basis of one new share for each five held.

LAST Friday we considered in this space a collection of short stories by an 84-year-old writer who has been busily producing books for fifty years, "Grandfather Stories," by Samuel Hopkins Adams. Today we have with us a collection of short stories by an 83-year-old writer who has been busily producing books for fifty-nine years, "Night mares of Eminent Persons and Other Stories,"* by Bertrand Russell.

Capacity plus marked Saturday night's performance of "Arabian Nights," the outdoor spectacle at Jones Beach. The mammoth Marine Stadium was jammed by 8,329 persons. Ordinarily, the stadium seats 8,206.
Five new films, including importations from England and Russia, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Cotton futures prices turned firmer on Friday after declining moderately in the previous four sessions. At the week's end, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 60 cents to up $1 a bale from the close of the previous week.
A hippopotamus has been born at the Central Park Zoo.
The Fire Marshal's office was to continue today an investigation of a three-alarm tenement fire in Harlem early Sunday in which a 5-year-old child died.
GENEVA, July 24 (AP) -- Thousands of sightseers turned up at the gates of the Palace of Nations today in the hope of getting a glimpse of the chamber where the Big Four meeting was held.
GENEVA, July 24 (UP) -- Following is the text of a translation from the Russian of Premier Bulganin's farewell statement today:

A study of recent work records on the waterfront and of the last available statistics covering earnings strongly supports the dock union's contention that some control must be established over the register of longshoremen.

Representatives of the five county medical societies in New York City and a store workers' union announced yesterday a plan to provide prepaid medical care, with a free choice of doctors, for 25,000 union members and their families.
Diversification, a post-war industrial phenomenon, has become more than a trend -- it is almost a way of life for present-day American business. And like life itself, it is infinitely varied.
The General Electric Company served notice yesterday that it did not regard the auto and steel wage settlements as patterns for it to follow in union negotiations covering 135,000 G. E. workers.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- President Eisenhower came home from the Geneva conference this morning declaring that there was "evidence of a new friendliness in the world."
Vigorous continuation and expansion of the city's public housing program was urged yesterday by the Mayor's Committee for Better Housing.

The two-story building containing eleven stores and twenty-four offices at the southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Twenty-third Street has been bought by I. Jerome Riker, president of the Mutual Bond and Mortgage Company, who has resold it to a client of Herbert Jacques Morris for investment.
Carmine G. DeSapio was sounded out yesterday on what he thought of a 1956 Democratic ticket consisting of Governor Harriman for President and Mayor Wagner for Senator.
NORTHVILLE, Mich., July 24 -- In a match that required nine hours, Cary Middlecoff rallied magnificently today to reach the semi-finals of the Professional Golfers Association championship.

Legislation is again being processed in Congress (the Green bill) having as its objective repeal of the Silver Purchase program, initiated in 1933-1934 and embroidered and embellished in subsequent measures over the following two decades.

The sons of one of the founders of Lewis Conger, the housewares store at Forty-fifth Street and the Avenue of the Americas, have sold their interest in the business and retired. R. V. Lewis, president, and A. V. Lewis, vice president, have been active in the store for a total of seventy-eight years.

As a lifetime friend and neighbor of Bob Taft I wish to make reference to Robert E. Sherwood's letter to The Times printed July 8 in which he agreed with your editorial objections to the proposed monument to the memory of Senator Taft and to the suggestion that it be erected on Capitol Hill.
FRANKLIN, N. H., July 24 -- On a scorching day, young and old in Franklin usually head for the cool shores of Webster Lake. Not so this week-end.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams said yesterday that "law and order are gradually returning to the streets of New York."

PARIS, July 24 -- A series of consultations in French Morocco gave rise this week-end to the belief that a compromise solution of the troublesome Moroccan can dynastic question was being given urgent consideration.
LONDON, July 24 -- The Geneva conference is being hailed throughout Europe as a successful attempt to relieve international tension.
CHICAGO, July 24 -- Last week saw much long liquidation in corn, oats and soybeans. Crop conditions were regarded about perfect for these crops, and prices dropped to new crops lows.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 24 -- The signing of a new two-picture contract between Stanley Kramer, producer-director, and United Artists was announced today by Robert S. Benjamin, board chairman of the distributing company.
Office space in Manhattan -- new and old -- continues to be absorbed at a record pace.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- Certificates for rapid tax write-offs for forty defense-related projects were issued between June 30 and July 13, the Office of Defense Mobilization announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- Senator Walter F. George said today he had noted a "disturbing tendency" on the part of some United Nations agencies "to go their own separate ways" without proper coordination.

When the Attorney General's list of subversive organizations was first formally circulated in 1947 it was meant to be used merely as one element in helping to determine fitness for Government employment under the security program. It still is supposed to be used only in that manner; but its actual use by public and private agencies has extended far beyond that official and original purpose.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, the nation's largest freight carrier, has ordered 4,000 new freight cars, costing $32,400,000. It is one of the largest equipment purchases announced by any railroad since the Korean War.
M'CLOUD, Calif., July 24 -- Timber crews are logging stately sugar pine, ponderosa pine and fir on the 67,000-acre estate of the late William Randolph Hearst in Northern California.

STOCKHOLM, July 24 (AP) -- The United States high jump champion, Ernie Shelton of Southern California, again lost a duel with Sweden's Bengt Nilsson in their month-long competition -- and this time lost his temper, too.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 24 -- About 2,000 members of the Screen Actors Guild voted unanimously for a strike against producers of filmed TV entertainment. This action, taken at an "emergency" meeting tonight in the Hollywood Legion Stadium, was coupled with the qualification "if it is necessary to obtain a just and decent contract."
Fifty-five thousand persons poured into Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon for the final session of the "Triumphant Kingdom" assembly of Jehovah's Witnesses.

After drawing his games in the first two rounds, Edmar Mednis of New York gained two victories over the week-end in the world junior chess championship in-Antwerp, according to a report received yesterday through Belgian news sources.

HONOLULU, July 24 (AP) -- Three former United States soldiers reached American soil today. They said a radio speech by President Eisenhower has sped their decision to turn their backs on Communist China and return home.
PROBABLY the most active farm in New York City lies, incongruously, in the East River. It is on Rikers Island, and is worked by men from the city's penitentiary and workhouse.
LOWELL, Mass., July 25 -- The Merrimack Manufacturing Company and the Workers' Independent Union announced today an agreement calling for profit sharing and wage increases.
LAST night's television presentation of "The Fourposter," with Jessica Tandy and her husband, Hume Cronyn, in their original Broadway roles, was a delight and joy.

Massachusetts Investors Trust reported yesterday that its total net assets were $904,905,194 on June 30. On the same date there were also 28,712,743 shares outstanding and 126,901 stockholders. These are the highest figures in the mutual investment company's thirty-one-year history.
The Walworth Company, valves and fittings manufacturer, announced yesterday it had completed arrangements to buy the assets and business of the M. and H. Valve and Fittings Company, Anniston, Ala.

MADRID, July 25 (Reuters) -- Twenty-one Spaniards convicted last November of having attempted to organize a Masonic lodge will be moved to Federal prisons on Wednesday to serve out terms, it was learned tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 25 -- The congregation of All Saints Protestant Episcopal Church in Beverly Hills offered prayers yesterday asking divine guidance for a successful conclusion to contract negotiations between the Screen Actors Guild and the producers of filmed television entertainment.
NORWALK, Conn., July 25 -- The ouster of Alden A. Ameden, area Civil Defense director, has stirred plans for a protest by members of his staff. The area includes all of Fairfield County.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The equivalent of atomic documents that would fill 250 feet of library shelving has been shipped to twenty-three foreign countries in support of President Eisenhower's atoms-for-peace program.
Two of the giants of the distilling industry locked horns yesterday over the problem of stocks of bonded whisky soon to be forced, tax paid, on a shrinking market.
TOKYO, July 25 -- The United States Eighth Army is moving its headquarters back to Korea after only eight months in Japan.

Welcome to the Canadian air mass! All hail that traveler to whom we eagerly play host from time to time during the summer. We may get tired of visitors who come for the week-end and stay the month. We may turn out the light and hide in the cellar to avoid callers.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 25 (Reuters) -- Dr. Carl Gustav Jung, last of the three scientists, famous for pioneering exploration of the subconscious mind, will celebrate his eightieth birthday here tomorrow.

BOSTON, July 25 -- Icebergs caused no chills for captains of ships traveling the regular lanes between the United States and Europe this year. It was the third straight year the International Ice Patrol at Argentina Nfld., had observed little iceberg trouble.
Record sales and earnings were achieved in the quarter and six months ended June 30 by the Climax Molybdenum Company, large mine producer of molybdenum.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The House of Representatives approved finally today the much revised and compromised military Reserve bill.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Government abandoned today its sixteen-month-long effort to deport Dick Haymes.

Today's new film is "Land of the Pharaohs," a Warner Brothers drama in CinemaScope and WarnerColor, with Jack Hawkins, Joan Collins, Kerima, Dewey Martin and Alexis Minotis, at the Mayfair. Howard Hawks directed and produced from a screen play by William Faulkner, Harry Kurnitz and Harold Jack Bloom, James R. Justice, Luisa Boni and Sydney Chaplin head the supporting cast.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Independent Socialist League opened its fight today for removal from the Attorney General's subversive list. Its attorneys accused Justice Department lawyes of "vicious distortions" and "cheesy tricks."

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Cordell Hull lived to be very old, and in the eleven years that followed his retirement from public affairs personal inclination and recurring illness removed him wholly from the notice of the busy World. But he did not live too long to survive his contemporaries.
Richard Kollmar and James W. Gardiner have invited Tallulah Bankhead and Mitzi Gaynor to head the cast of the "Ziegfeld Follies."
LONDON, July 25 -- The British European Airways formally opened today a helicopter service between London airport and the city. The seventeen-and-a-half-mile flight takes fifteen minutes.

SINGAPORE, July 25 -- The Legislative Assembly approved a resolution today demanding the transfer of power from the British Government to the people of Singapore. It asked the granting of a new Constitution providing for immediate self-government.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., July 25 -- The Village Board here adopted tonight the village manager form of government, making Patchogue the first incorporated village on Long Island to have that administration plan. The vote was 6 to 1 and came after a public hearing.

LONDON, July 25 (Reuters) -- England, which faced the task of scoring 481 runs for victory, was still 365 runs behind in the fourth cricket test match against South Africa at Leeds today. England had eight second-innings wickets standing at the close of the fourth day. The match ends tomorrow.

Domestic steel production last week fell short of expectations and declined to 2,195,000 net tons. Operations were at 91 per cent of the industry's rated capacity. The previous week's output was 2,202,000 tons and the operations at 91.2 per cent.
PARIS, July 25 -- Six West German officers, veterans of World War II, will report Wednesday for duty at the Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Powers in Europe.
HUMBOLDT, Iowa, July 25 -- The visiting Russian agricultural officials abandoned the dinner circuit today. They directed their attention to studies of the farm techniques in which they specialize.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A witness testified today that Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, had continued to seek a contract with the Radio Corporation of America for his management engineering concern after R. C. A. had expressed doubts about the contract's legality and propriety.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 25 -- The solution of one of nature's most formidable puzzles -- the exact chemical structure of Vitamin B-12 -- has been achieved by a team of British chemists at Cambridge University.

The deferred annual meeting of stockholders of Venezuela Syndicate, Inc., holder of oil and gas concessions in Venezuela, will be held at 120 Broadway on Aug. 8. A proxy statement sent out by a stockholder group headed by Clint W. Murchison, Texas oil operator, carries the statement that the present directors of Venezuela Syndicate will resign at or prior to the meeting and that a new board will be elected.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, warned television newsreel camera men today he would complain if he detected "bias" in their films of hearings on the business activities of Air Force Secretary Harold E. Talbott.
