S. Johanessen of Norway, in Section B, and D. K. Keller of Switzerland, in Section C, won in the fifth round of the world junior chess championship at Antwerp, according to a report received yesterday through Belgian news sources.
LONDON, July 25 -- Admiral Earl Mountbatten said today that the whole shape and size of the British Fleet was undergoing a change to fit it "into the new pattern of possible warfare."

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., July 25 -- Already aglow at the presence of a flock of baseball immortals of the past, this community was treated today to a stirring glimpse of a sure-shot diamond immortal of the future.

The semi-annual report of the Glenn L. Martin Company, Baltimore aircraft builder, disclosed yesterday a 30.6 per cent increase in sales but a 19.3 per cent drop in earnings from the first half of last year.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's broadcast last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

WHITE PLAINS, July 25 -- One-quarter of the sixteen-mile natural gas pipeline being constructed through the heart of Westchester County has been laid. Engineers predicted today they would complete the project by Oct. 1.
LONDON, July 25 -- Fears of Government measures to counter inflationary trends swept the stock market today and prices broke an average of 3 per cent.
BOSTON, July 25 -- Southern New England trucking firms will offer their drivers pay increases ranging from 30 to 43 cents an hour tomorrow in an effort to end a forty-day strike.
As an air raid warden in a large office building I feel some responsibility for the manner in which drills are conducted.

The Libby, McNeil Libby Independent Stockholders Committee announced yesterday it had filed a suit in the state Supreme Court seeking an injunction to "prevent the company's employes from neglecting their normal duties to engage in soliciting proxies."

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The House Rules Committee cleared today for a floor vote tomorrow a thirteen-year, $48,500,000,000 highway building plan. It was sponsored by Democrats as a substitute for President Eisenhower's program.
PARIS, July 25 -- A nationalist riot swept the Arab quarters of Meknes, French Morocco, today when the French Resident General arrived for his first official visit.
Half-year earnings of the Continental Oil Company and its subsidiaries totaling $22,172,000 exceeded any similar period in the company's history.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Treasury Department stuck today to its criticism of a House-passed bill proposing a new formula for assessing the Federal income taxes of life insurance companies.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization has opposed Government aid for a planned $106,000,000 oil pipeline from Midland, Tex., to Norwalk, Calif.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- The Navy announced today that thirty-nine captains, including Capt. William H. Leahy, son of Fleet Admiral William D. Leahy, retired, had been selected for promotion to rear admiral. The list was approved by President Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Following are excerpts from the testimony before the Senate Investigations Subcommittee inquiry into activities of Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force:
BERLIN, July 25 (UP) -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, first secretary of the Soviet Communist party, said today of the Geneva conference that "both sides won the conviction that neither side wants war."

HONG KONG, Tuesday, July 26 -- Communist China's official news agency declared today there was now "every reason to demand" that the questions of Formosa and Peiping's entry into the United Nations should be settled by consultation "in accordance with the spirit of Geneva."

JERSEY CITY, July 25 -- A 5,000-pound shipment of frozen shrimp from Karachi, capital of Pakistan, was unloaded today from the American President liner President Monroe, which docked here yesterday. It was the first shipment of frozen shrimp from that country to the United States.
Albert J. Messler's War Command sprang to the front at the start and stayed there all the way to win the mile-and-a-sixteenth feature race at Jamaica yesterday.
Gene Poirier, Niagara Falls (N. Y.) welterweight, gained a unanimous decision over Danny Jo Perez of New York in a ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

Enkells-Rakoff Co., real estate operators, have contracted to buy the five-story apartment house at 2463 Valentine Avenue in the Bronx from Louis Cella for cash over mortgages of $100,000. The building contains twenty-five suites and three stores.
This land of plenty is short one very important commodity -- working girls.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Army plans to arrest three turncoat prisoners of war, barring a possible high-level veto, when they arrive in San Francisco on Friday.
President Eisenhower's Committee on Government Contracts has been asked to order a clause banning job discrimination in all contracts between the Government and the country's air lines.

" NUTRITION and Healthy Growth," a new pamphlet issued by the Children's Bureau of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, tells mothers what foods youngsters need from infancy through adolescence. The emphasis is more on the physical than on the psychological aspects of feeding.
The weather yesterday was more for enjoyment than conversation. But for today, the local Weather Bureau has promised more material for small talk -- a high near 90 degrees.

The Geneva conference is over and the world is still trying to assess its meaning and its potential effects. From our Government's point of view this assessment was made last night by President Eisenhower when he said that Geneva ignited a spark for a whole new series of conferences with the Soviets designed to solve the problems that Geneva did not solve and was not intended to solve.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 25 -- Greece proposed today that the United Nations General Assembly take up again the question of equal rights and self-determination for the people of Cyprus. The island in the eastern Mediterranean is under British colonial rule.
City Hall political circles speculated yesterday over who would be the new Police Commissioner.
Sixty-thousand cubic centimeters of Salk anti-polio vaccine, the first to be sent to the city under the new Federal safety regulations, arrived last night.

LONDON, July 25 (Reuters) -- The British Government announced today it would sell two destroyers to Egypt to "preserve a balance" -- presumably with two destroyers sold to Israel earlier in the month.

Billy Pierce of the Chicago White Sox and Robin Roberts of the Philadelphia Phillies, the starting pitchers in baseball's All-Star game earlier this month, have taken over the major league earned run leads as the season closes in on the two-thirds mark.

An eyewitness account of the bombing of Hiroshima will be published by the University of North Carolina Press on Aug. 6, the tenth anniversary of the occasion. "Hiroshima Dairy" is written by Dr. Michihiko Hachiya, the director of the Hiroshima Communications Hospital, who was wounded in the blast and whose hospital was gutted by the fire that followed.

Balked in their effort to enact any type of Federal civil rights law, proponents of such measures have been giving increased attention to state legislatures. This year's crop of state civil rights laws is a bumper one.
Retailers will lay in slightly heavier stocks of curtains, draperies, linens and domestics for the fall seson in hopes of improving last year's sluggish sales pattern.
I enjoyed reading your editorial on the summer schools which outlined the activities of the Board of Education to provide wholesome recreation for our children.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Rice growers and corn millers gave a House Agriculture subcommittee conflicting recommendations today on how to handle acreage allotments for the 1956 rice crop.
JERUSALEM, July 25 -- Israel's 1,000,000 voters will elect parties tomorrow to govern the country for the next four years. Balloting will go on until 11 P. M. [4 P. M. Eastern daylight time].

The people of Franklin, N. H., have not always been, as Kathleen Teltsch reports to this newspaper, "particularly United Nations-minded." They have been inclined to be "a little bit critical," so Miss Teltsch was told by Roy T. Barnhill, a New York publisher now sojourning among them.

Vinton Hayworth, TV and radio actor, has submitted his resignation as a member of the national and New York boards of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, A. F. L. The two groups are expected to take up the matter at meetings this week.
NEW DELHI, India, July 25 -- India ordered the Portuguese today to close their legation in New Delhi by Aug. 8.
In a market that saw long gains for a handful of issues, stocks yesterday had their fourth successive day of advancing prices. Volume was the same as on Friday, 2,500,000 shares.

The title of your editorial in The Times of July 20, "Insuring Every Auto," very well expresses, it seems to me, the idea you sponsor that every car appearing on the public roads should carry insurance.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman accused the Administration today of "perverting" Federal regulatory agencies.

TWENTY - NINE PALMS, Calif., July 25 (UP) -- An "irregularity" of more than $600,000 forced the closing today of this desert community's only bank. Its vice president was arrested at Del Mar race track on embezzlement charges.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Maritime Administration announced today that as of July 1, employment of seamen and use of vessels were showing improvement.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 25 -- Louis de Rochemont has changed his mind about joining a major studio in producing "The Cardinal," based on the novel by Henry Morton Robinson. He will make and release the film through his own organization, Louis de Rochemont Associates.

The appointment of Dr. Harold W. Stoke as dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences of New York University was announced yesterday. He will also be chairman of the graduate commission and Professor of Government.
CHICAGO, July 25 -- The directors of the Peabody Coal Company of Chicago today elected Otto Gressens chairman and L. Russell Kelce president.
A record volume of $36,800,000,000 in United States foreign trade this year was predicted yesterday by a major trade organization.
Earnings of two cigarette companies in the first half of this year were below those a year before, according to their reports issued for publication today.
The Yankees, back on top in the American League pennant chase, will open a seventeen-game home stand tonight against the Chicago White Sox at the Stadium.
The nation's airlines are enjoying a boom in passenger travel that shows no signs of abating.

Open hearings may be held on bill before Congress to require that ships at sea report their position by radio every twenty-four hours. Representative Daniel J. Flood, Democrat of Pennsylvania, has requested that the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee schedule such hearings.
PARIS, July 25 -- Officials in closest touch with French diplomacy fear the almost world-wide optimism about the Geneva conference may lead to disappointment.

Your recent editorial in support of the proposed compulsory installation of central heating in all tenement houses of ten families or over contained several major errors. You stated that the cost would average $8,000 per building, or $800 per apartment, and intimated that rents should not be unduly raised in order to amortize the cost of this "permanent improvement" in value.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- Senator Sparkman, in his charge today, referred to testimony that Sherman Adams, Presidential assistant, requested a recess in the commission hearings last month when the agency was studying financial plans for the controversial Dixon-Yates private power project.

ROME, N. Y., July 25 (AP) -- President Eisenhower was asked today to invoke the sixty-day cooling-off provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law in the strike against copper-producing industries in the western states.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 25 (UP) -- A general conference of the Latin-American hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church convened here today under the chairmanship of Adeodatto Cardinal Piazza, representing Pope Pius XII.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 25 (AP) -- The Glory Bea of Detroit was the over-all winner today of the Port Huron-to-Mackinac 243-mile yacht race.

Brazil's and Colombia's share of the United States coffee market dwindled during the first six months of this year. Despite a decrease in total imports by the United States, other producing nations increased their shipments.
DETROIT, July 25 (UP) -- An anti-Communist from the only Communist-dominated country west of the Iron Curtain brought her homeland's political campaign to the heart of the United States today.

BUENOS AIRES, July 25 -- The Peronist party asked President Juan D. Peron today to break his promise to the nation and remain as chieftain of the revolutionary movement he has headed for more than a decade.

Plans have been made at recent meetings for a dinner dance in behalf of the Camp Fire Girls to be held on the night of Oct. 24 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Whitelaw Reid is president of Camp Fire Girls Council of Greater New York, Inc. Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel is honorary chairman of the dinner dance.

LONDON, July 25 -- The big twelve of London fashions, members of the Incorporated Society of London Fashion Designers, launched their autumn collections today with shows at Norman Hartnell, John Cavanagh, Mattli and Worth.
Leonard Bernstein will lead the Symphony of the Air in six subscription concerts at Carnegie Hall during the coming season.
International conferences on atomic energy, disarmament and world organization are getting to be routine accompaniments to efforts of the great powers to negotiate a peace treaty in the cold war.

India's Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, is taking a courageous course on the explosive issue of the disposition of the Portuguese holding of Goa on the Indian subcontinent. In the face of strong domestic pressure he has set himself against any display of violence, overt or concealed, and has insisted that the means of settlement must be legal and peaceful.

The work of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York will be furthered by a theatre party. Mrs. Herbert L. Carlebach, benefit chairman, has announced that the organization has taken over the Dec. 7 performance of "Janus" by Carolyn Green in which Margaret Sullavan, Claude Dauphin and Robert Preston have the leading roles.

BABYLON, L. I., July 25 -- A Long Island State Parkway patrolman, suspended July 12 for refusing to void three summonses he had given a news photographer, received a departmental reprimand here today. However full pay was awarded to him for the time he was under suspension.
COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., July 25 -- Joe DiMaggio scored his crowning baseball triumph today.
Masonic membership in England is at a new high and is still growing, Maj. Gen. Sir Allan Adair, assistant grand master of the Grand Lodge in England, said yesterday.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 25 -- Mohammed Ayub Khuhro, Chief Minister of Sind Province, wanted to be elected from his home district to a vacancy in the Provincial Assembly. Complying with the election rules, he filed nomination papers last Thursday with the district authorities.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had increased to the highest point in more than a year and a half.
TAIPEI, Formosa, July 25 -- Twenty-nine crewmembers of the Soviet tanker Tuapse, captured by the Chinese Nationalist Navy almost thirteen months ago, are returning to their homeland.
LEWES, Del., July 25 (AP) -- Rescued after a night of clinging to a swamped boat in storm-tossed Delaware Bay, two men and their wives were in a hospital today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 25 -- A political vacuum prevailed today in the Government of Indonesia. It may result in the postponement of the Parliamentary elections now scheduled for Sept. 29.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 25 -- Sons of cannoneers who served under Lieut. Col. William Gray of Boston in World War II will share in a Harvard College scholarship established in his memory by members of the battery he commanded.
LEXINGTON, Ky., July 25 (AP) -- An Alibhai filly brought $34,000 today, top price for the eighty-eight thoroughbred yearlings sold at the first session of the Keeneland summer sales.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Senate authorized today the appointment of a twelve-member special watchdog committee on disarmament.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WEST CHESTER, Pa., July 25 -- Chester County Judge Ernest Harvey reversed today an earlier decision in a case involving attempts of the Commonwealth of Peennsylvania to collect inheritance taxes from the estate of the late Pierre S. du Pont.

Florida's Governor described his state's balmy business climate yesterday before a group of Northern business men. "We in Florida have no state income tax, individual or corpo rate," Gov. LeRoy Collins said at a luncheon given at the Hanover Bank by its president, R. E. McNeill Jr.

The Long Island Rail Road was threatened yesterday with a strike of 1,500 trainmen next week. However, the peace provisions of the Railway Labor Act seemed likely to delay any walkout for six to sixteen weeks.

DETROIT, July 25 (AP) -- The General Motors Corporation today reported a record number of employes and a peak payroll during both the second quarter and the first half of 1955. G. M. said its world-wide employment averaged 624,954 and its payrolls totaled $1,563,000,000 in the six months.
LONDON, July 25 -- R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer. announced today a new series of restrictions on credit designed to reduce consumption and increase exports.

AGAINST the background of the mechanical gate, the starter at thoroughbred racing tracks is seldom noticed by the crowd. To many of the spectators he is just a button-pusher sending the horses on their way.
Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, independent, declared yesterday his union was preparing court action against the Waterfront Commission.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 25 (AP) -- Texas Democrats today ousted Wright Morrow as National Committeeman in an apparent move to improve their standing in national party affairs. The session was marked by a clash between Mr. Morrow and Gov. Allan Shivers, his old political ally.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 25 (AP) -- Thomas F. O'Neil, president of General Teleradio, Inc., turned over a $25,000,000 check today to a representative of Howard Hughes to complete purchase of R. K. O. Pictures Corporation for Mr. O'Neil's extensive radio and television operations.
Stockholders of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company voted at a special meeting here yesterday to increase the authorized number of common shares outstanding from 1,700,000 to 3,000,000.
TAIPEI, Formosa, July 25 -- Nationalist China increased the selling prices of American-aid cotton and soybeans, effective today, about 37 and 25 per cent, respectively.

Sixteen well-traveled Boy Scouts and two adult leaders from eight European countries neared the end of their trail in the United States yesterday. They came back to New York after having spent five weeks in various parts of the country as guests of the Boy Scouts of America.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 25 (AP) -- Cliff Battles, a halfback at little West Virginia Wesleyan in 1929-31, was among the sixteen players and five coaches who were named today to football's. Hall of Fame.

The number of persons on public assistance increased by 303 in June, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy reported yesterday. The rise brought the total to 285,556. The amount of grants increased by $72,487, to a total of $12,692,598.
The police of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station had a "lost adult" on their hands for three hours yesterday.

This is "clean-up" time for automobile dealers. Late summer is the period when they traditionally try to dispose of current models in preparation for the new lines. This year, from all reports, the cleaning-up process is going to be an unusually tough one.
MUERREN, Switzerland, July 25 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer put the stamp of West German approval today on the results of the Geneva conference.
The Southern Pacific Company and its wholly owned, separately operated subsidiaries carried more than half of a $21,081,654 gain in gross revenues through to net income in the first half this year.
BONN, Germany, July 25 -- West German newspapers interpreted the results of the Geneva conference today as a setback to reunification and a defeat for the Chancellor's foreign policy.
A large estate in Ridgefield, Conn., and farmland in other parts of the state were involved in big realty deals recently made by Connecticut brokers.
The Chase Manhattan Bank, the country's second largest, yesterday suggested that the Government combine current revenues with borrowing to finance badly needed improvements in the highway system.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Eisenhower told the country tonight in a radio and television broadcast that the Big Four conference in Geneva had shown that the whole world wanted peace.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 25 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff and top state officials urged Connecticut parents today to "restrict" the use of family cars by their children unless they returned by midnight. Alarmed by the increase in "teen-age" highway fatalities, the Governor said parents had a "grave responsibility" in granting the use of their cars to children unless "they know where the children are going and when they are coming back."

FLORENCE, Italy, July 25 -- Guidi, the Italian designer, shows himself to be essentially a suit man in his fall and winter collections, which he calls "Tanagra." Straight and cut short in front, his suit jackets usually have bloused backs to a snug, low waistline belt and standaway collars.

The Military Reserve bill -- formally designated the Reserve Forces Act of 1955 -- is in the final stages of Congressional consideration. The House of Representatives approved the bill yesterday; the Senate is expected to act today.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Federal Housing Administration moved today to take over the Ed Donner Gardens apartment project in Queens, New York.

TRENTON, July 25 -- Many New Jersey crops have been damaged by the drought. Alvah W. Severson, market reporting and cooperatives chief, said today that the crops that had suffered most were potatoes, tomatoes and corn.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 25 (UP) -- An educator charged private colleges and universities today with failing to accept their share of steadily mounting enrollments.
Mayor Wagner gave a boost yesterday to a baseball game that will be played at the Polo Grounds Wednesday night, Aug. 3, between two teams of amputee veterans.
The staute of Simon Bolivar, who helped free much of South America from Spanish rule, was adorned yesterday with flowers in honor of the 172d anniversary of his birth.
THE week-end not only provided plenty of bluefish, school tuna and a scattering of white marlin for the salt water anglers, but offered unusual activity for those who turned to the bass lakes.
Upward adjustment of freight rates has been made by the Flota Mercante Grancolombiana because of the considerable increase in operating costs.
HARTFORD, July 25 -- A special election will be held in Connecticut tomorrow on a proposed constitutional amendment that would eliminate the need for special elections on constitutional questions.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver said today that a Congressional call for an international conference on Atlantic union "would electrify free men everywhere."
A last-minute change of conductors and programs took place at Lewisohn Stadium last night.
YANKTON, S. D., July 25 (UP) -- Army engineers began closing the Gavins Point Dam today, bringing to completion the fourth main dam on the Missouri River.

MONTE RIO, Calif., July 25 (UP) -- Former President Herbert Hoover described as a "master stroke" today President Eisenhower's challenge to the Soviet Union to exchange full military information with the United States.
NORTHVILLE, Mich., July 25 -- Doug Ford, the medalist, moved into the final round of the Professional Golfers Association championship today.

In the July issue of its Monthly Bulletin the Federal Reserve Board presents figures which, when added up, show that business and consumer credit have played a very important role in the newly evident prosperity of 1955. The Federal Reserve does not say in so many words that such credit has played a bigger part than it should in the incipient boom of recent months.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- Following is the text of a State Department statement today accompanying the announcement of talks at Geneva between the United States and Communist China:
The New York Central Railroad was accused yesterday of deliberately neglecting its commuter business on the west side of the Hudson River to create an excuse for ending service.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The United States and Communist China announced plans today for direct conversations by Ambassadors.
The city will outlaw unnecessary horn honking, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.

BABYLON, L. I., July 25 -- A fleet of 130 craft opened the 1955 Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual Cruise Week today. Conditions were only slightly below ideal, with a moderately strong south-easterly wind freshening up as the afternoon progressed.
Thirty per cent of a group of women's accessory and specialty stores surveyed by Dun Bradstreet reported unprofitable operations for 1954.
ELIZABETH, N. J., July 25 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner agreed today to join Federal, state and municipal officials in a conference here on low-flying airplanes.

SOME of the world's great makers of history are less colorful, less appealing and less interesting as individuals than many of their lesser contemporaries. How many educated people today know as much about William Cecil, first Baron Burghley, as they do about Francis Drake, who was a pirate; about Philip Sidney, who was a poet, or about Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester, and Robert Devereux, Earl of Essex, who were handsome courtiers and indifferent soldiers?

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 -- A loyalty oath required of California veterans seeking property tax exemptions was ruled legal here today by Superior Judge William T. Sweigert. He thus took issue with the Superior Court of Contra Costa County, whose five judges last Feb. 10 declared invalid the 1952 State constitutional amendment and its legislative implementation.
A noble experiment went slightly awry yesterday. The result was that the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue at Forty-second Street was shorn, temporarily, of its West Side identification.

A seventeen-inch television receiver to sell at less than $100 is being introduced in this market by the Hallicrafters Company, Chicago manufacturer of video sets, radios and high-fidelity equipment. Its product, described as a "first" for the industry, will sell for $99.95, housed in a textured spatter-toned mahogany cabinet.

FORT WILLIAM, Ont., July 25 (Canadian Press) -- C. J. Warwick Fox, president and general manager of the Great Lakes Paper Company, Ltd., announced today that his company had purchased Great Lakes Canadian, Inc., of New York, handlers of the company's sales for many years.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 25 -- The prospects of political harmony between the Malay and Chinese communities will be tested Wednesday in the multi-racial Federation of Malaya's first national election.
BOSTON, July 26 (AP) -- Frank Sullivan's stylish five-hit pitching, backed by home runs by Ted Williams and Sammy White, paced the Boston Red Sox to a 5-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.
BUENOS AIRES, July 26 -- Argentines closed up shop today as the nation observed the third anniversary of the death of Eva Peron.
New woes piled up yesterday for Harry Lev, much-investigated Chicago cap manufacturer.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The most powerful of President Eisenhower's foreign-policy backers in the Senate are pressing for a major meeting between the United States and Communist China. They seem to have every prospect of success
MOSCOW, July 26 (AP) -- Pravda and Izvestia, the big guns of the Soviet press, warned Communist party functionaries today to go to farms and spur farmers to better production.

Prisoners in the workhouse and penitentiary on Rikers Island will be among the donors today to the New York Regional Blood Program. In the last five years, Red Cross spokesmen said, the prison population on the island has contributed more than 5,000 pints of blood.

The Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn is supplying Mortgage financing totaling about $2,000,000 for a section of 115 dwellings in Seaview Village being built by Waxman Brothers at Rockaway Parkway and Avenue M. Brooklyn.

There are occasions, though happily they do not occur often, when Yogi Berra, the American League's premier catcher, suffers extraordinary lapses behind the plate. But at such odd moments, Yogi, as a batsman, is perhaps never more dangerous.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The House of Representatives voted, 178 to 89, tonight against attempting a highway expansion program without specifying any method of paying for it.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 26 -- The United States paid today its 1955 assessment for the regular budget of the United Nations. A check for $13,212,012 was handed to Andrew W. Cordier, executive assistant to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, by James J. Wadsworth, deputy United States representative to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Following are excerpts from the testimony before the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee inquiry into activities of Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force:
HARTFORD, Conn., July 28 -- Connecticut voters decided today to eliminate special elections on proposed constitutional amendments.

CLEVELAND, July 26 (AP) -- Cyrus S. Eaton, the industrialist, will be host beginning on Monday to an international group of intellectuals at his summer home in Pugwash, N. S. For two weeks men of science, education and business will gather to think and exchange their views.
The Internal Revenue Director for Brooklyn and Long Island filed tax liens totaling $5,013,426 yesterday against Frank Erickson, the gambler, and his wife.
A private consulting chemist reported here yesterday that he had detected high levels of sewage pollution in beach waters near Coney Island.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 26 -- Alan Gilison of West Hempstead led the way into the semi-final round of the Long Island Golf Association junior and boys' championships at Cherry Valley today.
Jean Cocteau's psychological detective play, "The Typewriter," will be performed here for the first time at 8 o'clock this evening.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 26 -- The Soviet Union is reported trying to undermine the West's confidence in Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Following are excerpts from remarks by Secretary of State Dulles at his news conference today on coming United States talks with Communist China and last week's Big Four conference in Geneva:

The United States Steel Corporation announced four new records yesterday. Its sales, net earnings and shipments reached new high levels in the second quarter this year, and its profits for the first half were the best in its history.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Congress completed action today on the long-disputed plan to build the present 800,000 trained and ready military Reserve to 2,900,000.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- The Senate approved tonight by voice vote a $1,830,078,614 supplemental appropriations bill with funds for a variety of items from poliomyelitis vaccine shots to the new Air Force Academy at Colorado Springs.
OTTAWA, July 26 -- Canada's powerful atomic energy reactor will be out of action for several weeks as a result of a mishap yesterday.
The hot weather drove consumption of city water to a new seasonal high last week -- an average of 1,278,000,000 gallons a day.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Two plane loads of European air cadets arrived today at Andrews Air Force Base. The ninety youths will begin a two-and-a-half-week tour of United States air installations.
The Military Reserve bill, passed by the Senate yesterday and thus finally approved by Congress, provides for three to six months of active duty training for no more than 250,000 young men annually.
BOSTON, July 26 -- Representatives of Southern New England truckers and of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters prepared tonight to sit for hours in an effort to settle a forty-one-day strike.

FLORENCE, Italy, July 26 -- The Italian fashion showings ended last night in a swirl of riotous romanticism with the fall-winter collection of the designer Schuberth. His was undoubtedly the most controversial show of all but everyone will remember it.
PARIS, July 26 -- Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, said today France was considering recognizing Communist China but would not do it without her Western Allies.
The new owners of R. K. O.-Radio Pictures, Inc., said yesterday that existing plans call for emphasis on the production and distribution of theatrical motion pictures.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Temperament, training and circumstances have combined to put U. Alexis Johnson in charge of United States negotiations with Communist China at Geneva next Monday.

The Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler trophy, for outstanding marksmanship among members of the Seventy-seventh Infantry Reserve Division, has been awarded to Maj. Paul S. Graziano, judge advocate general of the division.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- George V. McDavitt, security chief of the Small Business Administration, has been dismissed under heavy criticism by a Senate security investigation.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- Sponsors of a bill to authorize a vast reclamation project in the upper Colorado Basin decided today to put off the legislation until next year rather than face "certain defeat."
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Government today tightened quotas and other restrictions governing the export of copper in order to conserve supplies for domestic use.
Insurgent Democrats won endorsements in five Tammany district leadership contests last night at a city-wide meeting of the New York Young Democratic Club.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Several House members threatened today to "stay until Christmas" if necessary to defeat Senate plans to restore more than $500,000,000 to the foreign aid appropriation.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- Surgeon General Leonard A. Scheele said today enough Salk polio vaccine would be available by next spring to inoculate all Americans under 20 years of age.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 26 -- Pope Pius XII has urged the Roman Catholic clergy of Latin America to adapt themselves better to the modern world by intensifying their work for the solution of social problems.

IN the early morning on Sept. 16, 1878, a frightening rumble and clatter outside the window awakened a five-year-old boy in his bedroom over Lyman G. Bloomingdale's hoop skirt and ladies' notions shop on Third Avenue between Fifty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Streets.

Waterfront Commission findings against 141 longshoremen who had been involved in the port-wide strike that started March 4, 1954, were rejected by the men's union last night. The action was taken at a meeting of the New York District Council.

J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., a leading textiles concern, announced yesterday that it was sending two executives to Japan to appraise that country's textile industry in light of impending United States tariff cuts.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Wednesday, July 27 -- Between 75 and 80 per cent of the eligible voters went to the polls yesterday in the third national Israeli elections. The figure was set in an unofficial estimate of the Central Elections Committee.
Legislation containing $60,000,000 for ship construction subsidies is going to get a second chance.

Edmar Mednis of New York and D. K. Keller of Switzerland, competing in Section 3 of the tournament for the junior world chess championship in Antwerp, drew in a sixth round match, according to a report received yesterday through Belgian news sources.

GLEN COVE, July 26 -- Mrs. William Tracy, Essex Fells, and Miss Charlotte DeCozen, Montclair, gained the semi-finals of the Women's Metropolitan best-ball championship at the Nassau Country Club today.

Coffee prices rose as much as the 2-cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday during trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Profit taking late in the day reduced the gain. Volume was the fifth largest of the year and the heaviest since Feb. 17.

OZAN MARSH, California pianist, who has given four New York recitals, last night made his first appearance at the Lewisohn Stadium. His playing of Liszt's "Todtentanz" brought a flash of life to an otherwise pedestrian program.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- A little known incident of the Korean prisoner exchange has provided the Army with an unusual charge against at least two of the three American turncoats who are coming home. The three will be arrested when their ship reaches San Francisco Friday.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- This Federal District -- language butcher of the English-speaking world -- offered "urbiculture" to the mother tongue today.

TOKYO, July 26 (AP) -- A representative of seven big publishing concerns said today he has halted Japanese pirating of United States scientific books costing $150,000 to $200,000 in revenues annually.
Charles H. Tuttle, chairman of the Metropolitan Transit Commission, warned yesterday against "the rapid deterioration of rapid transit" in the metropolitan area.
Eleven men, all paraplegics and employes of Pan American World Airways, left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 3:35 P. M. yesterday on a plane for London.

LAURENS, Iowa, July 26 -- An attempt was made today to explain the United States system of farm price supports to the Russian agricultural delegation touring Iowa. But there was no evidence of success.
THE second of the "Evenings-by-the-River" concerts presented by the Lower East Side Neighborhoods Association drew a near-capacity audience to the East River Park Amphitheatre last night.

PARIS, July 26 -- As cold war tensions subside in Europe the position of Italy is bound to give concern. Neutralism is growing. The new affability between two neighbors -- Yugoslavia and Austria -- and the Soviet Union has had repercussions.

BONN, Germany, July 26 (AP) -- Hans Speidel and Adolf Heusinger, former German Army generals, will become the highest ranking generals of the new West German Amy. The Security Committee of the Bundestag announced the appointments tonight.
ALBANY, July 26 -- The New York Telephone Company's campaign for a rate increase was countered today by a request that rates be reduced immediately by $31,800,000.

The Manhattan Beach Air Force station vibrated yesterday to the sound of hammers driving nails into planking for new floors. This activity was all part of the Dependents Assistance Program, which aims at making Air Force personnel and their families feel that they really have found a home here.

LONDON, July 26 -- An improvement in sterling, following Chancellor R. A. Butler's remarks yesterday on measures to improve Britain's balance of payments, led to a late rally today in Government stocks. Long before the Chancellor's further statement today, buying orders for sterling had been coming in from both America and the Continent.
Bingo, which has been more or less prohibited by the police in New York since last fall, is apparently operating again -- although anonymously, and legally -- in Brooklyn.
ODESSA, U. S. S. R., July 26 -- Trofim Lysenko's controversial theories on plant genetics are now being applied by all seventy plant breeding stations of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- The Government reported today that United States manufacturing corporations made higher profits, after taxes, during the first quarter of 1955 than for any quarter in four years.
The stock market had an erratic day yesterday, opening mixed, sagging toward midday, regaining its losses in the early afternoon and then selling off at the close. Net changes were small.

The American Tobacco Company, Inc., realized an increase of 16.7 per cent in its half-year earnings on a sales gain of 3 per cent over the period a year ago. This was made known in the semi-annual report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Ross Rizley, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board said today that the State Department had "persuaded" his agency to go along with an agreement giving a West German airline the right to compete with United States companies for trans-Atlantic and Latin-American business.

Five deck officers of the United States Lines, including Capt. L. J. Alexanderson, relief master of the America, have been named to take the giant carrier Forrestal to sea next month on her first trial run.
The Soviet consumer appears to be back in his accustomed place at the end of the line after a brief spell of better luck under former Premier Georgi M. Malenkov.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 26 -- A new antibiotic was reported today at the fourteenth International Conference of Pure and Applied Chemistry. Test-tube 'studies have shown it to be highly active against many fungi and to inhibit the growth of certain bacteria as well as of two types of bacterial viruses.

FLORAL PARK, L. I., July 26 (AP) -- State Senator Edward P. Larkin announced today that nine organizations and forty individuals had been subpoenaed in an investigation of alleged Communist influence in children's summer camps.
LONDON, July 26 -- R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today that the credit restrictions he announced yesterday were not a result of any economic crisis.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby advised the Senate Finance Committee today to take a long look before acting on the increased Social Security benefits rushed through the House of Representatives last week.

ALBANY, July 26 -- New York farmers, desperate over their parched crops, received gloomy news today from the Weather Bureau. Thunder showers by the week-end, fore casters said, but there is no sign of a soaking downpour to break a two-month siege of hot, dry weather.

IT is not every day that Yehudi Menuhin, the violinist, can be seen and heard on television. For that reason alone last night's presentation of the Stan Kenton program "Music '55" was decidedly worth tuning in (8:30 on Channel 2).

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 26 -- Asian, Arab and African delegates refused today to sponsor a charge that Britain had committed genocide against the Kikuyu people in the British colony of Kenya. Anti-British Mau Mau groups have been recruited from the Kikuyu.

United Newspapers Magazine Corporation, publisher of This Week Sunday supplement, has leased the thirteenth floor in the thirty-story building under construction at 485 Lexington Avenue. The company's main office now is at 420 Lexington Avenue.

After an ownership of almost two months, the building at 673 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of Sixty-first Street, has been resold by John McGrath to a client represented by I. Jerome Riker. It formerly was owned by the Shaffer family, which conducted a meat market there for many years.
BAY SHORE, L. I., July 26 -- Stan Ogilvy's Flame began the defense of the Corry Trophy, emblematic of Great South Bay, Star Class supremacy, by capturing the opening race of the series today.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Consumer Price Index rose 0.2 per cent from mid-May to mid-June.
The Kaiser Steel Corporation announced yesterday purchase of what it described as the largest single area of coal land in the United States.

Reflecting the record volume of sales in the first half of this year, the net income of the Union Bag and Paper Corporation increased to $7,155,294 from $5.479,365 earned in the initial six months of 1954.
A 37-year-old man was killed yesterday when he was thrown from a car that collided with a Brooklyn bus and fell under the bus wheels.
The State Liquor Authority thinks that New York City may have reached the saturation point in restaurants licensed to sell wine and liquor.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 26 -- The Russian Government will lend a helping hand to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in the filming of "Lust for Life," the biography of the Dutch painter Vincent Van Gogh.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that he did not exclude the possibility of negotiations between himself and Chou En-lai, Communist Chinese Premier and Foreign Minister.
TUNIS, Tunisia, July 26 -- A twenty-four-hour general strike ordered here by the Trade Union Federation for Aug. 10 is expected to be a test for Tunisia's Nationalist Government.
TIJUANA, Mexico, July 26 -- President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines opened an industrial fair here today with a plea for economic integration.
ALBANY, July 26 (AP) -- New York State's temporary Highway Finance Planning Commission voiced opposition today to any increase in Federal motor fuel taxes to finance a Federal road-building program.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Some three and a half hours after they had gained a 5-0 lead over the Cubs in the first inning, the Giants posted a 6-5 decision with an unearned run in the twelfth today at Wrigley Field.
A large apartment property on the upper East Side soon will be modernized into small units as a result of a sale of the property by Donald M. Hyman Co. to Herbert Hersh Enterprises, Inc.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Wednesday, July 27 -- Special police precautions are being taken to guard against any attempt by Malaya's Communist rebels to disrupt the polling today. For the first time the Federation is choosing an elected majority in the Legislative Council.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 26 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Paul E. Bishop of Minneapolis, president of the Northwest Synod, United Lutheran Church in America, said today the Rev. George Christ Jr. of Durham, Wis., would go on trial in Milwaukee tomorrow on heresy charges. It will be the first such trial in the sixty-five-year history of the church.
Three programs of the Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood, Lenox, Mass., have been revised because 'cellist Gregor Piatigorsky, the scheduled soloist, is unable to appear.
LEEDS, England, July 26 (Reuters) -- South Africa gained a 244-run victory over England today to even their current cricket test series at two matches apiece.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Here is how the Military Reserves program will work for the main categories of young men, trained and untrained:
A vice president of the Community Service Society, Mrs. Garret J. Garretson 2d, has been named women's committee chairman of a campaign to raise $1,000,000 in support of the agency.

The status of Africa today is the subject of two books to be published during the fall. Roy Publishers will issue on Sept. 19 "Pan-Africanism or Communism," by George Padmore, an evaluation of the rise of nationalism in Africa.

Appeals to civic organizations and citizens to urge the Board of Estimate to assign the site of the defunct Neponsit Beach Hospital as a public bathing beach were made yesterday by directors of the Park Association of New York City.

The State Supreme Court heard arguments yesterday on a petition for an order directing the city's Budget Director to provide more than $94,000 for increases for 400 employes of the city's court system.

A New York Times report quotes Premier Bulganin's criticism of Soviet industrial leaders for failing to keep abreast of United States technological advances. And he demands closer scrutiny and study of foreign technical achievement to overcome deficiences in textile, shoe, printing, food and chemical production.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Wheat prices held in a narrow range today with some support on price dips but little buying on rallies. Coarse grains were inclined to sag at times, but on the whole showed a fairly steady tone.

NORTHVILLE, Mich., July 26 -- Doug Ford, the Professional Golfers Association national champion, accepted his new honor graciously today. "This brings to an end my best stretch of golf," he commented.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Treasury today announced that all but $147,000,000 of the $8,477,000,000 in debt certificates maturing Aug. 15 had been exchanged for the new 2 per cent securities offered last week.
The Jacob Ruppert Brewery is planning a splash in most media, including airplane streamers, to call attention to a $50,000 give-away program for its Knickerbocker beer.
PALO ALTO, Calif., July 26 (AP) -- Sumner H. Slichter, Harvard University economist, said today that neither big business nor the recent rash of mergers is to be feared.
Price-fixing in the $15,000,000-a - year Austrian imitation precious stones industry in this country was ended by court order yesterday.

Record earnings were reported yesterday by three leading oil companies in semi-annual statements covering the six months ended on June 30. Directors of the Gulf Oil Corporation at the same time increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock by 12 1/2 cents.
Troops at Fort Jay, Governors Island, will tender the retreat parade today to one of the most decorated officers in the Medical Corps.

"Son of Sinbad," an R. K. O. adventure in Superscope and color with Dale Robertson, Sally Forrest, Lili St. Cyr and Vincent Price, is today's new film at the Globe. Robert Sparks produced and Ted Tetzlaff directed, from a screen play by Aubrey Wisberg and Jack Pollexfen.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 26 -- Justice Townsend Scudder, retired, today celebrated his ninetieth birthday in quiet conversation with his family and a few friends.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, July 27 -- The second anniversary of the armistice that ended the Korean war finds South Korea discontented and fearful. But its economic outlook has improved.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Senate-House Atomic Energy Committee asked members of the Atomic Energy Commission today why a utility official who visited the commission seventy-three times last year had been omitted from Dixon-Yates contract chronologies issued by the Administration.
Stations WRCA and WRCA-TV will produce a series of programs on juvenile delinquency in cooperation with the New York City Youth Board.
HONG KONG, July 26 -- Twenty-nine lens-shy members of the crew of the seized Soviet tanker Tuapse arrived here today by air from Formosa on their way home as released repatriates.

BASEBALL, 'tis said, is a pretty rough and tumble game without much heart. No one worries how the fellow at the rear end of the line is doing, except on days when he plays in your home lot and fails to draw flies. It is a highly commercialized product. Some even refer to it as strictly "big business."

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- The House Rules Committee today cleared for House action a controversial bill to exempt independent natural gas producers from regulation by the Federal Power Commission. Rules Chairman Howard W. Smith, Democrat of Virginia, said he understood the House would act on the measure tomorrow if it passed the Highway Bill tonight.

Shipbuilders in the main maritime centers of the world have contracts for more than 12,000,000 gross tons of passenger and cargo vessels, according to Walter L. Green, chairman of the board and president of the American Bureau of Shipping.
LONDON, July 26 -- Now that eight of the big twelve fashion houses here have shown their autumn collections, one thing is certain: there is no civil war among the London designers.
SAN JUAN, P. R., July 26 -- Operating under the laws of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico is a World Research Center for the Blind.

NORTHVILLE, Mich., July 26 -- Doug Ford successfully completed his first bid for the Professional Golfers Association national championship today. The 32-year-old golfer, who carried off the medalist honors last Thursday at the Meadowbrook Country Club Course, defeated Cary Middlecoff in the final.

WASHINGTON, July 26---Former Secretary of State Corder Hull was laid to rest today in that space beneath Washington's National Cathedral reserved for those who have "given service of an outstanding nature to God and mankind."

NORFOLK, Va., July 26 -- Vice Admiral John W. M. Eaton of the British Navy has been designated as the new Deputy Supreme Allied Commander in the Atlantic. In October he will succeed Vice Admiral Sir John F. Stevens of Britain, who has served in that capacity since October, 1953.

Gotham Hosiery Company and Chadbourn Hosiery Mills have agreed to merge into a new company to be known as Chadbourn Gotham, Inc. The companies' respective boards approved the merger yesterday, for submission to stockholders in mid-September.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Political quarters reported tonight strong indications that the resignation of Harold E. Talbott as Secretary of the Air Force might be imminent.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- A former champion and the 1954 runner-up were defeated in the first round of the fifty-fifth women's Western amateur golf tournament today.

On July 17 you printed a letter signed by ten senior social scientists commenting on the various proposals now before the Senate to change the method of electing our President and Vice President. Your columns on June 22 had already graciously printed a rather lengthy letter by me setting forth my views on the question, which was apparently not read by the ten authors.
The city's second roving fire squad will begin operating next Monday, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. announced yesterday.
CINCINNATI, July 26 -- Big Don Newcombe gained his seventeenth triumph tonight as the Dodgers beat the Redlegs, 4 -- 2, in the sweltering heat of Crosley Field.

Net income of the Southern Railway last month was double that of June, 1954, although gross revenues rose only 16.8 per cent. The road's six months' income statement, issued yesterday, showed earnings of $3,714,438 for June, compared with $1,785,952 for the same month last year.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Pentagon reported to Congress today it had learned the fate of 474 United States servicemen missing at the end of the Korean war, but had been unable to account for 470 others.

If his words were meant seriously, then we welcome Nikita S. Khrushchev's declaration that at Geneva "both sides won the conviction that neither side wants war." The First Secretary of the Communist party of the Soviet Union is probably the most important single person in that country.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The danger of war between the East and the West has been pushed back by the Geneva conference, in the view of Secretary of State Dulles.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The nomination of Newell Brown of New Hampshire to be Wage and Hour Administrator was opposed by organized labor today. It was asserted tha he was a low-wage advocate and lobbied in Congress at Federal expense.

The enemies of public and quasi-public housing base their objections on two principal grounds. They say that public housing stifles private initiative in the housing field and forces it into other channels. They also assert that the whole idea of public housing is socialistic and is symptomatic -- as well as causative -- of the "creeping socialism" manifestations which are said to afflict the nation.
The Hospitalized Veterans Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund will benefit from Five Enchanted Theatre Evenings and Five Enchanted Musical Evenings during the 1955-56 season.
The city will have to invest at least $5,000,000 in new buses if the Transit Authority does not find a buyer for the municipally owned bus and trolley lines by Nov. 1.

Eight hundred persons went out in the noonday sun in the financial district yesterday to attend the sixth in a series of two-hour concerts in Battery Park. Many office workers ate their lunch outdoors to music of the fifty-piece Brooklyn Post Office Band.

Plans for a group of apartment buildings to house 500 families have been announced by the Lefrak Organization, builders, who have purchased for the purpose a plot on Eightieth Street, near Broadway, in the Elmhurst section of Queens.

There is a modern musical on Broadway called "Damn Yankees" that was written over three hundred years ago. And if anyone who has seen the play should wonder if the Yankees were winning pennants long before our Republic was formed, we might mention that "Damn Yankees" is a new story with a very old plot.
MANILA, Wednesday, July 27 -- President Ramon Magsaysay broke politically yesterday with Senator Claro M. Recto, a leading figure of the old guard in his Nationalist party.

At a cost that is relatively trifling; the United States has been showing the world in the past year that we respect the values of the mind and heart. We have sent orchestras, ballet troupes and theatrical companies to Europe, South America and Asia.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Alex Kellner and Tom Gorman combined to restrict Washington to seven hits as the Athletics won the second game of a double-header, 3 -- 1, tonight.

The new conference which will begin in Geneva on Monday is in part a continuation of previous contacts between the United States and Communist China on the liberation of the American prisoners. But in the broader scope envisaged for it, it is also a result of Premier Chou En-lai's bid for direct negotiations with the United States made last April at Bandung.

TAIPEI, Formosa, July 26 -- Nationalist China gave begrudged and pointedly qualified blessings today to the forthcoming talks between the United States and Communist China on the release of Americans imprisoned by Peiping.

STRATFORD, Conn., July 26 -- The American Shakespeare Festival Theatre introduced "The Tempest" into its repertoire here tonight. The fantasy joined "Julius Caesar," with which the theatre was inaugurated two weeks ago. Henceforth, it will alternate with the drama about politics in ancient Rome until the conclusion of the season on Sept. 3.

Several thousand Brooklynites who still use trolleys to get to work were delayed yesterday morning. A trolley on one of Brooklyn's three remaining lines crashed into the rear of a car on another line, causing tie-ups on four tracks.
A special award for his work in behalf of oppressed Jews in Europe was presented yesterday to Simon H. Rifkind, former Federal Judge and at present a member of the Board of Higher Education.
PARIS, July 26 -- The French National Assembly attempted today to cut down on absenteeism. It took action to require that Deputies be present in the building to vote on certain important questions.

An underwriting group headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. will offer to the public today a new issue of $35,000,000 of Container Corporation of America 3.30 per cent sinking fund debentures, due on July 1, 1980. The debentures are priced at par and accrued interest.
WATERTOWN, Conn., July 26 (AP) -- The man who is supposed to help bring new industry into Connecticut said today he was planning to move out a division of his own company.
WITH the National Matches only a few weeks off, Remington has brought out a fine, .22 caliber match rifle with several features that should appeal to the dedicated target shooter.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- A subcommittee of the Senate Public Works Committee approved today construction, under a lease-purchase agreement, of a $3,300,000 building in New York City to accommodate the United States mission to the United Nations.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Yesterday, like Monday, was an intermediate day for the heat wave, with the mercury rising only to the middle eighties.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 26 -- The first efforts to form a caretaker Cabinet to govern Indonesia during the critical election period were made today. There was a wide divergence of views.
For the first time in many years New York will play host to a visiting cruise vessel whose passengers will use the ship as a hotel while in port.

LONDON, July 26 -- The Soviet Union has promised to free sixteen Japanese. It says they have served out their sentences of imprisonment and may return to their homeland for the first time since World War II.

The Bulova Watch Company announced yesterday that it had arranged to acquire the one-fourth interest in Tiffany Co., Fifth Avenue jewelers, now held by Irving Maidman, real estate investor and builder.
"Nice pitchin'," said Casey Stengel by way of greeting Tommy Byrne after the Yankee southpaw's 1 -- 0 victory over the White Sox last night.

The recent publication in The Times of a letter, signed by Marshall N. Dana, Glenn R. Phillips, William S. Nelson, Charles J. Turck and Ralph W. Sockman, concerning the Arab refugee settlement, was of particular interest in so far as it referred to the Refugee Relief Act.

BEST customers for bottled melba sauce are French-trained chefs who use the raspberry concoction with the wonderfully true fruit flavor in many desserts. These professionals buy the sauce by the gallon. But the six-ounce and eight-ounce jars in retail stores are what the trade describes as "slow movers," that is, they just don't sell.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 26 (UP) -- Dr. Carl Gustav Jung, the last living member of the "big three" of psychoanalysis, celebrated his eightieth birthday today with his family -- "the biggest success of my life."

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday net income for the first half and for June were just about double the comparable 1954 levels. Walter P. Marshall, president, traced the improvement to a combination of telegraph rate revisions that went into effect during last year's second half, the increasing sale of private wire and facsimile services and betterment of message volume.

From time to time it becomes desirable, and even necessary, nature being what it is, for governments to apply the brake-pedal to prosperity lest it defeat its own ends. Yesterday this newspaper echoed here the views of a number of experienced economists and public officials in this country who have expressed concern over the part that expanding credit was playing on the boom into which we have emerged from the post-Korean recession.

So far this month the Federal Government has issued accelerated tax write-off certificates covering $47,768,000 worth of new industrial facilities. A partial list of the companies receiving fast write-offs:...
Cardinal Spellman, now sailing south from Rio de Janeiro aboard the Brazil, does not plan to visit Argentina on his present voyage.

Bankers peeking over the economic horizon foresee continued prosperity in the remainder of the year. The Credit Policy Commission of the American Bankers Association reported yesterday that its regular semi-annual survey of bankers' opinions on the business outlook produced the following:
Summer clinics for vaccination against polio will be held in the city during the week beginning Aug. 8.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Representatives of the New York Port Authority asked Congress today to approve legislation that would permit them to proceed with planned improvements on the Old Port Newark Army Base.

Some measures to improve military morale and to increase the attractiveness of a military career have been enacted at this session of Congress. Service pay has been increased; a $254,000,000 housing plan for 17,000 service homes has been approved, and other needed legislation has been passed.
THE "something blue" that brides are supposed to wear on their wedding day is something new at Rosette Pennington's.
The persistence of the 16,798 fans at Jamaica yesterday surpassed all understanding. They repeatedly booed Jockey Eddie Arcaro for losing and they repeatedly bet their money on his mounts.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 26 -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati and Kurt Nielsen of Denmark, the Wimbledon finalists, were in the field that started play today in the sixty-seventh annual Southampton invitation tennis tournament.

A Roosevelt elk calf, six weeks old, was introduced to the public yesterday at the Bronx Zoo. The Roosevelt elk, named after Theodore Roosevelt in 1897, is, when full grown, the largest of all the elk in the United States.
CLEVELAND, July 27 (AP) -- The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company announced today plans for the immediate construction of a $17,000,000 office building on Public Square.

You urge Mayor Wagner in your editorial of July 22 to lead the Beard of Estimate in overturning the board's recent defeat, during the Mayor's absence, of two proposals by Joseph Schechter, the Director of Personnel.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A Senate subcommittee today charged "collusion and complicity among insurance, union and employer representatives" in the million-dollar looting of a union welfare fund.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Following are House today on rival highway measures:

BALTIMORE, July 27 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles overcame a six-run deficit with two three-run bursts in the fifth and sixth innings and snapped an eight-game losing streak tonight by defeating the Detroit Tigers, 3 -- 7. The Bengals had taken the twilight opener of the double-header, 8 -- 4.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Senate, by voice vote, approved today a compromise bill extending the Mexican farm labor program until June 30, 1959. The measure now goes to the House.

As recently as three or four years ago the release of the Bureau of Labor Statistics monthly index of consumer prices was almost surefire page one news. Those were the days when, under the influence of the Korean rearmament boom, the index was moving steadily upward.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- A budget-minded couple can plan wholesome meals on only $4.28 a person a week, Department of Agriculture food experts said today.
Some days a ball club seems destined to lose no matter what it tries. The Yankees had such an experience yesterday.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, June 26 -- The Vale of Kashmir, a land of loveliness dressed in rags, is welded firmly to India. Four things have made this so: time, money, hard work and power.

In its first venture on the West Coast the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation has purchased the assets of the Rhodes Lewis Company, a subsidiary of the McCulloch Motors Corporation of Los Angeles. The price was not announced.
A large plot on Crompond Road in Yorktown Heights, N. Y., has been purchased by David S. Meister, realty investor, who will erect a supermarket for Shopwell Stores, Inc.

An official of the New York Central Railroad has recommended abandonment of other passenger service in addition to the West Shore division. This disclosure was made at yesterday's hearing on the road's application to discontinue ferry service between Manhattan and the West Shore's Weehawken terminal.
ROCQUENCOURT, France, July 27 -- The first German soldiers to join the forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization reported today to Supreme Headquarters here.

BOSTON, July 27 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters won wage rises of up to 50 cents an hour today in southern New England. The victory ended a strike that began June 13. Drivers were instructed to man trucks beginning at midnight.

On the premise that this city has a Spanish-speaking market of more than 800,000 persons, of whom more than half are Puerto Ricans, a Spanish-language advertising agency, described as the first such in this country, has been formed here.
A full-blooded Indian known as "Geronimo" was "scalped" here yesterday by a barber-turned-detective.

No youngster wanted to write Bored of Education yesterday at Public School 196 in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. A circus of sorts had come to the schoolyard, and it was the very proper board (during school terms) that was acting as impresario.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The President of Eastern Airlines testified today that integration of Eastern and Colonial Airlines would effect savings to the Government of nearly $1,300 a day now being paid to Colonial in subsidies.
PARIS, July 27 -- The French National Assembly voted late tonight to carry over this year's civil budgetary figures into 1956 in a move to limit the national deficit.

The new Military Reserve bill, which will now be the law of the land for the next four years as soon as the President signs the Congressional - approved legislation, is frankly a compromise, satisfactory in all its provisions to none.
CHARLESTON, S. C., July 27 (UP) -- A Negro team won the Little League baseball championship of South Carolina by default today when the fifty-five other teams withdrew.
TAIPEI, Formosa, July 27 -- The Chinese Communists have virtually completed the building of five air bases for jet fighters along the coast of Fukien Province opposite Formosa.
The Federal Government has allocated $270,000 to enable the city to replace "Rookery Row" in the Rockaways with modern, privately built housing.
Sales and earnings of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for the quarter and six months ended June 30 declined from the levels of those periods a year ago.

Fred Schwartz, president of Distributors Corporation of America, will arrive in Hollywood today to confer with Geoffrey Shurlock, head of the Production Code Administration, over the Distributors Corporation release "I Am a Camera."

GLEN COVE, L. I., July 27 -- Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Piping Rock collected a par 4 on the twentieth hole to enable her and Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century to defeat Mrs. E. C. K. Finch of New Canaan and Mrs. C. F. Spalding of Round Hill today.
CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- Arab Actress, a 13-1 shot, today won the $60,175 Arlington Matron Stakes.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Eisenhower pledged anew today that Administration officials would "tell the entire story" of the Dixon-Yates private power contract. At almost the same time, J. Sinclair Armstrong, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, refused to tell Senate investigators about a conversation he had had on July 13 with Sherman Adams, Assistant to the President, on the contract.

Eighty-five shares of Standard Factors Corporation went yesterday as a gift to 85-year-old Edmund Wright. Standard Factors stock was traded on the American Stock Exchange for the first time yesterday and the company bought the eight-five shares for Mr. Wright at the opening.
LONDON, July 27 -- Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin and Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party secretary, will visit Britain next spring, Sir Anthony Eden announced today.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 27 -- There were 122 craft out for the Law Cup junior regatta at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today. The event also opened the first Eastern junior open race week, held under the auspices of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Eisenhower made the following major points at his seventy-fourth news conference today:

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that its minimum sales prices of Government-owned surplus cotton will be reduced by the equivalent of half a cent a pound, effective Aug. 1.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- A Senate Public Works subcommittee decided today to postpone until next year consideration of legislation to authorize construction of new power plants at Niagara Falls and to deepen the channels connecting the Great Lakes.

TRENTON, July 27 -- Despite protests from two local chapters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today that he would stand by his appointment of Mario H. Volpe as judge of the Mercer County Court.
Mayor Wagner set up an interdepartmental "task force" yesterday to study overcrowding in the city's correctional and welfare institutions.
Despite the gains in policing under Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams, crime still remains all too successful an occupation:
BUFFALO, July 27 -- New York State's Motor Vehicle Commissioner said today a spot-check plan for automobiles was under study as a substitute for compulsory periodic inspection.
TWENTY-FIVE teams are entered in the United States Atlantic tuna tournament this year. The three-day horse mackerel derby is scheduled to open Aug. 9 at Narragansett, R. I.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Following are excerpts from testimony before the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee, including the full transcript of testimony by Harold F. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 27 -- The United States has reached tentative agreement with seven countries on "articles of incorporation" for an international agency for developing peaceful uses of atomic energy.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 27 (Canadian Press) -- Jackie Pearce of the Hamilton Leander Boat Club, one of Canada's brightest young prospects in sculling, tonight won the junior high school singles in the opening of the four-day Royal Canadian Henley regatta.

PARIS, July 27 -- A report published here today said the Government was considering sending another Army division from Europe to Algeria The report attracted attention in North Atlantic alliance circles.
HONG KONG, Thursday, July 28 -- The Peiping Government has named Wang Pingnan, Ambassador to Poland, as its representative for the forthcoming Ambassadors' talks with the United States at Geneva.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Eisenhower said today that the United States might "eventually" have to agree to a meeting of the Secretary of State with the foreign minister of Communist China.
After forty years at 120 Broadway the Empire Trust Company, one of New York's leading commercial banks, will move to new offices in the area.
The first vessel of a fleet of thirty war-built Liberty ships to be used as floating surplus-grain storage bins in the Hudson River began loading 6,000 tons of wheat here yesterday.

H. A. Brassert Co., an engineering concern, reported yesterday it had started diamond-drilling exploration of what its engineers believe to be one of the six or seven largest iron ore deposits known in the free world. The deposit is at Mutun, near the Paraguay River in the far eastern tip of Bolivia.

IN "A Tale for Midnight" Frederic Prokosch has made a curious Gothic novel out of one of the somberly immortal stories of the Renaissance. This is the legend of the Cenci, "eminently fearful and monstrous," as Shelley called it when he wrote a play about it in verse; filled with murders, perversions, the suggestion of incest and the deathly glitter of a decadent society.

A suit designed to reduce the cost of refreshments sold by the Good Humor Corporation at Coney Island and in the Rock-aways was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Morton Birnbaum, an attorney. He says he believes he is "representing the wishes of more than 8,000,000 fellow citizens."
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- House investigators today reported "shocking inefficiency and unskilled performance" in the Immigration Service's handling of the Francesco Brancato deportation case.
BUENOS AIRES, July 27 -- Arturo Frondizi, head of the opposition Radical party, spelled out tonight the freedoms that must be restored if Argentina were to enjoy internal peace.

The city of Springfield, Ohio, announced yesterday that it iwould receive bids on Aug. ll on $5,750,000 of waterworks revenue bonds. The obligations be {dated Aug. 1, 1955 and will Icome due serially on Dec. 1 from 1959 to 1987.

President Tito's speech in Croatia yesterday was a major political pronouncement covering many topics. The speech seems to represent a new tone in Yugoslav foreign policy, a difference that may complicate Belgrade's relations with Washington.
LONDON, July 27 -- There was no giant display of fireworks to wind up the last day of London's fall fashion collections, but a few gentle sparklers made pretty lights off and on throughout the day.
TART lemon juice makes a pleasant change from vinegar in a French dressing for salad greens. Cooked greens or beets take on new zest when sprinkled with lime juice.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Representatives of the Kohler Manufacturing Company and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., reconvened today for the first time since April 21 in an effort to settle the fifteen-month strike against the Wisconsin company.

Commodity futures continued irregular in generally dull trading on the New York exchanges. Coffee, potatoes and hides were mixed; rubber, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, copper, lead and zinc rose, and cocoa, sugar, burlap and wool eased.

Your editorial of July 26 concerning the Neponsit Beach Hospital site, in which you urged Mayor Wagner to "take up the cudgels and save this beach for the people * * * " does, I am convinced, accurately reflect the judgment of most New York City residents.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- Six Senate Democrats accused the Eisenhower Administration today of trying to make "the coach of the home team the umpire of the game" in its appointments to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ATHENS, Thursday, July 28 -- Silence today surrounded the crash of an Israeli airliner in Communist Bulgaria. Nearly twenty-four hours after, nothing certain was known of the fate of the fifty-eight persons reported aboard.

Allied Department Stores Corporation, said to be the nation's largest department store chain, soon may acquire its first store in Tennessee. B. Earl Puckett, Allied chairman, announced yesterday plans for the acquisition of the Cain-Sloan Company, in Nashville, subject to the approval of Cain-Sloan stockholders.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Newell Brown, fighting for confirmation as Wage and Hour Administrator, replied to union critics today. He said that the wages of woodsmen in New Hampshire had gone up, not down, during his tenure as Director of Employment Security in that state.

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- Willie Pastrano, 175 1/2 pounds, New Orleans, combined a sharp left jab with fast footwork tonight to gain a unanimous ten-round decision over Chuck Spieser, 171 1/2, Detroit, in Chicago Stadium.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 -- David Rockefeller defended today day the policy of economic aid to India despite Prime Minister Nehru's failure to give the West positive support against Russian and Chinese Communists. Mr. Rockefeller said it was likely that India would need larger capital funds from abroad during the last half of this decade than she now could use with benefit.
A general improvement in water conditions has been shown at most of the city's bathing beaches, the Health Department reported yesterday.
Federal grand jury yesterday indicted George Wolk, former manager of the Staten Island office of the Social Security Administration, for divulging confidential information.
LONDON, July 27 -- The oldest sports event in British life was staged on the Thames River this afternoon, with undiminished pageantry supplied by London Medieval guilds.

A look at America's security system at work and a study of the important issues raised in the withdrawal of security clearance from J. Robert Oppenheimer are presented in "The Oppenheimer Case: The Trial of a Security System," by Charles P. Curtis, a Boston lawyer. It will be published Aug. 25 by Simon Schuster.
