GENEVA, July 27 (AP) -- Dr. G. J. van Heuven Goedhart, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said today he was breaking off relations with the Tolstoy Foundation of New York.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower nominated today Francis O. Wilcox, aide to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, to be Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27 -- The first group of candidates for "movie bests" to be voted upon annually by the public was announced today at a luncheon in the Beverly Hills Hotel. Studio executives, theatre association representatives and a handful of stars attended.

Edmund S. Mansure, Administrator of General Services, has asked the Committees on Public Works of the Senate and House of Representatives to approve the construction of an eight-story, air-conditioned building to serve as a new home for the United States Mission to the United Nations.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- There were two developments today in the proxy battle for the control of Libby, McNeill Libby, $137,000,000 Chicago food enterprise. The issue will be settled at the annual meeting in Portland, Me., on Aug. 17. The developments:

Chesapeake Industries, Inc. announced yesterday that it had formed a new subsidiary, Pathe-color, Inc., to develop and print under license Eastman Kodak amateur color still film. The new company will be a subsidiary of Pathe Laboratories, Inc., of New York and Hollywood, a wholly owned Chesapeake company.
The House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee reported favorably yesterday on bills that would authorize the sale of the passenger liners Monterey and LaGuardia for American-flag operation.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The House of Representatives rejected today rival Republican and Democratic bills for new road-building programs. The action apparently ended all prospect for highway legislation at this session.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- Americans for Democratic Action urged President Eisenhower today to "make known your position" on the controversial natural gas bill.
CINCINNATI, July 27 -- Brooklyn's failure to make a double play enabled the Redlegs to tie the score in the ninth inning and Cincinnati beat the Dodgers in the tenth 4 -- 3, tonight at Crosley Field.

The White Sox did not appear on the field at the Stadium yesterday until just before their scheduled time for batting practice. While the Yankees were working out, the Chicagoans were closeted in their dressing room with Manager Marry Marion.

I read again and again that the Transit Authority is in trouble and intends to do this and that about the bus system it owns -- sell it, raise fares, raise wages. I never read that it or any other trustee of the public interest -- including the press -- has bothered to concern itself with details of service to the people.

The heat established a record for July yesterday. It was the eleventh day this month with temperatures of 90 or over, one more than the previous July maximum of ten. The mercury did not stop at 90 yesterday, but went on up to 93.1 degrees at 2:10 P. M.
George Meany rejected yesterday an invitation to go to the Soviet Union to get a first-hand view of labor conditions there.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities, as announced today by the Federal Reserve Board, shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 20:
Another project designed to help the aged was started yesterday.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation will spend $5,000,000 to sponsor coverage of the 1956 Presidential conventions, campaigns and election returns over the Columbia Broadcasting System television and radio networks.
One of the Government's top map-making experts, Rear Admiral Robert F. A. Studds, will retire Monday after a lifetime of public service.
LONDON, July 27 -- The Egyptian Government has denied firing on the British ship Anshun on July 3, and has repudiated all responsibility for the incident, Parliament was told today.
PARIS, July 27 (UP) -- Premier Edgar Faure declared today that a last-hour proposal by President Eisenhower had broken the deadlock in the Big Four conference at Geneva and insured its success.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Thursday, July 28 -- The Alliance party won yesterday the first national elections ever held in the Federation of Malaya.

FAYETTEVILLE, N. C., July 27 (AP) -- The president of the Association of Consulting Management Engineers said here tonight that to his knowledge Paul B. Mulligan Co. had never formally applied for membership.

Ten of the twenty-four competitors in the preliminaries of junior world championship chess tournament at Antwerp qualified for the finals as the result of play in the seventh round, according to a report received here yesterday through Belgian news sources.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Trade was slow in the grain and soybean markets today. Early in the session there was some pressure in all pits, but demand stiffened, resulting in modest recoveries. Oats led a late rally.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- The average of the three-man board of strategy operating the Giants in the absence of Leo Durocher dropped from 1,000 to .333 today at Wrigley Field. If Herman Franks, Fred Fitzsimmons and Frank Shellenback did not know about the ups and downs of managing a big-league ball club before this sultry afternoon, they know now.

The Radio Corporation of America, in the first six months of 1955, had the most successful first half-year in its thirty-six-year history. David Sarnoff, chairman, so reported in the semi-annual statement issued for publication today.

Profits of the knew York Stock Exchange in the first half of 1955 were $708,618 against $180,030 in the corresponding 1954 period, Keith Funston, president, reported yesterday. Most of the increase was from higher receipts from members and member firms, who pay 1 per cent of their commissions to the Exchange.
The indictment of Corliss Lamont for refusing to answer questions of the McCarthy Committee in 1953 was dismissed yesterday.
JERUSALEM, July 27 -- A 10 per cent swing of votes in Israel's Parliamentary election yesterday weakened the authority of the two parties that have been running the nation.

VIENNA, July 27 -- Austria formally regained her sovereignty today. France deposited her instrument of ratification of the Austrian state treaty in Moscow this morning, thus completing the process of putting the pact into force. The Allied Council for Austria held a last meeting here to terminate the control agreement under which it ruled Austria for ten years. The

A FORECAST of the Mozart bicentennial observations, which will get under way officially in 1956, was offered last night at Lewisohn Stadium. Three of Mozart's piano concertos and "The Marriage of Figaro" Overture made up the program.
The world's largest manufacturing concern, the General Motors Corporation, achieved the biggest sales and profits in its history in the second quarter and in the first half of this year.

Stocks yesterday followed the Tuesday pattern, but with more vehemence. There were early gains based on favorable business news. A late sell-off was resisted principally by the oils. The losses generally were wider.

HOLSTEIN, Iowa, July 27 -- An example of capitalistic civic pride was given the visiting Russian agricultural delegation today when a Governor, a member of Congress, a Mayor and a Chamber of Commerce joined forces to give some of them a look at Sioux City.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The possibility of a visit by President Eisenhower to Moscow and of Soviet leaders to Washington was evoked at today's White House news conference.

MIDSUMMER is the welcome season when those who have been "long in city pent" may at last buy vegetables fresh from the garden. Many have been harvested as recently as the day before on Long Island, upstate and New Jersey farms.
ONE and seven-ninths men will be on college campus this fall to every one woman. As everyone who's passed high school arithmetic knows, this means close to two male admirers for every girl.

A drop last week of 1,144,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies were 157,678,000 barrels on July 22, compared with 158,822,000 a week earlier and 158,844,000 a year ago.

Four aviators who were imprisoned by Communist China, the Air Force announces, are back on active duty with no prejudice against their service records. Much more important is the fact that they have been used, and are still being used, in a thorough study of what ought to constitute the best mode of behavior on the part of men who are taken captive.

LONDON, July 27 -- The firmness of sterling following Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler's further statement on exchange policy helped Government issues to rally strongly on the stock market here today. Industrial shares also closed firm, though some were below the day's best.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Guild said today it felt any false impression that it was Communist-influenced had been set straight. It declined with thanks an offer to testify before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.
Dates have been reserved at Carnegie Hall this fall for the American debut of Emil Gilels, Russia's best-known pianist and a Stalin prize winner.
Roman Catholic educators were advised last night to teach faith rather than just preach good conduct.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A Senate-House conference approved today a foreign aid bill providing about $2,700,000,000 for the 1956 fiscal year, which began July 1. The President had requested $3,266,641,750.
The following hints are not intended for those in air-conditioned apartments. Such fortunates are referred to the food column, since they probably still have their appetites intact.

The little army that sprang up with such hope and enthusiasm in the spring, all flags flying to meet the enemies that it knew were lurking everywhere to attack it, is beginning to fade, to wilt. Flags are still flying, but they are a bit worn, they lean every which way.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Eisenhower has received an amazing personal briefing on inside Kremlin secrets from Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov.

In his statement in Rome recently concerning Goa Prime Minister Nehru says, "Rest assured that Goa will be Indian territory." Any incorporation of Goa constitutes an act of aggression whether by force of arms or by outwardly passive means. The people of Goa are loyal to Portugal and want to remain Portuguese.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 27 -- Robert Falkenburg of Brazil, the Wimbledon champion in 1948, was eliminated in the second round of the invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club today.

The New York chapter of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation, 432 Fourth Avenue, gave yesterday $3,072 to the arthritis clinic of French Hospital, 324 West Thirtieth Street. This brought the total of medical and scientific grants made by the chapter to more than $1,000,000.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- The Administration put in another bid today for President Eisenhower's atomic - powered merchant ship, already rejected by both the House and Senate.
BONN, Germany, July 27 -- Dr. Heinrich von Brentano indicated today the West German Government considered the Geneva conference a setback for the cause of reunification.

Harold Schneider, builder of apartment houses in Brooklyn and Queens, has turned to Manhattan's East Side. He has purchased the northwest corner of First Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street for improvement with a twenty-story apartment building.
CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The high rate of operations in the quarter and six months ended June 30 enabled four steel companies to report substantial increases in sales and earnings over the corresponding periods last year.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 27 (AP) -- Sammy Boulmetis, who has won more races at Monmouth Park than any other rider in the ten-year history of the track, captured his seventh stakes event here today by booting home W. E. Brown's Royal Battle in the $17,750 Rumson Handicap.

Continued close control of expenses and non-recurring credits of $1,782,897 helped lift net income of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad to $5,990,461 before sinking fund reserves in the first half of this year. This compares with $672,420 earned in the first six months of 1954.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- The House Civil Service Committee approved a bill today to grant salary increases to the ten Cabinet members and about 300 other top Government officials.

TOKYO, July 27 -- Government circles voiced a hope today that negotiations between the United States and Communist China might lead to some relaxation of the embargo against many exports to the Chinese mainland.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson. said today an injustice had been done to Lewis L. Strauss in connection with charges of "one-man rule" on the Atomic Energy Commission.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Administration ran into trouble today in its efforts to get early action on a tariff measure designed to plug a "loophole" in the duty on imported watch movements.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House authorized direct quotation of the President throughout:

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 27 -- Alan Gilison of West Hempstead won the Long Island Golf Association junior championship at the Cherry Valley Club today. Gilison defeated Don Parker of the Garden City C. C., 4 and 3, to take the Alfred S. Bourne Trophy in the thirty-fourth annual tournament.
RYE, N. Y., July 27 -- Thomas J. Goodwin of the Westchester Country Club won the qualifying medal in the thirty-sixth annual Westchester amateur championship over the Apawamis Club course today.

ODESSA, U. S. S. R., July 27 -- The United States agricultural delegation got its closest look today at living conditions of Soviet Union collective farmers. For the first time on their tour of the Soviet Union the delegation visited homes of rank-and-file members of a large collective farm.

The Harriman Administration is still seeking a way to escape the governmental task of executing the law for compulsory semi-annual inspection of automobiles for mechanical safety. In early April the Legislature, yielding to Governor Harriman's request, postponed effectiveness of the requirement for inspection.

WHETHER you like dog shows or whether you think them a dreadful bore, there's one claim they can make that few other sports can. Blow high, blow low, come rain, come flood, they never are canceled or postponed.
OTTAWA, July 27 -- The second session of Canada's twenty-second Parliament came to an end today.

LONDON, July 27 -- Britain's drive to assure industrial stability moved a step closer to success today. The General Council of the Trades Union Congress decided to seek greater power to intervene in disputes.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Eisenhower strode this morning into the room where his news conferences are held and beamed at 184 perspiring newsmen.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 27 -- President Tito declared today that he would not permit United States "supervision" of military equipment granted to Yugoslavia under the air program.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Eisenhower broadened today his offer to exchange military "blueprints" with the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A subpoena was issued by one Congressional committee today to require sworn testimony from a Clerk of another.

FIRE ISLAND, N. Y., July 27 -- Stan Ogilvy means business. That's the impression the Larchmont skipper is giving this week in the Star Class competition for the Corry Trophy, being sailed in conjuction with the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual cruise week.
Sportsmanship on the fishing grounds off New Jersey has been backed up with a shotgun.
" Strip for Action" saw plenty of action yesterday.

Borrowing to buy securities is about to become more costly. Most major New York City banks announced yesterday that in the next few days they would increase the rate of interest on loans to brokers and dealers by one-fourth of 1 percentage point.

Hell's Canyon, in the remote fastnesses of the Snake River on the Oregon-Idaho border, is one of the finest unexploited power sites in the country. For at least eight years the dispute has raged over the question of how the great hydroelectric potential there should be developed, whether by public or private enterprise.

Tonnage sales of the General Foods Corporation in the fiscal year ending next March 31 may exceed those of the previous year, and dollar sales may reach the same or an even smaller total, Charles G. Mortimer, president, told 400 stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday. In the fiscal year ended last March, sales were $824,837,506.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Kansas City swept a double-header with Washington tonight, taking the 11-inning opener, 6 -- 4, and then capturing the second game, 4 -- 1. Gus Zernial slammed a three-run homer, his twentieth, in the first game for the Athletics.

The Western Maryland Railway, often thwarted in its efforts to refund its 177,420 shares of $7 first preferred stock, has decided to leave the issue outstanding and to pay off the $19,250,000 of back dividends that have piled up on the shares.
Note to Moscow: there are more "capitalists" in the American steel industry than there are workers.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Eisenhower's genius for doing the disarming momentarily cooled off a pack of steamy reporters at this morning's news conference.

ALBANY, July 27 -- A vice president of the New York Telephone Company testified today that a $34,000,000 a year stopgap rate increase would give the utility a return of only a little more than 6 per cent for the next two and a half years.

At his most recent press conference Secretary of State Dulles expounded again what may be called the "no-force" doctrine which is basic to American foreign policy. This doctrine holds that, whatever the differences now dividing the world may be, these differences must not be settled by recourse to force where this would be likely to provoke war.

CHICAGO, July 27 (UP) -- Mrs. Scott Probasco, Chattanooga, defeated Ruth Jessen, Kenmore, Wash., on the nineteenth hole today to advance to the quarterfinals in the women's Western amateur golf tournament.
After the running of the Adirondack Stakes at Jamaica yesterday Tony DeSpirito said, "I don't think I've ever ridden a faster filly."
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- President Eisenhower said today he was not satisfied with the compulsory military reserve bill passed by Congress this week. But he did not say he would veto it.

Frederick Brown announced yesterday that he had assembled a building site at the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street. It has frontages of 102 feet on the avenue and 100 feet on the street.
Decision was reserved yesterday on a motion by Queens Borough President James A. Lundy to quash the report of a special grand jury that found him "lacking the proper concept of public office."

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Eisenhower said today that Harold E. Talbott's tenure as Secretary of the Air Force hinged largely on the ethics rather than the legality of his private business dealings.
ROME, July 27 -- An appreciable weakening of the Communists' hold on organized Italian labor is confirmed by final results of the shop steward elections.
CINCINNATI, July 28 -- Lanky Roger Craig hurled the Dodgers to a five-hit, 10-2 triumph over the Redlegs at Crosley Field tonight before 10,422 fans.

A $2,254,502 contract for a new passenger and automobile ferry boat for the New Bedford, Mass.-Martha's Vineyard run has been awarded to the John H. Mathis Company of Camden, N. J., by the New Bedford, Woods Hole, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket Steamship Authority.
CHICAGO, July 28 -- Record sales and earnings of the Borg-Warner Corporation in the first half of 1955 reflected increases in the demand for industrial products, Roy C. Ingersoll, pres-
WITH most species of upland game birds and small game plentiful, the New York Conservation Department has announced the opening dates, seasons and bag limits.
All twelve United States passengers killed in the crash of an El A1 Israel airliner in Bulgaria were from New York.

A 62.7 per cent increase in earnings of North American Aviation, Inc., brought the net to a record $23,635,000 for the nine months ended June 30, the preliminary unaudited report disclosed yesterday. The income, equal to $6.88 a share, compares with $14,525,000 or $4.23 a share for the corresponding nine months of the previous year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since the greater part of the New York City population necessarily uses the subway to reach its places of work and centers of shopping, it is not too early to direct the thinking of our city administration to the character of the construction of the subway system now on the planning boards.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Public Health Service reported today a seasonal increase in poliomyelitis cases last week. It noted, however, 2,191 fewer cases so far this year as against the same period of 1954.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Army announced today it was bolstering its forces in the Far East with the "deterrent power" of atomic artillery and rockets.
LONDON, July 28 -- An ambitious project to duplicate the historic ship Mayflower was begun today at a ceremony in Brixham, a Devonshire fishing village.

The House, in a depressingly irresponsible action, has defeated all legislation to accelerate highway construction. It repudiated the good sense and sound financing of its Public Works Committee by rejecting the Democratic highway bill by a vote of 292 to 123. The committee, with great political courage. I had agreed by an impressive major,; ity to match spending with taxation in a single package.
Promotions came quickly yesterday for two patrolmen who had joined the force a year ago last March.

William J. Keating, former counsel for the New York City Anti-Crime Committee, has been offered the post of counsel to a dock workers' union. He was reported to be undecided whether to take the position.

The New York Regional Red Cross will collect blood today from naval and civilian personnel aboard the Mission Bay. The vessel is the aircraft carrier headquarters of the New York Group, Atlantic Reserve Fleet, at Bayonne, N. J.

Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., will close its mills at midnight tonight because its copper inventories are exhausted and further supplies are unobtainable owing to strikes in domestic mines and smelters.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 28 -- Fred Schwartz, eastern film theatre chain operator and head of the Distributors Corporation of America, indicated today that the company planned to appeal the withholding of a production code seal of approval for the movie "I Am a Camera."

BELFAST, North Ireland, July 28 -- James Chuter Ede, Labor Member of the British Parliament from South Shields, was elected president of the International Association of Liberal Christianity at its fifteenth triennial Congress here. He succeeds Percival F. Brundage of New York.

The Seas Shipping Company, operators of the Robin Line's steamship service to South and East Africa, has realigned its top operating personnel in anticipation of the retirement of Peter P. Lannig as operating manager.

CLEVELAND, July 28 -- Dr. F. Eppling Reinartz of New York, secretary of the United Lutheran Church in America indicted tonight Protestant Sunday schools for conveying "sweet bits of morality" to the nation's young people.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Soybean futures showed considerable strength today. There was covering by shorts on the possibility the Government report on stocks in all positions will show a downward revision in the 1954 crop estimate.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -A Pentagon spokesman said today thirty-eight life insurance agents had been banned from military posts for improper practices during the last four years and "more are corning up."
AUSTIN, Tex., July 28 (AP) -Bascom Giles, former Texas Land Commissioner, was found guilty today of being an accomplice to theft of $6,800 of the state's Veterans Land Program funds.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Administration was charged today with sponsoring a new tariff concept that could disrupt the nation's historic tariff structure.
PHILADELPHIA, July 28 -- Military men watched an impressive test flight today of a large transport plane equipped to operate from concrete runways, water, ice, snow, sand or farm fields.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -The Federal Bureau of Investigation was reported tonight to have turned down any assignment to find out who "leaked" documents in the Talbott case to The New York Times.

The former wife of Supreme Court Justice Joseph Force Crater, who disappeared on Aug. 6, 1930, during an investigation of Tammany corruption, said yesterday that after twenty-five years she was still convinced he had been murdered. The jurist was declared legally dead in 1937.

LONDON, July 28 -- Government stocks continued to rise today despite a slight reaction in sterling against both spot and forward dollars. Industrial shares were not all able to sustain their early strength as business declined before the Aug. 1 weekend holiday.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The United States Government expressed its indigation today over the shooting down of the Israeli airliner by Bulgaria.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Leo Durocher rejoined the Giants today and immediately restored order among his floundering forces at Wrigley Field. The little Durocher touches -- a mild debate with an umpire, a pep talk with a pitcher, a shift of an infielder -- were in evidence as the Polo Grounders beat the Cubs, 4 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Federal Court of Appeals reversed today the conviction of Clyde L. Powell for contempt of court in refusing to answer questions of a grand jury.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -The Maritime Administration signed contracts today totaling $38,000,000 for the sale and conversion of two vessels. The Oceanic Steamship Company will use them to reopen passenger and cargo service between the United States and Australia and New Zealand.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- An apparently foredoomed attempt was begun today to have the Senate insist on Chinese Nationalist participation in the forthcoming talks between the United States and the Chinese Communists.
For its millions of sweltering riders, the Transit Authority had a cool thought yesterday -- air conditioned trains.

JEAN COCTEAU'S "The Typewriter," being offered by the downtown Tempo Playhouse (where it receives intermittent competition from an infernal air-conditioning machine), is billed as a psychological detective story.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -Democrats pounced again today on the Dixon-Yates private power contract and "one-man rule" of the Atomic Energy Commission.

A RELATIVELY new wrinkle in the curing of Virginia hams, which dates back 300 years, is cooking, boning and pressing the product into a neat loaf. Traditionalists with sensitive palates will immediately object that such ham is drier than bone-in meat.

Denver, Colo., raised $12,000,000 in the bond market yesterday through the sale of issues of serial bonds to finance street and traffic control equipment, parks and recreational facilities and sanitary sewerage.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points lower to 9 points higher yesterday. Trading was fairly active in the session.
The United Corporation increased its net income and net asset value per share during the first half, William H. Hickey, president, reported yesterday.
PARIS, July 28 -- Governor Harriman said here today he looked forward to the time when Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov would no longer represent the Soviet Union.
A series of deals involving the 150 room Webster Hotel at 40 West Forty-fifth Street, near Fifth Avenue, was announced yesterday by the M. MorgenthauSeixas Company, brokers.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP) -- Maj. John Eisenhower, the President's son, said today he was as much in the dark as anyone about whether his father would seek a second term.

Today's new film is "The Scarlet Coat," a Metro-GoldwynMayer adventure drama of the Revolutionary War in CinemaScope and color, at the Palace Theatre. Cornel Wilde, Michael Wilding, George Sanders, Anne Francis and Robert Douglas have the principal roles.
Detailed plans for expanding the work of the New York City Youth Board against juvenile delinquency were announced yesterday.

There is a point beyond which even a Senatorial subcommittee may not go. This seems to be the gist of the decision of Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld to dismiss the contempt cases against Corliss Lamont and two other defendants.

JERUSALEM, July 28 -- Communist Bulgaria acknowledged today her anti-aircraft gunners had shot down the Israeli airliner that carried fifty-eight persons to death yesterday. Among the dead were twelve Americans, all from New York.
The Ethyl Corporation's campaign to stimulate demand for the products and services of all businesses with a stake in automotive transportation is to have considerable newspaper support.
The retirement of Clarence R. Krigbaum, regional commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service for the New York area and a career tax official of thirty-four years' service, was announced yesterday.
Yehudi Menuhin was in superlative form last night at Lewisohn Stadium. He appeared as soloist with Efrem Kurtz and the Stadium Symphony Orchestra in the Brahms Violin Concerto.

Devotees of the 4=Day Growth Vacation time means many things to many members of the family. To Father it often means welcome surcease from one of the peskiest of routine chores to which the male is heir -shaving.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 28 -- On slippery turf, in drizzling rain, Hal Burrows defeated Kurt Nielsen of Copenhagen today in the invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -Another of President Eisenhower's Air Force appointments ran into trouble when the Senate Armed Services Committee deferred action on the nomination of Dudley C. Sharp to be Assistant Secretary because Mr. Sharp said he wanted to retain his stock in an investment trust.

Prices were irregular in the commodity futures markets yesterday. Trading was dull and featureless in most markets. Coffee, zinc, copper, sugar and cottonseed oil were mixed; rubber, hides, soybean oil, silk and potatoes rose, and cocoa and wool eased.

Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court John M. Harlan has agreed to listen on Monday at 2 P. M. in the Federal Court House at Foley Square to a plea of the Alleghany Corporation, holding company.
Hen Party, carrying Louis Lee Haggin 2d's silks, gave a party for form players at the Saratoga -at-Jamaica meeting yesterday.
VIENNA, July 28 -- The Austrian Government has yielded recently to two Soviet demands. One of the demands was supposed to have been ruled out by the state treaty.
ALBANY, July 28 -- A Republican State Senator charged today that "scandalous bickering and feuding" among state departments were delaying rehabilitation services to the crippled and handicapped.
VERNON, N. Y., July 28 (AP) -Scott Frost, the odds-on Hambletonian favorite, boosted his stock tonight by capturing the $10,000 Hambletonian Test at Vernon Downs.

There are two aspects of the justconcluded popular election in the Federation of Malaya that give it more than ordinary significance. The first is obvious. This election, in which for the first time the people chose the majority of a legislature, is a large step toward selfgovernment. This is political progress.

Two historic landmarks were set in Europe Wednesday. One was the formal proclamation of Austria's renewed independence and sovereignty after seventeen years of subjugation, first under Hitler and then under a Soviet occupation kept in check only by the simultaneous presence of Western troops.
OSCEOLA, Iowa, July 28 -Like their Iowa hosts, the visiting Russian farm delegation today could talk about only one thing -- the heat.
It seems there is no discouraging Chicago's Go-Go White Sox.

Like a patient who has built up an immunity to miracle drugs, the stock market failed to react to good business news yesterday. Prices closed irregulargly lower, with some of the larger losses registered by companies that had issued good reports or raised dividends.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The gallantry of United States Senators was on display today as a Senate Judiciary subcommittee approved Miss Mary H. Donlon of upstate New York to be a judge of the United States Customs Court.
When Manuel Velez was 12 years old he left school, having gone only through the fourth grade. For most of the nineteen years since then it never occurred to him that he would go back to school.

Amerigo Vespucci, the Italian explorer whose name was given to the two continents of the New World, is the subject of a new book by German Arciniegas. In "Amerigo and the New World," Mr. Arciniegas presents a picture of the fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries in Italy, France, Spain, Portugal and America. Translated from the Spanish by Harriet de Onis, the biography will be published Aug. 22 by Knopf.
TAIPEI, Formosa, July 28 -The Chinese Nationalist Government and the public are apprehensive about next week's Geneva talks between two ambassadors of the United States and Communist China.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, June 27 -- Indian Kashmir is headed by a prince, ruled by a Prime Minister and haunted by a prisoner.

AKRON, Ohio, July 28 (AP) -- Doug Ford of Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., winner of the national Professional Golfers Association championship last Tuesday, fired a six-under-par 66 today on the opening eighteen holes of the Rubber City open.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 28 -Morris MacDonald, a substitute driver, guided Adios Harry, the world's fastest harness horse, to a length and three-quarter victory in the $35,000 Nassau Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- An industry witness urged continuation of rapid tax amortization allowances today as a major incentive for capital improvements by railroads.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -A Senate Banking Subcommittee today approved a bill to place trading in unlisted stocks under the same Government regulations now applied to trading in securities listed on stock exchanges.
OTTAWA, July 28 -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent filled thirteen of twenty-three vacancies in the Canadian Senate today.

The estimated consolidated net earnings of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) for the six months ended June 30 were at a record half-yearly high of $344,000,000. This was equal to $5.26 on each of 65,435,474 capital shares then outstanding, the company announced yesterday.
An unusually large number of city policemen -- seventy-two -were among the 425 probationary firemen sworn in yesterday by Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.
PARIS, July 28 -- Jean Patou, at today's opening collection, first in the current series of fall showings, widens the shoulders and gets his detail inspiration from the envelope.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I offer a word of congratulation on your editorial on July 26 calling for a reconsideration of the decision to sell the Neponsit Beach Hospital and the Seton Hospital properties.

Enkells-Rakoff Company, operators, have contracted to buy the taxpayer containing six stores at 1550-58 Watson Avenue, the Bronx. The property is on the southwest corner of Ward Avenue and fronts 100 feet along Watson Avenue.
LONDON, July 28 (Reuters) -The Government's single-channel television service has paid its own way for the first time since it started in 1936, the British Broadcasting Corporation announced today.
In an effort to bolster their shaky pitching staff for the stretch drive, the Yankees decided yesterday to recall Don Larsen from their Denver affiliate of the American Association.
Pennsylvania Power and Light Company has decided to build its own atomic electric power plant, Charles E. Oakes, president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, today demanded an investigation of a multimillion-dollar defense housing contract he said had been let in Puerto Rico "in complete violation of the spirit of the law."

What has been most depressing about the long July heat wave is the psychological condition of its victims. The first days in the nineties stimulated all sorts of criticisms, speculations and proposals. But after eleven of them a New Yorker who survived emerged from the subway, dragged his dehydrated self home to his family, and mumbled miserably to his wife, "Hot."
A quick-thinking mailman was cited yesterday for his courage in saving a 4-year-old boy from what might have been fatal injuries.

The possibility that a group of American business executives would visit Moscow next spring to expound the advantages of free enterprise was disclosed yesterday by the head of National Sales Executives, a trade association.
BUENOS AIRES, July 28 -The Peron Government announced today that seven police officers had been discharged and were awaiting trial in the death of a Communist leader during interrogation.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -Two Senators declared today that if Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin and Nikita S. Khrushchev wanted to visit the United States they would be very welcome.

The other day a group of European students gave a dockside interview in New York that provides an interesting footnote to the steppedup moves for international understanding. Five hundred teen-agers from eighteen nations had just completed special studies at various high schools throughout the United States.
WEEK-END food markets show the unfortunate effects of wilting weather.
IN FORMOSA STRAIT, July 7 -- The DD 15 "sank" at least six "enemy" submarines today.

A prospective bus-train commuting trip between West Nyack in Rockland County and Manhattan was held out yesterday as a "very desirable" alternative to present service on the New York Central's West Shore line that connects with the Weehawken ferries.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The first session of the Eighty-fourth Congress neared the end today. At least two major issues clearly had been put aside for next year.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., July 28 -- The second day of Eastern Junior Race Week gave almost 300 youngsters a real workout and a thorough drenching off Stamford Light this afternoon. The Rocky Point Sailing Club played host.
Earnings of the Union Pacific Railroad in the six months to June 30 were the highest for any first half-year in the company's history. Net income reached $35,569,662, or $7.55 a common share.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -Democrats maintained tonight steady public pressure on President Eisenhower for prompt removal of Harold E. Talbott as Secretary of the Air Force.
In spite of the continued improvement in the nation's economy, the soft goods industries are "going downhill" in competition for the consumer's dollar, an economist said yesterday.

Thirty nations, including the Soviet Union and Communist China, have accepted this country's invitation to attend the next International Conference on Lighthouses and Other Aids to Navigation in Washington in 1960.
HELSINKI, July 28 (AP) -- Sandor Iharos of Hungary, 22-year-old Army lieutenant, today broke the world record for 1,500 meters in time that was comparable to a 3:58 mile.

Shows with music will be more abundant than heretofore in television's schedule of color "spectaculars" during the 1955-56 season. This preoccupation with musical productions is apparent in the program planning of both the National Broadcasting Company and Columbia Broadcasting System.

PARIS, July 28 -- A new and looser system to replace the European Payments Union was discussed today by the Council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation. It appeared likely to be adopted.

We are glad that name trouble is not going to block the merger of the American Federation of Labor land the Congress of Industrial Organizations. After all the problems of substance had been amicably adjusted, it would have been silly to let a dispute over what to call the merged group get in the way of unity.
Thanks to the cool beneficence of Canada, long-suffering New Yorkers worked yesterday and slept last night in the most comfortable temperatures they had known for two weeks.
HARTFORD, July 28 -- James R. Neill of Watertown resigned today as a member and chairman of the Connecticut Development Commission, which tries to lure new industry to the state.

BOSTON, July 28 (UP) -- The Cleveland Indians snapped back after two straight losses to the Red Sox to down Boston, 6 -- 4, today. The Indians bunched their nine hits to take the finale of a three-game series and retain their hold on third place, in the American League pennant race.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 28 -- Several thousand pounds of powdered milk donated by a United Nations agency to refugees in East Pakistan have been sold in the black market.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The House of Representatives passed tonight the bill to exempt natural gas producers from Federal regulation.
TOKYO, Friday, July 29 -- Japan's House of Representatives approved yesterday a plan to study major revisions in the Constitution drafted under Allied occupation.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 28 -- The skipper of a charter fishing boat, who had been arrested for firing shotgun blasts at private fishing boats off the Jersey coast Tuesday, was released tonight in $500 bail. He had been arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -Pentagon spokesmen said today that Harold E. Talbott, the Secretary of the Air Force, had personally modified regulations in favor of a Moral Re-Armament group now touring the Far East in Air Force aircraft.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -President Eisenhower voiced hope today that Congress would revive a road-building program before adjournment.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 28 -- The impending resumption of large United States contributions to the United Nations Technical Assistance Program brought an indication today of reciprocal action by other governments.

The trustees of Columbia University have made a first mortgage loan of $300,000 at 5 per cent for twelve years on a new industrial plant on Bridge Street in New Cassel, L. I. Henry Waltemade, Inc., broker, arranged the loan for the Maral Holding Corporation, owner.

MILWAUKEE, July 28 (UP) -A young Lutheran minister was found guilty today of nine charges of heresy. A church trial committee recommended his immediate suspension. It was the first heresy trial in the sixtyyear history of the Northwest Lutheran Synod.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The United States Court of Appeals, splitting 2 to 1, ruled today that the Administration's personnel security program was "rational and reasonable."
Nine times since World War II Communist planes or ground batteries have shot or forced down non-military-type planes of non-Communist countries.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 28 -- A family fashion show, featuring midsummer togs for children as well as the latest styles for their parents will be part of a benefit luncheon next Monday at Herb McCarthy's Bowden Square for Boys Harbor.

COLUMBUS, N. J., July 28 -A man who took a bus for a visit to his wife in Lynchburg, Va., got into an uncommon amount of trouble. The state trooper who interrupted his trip early this morning charged that Frank Henry LaMar, a Bronx mechanic, made several mistakes:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with special interest the letter recently published in The New York Times, "To Aid Arab Refugees." As I happen to be one of the nearly one million Arab refugees who are now scattered throughout the Arab countries, I venture to make the following comments:
Loans to business by New York City banks increased $60,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
A First Army court martial sentenced a Jamestown, N. Y., business man yesterday to twenty-five years at hard labor after he pleaded guilty to desertion from the Army in 1944.
New York's sweltering July and New Yorkers' efforts to keep cool have combined to make things hot for Consolidated Edison's electric cables.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The weekly average of member bank reserve balances for the week ending July 27 increased $171,000,000 to $18,945,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
An investigation into television repair fraud that began nearly four years ago in Queens culminated yesterday with the arraignment of two fugitive defendants.
CITY trees in backyards and in Wall Street offices, among other places, have gone in for somewhat freakish behavior this season, some because it's hot, some because it's cold.
STRATFORD, Ont., July 28 (Canadian Press) -- The Stratford Festival company will go to New York early in 1956, A. M. Bell. president of the festival foundation, announced today.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced yesterday record first-half earnings, production and shipments. As a result, it declared an increased quarterly dividend on the common stock.

" CLIMAX" last night was video labor lost. The Channel 2 program at 8:30 P. M. stood several megacycles away from the Robert Louis Stevenson classic, "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde." It never did get any closer.
Two hundred eighty Turks and Greeks trooped down the gangplank of the Turkish liner Tarsus yesterday, talking excitedly about their first visit on American soil.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., July 28 -- Colonial Williamsburg is to start construction immediately on a $7,000,000, forty-acre information center. It will include a motor hotel, two dormitories for visiting school groups, a cafeteria, a swimming pool, and a parking area for 1,000 cars.

The appointment of Prof. Dennis McNeice Healy as dean of Long Island University's College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, Brooklyn, was announced yesterday. Professor Healy has been acting dean since last May.

Brazil's devaluation of exchange rates on all exports but coffee and bananas was looked upon without much enthusiasm by foreign traders here yesterday. Its effect will be to provide more cruzeiros per dollar for exporters of such products as pine lumber, carnauba wax, iron and manganese ores and such sources of fissionable material as tantalite, columbite and monazite.

Mrs. Andrew W. Shuman, benefit chairman, has announced that a committee has been chosen to work for the success of the sixth annual Fall Frolic, a dinner dance for the benefit of the Hemophilia Foundation. It will take place on Oct. 21 at the Pierre.
LONDON, July, 28 -- Sir Anthony Eden painted tonight a reasonably hopeful picture of the international future based on the willingness of the United States to underwrite a European security pact.

Burlington Industries, Inc., textile concern, yesterday filed a counterclaim in United States District Court, asking $1,000,000 in damages from a group of minority stockholders in Pacific Mills, which Burlington controls.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -Today's report jar the livestock markets here by the De]partment of Agriculture follows.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Government brandished a new weapon against a new adversary today in its warfare on subversion.

Two lawyers and an accountant who testified against Henry W. (The Dutchman) Gruenwald and Daniel A. Bolich, former Assistant Commissioner of Internal Revenue, received fiveyear suspended sentences yesterday.
MANILA, July 28 -- President Ramon Magsaysay charged today that Senator Claro M. Recto -- once a political aide and now the Government's severest critic -- was pro-Communist.
The Reynolds Metals Company announced yesterday that its domestic facilities are now on a completely privately financed basis as the result of a $235,000,000 transaction just completed.

RYE, N. Y., July 28 -- Lloyd Ribner of Metropolis, the defending champion, and J. Henry Attas of Dellwood, the victor in 1951, won two matches apiece today to reach the quarter-final round of the Westchester amateur golf championship.

ROME, July 28 -- In a message to Germany today the Pope upheld what he described as Christian East-West coexistence. At the same time he implicitly cautioned the Germans against the type of coexistence proposed by Communists and fellow travelers.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -Federal Judge Edward A. Tamm today dismissed the latest attempt to block New York City's redevelopment program of Washington Square Southeast.

DUNGENESS, England, July 28 -- A 59-year-old Frenchman flew the English Channel today in a copy of the plane used by Louis Bleriot in the first crossing forty-six years ago. Jean Salis sputtered to a landing at near-by Ferryfield commercial airport one hour and twenty-two minutes after he had taken off from Calais, France.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company yesterday reported gains in net income for the three, six and twelve months ended June 30. However, operating revenues for the June quarter fell slightly behind the year-ago level. This decline was laid to a house heating rate reduction that became effective on April 1.

The United States Rubber Company set new records in sales arid earnings for the quarter and six months ended on June 30, according to the report of H. E. Humphreys Jr., chairman, issued for publication today.

BELLPORT, L. I., July 28 -The fleet competing in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual Cruise Week moved into this port today, sailing a "no-point" race from Great River. Only the Star Class had scoring competition.

A deep sense of shock is the inevitable reaction to the facts surrounding the wanton shooting down of an Israeli airlines plane by Bulgarian anti-aircraft fire. A peaceful commercial plane makes a navigational error and strays off its scheduled route so that it crosses a few miles over the border of another country.

Karl Malden, who is co-starred with Nancy Coleman and Paul Newman in "The Desperate Hours," will relinquish his role on Aug. 13. Mr. Malden insisted his withdrawal should not be attributed to any differences with the management, Howard Erskine and Joseph Hayes.
Caught between a building boom and tenement deterioration, the southeast section of Brooklyn has become an exciting stage in the struggle of middle-class families to remain in the city.
General Motors Acceptance Corporation is considering borrowing $200,000,000 to bring working capital up to a level in keeping with the company's record business activity.
A tragedy deep below decks on the aircraft carrier Bennington was narrowly averted early Tuesday morning.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 28 -- The United States has warned Yugoslavia that acceptance by her of Soviet MIG fighter planes would have an immediate effect on the American...

JERUSALEM, July 28 -- Israel protested to Bulgaria tonight against the "shocking recklessness" of Bulgarian forces in shooting down the El Al airliner. Walter Eytan, director general of the Foreign Ministry, delivered the note to Christo Goutev, charge d'affaires of the Bulgarian Legation in Tel Aviv.

The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., pledge yesterday that it would oust any Communist or fellow-traveler who might have joined its staff through the recent absorption of twelve farm equipment locals.

PARIS, July 28 -- News of fierce fighting in eastern Algeria in which twenty-four French soldiers lost their lives arrived here today. It came shortly before the opening of a two-day debate on French North Africa.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -Congress completed action on a compromise $2,703,341,705 foreign aid bill today and sent it to the President.

Willy Ley, German-born rocket expert, a well-known writer on interplanetary travel, was a founder of the German Society for Space Travel. He has been a naturalized United States citizen for more than ten years. In the following dispatch Mr. Ley analyzes the significance of yesterday's satellite announcement in Washington.
SAN FRANCISO, July 29 -- Following is the text of remarks by a military police officer as he placed three American turncoats under arrest today upon their return to the United States:

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today cleared major proposals of American Natural Gas Company, New York, and its subsidiary, American Louisiana Pipeline Company of Detroit, to help to finance a $130,000,000 gas pipeline system from Louisiana to Michigan.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Jackie Gleason of New York has applied for registration of a service mark that depicts a man about to break into a dance. (Service marks are to services what trade-marks are to goods.) He says he has used the mark since Jan. 1, 1953, "for selecting, evaluating, promoting, and arranging for production of musical works and for producing radio and television broadcast programs."

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Following is the text of an announcement today by the National Science Foundation and the National Academy of Sciences regarding plans for constructing an unmanned earth satellite vehicle. The text was released at the White House.

SAN JUAN, P. R., July 29 (AP) -- Francisco Fullana, president of the Fullana Construction Corporation, declared today he would welcome any investigation of his negotiations with the Air Force for a multi-million dollar housing project at Ramey Air Force Base.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 29 -- The new Alliance party majority in the Legislative Council will start early pressure to gain increased self-government for the Federation of Malaya.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Average primary market prices decreased 0.1 point to 109.9 (1947-49 equals 100) over the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Administration spokesmen expressed confidence today that Congress would enact a bill to curb the "upjeweling" of imported watch movements before adjourning.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 29 -- Assistance in Europe by the United Nations Childrens Fund in the field of mass health "appears to be in its final stages," the organization reported today.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 29 (AP) -- L. H. Nelles' Dear Brutus won the $17,100 Midsummer Hurdle Handicap before 19,100 fans at Monmouth Park today.

A research engineer for the New York Central Railroad acknowledged yesterday that he had studied what could be saved by dropping the Weehawken ferry service, but had made no recommendation for maintaining the service on a more efficient basis.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 29 (AP) -- The four top-seeded juniors were knocked out of the national junior and boys' tennis tournament in the quarter-final round today.

LONDON, July 20 -- British conservationists claim to have made zoological history by importing animals threatened with extinction, breeding them and then returning a few to the place whence they came.

Backers of a new type of mechanical garage contended yesterday that they could meet New York's off-street parking needs if city officials would lend a hand. City help is needed in assembling the substantial plot required to construct the facility, Benjamin Kahn, spokesman for the garage company, said.
Marty Marion is the hero of a baseball success story that is making wonderful reading for his many admirers in our national pastime.
The 33,000-square foot industrial building at 90-28 Van Wyck Expressway in Jamaica, Queens, has been leased by the Allen Carpet Company, Inc., from the Hygrade Folding Box Corporation.

It was a shock and disappointment to read the item carried by your paper on July 26 which reported that the president of the National Association of Doll Manufacturers had objected to President Eisenhower's recent purchases of foreign-made dolls for his grandchildren.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 29 -- The superintendency of money and credit of the bank of Brazil has taken a minor step toward devaluation of the cruzeiro.

MOSCOW, Saturday, July 30 (UP) -- Russia is preparing to launch an earth-circling satellite similar to the one planned by the United States, authorized Soviet sources disclosed today. The launching date of the satellite has not yet been revealed.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- House and Senate conferees today agreed on a compromise $20,000,000 to start construction of an Air Force Academy at Colorado Springs, Colo.
Man's age-old dreams of leaving the earth to fly freely through space apparently are not in vain.

WIESBADEN, Germany, July 29 (AP) -- A United States Air Force C-47 transport went down in the Mediterranean today, but all its eighteen passengers and crew were rescued, United States Air Force European Headquarters said tonight.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., July 29 -- Mrs. Samuel Trepner of Glen Head and Mal Galletta of North Hills scored 39, 32 -- 71 to win the low gross prize in the Women's Cross-County Golf Association mixed foursomes charity tournament for the Industrial Home for the Blind at the Seawane Harbor Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- "This raises all sorts of interesting questions," Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan, said with a grin. "Is discovering space like discovering land? Can we lay claim to interplanetary space ?"

Letters to The Times on July 24 included a poignant appeal by James A. Michener for better medical facilities for our overseas civil servants. This was followed by a letter from a University of Connecticut professor concerning the importance of language study to the maintenance of America's role of world leadership.

The Thermoid Shareholders Committee has nominated nine candidates for the board of the Thermoid Company, Trenton manufacturer of a wide range of industrial products. The adjourned annual meeting is now scheduled for Aug. 9.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Hydrogen weapons, apparently of several types, have been produced for the United States atomic arsenal in the first six months of this year.
Underwriting commitments are continuing on the light side as the summer moves into the month of August, traditionally a period of inactivity in the new-capital market.

Today's new film is "Devotion," a Russian-made drama in color, at the Stanley Theatre. The Mosfilm production was written by I. Pyryev and the Tur Brothers, and directed by Mr. Pyryev. The leading roles are taken by S. Romodanov, N. Ladynina and L. Gallis. Artkino is releasing, the import, which has English titles.
LONDON, July 29 -- Britain announced today she was returning 400 Sabre Jet fighters to the United States and replacing them with British-made Hawker Hunters.

DETROIT, July 29 (AP) -- The Studebaker-Packard Corporation reported today an operating loss of $3,944,258 for the second quarter ending June 30. The company reported a loss of $5,694,141 for the first quarter.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 29 -- Dorothy McGuire will co-star as the wife of Gary Cooper in "Mr. Birdwell Goes to Battle," which William Wyler is preparing to direct and produce for Allied Artists.
Efforts continued yesterday to avert a strike that threatens to stop milk supplies for 12,000,000 persons in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut at midnight tomorrow.
Churches in New York will be hosts tomorrow to more than a score of guest ministers. Several of the visiting clergymen will come from overseas pulpits.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 29 -- Yugoslavia has canceled the huge financial claims for damages once said to have been caused by the actions of the Soviet Union following Belgrade's break with the Cominform.

The Bethlehem Steel Company's Staten Island shipyard was the apparent low bidder for a contract to build a new type of ice-breaker and oil tanker for the Military Sea Transportation Service, the Maritime Administration announced yesterday.
J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has declined an invitation by Mayor Wagner to become the city's next Police Commissioner.

Various forward-looking optimists have insisted that some day the common cold will be as rare as shingles, some day bridges will span the oceans. However, what science-fiction writer, what dreamer, what poet has ever dared propose that some day our subways would be air-conditioned?

MILWAUKEE, July 29 -- There was no catching the Braves tonight after the first three batters that faced Johnny Antonelli had hit safely and scored. From there Manager Cholly Grimm's runners-up proceeded to beat the Giants, 5 -- 2, posting their fifth straight triumph before 40,492 fans at County Stadium.
A plan to increase the scope of news coverage by the National Broadcasting Company was announced yesterday by Davidson Taylor, vice president in charge of public affairs for the network.
LONDON, July 29 -- The fortune of Calouste Gulbenkian, who died last week, was nowhere near the figure of $840,000,000 that had been reported in the newspapers, his attorney said today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board postponed today the planned Sept. 1 revocation of the operating authority of the four large non-scheduled airlines making up North American Airlines.
Harland Wolff, Ltd., of Belfast, one of the world's biggest shipyards, has enough vessels under construction or on order to keep "well occupied" until early 1957.

LONDON, July 29 -- The rally in Government stocks was extended slightly today on the last day of business before the long Aug. 1 week-end Bank Holiday. Gains ranged up to seven shillings sixpence ($1.05).
Market reactions to the President's earth-satellite announcement were upset by the confusion of investors.

NEW YORKERS are used to out-of-towners who inspect the marvels of the big city with wide-eyed wonder. But when the summer visitors are Japanese, young, pretty and dressed in colorful kimonos, Fifth Avenue shoppers take second glances.

May the writer be given an equal opportunity to rebut the recent letter of Arthur O. Dietz headed "Our Highway Needs." I most strongly protest the erroneous inference in the second half of the letter.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee approved today two long-pending nominations. Newell Brown, to be Wage and Hour Administrator, and Ewan Clague, for a new term as Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Department of Labor, were the nominees.
The Reynolds Metals Company, one of the three major American aluminum producers, is planning to split its common stock five-for-one.
Large-space newspaper advertising one day this week offered the product known throughout the world as Band-Aid under the private label of the retailer.
ALBANY, July 29 -- The Court of Appeals has ruled that a corporation's stockholders need not reimburse directors for the expense of a proxy fight that is "a purely personal power contest."

The city has reason to be thankful for the three reservoirs of the new Delaware system -- Rondout, Neversink and Pepacton. Thanks to the billions of gallons of water added to the city's reserves by these three reservoirs, the old Catskill and Croton systems are better than 85 per cent filled, despite the many days of blisteringly hot weather.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, was named today as having helped to draw up the original partnership agreement :that put Mr. Talbott and Mr. Mulligan in business together in 1951.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm prices declined 2 per cent during the month ending in mid-July.
RABAT, French Morocco, July 29 -- The expectation here is that the Sultan of Morocco, Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa, will have to withdraw before Aug. 20.

BONN, Germany, July 29 -- The Soviet Union and East Germany have begun to negotiate the release of hundreds of thousands of deported German civilians and prisoners of war still held in the Soviet Union.

HONG KONG, July 29 -- Red China's foreign trade in 1954 exceeded 9,000,000 tons and was valued at more than 8,400,000,000 yuan, it was announced today. At the Peiping Government's official rate for the United States dollar this sum is equal to $3,549,000,000.

The largest retirement of railroad securities this year lifted to $106,974,000 the total of bonds called for redemption in July before maturity. This was the largest for any month since March and compared with $87,496,000 retired in June and $209,865,000 in July, 1954.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The General Accounting Office said today it had not withdrawn its charge that the American Zinc, Lead and Smelting Company had sold zinc to the Government at a premium price while its president was an official in the buying agency.

The International Longshoremen's Association has asked Jacob Grumet for "clarification" of his report and recommendations on the punishment of 141 longshoremen for participation in a waterfront strike early last year.
Following is an outline of the program for the geophysical year issued yesterday by the United States National Committee for the International Geophysical Year 1957-58:
A former Government employe who invoked the Fifth Amendment in defiance of the immunity statute faced a jail term for criminal contempt yesterday.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 29 (Canadian Press) -- The St. Catherines Rowing Club of Ontario retained the lead in the Royal Canadian Henley regatta today by scoring two victories to lift their total to 169 1/4 points. The New York A. C. was second with 110 1/2.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Eisenhower said today that a properly unified Republican party could retain control of the national Administration "forever."
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Eisenhower intervened personally today and obtained approval of his atom-powered "peace ship" from the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy.
An ingenious balance of cosmic forces will allow an earth-circling satellite to ride the skies so long as forces are maintained in proper relationship.

A builder represented by Farber-Wittman, Inc., brokers, has purchased the three parcels forming a plot 75x100 feet at 321, 323 and 325 East Sixty-sixth Street for improvement with a six-story apartment house.
Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries yesterday reported increases in operating revenue and net income for the six and twelve months ended June 30.

PITTSBURGH, July 29 (AP) -- A possible strike at midnight Sunday of workers of the Aluminum Company of America was averted tonight. Rival American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organization Unions agreed on new wage pacts providing an average pay rise of 15 cents an hour.

Two New York City reservoirs in Westchester County soon may become available for private development. They are Byram Lake and Wampus Lake north of Kensico Reservoir and near Armonk, N. Y. As reservoirs, both have become obsolete.

The City Auto Stamping Company, Toledo, Ohio, has completed.negotiations_ for the purchase lof GlobeWerr{icke Company, Cincinnati, for about $6,000,000, including about $5,000,000 in cash, it was announced yesterday.

Even a rainy Monday morning is not so bad as a rainy Saturday afternoon. There is nothing worse, socially speaking, than a rainy Saturday afternoon. A rainy Saturday morning is not good, to be sure, but it at least submits notice that all of Saturday is likely to be a total loss, and everybody being so advised as soon- as he wakes up is prepared for the worst.

LENOX, Mass., July 29 -- The second week-end of concerts in the music shed and the fourteenth program of the current season got under way tonight at the Berkshire Music Festival. Charles Munch conducted the Boston Symphony, and the generous program consisted of Handel's "Water Music" Suite in the familiar arrangement by Sir Hamilton Harty, Schumann's Fourth Symphony, Samuel Barber's "Prayers of Kierkegaard" and the Fourth Symphony by Brahms.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The two organizations that took part in today's announcement of earth satellites are both connected with the Government.

PARIS, July 29 -- Hubert de Givenchy, the youngest of the Paris designers, shows a collection so bubbling, young and gay and packed with ideas that press and buyers here today gasped. His is the most fluid of the fluid lines up until now.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Mrs. Mary Knowles, librarian at Plymouth Meeting, Pa., told the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today that she had not been associated with the Communist party or other left-wing organizations "for many, many years."
Stock prices lost ground yesterday but closed on a firm note. Volume, at 2,070,000 shares, was the smallest in two weeks and compared with 2,090,000 shares on Thursday.

Black Record was easily the best in the main race at Jamaica yesterday. With a crowd of 17,701 on hand for the next to the last presentation of the Saratoga Association's downstate meeting, Black Record carried the colors of Edward Seinfeld to a three-length victory over Max Noble's South Point in the six-furlong purse called the Wyantskill.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 29 -- A Lightning Class ace, Fred Hibberd Jr. of the American Y. C., Rye, and Vincent J. (Bizzy) Monte-Sano Jr., son of the Larchmont Y. C. commodore, in the Blue Jay division, captured series honors in the two most populous classes of the first Eastern junior race week.

LONDON, July 29 -- Lord Adrian, president of the Royal Society, said here today the big problem with the earth-circling satellites to be built by the United States would be to get them to the planned height of 200 to 300 miles.
NOVOROSSISK, U. S. S. R., July 29 -- The American farm delegation was welcomed to this small Black Sea port tonight by a frenzied crowd of almost 10,000 persons.

BELLPORT, L. I. July 29 -- Competition for the Corry Trophy, emblematic of Great South Bay Star Class supremacy, came to a close today. Although Stan Ogilvy's Flame was finally defeated in this cruise week regatta, the Larchmont boat easily won the trophy for the second straight year.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Eisenhower's top aide, Sherman Adams, refused again today to testify in a Congressional investigation of the Dixon-Yates prvate power contract.

PARIS, July 29 -- Germany is potentially the greatest military power in Western Europe and a full-fledged partner in NATO. Nevertheless, until this week her role was approximately equivalent to that of the smallest alliance member, Iceland. That is to say, she made no contribution other than offering some highly convenient real estate for bases and troop accommodation.

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., July 29 -- This harbor was filling slowly all this afternoon with the sailing craft that will take part in one of the summer's tonier fixtures through New England waters. Tomorrow they will be off on the racing cruise of the New York Yacht Club.

BRUSSELS, July 29 -- Prof. Marcel Nicolet, secretary general of the special committee of the International Geophysical Year, was authorized today to make the first official announcement of the planned satellite to emphasize the international character of the operation.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's plan to share with Russia and other countries the scientific data obtained from a proposed earth satellite drew quick and sharp protests today from some members of Congress.
THE week-end angling opportunities find bluefish and school tuna in first place at most coastal fishing resorts from the mouth of the Delaware to Cape Cod.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 29 -- A bright afternoon sun brought traditional color and gaiety to the Ladies' Village Improvement Society Fair, highlight of the social season in this resort community.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The earth satellite will have no practicable military application in the foreseeable future. However, it will help man come to a better understanding of the natural laws of the universe.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 -- Three dishonorably discharged soldiers who renounced America two years ago for life in Communist China came home today to an emotional greeting from relatives and to an Army stockade.
CHICAGO, July 29 -- Irregular price moves featured the grain futures market today. There was an easier turn early, with rally in corn stimulating a little buying in other pits.

With the ink scarcely dry on the Austrian treaty which restores that country's sovereignty, rules out any reparations and specifically forbids any Soviet extra charges for the return of seized Austrian property, the Soviets have started to violate all these provisions.
HARTFORD, Conn., July 29 -An investigation of the operations of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was ordered today by the Connecticut Public Utilities Commission.
MRS. ALLEN FORTE of New York City, the professional photographer known as Sharland, is very much at home on the range.
Announcement yesterday of plans for an artificial earth satellite meant the culmination of thirty years of dreaming and research for a 62-year-old German who just arrived in this country.
JERSEY CITY, July 29 -- The Colgate clock, a landmark on the New Jersey side of the Hudson River since 1924, had a new pair of hands on its eighty-foot face today.

Following is the text of a letter from Joseph Kaplan, chairman of the United States National Committee for the International Geophysical Year, delivered yesterday in Brussels, Belgium, to Prof. Sydney Chapman, president of the Special Committee for the International Geophysical Year, on plans or a man-made earth satellite:

Three times as many women as men suffer from rheumatoid arthritis, according to a pamphlet just published by the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation. Most of these women get this crippling disease between the ages of 20 and 35.

MONTREAL, July 28 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Pacific Railway passed the halfway mark of 1955 with net earnings of $12,613,703, an increase of better than $4,000,000 from the first six months of 1954, the company reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The House of Representatives approved today a much-diluted housing bill. The measure does not carry out President Eisenhower's request for continuation of the public housing program.
Congress moved yesterday to investigate a problem that has plagued the Port of New York's shipping and waterfront industry for many years.

Congress drives toward adjournment with much work completed, some of it well and some of it badly done, and very important measures either abandoned or the subject of possible last-hour, hasty consideration. The mood is familiar, after adjournment fever spreads its contagion.
The American flag will appear on tankers of the 35,000-ton-plus class for the first time as the result of a contract announced yesterday by the Maritime Administration and the Esso Shipping Company.
The Budd Company, manufacturer of automotive parts, railway passenger cars and brakes and agricultural equipment, achieved record sales and earnings in the first six months of 1955.
New financing in July showedI a seasonal decline. The volume! of bonds and stocks publicly of-! fered here dropped from the totals of recent months and a year ago.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Republican Senators high in Administration councils said tonight that the resignation of Harold E. Talbott as Secretary of the Air Force was "imminent."

ATHENS, July 29 -- The Bulgarian authorities gave permission today to three members of the six-man Israeli commission to enter Bulgaria to investigate Wednesday's crash of the El Al airliner brought down by Bulgarian gunfire.
Cotton futures advanced 4 to 12 points on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.

Fernand van Langenhove of Belgium, president of the Security Council of the United Nations for July, and Mme. van Langenhove gave a dinner last night in the Louis XV Suite of the St. Regis for representatives from various countries serving on the Council.
CAIRO, July 29 -- Relations between the Sudanese and Egyptian leaders nearly reached the breaking point this week, according to a statement by the Sudanese Premier, Ismail el Azhari.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, June 29 -- Sometime this summer Indian and Kashmiri officials will crank open sluice gates to set going Kashmir's first new power plant in forty-five years.
Four men were arrested early yesterday on charges that they were submitting repair bills for $60 or $70 to owners of television sets although the repairs were worth only $5.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 29 -- The Bulgarian Government has agreed to pay at least part compensation for the shooting down of an Israeli airliner Wednesday. Fifty-eight persons, including twelve New Yorkers, died in the crash.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 29 (UP) -- The Florida Supreme Court today overruled the disbarment of Leo Sheiner, an attorney of Miami and New York, on grounds that it never has been proved that he is a Communist.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 29 -- Soviet contributions in rubles to the United Nations technical assistance program are being used to buy equipment from the Soviet Union rather than for sending its technicians abroad.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Manufacturers' sales reached $27,400,000,000 in June, a gain of 2 per cent from May and almost $4,000,000 higher than in June a year ago.

Audrey Christie, known on Broadway for her humorous characterizations of sharp-tongued blondes, is the leading contender for a major role in "The Desk Set." The play, a comedy by William Marchant, is scheduled to arrive at the Broadhurst Theatre on Oct. 13.

A leading economist has called for a "searching and fearless survey" of business ethics. The proposal was made yesterday by Harvard Professor Sumner H. Slichter, at the closing session of Stanford University's annual business conference.
PARIS, July 29 -- An agreement was reached tonight to reduce tensions and facilitate coexistence among the nations of West Europe.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Congress was caught tonight in the traditional minor frenzy of the eleventh-hour as the controlling Democrats labored urgently toward bringing this session to an end.

DETROIT, July 29 (AP) -- Work stoppages attributable to heat, some wildcat strikes and changeover operations hampered motor vehicle output this week, but 164,756 cars and 26,835 trucks are expected to be completed, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 -- Federal Judge Louis E. Goodman today refused to strip Harry Renton Bridges, Pacific Coast labor leader, of his United States citizenship.

John C. Siemer, former Staten Island bank teller, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court to an indictment charging him with embezzling $93,780 of his employer's funds. His bail was reduced from $50,000 to $35,000, but he was unable to raise it.
Nonclassified discussion by scientists of the best way to put an earth satellite into space has centered mainly on a three-stage rocket.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development made a loan yesterday of $18,200,000 to Guatemala to assist in financing road construction. The improvement is intended to stimulate agricultural production, Guatemala's main economic activity.

TOKYO, July 29 -- A Washington announcement that atomic cannon and rockets were being sent to United States forces in the Far East brought big headlines in the Tokyo press and sharp questioning of the Government in the Diet this afternoon.

CLARINDA, Iowa, July 29 -- Vladimir Matskevich, leader of the Soviet agricultural delegation touring the Midwest, promised today to "describe truthfully" to the Russian people the living conditions he had found in Iowa's fabulous farm areas.
