Sales and earnings of the Aluminum Company of America and its subsidiaries in the first half of this year were the highest for any six-month period in the history of the company. With third-quarter results expected to continue at the same high level, indications are that 1955 will be one of the best years on record, the company says.

AKRON, Ohio, July 29 (UP) -- Fred Hawkins and Henry Ransom, both playing out of St. Andrews, Ill., shot 66's today to take the lead at the halfway mark of the $15,000 rubber city open golf tournament. Each had 134 for two rounds.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- Mrs. Oveta Clup Hobby attended her last Cabinet meeting today and tearfully accepted a farewell gift from President Eisenhower and her colleagues.

J. B. Sidgwick, author of several books on astronomy, has three new works on Macmillan's list. The first to appear will be "William Herschel: Explorer of the Heavens," a biography of the personal astronomer to George III, discoverer of Uranus and the first man to reveal the structure of the galaxy of stars.

An important forward step in regard to Japan's Constitution has been taken by the Diet. Premier Hatoyama has been successful in obtaining approval of a measure that authorizes a committee to proceed with studies of constitutional revision.

From the White House comes the striking announcement that in two years or so the United States will launch artificial satellites which will be equipped with scientific instruments and which will play their part in carrying out the program of the International Geophysical Year.
PARIS, July 29 -- A Chinese Communist theatrical company and an American theatrical company have exchanged invitations to appear in each other's country.

Following is a transcript of the White House briefing, directed by the Presidential press secretary, James C. Hagerty, announcing plans for launching small earth-circling satellites between July, 1957, and December, 1958. The questions are by the reporters and the answers by Mr. Hagerty and the assembled scientists.
DETROIT, July 29 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers, C. I. O., pleaded innocent today to a four-count indictment charging it violated the Federal Corrupt Practices Act.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that its prices on surplus cotton for export in August would remain unchanged.

While the Yankees' principal rivals in the tense American League pennant race were having things a lot easier, the Bombers scrambled to a 3-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics at the Stadium last night.
DETROIT, July 29 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers, C. I. O., pleaded innocent today to a four-count indictment charging it violated the Federal Corrupt Practices Act.
A hundred policemen have requested transfers from the West 100th Street Station, one of the four precincts that Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams saturated with large numbers to fight crime.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- A House Judiciary subcommittee, headed by Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, today urged creation of an international refugee agency to find more homes for Europe's refugees elsewhere than in the United States.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Federal Housing Administration moved today to take control of Shore Haven, Inc., a huge apartment project in Brooklyn.
BUENOS AIRES, July 29 -- The semi-official newspaper Democracia opposed today a proposal for immediate repeal of the decree and law that placed Argentina "in a state of internal war."
PARIS, Saturday, July 30 -- The Government's emergency powers to fight terrorism in Algeria were extended to next April by the French National Assembly early this morning.

MONTREAL, July 29 (UP) -- Australia's Davis Cup team breezed to a 2-0 lead over Canada in the North American zone final today. Ken Rosewall defeated Bob Bedard, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2, and Rex Hartwig downed Lorne Main, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, before a crowd of 2,000 at the Mount Royal Tennis Club.
A $7,600 payroll was saved in an attempted Queens robbery yesterday, but the would-be thief escaped in a spray of bullets and a comedy of confusion.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Hog prices broke sharply today with the best quotation, $17, at a new low since March 18. A year ago on this date the top was $22.75. Losses ranged from 50 to 75 cents on all hogs. Prices at the finish were off the full 75 cents. Most 190 to 270 pound butchers sold at $15.75 to $16.50 with small lots at $16.75 and 71 head at the $17 top.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Senate ratified a new treaty tonight with the Republic of Panama granting it an increase of $1,500,000 over the present $430,000 annual payment for use of the Canal Zone.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 29 -- The two members of the Japanese Davis Cup team were defeated in the invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club today but not before one of them had taken a set from the defending cupholder.

Rubber futures prices on the Commodity Exchange soared to a new high for the life of the contracts yesterday. The 7,270 tons traded was the largest volume since World War II. The spot price of No. 1 smoked rib sheets was up 1 1/3 cents a pound to 44 3/4 cents, the highest level since May, 1952.
A company that plans to turn Shanks Village into a large-scale housing development bid $2,501,000 yesterday for the former Army camp site.
TOKYO, July 29 -- Japan's Communist party announced today its veteran leader, Kyuichi Tokuda, died nearly two years ago in the Red Chinese capital of Peiping.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. announced yesterday the appointment of Wallace E. Gordon as director of advertising, effective Sept. 1. He succeeds William A. Hart, who retires on Aug. 31 after thirty-one years with the company.
Ford C. Frick, the commissioner of baseball, took steps yesterday to bar major league teams from using the disabled list as a means of circumventing the twenty-five-player roster limit.
WAHN, Germany, July 29 (UP) -- The United States Army team won the General LeClerc small arms shoot yesterday for the second straight year, official scores released today showed.
RYE, N. Y., July 29 -- J. Henry Attas of Dellwood and Joseph A. Marra of Tamarack will meet in the thirty-six-hole final of the Westchester amateur golf championship at the Apawamis Club tomorrow.
LONDON, July 29 -- Sir Winston Churchill emerged briefly today from his seclusion to find that London and its crowds have not forgotten him.

Only a bare hint of the size, shape and structure of the proposed earth-circling satellite was available yesterday. The White House anouncement said only that the craft would be launched: tentatively, it will be round, the size of a basketball; it will travel around the earth every ninety minutes at a speed of 18,000 miles an hour in a path some 200 to 300 miles above the earth.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- This country plans to launch history's first man-made, earth-circling satellite into space during 1957 or 1958.

London, Saturday, July 30 (Reuters) -- Great Britain's national newspapers today greeted the news of the United States plan to shoot earth-circling satellites into space with front page banner headlines.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox scored three runs in the ninth inning to defeat the Senators, 5 -- 2, tonight and retain their American League lead. Virgil Trucks held Washington to six hits to gain his tenth victory.
The New York County second grand jury, which held its last meeting yesterday in the Criminal Courts Building, opened and closed its month's work with prayers.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange declined sharply this month.

KALAMAZOO, Mich, July 30 (UP)--Earl Buchholz of St. Louis, seedsd No. 1, and Ned Neely of Atlanta, No. 2, reached the final of the boys' division of the fortieth annual national junior and boys' tennis championships today.

BALTIMORE, July 30 (UP)-- Jim Dyck's fourth-inning single just past the outstretched glove of shortstop George Strickland was the only hit off Herb Score today as the Cleveland Indians beat the Baltimore Orioles, 7--0.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 30--A steady 12-to-15-knot breeze straight out of the East provided perfect sailing for the Yacht Racing Association's twenty-second regatta of the season today.

YOUNG people do not have the same amusements in every country. Sports do not have the same importance in France as in America--unless we consider literature as a sport and unless reading novels might advantageously replace attendance at baseball games.

NEWTOWN, Conn., July 30-- Two hundred and fifty years ago a pair of land speculators from Stratford accompanied by one out of New York completed a notable transaction here. The deal marked the beginning of Newtown, an event to be celebrated next Saturday.

SAN FRANCSCO, July 30--The Bay area's multi-million dollar wholesale floral industry is about to point the way to dressing up a down-at-the-heel business area. Three cooperative grower associations, comprising a total membership of almost 300, expect to begin construction of a $1,000,000 wholesale market next month.
TO THE EDITOR: John Gould's "The Importance of Being Ornery" (July 17) was interesting, amusing and illogical.
More centralized buying saved the city $10,000,000 in the fiscal year 1953-54, the Department of Purchase has announced.
PARIS, July 30 -- A bill has been drafted to reorganize Agence France-Presse, the major distributor of French news and foreign news in France.
Department store sales across the country in the week ended July 23 were 12 per cent higher than in the same week last year. It was the fourteenth consecutive weekly increase in retail volume.
WASHINGTON, July 30-- The Washington Senators, after losing twelve in a row to Chicago, nipped the White Sox, 1--0, today behind the sevenhit pitching of Bob Porterfield.

FEW desserts so delight the eye and excite the palate as fruit and cheese. Inviting at any season, the combination is particularly practical in late summer and fall when more fresh fruit is available than at any other time of the year.

Elevators are "talking" now. They're talking in New York and soon they'll be heard all over the country, even using the broad A in Boston. Their power of speech is due to the electronic brain controlling the operatorless elevators which are replacing the old attended type.

BRUSSELS, July 30--The Roman Catholic Episcopate of Belgium called on the faithful today to do everything possible to bring about the abrogation of the school reform law introduced by the Socialist-Liberal Government.
WASHINGTON, July 30--The House of Representatives approved, today the extension until June 30, 1956, of vital authorities granted under the Defense Production Act of 1950.

The Encampment for Citizenship, a six-week training course in youth leadership given at Fieldston School, Riverdale, will complete its tenth annual session this week with a "graduating class" of 126 young adults who were chosen by their communities as potential leaders.
CHICAGO, July 28--Illustrations and photographs of the newest atomic furnaces to produce peacetime power were displayed today by Argonne National Laboratory, Lemont, Ill.
Just how big is the freight car shortage--If any?

THIS is a series of a philosopher's fantasies, not all intended, as Lord Russell warns us in his preface, "to cause amusement." The philosopher, now in his ninth decade, seems to have lost none of his boyish prankishness.
A NEW area for exploration has been suggested to aircraft designers--a replacement for the DC-3.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: William L. Laurence in your issue of July 10 wrote an article in which he criticized the recent statement of Bertrand Russell, Albert Einstein and others. He said it ignores "the deterrent effect of the fission as well as the fusion bomb against any temptation by an aggressor to unleash a nuclear war against a victim."

Anxious and turbulent were the words for President Eisenhower's first two years in the White House. He was beset by great problems-- the worsening situation in IndoChina, the long delay over West German re-armament, the recession at home.
WEST HAMPTON BEACH, L. I., July 30--The Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual cruise week ended today with some sort of record set.

WASHINGTON, July 30-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon visited the Senate majority leader, Lyndon B. Johnson, at Bethesda Naval Medical Center today. He reported that the Texas Democrat, who is recuperating from a heart attack, was "looking fit" and predicted that he would be back at his post next session.

NEARLY forty years ago a critic wrote that the short stories of Wilbur Daniel Steele "represent the best that is being accomplished in America." Mr. Steele has sustained this reputation over a long period. Both as a short story writer and as a novelist (though here he is not on so sure a ground) he is a conscientious literary craftsman, with a technique and feeling for character that is outstanding.

A MAN who just recently got around to doing some much needed work on the upper trim of his house found that he was in for some vertical gardening. His is an oldish stucco house, festooned with vigorous ivy, trumpet vine and rambler roses. Very picturesque and much admired by all.
LONDON, July 30 -- Britain delivered a protest in the strongest terms to Bulgaria today against the downing of the Israeli airliner.

ON Fifty-seventh Street they have a term for the conducting field in this country --the checkerboard. It comes from the way a conductor will go from one orchestra to another until, he hopes, he is "crowned" with the leadership of a major orchestra.

MONTREAL, July 30 (UP)-- Australia clinched the honors in the American Zone Davis Cup final today when Lew Hoad and Rex Hartwig defeated Bob Bedard and Don Fontana in doubles for a 3-0 lead over Canada.
LONDON, July 30--Chris Chataway, pace-setter for Roger Bannister and John Landy a year ago, broke a world record today with a magnificent clocking of 13 minutes 23.2 seconds for three miles.
Work will begin about Aug. 15 on the new Youth House, or shelter for delinquent boys, at Barretto Street and Spofford Avenue, the Bronx.

IN one of the best of his ten novels, Frederic Prokosch has made a masterful reconstruction of a classic murder case which has generated novels, dramas, poems and nonfiction studies for centuries. Now that it has been done so well, I marvel that no contemporary novelist has come forward before this with the appalling story of the Cenci, a noble Roman family shattered by tragedy in the last years of the sixteenth century.

RYE, N. Y., July 30 -- The American Yacht Club's annual cruise, a 24-year-old sailing tradition on Long Island Sound, began early this afternoon. An overnight race to Duck Island Roads, off Clinton, Conn., was the first leg of the six-day event.

CHICAGO, July 30 (UP)--Bob Miller, a right-hander, hurled nine innings of shutout relief ball and Del Ennis smacked a two-run homer to pace the Philadelphia Phillies to a 3-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

FOR more than twenty years Professor of Philosophical Theology at Union Seminary in New York. Paul Tillich goes to Harvard next fall as University Professor of Religion. In this fascinating book he gives us the sermons that he has preached recently to students at Union Seminary and at Connecticut College for Women.
THE intimate war lives of the French flying officers in the Royal Air Force have at last been brought fittingly into literature in this exciting first novel by one of them.

Ted Atkinson had an enjoyable and profitable afternoon at Jamaica yesterday. Ditto for members of the Atkinson Rooting Marching and Ticket-Cashing Society who played his first three mounts and then decided not to "bet it all back!"

WASHINGTON, July 30--The most succinct way to characterize the first session of the Eighty-fourth Congress, which appears to have only a few more days to run, is as a triumph of coexistence. A Republican President has got a creditable portion of his program enacted, and a Democratic Congress proudly congratulates itself on the achievement.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In recent weeks many news stories concerning three American soldiers returning from China have appeared in our newspapers and other media of information. Almost without exception they have been referred to as "turncoats." I wish to protest the constant use of this ugly and opprobrious term.

BOTH British and American mystery novels often change titles when they cross the Atlantic --and frequently with unfortunate results, as when Dorothy Sayers' provocatively titled "The Five Red Herrings" acquired in America the untempting name of "Suspicious Characters."

The American League pennant race tightened yesterday with three teams in a virtual tie for first place. The Yankees lost to the Athletics, 12 to 2, and were tied for second place by the Indians, who toppled the Orioles, 7--0.

Jacob Grumet will give "due consideration" to a request by the International Longshoremen's Association for a "clarification" of his report and recommendations as to punishment of 141 New York longshoremen for a twenty-nine-day dock strike early in 1954.
With East-West tensions officially eased as a result of the Geneva conference, a basic shift in factors determining United States trade policies appears likely soon.

SOME 1,800 years ago the Alexandrian, Ptolemy, in his great astronomical work, the Almagest, listed the positions of 1,022 stars in the sky. Century after century since then man has pushed his frontier of knowledge farther into the heavens, ever reaching out for the unknown.

CLEVELAND, July 30 (UP)-- Joseph L. Rauh Jr., chairman of Americans for Democratic Action, charged tonight that President Eisenhower was personally responsible for the "most corrupt" administration since that of President Harding.

LONDON, July 30--The Observer, influential Sunday newspaper, reports in its editions for tomorrow that the Soviet Union has promised Hungary and Rumania that it will withdraw its occupation troops in October. Such withdrawal would coincide with the scheduled end of the occupation of Austria.

MILAN, Italy, July 30--Italians are spending less of their disposable income for textiles and apparel and more for hard goods, such as motor scooters and small automobiles. This trend has aggravated the Italian textile "crisis" that began a year or more ago, when many foreign customers curtailed their orders.

I believe a publio [official's] actions [must be] impeccable, both from the standpoint of law, and from the standpoint of ethics. So what is now involved is: Was a proper standard of ethics violated? * * * Was an office used improperly or was a man in an office merely trying to use his own personal influence completely divorced from his office?

Diamond heroes of the past climbed down from baseball's Valhalla yesterday to disport themselves for a few pleasant moments on the green of Yankee Stadium. Then they climbed back again and what they saw from aloft must have left them a trifle puzzled.
WASHINGTON, July 30--Credit terms on home purchases under Federal mortgage guarantee programs were stiffened today. This action was described as a precaution against possible inflationary dangers.

THE world-of-tomorrow envisioned by these two authors is a strange and frightening one, the more so because its seeds can be seen in today's society. Charles Mundin, a young lawyer whose practice and future are limited because he has not been born into one of the great hereditary legal families, faces a world in which cruelty is commonplace.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 30--Dan Huntting, solid claimant to the title of "Long Island's Oldest Cowboy," will be back in the saddle again tomorrow.

OF about twenty LP listings of music by Carl Nielsen, three-fourths have been recorded by London Records. But London does not "own" Nielsen, as one might sometimes think, and to prove the fact Victor has released an H. M. V. disk containing the Danish composer's Violin Concerto.
A turnabout in the Soviet Union's attitude appears to have been caused by the White House announcement Friday of plans for a space satellite.

ONCE last winter, while I was working on a new play in Wilmington, Del., my telephone rang at 8:30 A. M., which is abnormally early for most of us in the theatre. A voice from the hotel lobby told me he was from the university, where I had promised to speak that morning to the drama class.

Stocks made a labored attempt to extend their recovery last week, but after a firm start the market lost its early gains and closed irregularly lower. Thus, July came to a close with The New York Times combined average down 2.67 points for the week.

A thrilling ride through city streets in an ambulance recently started an excited contingent of boys and girls on a trip for a health-building stay at the Tuberculosis Preventorium for Children at Farmingdale, N. J.
Seven key Connecticut volunteer Civil Defense workers have resigned in protest against what they called political dismissals in the organization.

THE green and pleasant Connecticut countryside beyond New Haven manages to hold its rural character intact against the encroachments of suburbia. In like manner, but with less happy results, the Lyme Art Association at Old Lyme conducts a skillful retreat away from the forces that have stirred painting from top to bottom during the last sixty years.
MONTREAL, July 30 (Canadian Press)--Canada Steamship Lines has urged that Canada's coastal shipping trade be limited after Jan. 1, 1957, to ships built in Canada.

FOR use on arbor table saws, a tapered-edge aluminum alloy sanding plate has an abrasive paper fastened to each side. The disc fits in place of the saw blade and the tapered edge permits feeding work into it without tearing the paper.

CHICAGO, July 30--The Hasty House Farms' Platan, ridden by Johnny Adams, raced to victory in the American record time of 1:54 3/5 today to earn $104,650 in the mile and three-sixteenths Arlington Handicap. Grossing $161,600, this was the world's richest race on grass.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UP) --The Senate passed and sent to the House of Representatives today a bill authorizing District of Columbia Commissioners to seize and operate the strikebound Capital Transit Company and cancel the company's franchise.

The 1,500 chemists who attended the meeting of the International Congress of Pure and Applied Chemistry at Zurich, Switzerland, last week heard news which was of as much importance to the world as it was to them as professional manipulators of atoms and molecules.

Ever since the Korean War the threat of inflation has been stopped dead in its tracks. Now, however, many bsuiness observers are beginning to wonder if a major break in the price front is in the making.
Some time ago an East Side woman became highly annoyed when her bicycle was stolen. She undertook a little private investigation, which uncovered a juvenile delinquency problem in her neighborhood.

PARIS, July 30 -- Governor Harriman of New York said today foreign policy would be an issue in the 1956 campaign if right wing Republicans forced President Eisenhower to abandon "Democratic Objectives."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 30--An audacious move against Eastern European Communist officials who cling to the Stalinist attitude toward the Yugoslav regime is being attributed to President Tito.

PHILATELY'S expanding portrait gallery may be enriched in September by a likeness of Ethan Allen (1738-1789), the American Revolutionary commander who, with Benedict Arnold, captured Fort Ticonderoga, sometimes called "The Key to a Continent," on May 10, 1775.

Wreckers were busy last week tearing out the sturdy old bank vaults from the site of the proposed Bank of New York Building, a twenty-five-story office structure soon to rise at 530 Fifth Avenue, at Forty-fourth Street.

The ocean-going tanker fleet under the United States flag was reduced by 338,000 deadweight tons in the first six months of this year, the American Merchant Marine Institute, reported yesterday. A further shrinkage was said to be indicated.

ALL newspaper men with real ink in their veins are supposed to yearn for their own weekly newspaper, particularly in some place where fishing is fine and the skies are not cloudy all day. Ed Groshell, news editor of The Chicago Daily Times, had his mind made up for him when that paper disappeared in a merger.

AS I read these stories, collected by a man whose collections of Ozark folklore have made his name synonymous with the region, I am reminded of a Christmas Day party I attended years ago in Williamsburg, Va., before the Rockefeller millions had completely turned the old town into

With the summit meeting over, the focus last week swung back to the Far East. There, deep conflicts remained to be solved -- conflicts that only a few months ago seemed to have brought Communist China and the United States perilously close to war.
MOSCOW, Sunday, July 31-- The Soviet Union today ordered its 44,000 occupation troops withdrawn from Austria by Oct. 1. It announced that the Soviet armed forces would be reduced by that number.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 30-- The Far West is about to commemorate a century of railroading.

The problem of what to do with exceptionally talented children--who can be "problem children" if their talents are misdirected--is the subject of a report issued by the Horace Mann-Lincoln Institute of School Experimentation of Teachers College.

OFTEN people with small gardens feel that they do not have room for all the plants that they would like to grow. But where there is a fence or wall, there is a way, for many decorative shrubs and trees can be trained against them as espaliers.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 30 --Indonesia is approaching the first general election in the history of the young republic in an unhealthy atmosphere of crisis.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 30-- An attempt to crush at home the political power of the United States Senate's acting majority leader, Earle C. Clements of Kentucky, has agitated a Democratic factional struggle in this state.
Dr. Hugh E. Agnew, Professor Emeritus of Marketing at New York University, died in his home, 80 Quaker Ridge Road, Manhasset, L. I., yesterday afternoon. He was 80 years old.
DETROIT, July 30 (AP)--The era of complete pushbutton motoring may be closer than one thinks.

AS more and more early music is recorded, the past emerges from silence the way a photographic print, thrown into developing fluid, emerges from an apparently blank sheet of paper. What is in the choral corner can now be more clearly discerned, and that part of the picture is further developed by recent releases.

CINCINNATI, July 30 (UP)-- Jackie Collum of the Cincinnati Redlegs threw "gopher" balls to Frank Thomas and Gene Freese today and then went on to complete a five-hit, 5-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates with the help of Ted Kluszewski's thirtyfourth homer.
Sponsors of housing developments in Suffolk County are showing several new models to meet the demands of the summer market on Long Island.

Just what is a "race" ? Anthropologists do not like the term. Skin color is no indication of race, though taken with other indications it may have its value. Neither are physical characteristics trustworthy, taken individually. High cheekbones, for example, are as common among Slavs as among Monoglians.

FORT ROSS STATE HISTORICAL MONUMENT, Calif.--The weatherworn headquarters of Russian traders and otter hunters set up on the northern California coast nearly a century and a half ago are being restored.
BALTIMORE, July 30 (AP)-- Tugboat crewmen in Baltimore harbor voted today to end a strike they started July 12.
WASHINGTON, July 30--The proper definition of propriety in the public service has created in Washington the most live political topic of the departing first session of the Eighty-fourth Congress.

MOSCOW, July 30--Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas of the United States was warned by Pravda today to avoid what the paper called "ignorant" statements such as his reported suggestion that certain Asian Republics of the U. S. S. R. could be restored to independence.

Although final figures have not yet been compiled, it is estimated that more than 1,000,000 persons have skipped all or part of their vacations this year to attend summer classes in the nation's colleges. Some, of course, are there under pressure to make up lost time or credits.

RAISING money for a European tour by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in 1930 was a lot easier than it is in 1955. Those were the days, even though the market had crashed in the fall of 1929, when a few individuals could and would underwrite the deficit of such a trip, and it was accomplished with several telephone calls.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UP) --Congress blanked the Eisenhower Administration's plea for funds to expand the Government's housing and construction survey work, but one agency is considering a plan to expand without the requested funds.

The first session of the Eightyfourth Congress approached its last hours with the usual swift passage of long-debated measures, the usual postponement of difficult issues, the usual tumult followed by silence.

LIKE the majority of Broadway musicals, "Plain and Fancy" has been under close West Coast scrutiny since it opened last January at the Mark Hellinger to enthusiastic critical and public response. Last week, a spokesman for the producers of the musical, which describes the invasion of an Amish community by two seasoned New Yorkers, disclosed that Hollywood bids are now narrowed to three main contenders.

In 1892 John D. Archbold, a Rockefeller partner, organized a riding and driving club on his Knollwood estate near White Plains. Here his friends from the nearby countryside and from New York would gather on week-ends.
ST. LOUIS, July 30--The Dodgers beat the Cardinals tonight, 6--0, with Johnny Podres and Don Bessent collaborating in wielding the whitewash brush.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30-- The $360,000 project to rebuild Robin Hood Dell got under way yesterday. Only hours after the last summer concert of the year in the picturesque Fairmount Park amphitheatre, bulldozers began clearing the site for a new bandshell designed for finer acoustics and improved facilities.

The concept of family living and attitudes toward a home have changed as much as its outside appearance in recent years, according to Fred R. Brunetti, president of the Home Builders Association of Northern New Jersey.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 30 --The mammoth Berkshire music Festival, with, its many and varied activities, generally commands the most attention among American music festivals. But there are in the vicinity several more modest endeavors in the way of summer festivals--and older ones, too.

VALDIVIA, Chile, July 30 (AP)--More than twenty earthquakes rocked this Southern Chile resort city yesterday and today. They tumbled scores of homes in three provinces and shook two volcanoes into new activity.
A Division of Fire Fighting Equipment has been established by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.

DEFYING the heat and ignoring the customary midsummer somnolence in art circles, the Guggenheim Museum has opened an exhibition of some seventy paintings, drawings and pieces of sculpture in its collection.

The petroleum industry in the free world established new records in virtually every division in the first half of 1955. With the demand for oil products continuing at a record level, another banner year for the industry appears in prospect.

FEW efforts in the theatre have been so personalized as Margo Jones' Theatre '55 in Dallas. An ebullient and vivid personality, she had spoken for it, fronted for it, greeted its patrons at the portals, made the intermission pitches for season subscribers and loaded the local press with interviews.
WASHINGTON, July 30--This summer might bring the greatest influx of American legislators to the Soviet Union in recent history.

Many a man now within hailing distance of the Jack Benny years can recall with little effort the advertising injunction that used to adorn the transit lines: "All passengers in this car," it read firmly, "will please change to Reis underwear."
THE retail automobile industry is suffering from economic indigestion.
Union negotiators seeking a new contract for milk tanktruck drivers rejected early today a proposal by milk dealers to arbitrate disputed issues, including wages.

HIROSHIMA. TEN years after this city was left a mass of smoking debris in one fearful gust of heat and force, a single building only remains in ruins. This wreck, formerly the stately Industrial Exhibition Hall, is preserved deliberately as a reminder and symbol.
Grace Line officials, including C. C. Mallory, chairman of the board, joined last week in honoring Capt. Albin A. Andersen. He will retire tomorrow after fortyone years of service with the company.
EVERY gun crank, most varmint shooters and the majority of deer hunters will be interested to learn that the trend toward the small caliber, high velocity bullet has advanced a long step.

THE theme of love and passion between a man and a woman from different latitudes is always a lively and interesting one, if only because it permits some of us to see how incomprehensible we seem to others, how irrational are the things we take for granted in our own meridian.

ANNOUNCEMENT of the first independent laboratory to process Kodachrome miniature color film for the general public other than Eastman Kodak Company, which introduced the film twenty years ago and has been processing it exclusively ever since, was made last week by Pathecolor, Inc.
WASHINGTON, July 30--The first session of the Eighty-fourth Congress wearily and rather grumpily gave up tonight for good its long-held plan to adjourn this week-end.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- A strong protest against the shooting down of an Israeli airliner Wednesday was sent to the Bulgarian Government today by the United States.
NOVOROSSIISK, U. S. S. R., July 29 -- The American farm delegation got a rare glimpse today of the luxury-goods trade in this proletarian society.

But as there are many things that I cannot help doing that the universe can, I do not venture to assume that my inabilities in the way of thought are inabilities of the universe.

IT was the rich oil fields lying outside Maneppo that gave that Syrian town its international importance. It was the reason for the uneasy British colony, the British troops (at a distance from the faraway capital).

IT has been said--and so far as we remember it has not been refuted--that more books have come out of the American Civil War than any other war in history. The rage to relive the battles of that bloody conflict goes on unabated, and there are more professional and amateur historians of those famed attacks and counterattacks than there are machines at IBM or men who wear gray flannel suits.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)-- The Federal Housing Administration began action today to take control of the Glen Oaks Village apartment development at Bellerose, Long Island. The step was taken in an effort to recover $4,600,000 in alleged "windfall" profits.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 30 (AP) --Brooke's Honor scored by half a length over Chestertown Boy in the Woodmere Pace in 2:03 2/5 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Ichabod Crain finished third in the mile event.

The United Seamen's Service is setting up full-scale shoreside programs for merchant seamen of all flags in the Iranian ports of Abadan and Bandar Mashur, Otho J. Hicks, executive director of the service has announced.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 30--The seven-year-old Communist insurrection in Malaya may be brought to an end as a result of the Alliance party victory in last Wednesday's federal elections.

The revival of disarmament negotiations should demonstrate fairly soon whether the cordial personal contacts made at Geneva will produce any real improvement in SovietAmerican relations. Findings of the United Nations Disarmament Subcommittee will not be conclusive, since they will be reviewed later by the Big Four Foreign Ministers; but those findings ought to reveal how much foundation there is for the sweetness and light of post-Geneva statements in Washington and Moscow.

ORIGINAL, photographs by Edward Weston printed under his supervision by his son, Brett Weston, are now available at $25 each from Brett Weston, Wild Cat Hill, Carmel, Calif. The prints are the result of a project completed under a grant donated for the purpose of making several prints each from a list of 1,000 negatives selected by the photographer from the work of a lifetime.
WASHINGTON, July 30--The seeds of a controversy between scientists and politicians began to sprout today in this country's project for sending an earthcircling satellite into space.
CLARK AIR FORCE BASE, the Philippines, July 18--There is a small American community here that has all the comforts of many a United States town --and more.

EACH month of the growing season has its peaks of bloom from the major flowers, the familiar "backbone" performers such as phlox and lilies. But the bed or border needs extras--call them lesser lights--to enhance the featured stars of the garden show.
MILWAUKEE, July 30--There is in this baseball-wild community a young man in a dilemma, and all because the Braves beat the Giants, 5--3, today at County Stadium for their sixth straight victory.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)-- The House passed by voice vote and sent to the Senate today a bill to raise the pay of top officials in Government. Cabinet members would get a $2,500 increase to $25,000 a year.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 30 (UP)--Press censorship has been reimposed throughout Colombia, ending nearly two years of relative freedom for the newspapers, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 30--The more the officials of this Administration look at the results of the Geneva Big Four conference, the better they like what they see and what they hear from the capitals of the world.

At mid-year the nation's building industry is turning out more work than ever before and there is no sign that it will let up, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation, research organization for the building trades.

IN our day, those two gifted whipper-snappers Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein II, have achieved considerable acclaim in the musical theatre. But the lads have a long way to go before they are granted the idolatry accorded to Edward Harrigan, actor and playwright, and Anthony Hart, actor, more simply Harrigan and Hart, in the New York of the Eighteen Seventies and the Eighteen Eighties.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial "Tito's New Tune" you say that "perhaps most inexplicable is Tito's decision to choose this time to announce his defiance of American suggestions for close supervision over military aid deliveries to Yugoslavia."
Television's future in the nation's banks is brightening.

WASHINGTON, July 30--Senator Wayne Morse, renewing his demand that Harold E. Talbott resign or be dismissed, called tonight for further investigation of the Air Force Secretary's outside business activities.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 30 (AP)--Americans took the classic events -- the championship singles and the senior eights --but the St. Catharines Rowing Club won the team title with 315 1/4 points today in the seventy-third annual Royal Canadian Henley regatta.

RABAT, French Morocco, July 30--The Moslem Greater Festival of Bairam was celebrated within the heavily guarded precincts of the Imperial Palace at Rabat today. Observances elsewhere had been banned by the Moroccan nationalists in token of their opposition to the reigning Sultan, Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa.

Early, American interiors will be featured in the new development at Orchard Park in Huntington, L. I., where a preview of models is being held at Caladonia Road, west of Deer Part Road in the Dix Hills estates area of that community.
MAMARONECK, N. J., July 30--On a rough and raging Long Island Sound, Dr. Allen B. Du Mont won another predicted-log cruiser contest this afternoon.

OCEANPORT, N. J. July 30-- Saratoga won the $29,050 Choice Stakes at Monmouth Park today. The son of Blenheim II carried the Montpelier colors to victory by a head over Clifford Mooers Traffic Judge in the mile and a furlong fixture for 3-year-olds.

WHEN planning to paint stucco, brick, or other masonry surfaces around the outside of the house, it is well to make certain that the paint to be used is one which has been specifically designed for that purpose.

A WHOLE new field of medicine -- travel medicine -- that directly affects the tourist both at home and abroad has developed in the postwar years. It deals with immunization by inoculations and vaccination, and with problems arising from exposure to new and unfriendly bacteria in strange places.

THERE are within the 281 pages of this novel a series of sore-fire combinations. There are the combinations of sex and dismal background, sex and colorful characterizations, sex and sadism, sex and breathless action, sex and suspenseful writing.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Unless community restrictions forbid, water lawns, shade trees, deciduous and evergreen shrubs once a week. Bloom on roses will be better if they are watered too. Soak the soil thoroughly, allowing water to run slowly from the hose for a minimum of three hours. Then cultivate all plantings except lawns if there is no mulch.
WAHOO, Neb., July 30--Russia's junketing farm officials were beginning today to act like a travel-weary group of American business men.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 30-- Prof. Allan Nevins, a "humble biographer but at heart a historian," declared this week-end that biography could never be accurate in presenting an understanding of the past.

IN 1832 Washington Irving, just returned to America at the height of his fame, joined the expedition of Treaty Commissioner Henry L. Ellsworth to the Indian country of present Oklahoma. Later, he published a lively account of his experiences in "A Tour on the Prairies."

TOMORROW will mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the introduction of the flash lamp in this country and the end of the flash-powder era. On Aug. 1, 1930, flash powder on a metal tray gave way to the bottled sunlight of foil enclosed in a glass bulb.

RYE, N. Y., July 30--J. Henry Attas of Dellwood, regained the Westchester County Gold Association amateur championship today. He defeated Joe Marra of Tamarack, 2 and 1, in the scheduled 26-hole final at the Apawamis Club.

THERE once was a cautious producer in Hollywood named Abe Stern who was supposed to have stopped an ambitious director from charging off into the hinterland with the remark, "A rock is a rock and a tree is a tree, shoot it in Griffith Park!"
CHICAGO, July 30 (AP)--Pat Lesser of Seattle routed Carol Diringer of Tiffin, Ohio, 7 and 6, in their scheduled thirty-six-hole title match of the fifty-fifth women's Western amateur tourney today.
SLOATSBURG, N. Y., July 30 --A 200-acre tract in the rolling foothills of the Ramapo Mountains here was opened for residential development today.
LONDON, July 30--The economic difficulties Britain is experiencing are largely a result of the unprecedented prosperity she has had.

To the Travel Editor: IN a recent issue, you published a letter from the Planning and Development Commission of New Hampshire in which that state disputed Rhode Island's claim to the title "America's First Vacationland."

THE problem is no longer one of keeping up with the Joneses, but of keeping away from them. Of being able to enjoy the Grand Canyon, Old Faithful and other long-looked-forward-to natural beauty spots undisturbed by elbowing humanity, undismayed by empty beer cans and discarded sandwich wrappers.

BERKELEY, Calif., July 28-- A nation-wide move has been quietly put under way to improve the lot of the emeritus professor by using his talents and giving him a moral and economic lift in his retirement.

AUGUST officially arrives tomorrow and to the gladiolus fancier it means showtime. Starting this week and throughout the rest of the month, shows will he opening here and there across the nation. And growers, whether professional or backyard dabblers, will be earmarking their most promising spikes for a possible blue ribbon.

Services for teen-agers in Manhattan, Bronx and Staten Island branches of the New York Public Library arc outlined in a new brochure of the Office of Young People's Services. Copies may be obtained free at any of the neighborhood libraries or in the Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street building.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Now that the conference at the summit has opened the way for more detailed discussion of solutions to the international problem, we would like to make one specific suggestion.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sunday, July 31--The Chinese Nationalists rejected early today Premier Chou En-lai's suggestion that the "peaceful liberation" of Formosa be discussed between Peiping and the authorities here.
HONG KONG, July 30--Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China called today for the signing of a collective peace pact among countries of the AsianPacific region, including the United States.
LONDON. THE young actress most sought after by film producers in England today isn't Grace Kelly or Audrey Hepburn. She's the trumpet-playing model of "Genevieve," Kay Kendall.

The city's two obsolete reservoirs at Byram Lake and Wampus Lake in Westchester will be turned into state parks if Parks Commissioner Robert Moses has his way. He expressed that hope yesterday after the disclosure that the city might soon make the reservoir areas available for private development.

August is the year at early harvest, a farm wife with a baby napping in the crib, a preserving kettle on the stove, fryers in the freezer, new potatoes in the pot, and a husband in the hay field baling the second cutting. August is tomatoes ripening and the insistent note of the cicada punctuating the heat of midafternoon.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)-- The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today the nomination of Dudley C. Sharp as Assistant Secretary of the Air Force.

LONDON. THE most exciting, farreaching and controversial change in the British broadcasting system since it was started thirty-three years ago takes place on Sept. 22. Amid much confusion and uncertainty this has emerged as a definite date for the start of commercial television transmissions from the London station of the Independent Television Authority, set up as a rival to the British Broadcasting Corporation by act of Parliament.

HOLLYWOOD. THE Council of Motion Picture Organizations has begun the audience award poll it proposes to conduct annually. The purpose is to let the public vote for what it regards as the best picture, best performance (male and female) and most promising newcomer (male and female) during the twelve-month period from October to October.

MANY home craftsmen have given up in disgust after spending an hour or so trying to get a blow torch to burn with the proper not blue flame. The gas in the priming cup must heat the valve seat and the combustion chamber evenly, and this will not take place in a draft.

LONDON. UNDER the Royal Marriages Act of 1772 no member of the British Royal Family may marry before reaching 25 without the consent of the sovereign. A marriage contracted without such consent is null and void.

WASHINGTON, July 30--The lobby groups that for months have labored for and against the natural gas bill have just begun to fight. The bill gained House approval this week, but Senate action is to go over to next session.

AS our Giants plod their way through the West, winning one here, losing one there, the picture is scarcely the one that Polo Grounds enthusiasts envisioned last March. True, their plight is no worse than that of six other entries in the National League. It is not even so bad as some, considering the New Yorkers are still keeping their chins above the 500 level in the backwash of the scudding Dodgers.

The first and probably the most important issue taken up at the Geneva "summit" meeting was German unification. All signs at Geneva pointed to long delay before unification could be achieved. But the problem goes to the root of the "cold war." The division of Germany is the direct result and a most striking symbol of the East-West rift.
BUENOS AIRES, July 30-- A policeman was killed early today and another was wounded by unknown assailants while they were on duty guarding a suburban Roman Catholic Church.

JERUSALEM, July 30--Israel's party leaders are busy with their lightning calculators. A small number of still-uncounted votes in last Tuesday's parliamentary election could change the allotment of several seats. But while mathematicians are busy with these details, the public, in general, pursues another calculation--"What will B-G do?"

ANAHEIM, Calif.--When the loud speaker at Los Angeles International Airport boomed out the information that a shuttle-helicopter was leaving for Disneyland, an elderly lady was overheard asking, "Is that in California?"
WRITTEN in a gentle, almost affectedly quiet style, 'Watching at the Window" traces out a pair of gradually drawn - together story lines to a grim and deadly conclusion.

WASHINGTON, July 30--Senator Walter F. George said today that Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China "sounded conciliatory" in his remarks about the Washington-Peiping talks scheduled to begin Monday in Geneva.
Construction levels have been maintained and in some areas of the South Shore and central sections of Nassau County have increased for both moderate priced and luxury homes.

HONG KONG, July 30--Unaccustomed as they are to anything but discordant notes from Washington and Peiping, political observers here were jarred a bit this week when similar communiques came out of the United States and Communist China.
HOLLYWOOD WORTHINGTON MINER, executive producer of "Medic," has two new documentary-type programs on tap for next season. One is called "Frontier" and the other "The Challenge."

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 30--Favoring a lame shoulder, Tony Trabert, the player on whom the United States' Davis Cup hopes rest, was carried to five sets by Herbert Flam in the semi-finals of the Meadow Club invitation tennis tournament today. Trabert won by 6--8, 6--1, 6--4, 2--6, 6--1.

THE American Federation of Television and Radio Artists has under consideration a critically important proposal designed to combat Communist influences in broadcasting. Unfortunately, there has been little or no discussion of the measure, yet it merits the most searching and careful study before its adoption.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 30 --William P. Jenks of Mount Kemble Avenue, retired stockbroker who was for many years senior member of the old New York Stock Exchange firm of Jenks, Gwynne Co., died today in a local hospital.

ONE expects a book by Reinhold Niebuhr to be extraordinarily discerning, timely and relevant. This one is no exception. Moreover, in this volume we have an analysis and exposition of the nature of the self that has been assumed and only partially delineated in previous works by the author.

It was for me in my student days exactly what William James had prophesied: "One of those moral crises that become starting points and high-water marks, and leave traditions and rallying cries and new forces behind them."
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis has completed its summer phase of shipments of polio vaccine in areas where second shots are being given during school vacations.

Sessions on industrial, press, commercial and portrait photography, a historical pageant covering three-quarters of a century, and a trade show of new photographic products, will be among the principal features of the seventy-fifth anniversary meeting of the Photographers' Association of America to be held Aug. 15-19 at the Conrad Hilton Hotel in Chicago.

ELEANOR OLHA, whose "Hickory Dickory Dock" is a sort of early early show on WCBS-TV Saturday mornings at 8:30, regards her television chores as something of a bus man's holiday.

THERE are some beautiful bridge hands, found in advanced textbooks, in which the defenders have a "sure" trump trick, but the declarer by very skillful play can avoid losing it. Any bridge player would enjoy executing such a play, but perversely he would find even more enjoyment if he could make the opponents lose their "sure" trump trick not by force but by a swindle.

THE boom in Toulouse-Lautrec's reputation has had the effect, customary in such a case, of promoting a too uncritical acceptance of his work. For me he is seldom an easel painter of the very first rank. He made mistakes on canvas analogous to those of Gauguin, another post and "anti" impressionist, illustrating a derived conception of art rather than one achieved through the processes themselves of oil, canvas and immediate experience.

TRAFFIC congestion probably costs the American people some $30 billions a year. This is about what they pay in personal income taxes and it's half of all that's being spent for highway construction and maintenance during the last thirty-five years.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., July 30 (AP)--Marilynn Smith of Wichita, Kan., set a course record for women today when she fired a 34, 36--70 to gain a first-place tie at 147 in the $5,000 Battle Creek women's open golf tournament.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30-- Department store sales in the Third Federal Reserve District were 2 per cent higher this June than last and the highest on record for that month, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reports.

EVENTS in television take surprising turns. It developed last week that the Aluminum Company of America, which dropped sponsorship of Edward R. Murrow's "See It Now" program, has taken an option on the show's former time period.
Memphis, Tenn., has done "just what we said we'd do about building our own power plant" instead of taking power from Dixon-Yates.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 30 --Lloyd Waddell Smith of Florham Park, who died July 2, left his collection of Americana-- centering on George Washington --to the Morristown Historical National Park.

AT least 10,000,000 good, bad and indifferent used cars will be sold in this country before the end of the year. As a general rule the buyers of these vehicles are bargain hunters and many experienced dealers utilize this desire to dispose of their wares at the best profit obtainable.

UNQUESTIONABLY one of the supremely great figures in the history of Christianity, St. Augustine of Hippo combined breadth of human interest with deep religious insight, superb dialectical powers, and consummate literary skill.

THE third son of Ring Lardner will be remembered by moviegoers as one of the more brilliant scenarists of the Nineteen Forties ("Woman of the Year," "Four Days' Leave"). The general reader will recall that his Hollywood career ended abruptly after he had served a prison term for declining to answer questions before the House Committee on Un-American Activities in 1947.

"You may dramatize the scenes in any way you wish, but whatever episodes you employ must be justified to me in terms of recognized authorities.

IN all history was there ever a more fantastic episode than the Klondike gold rush? When Siwash George Carmack found gold in a Canadian moose pasture in 1896, his discovery set off a wild stampede. In the next three years, about 100,000 men--mostly Americans--headed north.

PROPERLY placed trees, shrubs and lawn can effectively air-condition a home. Shrubs and trees may actually insulate the outside of the house, for they can decrease the sun's radiation by more than 75 per cent.

THE reputation of Conyers Read as a master in Tudor history has been long and firmly established. His three-volume biographical - historical treatise, "Mr. Secretary Walsingham and the Policy of Queen Elizabeth," published thirty years ago, is a monument of erudition and remains the indispensable authority on the career and achievements of one of the great Ministers of Elizabeth the Great.
BOSTON, July 30--(UP) Ray Boone drove in three runs with a triple and double to pace the Detroit Tigers to a 5-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox today. A crowd of 22,481 attended at Fenway Park.
FRIBOURG, Switzerland. FOR any tourists who may have thought of yodeling as a sort of Alpine whoopee, the Tenth Annual Yodel Festival of the Swiss Confederation here was certainly an eye-opener.

AKRON, Ohio, July 30 (AP)-- Tommy Bolt of Chattanooga, the 1954 winner, dropped out of the $15,000 Rubber City open golf tourney in the third round today. Henry Ransom of St. Andrews, III., continued to set the pace, shooting a 67 for a 54-hole total of 201.
Five hundred Army Reservists from New York State are coping with a military government problem this week-end at Fort Devens, Mass.

WISCONSIN--Reading Dispute The annual Institute in Reading, which will be held Aug. 1-3 at the University of Wisconsin, will consider the present controversy over the use of phonics in reading. A special session on the question of aural versus visual word study, which will give laymen and educators an opportunity to examine critically current teaching practices, is planned.

European and Japanese shipyards are building 213 vessels to specifications of the American Bureau of Shipping. The ships aggregate 2,446,315 gross tons and represent an 800,000-ton increase over a year ago.
TOKYO, Sunday July 31--The Japanese Diet adjourned at midnight with two of Premier Ichiro Hatoyama's most important bills blocked in the upper house.

THE author of this novel is an anthropologist who has essayed fiction to bring the life of remote Tibet closer to our understanding. "Tents Against the Sky" logs the private life of a Tibetan herdsman, his family and tribe, but it is first and last a broad and sympathetic canvas of a nomad culture that, after being preserved virtually intact from the beginning of time, seems now to be headed for a change.
Veterans of four wars who are patients in Veterans Administration hospitals will pay special tribute today to the Chaplains Corps of the V.A. on the corps' tenth anniversary.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 30-- The nations that met recently at Bandung, Indonesia, were reported today to be taking action to obtain entry into the United Nations of self-governing AsianAfrican democratic countries, such as Cambodia, Ceylon, Japan, Jordan, Laos, Libya and Nepal.

PICKING up again Max Lerner's superb edition of the speeches, letters and judicial opinions of Mr. Justice Holmes ("The Mind and Faith of Justice Holmes." Little, Brown Co., 1943, and now also available as a Modern Library Giant), one finds himself magically transported back into the midst of the nineteenth century and forward into the twenty-first.

CAIRO, July 30--Egypt has proposed that the Soviet Union and the Ukraine replace Britain and Egypt on the international commission to supervise the Sudan's exercise of self-determination, according to a newspaper article published with the Government censor's approval today.
THE 9-year-old and his mother sat on the edge of the swimming raft, well out in the lake. None of the other youngsters of the summer colony was anywhere about.
MOSCOW, July 30--The top Russian interplanetary investigator said today the Soviet Union was ready in principle to cooperate with other nations in outer-space research.

IN the ever-expanding army of science-fiction writers, Theodore Sturgeon still ranks ahead of most. Contrary to some critics, I feel that Sturgeon is concerned primarily with fantasy. The "science" element in his stories is pretty slight stuff, not comparable with the detailed extrapolation from present fact to future potential one finds in the work of, say, Robert A. Heinlein.

THE Library of Congress, which has been assiduous in recording United States folklore, currently offers three disks of Animal Tales in the Gullah Dialect. The recordings were made by Albert H. Stoddard of Savannah shortly before his death in 1954.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 30-- Suffolk County may get its first starch factory after all.
A ranch-style model home has been opened at the Elm Hill residential development of 150 dwellings on Ridge Street in Rye, N. Y. The Bonwit Construction Company is the builder.
Twenty of the thirty-four living members of baseball's Hall of Fame were the showpieces in a stirring tribute to yesteryear at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

HELICOPTER service between London Airport and Waterloo Air Terminal in the heart of London was inaugurated last Monday by British European Airways. The Sikorsky helicopters will carry five passengers between airport and terminal in twenty minutes for thirty-five shillings ($4.95 a head) against the seventy-cents and forty-five minutes to an hour required by airport coaches.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. DURING thirty-odd years of living in the fascinating and unsparing City of New York I often thought of giving it up, of moving away, of leaving the jangling metropolis --the stainless steel, the shiny chromium, the rush-hour mobs, the outrageous manners--to hardier souls.

MONTPELIER, Vt. During the last three months the physically handicapped homebound of Vermont have focused their attention on a small office at 7 Langdon Street. From this office they are hopeful will come the long awaited answer to their greatest wish-- employment for pay that they can do in their own homes.
MONTAUK, L. I., July 30--A stout Coast Guard patrol boat based at Lake Montauk received a distress call on a recent Sunday afternoon from a fishing boat.
The destruction last week of an Israeli airliner by anti-aircraft gunfire from Bulgaria emphasized again that the basic strategic problem in Europe still is the Iron Curtain.

There is a new twist to an old comment on the Soviet press: "There is no izvestia (news) in Pravda and no pravda (truth) in Izvestia." In recent days there has been more pravda and izvestia in both the major Soviet papers than veteran readers can remember ever seeing.

ROME, July 30--Fleeing from an exceptionally hot summer in Rome, Pope Pius XII moved fifteen miles south today to his summer residence at Castel Gandolfo. He is not expected to return to the Vatican until the end of November.
Michael Daroff is a man on the move--both literally and figuratively.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 30--The Santa Barbara Museum of Natural History is preparing to open a Hall of Butterflies in its main building in Mission Canyon.
Shipments of fall coats, suits and dresses are beginning to show strength and many stores have already begun to reorder, resident buying offices report.

There were twenty-one American prisoners of the Communists in Korea who originally elected to stay with their captors. Two others had changed their minds before the finality of the exchange was completed. Both of these have been convicted of offenses against military law and against their comrades and are now serving sentences.

NANCY WALKER and Maureen Stapleton, who managed not so long ago to enlarge their scrapbooks with some of the nicest love notes from the critics--Miss Walker for her performance in "Phoenix '55," Miss Stapleton for her work in "Twenty-seven Wagons Full of Cotton"--may appear together in a play.
The Port of New York will greet another addition to the North Atlantic passenger fleet tomorrow--the 17,000-gross-tonliner Arosa Sun.

NEW ROCHELLE. THE city of New Rochelle, N. Y. --population, 70,000; major occupation, commuting--is quietly celebrating this year the fiftieth anniversary of a little canard affectionately bestowed on it by George M. Cohan.

A world symposium on applied solar energy is to be held Nov. 1-4 in Phoenix, Ariz., with a preliminary conference at the University of Arizona, Tucson, Oct. 31 and Nov. 1. The Ford Foundation of New York has made a grant of $26,500 to Stanford Research Institute, Menlo Park, Calif., to bring over more than fifty foreign scientists and engineers from thirty nations for the symposium.

Philip Wernette has written three books in one in "The Future of American Prosperity."* There is the possible college text, for here are chapters on money, productivity, prices and spending -- although the emphasis is heavily on money.
GOSHEN, N. Y., July 31 (AP) -- The Grand Circuit opens a five-day stand at Good Time Park tomorrow. The $95,000 Hambletonian for 3-year-old trotters on Wednesday is the big attraction at the meet.

BALTIMORE, July 31 (UP)--Paul Richards, the general manager of the Baltimore Orioles, gave up today on John Swango, a bonus pitcher. Richards admitted that the club had made a "big mistake" when it gave the 18-year-old youngster $36,000 to sign a contract.
The First Ward of Queens -- Long Island City, Astoria and Sunnyside -- is today pretty much what it was in 1930. Only more so, of course, like everything else in this rapidly growing county.
FISHERS ISLAND, N. Y., July 31 -- Forty-three starters had a bit of on-the-wind dusting during the first and longest squadron run of the New York Yacht Club cruise that was completed this morning.

CLEVELAND, July 31 -- The future of human freedom may depend on how good a job is done by the nation's Sunday schools, Dr. Charles B. Templeton, the evangelist, told 5,000 religious educators. He spoke tonight at the final session of the International Sunday School Convention.

In its first change ownership in sixty years the plot 51 by 147 feet at 3013-15 Third Avenue, southwest corner of East 155th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by John G. and Mildred T. Olt. The property includes three and four story brick buildings.

ALL those who love Irish writing, a discriminating but not, alas, a very numerous company, have cause to be thankful to Devin A. Garrity, president of the Devin-Adair Publishing Company. In recent years he has waged a private crusade in behalf of the pleasures and wonders to be found in the literature written in the island home of his ancestors.

ATHENS, July 23 -- In the next few weeks the Government of Greece is expected to increase income taxes. This is one more indication that this Balkan nation is really serious about putting its economic house in order.
AKRON, Ohio, July 31 (AP) -- Henry Ransom won the Rubber City open golf tournament today on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff with three other pros.
Preaching yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, the Rev. Vincent J. Kenney questioned whether "time is running out for America as it did for Jerusalem."

The Health Department has served notice on Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy to end overcrowding at the city's Children's Center, 1 East 104th Street. The center cares for neglected and dependent children referred to it by the Children's Court.
General Mills, Inc., in the fiscal year ended May 31, achieved more than a half billion dollars in sales for the first time in its twenty-seven-year history.

PARIS, July 31 -- Great Britain had the profound postwar sense to modify traditional imperial concepts. This process is still under way -- and not without headaches. But the basic decision was taken to grant self-government to former dependencies and reassociate with them inside a Commonwealth.

BOMBAY, India, July 31 (AP) -- Policemen opened fire last night on a huge throng of Indians assembled in a remote village to watch a Hindu woman commit suttee -- throw herself upon her husband's funeral pyre. Official reports said three persons were killed and five wounded.
By the end of February, 1954, the great drab metropolis of Moscow had become very distasteful to me. A two-month bout with jaundice made me wish for nothing so much as a change of scenery.
The Yankees started with a flourish at the Stadium yesterday. They smacked three homers in the first inning of the opener of the afternoon's double-header.

We yield to Chicago in few matters worthy of civic pride, but the second largest city has now gone ahead of New York in one important public health measure. Its Mayor has ordered contracts made for fluoridation of water supply, which will benefit not only Chicagoans but also fifty-one suburbs buying Lake Michigan water from Chicago.
LOS ANGELES, July 31 -- A new drug that alleviates the withdrawal symptoms of acute alcoholics and speeds rehabilitation has been used in France for the last eight months.

AMSTERDAM, July 31 -- The Dutch labor shortage is continuously increasing and becoming a big headache for many industries. Many employers do not even take the trouble of registering vacancies with official labor bureaus, knowing that it is practically fruitless.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 31 (Reuters) -- The "Kastner case" was revived today when Dr. Rudolf Kastner was accused of perjury in Tel Aviv Magistrates' Court.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- A week of hearings on freedom of religion and separation of church and state is planned Oct. 3 by a Senate subcommittee on constitutional rights.

Guy de Berc, general manager for the French Line in this country, Canada and Mexico, has announced the appointment of William A. Muller as general passenger and freight agent with headquarters in the company's downtown offices at 17 State Street. Mr. Muller has been with the French Line since 1929.
There will be no strike of milk tank-truck drivers today.

A woman armed with a pistol and pretending scornfully to represent the patron saint of the poor left a 65-year-old churchgoer with three dollar bills yesterday after she had robbed him of $40 on a Brooklyn street.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 31 -- For the next fifteen months the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace will study reactions in the United States to the United Nations. The start of the special research was announced today.

COPENHAGEN, July 31 -- The announcement of the United States' earth satellite project has put delegates to the sixth International Astronautical Congress in the position of a long-term gambler who has suddenly and unexpectedly won the jackpot.
LONDON, July 31 -- Richard A. Butler's economy axe fell on the City and, indeed, on the whole country last Monday with a soft thud and not as a sharp blow, which many had been fearing.

Mayor Wagner was warned yesterday that the city's public housing program should in future provide space for at least 50 per cent more families than are displaced by razing dwellings to make room for new projects.

YANKTON, S. D., July 31 (UP) -- The Secretary of the Army said today that the United States no longer could treat water "as an inexhaustible resource and allow it to run a wayward and wasteful course to the sea."

MANY a man who wouldn't much as plug in the electric coffee pot insists he alone is entitled to perform at the outdoor grill. Every summer day more of these amateurs become expert with charcoal, skewers and garlic salt -- or so it would seem from a poll conducted recently by this department.
GENEVA, July 31 -- Representatives of the United States and Communist China exchanged polite compliments here today on the eve of talks that promise to cover a broad range of issues.
TRENTON, July 31 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner announced today he would sign a $150,000 appropriation for a study by the Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that the number of employed women had jumped 40 per cent from about 11,000,000 in 1940 to 15,752,820 in 1950.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- Dr. John Dunning, dean of Columbia University's School of Engineering, urged today that everything possible be done to overcome the "desperate situations" posed by the lack of engineering and science students.

Recent announcements by city officials have assured us that one important approach to solving Manhattan's crushing traffic problem -- the improving of existing borough highways -- is not being neglected. A traffic survey now under way on the West Side Highway may ultimately lead to a $50,000,000 expansion of that vital artery.
Hatless women who improvise head coverings when entering St. Patrick's Cathedral have incurred the censure of Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly, cathedral administrator.

LENOX, Mass., July 31 -- The second week-end of concerts in the main shed of the Berkshire Festival ended this afternoon with one in which Pierre Monteux directed the Boston Symphony. An audience of about 12,000 attended -- a good turnout, but nothing like last night's, in which 15,000 came to hear Rudolf Serkin play the "Emperor" Concerto.

CLINTON, Conn., July 31 -- Harold M. Lane's big white yawl, Doris, won by a huge margin today in the prolonged overnight race that opened the American Yacht Club's twenty-fourth annual cruise on Long Island Sound.

CINCINNATI, July 31 (AP) -- Ted Kluszewski singled with the bases loaded in the ninth inning of the second game of a double-header to give the Cincinnati Redlegs a 6-5 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates and a sweep of the twin bill and a four-game series today. The Reds won the first game, 7 -- 4.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 31 -- Zurich stock exchange turnover was exceptionally heavy last week, but price movements were erratic. Bank insurance and industrial stocks were all firm but profit taking by speculators was marked.
Charges that the Peiping regime had taken the lead in international narcotics traffic were cited yesterday as proof of the inadmissibility of Communist China for membership in the United Nations.

PARIS, July 31 -- While Great Britain's economic situation is considered uncertain, according to the recent report by Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler, two important factors in the French economy are considered favorable.

NEW DELHI, India, July 31 -- Indian experts who toured the Soviet Union have reported that, from the steel plant to the ballet troupe, the Russian incentive system is based on a "very big carrot" and a "very big stick."
The award of 171 police citations for outstanding service, including one for an act of bravery performed at the risk of life, will be announced today by Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A controversial public housing bill is the last major obstacle standing in the way of Congress' rush to adjournment.
THE participation of a quarter of a million children over the last year has assured a happy first birthday this month for an unusual museum shop.
The city can finance a large and adequate capital construction program over the next six years without exceeding its legal debt limit, the Citizens Budget Commission declared yesterday.

Since its entry into the Lewisohn Stadium repertory in 1948, the annual Rodgers and Hammerstein night has generally set the attendance record for the season. Saturday night it did it again. But the 18,000 persons it drew placed the management in a predicament.

MONTREAL, July 31 (AP) -- Australia today made a sweep of the North American zone Davis Cup final with Canada. Ken Rosewall beat Henri Rochon, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, after Lew Hoad downed Don Fontana, 9 -- 7, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 1, in the two concluding singles matches.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 31 (AP) -- Racing returns to historic Saratoga for the ninetieth summer tomorrow. The $10,000 added Flash Stakes for 2-year-olds is the feature of an eight-race card.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., announced yesterday that it had petitioned for dismissal of a complaint accusing it of conspiracy to restrain trade in the Los Angeles sportswear industry. The complaint was filed last April by the Federal Trade Commission.
ATHENS, July 31 (UP) -- Bulgarian fighter planes shot down the El Al Israel airliner last Wednesday, an Israeli spokesman said today after examining wreckage of the aircraft.
LONDON, July 31 -- Marilyn Bell, 17-year-old Toronto schoolgirl, swam the English Channel today. She was the youngest person ever to do so.
The time has come for another Boston tea party, but this time it must be in Washington, our capital city, where nearly one million American citizens are disfranchized.

MILWAUKEE, July 31 -- A double loss was suffered by the Braves today at County Stadium. They dropped a 7-3 decision to the Giants and lost the services of Joe Adcock, their long-hitting first baseman, who suffered a fracture of the right forearm.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Government disclosed today that it had put into effect a plan giving the states responsibility for the distribution of Salk poliomyelitis vaccine.

The New York Times of July 11 carried an article describing a drive-in church service held the previous day at Elmsford, N. Y. In this the pastor described the service as being "really a good thing" which would make religious worship "more convenient and comfortable."

Your editorial of July 21 "Any Jobs for Teen-Agers?" brings up a subject which, for several years, has seemed to me of very great importance. I never realized how important until my own grandson began last winter to write to every filling station, garage mechanic or boat-building concern he ever heard of asking what chances there might be for a summer's workout.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 31--The question of economic aid for Indonesia is proving to be a very ticklish one for the island republic and the United States.

The Congress of Industrial Organizations has approved the creation of a multi-million-dollar fund to enable the merged labor movement to organize the unorganized. All the principal C. I. O. unions have indicated their readiness to contribute $1 a member to an organizing "kitty."

This morning, in Geneva, representatives of the United States and Communist China will meet "at the ambassadorial level" to talk about possible solutions to some immediate problems. This is the first meeting of this precise character between negotiators for this country and the Red Chinese regime.

The strife between Senator Claro M. Recto and President Ramon Magsaysay of the Philippines has now come out into the open. We think that this is a good thing and that it will clear the Philippine political atmosphere. Senator Recto, in our judgment, chose the wrong ground upon which to dramatize his opposition to the President.
Dr. Arthur B. Whiting preached his farewell sermon yesterday at the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street.
PARIS, July 31 -- Three women headline today's Paris collections, Mmes. Fath, Gres and de Rauch. This is news in itself in an era when the couture is predominantly male.
An alert Queens patrolman yesterday arrested three young hoodlums, fresh out of the Elmira Reformatory and accused of a series of felonies.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 31 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley, the warhorse of Kentucky's Democratic party, may be enlisted actively this week in the intra-party battle for control of the state organization.

Sir Winston Churchill is the subject of still another biography. To be issued Aug. 16 by Houghton Mifflin, it is Alan Moorehead's newest book, "Winston Churchill in Trial and Triumph." It is an appraisal of Sir Winston's life from his "difficult" childhood to his "ultimate domination of a world in mortal struggle."
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 31 -- Agitation to build up trade with the Soviet Union to bolster Brazil's shaky finances has become evident again.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- Hospitals in the United States cared for a record 20,345,431 patients in 1954, the American Hospital Association announced today. This represented an increase of 161,604 patients over 1953.
