CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- Dee Fondy's two-run homer paced Chicago to a 6-5 victory over the Phillies in the second game of a double-header before 14,469 today after the Cubs, on Warren Hacker's five-hit pitching, had defeated Philadelphia and Robin Roberts, 7 -- 1.
SEOUL, Korea, July 31 -- Foreign Minister Y. T. Pyun has resigned and his resignation has been accepted, the South Korean Government announced last night.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- Grain markets last week generally reflected considerable profit taking by shorts. This with hot weather implications tended to tighten prices, notably in corn and oats. However there was an absence of bullish news, and the shadow of big supplies of grain continues to hang over the markets, making buyers extremely cautious.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 31 -- After standing within two strokes of victory in the fourth set, Tony Trabert defaulted in distress to Edward Moylan in the final round of the invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club today.

Perhaps vacation time is not the one in which to think of wandering words and washed-away cares. Better, possibly, to just let them go. Yet vacation provides a morning hour for lying on the beach, where the words go by overhead and the cares vanish just beyond the breakers.
Over-all volume and rates in the ship-charter market remained healthy last week, but King Coal's crown slipped a bit. Coal cargoes have been the bulwark of the charter field for some time.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- The United States reclamation bureau, which opened its current fiscal year July 1 with a record budget of $13,450,000, reported today that it expects to collect $204,000,000 during the year.
A Methodist minister from England said yesterday that the United States and Great Britain "share a faith that no seas can divide."
The American Civil Liberties Union issued a report yesterday on a complaint that pressure had been exerted on networks to ban radio and television programs sponsored by Facts Forum.
VALENTINE, Neb., July 31 -- Three of the touring Russian farm experts got their first look today at real cowboys.

MILWAUKEE, July 31 -- Sal Maglie's brilliant career with the Giants and in the National League ended suddenly today. The Barber was sold to the Cleveland Indians in a straight cash deal, the terms of which were not disclosed.
BATTLE CREEK, Mich., July 31 (UP) -- Beverly Hanson of Indio, Calif., carded a 72 for 220 today to win the Battle Creek women's open golf tournament.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 31 -- Seventeen alleged Communists, including former Congressman Roberto Morena, were reported arrested last night. They were said to have been seized in a raid on the offices of two publications accused of Communist connections.

SVENGALI and Trilby were caught in television's maw Saturday evening over Channel 4. After years of retirement that were both blessed and deserved, the two overworked characters were brought out for one more time around. If the world of science does not stop inventing media, they never will get any rest.

PITTSBURGH, July 31 -- There was no let-up last week in the heavy demand for all steel products. In most cases new orders exceeded mill capacity. The tightness was aggravated by the fact that most steel companies were unable to meet the production schedules they set up from week to week.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, proposed today that Congress provide for federal court review of any Labor Department finding that a state was out of conformity with Federal rules governing the unemployment compensation system.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3 -- Earnings of writers working in motion pictures and filmed television are expected to reach a record total of $13,000,000 for the twelve months ending next Sept. 30. This forecast was made by the Writers Guild of America, West, on the basis of a report prepared by Curtis Kenyon, secretary-treasurer, for the organization's July council meeting.

TURIN, Italy, July 31 -- The words automobile and Fiat are synonymous in Italy. At the Mirafiori plant of Fiat in Turin, one of the largest assembly plants in the world, Fiat produces more than 900 motor cars a day.
IT'S getting to the crucial stage for the captains and the kings of the court in the gunning for the Davis Cup.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 31 -- Harold E. Stassen, President Eisenhower's special assistant for disarmament, has drawn up a radical new plan for the reduction of nonatomic forces and the prohibition of nuclear weapons.

The Eastman Kodak Company pany in the first half of this year had a record consolidated net income of $36,365,989, or $1.97 each on the 18,277,260 common shares outstanding, the company reported over the weekend.

The Fulton, which has been occupied by "The Seven Year Itch" since Nov. 20, 1952, has a new booking. Called "The Isle of Goats," it is due in late September with Laurence Harvey, British film star, prominent in the cast.

SINGAPORE, July 31 -- Singapore demonstrators carrying anti-colonialist placards thronged the entrance to the airport as Alan T. Lennox-Boyd, British Colonial Secretary, arrived here from Hong Kong tonight. He is in Singapore on a tour of British Far East territories.
VALDIVIA, Chile, July 31 (AP) -- Hundreds of persons carrying their children were reported fleeing today from burning lava and rocks erupting from the craters of Nilahue and Rininahue volcanoes.
Persons struggling with sex problems need "understanding love," the Rev. Joseph D. Huntley said yesterday.

LONDON, July 31--The British are going off the beer. The race that has quaffed brown October ale and ordered the landlord to fill the flowing bowl until it runs over is slowly but steadily cutting its intake of beer, ale and allied beverages.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A boyish-looking Nebraskan may be the next Solicitor General of the United States.
There now are 2,229,100 units under rent control in New York State. Charles Abrams, Rent Administrator, reported yesterday.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 31 (AP) -- Anthony Cornero Stralla, gambling figure, died today after being stricken with a heart attack at a dice table. He succumbed in his suite at the Desert Inn. He was about 55 years old.
Substantial improvement in the city's personnel management was reported yesterday to Mayor Wagner by Joseph Schechter, director of the Department of Personnel.

HONG KONG, July 31 -- On the eve of the Washington-Peiping ambassadorial talks Red China's controlled press apparently had nothing to add today to the lengthy foreign policy statement made yesterday by Premier Chou En-lai.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 31 -- A Roman Catholic spokesman charged here today that Representative Francis E. Walter of Pennsylvania had done an "about-face" by "viciously" opposing amendments to the Refugee Relief Act of 1953. Mr. Walter and the late Senator Pat McCarran of Nevada were co-authors of the legislation.

Thor Johnson, director of the Cincinnati Symphony, conducted the Naumburg Orchestra last night on the Mall in Central Park. The concert was presented by George W. and Walter W. Naumburg in memory of their father, Elkan Naumburg, who began donating such concerts to the city fifty years ago.

Daniel T. O'Shea, veteran executive in the motion picture and radio and television broadcasting fields, has been named president of R. K. O. Radio Pictures, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Thomas F. O'Neil, chairman of the board.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 31 -- Competent Yugoslav sources, including a general, have said privately in the last two days there is no existing intention here to obtain Soviet MIG aircraft or to manufacture such planes under license.

A certain amount of tension has arisen between the United States and Yugoslavia. Some passages of President Tito's speech a few days ago testify to this, and so does the negative American reaction, transmitted through diplomatic channels, to the possibility that Yugoslavia might build Soviet MIG fighter planes.
Self-government was being priced in dollars and cents yesterday in the atomic-age cities of Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Richland, Wash.

BALTIMORE, July 31 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians pulled a triple play and two double plays against the last-place Baltimore Orioles today in winning the second game of a double-header, 6 -- 0, after losing the first, 4 -- 3.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 31 -- The Pakistan Government reduced the value of the rupee one-third today. This increased the rate for the United States dollar from 3 rupees 3 annas to 4 rupees 8 annas, the same rate as in India.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland of California said today he regarded as "most interesting" President Eisenhower's proposal of an exchange of military blue-prints with Russia.

The magazine distributing industry, which has seen sharp changes in recent weeks over who is to distribute what, made further news last night. Henry Garfinkle, president of the American News Company, announced an agreement with International Circulation Distributors, a Hearst Magazines organization, under which American News will distribute a list of Hearst publications in various parts of this country.

ST. LOUIS, July 31 -- Don Newcombe lost his usual dozen or so pounds in today's sweltering heat, but he posted his eighteenth victory as the Dodgers completed a sweep of the three-game series with the Cardinals.

RABAT, French Morocco, July 31 -- The nationalist riots that had marred the Moslem Greater Festival of Bairam in Marrakesh and in Moulay Idris yesterday subsided today, but there was continued evidence of nationalist agitation in both places.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- The National Federation of Independent Business called on Congress today to investigate what it called the failure of the Federal Trade Commission to enforce anti-trust laws.

NEWTON, N. J., July 31 -- A smart white miniature poodle notched his third best-in-show award in two weeks by taking top honors at the Lake Mohawk Kennel Club dog show at Memory Park today. The winner was Mrs. Marguerite S. Tyson's Ch. Blakeen Van Aseltine from Washington.
Lieut. Robert Walter Slezak died Friday when his Navy jet fighter crashed in the ocean in the area of Point Mugu, Calif.

Alice Belmont, a daughter of the late August Belmont Jr. and a granddaughter of the late August Belmont, sportsman and banker, was found dead early yesterday in her apartment at 617 West 113th Street.

After displaying some weakness at the start, cotton prices in the domestic market last week turned firmer to end the period with moderate net gains. At the close of trading on Friday on the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts were up 12 to 30 points from a week earlier.

DUBLIN, July 31 -- Gov. Averell Harriman of New York flew to Dublin from Paris today for a visit to Ireland. Accompanying him was Ambrose Chambers, who had been associated with him in the Economic Cooperation Administration.
BOSTON, July 31 (AP) -- Boston's lively Red Sox continued their drive in the tight American League race today by twice vanquishing the Detroit Tigers, 8 -- 3 and 3 -- 2.

SOME time between 8 and 10 o'clock this morning the ninety-foot, 100-ton yacht Souris (Mouse) II will be lifted from the deck of the Holland-America liner Westerdam at the lines dock at Fifth Street in Hoboken, ready to take off under her own power.

Stavros S. Niarchos, multimillionaire Greek shipping operator, is about to pioneer another trend in tankers. This time, his interest goes beyond giant size alone and into the realm of extremely high horsepower, great speed and improved maneuverability.

Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas was the target of a Pravda complaint this week-end, immediately prior to his scheduled visit to the Soviet Union. The justice, Pravda complained, had characterized some areas of the Soviet Union as "colonies." In doing so, the Communist newspaper says, he "retreats from the rule of personal observation" and bases himself instead on "false information from questionable third-hand sources."
Moscow's economists have begun drawing up plans for Soviet economic expansion to 1970 or 1975, the official magazine Planned Economy indicates.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- Key members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee generally agree today that "cold war" talks with Red China might prove more touch-and-go than the recent Big Four meeting with the Soviet Union.

The Tishman Realty and Construction Company, which plans an apartment building on East Sixty-third Street opposite its Sutton Terrace Apartments, has added the parcel measuring 25 by 100 feet at 403 East Sixty-third Street to the site.

NEW ROCHELLE, July 31 -- G. R. Corwin's 210, Harpoon. Stan Ogilvy's Star, Flame, and Fred Hibberd Jr.'s Lightning, Flash, made it two straight as the Echo Bay Yacht Club's week-end regatta ended today.
Americans should repent for dropping the atom bomb on Hiroshima and turn to "the power of love," forty clergymen and educators said in a statement issued yesterday.
Since early this summer, sparks have been flying along the tracks that bring the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad into New York.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The share of small business in the military procurement dollar is shrinking, according to a report filed today by the Senate Small Business Committee.

The Queens Civic Committee thoroughly disagrees with your editorial "A Challenge to the Mayor," wherein you take Controller Gerosa to task because he had the courage to vote against the wishes of Commissioner Moses in making parks out of the Neponsit and Seton Hospital sites.
Seven new films, including a pair of imports from England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

LONDON, July 31 -- A Vickers Valiant, Britain's latest bomber, left the Royal Aircraft Establishment at Farnborough today for Australia, where it will engage in extensive bombing trials at the Woomera rocket range.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Soviet interest in nonstrategic commodities available for export from this country is growing, Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, said today.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The State Department is preparing special facilities for handling the anticipated two-way expansion of cultural, scientific and social contacts with Russia and her satellites.
Twenty-six German teenagers made their first American purchases yesterday a few hours after arriving in New York. Each bought an ice cream pop from a vender outside the gates of the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Representatives of Governors of thirty-five states will confer with President Eisenhower for two days beginning tomorrow on the refugee relief program.

PABLO CASALS, man of principle and musician of distinction, visited in countless American homes yesterday afternoon, thanks to television. The occasion was another of N. B. C.'s filmed conversations with "elder wise men."

GENEVA, July 31 (AP) -- Since the Indochina conference ended last July, Franklin C. Gowen, United States Consul General, has held seventeen meetings with Shen Ping, Red Chinese Consul General in Geneva.

Last week's article here discussed the most recent effort to repeal the Silver Purchase program, through S. 1427, the newest version of the so-called Green Bill. This measure is jointly sponsored by an imposing list of legislators besides the Senator from Rhode Island, including Senators Douglas, Bush, Kennedy, Pastore, Purtell and Saltonstall.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox weathered a ninth-inning Washington rally to defeat the Senators, 6 -- 5, in the second game of a double-header today after taking the opener, 3 -- 1, in eleven innings.

KRASNODAR, U. S. S. R., July 31 -- The American farm delegation made its first unscheduled foray into the Russian countryside today. It was a revolt against the program of banquet dinners and formal visits planned by Soviet officials.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Leonard W. Hall said today that he believed he should stay out of the controversy surrounding Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- A Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee said today it was "greatly concerned" over the "record number" of unsold automobiles and high dealer mortality in the industry.

Top officials of the International Longshoremen's Association sought yesterday an "immediate meeting" with the Governors of New York and New Jersey. The union leaders want the meeting held to take up a possible work stoppage in the Port of New York because of recent penalties imposed on longshoremen by the Waterfront Commission.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 1 -- Personnel problems pose serious difficulties to Indonesia in the operation of the United States Technical Assistance Program.

JACK SIMON, guiding spirit of Bloomingdale's Epicure Shop, was the first to bring in wild strawberries by air from France and the first to sell fresh truffles from Italy. Today this enterprising merchandiser introduces fresh herbs -- tarragon, chervil, chives and mint.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Overriding Republican objections, the House today voted its Small Business Committee an additional $35,000 for investigations which Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, committee chairman, said have been "stepping on the toes of some pretty big fellows."
PUGWASH, N. S., Aug. 1 -- Scientists and educators gathered here today for a series of informal exchanges of thought.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation raised the quarterly dividend by 50 cents a share on the common stock with the declaration yesterday of $1.50. It is payable Sept. 10 to shareholders of record of next Monday, Aug. 8.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 1 (AP) --West Germany's spectacular world trade boom is shattering all records this year.
The trial of four secondary Communist leaders has been scheduled for Aug. 10 in Federal Court here, United States Attorney Lloyd F. MacMahon announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, told representatives of thirty-five Governors today they could foster the United States tradition of helping "the weary and the persecuted."
Yesterday was Thanksgiving Day, 1955, for the families of eleven American fliers. The airmen's release was promised by Communist China.
Salvatore M. Parisi, a lawyer, was sworn in yesterday as a deputy commissioner of the State Liquor Authority by Secretary of State Carmine G. DeSapio.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The National Safety Council said today that, statistically, the nation s highways were safer than ever.

Governor Meyner's announcement that he will approve a $150,000 appropriation for the Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission apparently clears the way at last for the completion of a well-financed study of New York-New Jersey commuter railroads, their plight and their future.

MOSCOW, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, commenting on President Eisenhower's satellite announcement, said tonight that Russia would cooperate with the United States "if it is in the interests of mankind."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The House or Representatives rejected today a bill aimed at settling the month-long transportation strike here. However, sponsors soon scheduled a reconsideration under different rules.

Today's new film is "The Private War of Major Benson," a comedy starring Charlton Heston, Julie Adams and William Demarest, at the Plaza. The supporting cast is headed by Tim Considine and Sal Mineo. The screen play was written by William Roberts and Richard A. Simmons from a story by Joe Connelly and Bob Mosher.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 1 -- Israel charged Bulgaria today with trying to remove incriminating evidence in the shooting down of an Israeli airliner Wednesday.
Twenty-four hours more of peace appears likely in the dispute between milk tank-truck drivers and their employers.

A stockholder group of the Alleghany Corporation has won a belated victory in its effort to restrain Robert R. Young, Alleghany's chairman, and his associates from using the company's funds in their "personal partisan interests."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- In a telephone message from Sweden Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, said:
IF THE family pooch is leading a dog's life these days, some tips on relieving his hot-weather discomfort have been offered by Dr. Cherry Ann Hopper.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 1 -- A sharp cold wave sweeping southern Brazil is causing concern for the coffee crop.

HONG KONG, Aug. 1 -- A welcome is being prepared here for the eleven United States fliers whose release was announced today by Communist China. Like the four United States fliers who were "deported" May 31, they are expected to make their exit across the Hong Kong-Kwangtung border and reach freedom in this British colony.

The Saturday Review announced yesterday that twenty-four major corporations and industry associations had received its third annual awards for "distinguished advertising in the public interest." The winners are named in the weekly's issue of Aug. 6, which is in the mail today.

DURING the last two summers it has been demonstrated that there is an eager audience for chamber music in the Greenwich Village area. And that fact was proved again last night when an all-Mozart program played by a chamber orchestra drew a throng of 3,800 to Washington Square Park.

Inevitably, the first reaction to Peiping's announcement that eleven American aviators who have been imprisoned in Red China for about two and a half years are now to be set free is a feeling of relief and satisfaction. We are happy that these men can come back to their own world.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 1 -- School problems, it seems, are the same the world over.
Under terms of a sales contract signed last May, three well-known hotels in the Kirkeby Hotels chain have passed into new control, but Kirkeby will continue to manage two of them.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 1 -- Two Philadelphia men were sentenced to three days in the Nassau County Jail here today for bombarding cars on the Wantagh State Parkway with green apples and rocks from the Newbridge Road overpass in Wantagh.
Two old cannons of purely ornamental value were reported missing yesterday, one on Long Island and one in New Jersey. The cannons disappeared from lawns on which
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Following is a State Department list of forty United States civilians known to be still held in Communist China:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Senator Estes Kefauver today accused President Eisenhower and his top aide, Sherman Adams, of withholding "important information" about the Dixon-Yates private power contract.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The House of Representatives passed and returned to the Senate today a bill to give national banks more freedom to make real estate and construction loans.

Operating revenues of Duquesne Light Company and its subsidiaries in the quarter to June 30 were $2,123,966 above those for the same 1954 period and net earnings rose $546,839, the company reported. Common share earnings rose from 55 to 58 cents.

The Geneva talks between Washington and Peiping, diplomatically appropriate as they have become to the new spirit of "co-existent" international relationships recently there founded, should excite us by the imaginative prospect of an American return to mainland China.

Domestic steel production declined slightly last week to 2,190,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, with operations at 90.7 per cent of the industry's rated capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- John L. Lewis, who often makes news by making phrases, made it today with silence.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- An angry partisan dispute broke out in the House of Representatives today as it debated a bill to give states assistance with their poliomeylitis vaccination programs.
Eleven firemen and three policemen were overcome by smoke or injured fighting a two-alarm fire in the Morrisania section of the Bronx yesterday.

A night in a railroad station in Soviet Central Asia is a never-to-be-forgotten experience. No one at Kagan's station seemed to know, or care, what had happened to the train from Moscow we would take to Chardzhou. So we waited.
Glenda Farrell, a Hollywood-Broadway commuter for the last twenty-five years, is likely to be signed for the feminine lead in "The Hot Corner," a comedy about baseball by Allen Boretz and Ruby Sully.
Yesterday was a day to try the most patient commuter. He was late getting to work in New York whether he traveled by car or rail, by the Long Island Rail Road, the New York Central or the New Haven.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Willie Shoemaker rode three winners today at Washington Park, including the Calumet Farm's Duke's Lea in the $22,850 Clang Handicap. He now trails Willie Hartack by only one winner in their race for the national jockey championship.

KIMBERLEY, South Africa, Aug. 1 -- The 6,000 white miners of the Northern Rhodesia copper belt have agreed that twenty-four categories of jobs at present done by Europeans be transferred to Negroes. An agreement to this effect has been signed by the Northern Rhodesian European Mine Workers Union and the Rhodesian Anglo-American group of companies controlled in Johannesburg.
The City Housing Authority decided yesterday to put off temporarily the eviction of twenty-one tenants refusing to sign loyalty oaths.

A 30-year-old auditor in the Brooklyn office of the Internal Revenue Service was arraigned yesterday in Federal Court Brooklyn, on a charge of accepting a $200 bribe from a taxpayer. United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay released the defendant, Felix A. Scancella, in his own recognizance for action of the grand jury.
PARIS, Aug. 1 -- Christian Dior today introduced the "Y" line, skimming over the alphabet from his last season's "A" line.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 1 -- Nationalist official circles said today they believed the Chinese Communist release of eleven United States airmen was an obvious attempt to inject other problems into the ambassadors' talks in Geneva.

LONG, long ago when I was a junior in college I read extensively in the English novel. For the most part I found my way around a vast territory as best I could, reading the most famous books by the most famous writers and a fair sampling of the critical and biographical writing about them. The literature about English fiction was enormous then and is larger today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Many baseball fans would like to see some changes made, particularly in regard to car parking and length of games, a survey authorized by Commissioner Ford Frick disclosed today.

The Department of Labor has ordered a "conformity hearing" on the California Unemployment Insurance Law. It attacks a decision of the California District Court of Appeal holding that certain seamen were strikers refusing to do their work and so were ineligible for unemployment benefits during their 1949 strike.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Union leaders announced tonight the settlement of a seniority dispute that has closed the Studebaker plant of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation for eleven of the last thirteen working days.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 -- The United States Maritime Commission is ready and able to construct a nuclear-powered merchant ship as suggested by President Eisenhower.
Before the first searing blowtorch is put to a single rivet of the Third Avenue El may I suggest we preserve part of the history of this city which rolled along this railway.

When Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, is in his office at Grand Central Terminal, an electric percolator burbles continuously on a table beside his desk.

The first intercontinental passenger flight of Varig Airlines of Brazil is scheduled to leave New York International Airport at 10 A. M. today. The 5,000-mile trip from the Idlewild, Queens, airport to Rio de Janeiro will be made by one of Varig's new Super-G Constellations.
CHICAGO (UP) -- Severe frostbite can be caused by exposure to propane, a combustion engine fuel.
Peabody Coal Company common and preferred stocks yesterday were barred from trading by the New York Stock Exchange for failure to abide by the company's listing agreement.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 2 -- The South Korean Government said today it would ask the Communists to withdraw from areas south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel.
Judy Garland will star on the premiere of the "Ford Star Jubilee" program on Saturday, Sept. 24, from 9:30 to 11 P. M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that retail food prices might decline slightly in the next few months, reflecting record supplies. These prices, it said, averaged about 2 per cent lower in the first half of 1955 than during the same period last year.

Over the week-end the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration -- the two agencies that administer the financing of homes built with Federally backed mortgages -- issued a joint statement to the effect that the terms of financing in these two areas were to be tightened up.

Men who gained a place for themselves in the world with their fists have joined the fight against juvenile delinquency. They are members of the recently organized Hudson County (N. J.) Ring 14 of the Veterans Boxers Association.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Two Belgian soldiers who picked life in Communist China and then decided they wanted to leave have now asked to be repatriated to Belgium, Indian Red Cross officials said today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- The Saratoga Association drew a brow-mopping afternoon for the opening of its eighty-fifth at-home race meeting today. The mercury was in the 90's; a scout reported that a midtown thermometer had registered 100 at about the time a dead-heat was being run in the first race.
Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, has issued another warning on the "direct competition" given private shipping by the Defense Department's Military Sea Transportation Service.
KRASNODAR, U. S. S. R., Aug. 1 -- The visiting American farm delegation will spend the next two nights at farms in the rich North Caucasus foothills area.
The steel-making capacity of New York State has increased by 50 per cent in the last ten years. That report was made yesterday by Edward T. Dickinson, State Commerce Commissioner.

Mayor Wagner has declared this "Amputee Week" in honor of the National Amputation Foundation, an organization of veterans who have lost an arm or leg. This foundation, organized in 1919, has provided thousands of handicapped young men with rehabilitation, education and guidance.
There are now at least forty-two nuclear reactors in thirty-two nations, according to a world-wide survey reported yesterday by the Atomic Industrial Forum, Inc.

The New York City Housing Authority yesterday set Aug. 16 for the sale of $12,250,000 of short-term loan notes for the temporary financing of two Federally subsidized, low-rent projects, Throggs Neck Houses and Edenwald Houses, both in the Bronx.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 -- Don Liddle, his control flawless as he fanned eight and walked none, hurled a five-hitter for the Giants while defeating the Cardinals, 9 -- 1, tonight. The little left-hander, without a complete game this season, went all the way in his first start since May 30.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- High temperatures in the western half of the Corn Belt, with many readings over 100 degrees, brought in a little buying support in corn today, but the trade was still reluctant to believe there had been substantial damage as yet.
Sgt. James C. Gallagher of Brooklyn stood before a general court-martial yesterday and heard himself accused of murdering three fellow-Americans in a Korean prisoner-of-war camp.
Large apartment buildings will be erected on vacant land in the East Forties and in Washington Heights just purchased in separate deals by Manhattan realty investors.
Mayor Wagner issued instructions yesterday on the use of milk substitutes in the event of a strike.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Following are the texts of Harold E. Talbott's letter of resignation as Secretary of the Air Force and President Eisenhower's letter accepting the resignation.

The hottest July in the city's history drove customers into department stores to buy an unprecedented number of fans and air conditioners. But the heat kept many shoppers who might otherwise have bought most other types of merchandise out of stores.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

It is heartening, though not surprising that The Times has given such full and prominent news coverage to the dismissal of the indictment against Corliss Lamont for contempt of the United States Senate for refusing to answer questions about a book he had written, even though he had refused to take refuge behind the Fifth Amendment and testified under oath that he was not and never had been a member of the Communist party.

JOTTINGS: Garson Kanin, who will stage "Diary of Anne Frank," is expected to arrive here from Europe tomorrow. The drama is due at the Cort Oct. 5. . . . Richard Sharretts is substituting for Stefan Schnabel, who is on a one-week vacation from "Plain and Fancy."

GENEVA, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by Wang Ping-nan of Communist China at a meeting with Alexis Johnson, United States Ambassador to Czechoslovakia, today, plus the texts of a statement issued by the United States delegation and of a joint communique:

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 1 -- Three one-act operas and several groups of choral works were presented here tonight in the theatre-concert hall. The presentations were a combined effort of the Berkshire Music Center, making use of the opera, chorus and orchestral departments.
LONDON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Britain's track and field team defeated Germany in a two-day dual meet which ended today before 40,000 at London's White City Stadium.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 1 -- The Government introduced today a bill to appoint a press registrar to collect information about all newspaper activities.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 -- Frank Sinatra wants to make a western movie. He has selected an original screen play titled "The Loud Law," written by David P. Harmon. It will be filmed late this year as the singer-actor's first independent production for United Artists release.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The Post Office Department reported today that arrests for postal crimes had reached an all-time high in the twelve months ended June 30.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Harold E. Talbott resigned tonight as Secretary of the Air Force.

Someone, not publicly identified, has discovered that the milk drivers' walkout, threatened yesterday, would have violated the Taft-Hartley requirement of thirty days' notice of a possible strike. That ominous possibility is now presumably postponed until Aug. 14.

WILLIAM (BILL) CAMPBELL of Huntington, W. Va., recently won the amateur golf championship of his state for the fourth time. He was eighteen under par for the 111 holes he played. And he did it with a set of borrowed clubs.

When the United Nations Assembly meets in this city on Sept. 20 it will find high on its agenda an item which was forecast in the Charter in 1945, which has been on every Assembly agenda, in some form, since that time and which dovetails with the Geneva proceedings.
MOSCOW, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Pravda correspondent on the American farm tour said today that the Indians were right in calling Aiova (Iowa) a "wonderful land."

MONACO, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Judge Jacques de Courcelles ordered the Monte Carlo Banking and Precious Metals Society to shut its doors today. His action followed the discovery of a deficit in its accounts said to amount to $8,625,000.

Forty years ago, Bernard F. Gimbel, now chairman of the board of Gimbel Brothers, gave jobs to two students who were taking part in a new high school program. This alternated a week of formal class study with a week of job experience in a related field.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 1 -- The General Motors Corporation may move its Chevrolet motor and Fisher body plants from North Tarrytown to Red Hook in Columbia County, a Westchester legislator said today.

ATLANTA, Aug. 1 -- The Georgia Board of Education ordered all teachers who are members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to resign from the organization by Sept. 15 or have their teaching licenses revoked "for life."
COLUMBUS, Neb., Aug. 1 -- The Soviet farm delegation touring the Midwest corn and livestock areas got a brief look today at a part of this nation's air strength.

BRISTOL, Pa., Aug. 1 (UP) -- The body of a soldier, tentatively identified as Joseph J. O'Connell, 19 years old, of 521 West 166th Street in New York, was found today along the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks a mile from the station here.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 1 -- The pro-German parties in the Saar launched a campaign yesterday against the international statute that guarantees France's economic control of the territory in exchange for semi-political autonomy.
Two views of the New York Stock Exchange Monthly Investment Plan are current in Wall Street: (1) It has been a whopping failure. (2) It has been a tremendous success.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Legislation to authorize deepening of the upper Great Lakes channel at a cost of $115,000,000 was passed today by the House of Representatives and sent to the Senate.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Eisenhower promised today that he would try to resolve an inter-departmental fight over a cotton export policy at the Cabinet level.
Coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange rose the daily limit of 200 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on all contracts yesterday.

Bobby Boyd of Chicago knocked out Tony Anthony of the Bronx, a 3-to-1 favorite, with a crushing right hand to the jaw last night. The end came at 1:32 of the third of the scheduled ten-round feature at the St. Nicholas Arena.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Consumer installment debt soared $765,000,000 in June to a record total of $24,914,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The White House denied today that the Administration was studying a disarmament plan involving a reduction of non-atomic forces and the prohibition of nuclear weapons.

An ex-convict, whose two children have been abandoned in two states, is being sought for questioning in connection with the $305,243 robbery of the Chase Manhattan Bank in Woodside, Queens, on April 6, the police disclosed yesterday.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 1 -- Alan T. Lennox-Boyd, British Colonial Secretary, spent most of yesterday and a large part of last night in intensive discussions of Singapore's political future.

United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation has bought the G. B. W. Manufacturing Company, College Point, L. I., developer and producer of hydraulic, marine and aircraft instruments. Hoffman officials said G. B. W. will operate as a subsidiary of Hoffman, a manufacturer of clothes cleaning and pressing equipment.
August made a scorching 96.3-degree debut in New York yesterday.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 1 -- With Tony Trabert forced out by a sore shoulder, Victor Seixas and Hamilton Richardson led the field of sixty-four today in the Eastern grass court tennis championships.

ROME, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Premier Antonio Segni said today he intended to push a ten-year plan to wipe out unemployment and poverty. These chronic ills have helped breed communism in this nation, a key member of the North Atlantic Alliance.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Art Larsen, Budge Patty and Bernard Bartzen of the United States gained the men's singles quarter-finals today in Hamburg's international tennis tournament. Three other Americans were eliminated.

GENEVA, Aug. 1 -- Communist China formally notified the United States today that eleven United States airmen imprisoned as spies had been freed. It said they were released yesterday and would reach Hong Kong Thursday.

A biography of Gen. George S. Patton Jr., based on material never before available and recently released by the Patton heirs, will be published Aug. 15 by Appleton-Century-Crofts. It will be called "Portrait of Patton." The author is Harry H. Semmes, who served under Patton in two world wars and who knew him intimately as a fox-hunting companion over the years.

Roddy McDowall will fill the important role of Ben in the Broadway-bound comedy "No Time for Sergeants." The London-born actor was the 141st candidate auditioned for the part, which director Morton DaCosta and producers Maurice Evans and Emmett Rogers had found unusually troublesome to cast.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Recent developments in Israel, Egypt and the Arab states are being watched apprehensively by the British Government.

NEWARK, Aug. 1 -- Manufacturers of household chemicals were urged tonight to label their products with a list of ingredients. The request came from Dr. Morton J. Rodman, associate professor of Pharmacology at Rutgers University's College of Pharmacy in Newark.

The Fruehauf Trailer Company in the first six months this year achieved a 67 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 44 per cent over the period a year ago, Roy Fruehauf, president, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Senate has confirmed promotions of Army Reserve officers from the rank of brigadier general to major general.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Short-term borrowing costs of the Treasury, reflecting a tightening of the money market, today rose to the highest point in nearly two years.

New York State will buy the first 500,000 doses of Salk polio vaccine being allocated here by the Federal Government. The supply has become available now that summer needs of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis have been met.
Twelve major freezer-food-plan operators, handlers of 90 per cent of the business in area, have signed consent injunctions agreeing to regulate their advertising practices.
The Aluminum Company of America increased prices of primary aluminum yesterday, following the granting of wage increases averaging 15 cents an hour to 25,000 workers last week.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., Aug. 1 -- A fifty-foot Italian built yawl that was new a year ago had the best corrected time in kindly southwest air during twenty-three miles of easy sailing today. It happened on the second run of the New York Yacht Club cruise.
COPENHAGEN, Aug. 1 -- Rocket engineers present at the International Astronautical Congress here believe that man will have made his pioneer flight through space by 1970.

ARMONK, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors today ordered a study of a plan by New York City to dispose of two watershed properties in North Castle as "obsolete" for water supply purposes.
The Park Association of New York City, Inc., moved yesterday to seek an injunction against sale of the Neponsit Hospital site in the Rockaways, Queens.

The experiment at Cold Spring Institute, now ending its second year, suggests that old age can be an adventure, not a problem. A group of men and women, ranging in age from 55 to 77, have proved that growing old has its compensations. Under the auspices of the Walt Foundation the institute has provided elderly persons with a new lease on life.
The growing scarcity of lendable funds pinched one sector of the money market a bit further yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Senator William F. Knowland of California denied today that the Administration had made any "deal" to give Communist China the Nationalist island groups of Quemoy and Matsu in return for freeing eleven American fliers.

FISHERS ISLAND, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- The fleet had pleasant downwind sailing today as the American Yacht Club's cruise came here from Duck Island Roads off Clinton, Conn. Racing under spinnakers, the 20.3-mile passage was in decided contrast to the wind-blown cruise start of Saturday night.
GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Eleven 3-year-old trotters, headed by the 1954 juvenile champion, Scott Frost, were named today for the $86,867 Hambletonian at Good Time Park on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- An Army Judge Advocate's Review Board approved today a twenty-year prison sentence for Cpl. Claude J. Batchelor, the Kermit, Tex., soldier who chose to stay with the Communists in Korea but later changed his mind.

NEW FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 1 -- An aviation engineer and his daughter-in-law escaped with minor cuts and bruises today when their single-engine seaplane hit a high tension wire and crashed into Candlewood Lake.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dipped 9 to 19 points yesterday.
Two methods of enlisting the cooperation of department stores in promoting a product were outlined yesterday. One used stores that sell the product, the other stores that don't carry it at all.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 -- The Screen Actors Guild today announced that it will strike at 12:01 A. M. Friday against the multi million - dollar television entertainment production business.
The Port of New York rolled out the red carpet yesterday for the Arosa Sun as the liner made her first call here.

Washington's announcement last week that the United States would try to launch a man-made orbital satellite into space in 1957 or 1958 foreshadows the coming era of intercontinental ballistic missiles and orbital reconnaissance vehicles.
A threatened strike of 450 dining car workers on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was averted yesterday. The walkout was to have begun at midnight.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1 -- There may have been a broken heart for every light in County Stadium tonight, if not for all of the 37,721 fans who watched the Dodgers beat the Braves, 4 -- 3, in ten innings.
NIANTIC, Conn., Aug. 1 -- The school stripers are feeding, if not with abandon, at the mouth of the Niantic River, but they seem unusually fussy in the matter of diet.
The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation reported its net profit for the first six months this year at $19,941,739 compared with $18,550,969 for the similar period a year ago.

DOUGLAS, Ariz., Aug. 1 (AP) The Phelps Dodge Corporation and the independent International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers reached an agreement on a new contract today after a month-long strike.
YONKERS, Aug. 1 -- A new state law requiring that school teachers outside of New York City be paid in ten installments a year instead of twelve has got the Yonkers city administration worried.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 1 -- Housewives who went to market here today got a lesson in economics and they disliked it.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Otto Gressens, chairman of Peabody Coal Company, disclosed today that he has written to the company's stockholders explaining the situation.
CHANNEL 2 has a lean and hungry look this morning. Last night's presentation of "Julius Caesar" had much more in common with summer stock than Shakespeare. It was quite awful.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Justice Department asked the Subversive Activities Control Board today to order the American Peace Crusade to register with the Attorney General as a Communist-front organization.

STRATFORD, Conn., Aug. 1 -- Thanks to the American Festival Theatre, one of the finest and rarest of the Shakespeare plays is on the stage. "The Tempest" officially opened this evening as the second of the summer productions in the park beside the Housatonic.
As one who, as probation officer, clinical psychologist and research worker, has dealt with the problem of juvenile delinquency for many years, permit me to reply to Dr. Lauretta Bender.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The first session of the Eighty-fourth Congress approached the completion today of its greatest single remaining task but it again postponed final adjournment.

Selling pressures concentrated on leading chemical, oil, metal, steel and rail issues in yesterday's stock market. By the end of the session their prices were down 1 to 3 points and The New York Times average was at its lowest closing level since June 22.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- President Eisenhower signed today a bill authorizing the Langley-Laurel accord between this country and the Philippines to be put into effect.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 1 -- A Yugoslav parliamentary delegation left by plane today for a visit to the Soviet Union. The visit marks another stage in Moscow's rapprochement with President Tito's independent Communist regime.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Eisenhower expressed the nation's relief and joy today at the impending release of eleven United States airmen held by Communist China. The President issued orders to appropriate agencies to devote every effort toward the speedy reunion of the airmen with their families.
Just how sure do we want to be about tomorrow's weather -- or even of today's?

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Hearst Consolidated Publications, Inc., today announced an operating profit of $3,462,900 for the first six months of 1955. Net profit after taxes was $1,735,900, compared with an operating loss of $1,000 for the first half of 1954.

The use of precast concrete roof decking is gaining rapidly, it is indicated by a survey just completed. In the ten years ended last Dec. 31, a total of 202,577,676 square feet of such decking was installed on some 8,000 buildings for 6,000 owners.

An apartment house site of 16,500 square feet at 2972, 2976 and 2980 Marion Avenue in the Bronx has been assembled and purchased by a syndicate headed by Martin Besner. The group will erect a six-story building from plans being prepared by Leo Stillman, architect.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The work of Congress, as reflected in the daily news, leaves the impression that the legislative grind goes on hour after hour, unrelieved by pleasing distractions. This impression is the strongest, and nearest to the fact, as Congress races toward the adjournment of a session.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- More than 200 policemen patrolled the Goutte d'Or (Drop of Gold) section of Paris tonight in the wake of week-end rioting. The North Africans of the quarter had attacked a police station.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Two emergency boards recommended today wage increases for certain railroad and Railway Express Agency employes.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 1 -- A frightened baby deer that refused to eat while its two broken legs were mending has ended its hunger strike under the care of a 5-year-old girl. The tiny spotted fawn, found badly crippled several weeks ago by state troopers after being chased by dogs, was brought to the Pontiack Animal Hospital here. Dr. Herbert French, a veterinarian, set the animal's legs, but the fawn refused to eat.
BOMBAY, India, Aug 1 (AP) -- Two Indochinese monkeys, on their way to the Soviet Union, delayed two Indian elephants, also en route to the same destination, for ten hours today.
Support for the idea of a multi-million-dollar union organizing fund was expressed yesterday by George Meany, prospective president of the merged labor movement.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Dick Hall mastered the Chicago Cubs a second time in eight days today. He pitched and batted the Pirates to a 5-4 victory before 3,194.
"I was a little shocked, but I think it's a good break for me." That was how Sal Maglie, a 38- year-old right-hander, described his sale by the Giants to the Cleveland Indians on Sunday.

The seemingly "insatiable appetite" for wood pulp produced in the United States is not due to the roaring news presses alone. Women's rayon intimates, plastics in general, photographic film and explosives, though still minor customers, are beginning to affect the demand.

Today's new film is a British import. "The Divided Heart," at the Normandie. The drama about a small boy has a cast headed by Cornell Borchers, Yvonne Mitchell, Armin Dahlen, Alexander Knox, Michel Ray and Geoffrey Keen.

WASHINGTON, Aug 2 -- The Senate confirmed today the nomination of an "Eisenhower Democrat," Harold C. Patterson of Virginia, to be a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The vote was 49 to 29.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 2 -- Ways to raise the status of the teaching profession were proposed here today at the annual conference of the World Confederation of Organizations of the Teaching Profession.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- When Two Stars won the Schuylerville Stakes here last August she was a $61.70 collector's item at the $2 mutuel windows. Hardly anyone knew about her.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 2 -Leaders of the Republican-controlled Legislature met here today behind dosed doors and agreed upon a pre-election agenda for the Senate and Assembly. They decided to limit the sessions primarily to measures designed to increase New Jersey's supply of potable water.
Gordon R. Clapp, Deputy City Administrator, has resigned to go into the private consulting business here.
Sales of Pillsbury Mills, Inc., in the fiscal year ended May 31 were the highest in the company's eighty-six-year history, while earnings were the second largest on record.

It seems to be generally agreed in Washington that Harold E. Talbott has been an efficient and energetic Secretary of the Air Force. In accepting Mr. Talbott's resignation, indeed, President Eisenhower paid tribute not only to the Secretary's "tireless energy and effort" but also to his "devotion to the Air Force and concern for the security of the country."
Two legal appointments of major importance to the merchant marine and the maritime industry were announced yesterday in Washington.

Thousands of underprivileged children who, unfortunately, will not have the boon of one or two weeks in the country this summer are going to have a breath of fresh air at least. For Community Councils of the City of New York, Inc., 111 Broadway, New York 6, is transporting as many needy children as it can accommodate in July and August on one-day trips to Staten Island.
Unionized milk tank-truck drivers continued yesterday to play "cat and mouse" with the city's milk supply.

Thirty-two acres on U. S. Route 130 in North Brunswick, N. J., have been purchased by the Jampol Realty Corporation of New York. The acreage which fronts 440 feet along the highway, will be used for commercial and residential development as soon as financing arrangements are completed and buildings plans approved, according to C. B. Snyder Realty Company, Inc., broker in the sale of the land.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2--Victor Chemical Works, Chicago, announced today the development of ferrophosphorus--an alloy of iron and phosphorus--to increase the density of concrete walls forming the protective shielding for atomic "hot cells." Victor engineers said the development will simplify construction of the cells, which are being built in increasing numbers by university and industrial research centers.
The waning twenty-fifth anniversary celebration of the Museum of Modern Art has brought a handsome gift to this the youngest of the city's museums.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- The Ministry of Defense denied today reports from London that France had agreed to sell a group of Mystere IV jet fighter planes to Israel. An official Ministry spokesman said "no contract has been signed and none is projected."
TSOYING, Formosa, July 8 -- Chinese Nationalist leathernecks and frogmen are being taught here the art and the science of modern warfare.
One of the strongest British Wightman Cup tennis teams in years arrived yesterday. The players immediately began practicing for the annual competition against a team of United States women.
A three-year-old dispute over the value of krebiozen, a new anti-cancer drug, led yesterday to a $360,000 libel suit in Supreme Court here.

Skitch Henderson and his wife, Faye Emerson, television performers, have purchased for occupancy the four-story and studio dwelling at 245 East Sixty-first Street from Marshall Mundheim. The property is 16 by 100 feet and was sold through Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Officials were hopeful today that a five-week-old bottleneck on Route 45 here would end this week as bigger and better directional signs made their appearance on Palisades Interstate Parkway.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- It is not very widely known, but the United States is having some embarrassments with two of its Scandinavian allies, Iceland and Norway. In the case of Iceland the trouble closely parallels a famous British complaint during the second World War: "The trouble with you Yanks is that you're overpaid, oversexed and over here."

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 2 (UP) -- Craigwood, a close second to Westward Ho in the Kent Stakes, fought off a determined challenge to Koko Dozo today to score a neck triumph in the $6,000 Kaye Ballard Purse at Monmouth Park.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--Joseph M. Dodge, special assistant to President Eisenhower, disclosed today that as Budget Bureau director he had made the policy decision that gave rise to the Dixon-Yates private power contract.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 2 -- Yugoslavia's readiness to revive relations with the Soviet Communist party was made known today. President Tito insisted, however, that Yugoslavia would not return to her pre-1948 position in the Soviet-led Cominform bloc.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 2 (UP) -- Little Joe O'Brien, the man who will drive heavily favored Scott Frost in the thirtieth Hambletonian Stakes tomorrow, refused today to join in the generally accepted opinion that his colt was a sure thing.
The cost of borrowing rose yesterday in another area of the money-lending market.

My attention has recently been called to Olin Downes' article of June 19 regarding possible demonstration of Carnegie Hall. I am writing not only as a lover of fine music to approve all his remarks and recommendations but also on accounts of my interest in preserving New York's architectural and cultural landmarks.
BOSTON, Aug. 2 -- Mayor John B. Hynes termed the Boston poliomyelitis situation a "limited emergency" today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- A House subcommittee deplored today "obvious inequities and injustices" in New York City's proposed redevelopment program of Washington Square Southeast.

The seething International Longshoremen's Association was somewhat mollified yesterday by the news that the Waterfront Commission would be "pleased to entertain a petition for rehearing" in connection with the agency's acceptance of the controversial Grumet report.

Near the end of the summer of 1953 I decided to visit the Ukraine by car. Accompanying me were Leonia, the chauffeur; Adele Lee, a secretary at the United States Embassy, and Mary Wojnar, formerly secretary to Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- A quiet, yet dramatic, meeting has just taken place in Lisbon, Portugal, between two European leaders who had never met before. They are Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, Premier of Portugal, and Paul Henri Spaak, Foreign Minister and former Premier of Belgium.
REDFIELD, S. D., Aug. 2The Russian visiting farm group today traded the parched cornfields of e'astern Nebraska for the sun-blasted wheat and cattle ranches of South Dakota.

Because of a typesetting error, a story from San Francisco printed in The New York Times last Saturday stated that Harry R. Bridges was ruled to have been a Communist by Dean James M. Landis of the Harvard Law School in 1939.

This is a special day in the little upstate town of Goshen. This is Hambletonian Day, and the quiet Hudson Valley community doffs its solitude to take on a stirring vibrancy for one of the classic American sports events. The Hambletonian is the richest of all harness-racing contests and a true touch of Americana.

The Garles Holding Corporation has purchased for investment the five-story apartment house on plot 100 by 125 feet at 4568-70 Manhattan College Parkway, near the Manhattan College grounds and West 238th Street, in the lower Riverdale section of the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 - Following is the text of reporters' questions about the United States-Chinese Communist talks at Geneva and Secretary of State Dulles' replies at his news conference today:

Next Monday the National Labor Relations Board is scheduled to hold a hearing of national interest and importance. The basic issue involved has already aroused the entire labor movement and it also urgently concerns the public: orderly collective bargaining.

DETROIT, Aug. 2 -- University scholarships totaling $21,000 were given to nine 'teen agers tonight as their share of $91,000 in awards by the Fisher Body Craftman's Guild. The nine were national winners in the annual model car competition sponsored by the Fisher Body Division, General Motors Corporation.
Sal Maglie is a member of the Indians as a result of the operation of a major league rule pushed through to adoption two years ago by Hank Greenberg, general manager of the Cleveland club.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- Jean Desses calls his fall and winter collection "Moineaux de Paris (Sparrows of Paris)." Interest centered mostly around the waist and hips in sparrow-tailed jackets and waistcoats, hip or three-quarter length to just above the hem of the skirt.
DAVOS, Switzerland, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The World Council of Churches opened its annual meeting today.
Stripped of its elevated railroad, Third Avenue is to emerge as a thing of beauty and a joy forever.
Jerome R. Allen Jr. has been named an assistant vice president of William Iselin Co., Inc., factoring concern.

Two books are published today. One is a two-volume work by Dr. Harald Hoffding, entitled "A History of Modern Philosophy: A Sketch of the History of Philosophy From the Close of the Renaissance to Our Own Day." Translated from the German by B. E. Meyer, it is issued by Dover Publications in a paper edition at $2 and a cloth edition at $4.
All coffee future contracts on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange rose the daily limit of 2 cents a pound for the second day yesterday in the slowest volume in more than a week.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 2 -- Despite the extreme heat, Victor Seixas, the national champion, and all of the other ranking Americans survived the second round of play without difficulty in the Eastern grass court tournament today.
The Board of Estimate unanimously passed out $597,250 in pay rises yesterday to 242 top city officials and jurists.

Secretary Dulles has taken advantage of a lull in the ambassadorial conference in Geneva between this country and Communist China to reiterate where we stand. This he did at his press conference yesterday. We are not prepared to surrender our principles in order to placate Peiping. We will not negotiate with a pistol at our head.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Aug. 3 -- Congress tested its vibrato, told a few jokes and moaned on its harmonica before it wearily adjourned early this morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -President Eisenhower fared better in the first session of the Democratic Eighty-fourth Congress than he had expected. In 1954 he predicted a "partisan cold war" if the Republicans failed to win control of the legislative branch in the elections that year.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 2 -- The deadlock between Singapore's Legislative Assembly and the British authorities continued today.
WASINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -- Senator William F. Knowland said President Eisenhower assured him today that he had made "no deal" at Geneva to "sell out" the United States' allies in Asia.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 2 -- This capital still was excited tonight over the Government's statement demanding that the Communists withdraw from territory they hold in Western Korea south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel.

One of the most widely discussed ideas in retirement planning marked its third year of operation last month. This is the variable annuity for educators, established by the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association. It has influenced the adoption of similar annuities in other fields.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Following are tables listing the record of the votes of the Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on thirteen major issues in the first session of the Eighty-fourth Congress:

THE subpavement surgery job for the pedestrian passageway from the new Socony Mobil skyscraper at Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street to Grand Central Terminal, started last May, is within two months of completion now.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- The five-day forecast for continued abnormally high temperatures over the Corn Belt states with only scattered showers indicated, started heavy covering of short lines in corn, and also stimulated fairly general commission buying of a general sort.
MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Aug. 2 -- A young matron of this commuting village on the south shore of Long Island has been appointed cantor of Temple Avodah, a Reform congregation at Oceanside.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 2 -- A break in the logjam blocking the formation of a new Indonesian Cabinet appeared to have been achieved today.

You report that the Board of Estimate has rejected the plan of Park Commissioner Robert Moses to convert the site of the abandoned Neponsit Beach Hospital, and you comment on the action in your editorial of July 22. I am deeply shocked that such a neglect of the public can occur in this day and age.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- President Eisenhower again voiced his irritation today with the "restrictive" and "awkward" Refugee Relief Act.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Congress ignored Administration objections today and sent the President a bill authorizing 45,000 new public housing units between now and July 31, 1956.
Six men were seized here early yesterday as members of a band distributing hundreds of thousands of dollars' worth of narcotics smuggled into the country from Mexico and South America.

Chief Inspector Stephen P. Kennedy became the city's new Police Commissioner yesterday. Appointed and sworn in by Mayor Wagner, the 48-year-old career policeman pledged that the force under his direction, would "stand together and give our utmost -- our lives if necessary" to stop crime.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 2 -- Two Connecticut crews representing the Riverside Yacht Club and Rocky Point Sailing Club were tied for the lead today in the girls' sailing championship of Long Island Sound.

Viewing the future with the exhilarating optimism of youth, Theatre 12 is examining the potentialities of "Judith" and "A Month in the Country." Each production will draw upon performers from the band's current offering of "The Trial" at the Provincetown Playhouse.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The furnishings for the scene in which President Eisenhower endorsed one of the most momentous decisions of his life have been presented to him by an anonymous donor.

HALIFAX, N. S., Aug. 2 (Canadian Press) -- The Maritimes Transportation Commission made a plea for free Commonwealth competition in Canadian waters. The plea was made today as the Royal Commission on the Coasting Trade opened its Halifax session.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Paul W. Williams of New York was confirmed by the Senate late last night as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The suggestion that the British Government's tighter money policy might make it necessary for holders to sell shares to reduce bank overdrafts depressed industrial shares on the London stock market today.

IT'S a rare parent who at some time or other hasn't lost his temper with his child. Whether this is (a) a grievous crime, (b) a mere reminder of human frailty or (c) a perfectly right and proper state of affairs is a point of difference among child-care specialists today.

Any thoughtful list of vacation pleasures can be started in only one way. High up there, indeed at the very top, there should be written the word clamming. Below it may follow such lesser things as fishing, sailing, golf, motoring, porch rocking and hiking.

SOME of the world's most celebrated writers are considerably more interesting for what they were than for what they wrote. Most readers, for instance, prefer to read about Samuel Johnson or George Sand than to read their works. The Bronte sisters are almost in this category and would be in it were it not for the endless fascination of Emily Bronte's "Wuthering Heights" and a half dozen of her magnificent poems.

Trainmen on the Long Island Rail Road voted yesterday to strike at 4 A. M. Saturday. But the National Mediation Board moved at once to block the walkout under the "cooling-off" provisions of the Railway Labor Act.
PUGWASH, N. S., Aug. 2 -Half a dozen scholars demonstrated today that there is more than one way toward the most congenial meeting of minds.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation and the International Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., announced yesterday that agreement had been reached on a wage increase for 4,200 employes in Hoboken and Brooklyn plants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP)--A former Federal Bureau of Investigation informant said today the Communists "didn't give a hoot" about Ethel and Julius Rosenberg but had fought their execution to embarrass the United States and help Russia.
Eleven physically handicapped young men returned to their jobs here in triumph yesterday after winning victories in the Fourth International Paralympic Games last week in Aylesbury, England.

Mayor Wagner, after looking around a bit, has decided to take his new Police Commissioner from the ranks. He is Stephen P. Kennedy, a veteran of a quarter of a century in the department, who has been chief inspector, in charge of the uniformed forces, since early 1954.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP)Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, accused the Eisenhower Administrationi today of abridging freedom of the press and putting a "shroud of silence" over Government activities.

The Precision Steel Corporation, whose chief asset is a Bridgeport, Conn., mill that makes specialty steels, has been acquired by three officials of the Solar Steel Corporation. The purchasers are Sol H. Friedman, president of Solar Steel, and Daniel A. Friedman and J. B. Ribakoff, vice president of Solar.

Increases in tire prices by three smaller manufacturers yesterday, following 3 1/2 and 6 per cent increases earlier by three major producers, again were attributed to rising costs laid to the tight supply of natural rubber. And the Natural Rubber Bureau in Washington said there was nothing much to be done about it.

After an irregular and weak opening, stocks improved in the middle of yesterday's session and closed a trifle higher on the day. Rails did better than the industrials, but there was strength for some aircrafts, motors, metals, electrical equipments and steels.
SEOUL, Korea, July 27 -- Kim In Ok and Lee Kwan Soon are two war prisoners at large here who probably never will be taken into custody.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Secretary of State Dulles suggested today that if Communist China would renounce the use of military force the path toward broad negotiations would be opened.

Max Fuks, 23-year-old French hitchhiker, arrived in New York two days ago from Mexico at the half-way mark of a world tour that has taken him to twenty-two countries so far. Two years ago with $4 in his pocket, a rucksack and an air mattress, he left his job of diamond cutting in a small Paris shop to embark on his life's ambition to hitchhike around the world.

An investment syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust Company submitted the best bid yesterday for $3,740,000 of school bonds of Wichita, Kan., due serially on Sept. 1 from 1956 to 1975. The bid designated an interest cost of 2.552 per cent. Subject to award, the bonds were reoffered at prices to yield from 1.4 to 2.6 per cent.
BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., Aug. 2--John N. Matthews' twelve-meter, Vim, climbed up-wind with great agility to win the Queen's Cup, today, one of the most desired trophies of the New York Yacht Club cruise.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) --The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged twelve mining companies, including several which deal in uranium, with failure to file required stock sales reports and ordered them to stop issuing stocks for public sale.
A series of animated cartoon films in color will be produced by United Productions of America for television-showing over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
Governor Harriman is to return today from a twenty-seven-day trip to Europe and Israel. He is due to arrive at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 8:42 A. M.

The New York Regional Blood Program will have three mobile units in operation today. They will receive donations from military and civilian personnel at Fort Totten, Bayside, Queens; Green Haven State Prison, Stormville, N. Y., and from employes of S. H. Kress Co., 114 Fifth Avenue.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company registered yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission the largest single issue of corporate securities in history.
Two Air Force officers whose 45,200-foot parachute jumps last year are the highest on record plan to double their mark.

PLEASANTVILLE N. Y., Aug. 2 -- A thousand signatures have been obtained by the Westchester Commuters Committee to petitions protesting late and dirty New York Central trains, Robert S. Larkin, temporary committee chairman, has announced.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP) The American Civil Liberties Union said tonight it had won a fight to obtain travel permits for two Americans whose applications had been rejected by the State Department.
LATE but welcome, peaches soon will be arriving here in quantity, to sell at much reduced prices. Crop failures in the South deprived us of the fine peaches usually available during June and July.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 2 -- Clifford Odets is talking with Columbia Pictures about directing the Biblical drama "Joseph and his Brethren," for which he wrote the final shooting script.
Stephen Patrick Kennedy, the city's new Police Commissioner, can use books or fists with equal facility.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 2 -- Dr. George K. C. Yeh, Nationalist China's Foreign Minister, warned the United States today that the Communist release of eleven American airmen should not be made the "subject of political bargaining" with Communist China.

Lieut. Gen. Clarence R. Huebner, retired, New York State's civil defense director, recommended yesterday that a Government subsidy be used if necessary to keep the New York Central's Weehawken ferries operating.

Not a great deal is known about Pere David's deer except by specialists who know a great deal about deer. Pere David's deer may not even know very much about itself, or even care to. As pictorially portrayed in a recent issue of this newspaper, it is a sad animal, which evidently wonders about things but doesn't arrive at any encouraging conclusions.
The Atlas Intercontinental Ballistic Missile will be the ultimate military end product of our years of post-war research and development in the science of rocketry.
A blistering sun brought two unwelcome records to the city yesterday. It was the hottest day of the year and the hottest Aug. 2 on record.

During the years which I spent at City Hall as administrative secretary to Mayor O'Dwyer and as chairman of the City Temporary Housing Rent Commission, and later for some years as attorney for the Tenants' Councils of New York City, I had occasion to learn at first hand that tenement fires are not particularly selective or discriminating.
LAKE RONKONKOMA, L. I., Aug. 2 -- When the young pupils attending the Suffolk School for the Deaf here return to classes in September they will miss an old friend, Bobo.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Sales of wholesalers in June ran 11 per cent ahead of sales for the corresponding month last year, the Bureau of the Census reported today. The June figure this year was 4 per cent above that of May.
ROME, Aug. 2 (2P) -- Italy reverberated today with repercussions of a soccer expose comparable to America's 1919 Black Sox baseball scandal.

CARLISLE, Pa., Aug. 2 (AP) -- A 60-year-old man, shouting he had been given a "raw deal" in a nonsupport case, went berserk in Cumberland County Court today. He whipped out a .38-calibre pistol and killed an attorney.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 2 -- Most of the nation's medical doctors went on strike today in protest against the death of Juan Ingalinella.
GENEVA, Aug. 2 -- The Russians are showing a great deal of interest in establishing some kind of formal connection with the Western system of international trade.

SHELTER ISLAND, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- A line squall with considerable sea and wind interrupted a sluggish start and finish in today's squadron run on the American Yacht Club's annual cruise. Hail stones also pelted the fleet as it crossed Gardiners Bay en route from Fishers Island to Cedar Island Light, a journey of 18.2 miles.

The Reynolds Metals Company announced yesterday that it planned to increase its primary aluminum producing capacity to 1,100,000,000 pounds a year. The nation's second largest aluminum producer, Reynolds now has a capacity of 830,000,000 pounds. Richard S. Reynolds Jr., president, called the company's latest expansion program the "largest and most comprehensive" in its history.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Defense Department announced today the allocation of $11,300,000 for the development of a light fighter plane by France, Italy and Britain for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 2 (UP) -- Budge Patty of Los Angeles, who teamed with Baron Gottfried Von Cramm of Germany, was the only American to reach the men's doubles semi-finals of the Hamburg international tennis tournament today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 2--The discovery that zinc plays an important role in the processes of digestion as well as in the respiratory mechanisms of the living cell, was reported here today. The announcement was made at the third International Congress of Biochemistry.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 (UP) -- A local radio station today completed arrangements to buy controlling interest in the San Francisco Seals, but Paul I. Fagan, who owns the Stadium, indicated he might block the deal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Following is a summary of the twenty major legislative proposals President Eisenhower made in his State of the Union Message Jan. 6, and how they fared in the first session of the Eighty-fourth Congress:
SODA SPRINGS, Calif., Aug. 2 (UP) -- Airman Daniel C. Schmidt, one of the eleven American fliers being released by the Chinese Reds, will come home to find his 20-year-old wife has remarried.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 22 -- It was a rough three-day drive here from Baghdad, Iraq. But it was a breeze compared with the ordeal of crossing the 600 miles of desert from Damascus, Syria, to Baghdad.
THERE are few forms of angling with a lower success ratio than that of fishing for broadbill swordfish.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points down to 5 up yesterday.
Tommy Byrne, who was pretty much the strong, silent type during his first tenure with the Yankees, has perfected a new "pitch" since he returned to the Stadium last September.

A syndicate of investment houses headed by Lehman Brothers is offering today a new issue of common shares of the Scudder Fund of Canada, Ltd., to enable the investment company to put about $10,292,000 of more capital at work in developing Canadian industry.

The history over recent years of the proceedings of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations would reasonably indicate that the committee's investigations produce results most beneficial to the country when its chairman and its counsel are of a political faith different from that of the Executive branch of our Government.
