The Boeing Airplane Company showed a drop of 21.4 per cent in its half-year earnings from the period a year ago, reflecting a 25.4 per cent decline in sales.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Following are the major legislative enactments of the first session of the Eighty-fourth Congress:
GENEVA, Aug. 2 -- The Russians announced their plans today for the atomic energy exhibition to be held here during the atoms-for-peace conference that starts next week.
GENEVA, Aug. 2 -- Communist China proposed today that a third power be assigned to verify the unwillingness of Chinese students in the United States to return home.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 2 -John Sherman Cooper, United States Ambassador to New Delhi, said today that the Indian Government had played a "very important and very effective role" in the release of the United States airmen held by Communist China.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- The police used tear gas here tonight to disperse demonstrators who had smashed windows in the British Council building and tried to set fire to it.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The report of the Department of Agriculture on today's livestock markets follows:

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (UP) -- Lionel Hebert of Erie, Pa., shot a seven-under-par 65 today to lead approximately 150 professional golfers in the qualifying play for Tam o' Shanter's annual All- American golf tournament. The tournament proper will start on Thursday.
A trade group urged yesterday that the Government of India take prompt action to establish more stable policies on exports of specialty cottons.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -Male assistants to Republican members of the House of Representatives, who style themselves the Bull Elephont Club, gathered on the White House lawn today.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 2 -- Little Don Zimmer made his first error since April 22 last night and it cost the Dodgers a ball game. The Braves scored two unearned runs in the eighth inning on the bad throw to break a tie and win, 5 -- 3.

Despite a lower volume of defense business, sales of Robertshaw-Fulton Controls Company in the first six months this year reached a record $31,404,104, a gain of 8.25 per cent over the $29,009,109 volume for the period a year ago, John A. Robertshaw, president, reported yesterday.
Casey Stengel and his Yankees sprang something new on the Indians at the Stadium last night. They sank the Tribe, 2--1, with a one-man attack. Joe Collins was the man.
In a bitter Queens primary fight, nominating petitions bearing 42,293 names were filed yesterday for State Senator Frank D. O'Connor as Democratic candidate for District Attorney.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Aug. 3 -- The first session of the Democratic Eighty-fourth Congress adjourned early today.
Children from 100 lands are speaking a common language in a show that opened here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Following are tables listing the detailed record of the most significant votes in the Senate in the first session of the Eighty-fourth Congress now ended. All Senators are recorded.
HONG KONG, Wednesday, Aug. 3 -- Two United States Air Force planes are standing by at Kaitak Airfield here to carry home the eleven American fliers about to be released from Communist China.

Thomas J. Maldona, 21-year-old seaman, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to broadcasting a false distress signal. The hoax, carried out last July 7, started a search that cost the Government $50,000.
PARIS, Aug. 2 -- Nationalist agitation in North Africa is part of a world-wide Soviet plot aided by United States anti-colonialism, according to Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -- Chicago maintained its one-game hold on the American League lead tonight. Connie Johnson pitched the White Sox to a six-hit, 2-1 victory over the threatening fourth-place Boston Red Sox before a crowd of 35,455.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 2--The Ceylonese Government has been informed that the question of exempting Ceylon from the restrictions of the Battle Act and thereby making her eligible to receive United States aid will come up for discussion soon in the United States Government.
TOKYO, Aug. 2 -- A Defense Council was formed today by the Japanese Government.

KRASNODAR, U. S. S. R., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Members of the American farm delegation touring the Soviet Caucasus are asking their Russian hosts what religious facilities are provided for collective farmers and if Soviet youths are attending church.
Home owners can now install their own fire alarms. Two new, permanent, automatic systems by the Edwards Company, Inc., are available at Patterson Brothers, 15 Park Row.

Latin America appears to be gaining as a market for this country's producers, and vice versa. Following last week's formation of a New York subsidiary of publicidad Badillo, Puerto Rican advertising agency, to serve marketers in the Latin-American area, word came yesterday that International Advertising Service, Buenos Aires agency, would extend its marketing promotional services to Latin-American industries in cooperation with Reed-Jones, Inc., of this city.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--The Air Force announced tentative plans today for bringing the eleven airmen being released by Communist China to the West Coast for reunion with their relatives.
STRANGE, indeed, are the devious routes baseball's peons must follow as they make their appointed rounds before coming to the road marked "dead end."

The Columbia-Southern Chemical Corporation of Pittsburgh and Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., of England have applied for a United States Government contract to supply granular titanium. Under the proposed agreement, the Government would buy 5,000 short tons a year of the metal over a five-year period.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Private American business interests have submitted to Soviet authorities a plan for a United States trade exposition in Moscow next summer, specializing in agriculture.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 2 -- The head of the Satellite Project Commission in the Soviet Union said today that the Russians were considering launching satellites of different weights and sizes.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 -- A year ago Johnny Antonelli of the Giants led the league with six shutouts. Tonight at Busch Stadium the southpaw fashioned his first whitewashing job of 1955, a 3-0 blanking of the Cardinals.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Aug. 4 -- President Syngman Rhee said today South Korea did not intend to create the impression that "we want to renew a war." He spoke of reactions to his Government's statement two days demanding Communist withdrawal from below the Thirty-eighth Parallel.

According to H. Daniel Carpenter, director of the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House, a settlement house should not serve just as a center for recreation -- it should be the headquarters for combating community problems. In line with this, the Guild, which is located in the Chel sea section of Manhattan, has been focusing great attention on easing the integration of the many Puerto Rican newcomers to the neighborhood.

ABERDEEN, S. D., Aug. 3 -- The search for a variety of corn that would flourish in Russia's dryer, shorter growing season was extended to North Dakota today. One of the specialists in the Soviet farm delegation flew to Fargo to confer with corn growers of North Dakota State College.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Aug. 3 -- A long-smoldering dispute at the College of William and Mary broke into the open today with the resignation from the faculty of Dr. James W. Miller. Professor of Philosophy, former dean and at one time acting president of the college.

Shipping activity in the Port of New York in the first seven months of the year showed an appreciable numerical gain over the same period of last year, according to statistics released yesterday by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Butcher hogs and sows mostly sold steady to 25 cents higher today. Salable receipts at 6,500 head were 1,000 less than expected, which helped bolster the market. Despite the general advance, the top price at $16.25 was 25 cents below yesterday's and at a new low since March 9, when the top was $16.
The plum of museum posts in this hemisphere -- directorship of the Metropolitan Museum of Art -- was awarded yesterday to James J. Rorimer, director of its famous Cloisters.

The Port of New York Authority took the first step yesterday in its proposed $70,000,000 reconstruction and modernization of the two miles of Brooklyn waterfront from Brooklyn Bridge south to Atlantic Basin.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- Edgar Faure, l' remier of France, hopes to fol-] lowChancellor Adenauer to] Moscow within about a month,I subject to approval of his cabi-I net. With him will go the Foreign Minister, Antoine Pinay. Meanwhile, a French parliamen-, tary delegation has been invited to visit Moscow in the second half of September.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 3 -- The coalition effort to form a cabinet to govern Indonesia collapsed this afternoon. A new attempt was launched with a single political party taking the lead.
Governor Harriman, in a two-edged compliment, said yesterday that "sincere statements" by President Eisenhower at Geneva "undid much of the damage done in recent years."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- The United States Border Patrol has set up a highly mobilized task force of 400 men in the Southwest ready to spring into action anywhere "on very short notice."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 -- If what has been happening to the Giants' pitchers recently had happened a couple of months ago, things might have been different in the National League race this season. Instead of battling for second place, Leo Durocher's lads might now be considerably closer to the Dodgers, fighting them for the top spot.
The Park Association of New York City, Inc., obtained a stay yesterday that temporarily prohibits the city from selling the Neponsit Beach Hospital site in Neponsit, Queens.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy promised yesterday that promotions in his department would be made only for what policemen "do in the public interest."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 -- Kim Hunter, who has given most of her time to the stage since appearing on the screen in "Deadline, U. S. A." three years ago, is coming back to Hollywood for one movie, at least.

Hewitt-Robins, Inc., Stamford, Conn., manufacturer of rubber and machinery products, has arranged to acquire the W. A. Jones Foundry and Machine Company, Chicago. The latter concern makes heavy-duty speed reducers, pulleys, gears and other accessories used to drive machinery.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 3 -- The Soviet Government invited Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today to visit Moscow at the end of this month or early in September. The purpose of the visit would be to discuss diplomatic, economic and cultural relations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- The head of the General Services Administration testified today that Harold E. Talbott had praised two concerns that later received a $1,000,000 Government contract. But the retiring Air Secretary did not use "pressure" in their behalf, Edmund F. Mansure declared.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson, the third-ranking heavyweight contender, befuddled and outfought the former world champion, Ezzard Charles, tonight to gain a unanimous ten-round decision. The defeat may have ended Ezzard's sixteen-year career.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The United States will agree to permit a third power to check the situation of only those Chinese students who say they want to return to Communist China.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -A New York City couple filed suit today in Federal District Court in Chicago charging that stockholders of Peabody Coal Company were cheated out of $10,000,000 in the recent acquisition by Peabody of the Sinclair group of coal companies.

New York City is governed by people and it is mistaken economy to underpay them. The Board of Estimate has voted $597,250 to increase the salaries of 242 executives and judges. Some opposition was voiced in a public hearing, but it was not impressive in volume or in persuasiveness of argument.
Middle-income families, who have had to live in substandard housing in "increasing numbers,'' were told yesterday they could expect aid from the state's new Limited Profit Housing Law.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $37,801,184 in the first half of the year. This equaled $2.92 each on the average of 12,939,543 shares outstanding in the period, and compared with $36,515,125, or $2.96 a share, in the first half of 1954, when there were 12,310,398 shares outstanding.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- The Royal Society announced today a new British research program for exploring the earth's upper atmosphere by the use of high-altitude rockets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended July 27:
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 3 -- Kentucky's most powerful Democratic leaders personally took the reins today in an all-out drive to defeat Albert B. (Happy) Chandler, their long-time factional opponent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Texas Democrats dropped $30,000 in the party's national till today and talked party harmony with the National Chairman, Paul M. Butler, and Speaker Sam Rayburn.
Two youths adrift on a raft in the Harlem River were rescued yesterday by a passer-by who dived into the river and swam 200 feet against a nine-knot current.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- The fashion world, gathered here from the four corners of the globe, had been jittery for two days because Balenciaga had postponed his showing. Today the big event took place, and set new exciting trends in fashion that are the talk of the town.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- The American Association for the United Nations proposed today that the United Nations take jurisdiction to coordinate human attempts to launch earth-girdling satellites into space.

Three perfect papers were turned in last night at the annual Music Memory Contest of the Guggenheim Memorial Concerts on the Mall in Central Park. They were written by Albert E. Koonz, 1650 Bogart Avenue, the Bronx; Marcus L. Erstling, 53 West Eighty-second Street, and Nicholas J. Eberhard, 3209 Park Avenue, the Bronx.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Britain's gold and dollar reserves fell by $136,000,000 last month.

The Avis Rent-a-Car System, which operates throughout this country and Canada and in eleven other nations, is to be a national advertiser. Through N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., the concern, consisting of its franchise-operated rental offices in more than 300 cities, plus company-owned branches, is to be promoted in a list of national magazines and in two series of newspaper advertisements.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 3 -- The Peronista party's new titular chief, Dr. Alejandro Leloir, reaffirmed tonight the party's "inflexible determination" to remain unprovoked by opposition attacks and to restore political peace to the nation.

Summertime is a terrible time to be sufficiently indisposed to stay home from the office but not ill enough to be flat on one's back. Any time, of course, is a bad time not to be well, but somehow it is worse to be indisposed in summertime because there are so many things going on, and because the line between outdoors and indoors is so easily crossed.

The nation's stocks of gasoline declined 673,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 157,005,000 barrels, compared with 157,678,000 a week earlier and 158,402,000 a year ago.
Twenty-one cases of polio in New York City, the largest daily total since the first of the year, were reported to the Health Department yesterday.
"IS this a legal trout, or am I eligible for a fine?" This was not a new or unusual question, but it did involve a new and unusual fish.

The irresponsible act of Communist frontier guards in Bulgaria, which ended in death for fifty-eight innocent passengers, has rightly outraged world opinion. It has brought sadness to thousands of Bulgarian exiles, and has intensified their distaste for the present rulers of Bulgaria, who have just cast another infamous blot on the good name of their fatherland.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- An appeal for suspension of the death penalty was presented to Maj. Gwilym Lloyd-George, the Home Secretary, today by the Howard League for Penal Reform. The appeal was signed by about 100 clergymen, scientists, lawyers, doctors and others.
PADANARAM, Mass., Aug. 3 -- Tioga, a year-old, Italian-built yawl, owned by Bradley P. Noyes, took on the look of a heroine on the New York Yacht Club cruise during the last twenty-four hours.
Mechanics at Hare Motors in Jackson Heights, Queens, were as frightened as hares yesterday when a pair of husky horses galloped into the garage with an ancient landau in tow.
ATLANTA, Aug. 3 -- Georgia's Attorney General announced today the appointment of twenty-five "special deputies" to assist his office to preserve segregation of the races in the public schools.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Soviet scientists who attended the opening of an international scientific conference on nuclear developments here today denied that it was inevitable that nuclear weapons would be used in a future world war.

Mobile Ala., borrowed $17,000,000 in the public market yesterday to refund outstanding debt of the Bankhead Tunnel and to finance modernization of the vehicular river crossing and the building of approach highways.

The Nassau County Cerebral Palsy Association will be the beneficiary of the third annual Forget Me Not Ball to be held on Sept. 24 in O'Hara Hall at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L. I.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 3 -- Machinery to bring about closer relations between teachers of the free world and the Iron Curtain countries is in sight. A resolution was proposed today at the conference of the World Confederation of Organizations of the Teaching Profession to establish a liaison committee with Soviet-dominated International Federation of Teachers Unions.

Recent dispatches from Belgrade indicate that President Tito of Yugoslavia is going somewhere, politically speaking. It is still hard to determine where. The best surmise one can make is that he is at the moment captivated with the idea of neutralism and a comfortable position on the middle ground.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Aug. 3 -- Traffic from New York coming out of the Lincoln Tunnel here was detoured again today. Blasting of rock for construction of the $100,000,000 third tube prevented use of the circular ramp leading to main New Jersey highways.

Prices of coffee for delivery in 1956 rose the daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange for the third day yesterday. Contracts expiring this year closed unchanged to 75 points (hundredth of a cent a pound) higher.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, asked Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. today to assign the "best talent" in the Justice Department to a second attempt to indict Corliss Lamont for refusing to answer questions of Senate investigators.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 3 -- A French woman and a Vietnamese man were injured tonight when a bomb exploded in the main postoffice. The building is across the street from the National Police Headquarters.

HONG KONG, Thursday, Aug. 4 -- After more than two and a half years as prisoners of the Chinese Communists, eleven United States Air Force fliers reached freedom here today. They crossed the Kwangtung-Hong Kong border into this British Crown Colony at 1:37 P. M. [12:37 A. M., Eastern daylight time].

BOSTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury was impaneled today to investigate the gasoline industry, in what Judge William T. McCarthy said was a Government contention that the industry violated the Federal Antitrust Act by price fixing.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- The Labor party's annual conference at Margate in October promises to be largely a post-morten on the election the party lost to the Conservatives this spring.

A militant division of the Treasury Department, established to help suppress smuggling, is pausing today to look back on its long history. This is the 165th anniversary of the founding of the Coast Guard.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Air Force will shoot a huge cloud of vaporized sodium sixty miles up next fall, re-creating the glow of the moon in its exploration of outer space.

CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 3 -- A two-day strike at the John H. Mathis Shipyards ended today as 190 workers voted unanimously to accept wage increases agreed on last night by officials of the company and Local 56, Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America. C. I. O.
AMOUNTED buffalo head that has waged a losing fight against generations on moths and that stares at yachtsmen with sodden eyes may be the most heartily avoided of all sports trophies.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange eased 6 to 14 points (30 to 70 cents a bale) yesterday in slow trading.
The General Dynamics Corporation will be represented by an eye-catching exhibit at the commercial atomic energy exposition to be held at Geneva, Switzerland, Aug. 8-20.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 3 -- Space-flight enthusiasts at the annual Congress of the International Astronautical Federation here are still uncertain about what part they can play in the launching of the first man-made satellite by the United States.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 3 -- Invisible light from the nucleus of an artificially made form of carbon has indicated the course taken by green plants in the creation of sugar.
TORONTO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Canadian Boy Scout officials have announced that Polish Scouts in exile are not qualified to attend the World Scout Jamboree in Niagara-on-the-Lake, Aug. 20-28.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- A onetime informant for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today a fellow-Communist had told him of having persuaded two ministers to take up church collections for the defense of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg.
Special "gardens of fragrance" for the blind were sharply criticized yesterday at a national meeting of blind war veterans.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Bob Hale stepped in as a pinch hitter with two strikes against him and smashed a two-run double in the ninth inning as the Baltimore Orioles defeated Kansas City, 4 -- 3, tonight in the first game of a twilight-night doubleheader.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The president of a Kansas City, Mo., concern today disputed testimony that it sold defective grain bins to the Agriculture Department.

A 19-year-old clerk for a hardware company was kidnapped yesterday morning on crowded Seventh Avenue, near Twenty-eighth Street, and taken to Fairview, N. J., where he was knocked unconscious and robbed of $1,632.
A possible gang fight in the east Bronx was averted late last night with the arrest of eight youths armed with six "Molotov cocktails," the police of the Williamsbridge Road station reported.

TOMATOES, the most popular vegetable we eat next to potatoes and cabbage, will reach peak supply this month and next. Locally grown specimens will be at their fullest in flavor, lowest in price and highest in nutrients. Garden tomatoes supply approximately twice the amount of ascorbic acid (Vitamin C) as the hothouse variety.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The State Department bowed today to a court ruling that the department had no absolute discretion over passports.

STONINGTON, Conn., Aug. 3 -- A pair of noted Two-Ten skippers, Dick Becker of Larchmont Y. C. and Commodore James Mertz of the host club, dominated the sailing today as the American Y. C.'s twenty-fourth annual cruise moved twenty-two miles from Shelter Island to this port.
The four-month Waterfront Commission proceedings against six New Jersey dockworkers charged with exacting kickbacks were completed yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, United Nations Under Secretary General, has given permission for the new "Du Pont Calvacade Theatre" to dramatize a portion of his youth for the series.
The marked recovery of textile producers was evidenced in the reports of companies that announced their operating results yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -Strains put upon the nation's metal supply by the expanding volume of production of consumer goods resulted in two Governmental steps today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 3 -- While coffee futures soared in New York because of frost damage to next year's Brazilian crop. warnings were heard here today against forcing them too high.

The Securities and Exchange Commission intervened yesterday in the bitter proxy contest for control of Libby, McNeil Libby. It sued to block temporarily efforts of an insurgent group to win control of the big food company at the annual meeting in Portland, Me., on Aug. 17.

BALDWIN, L. I., Aug. 3 -- Two brothers, 9 and 12 years old, admitted today that they had killed their four-month-old dog in a park here last Saturday, but denied witnesses' reports that they had tortured the puppy to death.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 3 -- Gil Hodges hit the eleventh grand-slam homer of his career and another two-run blast tonight as the Dodgers beat the Braves, 9 -- 6, at County Stadium.

Today's new film is Paramount's "To Catch a Thief," starring Cary Grant and Grace Kelly, at the Paramount. Jessie Royce Landis, John Williams, Charles Vanel, Brigitte Auber and Georgette Anys head the supporting cast.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Government bonds were dull, along with industrial shares, as buyers withdrew from the stock markets today. News of the big fall in gold and dollar reserves in July sent Government bonds as much as ten shillings ($1.40) lower.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 2 -- Recent action by the United States Government has called attention to the unannounced and informal devaluation of Yugoslav currency.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- The state Civil Defense director unveiled here today a state-wide plan for evacuating New York's major urban areas in advance of an enemy attack.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- James P. Mitchell issued today a minimum wage order for soft coal mined on Government contracts, proposing rates in virtually all areas at the levels paid to John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture today estimated the value of farm exports for the fiscal year ended June 30 at $3,130,000,000.
WE have four books on our table this morning -- and a letter from John Kieran. The books take us to two wars and two encounters with childhood. The letter from Mr. Kieran is strictly about the birds.

An impulsive reaction to the circumstances that caused Harold E. Talbott to resign as Secretary of the Air Force and the President to accept that as the "right" thing to do, seems to have pervaded the business and financial communities. This reaction was, as one industrialist expressed it with bitter wit: "The only thing a business man has to gain in a Washington job is the loss of his reputation."
SEATTLE, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Record speeds and tough luck rode Lake Washington together today in qualifying trials for Sunday's Gold Cup.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- Before the first race today Ted Atkinson, the Greentree Stable contract rider, was sitting outside the Saratoga jockey room chatting with a friend. Among other things, Atkinson talked about Greentree's lack of success at the meeting that opened Monday.

Your recent feature entitled "Garden for the Blind to be laid out in Central Park" caught my interest. I am compelled to offer my observation on Leonard Wallstein's generous offer in the interest of blind people in general, and sighted people who wish to help in the adjustment of blindness.

GENEVA, Aug. 3 -- Washington is expected to reject Peiping's proposal that a third power be asked to determine whether Chinese students in the United States have freely decided against returning to their Communist-ruled homeland.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- One hundred teachers from thirty-two states will leave Friday to exchange positions during the 1955-56 school year with the same number of teachers of the United Kingdom.
A hotel and two apartment houses at the northeast corner of Broadway and West Sixty-ninth Street have been sold by Samson Rosenblatt to an investing client of Nathan Miller, broker in the deal.
HONG KONG, Thursday, Aug. 4 -- Upon arrival at the Jockey Club, the eleven fliers posed for photographs for about twenty minutes and then asked for cold beer and milk.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Fuen Ronnapakas, chief Air Force marshal, became Deputy Premier in a reshuffle of the Thai Cabinet, it was announced today.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 3 -- Bulgaria acknowledged today that two of her fighter planes shot down the Israeli airliner that carried fifty-eight persons to death a week ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- President Eisenhower gave the Republican party fresh cause for worry today about his plans for a second term.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 -- The Screen Actors Guild announced late today a break in the opposition by producers of television entertainment films to its demands for extra payment to actors starting with the second run of such movies.
Gene Woodling was accepting congratulations on the two-run homer he hit to beat the Yankees yesterday.

Federal Maritime Administrator Clarence G. Morse will be the principal speaker at the commencement exercises to be held tomorrow afternoon at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L. I.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 3 -- Jeronimo Remorino, the Foreign Minister, made public today a note to the International Court of Justice stating that the Argentine Government would not submit the problem of disputed Antarctic territories to the court.
There are no "big, bold strokes" that will solve the traffic problem, Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley reported to Mayor Wagner yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- A 482-year-old contract for the building of a house in Bristol's High Street has just come to light.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Air Force has awarded speed-up development contracts for three new supersonic aircraft. They are a long-range interceptor, a fighter-bomber and a tactical bomber.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 3 -- The parties comprising the middle-of-the-road coalition government of Premier Moshe Sharett obtained a total of 61 of the 120 seats in the third Knesset (Parliament), according to official results announced tonight.

In many ways the controversy developing about the satellite project was as inevitable as the project itself. Every great scientific development of our time, from the A-bomb to the Salk vaccine, creates new problems, and new problems create new arguments.
A HOT bread for a cold summer meal is a sound old theme in cookery that may be reworked to meet the demand for the quick-and-easy.
WASINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A credit of $60,000,000 in favor of the Bank of Japan to finance the purchase of American cotton was approved today by the Export-Import Bank here.

ELLENVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- A new musical festival was born here tonight on a high plateau that was meadow and woodland only six weeks ago. The Empire State Music Festival offered an inaugural program by the Symphony of the Air, with Eduard van Beinum, distinguished conductor of Amsterdam's Concertgebouw, on the podium.

In your story in The Times of July 29 concerning the petition of the Attorney General to determine that the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers is a "Communist-infiltrated" organization, you state that if the Subversive Activities Control Board so determines, the union would lose the right to represent the employes and all rights and privileges under the National Labor Relations Act.

An increase in international passenger traffic was reported yesterday by Trans World Airlines. E. O. Cocke, vice president, said that last month the airline had flown 76,500,000 passenger miles on its overseas routes, a 16 per cent increase over July, 1954.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A Soviet Embassy spokesman said to day that there had been a substantial increase in the number of visas issued to Americans "in recent weeks" for travel to the Soviet Union.

The recently published 1954 annual report of the Fire Department reveals two dramatic achievements under Commissioner Cavanagh's able leadership. They deserve wide public understanding -- and appreciation.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 3 -- Herbert Flam was beaten and Hamilton Richardson just managed to survive in the Eastern grass court tennis championships today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- The Continental Casualty Company and Continental Assurance Company expanded their business at record rates in the first half of the year, Roy Tuchbreiter, president of the two companies, said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Federal Reserve System moved today to dampen the mounting volume of business loans by member banks. It acted to diminish that source of inflationary pressure on the price structure.

A few Senatorial voices have been raised to protest against the President's intention to tell the world, the Soviet Union included, what information may be telemetered to ground stations by the artificial satellites that are to be sent up in 1957 or 1958.

WASHINGTON, Aug 3 (AP) -- President Eisenhower presented today to Robert B. Anderson the Medal of Freedom for "exceptionally meritorious service in furtherance of the security of the United States." Mr. Anderson of Vernon, Tex., is retiring soon as Deputy Secretary of Defense.
An adaptation of "Show Biz," a book about the history of the entertainment business, will be televised in color by the National Broadcasting Company on Sunday, Oct. 9, from 7:30 to 9 P. M.

A strike of trainmen on the Long Island Rail Road, scheduled to start at 3 A. M. Saturday, was postponed indefinitely yesterday by the union. W. P. Kennedy, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, independent, notified the National Mediation Board that he had instructed the Long Island local to delay the strike pending mediation proceedings.
That hardy perennial, the International Flower Show, will bloom next spring in a temporary plot -- the south building of the old Wanamaker department store on Astor Place.

A military court ruled yesterday that Sgt. James C. Gallagher must stand trial for the murder of fellow war prisoners in Korea even though he was honorably discharged from the Army after the alleged offenses took place.

DETROIT, Aug. 3 -- A top-level General Motors executive expressed confidence today that the American market could absorb current and contemplated auto production. Ivan L. Wiles, vice president of the General Motors Corporation and general manager of the Buick division, said Buick's recently announced capacity expansion program was evidence of faith in the ability of the American economy to keep growing.
In May, 1954, I visited Sochi on the Soviet Riviera.
A little shift in the wind from south to southeast brought New Yorkers yesterday a welcome respite from the heat.
The ability to keep going still is not among the Yankees' better accomplishments this year.

"Makers of the Modern World," Louis Untermeyer's biographical portraits of ninety-two great moderns who, in his opinion, have most influenced our lives, our thinking, our emotional attitudes and tastes, will be issued Aug. 22 by Simon Schuster.
TRENTON, Aug. 3 -- State hospitals for the mentally ill in New Jersey are now discharging patients at a record rate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads said today the bulk of Class 1 rail carriers had an estimated net income of $416,000,000 for the first six months of this year. This is about 79 per cent higher than the $232,000,000 in earnings reported for the first half of 1954.

Options on two sites in New Jersey and New York, within fifty miles of the city, have been taken for construction of what is believed to be the first nuclear reactor to be owned and operated by private industry for research purposes.

Sales and earnings of Foremost Dairies, Inc., and its subsidiaries for the first six months this year were the highest in its history, Paul E. Reinhold, board chairman, reported yesterday in the semi-annual statement to stockholders.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -Millions of pounds of mild, top-quality tobacco, ignored by private buyers, are moving into the Government price-support program at Southern auctions.

Jack Resnick, realty investor, has purchased the ten - story Busher Building at 349 East 149th Street, the Bronx. The structure, one of the largest commercial buildings in the borough, was erected by the late Eugene J. Busher in 1928.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Dixon-Yates officials contended today that cancellation of their private power contract had to be negotiated.

Efforts are being made to pave the way for an exchange of paintings and entertainers with the Soviet Union. Carleton Smith, chairman of the advisory committees of the National Arts Foundation said yesterday that the approval of the Soviet Embassy in Washington had been obtained.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 3 -- All over northern and central India today young women were contentedly gathering in their small annual profit from the defeat of the demon king Bali.
A solid patch of sunlight broke through into a segment of Third Avenue yesterday.

OTTAWA, Aug. 3 -- C. D. Howe, Minister of Trade and Commerce, announced today that the Canadian Government probably will make no new contracts with uranium producers after March 31, 1956, unless the Government is satisfied that production will start by April 1, 1957.

How are women faring in the male-dominated career of medicine? "Women and men are accepted on an equal basis as physicians now and the battle, it seems to me, has been won," was one reply in a recent survey of women doctors by Barnard College.
If one may judge by the art exhibit of children's works on view through October at the main branch of the New York Public Library, no rose-colored bifocals are required by youngsters in viewing life.
President Eisenhower's prestige in Europe has been "enormously" increased as a result of the recent Geneva conference. Winthrop W. Aldrich, United States Ambassador to Britain, said here yesterday.
BOSTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Jackie Jensen's two - run double in the eighth inning gave the Boston Red Sox a 6-4 victory over the Chicago White Sox today.

The threat of a strike by unionized milk tank-truck drivers was renewed yesterday. But Martin T. Lacey, president of the Teamsters Joint Council, A. F. L., said there was little likelihood of a walkout before Monday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Louis E. Wolfson, Florida financier, asked $30,000,000 damages today in a suit filed in Federal District Court against The Washington Post and Times-Herald.

OTTAWA, Aug. 3 -- Better than average crops are expected everywhere in Canada except in the Central Provinces. Here in Ontario and Quebec prolonged drought is expected to cause farmers a loss of $100,000,000. After a bad harvest last summer farmers of Alberta, Manitoba and Saskatchewan are looking forward to a better than average grain yield this year.
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Aug. 2 -- The visitor to Casablanca would not guess this bustling and apparently peaceful city was convulsed only a fortnight ago with riots and bloodshed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Congress was adjourned today. But Capitol Hill was far from depopulated.

West Penn Electric Company and subsidiaries reported increases yesterday in operating revenues, net income and sales in the three major categories for six and twelve months ended June 30. Kilowatt hour sales to residential customers increased by 9.6 per cent in the first half over the like 1954 period, and by 10.4 per cent in the twelve-month period.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Corn and soybean futures extended their advances early in the session, but met considerable profit-taking, causing recessions from top levels. But there was a good deal of uneasiness over weather conditions, especially as the Government, as well as private forecasters, look for a hotter than usual August with a lack or rain over the central areas and plains sections.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Roger Moens of Belgium bettered one of the oldest existing track records today when he established a world mark of 1:45.7 for the 800-meter run in an international meet at Bislet Stadium.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Yugoslav communism demanded today that the Soviet-dominated Cominform be dissolved and replaced by a new organization that would include all socialistic movements.
MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 3 -- Robert Behrle, taxi driver, didn't argue very long last night when a fare told him, "You have passed my street."

KRASNODAR, U. S. S. R., Aug 3 -- Twelve embattled American farmers touring the Soviet Union are engaged in a personal "cold war" with their hosts to determine whether they can survive massive daily doses of Russian hospitality.
BUFFALO, Aug. 3 -- Three masked men staged a hold-up tonight at the Brink's, Inc., garage. They forced their way into an armored truck carrying $498,500 in race track receipts.
TOKYO, Aug. 3 -- Judging by newspaper and political comment, Japan is extremely eager to have Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu visit Secretary of State Dulles in Washington as soon as possible.
GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- California's Scott Frost, the colt they said couldn't be beaten, lived up to that rating in the thirtieth Hambletonian Stake at Good Time Park today.

Stocks made small gains yesterday, with almost all action confined to the hours before noon. Thereafter volume dropped away and prices moved little, almost as if traders knew that some portentous development was in the offing.

Producers Robert Fryer and Lawrence Carr spent a busy afternoon yesterday signing a major portion of the cast of "The Desk Set." The William Marchant comedy, which will star Shirley Booth, begins rehearsals Aug. 15 for an opening at the Broadhurst on Oct. 13.
The Northern Trust Company of Chicago raised its voice in caution yesterday against the threat of a boom-and-bust cycle. In its monthly, Business Comment, it warns business men against:

HONG KONG, Aug. 3 -- About twenty Chinese Nationals have been under detention here for at least a month. They were apprehended in connection with the crash. April 11, of an Indian airliner carrying Chinese Communist officials to the Asian-African conference in Bandung, Indonesia.
PARIS, Thursday, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Upper House of the French Parliament gave final legislative approval early today to a plan giving a large measure of home rule to Tunisia.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 4 -- The prospective Chief Minister of the Federation of Malaya said today he favored a lawful status for the Malayan Communist party if the Communist rebels received an amnesty.

SOME men object to walking as far as the closet to fetch their own clothes. But Oscar Schoeffler, fashion editor of Esquire magazine, has just completed a 20,000-mile shopping tour of the world in which he bought more than 200 items of men's wear -- all of which he'll be able to keep since his wife has approved them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Council of the Organization of American States heard today Costa Rican and Nicaraguan proposals and counter-proposals for maintaining the peace between them. The organization met as "provisional organ of conciliation" to review the work of committees it had named to iron out Costa Rican-Nicaraguan differences.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- British official circles reacted coolly today to Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin's speech to the Soviet Parliament.

The trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art are to be congratulated on their sagacity in appointing James J. Rorimer director of that institution. In Mr. Rorimer, a man who came up from the museum ranks and has been the able and imaginative director of the Cloisters, they have found a rare combination.
ROSTOV ON DON, U.S.S.R., Aug. 4 -- The Soviet Union is seeking permission to send a mission of agricultural machinery experts to visit the United States.

GELSENKIRCHEN, Germany, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Heat and gas from an underground fire forced rescue workers today to abandon twenty-five men believed missing in a coal-mine explosion. Sixteen other miners were killed instantly.
PARIS, Aug. 4 -- The Pasha of Marrakesh rejected today what he called a French plan to vacate the Moroccan throne for two years.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A temporary restraining order barring enforcement in Indiana of a union-shop clause in the new contract between the General Motors Corporation and the United Auto Workers, C.I.O., was issued in Marion County Superior Court today.

During the past month I have been confronted with numerous literary diatribes concerned with the proposed conversion of a Central Park area, the Ramble, into an amusement center for our older citizens.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower planned to spend most of next week at his Gettysburg farm, to return here briefly and then to fly to Denver, Aug. 14 or 15 for a vacation.
The hot, humid hand of midsummer held New York in its oppressive grip yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A $20,000,000 loan to the Nationalist Chinese Government in Formosa was announced today by the International Cooperation Administration.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 4 -- Three American rocket experts gave members of the Astronautical Congress here today an encyclopedic text on the subject that has been most discussed: the uses and lifetimes of man-made satellite vehicles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Soviet Union has started a new series of atomic tests.

The expected happened when the Federal Reserve Board approved the action of the banks in nine Reserve districts in raising their rediscount rates. The regional banks of Chicago, Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Kansas City, Dallas, San Francisco and Atlanta are advancing their rates from the 1 3/4 per cent hitherto prevailing to 2 per cent; the Cleveland bank has acted more aggressively, raising its rate from 1 3/4 to 2 1/4 per cent.
Three new films open today at first-run theatres.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 4 -- A consolidated railroad passenger terminal costing $10,000,000 to $25,000,000 and linking several transit systems was proposed for this city today by State Senator James F. Murray Jr.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The State Civil Defense Director said today that he might ask the Legislature for power to force people to evacuate their homes in impending enemy attack.

MOSCOW, Aug. 4 -- President Eisenhower's proposal for the mutual inspection of military establishments of the Soviet Union and the United States was dismissed today by Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Premier.

HONK KONG, Aug. 4 -- Officially pronounced in "pretty good health" and "fine" mental condition, eleven United States fliers left for home today after thirty months as prisoners of the Chinese Communists.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 4 -- Gen. Jose Embrioni, subsecretary of the Army Ministry, described today as "impertinent" a suggestion that he lead army forces in the overthrow of the Peron regime.

Governor Harriman urged the Eisenhower Administration yesterday to negotiate a security pact with Israel as quickly as possible. He said the pact should be a step toward more peaceful relationships in the Middle East.
LOUISVILLE, Aug. 4 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley appealed to Kentucky's Democratic voters tonight to rebuff at the polls on Saturday his long-time political enemy, Albert B. (Happy) Chandler.
FALMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 4 -- The soldier on first-line watch for an enemy attack across the Atlantic sits in a windowless, darkened sentry box high out over the ocean.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Men run a greater risk than women of developing cancer, Dr. John R. Heller, director of the National Cancer Institute, said today.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, by far the largest of the system's twelve banks, raised the rate it charges on loans to member commercial banks yesterday from 1 3/4 per cent to 2 per cent.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 4 -- The bodies of the air travelers who were shot down by Bulgarian warplanes July 27 were buried today in a common grave in the Plain of Sharon north of Tel Aviv. The fifty-eight dead, including twelve New Yorkers, were given a state funeral.
TOKYO, Aug. 4 -- Premier Hatoyama said today his Government planned to convene a special session of the Diet (Parliament) in November.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 4 (UP) -- El Tiempo, Colombia's leading morning newspaper, did not appear today because it refused to publish a statement dictated by the Government. The paper supported the Opposition-Liberal party.

In his dispatches on the Israel election results your always perceptive correspondent Harry Gilroy falls, unfortunately, into a common error when he attributes the large vote cast for Achdut Avoda and Herut to the demands of these parties for an "activist" policy in response to Arab frontier incidents.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 4 -- Hall Bartlett, independent film producer, announced today that he had obtained permission from Gov. Joe J. Foss of South Dakota to dramatize the story of his life in a motion picture.
Seven state posts were filled yesterday at swearing-in ceremonies in the office of Secretary of State Carmine G. DeSapio.

LONDON, Aug. 4 (Reuters) -- Following are translated excerpts from Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin's speech to the Supreme Soviet today on the Geneva conference, as reported by Tass, official Soviet news agency.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- France and West Germany will sign an agreement tomorrow to increase their reciprocal trade. French officials said it was the most important and for the longest term that France had ever made with a foreign country.
HONG KONG, Aug. 4 -- "It's a long road to Usashima, to the sweetest land I know." With this song, eleven United States fliers reached freedom today.
Let the far-flung Stratfords of Connecticut, Ontario and England enjoy their Shakespearean festivals. New York is about to greet one, too.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 4 -- Israeli and Jordanian representatives agreed today to establish direct field telephone lines between military commanders on both sides, a foreign ministry spokesman said.

Members of the New York Wellesley Club, comprising Wellesrey College alumnae in the metropolitan district, have arranged a luncheon and fashion l ,Show for the benefit of their[ scholarship fund. It Will be held Sept. 28 in the Cotillion Room 'of- the Pierre.
YARMOUTH, N.S., Aug. 4 -- In a maritime region famous for tuna two far humbler examples of marine biology -- a worm and a weed -- are contributing mightily to the local economy.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 4 -- Brazilian military leaders have given assurances that tomorrow will not be D-Day for a coup. The consensus is that they are right.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UP) President Eisenhower was confronted today with the question whether to give temporary appointments to eighteen nominees whom the Senate did not confirm before adjourning.
The energetic chairman of the New York City Transit Authority has "found" $5,000,000 more.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House authorized direct quotation of the President throughout.
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Three hundred Koreans who lost their homes in a nationwide shack clearance program marched on President Syngman Rhee's residence today demanding more Government aid.
Milk haulers and tank-truck drivers made a fresh start yesterday in their attempt to avoid a strike that would cut off milk deliveries to 12,000,000 persons in the metropolitan area.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Scientists at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia said today they had found a safer, quicker and less expensive way to produce and test polio vaccine.
NEWBURG, Mo., Aug. 4 -- An American Airlines plane crashed into woods and exploded near here today. All thirty persons aboard were killed.

Soviet Premier Bulganin reported to the Supreme Soviet yesterday on the results of the Geneva conference. From the Western point of view his lengthy speech had both gratifying and disappointing features. Yesterday, too, the Atomic Energy Commission in Washington announced that new Soviet nuclear tests are being held, evidence that there has been no slackening in Soviet military efforts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Eisenhower rejected today the idea of a meeting "at the summit" of all countries concerned with relieving tensions in Asia.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The United States proposed today that the United Nations undertake the collection and publication of the world's knowledge of the dangers of atomic radiation.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 -- Fantastic plans for the projected $100,000,000 Palace of Progress, merchandising center over Pennsylvania Station in New York, were outlined today by the promoters and architects.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Eisenhower made the following major points at his seventy-fifth news conference today:
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 4 -- Gatlinburg, which draws more than 2,500,000 visitors a year to see the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, is to have an outdoor drama as another big attraction.
Long Island Rail Road trainmen renewed yesterday their threat to strike at 4 A.M. tomorrow. This action defied an order from their union president to await Federal mediation.

BUFFALO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The police spread to Canada tonight their search for the last of three gunmen foiled in an attempt last evening to rob the Brink's Armored Car Service of nearly half a million dollars.

ATLANTA, Aug. 4 -- The Atlanta branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People served notice today that it stood "ready, willing and able" to challenge in the courts any attempt to revoke the licenses of teachers belonging to it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Congress may be called back into special session in the fall to enact four "absolutely vital" bills, President Eisenhower said today.
BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 4 -- An operation under which inmates of the Louisiana State Penitentiary went free on altered records was being investigated today by the State Department of Institutions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Eisenhower said today that the United States had been willing, and apparently still was willing, to accept the Soviet disarmament proposal if the Russians accepted that of the United States.

Sgt. James C. Gallagher, on trial for murder and collaboration with his Communist captors, was described yesterday as a friendly associate of three turncoat Americans while a prisoner of war in Korea.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 4 -- India has informally put forward the idea of having Red Cross officials assist in the return of Chinese students in the United States who wish to return to the Chinese mainland.
CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 4 (UP) -- The New Hampshire Senate voted today final legislative approval of a plan to set up a state sweepstakes, the first in the nation.
REPORTS from local truck gardens indicate that vegetables are wilting from the abnormal heat and lack of rain and are failing to reach their customary size.

Arthur Levitt, State Controller, has announced plans for a program designed to develop and train executive talent among state administrative employes. Appointed by Governor Harriman to head the sponsoring committee for a New York State Public Administration Program, Mr. Levitt proposes that an executive institute be organized to prepare promising officials "to take over duties on the highest level."

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The Empire State Musical Festival tried its hand at opera tonight and emerged with an unusual performance of "La Boheme." There were no sets, properly speaking, although the furniture and props were on the stage and the singers wore costumes.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 4 -- The opening night performance of the George Gershwin-Du Bose Heyward-Ira Gershwin operetta "Porgy and Bess," by the American Everyman Opera Company, was acclaimed by this city's critics as the "best show hit here this season.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 4 -- The note inviting Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to Moscow confirmed the view that the Soviet Government intended to legalize the partition of Germany and postpone indefinitely the question of reunification. The text was made public today.
YANKTON, S.D., Aug. 4 -- Missouri River waters were running today over the spillway of Gavins Point Dam another barrier raised to control and utilize the turbulent stream.
Large tanks in oil storage plants, which up to now have been in technical violation of the city's statutes, will be legal henceforth.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Federal Power Commission approved today private rather than Federal development of the Hell's Canyon area of the Snake River on the Idaho-Oregon border.

The annual report of the city's Traffic Department is refreshingly free of unsupported large claims of accomplishment or grandiose promises for the future. Commissioner T.T. Wiley remarks that "there are those who advocate big, bold strokes to solve the 'traffic problem.'"
TOKYO, Aug. 4 -- Japan's Foreign Minister, Mamoru Shigemitsu, announced today he would go to Washington later this month to "promote better relations" between his country and the United States.
Decision was reserved yesterday in the case of a Queens garage mechanic who has sued to clear himself of suspicion in the murder of his wife last Jan. 13.

Our gratification over the release of eleven American airmen who had been imprisoned by the Red Chinese cannot blind us to other aspects of this whole "prisoner" problem. We all rejoice that these young men are back in the free world.
HOBOKEN, N.J., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Two workmen were injured today when two gas ovens exploded at the Hostess Cake Company, a division of the Continental Baking Company, here.

The Georgia Board of Education has just distinguished itself by a resolution which would seemingly be rejected in most states by anyone who had been educated beyond the first grade. This resolution provides that "Any teacher in Georgia who * * * is a member of the N.A.A.C.P., any allied organization or any subversive organization shall have his or her license revoked and forfeited for life."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Senate investigation into the personal business affairs of Harold E. Talbott while he was serving as Secretary of the Air Force was closed officially today.

What is the best day of the year? Opinions on this may temporarily vary, although after thought opinion will go to the true one. It is not Christmas, admittedly a good day, nor is it the birthday, the wedding anniversary or the last day of school.

The first session of the Eighty-fourth Congress was unusual in our political history because it failed to produce a clear issue between the Administration and the opposition on which the people as a whole will vigorously divide. There are several explanations for this -- among them the surging economy and the narrow margins by which the Democrats control the Congressional machinery.

Since the Civil War the Presidential nominees of the two parties have come from only eleven of the forty-eight states. Two states, Ohio and New York, have accounted for 65 per cent of the nominees of the two major parties in this period.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Morehead Patterson, United States representative for international atomic energy negotiations, predicted today that Britain would inevitably lead the world in the peacetime development of atomic energy.
HOUSES planned for life in a contradictory climate aptly describes a collection of eight private homes on Long Island Sound that will be open to the public tomorrow afternoon.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Following is the text of a Soviet note to West Germany offering the establishment of diplomatic relations:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Justice Department will attempt to disqualify John Foster Dulles' old law firm from defending oil companies against a $100,000,000 suit by the Federal Government.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 -- The American man is beginning to catch up with birds of the male species and is no longer a color coward, an automobile stylist said here today. While this is true, according to George W. Walker, vice president in charge of styling for the Ford Motor Company, it is also true that men had precious little to do in bringing it about.

GENEVA, Aug. 4 -- Ambassador U. Alexis Johnson was reported tonight to have rejected Peiping's proposal that a third power check on the willingness of Chinese students in the United States to return home.
A $16,500 Colonial Airlines payroll was stolen yesterday at La Guardia Airport.

The second-ranking student in the graduating class at the United States Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point, L.I., was told yesterday he had been refused a commission in the Naval Reserve. He was to have been honored this afternoon for achieving the highest grades in naval science.
Governor Harriman announced in Albany yesterday a move to obtain Federal loans for farmers. The growers and dairymen face huge losses because of the continuing hot, dry weather.
BROOKING, S.D., Aug. 4 -- Two elements of luxury living in the Midwest were shown today to the Russian farm delegation touring this area.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. said today that the United States attitude toward admission of Communist China to the United Nations would not be affected by the Peiping regime's release of the United States airmen.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 4 -- The Cabinet decided today on the replacement of the Governor General of Pakistan. Maj. Gen. Iskander Mirza, Interior Minister and former Secretary of Defense, is to be appointed to the office held by Ghulam Mohammed.

EVER since Thomas Coryate traveled through France, Italy, Switzerland and Germany in 1608 and wrote a book about his experiences, "Coryats Crudities," which was published in 1611, other enterprising Englishmen have been following his example. They have journeyed to Paris and to Samarkand with equal sang froid and with the same intention: to write a book.

OTTAWA, Aug. 5 -- An easing of import restrictions on Canadian farm produce and a modification of the surplus wheat disposal program will be urged on the United States at the second meeting of the joint United States-Canadian Trade and Economic Committee here on Sept. 26.

A prosecution witness quoted Sgt. James C. Gallagher yesterday as saying in 1952 that he expected to remain with the Communists when the opportunity came for repatriation from a Korean prisoner-of-war camp.
DAVOS, Switzerland, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Central Committee of the World Council of Churches replied today to a "peaceful coexistence" appeal from the Patriarchate of the Russian Orthodox Church.
ROME, Aug. 5 -- An appeal to the Eastern Catholic churches to rejoin the Roman Church was issued by Pope Pius XII today.
Negotiators for both sides in the threatened strike of milk tank-truck drivers met separately yesterday to study compromise proposals.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- A spokesman for the United States delegation said today that the United States would object to the elimination from the list of matters before the United Nations Security Council of the Communist seizure of Czechoslovakia in 1948.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 5 -- Beethoven's "Missa Solemnis," which Serge Koussevitzky was to have conducted at the Berkshire Festival in 1951, was performed in his memory here tonight. It was led by Leonard Bernstein, one of the most gifted of the young musicians who studied under Koussevitzky during the years that the conductor was the leading spirit of the festival.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Scientists at Harwell, the atomic research center are studying the use of nuclear propulsion for merchant ships.
WORTHINGTON, Minn., Aug. 5 -- Members of the Russian farm group now touring the Midwest will never be able to say they couldn't see the farms for the banquet tables.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Zenith Radio Corporation attorneys complained today that Radio Corporation of America spirited away important papers from London to Switzerland just as Zenith was about to make use of them in connection with a pending lawsuit against R. C. A.
Cool breezes off the Great Lakes, swirling like a giant electric fan, promise to bring relief today to sweltering New Yorkers.
The world-wide upsurge of interest in religion is more rediscovery than revival, in the opinion of five Lutheran theologians from five European countries.
A robber was shot dead by patrolman at Pennsylvania Station last night after a two-and-a-half block chase from the scene of a $94.55 hold-up.
A RECREATION program for grown-ups as well as youngsters can be as full of different, entertaining items as a small boy's pants pocket.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- White House harmony with a Democratic - controlled Congress was badly strained today. Just how badly was a matter of widespread speculation.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- With the thermometer at 90, 300 operators in the Gary, Ind., telephone exchange were on strike today for air-conditioning in their work quarters.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Army's foremost rocket expert predicted today that man would cruise through outer space "in our time."

ONE of the more refreshing oases among the dreary wastes of summer television is the Columbia Broadcasting System's "Windows" series, which has been fulfilling the function of an off-Broadway theatre for the crowded channels.

Marshall Wallace, 22-year-old New York television newsreel camera man, was killed yesterday when the plane from which he was taking pictures over Ciudad Trujillo, capital of the Dominican Republic, crashed and burned.

The Waterfront Commission agreed yesterday to hear oral argument on a petition by the International Longshoremen's Association for a rehearing of the case against 141 longshoremen who took part in the twenty-nine-day dock strike last year.
The Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue (Congregation Shearith Israel), Central Park West and Seventieth Street, announced yesterday the appointment of the Rev. Dr. Louis C. Gerstein as rabbi.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 5 -- A strike threat by the Communist-dominated Banana Laborers Union against the United Fruit Company may have serious consequences, Government spokesmen warned today.

CHICAGO, Aug 5 -- After the execution of overnight selling orders in coarse grains and soybeans there was a firmer tone, with traders keeping an eye on weather developments. Some cooler weather was indicated by tomorrow, but the five-day forecast predicted temperatures well above normal, with only scattered showers.

OTTAWA, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Canada's wheat acreage has dropped this year to a twelve-year low of 21,504,000 acres, the Bureau of Statistics reported today. The swing to coarse grain plantings has been bigger than anticipated.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 5 -- The forces that favor a suspension of Brazil's Constitution made elaborate efforts to stir up feeling today, the first anniversary of the assassination of Maj. Rubens Florrentino Vaz of the Air Force.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Sweden's European high jump record-holder, Bengt Nilsson, defeated the United States champion, Ernie Shelton of Los Angeles, tonight for the sixth time this summer. Nilsson leaped 2.06 meters (6 feet, 9 1/8 inches).

The report of the Workers Defense League, underwritten by the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Republic and presented to the Pentagon authorities on Thursday by Norman Thomas and its author, Rowland Watts, is, on its face, a serious indictment of the Army's security procedure in relation to draftees. Documented with summaries of forty-eight specific cases, the report charges widespread and flagrant miscarriages of justice.

Permission granted yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission for the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad to withdraw a three-year-old refinancing plan was no surprise to the owners of a majority of the road's common stock. The management had informed the commission that a majority of the common holders were opposed.
HIROSHIMA, Japan, Saturday, Aug. 6 -- Thousands of Hiroshima citizens bowed in silent prayer this morning for the 30,000 residents who died in the explosion of the first atomic bomb ten years ago.
Striking Safeway food store employes voted last night to accept the terms of a new three-year contract. The company's 135 stores in the metropolitan area are expected to reopen next week.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 5 -- There was no racing on the New York Yacht Club cruise today because none was scheduled, but it was not a day off for the regatta committee. It heard testimony on why the committee boat Tritona was struck by two yachts at the start of Tuesday's Una Cup race. There was no decision.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Award of Latin-American scholarships on a basis such as the Rhodes Scholarships was proposed today as a living memorial to Cordell Hull, Secretary of State for twelve years.

A scaffolding tower forty-five stories high gave the Grand Central area an anxious afternoon yesterday when it buckled and threatened to collapse. The iron-pipe tower, rising up the south side of the uncompleted Socony Mobil skyscraper occupying the entire block between Forty-second and Forty-first Streets and Lexington and Third Avenues, bent with a loud groan at about 1:30 P. M.
GOING to college this fall? Then start stocking up right now on Bermuda shorts, knee socks, tailored shirts and sweaters. This is The Uniform at schools across the country.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Peter Thomson, the British Open champion from Melbourne, Australia, ripped seven strokes off Tam o'Shanter's par for a 65 and a half-way lead of two strokes in the $25,000 All-American golf tourney today.
PARIS, Aug. 5 -- Under attack from the right wing of his majority, Premier Edgar Faure stood his ground today and in effect rejected attempts to halt concessions to Moroccan nationalism.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Eisenhower's advisers are unable to agree on a candidate for the National Labor Relation! Board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on immigration, said today he would try to determine why notorious criminals, ordered deported, have been allowed to remain in the country.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Bundesrat, the West German Parliament's upper house, trimmed today the Government's pay scales for the future 500,000-man defense force. The cut still left the monthly pay in the upper bracket for North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Air Line Pilots Association, A. F. L., protested today against a new Civil Aeronautics Administration poster advising fliers to "look out."
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 5 -- The Argentine Government has ordered criminal proceedings against Dr. Mario Amadeo on charges of having attempted to persuade the Army to depose President Juan D. Person.
TAIPEI, Formosa, July 30 -- This is a city where the shadow of war fails to cast its pall over the peace that is the essence of life here.

Max N. and Norbert Natanson, owners of the eighteen-story office building at the southeast, corner of Madison Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, purchased three four-story and one five-story buildings on an adjacent plot at 48 to 54 East Thirty-fourth Street.

Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japanese Foreign Minister, has now completed the arrangements for an official visit to this country late this month. Previous efforts to carry out this mission were snarled in protocol difficulties. We are glad that these have now been resolved.

Paul Hartman, proprietor of one of Broadway's wittiest sets of legs, will replace Eddie Foy Jr. in "The Pajama Game" for two weeks, beginning Aug. 15. Mr. Foy, who has missed only one performance since the musical opened fifteen months ago, will begin his vacation on that day.

Joseph V. Spagna, Commissioner of Purchase, has reported that increased centralized purchasing saved the city almost $10,000,000 in the 1953-54 fiscal year. Considerable savings, for example, were effected by purchasing coal in consolidated large-scale orders.
New York's department stores this week took their worst beating of the summer from the heat wave.

GENEVA, Aug. 5 -- The current Geneva talks between envoys from the United States and the Chinese People's Republic resemble last month's summit conference only as a good-sized molehill compares with Mont Blanc. Unlike the sweeping horizons scanned from here by the Big Four, those being surveyed by Messrs. Johnson and Wang are strictly limited.
An English mother brought her 17-month-old daughter to the United States yesterday to have her reared by an American couple who cared for the child during the early months of her life.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- David Alman balked at telling House of Representatives investigators today whether he took confidential papers from the file of an attorney for a star witness in the Rosenberg atom-spy case.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Eisenhower retreated to the quiet of his Gettysburg farm today for a week of sustained work on the many bills passed in the closing hours of Congress.

The five-story building containing nineteen apartments and two stores at 1010 Intervale Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Joseph Epstein to Mrs. Goldye A. Wind. The property' is assessed at $34,000. Jacob Schulman was the broker, and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 5 (AP) -- On doctor's advice, Tony Trabert, the Wimbledon champion, will not play in the Casino invitation tennis tournament at Newport, R. I., next week.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 5 -- The Kansas City Star Company was fined $5,000 here today in anti-trust charges. Emil Sees, its advertising director, also was fined $2,500 on a similar charge.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Ground water levels are generally down in the United States. They are below average for this time of year, the Geological Survey of the Department of Interior said today.
A group of educators and laymen will soon try to make the complicated formulas of school financing almost as easy to understand as A-B-C.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Navy would not budge today in its refusal of a Reserve commission to Midshipman Eugene W. Landy, but public support was rapidly building up behind him.

In the published hearings of the Kefauver subcommittee on Electoral College reform will be found a proposal made by me for counting the Electoral College vote. May I repeat the proposal for your readers?
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 5 -- Dennis Morgan and Patricia Medina will run into more adventures than their Geiger counters will register as the co-stars of Columbia Pictures' "The Uranium Story."
Four detectives found a solution yesterday to many thefts of clothing merchandise from the midtown garment area.

YONKERS, Aug 5 -- Picture a woman golfer who shows up for a tournament wearing the "wrong" clothing. That was the predicament of at least twenty-five women today as they appeared clad in Bermuda shorts for a pro-lady competition at the Hudson River Country Club.
The city sold yesterday at public auction the nine city blocks involved in the Washington Square Southeast slum-clearance and redevelopment project.

A survey of the Chinese Communists' economic resources, their military and industrial potential, is planned for October publication by Bookman Associates. The author is Yuan-li Wu, who at present is at Stanford University directing several research projects dealing with the Far East. His book will be titled "An Economic Survey of Communist China."
CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 -- Second-base problems continued to mount for the Giants tonight, even while they were en route to a weird, 12-9 victory over the Redlegs at Crosley Field.
Stock prices recovered moderately yesterday from Thursday's sharp setback.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- The Dodgers hit four homers to three for the Cubs at Wrigley Field today, but the Little Bears outscored the Brook 10 to 8, in the opener of the four-game series.
PUGWASH, N. S., Aug. 5 -- The scholars gathered here as guests of Cyrus Eaton, industrialist, divided into parties today to continue their exploration.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 5 -- Rubber prices are soaring again and Malaya is purring with pleasure. The situation was such that a front-page banner headline appeared today in the daily Straits Times reading "Boom Dollars Roll In."
Some "extraordinary shenanigans" have been involved in the proposed sale of the Neponsit Beach Hospital site, Park Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 5 -- The bustling television entertainment film production industry was at a virtual standstill today as 10,000 members of the Screen Actors Guild went on strike.
People in this country rarely wear anything out, and the American business man is constantly dreaming up new products to stop them from trying to do so.
OTTAWA, Aug. 5 -- That succulent delicacy, the soft shell, or steamer, clam, once but no longer plentiful all along the New England coast, is vanishing from Canadian waters, too.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 6 points down to 8 up.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 5 -- Israel offered today to send overland to the Arab refugees in the Egyptian-held Gaza Strip fifty tons of United Nations medical supplies captured yesterday aboard a Syrian schooner off Jaffa.
ALBANY, Aug. 5 -- Governor Harriman rejected the idea of a Vice Presidential nomination today.

GENEVA, Aug. 5 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council passed several resolutions today putting the United Nations more actively in business as a promoter of economic growth. The council then closed its busy twentieth session.
The Ingersoll-Rand Company, manufacturer of a wide variety of industrial products, achieved record half-year earnings in the first six months this year, according to figures reported yesterday.

Garden apartments are to be built on the northeast corner of Sutphin Boulevard and 108th Avenue in Jamaica, Queens. The building site consists of a plot measuring 71 by 100 feet on Sutphin Boulevard and thirteen lots extending 316 feet from the boulevard to 154th Street on the north side of 108th Street.

The new capital market continues to slow down with the advance of midsummer. Substantial new offerings of corporate and local government securities are becoming less frequent and additions to the backlog of new securities awaiting marketing are not formidable.
The National Broadcasting Company will televise a special report at 8 P. M. today on the mechanics and meaning of the plan to launch an earth satellite.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Leaders of the National Union of Mineworkers asked a union committee today to study a suggestion by the National Coal Board that miners be recruited in Italy and Austria.
WEEK-END guests in search of an appropriate hostess gift can find a wealth of remembrances in the shops that are useful as well as attractive.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The weekly index of average primary market prices eased 0.1 point to 109.8 (1947-49 equals 100) over the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The decline reflected continued reductions in prices of livestock and meat products.
MOSCOW, Aug. 5 -- Moscow's friendship offensive took another turn today. Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin invited every foreign Ambassador in Moscow to spend Sunday in the country with him.
