SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 -- A union business agent who had been ousted from a coastwise negotiating committee wounded three fellow officers of the Marine Firemen's Union, A. F. L., today. Then the assailant, Charles F. Berglund. 44 years old, shot and killed himself.
THIS appears to be a "new gun" year, for in addition to an assortment of rifles of new design and caliber, a gas-operated, auto-loading shotgun will now be available in the moderate price field.

Bulganin reappeared before the Supreme Soviet to assure the world he had been "misunderstood" the day before and he really hasn't rejected President Eisenhower's disarmament control plan completely.
HONG KONG, Saturday, Aug. 6 -- A United States citizen who spent more than two years in a Chinese Communist prison was deported from Hong Kong early today.
Dr. Stephen M. Corey has been appointed dean of Teachers College of Columbia University, effective Sept. 1.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The United States fell about 56,000,000 bushels short of filling its export quota of wheat under the International Wheat Agreement during the marketing year ended Aug. 1.
The editors of eighty-eight newspapers of the Eastern Air Defense Force and the Ground Observer Corps ended a three-day conference here yesterday. They visited The New York

In his recent report to Congress on United States participation in the United Nations, President Eisenhower said: "The United States representatives have actively used the U. N.'s forum to expound our ideas and ideals and reveal the fallacies of communism."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture, moving to head off new coffee price increases, said today that reported crop damage in one section of Brazil would have no effect on world coffee supplies.

The Navy stood fast yesterday in refusing a commission in the Naval Reserve to Eugene W. Landy when he was graduated from the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I. The 21-year-old midshipman, whose mother has admitted she was formerly a member of the Communist party, was notified Thursday that he would be denied his commission.
PENN YAN, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- Hot drought lay heavy across the rolling farmland of the Finger Lakes today.

LONDON, Aug. 5 (Reuters) -- The tighter money policy of the British Government sent share prices tumbling on the London Stock Exchange today. The curbs on loans came as a big shock to investors. They made stockholders begin to sell to try to clear bank overdrafts [loans].

The Board of Estimate majority that is bent on selling away the people's rights to the Neponsit Beach Hospital grounds in Queens instead of restoring this land to park use continues unresponsive to public opinion. Two weeks after the 10-to-6 decision in which Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa led the five Borough Presidents into this folly, the board is apparently trying to act as if this were a closed matter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The dispute between Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, and the Department of Commerce reached the subpoena stage tonight.
Alexander Johnson of Queens yesterday swore off hard liquor and throwing eggs in the subway.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Millard Howell fumbled a slow roller to the mound with the bases loaded in the eleventh inning to permit a run to score and Baltimore to defeat league-leading Chicago, 2 -- 1, tonight.

SAMPLING Westchester County restaurants, the itinerant epicure may find himself in an isolated French-style inn that hardly seats fifty people in its dining room. Or he may mingle with 300 other hungry guests in a sprawling stone structure high over the Hudson River. Atmosphere, cooking and prices in out- of-town eating establishments offer considerable variety.

SEATTLE, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Lou Fageol, Gold Cup speed ace, narrowly escaped death today, and Slo-Mo-Shun V, the cup defender, was knocked out of Sunday's classic. The boat leaped out of the water and flipped over while traveling about 160 miles an hour during a qualifying run.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- What is called "autonomous status" is being conferred by France on unnumbered penguins, 1,500 head of cattle and ninety Frenchmen who inhabit a territory as big as the mother country.

HARTFORD, Aug. 5 -- The Connecticut State Bond Commission has directed the expenditure of $2,500,000 for a start on a new state prison. It will be in the town of Enfield, about twenty miles north of Hartford.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today two loans totaling $19,800,000 to improve the ports of Pakistan and the roads of Peru.
The United States Lines expects another banner year for European travel in 1956.
Profit taking was evident yesterday in dealings in rubber and coffee futures contracts.
For the second time in two days the same thug has robbed the David Kopper candy shop at 158 West Fifty-seventh Street.

More than forty Indian tribes are gathering today and tomorrow in Sheridan, Wyo., for the third annual celebration of the All American Indian Days festival, a surprising reminder that only in recent years have the original inhabitants of our continent come to be considered "all American." Yet the influence that the Indian exerts on our lives remains enormous in spite of the unconscionable way in which he has been treated.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- A memorandum recommending the establishment of a new United Nations commission on disarmament has been approved by the Central Committee of the World Council of Churches, according to word received here last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Henrich C. J. Focke, founder of the German Focke-Wulf Company, has invented a birdlike aircraft for the Brazilian Government. The patent, issued this week, reveals an effort to merge the advantages of helicopter and airplane.
The on-again, off-again strike of Long Island Rail Road trainmen, set for 4 o'clock this morning, was called off again yesterday.
The battery of Don Larsen and Yogi Berra just about did it all at the Stadium last night as the Yankees downed the Detroit Tigers, 3 -- 0, in the opener of a four-game series.

The figures it has flashed recently have not been fully to the liking of Casey Stengel and his Yankees. That doesn't alter the fact that the huge electrical scoreboard at Yankee Stadium is one of the wonders of this baseball age.

Mayor Wagner was enthusiastic in his press interviews after visiting a score of European cities. It is unfortunate that he was unable to see the city of Budapest, which was and still is one of the most beautiful places in Europe.
HAVANA, Aug. 5 -- Policemen seized today their second cache of arms within the last twenty-four hours. They sought persons suspected of conspiring against the Government.
TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Masaru Furukawa broke the world record in the 200-meter breast-stroke last night as Japan took the lead in the meet with the United States team.
Directors of the Bates Manufacturing Company have elected Frank C. Mawby as president to succeed Herman D. Ruhm Jr., who resigned recently, the Lewiston, Me., textile company announced yesterday.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 5 -- President Sukarno returned today to a country facing a political crisis and anounced he was taking a ten-day leave of absence.
TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Eleven United States airmen arrived here last night on their way home to loved ones after more than thirty months of imprisonment in Communist China.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- Frank Strafaci and Don Cherry, the medalists; were forced to extra holes before gaining in the John G. Anderson Memorial tournament today.
Edmar Mednis of New York gained second place with a 5-1 score in the world junior chess championship at Antwerp yesterday, according to Belgian news sources.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 5 -- Philip Scott, Diamond Hal and Pearl Creed won the elimination heats of the $67,500 Roosevelt Raceway Pacing Tournament tonight.
The toss of a coin to decide the winner of the annual Music Memory Contest of the Guggenheim Memorial Concerts was found to be unnecessary last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (2P) -- Now that world tensions are easing, the United States may try to sell some of its huge farm surpluses to Russia and her satellites, officials said today.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Queen Elizabeth II and members of the royal family prepared today to leave the capital for their annual summer holiday. Their departure will close the most brilliant social season seen in England since the end of World War II.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Censorship was established today on all outgoing news dispatches dealing with the Government's closing of El Tiempo, Colombia's leading morning newspaper.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy will call together his chief officers Monday at Police Headquarters to explain the policy of his regime.
PARIS, Aug. 5 -- Premier Edgar Faure told the National Assembly today that economic progress at the present rate would enable France to double her standard of living within ten years.

Mead Johnson Co., producer of infant dietary products, pharmaceuticals and parenteral solutions, announced yesterday the election of Robert W. Johnson as a director to fill the vacancy left by the late Lambert D. Johnson St., former board chairman. The position of chairman of the board was abolished by the directors.
BOSTON, Aug. 5 -- The number of poliomeylitis cases in Massachusetts stood today at 772. A year ago, the total was eighty-eight.
LOUISVILLE, Aug. 5 -- Kentucky voters will go to the polls tomorrow in primary elections to nominate their candidates for Governor on Democratic and Republican tickets.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- An Administration decision on a new cotton export policy has been postponed until next week.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Prof. Joseph Rotblat of Britain has been chosen to supervise the preparation of a report on the dangers arising from uses of atomic energy.

Variable Annuity Life Insurance Company of America was licensed yesterday at Washington, D. C., as the first life insurance company offering variable annuities to the general public. The new company has $1,000,000 in capital and surplus and plans to "undertake to be admitted to do business in states where there is a demand for our services."
MOSCOW, Aug. 5 -- Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin protested today he had been misunderstood in his comments yesterday on President Eisenhower's arms inspection proposal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Administration officials believe that the comments in the last two days by Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin and President Eisenhower on arms plans have strengthened the "Geneva atmosphere" of easier relations between the great powers.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 5 -- Australia won both singles tennis matches from Japan today and is in a position to seal the Davis Cup interzone semi-final victory in the doubles tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Washington Senators scored five quick runs off Sal Maglie, the New York Giants' cast-off who was making his American League debut, and staved off a ninth-inning rally to defeat Cleveland, 7 -- 5, tonight.

First-half volume sales of petroleum products by Cities Service Company and subsidiaries reached a new high of 54,778,000 barrels, W. Alton Jones, chairman, reported yesterday. This topped the previous high, achieved in the like 1954 period, by 15 per cent, he added.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- Five 3-year-olds raced once around the track in the mile-and-a-furlong feature at Saratoga's old horse park today. When they had finished their chore, three of them were almost as close together as they had been in the starting gate.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- State Department quarters made clear today that the United States was not going to utilize Chinese residents in this country as pawns in any deal with Communist China.
BALBOA, C. Z., Aug. 5 -- A campaign is under way in Panama for review of the case of former President Jose Ramon Guizado.
CONCORD, N. H., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Gov. Lane Dwinell vetoed today a proposal to set up a state-operated horse-race sweepstakes.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- A civil service arbitration tribunal has granted pay increases averaging 5 per cent to 350,000 Government employes whose salaries range up to $4,200 a year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- President Eisenhower flew to his Gettysburg farm today in a new light plane that the Air Force said cost just under $75,000.

It was appropriate that Dr. Ralph Bunche, Under Secretary of the United Nations, should open the eleven-day International Children's Art Show, now at the Chrysler International Salon. The exhibit, part of the New York Summer Festival, features 500 paintings and drawings from 100 countries.

STYLES and taste change in crime-writing as well as in every other field, and woe to the writer who does not change with them. I can remember when, twenty-odd years ago, Leonard R. Gribble's "Famous Feats of Detection and Deduction" seemed a reasonably welcome volume, in an area when there were few fact - crime books of any kind and almost no distinguished ones.

TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 7 (AP) -Col. John Knox Arnold Jr. said today Chinese Reds had subjected him to "persuasion that civilized people simply do not know about" in efforts to make him confess to spy charges.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Cyane, owned by Henry B. duPont of Wilmington, Del., and Raymond Hunt's Harrier were away to fast starts today as a fleet of forty-eight boats began the 605-mile Fastnet Rock race in fine sailing weather.

BOSTON, Aug. 6 (UP) -- The Kansas City Athletics scored three ninth-inning runs today to make it two in a row over the fourth-place Boston Red Sox, 6 -- 5. Each team used four pitchers in the struggle that went down to the wire.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -Improved business conditions in Pennsylvania are reflected in the "sound shape" of the state's unemployment compensation fund. John R. Torquato, State Secretary of Labor and Industry, reported this week that compensation benefit costs during the first half of 1955 dropped 20 per cent below those paid during the corresponding period last year.
The New York Public Library's Fifth Avenue building offers the browsing summer visitor an unusual range of visual material for relaxation or study.
NOVARA, Italy, Aug. 6 (AP) -Seventeen Italians are to leave Tuesday for the United States to testify in a reopened investigation of the wartime, "cloak and dagger" slaying of Maj. William Holohan.

IN "The Sixth of June," Lionel Shapiro, a former Canadian war correspondent, has set his sights on a difficult moving target: love amidst the events leading up to the big show on D-Day. E. T O., 6 June 44.

THE camel is a member of the mammalia class, genus Cameleus, family Camelidae -- if anyone cares. What is more important is that zoologically and temperamentally the camel is one of the world's strangest, most ornery (as well as onerary) and most interesting beasts, which has undergone little evolutionary change in thousands of years. He is peculiar in more ways than one.

One of the greatest changes in medical practice in the last few decades has been the trend toward making the patient a part of the therapeutic team. Marx of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UP) -Two Senate Democrats accused Jerome K. Kuykendall, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, of "deception" in the Hell's Canyon power case in Idaho. They also charged him with having suppressed data in the Dixon-Yates power contract.

If man can place a small unmanned earth satellite by 1958, then he can set foot on the moon by the end of this century. WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -Striking bus and street car operators rejected today a Capital Transit Company offer of a fifteen -cent hourly wage package that would have included higher pensions.

Twenty-year-old Al Kaline has led the American League in batting almost from the start of the season. However, Detroit's infant prodigy will be as surprised as he will be happy if he finishes at the top of the list.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 6 -Month-end promotions in connection with the clearance of summer goods and the initial offering of fall lines met excellent response. In most areas of the Kansas City district last week sales ran from 10 to 20 per cent above a year ago, with the average closer to the low range.

ALONG time ago jazz moved out of the ginmills and honky-tonks, the cellars and special night clubs into the relative respectability of places like Carnegie and Town Halls. No one would now question its validity and vitality as a form of musical expression.

A relatively little-known group of metal products called clad steels has quietly been invading a score of industries -- and winning new friends by trimming costs and conserving scarce nickel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Army has proposed to start the new six-month Reserve training program in October with an initial class of about 10,000 teen-age trainees, a Defense Department manpower official disclosed today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Today's Dodger-Cub game was washed out eleven minutes after it started, but the rain couldn't stop talk of the home run rivalry between Duke Snider and Ernie Banks.
REDDING, Calif., Aug. 6 (UP) -- Arvid Nyleen of Willamine, Ore., swept into Kutras Lake thirteen minutes ahead of seven rivals to win the tortuous, 316-mile Stockton-Redding Diamond Cup race today.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Aug. 6 -- Maj. Gen. Harlan C. Parks, senior delegate to the United Nations Military Armistice Commission, accused the Communists today of crue' and inhuman acts against South Korean civilians.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- Pierre Montel, chairman of the Defense Committee of the National Assembly, said today all French forces in Europe should be sent to North Africa if they were needed to keep order there.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 6 -Australia won the doubles match from Japan at the Nassau Country Club today and qualified to meet Italy in the Davis Cup interzone tennis final.
FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 6 (AP) -- In all-Army tennis today Grant Golden, the nation's tenth ranked amateur, defeated Pfc. Roger Pharr, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3, to take the men's singles crown.

HONG KONG, Sunday, Aug. 7 -- A peasant housewife in Communist China was elected a delegate to a provincial youth congress recently as a reward for sending her "counter-revolutionary" husband to death by execution.
THE rudbeckias of today are vastly superior to the stiff, high-coned flowers of yesteryear. The modern kinds are easy to grow, have a wider range of color and are excellent for cutting.

At 11:56 last Tuesday night, the House having exhausted its lastnight-of-session repertoire -- "The Old Mill Stream," "On Moonlight Bay," I Want a Girl Just Like the Girl That Married Dear Old Dad" -- Speaker Sam Rayburn brought down his gavel.

MOSCOW, Aug. 6 -- Soviet farmers, virtually all of whom work for collectives or the Government, have lately been learning a little about methods and results of the free enterprise system of agriculture in the United States.

A WOODSIDE, Queens, inventor recently received U. S. Patent 2,713,168 for a jacket with a zippered panel in back to provide crossventilation in hot weather. The Patent Office cranked out the patent just in time for the biggest no-jacket heat wave in New York and the Northeastern states in years.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 6 (UP) -- Doctors, dentists, engineers and lawyers demanded today repeal of the law under which the Government seized control of their professional societies soon after Juan D. Peron became President.

The August ripeness creeps across the land, somewhat hastened by the heat but forever typical of the season. Forerunner of the later total harvest, it is a reminder, too, that no harvest is a brief and isolated completion in any year. Harvest is a continuing event, from the first hay through the oats, the wheat, the barley and rye to that amazing abundance which is corn and autumn.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 6 (UP) -Bob Friend and Ray Crone waged a pitching duel today, but Crone threw a gopher ball to Dale Long to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 2 -- 0 victory over the Milwaukee Braves. It was the second-place Braves' fourth straight loss.
The life insurance companies are on a studying binge these days. Most admit they're looking into the problem of issuing variable annuities.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 6 -- An eleven-acre site in downtown New Orleans bristled with structural steel this week. Aboveground construction was started on the city's $7,000,000 city hall building.

PORT McNICOLL, Ont. -This small port seems as central a focus point as could be chosen for any of the various summer activities which make this region of Ontario such a holiday delight. Here one can embark on Great Lakes cruises up through Lake Huron and Lake Superior to Fort William and back.
ROME, Aug. 4 -- The world's Latinists are invited to participate in a Latin competition organized by the Latin quarterly magazine Latinitas.

Our artistic world has been impoverished by the death of Coenraad V. Bos. He was one of the supreme accompanists of our time and one of the finest students of lyric music. Although he was a Netherlander by birth, we have always been inclined to claim him as our own because he made this country his home from 1908 on.

A VACATION spent in close quarters with a couple of live-wire sons is an experience hardly calculated to send a film reviewer back to his job with a thoroughly relaxed disposition toward the quaint eccentricities of boys.

ATLANTA, Aug. 6 -- Department store sales in the Southeast continue well ahead of last year's levels. Leading stores in the area estimate dollar volume since the first of this year has averaged an estimated 10 per cent more than that of the corresponding 1954 period.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Aug. 6 (AP) -- A determined farmer, armed with sticks of dynamite, stood behind two barricades on a road through his land today and demanded the state pay him $75,000 damages.

ISTANBUL, Aug. 6 -- The conference of the World Confederation of Organizations of the Teaching Profession brought together in Istanbul this week teachers of forty nations, including all major ones except Iron Curtain lands. Delegates representing 3,000,000 teachers attended the week-long conference.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Aug. 6 -- The nation's newest luxury hotel, a $16,000,000 production of color and modernistic design, will open for business after a week-long program of festivities starting tomorrow.
American modern dancer, who has recently made an independently sponsored solo tour of India and the Orient.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 (UP) -- Murry Dickson hurled a six-hitter tonight and Stan Lopata's tworun homer gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 5-3 victory over the St. Louis Cards.

IF the gypsy girl Lou had not climbed a sun-washed Yorkshire hill on a June day in 1900 she might have followed the tinker's cart all her life, and been far happier for it. But the light flashed on something bright at the summit and Lou (who could not resist the call of the road) left the cold valley and climbed upward toward the sunny slopes.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A two and a half-ton Army truck carrying twenty United States soldiers to Kimpo Airport for a holiday trip to Japan, hurtled through a bridge rail yesterday, dropped forty feet onto its canvas top and burst into flames.

NEW ORLEANS, La. -- The high temperatures and humidity which the eastern states have been undergoing this summer are practically an endless story here. Hence, through years of battling with this particularly uncomfortable aspect of weather, New Orleans probably has as good an answer as any city to the question of how to beat the heat.
EAST AURORA, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Erie County farmers hopefully scanned clouded skies today for a repetition of this week's rainfall that eased the three-month drought in western New York.

The first through service between the eastern United States and the East and West Coasts of South America, starting Aug. 18, will consist of four weekly round trips. This was announced jointly yesterday by Edward V. Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Air Lines, and Charles E. Beard, president of Braniff International Airways.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Voice of America is still fighting the "cold war," but its tones, in keeping with the times, are less strident, more relaxed, less given to denouncing and demanding and more to chiding and suggesting.

The rising cost of credit which was pointed up last week in a series of interest rate increases is not expected to curtail business borrowing much. But it will tend to further reduce the supply of lendable funds.
NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 6 -The Public Utilities Commission will open a public hearing on the operation of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad at 10:30 A. M. Tuesday.
The National Committee of the Communist party yesterday traced the line it urged party members to follow in advance of the October foreign ministers' conference in Geneva.

Capital expenditures by the petroleum industry in the United States this year again will establish a new record. According to leading oil executives, the total may approach $6,000,000,000, reflecting largely expanded drilling and improvements and additions to refining facilities.

A RADIO quiz program offering listeners a top prize of $250,000 in cash is being prepared by the Mutual Broadcasting System for a fall debut. A listener, who first must qualify for the quiz by writing an award-winning letter on "What I Would Do If I Won $250,000," could obtain that fantastic sum by answering a seven-part question over the telephone.

THE design of the 3-cent sepia stamp which will be released on Sept. 18 for the 200th anniversary of Fort Ticonderoga was made public last week by Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield. Superimposed on a plan of the fort are a cannon, cannonballs, a powder keg and a full-length figure representing Ethan Allen (1738-1789), the American Revolutionary commander who captured the stronghold from the British on May 10, 1775.
The Swedish freighter Holmialand radioed last night it was afire 330 miles southwest of Bermuda and asked all ships in the area to stand by.

TOKYO, Aug. 6 -- "The Teahouse of the August Moon" received a delighted reception tonight at Tokyo's famous Kabukiza Theatre. The audience of 1,500 seemed almost evenly divided between Japanese and Americans.

Time was when the most important qualification for the job of New York City Police Commissioner was political standing. In those days the major decisions affecting the Police Department were made at City Hall and almost every wardheeler in town had an "in" at Headquarters.
On the basis of figures for the first six months, North Atlantic travel may set a post-war record this year. The present mark was established in 1954, when 1,516,535 passengers crossed the ocean.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 6 -- A Brooklyn bartender and his young son drowned here today when the rowboat in which they were riding capsized.

I found Arnold J. Toynbee's article. "The Question: Can Russia Really Change?" (July 24), interesting and discerning. His conclusion that the facts of life at home and abroad in our atomic era compel at least a practical, if not academic, change in Russian policy fit my disposition to look at things from the human nature point of view.
BELLPORT, L. I., Aug. 6 -George Fenner and his Westhampton Yacht Squadron crew had a first, second and third today to take the lead in the Great South Bay Y. R. A. championship.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- A new British meteorological station will be established in Antarctica as part of Britain's contribution to the International Geophysical Year, 1957-58.

More than $2,500,000,000 was made available in the last century by John D. Rockefeller and John D. Rockefeller Jr. through their benefactions "to promote the well-being of mankind throughout the world."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- With Congress adjourned and the White House about to shut down for the Presidential vacation, national politics virtually loses its present tense. These are the political dog days when reporters and others with an occupational interest in the subject solemnly greet one another with the information, "There's not a thing going on."
HOLLYWOOD. BROADWAY'S Joshua Logan has descended upon Hollywood and left an impress on the town indubitably more enduring than the footprints in the forecourt of the storied Chinese Theatre.
IN the two months that it has been on the air "The $64,000 Question" has caught the interest of the nation's viewers in a way few other television shows ever have.
The Protestant Episcopal Church will be called upon next month to bridge what has become an almost traditional gulf between itself and the laboring man.

EARLY August is the time to set out additional plants and bulbs that will provide color in the autumn garden. Then later in the season when weather permits, the gardener has time to divide and transplant overgrown perennials and remedy planting faults while they are still fresh in mind.

The security regulations governing those who serve, or want to serve, the nation in either the civil government or the armed forces have again come under somewhat exasperated public scrutiny as a result of the strange case of Midshipman Eugene W. Landy.
William Horowitz, owner of a bar and grill at 233 Moore Street, Brooklyn, was fatally stabbed yesterday while fighting off a hold-up man armed with a hunting knife.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Republican and Democratic leaders in the Senate agreed today that the just-adjourned session of Congress had done a good job in foreign policy.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Water soil in window and planting boxes regularly, since rain may not penetrate. Pick faded blossoms and yellowed leaves daily, if possible, so that plantings always are neat and attractive. Pinch back vines that are too long and are whipped about by wind. Feed once a month.
A contract for the construction of a 9,400-ton special purpose vessel has been awarded to the Maryland Shipbuilding and Drydock Company of Baltimore by the Maritime Administration.

WISCONSIN'S Door County has the reputation in the Middle West of being one of the finest vacation spots in the Great Lakes area. It lies on the long narrow peninsula that juts out into Lake Michigan, separating Green Bay from the waters of the big lake.
PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 6 -This city today announced plans fora $4,500,000 midtown municipal parking garage.

SUMMER leisure-time themes dominate the new show at Limelight Gallery, 91 Seventh Avenue South, where fifteen photographers are represented in a group exhibition running through Sept. 2. Although social commentary continues, as in previous local shows of this type, to get a good share of the space, it is a relief to see a show in which this approach is presented as only one of several available to photographers.

LET there be no putting of the best people into office; this will stop vicious rivalry among the people. Let there be no prizing of rare merchandise; this will stop robbing among the people. Let nothing desirable be visible; this will save the people's minds from moral confusion.

CARL ZEISS, Inc., one of the leading importers of German lenses and miniature cameras and accessories, last week announced its first contest since before World War II. The news is less significant as a contest, however, than because it perhaps reveals a change in general policy.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 6 (UP) -- Senator Strom Thurmond, Democrat of South Carolina, said today he would fight discrimination against "the greatest minority group in this nation -- the white people of the South."

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 6 -- The United States Davis Cup selection committee may be out in force tomorrow to watch the final of the Eastern grass court tennis championship between Sam Giammalva of Houston and Gil Shea of Los Angeles at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The son of the late head of Scotland Yard's murder squad was charged today with the murder of his wife and their 13-month-old daughter.

ROME. THE actual start of a motion picture production such as "War and Peace," about which so much has been written and said and which many thought would never get rolling at all, is perhaps anti-climactic.

TO those who knock New York fashionably, what about those nineteen trees growing bravely on Eighty-eighth Street? Suburbanites and even some Manhattanites say the city is through -- air pollution, honky-tonk, unclean streets, overcrowding, and all the tourists from Jersey.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 6 -Illicit immigration into Ceylon from South India has reached a new peak for the first seven months of this year. The situation is causing concern to the Ceylonees Government.

Pakistan has a new Governor General, Maj. Gen. Iskander Mirza. It is believed that there will also be a change in the Prime Ministership shortly, with Hussein Suhrawardy replacing Mohammed Ali. There is a new value for the Pakistani rupee, to bring it into line with the sterling bloc.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Eisenhower reiterated today United States support for the reunification of Germany. He did so in a letter to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.

HAVANA, CUBA. SERIOUS music is becoming hard to find in Cuba. The situation is all the more tragic because the islanders, a musical folk, have shown an increasing appreciation of classical compositions in recent years. But lack of opportunities and financial problems have discouraged artists here. An indifferent Government is held chiefly to blame.
The new Soviet policy of "sweet reasonableness" was continued last week as Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin announced that the Soviet Union would consider any sincere plan for the limitation of armaments.

CATS' EARS -Cats have real high-fidelity ears. This is the finding of Dr. William D. Neff and Dr. Joseph E. Hind of the Laboratories of Physiological Psychology and Otolaryngology of the University of Chicago. They tested cats on both high and low notes. Below 500 cycles per second, the cats did not do very well.

BY more or less established custom, a brief report first on the nature of my vacation reading. It has, as usual, been scanty. I was more than ordinarily tired of the sight of printed matter, save for timetables and maps, when I left New York for the north woods.

UNTIL the air conditioning of homes becomes general cooks will continue to rely on refrigerated main dishes as one way of cooling family and friends in hot weather. In doing so, they follow a tradition that dates at least as far back as 1800. At that time Antonin Careme, the great Parisian chef, was elaborating aspics almost architectural in effect.
PARIS, Aug. 5 -- The French Communist party has long sought to break out of the isolated position in which its subservience to Moscow has placed it.
Samuel Reshevsky will be the strong favorite to win the United States Chess Federation's open championship, which begins tomorrow in Long Beach, Calif.

" AT 5 P. M.," a psychologist recently told assembled colleagues, "the American family goes to pot." He meant, in older cliches, that in the late afternoon the fabric of home life splits its seams, the simmering kettle of domesticity boils over, mother, father and offsprings jump their trolleys.

MORAN, Wyo. -- The Jackson Hole country, dubbed "the last of the Old West" by its devotees, is currently rent by a debate on architectural aesthetics of all things. No gunplay has been reported, and neither Frank Lloyd Wright, Lewis Mumford nor Robert Moses has as yet been deputized as United States Marshal in the wordy fracas.
SHORTLY after his regular television show first appeared on the National Broadcasting Company network last month, Matt Dennis received a letter from an elderly aunt eulogizing him and his music.
Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, may have suffered a sharp eclipse in power and prestige along with the eclipse of the "hard" foreign policy line he laid down only six months ago.
SEPTEMBER, the next page to be turned on the outdoor calendar, has been called the "alpha and omega of the sportsman," for to many it marks the end of fishing and the start of hunting.

The United States is now engaged in the first stage of what promises to be a long series of negotiations with Communist China. The negotiations may have far-reaching impact. The Chinese Communists' capture of the most populous nation on earth and their attempt to elevate it to the status of a leading world power have shaped the entire history of post-war Asia.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sunday, Aug. 7 -- Albert B. (Happy) Chandler had a comfortable lead over Bert T. Combs early this morning in returns from yesterday's state - wide primary election for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

AT the moment, highbrow criticism ignores A. E. Housman. But he still has plenty of readers, and to such of them as are interested in the way a poet works Tom Burns Haber's volume will become a companion to "A Shropshire Lad" and "Last Poems."

AIRPLANES with black noses are bringing a new standard of passenger comfort to airline travel. The black noses on the fuselages contain radar sets that scan the weather for 150 miles ahead. Using the picture on the radar scope as a guide, the pilot can pick his way through storm areas and steer clear of severe turbulence.

Dorothy FoscUck's article. "The Passport--And the Right to Travel" (July 17) was a timely elucidation of the arbitrary and capricious operation for too many years of the Passport Office--and as welcome as recent court decisions re-establishing the inherent right to travel.
SAN ANTONIO, Aug. 6 (AP) -Two seeded players were ousted today in singles competition of the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce tennis championships.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- An irascible Congress shed its toga early Wednesday morning and prepared for a long, comfortable recess in traveling togs and gumshoes.

THE growing and training of Bonsai or dwarfed potted trees is a fascinating field that is coming into great popularity with Americans. It seems to have a special appeal for city dwellers who, because of limited space for growing, have generally kept to the common, easy-to-care-for plants.

A summer group show displaying the work of four photographers opened last week at the Dryden Gallery of the George Eastman House, Rochester, where it will run through Sept. 5. The photographers are William Garnett, aerial photographs; Pirkle Jones, city and landscapes; Dorothy Norman and Alfred Stieglitz, who are represented by the mutual portraits which were first shown at Limelight Gallery here some months ago.

AFTER giving six performances in June at the Paris International Theatre Festival, "The Skin of Our Teeth" company is making a few local stops. It has already appeared in Washington, and is currently in Chicago. On Aug. 17 it will open for three weeks at the ANTA Playhouse in New York. There will also be a TV performance on Sept. 11.

" Anybody can come to Moscow these days," Nikita S. Khrushchev declared during the Geneva conference, thus sounding one of the major themes in the present Soviet campaign to demonstrate that the Iron Curtain is a myth of Western propaganda.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman said today that prospects for international peace "have been improving all along since 1946." He added that "we have all been working at it" and voiced optimism about an ultimate settlement.
HONG KONG, Aug. 6 -- The "old look" is back in China, and women on the Communist ruled mainland are going to look like women again.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 -Department store sales in the Twelfth District for the week ended July 30 showed the largest gain over 1954 figures reported in the last two months. Southern California and Pacific Northwest stores led, with central California and Bay Area stores lagging in gains.

HOLLYWOOD. THE notion that Hollywood people spend most, if not all, of their time lounging around swimming pools (a happy notion in these dog days) in quickly dispelled by a glance at the schedules of Robert Aldrich and Frank Sinatra.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 6 -- Dave Philley's grand-slam homer and another four-bagger by Gus Triandos with one on paced the Baltimore Orioles to an 8-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox today. Bob Kennedy's homer provided Chicago's run.

PICKING the right hammer for general home repair is important. A 16-ounce claw hammer is used for most carpentry work. For finer work with light wood and small nails, a 12- to 13-ounce claw hammer is best.

CARBON TETRACHLORIDE is non-inflammable and explosion-proof, but there are certain precautions. One frequent use for the solvent is to clean furniture and woodwork after using a paint remover. The carbon tet washes the wood clean rapidly and evaporates quickly.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Aug. 6 (Reuters) -- Gen. Sir Geoffrey Bourne, British Commander in Malaya, said today that 3,500 Communist terrorists had stopped fighting for the present.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- A $130,000,000 merger involving some home appliance divisions of the Radio Corporation of America, Sears-Roebuck Co., and two large appliance manufacturers has been approved by the Department of Justice.

SYOSSET, L. I., Aug. 6 -- The Cavcote Farm's Night Lily, a 7-year-old bay mare, scored 16 points to win the working hunter title at the Helping Hand horse show today. Mr. and Mrs. J. J. McDonald's Wings finished with 11 points to take the reserve ribbon.

THREE years have gone by since the country's last big strike -the eight-week shutdown of the steel industry in 1952. Unions are making unparalleled gains in real wages, pensions and welfare protection without a finish fight on the picket line.

The Tigers gained in the American League race yesterday by defeating the Yankees, 7 to 5. All the first-division clubs lost. Fifth-place Detroit is now five and a half games behind the White Sox, Indians and Yankees, who are in a virtual tie for first.
In women's fashions, a "Ford" is a style so popular year after year that every manufacturer tries to emulate it.

KIEL, Germany, Aug. 3 (Reuters) -- The first eight of a Soviet fishing fleet of twenty-four ships being built in West Germany have been delivered to their Moscow owners by the Howaldtswerke Yards at Kiel.

FOR really devoted household handymen, the annual vacation period usually includes one major project to be carried out -- something that calls for several days of sustained work. A happy man is he who actually gets it done. Even if he has bought all his materials in advance and gets a fair break in the weather and refuses all invitations for a day at the beach or golf course, other things can happen.

THE recent conviction of an auctioneer on the West Coast for falsely advertising five paintings as the work of Manet (2), Degas, Dufy and Rosa Bonheur is a unique, strategic and much too little publicized event. To the best of our knowledge, it marks the first time in the United States that successful legal action has been brought against an auctioneer selling fakes.

TOKYO, Aug. 6 -- The Government's appeal to the Japanese people to understand and cooperate in the extension of United States air bases has had a cool reception from several of the affected communities, according to the Kyodo news agency.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The economic trend is inflationary, mild but creeping. The Government took notice of it twice in a week. It puts restraints into effect on two fronts, those of home mortgages and borrowing by banks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Soviet Union, in the opinion of Americans at Geneva for the recent Big Four conference there, has accepted two principles that underlie the United States approach to disarmament in the nuclear age.

A BRIDGE player learns from experience that the play of certain cards will provoke predictable conditioned responses from the defenders. When dummy's holding is J-10-9 the lead of the jack will cause a defender to cover far more often than the lead of the nine.
The city seemed headed for the hottest summer in its recorded history as it set another heat record yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -Independence Mall, the new landscaped area in front of Independence Hall, will be the setting for a luncheon to be attended by 3,000 persons on Aug. 24.

THE hostess who has a guitar player among her friends has a problem: if she invites him over and asks him to bring his guitar he may feel that he is wanted only for the entertainment he can provide, while if she does not ask him to bring his guitar he will infer that his music is thought not good enough and be appropriately hurt. Either way she stands to make an enemy.

A GREAT deal of television drama is sick. Too many original dramas presented at choice evening hours are nothing more than dreary true confessions wired for sight and sound. The soap opera that once was heard in fifteen-minute stretches is now being offered in sixty-minute doses, and some eager beavers are suggesting that it's theatre. It isn't.

With a new approach to the problems of the Far East opened up at Geneva, the next major move in the international arena is expected to be Chancellor Adenauer's projected visit to Moscow in what would be a new round in the battle for Germany and for Europe.

THE major onslaught on Broadway contemplated by the Playwrights Company this season is beginning to take on an appearance of order, glitter and catholicity. The latest word from that busy establishment is that Lilli Palmer is interested in playing the leading role in Robert Sherwood's comedy "Small War on Murray Hill."

YARMOUTH, N. S., Aug. 6 -The bicentennial of the expulsion of the Acadians from Nova Scotia in 1755 will reach its high point Aug. 15. Inevitably the ceremony is set for "the little village of Grand Pre."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 -Chinatown is about to lose another link with San Francisco's colorful, sinful, Barbary Coast era.

SIGMUND FREUD had the tragic fate of seeing some of his most gifted pupils (Adler, Jung and Rank) leave him and become the leaders of rival schools. These men may have been the most ambitious of his followers, those most eager not to stand in Freud's shadow any longer; they were also original and active thinkers who saw some of the weaknesses of Freud's system and pointed to new roads in theory and therapy.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Willie Hartack, the nation's leading jockey, scored a triple -- including an easy victory in the $27,500 Sheridan Handicap -- at Washington Park today.

THE West Coast penchant for nautical musicals is well-known. List Broadway's "Ankles Aweigh" as the newest prospect, according to a spokesman for producer Anthony B. Farrell, who is doggedly continuing the engagement at the Mark Hellinger here against decidedly mixed reviews and erratic public response.

Ford B. Draper has been named general director of sales of the textile fibers department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. William L. Scarborough has been appointed director of the cellulosics manufacturing division.

HARVEY BREIT, in summing up his critique of my recent article on "Book Burning -- How the Librarians Do It," accused me of equating "McCarthy's total, barbaric hate campaign against literature and the occasional misguided library suppression of a particular book."

CALADIUMS, natives of the rain forests of the Brazilian State of Para, are winning greater popularity among American gardeners and house plant fanciers. Grown for their colorful foliage -- green, white, red and pink -- the caladium varieties have leaves that are speckled, blotched, crinkled and veined in interesting contrasts as gay as tropical birds.
For the last seven months, during which bond prices have been falling to the lowest levels since the "sound money" scare of 1953, Wall Street has been having a boom in convertible debentures.
SEATTLE, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Ten of America's fastest speed boats are set for tomorrow's Gold Cup racing classic on Lake Washington.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Factory sales of home laundry appliances for the first six months of 1955 were the highest of any first half year in the history of the industry, and were 33 per cent higher than in the corresponding 1954 period. The figures were announced last week by Guenther Baumgart, executive director of the American Home Laundry Manufacturers Association.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UP) -The National Labor Relations Board reported today a record number of illegal secondary boycott charges against unions during the second quarter of 1955.

BELGRADE, Aug. 6 -- Marshal Tito often has been pictured as walking a tightrope held taut by the "cold war." Should the tension between East and West be relaxed, it has been said, the rope would slacken and Tito would come tumbling down.
BUFFALO, Aug. 6 -- Extension of the State Thruway to the Pennsylvania state line and to the Canadian border has moved from the planning stage to construction.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 6 (UP) -- Budge Patty of California and Baron Gottfried Von Cramm of Germany won the men's doubles title for the third time in the German tennis tournament today. They defeated Adrian Quist of Australia and Russell Seymour of South Africa, 6 -- 1, 7 -- 9, 6 -- 4, 9 -- 7.

After an absence of ten years, the Department of Parks model yacht regatta will be held again in Central Park. A six class schedule of races for the craft of young sailors will be held on Conservatory Lake, SeventySecond Street and Fifth Avenue, next Saturday at 2 P. M.

PEOPLE are still failing in business -- boom or no boom. Last week Dun Bradstreet reported 201 failures in this country in the week ended on July 28. That was twenty-eight more enterprises than got into trouble a week earlier.

FAIR HAVEN, N. J., Aug. 6 -- Lawrence J. Riordan of the Richmond County Yacht Club on Staten Island today won the Shrewsbury River Yacht Club predicted-log race for the National Express Cruiser championship trophy.

FAILURE of President Eisenhower to get his $101,000,000,000 ten-year Federal road-building program through Congress and the surprising defeat of the Democratic counter - proposal in the closing days of the Congress will be felt acutely and for a long time by the nation's motorists.

A LITTLE girl's happy, busy day at play school is shown here in large photographs, each of which gives a feeling of "just like me," or "I'd like to do that, too." A few words accompany each picture including some of Pinny's own comments, which adds to the friendliness of the book.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 6 -Royal Pastime, an 8-year-old bay gelding owned by William A. Rorech of Old Westbury, came up on the outside near the end of the stretch to win the $7,000 Connecticut free-for-all trot tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
LONDON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Touring American farm experts visited the Stalin collective farm near Rostov yesterday. They found several things they did not like, the Moscow radio reported.

The continued hot weather finally made its full effect felt in New York department stores last week. Sales dropped below year-ago levels all along the line, and the major stores wound up with a volume decrease averaging about 5 per cent below sales of the comparable week last year.

IN the summer of 1862 Dostoevsky went as a tourist to various European countries. The following year he wrote several articles about this trip under the title "Winter Notes on Summer Impressions"; the English translation appears now in book form.

Capitalizing on the Yankees' shoddy fielding and relief pitching, the Tigers pushed across four runs in the seventh inning to defeat the Bombers, 7 -- 5, at the Stadium yesterday.

DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 6 -- The home-building boom which has placed Dallas fourth in volume in the nation continues, with dwelling construction here for the first half of this year already exceeding the figure for any previous whole year.

Forty thousand foreign students, scholars and doctors spent the 1954-55 academic year in the United States, according to the annual census of foreign exchanges issued by the Institute of International Education, 1 East Sixty-seventh Street.
The Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association's thirtieth annual championship will get under way at the Bonnie Briar Country Club tomorrow.

TO THE EDITOR: In the picture-feature on the Russians visiting Iowa farms--"Russians in Iowa" (July 24)--the caption with the photograph showing a sign in Russian translates the sign as "Welcome." Well. I'm no expert on modern Russia-n; I learned it as a child from my Vlite Russian migr parents.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The State Department's Passport Division soon will leave the rats and termites in its Civil War vintage home for a modern building.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 6 -- A major general who speaks the tribesmen's language and plays a profitable game of bridge with diplomats will become Governor General of Pakistan tomorrow.
NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 6 -- The cruise of the New York Yacht Club began to look a little today like a duel between that distinguished organization and the Eastern Yacht Club of Marblehead, Mass.
GENEVA, Aug. 6 -- A United States spokesman predicted today the opening of a vast store of secrets on the non-military application of atomic energy.
A young man who is on the police waiting list slugged one early yesterday morning and now finds himself charged with felonious assault and free on $2,500 bail.
TRENTON, Aug. 6 -- Northern New Jersey, which now has three-fifths of the state's population, is thirsty, parched and dry. Never before has it needed water to such an extent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The United States is now looking to the future in terms of probable peace, rather than of possible war.

The educational and recreational activities of the Jacob A. Riis Settlement will be furthered by the Oct. 6 performance of the Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House. The settlement has taken a number of seats at the performance, which will include presentation of a new ballet by Frederick Ashton in addition to "Daphne and Chloe" and "Madame Chrysantheme."
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 6 -- Premier Pibul Songgram has resumed full control of his government and decreased the power of two of the most powerful men in the country.
GALVESTON, Tex., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias rested under sedatives today in her fight to overcome cancer a second time.
PANAMA, Aug. 5 -- The efforts of the five other Central American republics to swing Panama from her historic attachment to Bolivarian republicanism have for the present at least failed.

THAT one can achieve a rustic country atmosphere only an hour's drive from the heart of New York City is indicated by the two houses pictured here. Designed by David Henken, both houses are located on the same lakeside property in Armonk, New York.

BUFFALO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Jacob K. Javits, State Attorney General, urged today that the American Legion back a five - point program to further "peaceful competition between the Free World and the communistic world.

DENVER, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, independent, said today it had asked for a Senate investigation of "a possible relationship between Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. and the non-ferrous metals industry."
ALLATOONA LAKE, Ga., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Billy Roberts of Chattanooga, Tenn., won the junior national Snipe Class sailing championship today for the second year in a row.

STONINGTON, Me. -- Rare indeed is the seacoast travel folder that fails to talk of the charm of local fishing villages and their inhabitants. Not always do the little coastal towns live up to their advance billing.

THE simplest vital statistic of all -- how many people are there? -- is the one nobody knows. Nobody knows precisely how many Chinese there are, or Indians. We do know that between the two of them they represent nearly half the total of living human beings.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- After snapping pictures of his favorite golfers for several hours, Peter Thomson teed off in the rain today and shot a 70 to retain his lead after fifty-four holes in the $25,000 All-American tourney.
Negotiators for both parties in the threatened strike of milk tank-truck drivers were optimistic last night that a settlement would be reached without a walkout.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Two debutantes have been added to the official list for the annual Tuxedo Ball to be held Oct. 22 in the Tuxedo Club. They are Miss Fair Alice Bullock and Miss Virginia Loomis.

FOR the last four months the staff of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden has been augmented by a guest from the other side of the world. Kan Yashiroda has just left on his return journey to Japan.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Bob Kuntz, the metropolitan amateur champion, and his brother Bill of Bonnie Briar moved into the final of the John G. Anderson Memorial Tournament today.

Lawrence, author of "Sea and Sardinia," and other adventurous travelers could dislodge the widespread conviction that the island was as dangerous and disgreeble as the heart of the African jungle.

L., which generally attracts about 1,000 delegates from most of the states, will be held Aug. 15-19 at Fort Wayne, Ind. The problem of how to meet teacher and classroom shortages when the schools open this fall will receive top priority.

LONDON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Chapman stood impassive in the dock at a suburban magistrate's court as his father's closest friend, Detective Superintendent Philip Burney, testified on his arrest. Mr. Burney and the accused man had walked together as chief mourners at the elder Chapman's cremation.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 6 -- A score of 13 -- 0 would have looked horrible to the folks back home, so the Giants scored four times in the ninth inning and lost today's game to the Redlegs, 13 -- 4. Four of the seven hits the Giants made against Art Fowler, including a three-run homey by Sid Gordon, were achieved in the last round.

LONDON, July 22 -- A group of man-apes or ape-men of South Africa called Australopithecines (class of 150,000 B. C.) has been upgraded. The creatures were probably human, paleontologists say. Teeth of Australopithecines have been found in recently excavated beds of pebbles containing tools made of chipped quartz.

AN experimental television program called "Essays '55" had a tryout Saturday night over WRCA-TV, and it is a presentation that by all means should be seen again. The sampling was both amusing and stimulating, something a little different under the TV sun.

ZURICH, Aug. 7 -- Turnover declined on the Zurich Stock Exchange after the news Wednesday that the Bank Deutscher Lander had raised the official discount rate from 3 to 3 1/2 per cent and the National Bank of Belgium from 2 3/4 to 3 per cent on the same day.

MONTREAL, Aug. 7 (Canadian Press) -- Stockholders of Kenmac Chibougamau Mines, Ltd., have approved a loan and option agreement with Atlas Corporation of New York. MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 7 -- Groups of former Ukrainians living in this area demonstrated today against the Russian farm delegation, that is touring the Midwest.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Aug. 64 -- Wallace Groves, United States industrialist, has received permission to form a multi-million-dollar industrial area in a free port on the island of Grand Bahama, seventy miles east of Palm Beach, Fla.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- East-West trade could be most quickly expanded with United States surplus farm products to comply with the conclusions of the Geneva Big Four conference, according to qualified United States officials.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Doug Ford, the Professional Golfers Association champion, worked out a two-under-par 70 at Tam o' Shanter today to win the top prize of $3,420 in the All-American tourney with a total of 277. That was 11 under par for the seventy-two holes.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 7 -- New York fans may not be too familiar with the work of Joey Amalfitano, but the rarely used bonus boy of the Giants took the spotlight today at Crosley Field. Emerging from the bullpen, where he had been warming up relief pitchers, Amalfitano became the key figure in the 6-5 victory the Giants gained over the Redlegs in the second game of today's double-header.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 7 -- The stock market here showed considerable strength last week, while London and Wall Street were in retreat. There was marked activity on Friday following the rises in bank rates abroad.

A new drama has been completed by Graham Greene, whose two previous plays in this country, "The Living Room" and "The Heart of the Matter," were failures. Not disheartened, the popular novelist will endeavor to change his luck with "The Potting Shed."

GENEVA, Aug. 7 -- The Soviet Union invited scientists and reporters from the outside world today to a preview of its extensive atoms-for-peace exhibit.

The long-promised and long-awaited restoration of press freedom in Colombia is apparently further off than ever. News dispatches from Bogota report the closing down of El Tiempo, Colombia's leading morning newspaper and one of the best anywhere in Latin America. El Tiempo's sin was to refuse to publish a Government-dictated statement that would have, in effect, apologized for having contradicted President Gustavo Rojas Pinilla.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn suggested today that President Eisenhower crack the whip over some members of his own party if he wanted more action on Administration proposals next year.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 7 -- Despite the hiatus in government that exists here, the physical preparations have been completed so that the first nation-wide elections in the history of the young Indonesian Republic can be held Sept. 29.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 7 -- Plagued by heat, vacations and maintenance failures, the steel industry last week was further and further behind in its deliveries. Even the move of striking October promises from the books appeared to make little headway in the avalanche of orders, increasing backlogs and mounting carryovers.
BARGAINS just don't find buyers in the infants departments of stores hereabouts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -Americans earned slightly less in June than in the previous month, the Government reported today.

Thomas M. Goodfellow, general manager of the Long Island Rail Road, expressed the opinion yesterday that a compromise was possible in the dispute between the line and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, independent.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower attended church today and heard a sermon contrasting freedom of religion in the United States now with what the minister called "ignorance superstition, intolerance'' in the past.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Bus Mosbacher, commodore of the host club, won for the second straight time to take the International Class prize as the Beach Point Yacht Club completed its week-end regatta on Long Island Sound today.
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- The city was prepared for the gloomy tidings of the sharp July drop in the sterling area's gold-dollar reserves, but the security markets tumbled further nonetheless.
GENEVA, Aug. 7 -- Britain has taken a vigorous lead over the United States in exploiting the immediate commercial possibilities of atomic power.
Establishment of a regulatory agency to police the private carting industry was urged upon Mayor Wagner yesterday by the Greater New York's Cartmen's Association.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Following is the introduction to the tenth annual report of the Secretary General of the United Nations:

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- The heat wave, which took the edge off recent optimistic crop reports, induced active buying of corn, oats and soybeans last week. While there were some indications of moisture relief, much anxiety still prevailed as the five - day forecast was rather gloomy, indicating continued hot weather and only moderate moisture.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 7 -- Albert B. (Happy) Chandler, former baseball commissioner, appeared today to have won the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination in yesterday's closely fought primary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Senator Richard L. Neuberger asked today that Douglas McKay resign as Interior Secretary because of the "depredation" of natural resources under the Republican Administration.
An unfinished painting of 1519 was suggested yesterday as a guide to modern Christian living by the Rev. Canon Frederic Hood of London.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -- The Saar's newly formed Christian Democratic Union today joined other pro-German parties in urging rejection of the French-German statute for the region at the referendum to be held Oct. 23.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7 -- What a day! There was a boat race between Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, and the United States Ambassador, Charles E. Bohlen. The Ambassador won. From the shore of the lake Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin shook his fist and called out to Mr. Mikoyan: "You've let him beat you."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 7 -- Sale of radio station KBAK in Bakersfield by the Bakersfield Broadcasting Company, a subsidiary of The San Francisco Chronicle, to L. Benton Paschall, Howard L. Tullis and John P. Hearne of Hollywood was announced today.
The State Insurance Department announced yesterday that it was continuing its investigation of management-labor welfare plans.

Those twelve rules which Air Pollution Control Commissioner Greenburg has had distributed to apartment house superintendents in parts of Manhattan on the proper operation of incinerators make good sense. Wise superintendents will follow the rules, because the same inspectors who have been around recently distributing the regulations are due to make follow-up calls a little later issuing court summonses where incinerators are still smoking.

GENEVA, Aug. 7 -- The transcendent problem posed by this year's series of Geneva meetings is whether man's ingenuity irreparably exceeds his wisdom. Last month's summit conference produced a new mood but no solution to political puzzles.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -Central Committee of the World Council of Churches decided here tonight to hold its next annual session in Hungary. It accepted an invitation from the Protestant churches of Hungary to meet in or near Budapest, July 28-Aug. 5, 1956.

WOLFSBURG, Germany, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Volkswagen Company announced at its jubilee celebration yesterday that domestic prices will be cut and exports reduced to assume quicker home delivery of its little automobiles.
Mayor Wagner has been officially warned that the city should give special attention to the housing problems confronting large families, aged persons, Negroes and Puerto Ricans.

The United States hasn't been the scene of a Davis Cup challenge round since 1950, when we lost the trophy to Australia. Now that the cup emblematic of world team supremacy is "home" again, interest in the top event in tennis is high.
THIS is Guy Cleveland Miller's dream -- to make models of Manhattan and its 58,503 buildings in balsa, paper and glass, and to take the whole island on world tour.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, called today for a swift Government ruling to determine whether recent major mergers in the textile industry violate the law by "tending substantially to lessen competition."
New York's month-long hot and dry spells were broken last night by the heaviest rain of the year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that the Big Four conference in Geneva "substantially reduced" the chances of war, although the same basic differences existed between the East and West.
People all over the world are now wondering if, despite past bad faith and duplicity, they can now take Soviet professions of friendliness and peacefulness as sincere.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Federal regulation requiring loyalty oaths of tenants in Federally aided low-rent housing projects is running into serious legal trouble.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Scientists at Argonne National Laboratory, near Lemont, Ill., have put into operation a deep-water facility for testing the effects of atomic irradiation of foods and other substances, including plastics.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 1955 -- Contract bridge players -- l,236 of them -- this afternoon shattered all entry records as the American Contract Bridge League's twenty-seventh annual national contract bridge championships opened here at the Palmer House.
The Eighty-fourth Congress overlooked a major need when it failed to provide some kind of Federal aid for school construction during its first session.

American tastes and style desires are having a growing effect on European designers and had some influence in bringing back the bust and hip lines, David Nemerov, chairman of the board of Russeks Fifth Avenue, Inc., said yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 -- The Sierra Club urged today backers of the Colorado River storage project to abandon their advocacy of Echo Park Dam in Dinosaur National Monument.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- An American Federation of Labor committee proposed today Government curbs on what it called "subsidized industrial migration." It defined this as the use of special tax concessions or other inducements to lure plants to new locations.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 7 -- Talks will begin this week in Paris to prepare for Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's visit to Moscow at the end of this month or early in September.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -Thomas E. Coleman of Madison, Wis., was named today chairman of the finance committee to raise funds for the 100-foot bell tower to be erected on the Capitol grounds in memory of Senator Robert A. Taft.
TOKYO, Aug. 7 -- The eleven United States airmen released by the Chinese Communists after imprisonment for two and a half years said today that they had been tortured.

THE DREYFUS AFFAIR, as the French call it, aroused more passionate fury than any trial of modern times. In this country we have had the Sacco-Vanzetti and the Hiss-Chambers cases, but they caused only a ripple of public interest in comparison with the tidal waves of partisan emotion that swept over France in the Eighteen Nineties.
The 200-foot oil tank barge Betty K. of the New York Tank Barge Co., Inc., made her maiden appearance here yesterday.
Fifty-five years ago this afternoon two young men walked to opposite sides of a tennis court in Brookline, near Boston, and faced each other. One was an American, the other an Englishman.

The continued unrest in French North Africa has precipitated a move in France itself which could have serious repercussions on the whole European situation. This move proposes nothing less than the transfer of all active French military forces, including those committed to NATO for the defense of Europe, to North Africa on a more or less permanent basis if that is necessary to maintain order there.

NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 7 -- The incident of the two yachts that struck the New York Yacht Club's regatta committee boat at the start of last Tuesday's Una Cup race was closed today. Thor Ramsing's Solution and Frank Wetherill's Jubilee both withdrew at a race committee hearing.

Prices of domestic cotton futures softened last week and closed the period on moderately lower ground. Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed on Friday down 22 to 38 points from the close of the week before.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Boston's fourth-place Red Sox remained within striking distance of the American League leaders today by outlasting the Kansas City Athletics, 16 -- 12, in a 2- hour-54-minute ball game.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland charged today that Communist China was trying to gain at Geneva a "blackmail" list to force the unwilling return of Chinese to their homeland.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Until the seventh inning today, the Dodgers had made one hit off Bob Rush and had only one man left on base. Then the Dodgers loaded the bases on two hits and a pass and scored three runs.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 7 -- Rex Hartwig of Australia defeated Atsushi Miyagi of Japan before rain forced cancellation of the final tennis match in the Davis Cup interzone semi-final at the Nassau Country Club today.
INCHON, Korea, Aug. 7 -- An angry crowd of South Koreans isolated members of the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission today in their billets on an island in Inchon harbor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver said today he had asked the Attorney General to look into three phases of the canceled Dixon-Yates contract. The Tennessee Democrat asked Herbert Brownell Jr. to determine whether the Government was liable for any cancellation charges.
Mickey Mantle hit a towering tenth-inning homer to give the Yankees an even break with the Tigers at the Stadium yesterday.

Boris Spassky of Moscow captured the world junior chess title at Antwerp yesterday, according to a report received through Belgian news sources. Spassky, who was leading before yesterday's play, held first place by drawing with M. Farre of Spain in fifteen moves.

Forced to cancel their regular spring meeting because of New York State Thruway construction near the track, officials of Yonkers Raceway launch their 1955 harness racing season tonight. The meeting will run eighty-six nights.

The American Bosch Arma Corporation has elected V. Charles Schorlemmer as administrative vice president and Leslie E. Neville as director of public relations and advertising, it was announced over the week-end by Charles W. Perelle, president.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Consolidated net income of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company and its subsidiaries in the quarter ended June 30 rose to $4,570,100, equal to $3.71 a common share, from $4,054,749, or $3.63 a share, a year earlier, James F. Oates Jr., the chairman, announced today.
MOSCOW, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Some of the reporters noticed there was corn growing on the grounds, and asked Premier Bulganin whether "Khrushchev has also enlisted you in his corn-growing campaign?"

Today's Christians have the responsibility of keeping in this world "the balance of justice and liberty through love," the Rev. Francis X, Duffy declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick Cathedral.

A glaring fault in the New York State Income Tax law cries for correction. I'm referring to New York State's refusal to permit deduction of Federal income taxes in computing the individual's state tax, although the United States Government permits deduction of the state tax from the Federal return.

Bids for 6,000 tons of structural steel for the key buildings of the $60,000,000 terminal development at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, are being solicited by the Port Authority.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Washington swept an abbreviated three-game series from Cleveland today by winning the first game of a double-header, 9 -- 3. The second game was called because of rain in the last of the third inning with both teams scoreless.

WASHINGTON (AP) -- Congressional Secretaries, a group of Girls and Men Friday for members of Congress, are locking up shop on Capitol Hill and preparing to take off to Europe and Hawaii on package trips they've arranged for themselves.

JACKSONVILLE, Ill., Aug. 7 -Water will begin flowing through Jacksonville's twentythree-mile water pipe line from the Illinois River tbmorrow. The action will mark the end of a water shortage that has plagued this central Illinois city for 130 yea rs.
The eleven-story loft building [at 97 to 103 East Houston Street, near the southeast corner of the !Bowery, has been sold by the 97 Corporation to an investing client of Walter Scott Co.
