KARACHI, Aug. 7 (UP) -- United States diplomats said tonight they believed the change in leadership of the government would not affect the strong pro-United States policy of the country.

WINDSOR, Ont., Aug. 7 -- The Chrysler Corporation of Canada is on the home stretch of a $50,000,000 expansion program aimed at getting a third of the passenger-car busi ness in this country. The company's half-mile-long passenger-car building has been doubled in size to permit two-shift operations.

PARIS, Aug. 7 -- A controversy over financial policy rose again here last week with the announcement of credit restrictions West Germany, Belgium and the United States. These measures are contrasted with the official tendency here to make credit cheaper.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- The world may be approaching an era of lessened international tension and a greater role for the United Nations as an agency to prevent war, Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- The Senate Majority Leader, Lyndon B. Johnson, who had a heart attack July 2, was discharged today from the Bethesda Naval Hospital in Maryland.

The Luckenbach Steamship Company has begun work on a $487,120 addition to its freight terminal at the foot of Thirty-sixth Street in Brooklyn that will increase freight - handling capacity by 25 per cent.
Governor Harriman said yesterday that state taxes might have to be increased next year.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Hurricane Connie picked up forward speed and grew slightly larger late tonight. However, it continued on the northwesterly course it had been following the last twenty-four hours.
A police helicopter swooped down on a wind-whipped approach to the open Atlantic yesterday and gave two men a skyhook hitch to safety.
The affluence of American tourists in Europe demonstrates that the common man "never had it so good" as in the United States today, a visiting clergyman from Paris declared yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- The New York Athletic Club easily retained its team crown in the fifty-fourth annual championships of the New York Rowing Association today in rough water and intermittent squalls.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 7 -- Brazil and Colombia have begun talks here in a new effort to peg coffee prices at a level satisfactory to them. These are the world's two biggest coffee producers and Brazil's whole prosperity depends on her coffee exports.

An age-old dream of mankind is expressed by the Old Testament in Isaiah, in the passage which looks forward to the time when men "shall beat their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruning hooks." Today, in Geneva, what may well be a historic beginning toward realization of that ancient dream is being made.
PAWLING, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Christ Church on Quaker Hill will hold its annual Hymn Sing next Sunday at 5 P. M.

WASAGA BEACH, Ont., Aug. 7 (Canadian Press) -- Five men and two youths were drowned in wind-lashed Nottawasaga Bay within four hours today when they were swept into deep water by undertow. Seven other persons were rescued or swam to safety.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 7 -- Rossano Brazzi, Italian actor who appeared with Ava Gardner in "The Barefoot Contessa" and Katharine Hepburn in "Summertime," will be coming to this country shortly. Universal-International has signed him to a three-year contract calling for his appearance in one picture a year.
TOKYO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Japan's swimming team defeated the United States, 44 -- 35, in the fourth U. S.-Japanese dual meet tonight.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- For the second year in succession, Ralph Bogart and Bob Brownell of Chevy Chase, Md., won the John G. Anderson Memorial best-ball tourney at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Milwaukee snapped a four-game losing streak today, beating Pittsburgh, 6 -- 3 and 4 -- 2. Bob Buhl spaced seven hits for the victory in the second game.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 7 -- There is widespread optimism in Costa Rica that the long Nicaraguan-Costa Rican quarrel will shortly be resolved.
Eugene W. Landy signed aboard an oil tanker at Marcus Hook, Pa., yesterday, hopeful that while he was at sea the Navy would reconsider its refusal to commission him in the Naval Reserve.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 8 -- Jerry Lewis and Dean Martin agreed today to carry out their current contractual obligations as a team instead of attempting to pursue separate careers.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- Herman Barron won the Westchester Professional Golfers Association championship by three strokes today. With a one-under-par 70 this morning over the Fenway Golf Club course, Barron added a two-under par 69 this afternoon for a winning aggregate of 139.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 8 -- As Singapore heads toward full self-government, political loyalties of the island colony's Chinese turn increasingly in the direction of Peiping.

GENEVA, Aug. 8 -- Messages from President Eisenhower and from the heads of government of Switzerland, the Soviet Union, Britain, India and France gave the atomic scientists meeting here a send-off of good wishes and high hopes today.

An appeal by a dissident stockholders' group for an order to inspect and make extracts from the stock lists of the Alleghany Corporation, holding company, was denied yesterday by Federal District Judge Edward J. Dimock.
PARIS, Aug. 8 -- The French wage-earner's share of the national income has increased in the last two years and is expected to go on increasing throughout 1955.
Former Senator James M. Mead of New York is being considered for appointment as the State Commerce Department's representative in Washington.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Capt. Dan Parker, 63, skipper of the British tug Turmoil, was fatally injured today by a fall from the Turmoil's bridge. In January, 1952, Captain Parker and his tug figured in one of the most dramatic sea rescue attempts -- the vain effort to save the stricken American freighter Flying Enterprise.
If Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has his way the United Nations may soon undertake, informally and otherwise, some functions implied rather than expressed in the Charter.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 8 -- Real estate in the twenty-one municipalities comprising Union County has a true value of more than $2,000,000,000, according to a preliminary table of equalized tax valuations prepared by the state.

Domestic steel production declined last week for the fourth consecutive week and amounted to 2,098,000 net tons, with operations at 86.9 per cent of the industry's rated capacity. Output the previous week was 2,190,000 with operations at 90.7 per cent.

Travel in various parts of the world is the subject of at least five books to be issued in the near future. Scheduled for Sept. 19 by Knopf is Erna Ferguson's "comprehensive" look at Mexico more than twenty years after her first visit, entitled "Mexico Revisited.

POINT JUDITH, R. I., Aug. 8 -- With assurances from the weather man that nothing more serious than fresh winds and moderate seas would threaten local waters, the flotilla of the twelfth United States Atlantic tuna tournament will leave this crowded port a daybreak tomorrow.
MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 8 -Nassau County began its summer phase of the Salk vaccine program today with only .sixtenths of 1 per cent of eligible children appearing for second shots or booster doses.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Leaders of the American Federation of Labor assailed this year's Federal legislative record today as "generally disappointing."

If now the Board of Education of the State of Georgia really means business, then the first people to be ousted in connection with the Georgia public school system will be the members of the board itself.
DETROIT, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Work stoppages resulting from excessive heat, coupled with additional planning for model switch-overs, are cutting into auto production.
Net shipments and profits of the Gaylord Container Corporation increased in the three and six month periods ended June 30, the company announced yesterday.
Mary Drayton's play "Debut" has been taken under option for for the second time in as many years and, barring difficulties, will be done off Broadway this fall.
GENEVA, Aug. 8 -- Within the next two decades man will tame the hydrogen bomb and harness its energy to provide a limitless source of industrial power, it was predicted today.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Eleven United States airmen were completely on their own yesterday for the first time after thirty-two months in the prisons of Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- For the seventh time in a little more than a year, the Soviet Union asked the United States today to return the Soviet tanker Tuapse and its crew. Chinese Nationalist warships seized the tanker June 23, 1954, and took it to Formosa:

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 8 -The Ministry of Foreign Affairs denied today that the United States, Britain and France had "put pressure" on the Vietnamese Government to live up to the Geneva accords.
Sgt. 1/C Lloyd W. Pate redeemed yesterday a promise made to a dead American soldier in a North Korean prison camp four years ago.

The cost of borrowing money to buy securities is about to move up for the second time in two weeks. Five of the city's major banks announced yesterday they planned to increase tomorrow the rates on loans to brokers to finance margin buying by their customers from 3 1/4 per cent to 3 1/2 per cent.
Only a small fraction of the eligible children appeared at city health centers yesterday to receive second shots of Salk antipolio vaccine.
Refreshed and revivified by the year's heaviest rains, New Yorkers basked yesterday in pleasantly mild weather that promised to linger a short while before the heat and high humidity returned.
An investment syndicate headed by Scott, Horner Mason will place on the market today a new issue of 50,000 shares of Southeastern Telephone Company common stock at $17.25 a share.
Trans-Canada Air Lines, first Western Hemisphere carrier to fly turbine-propeller planes, extended that service to the New York-Montreal run yesterday.

CENTERPORT, L. I., Aug. 8 -- If a perfect start means anything, the first district Star Class sailing championship being contested in Long Island Sound off here should be one of the best in history. The committee, headed by Harry Pearsall, set a long starting line square to the wind and all twenty-two of the craft competing were on the line at the starting gun.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- The collecting of first money of $9,800 in the Schuylerville Stakes was an easy bit of business for Mrs. Helen W. Kellogg's Dark Charger today. Even though she was under a hold in the stretch, she frisked to a seven-length score.
A Supreme Court Justice went back to the legislative intent be- hind the law yesterday to order Roosevelt Raceway to issue a pari-mutuel clerk's license to a school, teacher.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -Prime Minister Eden has assured Chancellor Konrad Adenauer that "in the long negotiations which lie ahead,'' the British Government will have constantly before it the right of the German people to be reunited in freedom.
BLED, Yugoslavia, Aug. 8 -Yugoslavia has again minimized the importance of the military aspect of her alliance with Greece and Turkey today.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Aug. S (AP) -- Brazil moved into the lead today in the fourth international University Games.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- The breaking of the drought and heat wave the past few days resulted in a deluge of offerings in the grain pits on the Board of Trade today. All deliveries of rye except the September made new crop lows, and new low seasonal levels were registered in September and December oats, and March wheat.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Camarero, a shrimp as race horses go, may never break a speed record, but his name was in turf record books today as the winningest thoroughbred ever.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 8 -- The Nassour Studio became the ninth television film company to agree to Screen Actors Guild terms today.

GAZA ARMISTICE LINE, Aug. 8 -- Israel's chief truce negotiator warned today that Egypt's policy may be heading toward "ominous confirmation that direct contact between the two countries is possible only in war or border incidents."
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 8 -- "The Rope," an opera made for Tanglewood and with Tanglewood's help, achieved the right happy ending here tonight -- a premiere at Tanglewood.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has sold the 10:30 to 11 P. M. time period on Tuesdays for a television show to be sponsored by the General Motors Corporation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- An eighth-inning home run by Gene Baker today broke up a pitching-duel between Sam (Toothpick) Jones of the Chicago Cubs and Don Newcombe of the Dodgers.

The Reynolds Metals Company achieved record sales and earnings in the first half. Sales rose 28.6 per cent and profits 69 per cent over those of the corresponding six months last year.

CHICAGO, Aug 8 -- F. Ayres Bombeck of Kansas City and Byron Greenberg of Tulsa, Okla., forged ahead this afternoon in a field of 134 pairs in the Life Masters bridge championship. This was the premiere pair event of the twenty-seventh annual national championships that are being held at the Palmer House.

Potatoes go into the market basket for a nickel a pound. Newly dug and waxy, they turn up at table in a savory potato salad. That dish is no relation to the dismal delicatessen variety made with the mayonnaise that should be forbidden with cold spuds.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 8 Teen-age representatives of the Noroton, American, Riverside, Seawanhaka-Corinthian and Pequot yacht clubs entered the championship division of the Long Island. Sound junior sailing series at Larchmont Yacht club.

The salaries of Protestant Episcopal clergymen rank "somewhere below the wages of carpenters, but slightly above those of truck drivers." This estimate of the clergy is contained in a commission report scheduled to be discussed at the forthcoming triennial general convention of the church in Honolulu from Sept. 4 to 15.

GENEVA, Aug. 8 -- The continued imprisonment of twenty-five citizens of the United States in Communist China was described today as the main obstacle to progress in the negotiations here between ambassadors of the two countries. The Chinese are also holding three Americans under house arrest. The rest of the thirty-six persons whose return the United States is demanding have been denied exit permits.
Net income of the Kennecott Copper Corporation for the first six months rose 55.2 per cent to $65,430,468 from $42,149,193 a year earlier.

BALBOA, C. Z., Aug. 8 -- The Panama Canal Company expects to advertise late this month for bids on an electric-power conversion project involving one or more contracts totaling between $1,000,000 and $2,000,000.

Plans for construction of a twenty-two-story modern glass and metal office building at Public Square in Cleveland, Ohio, the first office building to be completed there in the last twenty-five years, have been announced by Brooks, Harvey Co., New York mortgage investing and financing firm. Financing was arranged by the brokers for a builder-client.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and subsidiaries reported today consolidated earnings of $64,964,743 for the first half of 1955, an increase of 22.5 per cent over a year ago.

A detective with sharp ears and an inquiring mind rounded up yesterday what the police said could have developed into a major murder and hold-up gang. At the same time he was able to keep a brand-new pistol out of the hands of some teen-agers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP)-Cash dividend payments totaled $1,400,000,000 in June, an 11 per cent increase over the same month a year ago, the Department of Commerce reported today.
Confusion was worse confounded yesterday in Brooklyn transit operations.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8 -- The junk Fre China, fifty-three days out of Yokosuka, Japan, sailed through the Golden Gate today and tied up here.

ORADELL, N. J., Aug. 8 -- Representatives of thirty, families here will appear tomorrow before the State Public Utilities Commission in Newark to protest against construction of a high-pressure natural gas main near their homes.

An audience of 4,000 crowded the western half of Washington Square Park last night to hear the second of the four summer concerts being sponsored there by the Washington Square Association. Again it was a program that in its selections and manner of performance would have been a credit to the city's indoor music season at its best.
Thomas J. Donlan resigned yesterday as assistant district attorney in Brooklyn to become chief investigator for the New York City Anti-Crime Committee.
MILAN, Italy, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Key Italian witnesses in the World War II slaying of a United States secret agent, William Holohan, prepared today to fly to the United States tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -The Civil Service Commission listed today 205 cases since Nov. 1, 1950, in which business or industry experts borrowed by the Government had served in operating jobs, rather than as consultants, in violation of regulations.
Senator Herbert H. Lehman and Governor Harriman met yesterday and said they talked legislative -- not political -- shop.

WHETHER Hannibal was the greatest military commander in history may be a proposition subject to differences of opinion, but there has never been any doubt about his genius. The Carthaginian general did not inherit a superb military machine as Alexander did. His troops never refused to obey his commands as Alexander's did.

The German princely house of Wittelsbach -- so much more fantastical and oddly ingratiating than those two other outstanding clans of the Germanys, Hohenzollern and Habsburg -- came into the news lately with the death of Crown Prince Rupprecht, 86.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast a surprisingly large cotton crop of 12,728,000 bales this year despite a rigid production control program designed to help reduce surplus stocks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Air Force plans to cut its basic training period by nearly 50 per cent to increase the flow of technical personnel to operational units.

Directors of Detroit Steel Corporation yesterday approved a plan for refinancing the company's first mortgage note to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and providing more than $2,000,000 in working capital. M. J. Zivian, president, said consummation of the plan will pave the way for a resumption of cash dividends.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., Aug. 8 -- The weather luck of the New York Yacht Club cruise, which had held since the event began a week ago Saturday, ran out today. On the twenty-nine-mile run from Nantucket, the squadron had hard rain, fog, a toss of sea and a wind spell of twenty-five knots or better.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, obtained court approval yesterday of his order to the Board of Examiners to give a second examination to a candidate who had failed to pass the first one. The position, now vacant, is for director of science for the city high schools.
Before the Government issued its forecast yesterday on the cotton crop it took many precautions to make it accurate and to prevent any leak.
An alert jurist and a clerk probably saved the old Brooklyn Supreme Court Building from going up in flames yesterday.
TORONTO, Aug. 8 -- Bicroft Uranium Mines, Ltd., announced today it had received a letter of intent from the Canadian Government for the purchase of $35,805,000 worth of uranium concentrates.
Public Service Electric and Gas Company is planning to raise $60,000,000 in the public market by the sale of preferred stock and long-term debentures.
Not once in 14,600 miles of travel westward across Canada and then eastward through the United States have Mr. and Mrs. Joop Wouters of Oakland, Calif., had to buy a ticket for transportation.

HOPKINS, Minn., Aug. 8 -Members of the visiting Soviet agricultural delegation inspected a large farm-implement center near here today and asked about purchasing some of the newest harvesting machinery.
Four thousand commuters were delayed ten to forty minutes on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad last night following a series of mishaps during the evening rush hour.

Ninety local housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration announced yesterday plans for borrowing $86,216,000 on next Tuesday on loan notes for the temporary financing of low-rent projects.

BRATLLEBORO, Vt., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Justice of the Peace Manuel S. Miller and his wife Lucille, who had defied United States marshals in a twelve-hour siege of their home in May, were sentenced in Federal Court today. They promptly appealed.

Today's new film is "The Sheep Has Five Legs," a Frenchmade comedy starring Fernandel, at the Fine Arts Theatre. Henri Verneuil directed and Raoul Plooquin produced, from a, screen play by Rene Borjavel and M. Verneuil. Delmont, De Funes, Paulette Dubost and Francoise Arnoul head the supporting cast of the United Motion Picture Organization release, which has English titles.

The Inter-American Press Association appealed yesterday to the press and radio of the Western Hemisphere to join in condemning press censorship in Colombia and the government shutdown of the newspaper El Tiempo of Bogota.

I believe that the recently published statistics have proved conclusively that the financial plight of the subway system is caused by the same trouble that is plaguing many businesses -- namely, not enough sales in relation to overhead.

In contrast to the celerity with which eleven tortured American airmen were released by Red China at the start of the ambassadorial talks in Geneva there seems to be a roadblock against progress toward the release of the 36 American civilians who are still held by the Communists.

For the thirteen years from 1937 to 1950 there was scarcely a labor dispute -- local or national -- that did not involve Arthur S. Meyer, former chairman of the State Mediation Board, as peacemaker or policy maker. He helped fashion the World War II "Little Steel Formula" that held the line against inflation while establishing the principle of union security.
EDWARDS, Calif., Aug. 8 (AP) -- A test pilot escaped unharmed today when an explosion ripped through the world's fastest rocket plane, high over the Mojave Desert.
STALINGRAD, U. S. S. R., Aug. 8 -- Twelve American farmers relived Stalingrad's wartime death and rebirth in a whirlwind tour of the city today.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 8 (UP) -- Rain today delayed the first round of the seventy-fourth annual invitation tournament at the Newport Casino.

Albert J. Feldman announced yesterday his resignation from the presidency of A. Hollander Son, Inc., one of the world's largest fur dressing and dyeing companies. He resigned also as president of two subsidiaries, the Hollanderizing Corporation of America and Competent Fur Dressers, Inc.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

As President Eisenhower concludes his examination of the bills that the Congress sent him for approval or disapproval he can reflect that only six of his predecessors were able to be as unhurried as he. Down to the end of Woodrow Wilson's second term Chief Executives went to the President's room in the Capitol and put their signatures to bills as they came through the legislative hopper.
VIENNA, Aug. 8 -- Matyas Rakosi, Communist leader of Hungary, gave a soft answer tonight to President Tito's accusation that he had been hindering a reconciliation between Hungary and Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- A "tax averaging" plan designed to give relief to persons with widely fluctuating annual incomes has been proposed to Congress.

It doesn't make much of a news splash when the new Police Commissioner says: "All laws will be enforced." If he had said that all laws would not be enforced the remark would, of course, have made startling headlines. Yet we believe it worth taking note of what he did say.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Because of reports that some oil companies are importing foreign petroleum in excessive quantity, the Government today called on industry for an accounting.

A special Defense Department task force has been established to study the 100 major recommendations and dozens of minor changes regarding the armed forces that were suggested by the Hoover Commission.
In a dispatch from Washington in your July 29 issue the following question was propounded:

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Two Republican Governors predicted today that President Eisenhower would be renominated and re-elected next year. They were Goodwin J. Knight of California and William G. Stratton of Illinois.
New York's longshoremen have opened a second-front attack on the Waterfront Commission.
GENEVA, Aug. 8 -- The British say they are approaching the "Cadillac stage" in their designs for fast power-producing atomic reactors.
DAVOS, Switzerland, Aug. 8 (UP) -- The Central Committee of the World Council of Churches ended a week-long meeting today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- The Asian-African conference of United Nations members agreed today to strive again for inclusion of the Netherlands New Guinea question on the agenda of the General Assembly's fall meeting.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 8 -- The Marathon Corporation of Menasha, Wis., announced here today that it would build a $30,000,000 pulp and paper plant in western Alabama near Myrtlewood. The company is one of the nation's leading paper products manufacturers.
MOSCOW, Aug. 8 -- If things keep going the way they are Pravda is soon going to need a society editor and a gossip columnist.

Fire Commissioner Cavanagh has decided that a practice he initiated -- one that has proved to be saving both of property and lives -- should not only be continued, but extended. On April 16 he put into operation a roving fire squad to answer first alarms in Harlem.
A crowd of 50,000 is anticipated at the Stadium tonight when the Yankees tangle with the fast-moving Boston Red Sox in the opener of a three-game set.
TRENTON, Aug. 8 -- The Republican-controlled State Legislature convened here today, its first session since June 17. The deliberations lasted two hours.

LARCHMONT, Aug. 8 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt captured the medal today as seventy-four players competed in the qualifying round of the thirtieth women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship.
Virgil Akins, St. Louis welterweight, gained a split decision over Isaac Logart of Cuba in a ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Akins weighed 146 pounds, Logart 144 3/4.
The Celanese Corporation of America and its domestic subsidiaries increased earnings sharply in the first six months of 1955. They reported profits up 449.5 per cent above the 1954 figure.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Republican National Committee's director of minorities said today that President Eisenhower had redeemed all his 1952 campaign promises on civil rights.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson challenged President Eisenhower today to compare the record of the Democratic Congress this year with that of the first year of the Republican - controlled Eighty-third Congress.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Tuesday, Aug. 9 -- Albert B. (Happy) Chandler won the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in Saturday's state-wide primary election on the basis of nearly completed returns tabulated early today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Pentagon's top research man said today the free sharing of information from the earth satellite this nation planned would not extend to all details of equipment and launching.
Without noticeable pressure, the stock market slipped back in its closing hours yesterday. Only the coppers were strong as a group.

YONKERS, Aug. 8 -- The 1955 Yonkers Raceway season got off to a sparkling start tonight. Fears that New York State Thruway construction might cause traffic snarls proved groundless. Most of the crowd of 20,832 arrived on time.

INCHON, Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 9 -- Two hundred South Koreans fought their way to Wolmi Island early today in a drive to capture Communist members of the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission. They were driven off.
GENEVA, Aug. 8 -- The Ford family has made a grant of $1,000,000 to provide "atoms-for-peace awards."

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he would ask his colleagues on the Board of Estimate to "take another look at the Neponsit site." It was hinted at City Hall that the Mayor's request might be made at an executive meeting of the board to be held tomorrow.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 8 (AP) -- A Florida-bred colt, who was given little chance in a race with two unbeaten juveniles, jumped into the running for Eastern 2-year-old honors before 31,225 at Monmouth Park today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Treasury announced tonight that its short-term borrowing costs were still rising. They are at the highest point in nearly two years.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 389 pints of blood on Friday, including 307 at Fort Monmouth, N. J. Today a bloodmobile will visit the Mitchel Air Force Base, Garden City, L. I.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- A special board of naval officers has been set up to review the case of Eugene W. Landy, who was denied a commission in the Naval Reserve. His mother was formerly a Communist.

From New York's earliest days the philanthropic instincts of its people have sought and found expression, with notable results for the city and nation. But charitable gifts that were once comparatively simple, neighborly gestures now assume more complicated forms.

Contradictory appraisals of party responsibility for failure of much domestic legislation to emerge from the Congressional session continue. While both political parties share the responsibility, it is rather difficult to accept, in the case of one major topic, the Democratic leaders' post-mortem conclusion blaming House Republicans for failing to vote a highway bill that could be adjusted with a Senate-passed Democratic measure.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Charles E. Wilson said today that he hoped to submit this week to President Eisenhower the name of a successor to Harold E. Talbott, who has resigned as Air Force Secretary.
The state will carry to the Appellate Division its fight to keep public employes earning more than $5,000 a year from taking spare-time jobs at race-tracks.

ASTRONOMERS at Hayden Planetarium, kept glued to telephones by all manner of inquiries since the Government announced its earth satellite project, have booked a general background conference on the subject for Tuesday morning, Aug. 16.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The Atomic Energy Commission made available to the public today considerable previously classified information on uranium ore processing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- National Red Cross headquarters kept a vigil tonight on Hurricane Connie in the first trial of a greatly expanded disaster-preparedness system.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- The Federal Reserve Board has reported that loans granted by its member banks increased $7,232,000,000 in the year ended on June 30, the second highest increase in history.
Having achieved the greatest hit of his producing career with "The Fifth Season," George Kondolf can't help wondering whether "The Joker" (temporary title) will develop along those lines, too.
BOMBAY, India, Aug. 9 -- India's dock workers have started to build their own economic blockade around the Portuguese colony of Goa on India's west coast.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 9 -- The board of directors of the Norfolk Community Chest approved a plan today whereby it and the Red Cross will conduct a united fund campaign this year. Officially the chest accepted the Red Cross as a member agency of its organization.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The Defense Department announced today it intended to close fourteen manufacturing and commercial-type military operations "in the near future."

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 9 -- President Eisenhower roamed about his farm here this afternoon in a Crosley runabout with fringe on top. He accepted two more livestock gifts, a Holstein heifer and a Berkshire hog.
The city of Passaic, N. J., yesterday announced plans for borrowing $3,875,000 on Oct. 4 on serial bonds to finance school and other public improvements. The bonds will become due from 1956 to 1985.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Eastern experts dominated the twentyseventh annual National Contrast Bridge Championships here this afternoon. Seventy-two topranking pairs played through the first of two final sessions in the Life Masters Pair Championship.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Congress has been inconsistent and intolerant in its attitude toward business men who join Government service, Clarence B. Randall, chairman of the Inland Steel Company, charged today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 9 -- Negotiators for the Association of Motion Picture Producers and the Alliance of Television Film Producers met this afternoon with the Screen Actors Guild to try to find a basis for settling the five-day-old strike by actors.

MALMOE, Sweden, Aug. 9 (AP) -- A world walking record was bettered by a Swede today, but the highlight of an international track and field meet was Ernie Shelton's victory in the high jump over Bengt Nilsson of Sweden.

VIENNA, Aug. 9 (Reuters) -- The Russians are using ten to twelve trains a day -- a total of about 600 railroads cars -- to move their troops and belongings out of Austria, the Austrian Railways announced here today.
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- The Foreign Office challenged today a South Vietnamese communique that implied that Britain had backed Premier Ngo Dinh Diem's refusal to start talks with North Vietnam.
A Queens bank teller was arrested yesterday after the disappearance of $46,000 from the Hillside Avenue branch of the Jamaica National Bank.
Certain religious and educational leaders have published a proclamation calling on the American people to repent for the alleged crime we perpetrated at Hiroshima.

BOSTON, Aug. 9 -- Eighty-two construction workers strove tonight to secure a steel radar island, 110 miles east of Cape Cod, against the approaching hurricane. Al ready working around the clock, the men redoubled their efforts to secure the foundations of their steel perch.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -The Immigration Service ordered drastic reforms today designed to assure fair treatment to aliens accused of being in this country illegally.

GENEVA, Aug. 9 -- In 1892 the Swedish inventor of dynamite, Alfred Nobel, observed to a pacifist friend: "My factories may make an end of war sooner than your congresses. The day when two army corps can annihilate each other in one second, all civilized nations, it is to be hoped, will recoil from war and discharge their troops."

MONTGOMERY, Minn., Aug. 9 -- Some of the mass canning techniques that have contributed to streamlined living in the United States were shown to visiting Russian farm officials today. The Soviet group toured a plant here to watch fresh sweet corn being shelled, placed in cans, sealed and cooked, and then packaged in one long, uninterrupted operation.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 9 -- The pro-German parties in the Saar are actively opposing the Paris-Bonn agreement conferring an international stature on the territory pending a final peace treaty settlement.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Eleven officials of the Fur and Leather Workers Union in New York and four in Canada have been forced out of office to meet the anti-Communist policy demands of the American Federation of Labor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Employment in July climbed to the record total of 64,995,000.
As fast winds and high waves struck along the coastline here yesterday, the Weather Bureau warned this area to be on guard for Hurricane Connie's possible arrival tomorrow.
CAPE HATTERAS, N. C., Wednesday, Aug. 10--Hurricane Connie roared to within striking distance of the Carolina capes early today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 13 points lower yesterday, with business rather quiet.
A new appeal has been made to Congress to check the growing tendency of United States ore importers to build their vessels abroad and to operate them under foreign registry.

CENTERPORT, L. I., Aug. 9 -- Andy Underhill's Emme, the winner of today's race, took the lead in the first district Star class sailing championship on Long Island Sound. Emme leads Bob Crump's Sirene, yesterday's winner, by two points.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- The French soldier, asked by the last Government to start drinking milk as a move against alcoholism, may be asked by the present one to drink more wine to help absorb the wine surplus.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 19 (UP) -- Three top American entries and two foreign stars were eliminated today in the second round of the singles matches at the seventy - fourth invitation tennis tournament at Newport Casino.

LONDON, Aug. 9 (Reuters) -- Abdul Mannan, 41 years old, a clerk in the Pakistan High Commissioner's office here, has been paying 95 cents a week into Britain's nationalized medical and health plan for nine years.

Washington's moves to increase margins -- the amount of cash that an investor must provide to enter a securities deal -- from 50 to 70 per cent of the amount involved, have reduced margin trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
GENEVA, Aug. 9 -- The United States agreed today to postpone until Thursday morning the resumption of talks here with Communist China.
ALBANY, Aug. 9 -- Assemblyman Anthony P. Savarese Jr. of Kew Gardens, Queens, was elected chairman of the joint legislative committee investigating wiretapping today.
When a hurricane approaches, go home, take in everything loose and batten down.
GINO PRATO, the softspoken shoemaker from the Bronx, followed his father's advice last night and took the $32,000 he had already won on "The $64,000 Question."

BOSTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- America's hopes of retaining the Davis Cup brightened today with the announcement that Tony Trabert -- sidelined with a back and shoulder ailment -- would be ready for tennis competition next week.

POINT-JUDITH, R I., Aug. 9 -- Connie is no lady, according to the unanimous vote of the judges and team captains of the United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament. They decided late this afternoon to postpone the horse mackerel derby until the weather was more settled.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, said today that regardless of the Soviet "new look" the United States must maintain a "reasonable posture of defense."

Personally, one sees very little reason for any jubilation on the part of the Administration when they heard of the release of the eleven American airmen. Some of these men have been imprisoned for as much as four years by a country that officially was not even involved in the Korean war.
THERE'S a fresh approach to shoes for fall, both in style and leather.

Todd Shipyards Corporation's Brooklyn yard has received a contract to convert the Maritime Administration's Liberty ship George Chamberlain for use by the Navy, it was announced yesterday by Capt. Hewlett R. Bishop, Atlantic Coast director of the Maritime Administration.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 9 -- The coffee talks concluded here yesterday between representatives of Brazil and Colombia have failed to solve the problem of averting a price crisis for coffee countries within the next year.
Boston's battering Bosox continued their torrid pace in the American League's seething pennant race last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- National Airlines offered today to buy Northeast Airlines.
The Sheraton Corporation of America, which operates a nation-wide chain of thirty hotels, completed its most successful year on April 30.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 9 (AP) -- More burial chambers with stone coffins bearing the names of the dead have been found at an ancient Jewish cemetery in lower Galilee, a spokesman for the Israel Exploration Society said today.

The New York City Housing Authority has begun the final moves to evict tenants who refuse to swear they are not members of any of the organizations designated by the Attorney General as subversive. This action of the Housing Authority to oust the twenty-one non-signers among its 30,000 tenant families is in accordance with Federal law adopted as a rider sponsored by Representative Ralph Gwinn of Westchester County in 1952.
Employes of the Jacob Ruppert Brewery, 1639 Third Avenue, gave 252 pints of blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program on Monday. The day's total was 294.

The Transit Authority made a formal offer yesterday of a 5.3-cents-an-hour wage rise for its 35,000 hourly paid employes. But Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., rejected the offer as unsatisfactory.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 9 -- The United States mission in West Berlin said today that 2,400,000,000 Deutsche marks ($571,421,000) counterpart funds had been granted to stimulate West Berlin's economy m the last six years.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- William Turnesa of Knollwood and Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer, Century, gained low-gross honors in the eleventh annual Westchester County Golf Association mixed-foursome tournament today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 9 -- Interparty strife forced cancellation today of the induction of a new Prime Minister.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The National Labor Relations Board was asked today to reverse its policy of not exercising jurisdiction in the hotel industry.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 9 -- Egyptian-Israeli negotiations on armistice security measures were adjourned today for ten days to permit the representatives of both sides to consult their Governments.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 9 -- Samuel Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., conqueror of Mikhail Botvinnik in Moscow recently, is the favorite in the annual open chess championship here.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Overnight selling orders depressed all grain future prices at the start this morning, but active short covering and apparently some investment purchases caused a good rally.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 9 -- "Seven League Boots," the late Richard Halliburton's account of his adventures in the Near East, will be turned into a motion picture by Louis de Rochemont, independent producer.

MARION, Mass., Aug. 9 -- Gilbert Verney's Sea Lion won the Astor Cup today in the last event of the New York Yacht Club Cruise. It was last because the annual regatta listed for Buzzards Bay tomorrow was canceled.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Although the top United States twosome was defeated, the American team scored a 2 1/2-to-1 1/2 victory over a foreign team in the opening round of Tam o' Shanter's international matches today.
A committee established by the National Broadcasting Company to review children's television programs and offer suggestions for improvement issued a report yesterday on its findings.

Mayor Wagner has taken the initiative in calling on the Board of Estimate to reconsider its July 21 vote, and to make a park out of the Neponsit Beach Hospital site in Queens. The Mayor himself voted, along with Council President Abe Stark, for adding this abandoned beachfront hospital property to Jacob Riis Park.
Willard Nixon pitched the final six innings of last night's Yankee-Red Sox game with a lump in his throat. But it was the Bombers, rather than Boston's ace right-hander, who shed the tears.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 9 (AP) -- Albert B. (Happy) Chandler's Democratic nomination for another term -- after twenty years -- as Governor of Kentucky was conceded today by Bert T. Combs, his chief opponent.
GENEVA, Aug. 9 -- World economic growth is being retarded by two kinds of protection of special economic groups, the secretariat of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GAIT) said today
ALLATOONA LAKE, Ga., Aug. 9 (AP) -- Harry S. Allen of Westport, Conn., won the Crosby Memorial Trophy today in the national snipe sailing championship, leading a field of fifty-eight boats.

An investor assembling a plot of land just south of the Brooklyn Bridge has added to his holding the five-story building at 84-86 Gold Street, southeast corner of Ferry Street. The latest purchase was made from the McRich Realty Company, which had held the property for twenty-two years.
IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, Aug. 9 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission revealed tonight that it had deliberately destroyed a small atomic reactor in a safety test of the device.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Governors of souehrn states who sparked a revolt against the so-called "loyalty oath" at the 1952 Democratic Convention appeared cautiously convinced today that they could trust the party not to attempt a repeat performance in 1956.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Furnaces of the European Coal and Steel Community now supply 60 to 65 per cent of all steel products moved in world trade and 75 to 80 per cent of all such imports by the United States.

GENEVA, Aug. 9 -- Thorium is likely to become a nuclear fuel more valuable than uranium in the production of large quantities of cheap atomic power. Thorium is an element about four to ten times more abundant than uranium. While it is in itself not fissionable, it can be transmuted into Uranium 233, a highly efficient nuclear fuel.

American Natural Gas Company is offering to its common stockholders today rights to subscribe to 736,856 shares of common stock at $48.50 a share on the basis of one new share for each five held. The offer will end on Aug. 23.

A $1,500,000 program by the building industries to provide homes and home-building skills for South Korea was announced yesterday by Gen. James A. Van Fleet, retired, honorary chairman of the Homes for Korea Committee.
GENEVA, Aug. 9 -- Estimates of the cost of producing electricity from nuclear energy have been revised substantially downward.

A group of former residents of San Marino tore a leaf from the tactical notebook of their Communist countrymen yesterday. They left Detroit by train, forty-four strong, on the first leg of a trip back to that tiniest and oldest European republic in the heart of the Italian Apennine Mountains.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- President Eisenhower today gave Thomas M. Healy of Atlanta a recess appointment as a member of the Railroad Retirement Board. He will succeed Frank C. Squire, who resigned.

The course of hurricanes can't yet be predicted -- such is the backward state of our knowledge of the upper air currents and the reporting of storms as they run their course. The Weather Bureau is better equipped this year than last to get reports and send out warnings.

The management of the Little Carnegie Theatre, where "I Am a Camera" opened Monday, has reported a net take of $3,580 for the first day's performances, marking the highest opening-day figure in the history of the showcase.

Alfred de Liagre's production of "Janus" on Nov. 30 at the Plymouth Theatre and "Pipe Dream," the new Rogers and Hammerstein musical at the Shubert Theatre on Feb. 7 have been selected by the New York Botanical Garden for its fall and winter theatre benefits. Mrs. Howard Maxwell Jr. and Mrs. Charles G. Stradella are benefit co-chairmen.
Several lively John Philip Sousa marches were played for luncheon crowds at Battery Park yesterday to honor the famous band leader and composer on the 101st anniversary of his birth.

The use of the word "minorities' in six large signs at Jones Beach warning against littering, vandalism and rowdyism has been protested by the Jamaica branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 9 -- Argentina's Secretary of Economic Affairs, Alfredo Gomez Morales, disclosed tonight that the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey was seeking to invest $12,600,000 in Argentine oilfields.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 9 (AP) -- An embargo was placed as a precautionary measure today on bulk rail shipments of grain to elevators in Buffalo because labor contracts between elevator owners and their A. F. of L. employes expire on Sunday. Railroad officials said it would take only about 2,000 loaded grain cars to plug up local switching yards. Local elevators have been receiving 200 to 400 carloads a day recently.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- President Eisenhower signed the Military Reserves bill today. However, he said he wanted it strengthened in the next session of Congress, opening in January.
MOSCOW, Aug. 9 -- News correspondents here have been speculating on the possibility that the Soviet Union may stop censoring outgoing news dispatches.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Only one former champion survived the first round of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association's thirtieth annual championship at the Bonnie Briar course today.

In a recent Harper's Magazine William Faulkner looks at the lost privacy of the famous with a violent eye. In his article Mr. Faulkner explained that a few years ago he refused to let a weekly picture paper print a description of his life, but because the public knew his name and was curious it was published in spite of his refusal.

Five eyewitnesses described in vivid detail yesterday the beating and death by exposure of two sick and helpless American soldiers in a Korean prisoner-of-war camp. All pointed to Sgt. James C. Gallagher as the slayer.

Commodity futures were irregular in generally dull trading on the New York exchanges yesterday. Rubber, cocoa, tin, potatoes and zinc rose; coffee sugar, silk, lead and wool eased; and copper, hides, and burlap were mixed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A fruit-marketing cooperative in Florida was held today to have violated antitrust laws by attempting to fix resale prices of citrus fruits.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians bunched two walks with singles by George Strickland and Al Smith and a double by Gene Woodling to score four runs off Ned Garver in the second inning tonight and beat the Detroit Tigers, 4 -- 2.
Shoe manufacturers, convinced they are in an expanding market, jammed the opening of the two-day Tanners' Council Leather Show at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.
"Whatever opportunity still exists to bring atomic weapons under control should be seized now," Bernard M. Baruch said last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's statement on signing the new Military Reserve Law:

Eight thousand employes of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., were awarded pay rises of $2 a week yesterday by an arbitrator. The increase, retroactive to Feb. 1, was granted to members of Local 1-S of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, C.I.O.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Aug. 9 -- Tengku Abdul Rahman, new Chief Minister of the Federation of Malaya, put an amnesty for the territory's Communist rebels at the top of a list of Government objectives today.

The cliff dwellers of New York City, unaccustomed to the sights, sounds and beauties of the country, have welcomed the Flower Show each year. For many years prior to 1954 the advent of the International Flower Show at the Grand Central Palace meant an opportunity to wander about lawns and gardens that had by some magic been re-created far from their natural habitats.
Gismo the Peaceful, a versatile robot, acted as master of ceremonies yesterday.
The orphaned International Longshoremen's Association may move closer today toward acquiring a working partner.

A new synthetic yarn, designed to retain the durability of man-made fiber and at the same time achieve the softness of natural material, was introduced yesterday by the Textured Yarn Company of Philadelphia.

INCHON, Korea, Wednesday, Aug. 10 -- Forty trucks carrying 1,600 chanting, banner - waving workers from Seoul reinforced other Koreans yesterday in besieging members of the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission.
Plans for apartment buildings on two East Side sites were filed yesterday.

In a recent story you seem to infer rather directly that the Israeli Government is doing everything possible to cooperate with the Egyptian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission and the United Nations. In an item printed just below you do your best to infer that the Egyptian Government is not doing so, by refusing the Israeli suggestion for direct talks between the two Governments to ease the tension at Gaza.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Eleven United States airmen released by Communist China departed for home today aboard two plush air transports equipped with bunks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- The Commerce Department reported tonight state shares of about $875,000,000 in Federal aid for highways.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The report of the Department of Agriculture on today's livestock markets follows:
Higher money rates plus indications that Washington is seriously concerned over the rapid expansion of consumer credit sent stock market prices sharply lower yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- Office of Defense Mobilization officials said today that yesterday's request for import information from major oil companies is a "preliminary, fact-finding step."

The Dodgers walked to a 3-2 tenth-inning victory over the Giants at Ebbets Field last night. Mary Grissom, Manager Leo Durocher's third pitcher, threw four straight wide ones to Don Hoak with the bases filled and that settled the issue.

As a pitcher, the Dodgers' Don Newcombe is 18 -- 2, an almost incredible average of .900. As a pinch-hitter, the big fellow is 17-for-8 for a .471 mark in emergency batting roles. Seven of the safeties were solid, authoritative blows.
Matters of finance affecting the elderly were in the news yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- Note to New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad commuters: That orange streak of steel columns and girders a quarter-mile southwest of the New Rochelle station will be the first completed major viaduct on the New England Thruway from New York to Boston.
ALBANY, Aug. 9 -- Attorney General Jacob K. Javits recommended today that grievance machinery for Civil Service employes be approved by the Legislature rather than ordered by the Governor.

Now that the elevated railroad structure along Third Avenue is being speeded to oblivion, it is only fitting that thought should be given to what Third Avenue itself will look like with the elevated gone. The city authorities, it is good to note, have worked out a rehabilitation schedule that will include widening the roadway from sixty to seventy feet and a $1,200,000 repaying job.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The release of 1,177,000 cubic centimeters of Salk anti-polio vaccine under the voluntary control program was announced today by the Public Health Service.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 9 -In an atmosphere of mild acrimony, hearings opened today before the Connecticut Public Utilities Commission on commuter complaints against the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation, second largest domestic producer of copper, increased its consolidated net income in the first six months of this year to $32,672,177 from $19,326,269 in the corresponding period of 1954.
An off-duty patrolman used his service revolver yesterday to arrest three teen-agers in Brooklyn for possession of a zip gun and an eight-inch hunting knife.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 9 (UP) -- Craigwood, a Djeddah colt from the Craigwood Stable, caught the pace-setting Boston Doge in the stretch today and went on to a length-and-one-half triumph over the New England speedster in the $17,300 Boardwalk Handicap.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- There's a new pet in Hirsch Jacobs' barn. She's a 3-year-old filly, and her name is Searching.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 9 (AP) -- A South Korean Army court-martial today condemned to death Lee Chang Kwang, one of the first Communists to interrogate Maj. Gen. William F. Dean after his capture in the Korean war.

Cigarette advertising in the country's newspapers is increasing sharply. In the first quarter national linage for cigarettes -- regular, king, filter, filter king "and their sisters, aunts and cousins, who are reckoned by the dozens" -- was off 16.8 per cent, according to a Media Records study of 228 newspapers in 110 cities.

ARMONK, N. Y., Aug. 9 -Dave Lapkin and Joe Scarp of Pine Hollow tied George Borbely and Walt (Sonny) Bittal of Mohansic with a thirty-six-hole total of 303 at Tamarack today to send the "Ike" golf tournament into a sudden-death play-off.

A LITTLE raspberry jam, thinned with brandy or rum, provides a pleasing, not to say easy, topping for that uncomplicated dessert known as cornstarch pudding. Or the basic cornstarch mixture may be enhanced with fruit juice and puree for a quick version of Danish fruit pudding.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The railroads should add 60,000 new freight cars a year to meet the country's needs in the event of full mobilization, a committee of consultation on railroad equipment said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson said today that an effort would be made to eliminate the possibility of future cases similar to that of Eugene M. Landy, who was refused a Navy Reserve commission.
Response to the city's summer anti-polio inoculation program continued to be light yesterday.

The International Paper Company rolled up record quarter and half-year sales and earnings in the three and six months ended June 30, according to the report yesterday of John H. Hinman, board chariman.

Joseph Wood Krutch, lecturer, critic and author of "The Desert Year," which won the John Burroughs Association medal, has a new book about the desert on William Sloane Associates' list. It is "The Voice of the Desert: A Naturalist's Interpretation," dealing with the flora and fauna in the Sonoran Desert of the United States Southwest. It will be published Sept. 9.

NAGASAKI, Japan, Aug. 9 -- Thousands of paper lanterns on tiny rafts floated through Nagasaki to the sea tonight. They were part of a Buddhist ritual in honor of the souls of those who died here after this city was stricken ten years ago today by the mightiest weapon visited on man.

May I congratulate you on the way you have focused public attention on the Landy case? This is not only a case of a clumsy and brutal wrong done an apparently innocent individual but an example also of a disturbing trend in the relations between the American Government and its citizens generally.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Revision of the United Nations Charter might meet the threat of nuclear warfare, a special Senate subcommittee suggested to Congress today.

One of the considerations that the Federal Reserve Board undoubtedly had in mind when it approved a general advance in rediscount rates last week was the recent rapid expansion in installment credit. In June alone the net increase in funds borrowed for installment purchases was $765 millions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- President Eisenhower officially revived the Small Business Administration today. He signed into law a two-year extension of its authority to make loans to small businesses and otherwise assist them.
Three aviation leaders joined yesterday in a tribute to Dr. Robert H. Goddard, rocket and jet-propulsion pioneer, who died ten years ago today.

IT is a matter of twenty-eight years since George Herman Ruth, called the Babe, set his sights on a goal and made it. He hit sixty home runs and left this mark as the supreme effort of his fabulous career.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 9 (UP) -- The Mexican Government today suspended the sixth annual Pan-American road race scheduled for Dec. 2-5.
PARIS, Aug. 9 -- An attempt has been made to find a middle course to save the Government's unity in Paris and bring a measure of peace to Morocco.

Directors of the Griesedieck Company and Potosi Investment Company have agreed on a merger. Stockholders of the two companies will be asked to vote approval at special meetings on Aug. 30. The surviving company would be called the Griesedieck Company and operate as a closed-end investment company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The operation of the Internal Revenue Service, which was reorganized after the 1952 scandals, has been "very disappointing," an advisory group of tax experts reported to Congress today.
A factory and office building will be built in Clark Township, near Westfield in Union County, N. J., for the marine division of the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company, now at 345 Hudson Street.

A dozen dissident stockholders of the Thermoid Company, maker of rubber molded goods and plastics, failed yesterday in an attempt to hold a formal annual stockholders' meeting. The group seeks to elect its own slate of directors.

The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation achieved new highs in the second quarter in operating revenues and earnings. This was disclosed in the quarterly report mailed yesterday to stockholders.
LONDON, Aus. 9 -- The British Army is receiving a new set of orders on relations with newspaper men.

The atoms-for-peace conference in Geneva more than lives up to the expectations aroused by President Eisenhower's memorable speech of Dec. 8, 1953, before the General Assembly of the United Nations. Some eighteen hundred delegates from seventy-two countries and a thousand unofficial observers testify by their presence that this conference may well mean a turn for the better in world affairs.
Only a single major challenge to political leaders' selections for party nominations in the Sept. 13 primary election appeared likely last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- President Eisenhower signed today the Defense Production Act. Controversial new curbs were included in the act on the use of "dollar-a-year men" in the defense mobilization program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The International Cooperation Administration announced today that it has issued an investment guarantee to the Lincoln Electric Company of Cleveland covering the company's investment in a French subsidiary.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Adlai E. Stevenson and Averell Harriman were the focal points of political speculation at the start of the forty-seventh annual Governors Conference today.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Billy Pierce fired a two-hitter tonight as the American League-leading Chicago White Sox defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 4 -- 1.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 10 -- "The Sweet Smell of Success," published originally in Cosmopolitan magazine as a novelette titled "Tell It to Me Tomorrow," has been bought for filming by Hecht-Lancaster Productions.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Representatives of forty unions in the shipbuilding and engineering industries and on the nationalized railways began today a drive for wage increases for more than 3,000,000 workers.

TOKYO, Aug. 10 -- Premier Ichiro Hatoyama has decided to send the secretary general of his Democratic party to the United States this month to help explain Japan's internal conditions to American leaders.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 9 -- Nicaragua seems to have developed a slight case of nerves in the last few weeks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Representative Celler brought out that the council had a fund to study the antitrust laws. He said that among contributors were officials of big concerns that had been defendants in anti-trust suits.
The cotton futures market was barely steady yesterday and prices eased 3 to 32 points (15 cents to $1.60 a bale). Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active.
Customs collections here last month totaled $27,657,638, a gain of almost $5,000,000 over July, 1954, Frank B. Laughlin, acting Collector of Customs, reported yesterday.
Carmen Basilio, the world welterweight champion, gained the unanimous decision over Italo Scortichini of Fabriano, Italy, in a nontitle ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night.
INCHON, Korea, Aug. 10 -Koreans continued to demonstrate today against the presence of Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission members in South Korea.
Oil paintings can be cleaned at home if care is used, Byron Jorns, artist at the University of Wisconsin, recently told The United Press in Madison.
BOSTON, Aug. 10 -- Boston appealed for more nurses tonight as the Massachusetts polio outbreak reached epidemic proportions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Following is a transcript of part of the record of Secretary of State Dulles' news conference today:
JERUSALEM, Aug. 10 -- The barriers across the Israeli-Arab armistice lines have been raised to permit a two-month exchange of The New York Times correspondents in Egypt and Israel.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Red Cross reported today its most careful preparation for a hurricane in history.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission took steps today to keep the frozen foods industry free of antitrust difficulties.

Mrs. Deborah Landy, an admitted former member of the Communist party whose son is seeking a commission in the Naval Reserve, has been asked by the House un-American Activities Committee to tell an interviewer all she knows about Communist activities.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 10 -- The Constitutional Affairs Committee of Argentina's Chamber of Deputies voted today to postpone for six months a national referendum on the separation of church and state.

SLAKING summer thirst is not entirely a matter of something wet and cool. Finger foods -- what one of our friends calls "go-alongs" -- are necessary, too. They should tempt the eye, complement the drink and, during this most relaxed season of the year, be relatively quick and easy to fix.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- The Governor of South Carolina said today that there was a "definite, strong possibility" of a third-party candidate for President in 1956. He said his state and a number of others in the South might back such a candidate.
ROCHESTER, Minn., Aug. 10 (UP) -- A Mayo Clinic doctor said today it was "unwarranted" to conclude from present statistical studies that smoking caused cancer.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 10 (UP) -- Two American players and two foreign seeded stars were eliminated today in the thirdround singles matches of the seventy-fourth invitation tennis tournament at the Newport Casino.
ASHTABULA, Ohio, Aug. 10 (AP) -- An explosion and fire in near-by Andover killed at least eighteen persons tonight and injured more than fifteen, state highway patrolmen reported.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Kansas City gained an early lead, then staved off rallies by Chicago for a 5-4 victory tonight that knocked the White Sox out of first place in the American League.
CHICAGO Aug. 10 -- Adlai E. Stevenson confirmed tonight that he would announce "no later than the end of November" his decision on whether to seek the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1956.
The United Aircraft Corporation in the first half of this year realized a 15.3 per cent increase in earnings on a 2.6 per cent gain in sales over the corresponding period a year ago.
Proposed pay rises for city employes not covered by the career and salary plan for civil service workers were considered yesterday at an executive meeting of the Board of Estimate.
ALBANY, Aug. 10 -- Motor vehicle deaths in New York State for the first five months of 1955 are running behind the same period last year.

Americans drank a million and a quarter fewer barrels of beer last year than they did the year before. But more Americans drank the smaller amount. This apparent paradox was revealed yesterday in the 1955 Almanac of the United States Brewers Foundation.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -United States golf pros swept six of eight matches from their foreign colleagues today to win the two-day international team matches 8 1/2 to 3 1/2.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Allen Co. and Salomon Bros. Hutzler is offering today $15,000,000 of new 4 1/2 per cent subordinated debentures of Foremost Dairies, Inc., to holders of the company's $4.50 dividend preferred stock and two series of $50 par value 4 1/2 per cent preferred stock.

It's no mere coincidence that the Red Sox began their spectacular surge toward the top of the American League standing on June 5. It was on that date that Manager Mike Higgins installed Billy Klaus as his regular shortstop.
Four Medal of Honor winners and ten generals took part yesterday in a review celebrating the First Army's thirty-seventh anniversary at Governors Island.

Africa's past and present are the subjects of two books to be published in American editions at the end of this month. Both were originally published in Britain. On Aug. 29, Praeger will issue "African Glory: The Story of Vanishing Negro Civilizations," by J. C. deGraft-Johnson, an economist and teacher on the staff of the University College, Gold Coast.

Electric Bond and Share Company's assets on June 30 reached $123,321,621, equal to $31.06 a share, according to the June quarter report mailed yesterday to stockholders. This represented an increase of $18,852,000 over the $105,600,794, or $27.47 a share, reported a year ago.

A 25-year-old truck driver argued in Supreme Court here yesterday that he had been denied an appointment to the Police Department because his father signed a "purported Communist petition" sixteen years ago.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 10 (UP) -- Colombian Finance Minister Carlos Villaveces said today that Brazil and Colombia are "marching together" in their coffee policies and predicted stability in the market for the next two years.

The First Army, for many years New York's good neighbor, celebrated its thirty-seventh birthday yesterday on Governors Island. Its life -- as military units go -- has been brief (the First Army was organized in the First World War), but its honors have been many, and deserved.
A Navy bomber flew into the eye of Connie on Monday morning and again on Tuesday night. It spent about eight hours each time in the storm area to see what was going on.

FRANK G. SLAUGHTER, the Florida doctor turned novelist, is something of a phenomenon on the American writing scene. Since his "In a Dark Garden" hit the best-seller lists back in 1946 there may have been a few publishing seasons when one of his books was not among the nation's top sellers -- but not many.
TWO brothers made a serious study of snug skirts and decided somebody should design skirts that allowed for certain -- ah -- figure faults common in women.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 10 -- With a decisive victory over James Bolton of New Haven, Conn., in the second round last night, Samuel Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., gained his second point in the annual open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Municipal Recreation Center Building.
BOGOTA, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Press censorship has been extended throughout Colombia. It covers all messages sent abroad as well as domestic publications.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- A House of Representatives subcommittee asked Government departments and agencies today whether they were withholding information as to their activities that the public had the right to know about.
KUIBYSHEV, U. S. S. R., Aug. 10Corn is king in the Volga Valley -- by order of Moscow. However, its reign may be short and turbulent.

GENEVA, Aug. 10 -- Canada is building what is said to be the most advanced atomic research reactor in the Western world. She is attempting to step up her total electrical generating capacity by atomic means.

CHICAGO, Aug., 10 -- The Texas pair, Ben Fain of Houston, and Paul H. Hodge of Abilene won a large trophy here this afternoon. They came from far behind to capture the Life Masters' Pairs Championship, most important pair event of the twenty-seventh annual National Contract Bridge championships.

Individual enterprise reared its head on two key plays at the Stadium yesterday. Jim Piersall of the Red Sox, in the second inning, and Gil McDougald of the Yankees, in the third, both were bunting on their own, it developed after the game.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -Twenty-seven figures in the entertainment field have been called to appear next week before a House Un-American Activities Subcommittee in New York.

MANCHESTER, England, Aug. 10 (UP) -- Tom Courtney of Fordham University easily won the half-mile run tonight at the Manchester police sports meet, but a stiff cross wind prevented any chance of his beating the British all-comers record.

The appeal of the Inter-American Press Association to the press and radio of the Western Hemisphere to condemn the recent actions of President Rojas Pinilla of Colombia deserves the fullest support. It would also be salutary if the United States State Department, Congress and other Government organs here took notice of what is happening in Colombia.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (UP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs slammed out twenty-six hits -- five by Ted Kluszewski -- today in sweeping a doubleheader from the Chicago Cubs,7 -- 2 and 6 -- 3. They climbed within a game and a half of the fifth-place Cubs.
GENEVA, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Two Soviet scientists today made a detailed report on the medical treatment given two Russians now said to be completely recovered from acute atomic radiation.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 -- An extensive offshore oil drilling operation of five square miles of submerged tidelands fifty miles southeast of Los Angeles was indicated today with the acceptance of bids from major oil companies by the state's Lands Commission.

HONOLULU, Aug. 10 (UP) -- Eleven American airmen returned to American soil today for the first time since their release from a Communist Chinese prison. They were still badly shaken by thirty-two months of torture and privation.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., Aug. 10 -- A handy haven for youngsters while their parents shop has been set up here in a recently refurbished residence. Just one block from the business center, it is called Lollipop House.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- It took racing luck, as well as racing ability, for the Rokeby Stables' Blue Banner to win the $18,250 Test Stakes at the Saratoga track today.
Two Queens real estate holding corporations and four individuals were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on charges of fraudulently obtaining bank loans.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- American Federation of Labor leaders frowned today on one aspect of the new "friendliness" between the United States and Russia.

Boatmen in Long Island waters were busy yesterday checking mooring and docking gear against the possible onslaught of Connie. They were mindful of the expensive damage wrought a year ago by the three weird sisters, Carol, Edna and Hazel.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner's home run with the bases filled and none out in the ninth inning tonight gave the Cleveland Indians a 6-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers. Kiner connected after Hoot Evers and Hank Foiles delivered pinch singles and Al Smith beat out a bunt.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 10 -- Premier Pibul Songgram is depriving his ministers of authority and preparing the nation for his new conception of democracy.
It is a serious question whether the city's parking-fine policy is designed to alleviate traffic and parking problems, or to serve as a source of municipal revenue.
GENEVA, Aug. 10 -- Industrially underdeveloped countries evinced keen interest today in the immediate prospects of nuclear power.

The forty-four former residents of San Marino who left Detroit on Tuesday to vote in their native land, the ancient republic in the Italian Appennine Mountains, were joined yesterday by twenty-seven others. The seventy-one left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, by chartered plane for San Marino.
Hurricane Connie, a powerful threat to the Eastern Seaboard, hung "nearly stationary" early this morning 200 miles off the South Carolina coast.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 -Vice President Richard M. Nixon spent the first day of his vacation today by participating in flag raising ceremonies at the new Beverly Hilton Hotel and playing golf at the Los Angeles Country Club.
HONG KONG, Aug. 10 -- Arnold M. Kiehn was released from hospital and police custody today on the sixth day of his fast in protest against the Hong Kong Government's move to deport him.
Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories Inc., is planning a revision of its corporate structure. A major purpose is to separate broadcasting from electronic research, development and manufacturing.

Coffee, rubber and wool futures contracts were major performers yesterday in an otherwise quiet commodity market. Coffee continued to decline, rubber developed an easier tone, and wool advanced sharply.

The charges of "unfair" proxy solicitation hurled by the Securities and Exchange Commission last week against a dissident group of stockholders of Libby, McNeill Libby were received yesterday in Federal Court here.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Swimmers and divers from Germany and the Netherlands won twice each today in the International University Games. Britain, Brazil and Austria supplied one victor apiece.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development yesterday made a loan of $12,000,000 in various currencies to the State Railway of Thailand. A loan of $3,000,000 for a similar purpose was made by the World Bank in 1950.
Production of steel in July and in the first seven months this year was the second highest for these periods on record.

After an emergency meeting with the Borough Presidents and heads of city departments yesterday, Mayor Wagner issued the following rules to reduce personal injury and property damage it case the hurricane strikes the city:

The small boy who went to Newberg, Ore., seventy years ago, an orphan, to live in the home of his uncle and aunt, Dr. and Mrs. Henry John Minthorn, went back yesterday. He went, on his eighty-first birthday, as the guest of the Governor and Legislature of Oregon.

William J. Hallahan, former chief clerk of the House Banking and Currency Committee, was sworn in yesterday for a four-year term as a member of the Home Loan Bank Board, it was announced by Walter W. McAllister, chairman. Mr. Hallahan was recently appointed to the board by the President.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UP) -- Thousands of white collars have wilted this summer in Washington offices. Today, the Government tentatively agreed to let Federal employes air-condition their offices at their own expense.

Plans have been made at recent meetings for the performance of "Reuben, Reuben," a new musical comedy, on the night of Nov. 10 at the ANTA Theatre for the benefit of the New York City Mission Society.
The amateur decorator can learn some lessons from the newly refurbished rooms at Bloomingdale's.

POINT JUDITH, R. I., Aug. 10 -- Fate, in the form of Hurricane Connie, overtook the United States Atlantic tuna tournament for the second year in succession. This time advance warning made it possible for the seventy-five fishing craft to prepare for the blow.

An appeal from the decision of the Production Code Administration denying the code seal of approval to the film "I Am a Camera" will be heard by Eric Johnston and the board of directors of the Motion Picture Association of America on Monday.

The Harlem club building at 2056 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of 127th Street, which was bought recently by the Trans-New York Corporation, realty operators, from the Finish Workers Educational Association, has been resold to Gospel Temple Church of God in Christ. It contains offices, an auditorium with 700 seats and a cafeteria.
Merchant shipbuilding in the twenty-one principal maritime nations of the world is more than 10 per cent above the level last year at this time.

It is axiomatic that the unity of the West and an adequate defense against the ever-present threat of the Communist East are impossible if France and Germany do not get along. To forge that link of tolerance and partnership has proved one of the most delicate and complex tasks for European statesmanship since the war ended.
