LONDON, Aug. 10 -- An 18-year-old sailor drew a twelve-month sentence today for having thrown his cap at his commanding officer in a fit of desperation over the seeming hopelessness of his case.

Mayor Wagner met in emergency session yesterday afternoon with borough presidents and heads of city departments to plan for battening down the city should the hurricane now dawdling off the Carolina coast veer this way.
MANILA, Thursday, Aug. 11 -- President Ramon Magsaysay is winning his battle for unchallenged political leadership of the Philippines.

BELGAUM, India, Aug. 10 -- Indian politicians said here today that 3,000 Indian volunteers would march across the borders of Portuguese Goa Monday despite Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's opposition to a mass "peaceful invasion."

Food retailers have increased their share of sales of popular health and beauty products from 30 per cent in 1952 to nearly 50 per cent at present, Robert W. Mueller, editor of Progressive Grocer, told the New York Merchandising Executives Club yesterday at a luncheon at Shor's Restaurant.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -President Eisenhower is proving that the Presidency can be a commuter's job.
Deliveries of magazines, paper-backed books and stationery within a radius of fifty miles of New York were halted yesterday by a strike.
Plans for a public school on Convent Avenue and for an apartment house on First Avenue were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Government moved today to make a smaller atomic submarine.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 (UP) -- The Australian and Italian Davis Cup tennis teams ripped into the final practice sessions today after meeting socially in a tour of the city and a noon luncheon.

A battle for a merger of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company into the Washington Water Power Company came to a halt yesterday. A shareholders' poll was canceled by a group identified as the Stockholders Committee for Puget Sound Power and Light Company.
Exercising extraordinary patience, Casey Stengel's Yankees stalked the Red Sox for close to three and a half hours at the Stadium yesterday.

I read with great interest your editorial of Aug. 1 "Soviet-American Exchange." In it you say that "the chief obstacle to personal observation of the Soviet Union these last ten years has been and is the Soviet Government. Refusal to grant visas has been and is one of the chief aspects of the Iron Curtain."
After six months of negotiation with the estate of Bernard Shaw, Roger Stevens and Robert L. Joseph have bought the exclusive English-speaking rights to "Major Barbara."
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Sir Leonard Lord, head of the British Motor Corporation, denied today reports that the Austin Motor Company was disbanding its sales and service organization in the United States.

The Retor Building Corporation, headed by Harry Horowitz, obtained a first mortgage of $850,000 at 4 1/2 per cent for ten years from the East New York Savings Bank on the new twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 4 East Eighty-ninth Street. The loan was arranged by the Sonnenblick - Goldman Corporation, brokers, and replaces a building loan obtained two years ago through the same brokers.
GENEVA, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Russians are taking a public opinion poll on their exhibit at the Geneva atoms-for-peace conference.
Chemicals, coppers, aircrafts, rubbers and some of the oils found the strength yesterday to resist the downtrend and the stock market closed with moderate gains.
Despite the refusal of the Transport Workers Union to accept a 5.3-cents-an-hour wage rise, a member of the Transit Authority described labor unions yesterday as "part of the family."

DETROIT, Aug. 10 (UP) -- Despite all the talk about "crazy credit" in the booming auto market, Americans are making just as big down payments as they've done in the past ten years, a study of new car financing indicated today.
BLOOMFIELD, Conn., Aug. 10 -- Insurance companies are sticklers for eliminating as much guesswork as possible. The Connecticut General Life Insurance Company is no exception.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 10 (Reuters) -- Britain's 17-day rail strike in June enabled West Germany to overtake the United Kingdom in steel output during the second quarter of 1955, according to estimates published here today.
The prosecution of Sgt. James C. Gallagher, accused of collaboration with the enemy and murder of three fellow prisoners in Korea, neared an end yesterday.
NEWBERG, Ore., Aug. 10 -Following is the text of an address here today by former President Herbert Hoover on his eighty-first birthday anniversary:
The new threat of a milk strike, like the threat of a visit from Connie the Hurricane, was postponed last night.
MOSCOW, Aug. 10 -- Soviet cultural leaders have begun to publish lists of Western singers, actors and artists they would like to see in this country.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Chaudry Mohammed Ali, the Moslem League party's new head, was picked today to end Pakistan's political crisis and form a government.

Several members of the Board of Estimate the other day seemed to have their doubts about the desirability of combining the Police Academy with facilities of the City College Baruch School of Business and Public Administration in a new building in the block bounded by Lexington and Third Avenues and Twenty-second and Twenty-third Streets.

Members of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, A. F. L., have authorized their local boards to take disciplinary action against a member who refuses to tell a Congressional committee whether he is or was a member of the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Beard reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 3:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Secretary of State Dulles expressed hope today that progress toward the release of Americans held in Red China would result from a clarification tomorrow of the Communist Chinese position in the Geneva talks.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 10 -- "Some progress" has been made toward settling the television film strike, a spokesman for the Screen Actors Guild reported tonight. His statement came at the conclusion of the second successive negotiating session between the union and representatives of TV entertainment film producers.

LARCHMONT, N. Y, Aug. 10 -- Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich and Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchetser Country Club reached the final round of the thirtieth annual Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's championship today.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 10 -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem rejected today an offer from Communist North Vietnam to discuss general elections to reunite the country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UP) -- Chairmen of the Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives and the Senate said today they would consult their members about the Defense Department's plan to shut fourteen commercial-type military activities.
A 2 - year - old boy was killed yesterday when he fell out of an automobile traveling at about thirty miles an hour along the Grand Central Parkway, Queens.

Net income of the C. I. T. Financial Corporation increased to a record total of $18,383,166 in the first six months this year from $17,649,278 a year earlier, according to the report yesterday of Arthur O. Dietz, president.

The New York City Transit Authority is peopled with new faces, but on the other side of the bargaining table Michael J. Quill, the president of the Transport Workers Union, seems little changed by time. Negotiations with the new authority have hardly begun, but they are already "deadlocked," according to Mr. Quill, and he has ominously summoned the executive board of Local 100 to a meeting for a "full report."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -Secretary of State Dulles appealed anew to the world today to avoid force in solving its problems.

Last night at Ebbets Field the Dodgers made it two straight over the Giants in a game curtailed to six innings by rain. The score was 5 -- 4 when time was called at 10:19 after two Giants had gone out in the top of the seventh.

A decline of 529,000 barrels in the Nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 156,476,000 barrels, compared with 157,005,000 a week earlier and 156,808,000, a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -American farmers will produce the largest combined volume of crop and livestock products in history this year if present favorable prospects continue.

WHEN Cornell won all three races in the championships of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association on Onondaga Lake, Syracuse, the press reported it as the first sweep ever scored in the regatta by the Big Red crews.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Eisenhower today grudgingly signed a bill aimed at ending what Democrats have called "one man rule" of the Atomic Energy Commission.

AN even coat of nail polish can't be applied at an odd momoment. It takes about an hour to give an impeccable manicure at home. Polish applied on thoroughly prepared nails should stay on for ten days, according to Revlon Products, which offers a nail-grooming regime that requires a bit of patience but offers professional results.

STATE fairs usually are devoted to the interests of rural folk, with the city stickers feeling out of place among the prize bulls and handicraft exhibits of the Four-H clubs. But this year New York State is paying tribute to those who use what the farmer produces.
BOSTON, Aug. 10 -- Forty-three construction workers were evacuated by the Coast Guard today from a radar island being installed in the Atlantic 110 miles off Cape Cod.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Export-Import Bank announced today the authorization of four credit lines to assist United States exporters in financing the sale abroad of productive capital equipment and related services, they are:
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

A new industrial building occupying a blockfront on Thirty-sixth Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by the Publishers Printing Company, Inc., which will move from 207 West Twenty-fifth Street. The company, founded in 1887, prints well-known periodicals and publications.

Three of the four directors of the corporations that own the Vanderveer Estates apartment development in Brooklyn were ousted yesterday. Their places were then assigned to three officials of the Federal Housing Administration, which holds all the preferred stock in the corporations.
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 10 -- Tanglewood is full of musicians, and tonight's chamber-music program proved that enough talent could be assembled in a short time to make an unusual evening of Beethoven.
Sale and earnings of the B. F. Goodrich Company in the first six months this year set new records for any half-year period in the company's history.

The Pennsylvania Railroad sought yesterday to transfer its inbound freight service from its Desbrosses Street station to its facilities at Piers 49 and 50 at West Twelfth Street, in order to increase the capacity for handling such freight in this area.

"I ALWAYS thought winners of recipe contests were housewives from the Middle West who entered an old family recipe," Miss Rosemary Rothschild said yesterday. This New York career girl, who cooks because she finds it relaxing, is the recent winner of $3,000 in a national recipe contest sponsored by the H. J. Heinz Company.
The prediction was made yesterday that sales of dietetic food to weight-conscious Americans would total $100,000,000 this year and double that figure in another two years.
Dividend payments on stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange broke three records in the first half of 1955.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 10 -- Members of the Russian agricultural delegation in the Midwest split into small groups again today. They are attempting to keep pace with a crowded schedule.
The Cinerama Productions Corporation has "reactivated" a production unit under the direction of Theodore R. Kupferman, vice president, to plan for future films in the Cinerama process.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday that it had solved the $312,219 robbery of the Woodside, Queens, branch of the Chase-Manhattan Bank. This was probably the biggest cash bank robbery in the country.

Under the caption "Landlords Blamed for Crowding" you recently published a letter by J. Clark presenting rather a one-sided analysis of housing abuses. It is well for the public to realize that a prime contributor to the unhappy rental situation in our city is, in many instances, the tenant himself.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 10 -- Police and Army units dispersed a demonstration here today in favor of freedom of the press.
In the American Museum of Natural History a scientist has been reconstructing the work of ancient weavers of Central Asia without a vestige of fabric as a clue.

GENEVA, Aug. 10 -- Development of a British experimental nuclear reactor that produces twice as much atomic fuel as it consumes was announced today. The disclosure was made at the United-Nations-sponsored International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy.

On one and the same day last week President Eisenhower urged that water resource problems be attacked "intelligently on a broad base" and the Federal Power Commission made public its decision to grant a license for private instead of Federal development of one of the greatest power sites in the nation.
Fifteen hundred persons in Carnegie Hall last night cheered a series of speakers who urged an end to atomic bombing and to war itself.
A NEW ease-of-care fiber from the Celanese Corporation of America, named Arnel, will appear this fall in men's, women's and children's clothes.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- It is understood here that divergent views have been revealed in preliminary studies by Western military authorities of the proposal of Prime Minister Eden for a demilitarized zone between Western and Soviet forces in Europe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The White House announced today the resignation of Edward F. Howrey as chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Atlantic Refining Company today reported net income of $18,902,904, equal to $2.03 a share of common stock, for the first six months of this year. This compared with $19,837,116 and $2.14 a share for the first six months of last year.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 8 -- The trial of Leon Jungschlager, a Dutch citizen, on charges of aiding a rebellion in Indonesia has become an international issue.
I read with interest your editorial in regard to the failure of the Congress to pass a highway program during the past session.
NEWBERG, Ore., Aug. 10 -Herbert Hoover today acclaimed the nation's ideals of freedom and religious faith as guarantees against any decline and fall of American civilization.

Last week's heat wave helped push electric power production to a new high of 10,925,000,000 kilowatt-hours. The figure for the preceding week was 10,727,000,000 and for the week ended Aug. 7, 1954, it was 9,059,000,000. Percentages compared with the like weeks of 1954 were:
The Weather Bureau pointed out yesterday that the wind during a hurricane might come from any direction.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Miss Mary Donlon of upstate New York was made a judge of the United States Customs Court in a folksy ceremony today.

The City of New York reported yesterday that it was planning a "revolutionary" $15,000,000 marine terminal on Manhattan's West Side for use by the Holland-America Line. It would be the costliest single pier ever built in the Port of New York.
The announcement from London that a group of scientists have agreed on the need for a universal study of ghosts and things ghostly is probably being met with mixed feelings in the world of letters.
GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Governor Harriman was described in his home county tonight by Speaker Oswald D. Heck of the State Assembly as having more interest in the Presidency than in the Governship.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- America's Governors agreed today that Congress should enact a national highway program at the earliest possible moment, perhaps at a special session.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Industrial shares extended their rally today with the start of a new stock exchange bookkeeping account despite the reaction on Wall Street. Government stocks lost part of Tuesday's gains and fell as much as 7s 6d ($1.05).
DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Ukrainian Nationalist organizations held a demonstration tonight around the Statler Hotel, where Vladimir Matskevich, Soviet farm chief, is staying.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- A threatened action for contempt of Congress failed today to budge the Department of Commerce in its refusal to produce files of its Business Advisory Council. The council of 165 top business executives advises the Secretary of Commerce. It was represented by Walter White, $25,000-ayear executive director.

New York City has borrowed $35,000,000 from banks on short-term notes in anticipation of the collection of taxes, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday. The borrowing was made at 1 1/2 per cent. Of the total, $20,000,000 will come due on Oct. 31 and $15,000,000 on Nov 1. The notes are callable on or after Oct. 21.

Wage rises averaging 5 cents an hour for 35,000 to 40,000 production workers in the southern mills of Burlington Industries were announced yesterday. J. C. Cowan Jr., vice chairman of the corporation, said the increases would take effect Aug. 22.

NEWARK, Aug. 10 -- A twenty-one-ton steel section was hoisted 240 feet above Newark Bay and set into place today. It was the final link of the bridge that, as part of the New Jersey Turnpike, will provide a short-cut to Manhattan.
COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Magnus Konow of Oyster Bay, L. I., sailed his yacht Llanoria into first place today to give the United States team a 2-0 lead in the British-American cup series.
Staten Island is the city's borough of paradox.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Secretary of Commerce blamed politics today for recent "massive attacks" upon business men in Government.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- James Eilbeck, formerly an executive of The Daily Mirror newspaper group, said today he would publish a new London afternoon paper, The Sun, next spring. It will be tabloid size and politically independent, he said.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 11 -- A coalition Cabinet under Prime Minister Chaudry Mohammed Ali took office today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 765,452 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 30,319 cars, or 3.8 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 97,860 cars, or 14.7 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 19,897 cars, or 2.5 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The Creole Petroleum Corporation, the leading oil producer in Venezuela, achieved for the first half year of 1955 the highest earnings in its history, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The general manager of the American Public Power Association told a Congressional group today that he believed some Eisenhower Administration policies "definitely encourage" a trend toward a private power monopoly.

An investing client of Alexander Schiffer, broker, has purchased the two apartment houses at 515-17 East 156th Street, the Bronx, from Charles Gessel, who had owned them twenty-seven years. The buildings contain fifty-six apartments and five stores. The Schiffer concern, Gilbert Lewis and Tanzer Associates, Inc., were the brokers in the sale.

SAN MARINO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The anti-Communists charged today that the Reds were going to vote living men twice and dead men once in the election of a new legislature Sunday in San Marino, smallest and oldest republic in the world.
GENEVA, Aug. 11 -- Surface deposits of thorium and uranium ores can be detected hundreds of miles away by the analysis of winds that blow over them, a physicist from India said here today.
GENEVA, Aug. 11 -- Japan has been officially admitted to the group of countries adhering to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). This was announced here today by the GATT secretariat.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UP) -- President Eisenhower returned to the White House today from his Gettysburg, Pa., farm to clean up his desk before taking off for an extended vacation in Colorado.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 -- A "break-through" in secret research has been accomplished and the Air Force expects to ask Congress for a supplemental appropriation of $100,000,000 or more to follow it up.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox, paced by Jim Rivera, broke out of a batting slump with sixteen hits today and a 14-1 victory over Kansas City. Rivera drove in five runs with two triples and a double.
TRIPOLI, Libya, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Premier Mustafa Ben Halim announced today that France was evacuating her 300-man Foreign Legion garrison from the Libyan Province of Fezzan.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 11 -- The sixth day of the strike the the Screen Actors Guild against the television entertainment film producers was marked by the third meeting of negotiators.

PARIS, Aug. 11 -- Sixteen Cabinet ministers spent almost nine hours today discussing the Moroccan problem. They reached agreement on some points but shied away from the major issue, the disputed Moroccan throne.

Pacific Gas and Electric Company reported yesterday operating revenues of $418,302,210 for twelve months ended June 30. This compared with $371,351,055 a year earlier. Net income of $68,655,462 was equal to $3.18 a share and compared with $59,370,170, or $2.84 a share, on fewer shares in the like 1954 period.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 11 -- The Brazilian Communists have formally thrown their support to Juscelino Kubitschek and Joao (Jango) Goulart for President and Vice President in the Oct. 3 elections. These candidates are generally believed to have the best chance of winning.

There may be a few broken hearts, and perhaps some red faces, on Broadway today among personalities in the local entertainment world who have not yet been summoned to appear next week at the United States Courthouse in Foley Square to testify before the House Subcommittee on Un-American Activities.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 10 points up to 6 points off, with only new December showing a decline.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- A code of ethics calling for equal treatment by suppliers for all retailers in the food-distribution industry was announced here today by the Cooperative Food Distributors of America.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 11 -Chile is determined to get at least 40 cents a pound for copper sold to the United States, instead of 36 cents as at present, it was confirmed today in official circles.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 8 -- Both the prosecution and the defense in the trial here of a Dutch citizen, Leon Jungschlager, agree that the principal witnesses against the former sea captain are unreliable.
The pageantry of old Persia found its way to lower Broadway yesterday noon.

When the country's jewelers gather at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Sunday for the annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association they will hear the details of a broad-scale national advertising program designed to help retailers sell more jewelry.

The Consolidated Foods Corporation, a leading canner, processor and distributor of foods, has acquired American Frigid Dough, Inc., in a stock transaction. The announcement was made yesterday by S. M. Kennedy, Consolidated Foods president, and Marvin R. Polkow, president of American Frigid Dough.
POINT JUDITH, R. I., Aug. 11 -- Fear of the gale was subordinated to boredom in this crowded harbor today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Bob Rosburg, Mike Krak and Gene Littler made a shambles of Tam o' Shanter's par 72 with 66's today to share the first-round lead in the "world" golf tournament.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 11 -- More than one third of a $50,000 fund to restore historic Touro Synagogue here has been raised, it was reported today at the eighth annual meeting of the synagogue's Society of Friends.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11 -- The press department of the Foreign Ministry said today a proposal that "Porgy and Bess,' American Negro folk opera, appear in the Soviet Union was under consideration by the Moscow Ministry of Culture.

Mrs. Deborah Landy told a representative of the House Un-American Activities Committee last night that she did not want to discuss her past affiliation with the Communist party until her son's appeal for a Naval Reserve commission was resolved.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 11 -- Nationalist China will ask the United States for $34,000,000 more in economic aid, Martin Wong, secretary general of the council for United States aid, disclosed today. This will be in addition to the $102,000,000 already allocated for the next fiscal year.

An American edition of "Doctor at Dienbienphu," an account of the siege of the Indochinese city, will be published in October by the John Day Company. The author is Paul Grauwin, the French Army major who was chief surgeon in the field hospital throughout the fifty-seven days of the battle. First published in France, it sold more than 50,000 copies there, and will shortly appear in a German edition.
The Bowery Savings Bank has received 4,532 applications for the 211 middle-income apartments it will rent next spring in a new twelve-story structure in West Harlem.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- President Eisenhower signed today the compromise housing bill, although he still had "serious objections" to it.

TOKYO, Aug. 11 -- Japan's leading Communist and two of his lieutenants dramatically emerged tonight from five years in hiding to lead the new Red "peace" line. Two hours after their surprise appearance at a youth rally they were in police custody.
Several floors in the old John Wanamaker warehouse at 426 Lafayette Street, now owned by David Rapoport, have beer. leased through Robert Joseph Co., Inc., brokers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Proposed consolidation of the Brooklyn office of the Veterans Administration with the New York headquarters was protested today by Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn. He urged that the decision be reconsidered.

LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The International Sugar Council today cut by 5 per cent export quotas of sugar producing countries under its jurisdiction. It also redistributed 86,568 metric tons of quotas surrendered to the pool by Czechoslovakia and Haiti.
VIENNA, Aug. 11 -- The Czechoslovak Government has appealed to its people to turn out to save this year's harvest from damaging rains of the last three weeks.

TRENTON, Aug. 11 -- The appointment of Donald A. Quarles to succeed Harold E. Talbott as Secretary of the Air Force came as a surprise to Republican leaders in New Jersey. The Assistant Secretary of Defense long has been a resident of Englewood and active politically in Bergen County.
JACKSONVILLE, N. C., Aug. 11 -- Hurricane Connie battered the coast of the Carolinas today with two powerful, windy arms.
HAVANA, Aug. 11 -- Former President Carlos Prio Socarras unexpectedly returned to Havana from exile today.
Dr. James T. Shotwell, president emeritus of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, returned yesterday from a three-month visit to Europe.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Mrs. William du Pont Jr. of Wilmington, Del., the former Margaret Osborne, will come out of virtual retirement to help defend the Wightman Cup against the British tennis team on Saturday and Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Department of Defense moved today to put the new military Reserves problem into effect at once.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (UP) -- Ernie Banks hit his thirty-ninth home run today to take the major league lead and equal a record. But the Chicago Cubs lost to the Cincinnati Redlegs in eleven innings, 6 -- 5. The victory moved the Redlegs within a half-game of fifth place, now held by the Cubs.

With volume still low and the public apparently on the sidelines, the stock market made large gains yesterday. Coppers, other metals, chemicals, rails, rubbers, oils and steels were strong, although hardly a group advanced with anything like unanimity.
One of the major problems a new manager usually has to solve in a hurry when he takes charge of a baseball club is to get to know and understand his players.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Public Health Service today reported 1,409 polio cases for the week ending Aug. 6, a new high for this year.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Prime Minister Eden will interrupt his holiday to return to London on Monday for a Cabinet meeting. This will be the first meeting of the Cabinet since Parliament adjourned.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Carolyn Green of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., American Olympic swimming star, won the 1,500-meter free-style championship for the fourth straight time despite a bad sinus attack in the opening event tonight of the annual women's national A. A. U. swimming and diving championships.
Representatives of 10,000 dairy farmers in the New York milkshed yesterday asked the Governors of New York and Pennsylvania, along with Mayor Wagner, to intervene in the threatened milk strike.

Directors of Chemical Corn Exchange Bank approved a 10 per cent stock dividend yesterday, subject to approval of stockholders and the New York State Superintendent of Banks. Stockholders will vote on the proposal Sept. 7.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The United States and the Republic of Korea agreed today, after ten weeks of negotiations, on a new rate of exchange between the Korean hwan and the dollar.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 11 (UP) -- Hoot Evers, playing center field in place of the injured Larry Doby, hit a three-run homer in the sixth inning today to give the Cleveland Indians their third straight victory over the Detroit Tigers, 3 -- 1.

HUSBANDS and wives agree less than half the time on what makes a satisfactory home. And the higher the income group, the more expensive the house, and the more extensive the education, the greater are the differences in opinion.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A former captain of the Air Force was arrested today on charges of unlawfully removing a secret document from Air Force files and converting it to his own use.

NEWARK, Aug. 11 -- Industry borrowed a weapon from labor today to fight industry. Five North Jersey building contractors set up a picket line in front of the Newark Center Corporation's market reconstruction job on Mulberry Street.

Ted Williams' first-inning single against the Yankees yesterday wasn't much of a hit. It was a droopy fly into short centerfield that fell just beyond the converging reach of Phil Rizzuto, Mickey Mantle and Elston Howard.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 11 -- "Tanglewood on Parade," the hours-long fiesta wherein the hundreds of musicians at Tanglewood strut their stuff, took place this afternoon and evening with undiminished spirit despite overcast skies, frequent showers and the pother about the wind named Connie.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 5 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
PARIS, Aug. 11 -- The foreign ministers of the Soviet Union and the Big Three will meet in Geneva Oct. 27. They will discuss the problems passed to them by the heads of their governments.

Loans to business for commercial, industrial and agricultural purposes by New York City banks increased $80,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
The National Broadcasting Company will cancel regularly scheduled commercial shows about once a month next season to televise a series of public affairs programs during prime evening hours.

Richard Ernst's letter to The Times which was printed in your Aug. 2 edition not only contains erroneous interpretation of fact but also neglects to tell your readers of his partisan interest in the case about which he writes. He is the principal employer attorney in the California Conformity Hearing, and part of the 2,984 pages of transcript of which he speaks is made up of his arguments, his exhibits and his briefs.
GENEVA, Aug. 11 -- The ambassadors of the United States and Communist China met here again today without moving off dead center on the return of civilians to their respective countries.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 11 -- Australia wants to know how the improved relations between the Soviet Union and the West are affecting the Pacific area. The Government is asking the ANZUS Council to meet soon to review the situation.

Holders of the tightly secured first batch of bonds sold to finance the Connecticut Turnpike (Greenwich - Killingly Expressway) are being asked to approve the issuance of further series of expressway bonds secured by only a subordinate claim to the state motor fuel tax fund.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Chattanooga Times said today that Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, "is planning to move within three months to project Senator Estes Kefauver into Ohio's 1956 Presidential primary."

There is a very real danger that the American people will be hoodwinked by the recent moves of the Communist Government now in control of the China mainland. Ambassador Wellington Koo of the recognized Government of China was right the other day when he said the release of the four fliers was like a highwayman giving up some of his spoils.

Net assets of Affiliated Fund, Inc., reached a new high of $337,976,230, equal to $6.18 a share, on July 31, according to the quarterly report released yesterday. This compared with $266,054,922, or $5.20 a share, on Oct. 31, 1954, end of the last fiscal year.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 11--Two United States Air Force Flying Boxcars carrying sixty-six men collided in midair today and crashed in flames thirty miles west of Stuttgart. There were no survivors.

SAUNDERSTOWN, R. I., Aug. 11 -- The whirlwind known as Connie that is coming up from the South may pass off to sea without doing violence to this pleasant lee shore of Narragansett Bay. But the gale known as Happy Chandler which struck the entrenchments of the Kentucky Democratic organization this week will leave its imprint on the entire political community of the nation.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11 -- Visas for several United States news correspondents to enter the Soviet Union apparently are being held up until Washington acts on the applications of the six Soviet correspondents.

The City Planning Commission has been asked by thirty city departments and agencies for 1956 capital budget allocations amounting to $1,122,471,942. John J. Bennett, chairman of the commission, said it was the largest request ever received by that body, exceeding the 1955 total by nearly $14,000,000.

Confronted with the danger of new flare-ups in the Far East, Secretary Dulles has solemnly and forcefully reiterated his "no force" doctrine as the basis of American policy, with emphasis on two specific points. One is that the United States proposes to apply this doctrine on a world-wide scale and to all situations, not just to the Formosa Strait issue, which first gave rise to it.

Motorists traveling in the New York-New Jersey area this week-end may expect detours or delays, because of new construction, repairs or congestion, on the following routes (the numbers correspond to those on the maps):
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- The United Nations Security Council unanimously adopted today its annual report to the General Assembly.

A suit to force the Good Humor Corporation to reduce the price of its orange drinks from 15 to 10 cents at Coney Island and the Rockaways was lost yesterday. Justice Owen McGivern in Supreme Court dismissed without comment the action brought by Morton Birnbaum, an attorney.
A restudy of the signal light pattern on the Eleventh-West End Avenue thoroughfare has been ordered by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.

Your editorial on "Summer in the Parks" was read with interest. As one of the thousands who use the tennis courts in Central Park I would like to call attention to their sad condition. They contain many depressions, ridges, stones and pebbles which not only make good play impossible but are a hazard to life and limb.

BANFF, Alta., Aug. 11 (AP)--A Coroner's jury tonight found that the camp leadership and equipment were "inadequate" for the July 11 climb of 11,636-foot Mount Temple, near Banff, during which seven United States youths died in an avalanche.
The defense of Sgt. James C. Gallagher began yesterday with a demand for segregation of a key prosecution witness during the court-martial.
There may have been some doubt yesterday afternoon as to where Connie the hurricane was heading. But the wind certainly shifted for the Yankees.

STUTTGART, Germany, Aug. 11 (Reuters) -- Eyewitnesses said the two troop carriers that crashed were flying in a tight formation with a third plane over the villages of Pfalz-Grafenweiler and Woernersberg when the C-119 on the right rammed the one in the center.

OXFORD, Ohio, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Joe Fries of Los Angeles, today won the men's target title at the National Archery Association championships. Mrs. Ann Clark of Cincinnati, competing in her first national tournament, captured the women's crown.
ALBANY, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The State Controller, Arthur Levitt, appointed today an eight-member committee to map plans for training selected state employes for top-level administrative posts.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The report of the Department of Agriculture on today's livestock markets follows:
The constitutionality of the city's toy pistol law is being challenged.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The National Red Cross reported more than seventy shelters ready today to receive all who might have to flee their homes because of Hurricane Connie.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Governors begged each other today to "stop raiding across state lines" for trained psychiatric workers.

LENOX, Mass., Aug., 11--Only a banker, or the Internal Revenue collector, would sing about the income tax. At Tanglewood tonight a retired banker, Avery Claflin of Brooklyn, contributed a madrigal, "Lament for April 15."
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 11 -- A renewed investigation into the comic book industry by the Senate subcommittee on juvenile delinquency was promised today by Senator Estes Kefauver the panel's chairman.
Anxious preparations here against Hurricane Connie turned out yesterday to have been just a drill, as the tempest headed inland 500 miles below New York.

By the beginning of 1955 most of those who had been highly critical of the Administration's recovery program in its early stages had become decidedly less vocal. But while they were agreed that the rebound in production had been surprisingly vigorous, they pointed out that this achievement had not been confirmed by the record on employment.

JAMES D. NORRIS was at his Mattituck (L. I.) home battening the hatches against the approaching hurricane. When that job was done he hurried to New Suffolk where his boat was moored and tied her securely in a place where she could swing with the wind and stay topside up. Now he was ready to talk about the Sept. 20 fight between the champion, Rocky Marciano, and Archie Moore for the world heavyweight title.
The clock is close to striking midnight in Morocco. Something has to be done quickly, and it is alarming to see the French Cabinet quarreling over what to do.
Longshore union officials hailed yesterday the announcement of the city's plans for a new $15,000,000 terminal on the Hudson River in Manhattan for the Holland-America Line.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 11 -- Dr. Franz Bluecher, West German Vice Chancellor, hinted today that the Western Allies should revise the Paris agreements if necessary to induce the Soviet Government to consent to the reunification of Germany.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- The Coast Guard has notified the Chicago District Waterways Association that it is up to barge operators to keep the Illinois waterway open this winter.
Col. John Knox Arnold Jr. and ten other United States fliers who were imprisoned and tortured by the Chinese Communists returned to United States territory Wednesday.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 -- David Levinson, a Philadelphia attorney, won his three-year battle today to keep Edward Brown from going back to a Georgia chain gang.
German automotive manufacturers are easing American motor vehicles out of the Indonesian market through the lure of long credits.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 11 -- Russia's visiting agricultural officials said good-by to the upper Midwest today after more than three weeks of touring this region.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Bearish August crop estimates issued by the Government after the close yesterday caused big declines early today in soybeans and corn futures, and lesser setbacks in wheat, rye and oats. But wheat and rye quickly rallied and closed higher for the day, and soybeans steadied.

ELLENVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- The Empire State Music Festival presented its second operatic production here tonight. It was Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" and again Basil Langton was the stage director.
CENTERPORT, L. I., Aug. 11 Philip Marriner's Soiree took today's race in the First District Atlantic Coast Star Class championships in Huntington Bay.
The frozen seafood industry has acquired an organization that would be novel in any trade to promote its products under a famous brand name.
GROEMBACH, Germany, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Only eight bodies had been recovered tonight from the collision-crash of the Flying Boxcars. The eight were burned beyond recognition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -The Government today set Oct. 7 as the deadline for bids on the synthetic rubber plant at Institute, W. Va., one of the biggest of the rubber plants built for the Government during World War II.

ALBANY, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission barred about 400 trucking companies today from increasing by 10 per cent their rates on shipments between New York City and most of the rest of the state.

BALBOA, C. Z., Aug. 11 -- Total cargo shipped through the Panama Canal during the fiscal year 1955 ended June 30 exceeded by more than one and a half million tons the previous record set the preceding year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A special review and evaluation of all medical research programs of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare was begun today.
Your report of the young matron appointed as a cantor contains several statements which are an affront to traditionally oriented Jews, as well as an affront to the truth.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Robert Wolfe, vice president and general manager of The Dayton Daily News, announced tonight that his paper and The Dayton Journal Herald had reached an agreement with the striking stereotypers union.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11--Labor unity is a foregone conclusion, but many of the old-line union leaders are privately expressing misgivings.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- President Eisenhower today appointed Donald A. Quarles, the Assistant Secretary of Defense, as Secretary of the Air Force.

Winding up forty-two years of seafaring with the Holland-America Line, Capt. Johannes B. van Gaart will sail his last command -- the Maasdam -- out of New York tomorrow. He has reached the mandatory retirement age of 60.
The Transit Authority has run into strong union opposition to a plan to curtail Brooklyn bus service at a saving of $1,000,000 a year.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Figures released by the Board of Trade today showed that British imports had continued to rise at a faster rate than exports last month.
The largest turnout so far this week was recorded yesterday when 760 city children received second shots of Salk anti-polio vaccine.
GENEVA, Aug. 11 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission has been working for a considerable time on a program to tame the vast power released by a hydrogen bomb and put it to peaceful work.

Ernest Luthi, owner of the Esplanade Restaurant at Lexington Avenue and Seventy-second Street, has purchased the building on a lot 20 by 85 feet at 969 Lexington Avenue, near Seventieth Street, and will move into two floors there.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 11 -- Philip Clarke, 22-year-old Dublin civil servant, emerged from prison here today to make his protest against legal moves to deprive him of his position as a Sinn Fein member of Parliament for Fermanagh-South Tyrone.
DETROIT, Aug. 11--Three members of the touring Soviet agricultural delegation turned from farms to industry today.
A court test of the jurisdiction of the New York State Athletic Commission was promised yesterday when Chairman Julius Helfand revoked the boxing manager's license of Charlie Bauer.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Industrial shares fell sharply late today and either closed lower or with curtailed gains on news that the Cabinet would meet on Monday. Although the meeting had been arranged before Parliament recessed, the idea got about that it had been called to consider the economic situation.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -Pure Oil Company said today that its net income in the first half of 1955 increased to $16,081,000, or $1.83 a share, from $15,016,000, or $1.59 a share a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -Prosperity in the United States is continuing to boom above-levels never touched before in its history, Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, said today.

Both lanes of the Brooklyn-bound roadway on the upper deck of Manhattan Bridge will be closed from 8:15 A. M. to 4:15 P. M. Monday through Friday starting next week. The shutdown will be in effect for three months while bridge cable bands and hangars are repaired.
INCHON, Korea, Aug. 11 -- With only minor exceptions, the thousands who had milled in the hot sun around compounds housing the Polish and Czech neutral inspection teams made no hostile moves today.

Rockefeller Foundation grants during the second quarter of 1955 totaled $5,686,004, it was announced yesterday. During the same period the foundation also awarded sixty-six fellowships to individuals from twenty-four countries.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- In spite of cautions from the State Department the Department of Agriculture is starting a worldwide drive to sell stored surplus farm products.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Gov. Allan Shivers of Texas aimed a new attack at Adlai E. Stevenson today. He said the former Illinois Governor lacked any qualifications for President. The tone of the Texas Democrat's criticism reflected a growing conviction at the forty-seventh annual Governors conference that Mr. Stevenson now had an almost insurmountable lead for next year's Democratic nomination for the President.
An airplane built to penetrate the 2,000-mile-plus speed range will soon be tested.
A homemade time bomb was found inside a Roxy Theatre seat yesterday afternoon. It was discovered by an upholsterer who had taken the seat to his workroom to repair a slash in the red cloth covering.

For years Dr. Melvin Calvin and his associates of the University of California have been trying to clarify the mystery of the green leaf. From Geneva yesterday came reports of Russian scientists working in this same field.

ACCORDING to a Smith girl who's real George (hep, in old-fashioned terms), last year's best-dressed-girl-on-campus wore charcoal flannel Bermuda shorts, a neat, well -tailored shirt, knee socks and polished loafers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UP) -- Dr. Frank S. Horne, dismissed recently as adviser to the Housing Administrator, Albert M. Cole, was offered another job by the agency today at his old salary of $12,690 a year.
Three teen-age boys. charged with the brutal beating of a partly blind war veteran, were held yesterday in bail of $500 each at a hearing at the victim's hospital bedside.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UP) -- A Washington inventor announced today he had devised a magnetic lamp to replace the screw thread light bulb introduced by Thomas A. Edison more than fifty years ago.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Aug. 12 -- Neutral truce teams defied today a South Korean order to leave the country by Saturday midnight. United States soldiers were reported setting up heavy machine guns to protect them at one point.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 -- Lewis Hoad was restored to favor today on the Australian Davis Cup team for the interzone final with Italy.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Herbie Flam of Beverly Hills, Calif., ranked among the United States top ten before Navy service interrupted his tennis career, today upset Denmark's Kurt Nielsen, top-seeded foreigner, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 11 -- 9, 6 -- 4, in the quarter-finals of the Newport tourney.
WASHINGTON, Aug 11 (AP) -- The Government put something of a damper today on the industrial expansion boom that started when the Communist hit South Korea five years ago.
BOSTON, Aug. 11 -- The number of new poliomyelitis cases in Massachusetts' "mild epidemic" declined today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Earl L. Butz, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, urged potato growers from twenty-one states, meeting today in the Conrad Hilton Hotel, to give serious consideration to promoting consumption of their product.
ROME, Aug. 11 -- About 5,000 United States soldiers are expected to arrive in Italy from Austria by Oct. 25.
Two Queens candidates for Democratic nomination for Municipal Court Justice challenged each other's primary designating petitions yesterday.
A strike that has tied up deliveries of magazines, paperbound books and stationery within a fifty-mile radius of New York since Wednesday continued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug 11 -- A group of six Soviet newspaper men may be permitted to visit the United States.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 (UP) -- A daring evacuation nearly turned into tragedy today when mountainous seas overturned lifeboats removing workmen from the wave-lashed "Texas Tower" radar station 110 miles off the tip of Cape Cod.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- The twenty-seventh National Contract Bridge championships continued here this afternoon with a record field of 212 pairs entered in the three-session men's pair championship and 156 pairs in the women's pair event.

HONG KONG, Aug. 11 -- Communist China called tonight for an international conference on the Far East to seek a "peaceful settlement" of the Korean question. It issued a formal statement denouncing South Korea's threat to oust the Neutral Nations Supervisory

Labor's drive for the guaranteed annual wage ran into a setback yesterday. A five-year agreement reached between the General Electric Company and the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., contained no provision for supplementary pay during periods of unemployment.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns, testing their muscles without Otto Graham, and the College All-Stars, trying a new coaching system, collide in the twenty-second All-Star football game before 75,000 at Soldier Field tomorrow night.
At last there is an answer to that silly question, How high is up? For years nobody could say, and the phrase was used rhetorically. Now we think the answer has been supplied by the Government.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 11 -- Samuel Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., scored his third consecutive victory last night in the annual open championship of the United States Chess Federation.
An experimental airlift of military personnel and dependents to overseas bases in Europe is being operated from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

BECAUSE of Hurricane Connie, housewives will find fewer of their favorite fresh fish available for the family week-end market basket. Warnings of that storm have kept fishing boats close to shore. And recent heat in the Georgian Bay area of the Great Lakes has sent fresh-water fish to cool, very deep waters, where they become harder to catch.

Springfield, Ohio, borrowed $5,790,000 in the public market yesterday through the sale of serial bonds maturing on Dec. 1 from 1959 to 1987. The bonds were bought by a syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., at a price costing the Ohio city 3.09 per cent in interest cost.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Michael Gerard (Mickey) Walsh, last year's leading money-winning trainer of jumpers, pulled the old one, two on the opposition, in the North American steeplechase at the Saratoga track today.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 11 -- Attorney General Jacob K. Javits warned today that solving the state's "very serious emergency" in juvenile delinquency was going to cost a lot of money at all levels.

The 143-year-old New York City Mission Society has under way a new project to help fight juvenile waywardness. Groups of twenty-five mothers and fifty children are having two-week vacations at Green Acres, thirty-five-acre former resort center near Dover Furnace, N. Y.

Companies in the American Gas and Electric System report a happy merry-go-round in the sale of home appliances and increases in commercial and industrial business. Sales and additions were headed for records this year, on the basis of first half-year reports.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 11 -- A youthful political leader representing the strongest Moslem party in the country formed a new coalition Government for Indonesia today.
MACAO, Aug. 11 -- There is gloom among the smugglers, gamblers and businessmen of Macao.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The weekly average of member bank reserve balances for the week ending August 10 decreased $86,000,000 to $18,824,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
DETROIT, Aug. 11 -- The United Automobile Workers. C. I. O., was reported tonight to be moving closer to agreement with both the Chrysler and American Motors Corporations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- A Civil Aeronautics Board inquiry into a Braniff airliner crash last month was told today that, just before it struck, the plane had swerved from its path and plunged into the ground at the northwest corner of Midway Airport.

An established novelist, Aldous Huxley occasionally likes to take an excursion into the dramatic field, in which he was last represented on Broadway by "The Gioconda Smile" (1950). His latest entry in the playwriting department is "The Genius and the Goddess."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Donald A. Quarles, new Secretary of the Air Force, misses the anonymity that until today had protected him from reporters, television cameras and the public at large.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Samuel Toranzo Calderon was reported sentenced today to life imprisonment on a charge of having master-minded the June 16 revolt.

A LITTLE volume turned up the other day by Mr. A. K. Baragwanath, librarian for the Museum of the City of New York, will give no comfort to the grumps who hold that Gotham weather isn't what it used to be.

Natural Resources Fund, Inc., and Natural Resources of Canada Fund, Inc., propose to merge into the newly formed International Resources Fund, Inc. The new fund would be set up to invest abroard the savings of shareholders in the production of basic raw materials, especially those related to the generation of energy.
Reflecting the record sales for the first half of this year, net earnings of the J. C. Penney Company increased to $17,980,771 from the $16,157,136 earned in the corresponding period of 1954.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 11 -- Universal-International has set a goal of thirty-six features to be produced during the twelve-month period commencing Nov. 1.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- A Negro labor leader appealed today for strong sanctions against discrimination in the constitution that will govern the unified labor movement.

The Neponsit Beach Hospital site in Rockaway, Queens, will be inspected next Tuesday afternoon by the six members of the Board of Estimate who last month voted down a proposal to turn it over to the Park Department.
The downpours that washed away August rainfall records also inundated at least 3,500 cellars, flooded roads and washed out tracks of the Long Island Rail Road.

A very curious thing happens at this time of year. With vacation due to begin in three weeks, say, the cook is acting as thought beset by the furies. Each afternoon she is out shopping, just as if Christmas were suddenly come again.
The city has lost another round in its fight on higher telephone rates.
The third hurricane of the 1955 season had already used up the energy of a few million atomic bombs or a few thousand hydrogen bombs as it moved north from Cape Hatteras last night.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 12 -- A northeast storm that brought torrential rain, lumpy sea and breakdowns to three boats -- and a thorough drenching to all participants -- failed to put off the start of the Hipkins Trophy eliminations at Indian Harbor Yacht Club today.

Women's apparel manufacturers and retailers are learning that fashion alone won't sell their product. As they prepare for what they hope will be a record fall season, they are giving greater recognition than ever to the importance of proper fit of garments.
The nation's chain and mail-order houses continued last month to show substantial increases in sales over 1954 levels.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Harold E. Talbott, who resigned as Secretary of the Air Force after writing business letters on official stationery, had a word of advice today for his associates:

I have just received a copy of your issue of July 26 which contains a news article entitled "Britons Discover Structure of Vitamin B-12." Although commendably accurate in the description it gives of the main features of the molecular structure of vitamin B-12, the article nevertheless conveys a false impression of the contribution made by the various groups of workers involved.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- Cable and Wireless, Ltd., the world-wide British communications system, has reported a $5,118,016 profit for the year ended last March.
BERLIN, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The United States Army announced today Maj. Gen. Charles L. Dasher Jr., deputy commander of the Fifth Army, had been appointed commandant for Berlin.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Despite a driving rain and brisk winds, one world record was shattered and a world and a meet mark were tied today in the women's national Amateur Athletic Union swimming and diving championships today. A major upset in the diving also marked the second day of the competition in the John B. Kelly pool.

Public support of the House Un-American Activities Committee's hearings on the entertainment world was urged yesterday by seventy members of the professions, arts, business, clergy and veterans' organizations.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12 0P)-- Stockholders of McDonnell Aircraft Corporation will meet l Aug. 25 to consider a proposed two-for-one stock split, already approved by the company's board of directors.
Sgt. James C. Gallagher once fought Chinese camp authorities in defense of a fellow prisoner, defense witnesses testified yesterday at the military trial of the Brooklyn youth.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- A Nazi spy who was landed on the Maine coast from a German submarine in 1944 was deported today to West Germany.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Army Corps of Engineers is beginning a $1,000,000 study of the behavior of hurricanes. The aim is to lessen loss of life and property.
The route to the New York Thruway from neighboring New Jersey highways is a deep, dark secret and Bergen County motorists are distressed at their state's insularity.

The former mansion at 4 East1 Eightieth Street, which was built in 1920. by F. W. Woolworth for his eldest daughter,I the late Mrs. Helena Woolworth] eCann, has been .old by theI Holy Cross Fathers to the Young en's PhilanthropicI League
FAIRFIELD, Calif., Aug. 12 -- Eleven glad American airmen set foot on the continental United States today after thirty months in Communist Chinese prisons.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Grains showed a firm undertone in the early trade today, but rallies met free selling and the demand was not sustained. Prices yielded quickly to moderate sales pressure. There was not much change in general.
The proposed working alliance between the independent International Longshoremen's Association and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters A. F. L., "appears to be in."
The market for new capital is about to feel temporarily a touch of the pressure that was characteristic of the first half of the year.
COOKING a large cut of meat for several meals is a kitchen practice appealing to all women at some time and to many women at all times.

John Emil Peurifoy, who was killed with one son in an automobile accident in Thailand yesterday, took the story-book attributes of the politician into the diplomatic profession. He made them work in some of the State Department's toughest assignments: Greece, Guatemala and Thailand.

On June 30, net asset value of the common stock of the Alleghany Corporation, a holding company, was $14.75 a share, according to the company's six months' income statement issued yesterday. The figure assumes full issuance of the company's 1,300,000 shares of new 6 per cent preferred stock.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Government has every intention of continuing its tax inducements for industrial expansion -- but on a much smaller scale than heretofore, Administration officials said today.

The Sonoco Products Company has purchased the former Canister Company plant in Phillipsburg, N. J., across the Delaware River from Easton, Pa. The plant contains several buildings with a total of 175,000 square feet of space. The sale was made through Hill Hill, Inc., brokers, of Westfield, N. J.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- If mudpacks are good for complexions, there should be some rosy cheeked little men reporting for work at the Saratoga jockey room tomorrow. This was another rainy day, and the track was deep in mud. Riders of slowpoke horses got the mudpack treatment.
Dress fabrics which achieve three-dimensional effects by reproducing color photography have been developed by Wamsutta Mills.
PARIS, Aug. 12 -- The Cabinet reached an agreement tonight on Moroccan policy aimed principally at saving its own life.
Wind gusts of more than forty miles an hour tore into the soaking city last night. Those windy arms of Hurricane Connie buffeted the area after a record downpour had deposited 6.87 inches of rain.

TOKYO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Japan's most influential economic journal, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, today said the Japanese Government will take strict measures to prevent indiscriminate sales of Japanese cotton goods to the United States and Canada.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Nervous speculation about next Monday's Cabinet meeting when R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, is expected to review results of his credit squeeze kept stock markets dull today. Government stocks rallied near the end but industrial shares closed without any real recovery.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- An invitation to visit Moscow was greeted with reserve today by Governors attending the annual Governors' Conference here.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today efforts would continue for the release of United Nations war prisoners still held in Communist China.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Bob Rosburg put his duffer-like golf swing to work for a 32, 35 -- 67 today and the sole lead in the "world" golf tournament with a thirty-six hole total of 133. He was eleven strokes under Tam o' Shanter's par.

VIENNA, Aug. 12 -- Premier Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej of Rumania announced today that Soviet troops would remain in his country until United States forces left Europe and the Western military alliance was dissolved.
ALBANY, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Former Senator James M. Mead has agreed to head the Washington office of the State Commerce Department, Governor Harriman announced today. His salary will be $12,000 a year.
TASHKENT, U. S. S. R., Aug. 12 -- A leading Soviet plant researcher said here today that natuure refused "to behave properly" unless conventional methods were applied in plant breeding.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 -- William Grami, leader of a drive to unionize farm workers in the Sebastopol area north of here, was kidnapped, bound and beaten early today.
SEOUL, Aug. 12 -- With President Rhee's ultimatum to the Communist truce inspectors nearing expiration, Inchon and other population centers resembled ghost towns today.

Led by Louise Brough, the Wimbledon champion, and Doris Hart, United States titleholder, America is a strong favorite to defeat England in the Wightman Cup series that is scheduled to begin today at the Westchester Country Club in Rye.

Maurice Collis, author of "The Land of the Great Image," "The Quest for Sita" and other books, has a new work on Harcourt, Brace's list. In "Cortes and Montezuma," he interprets the parts in history played by the Spanish conquistador and the Aztec ruler.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- United States officials expressed little surprise tonight at the announcement by the Soviet Union of manpower cuts totaling 640,000 men. They saw in it an effort by Moscow to keep alive the "Geneva atmosphere" of a general easing of tensions.
ORLANDO, Fla., Aug. 12 (UP) -- An Oklahoma student said today that he had played "spy" in an undetected tour of top-secret installations at one of the nation's major guided-missile bases.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- President Eisenhower signed into law today a bill to increase the legal minimum wage from 75 cents to $1 an hour.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 13 -- The Soviet Government announced today it had decided to reduce its armed forces, as a result of "the relaxation of international tension." The announcement was issued by the Soviet news agency Tass.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower arrived late today for a week-end at his country home here before departure Sunday for an extended vacation in Colorado.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Net income of Crown Zellerbach Corporation, paper manufacturer, in the first quarter of its 1955 fiscal year was approximately $9,000,000, or about $1.15 a share. J. D. Zellerbach, president, made this estimate at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday.

ALBANY, Ga., Aug. 12 (UP) -- A burning Air Force jet plane crashed into a house and an apartment building today, killing an airman who lived in one of the apartments and critically injuring the pilot and a housewife.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged at 110.1 (1946-49 equals 100) over the Week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. A moderate rise in average prices of farm products was balanced by a decline in the index for processed foods.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 12 -- The Governors of Connecticut and New York are expected to meet in Greenwich in the next ten days to try to work out an agreement over disputed water supplies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The tradition that goats thrive on a diet of old newspapers and the labels from tin cans got strong confirmation this week.
NORTH BEACH, Md., Aug. 12 -- Vicious advance winds of Hurricane Connie today wrecked an excursion schooner in Chesapeake Bay. Ten persons were drowned and four
BLED, Yugoslavia, Aug. 12 -- Yugoslavia is irked at Western Germany for the delay in resuming negotiations for payment of war indemnities and reparations.
At the critical end of the economic line -- the retail counter -- the figures continue to confound the pessimists.
In a recent letter Jose Bensaude states that Goa is as much a part of Portugal politically, economically and socially as any one of the forty-eight states is part of the United States.

Approval of new rate schedules for commercial and industrial power consumers of the Long Island Lighting Company was announced yesterday by the Public Service Commission. The new charges were made effective Thursday, Aug. 11.

In the future four major league players from each major league club will be permitted to play winter baseball in the four Caribbean countries that have baseball leagues -- Cuba, Puerto Rico, Venezuela and Panama.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 10 -- Communist countries and the Free World will make a determined bid to expand their trade contacts with India by displaying the most modern machinery and capital goods at the Indian Industries Fair that will open in New Delhi October 29.
The outlook for the duck season this fall is excellent. Reports from the Canadian prairie Provinces, known as the "duck factory," indicate better than average waterfowl production.
EDELWEILER, Germany, Aug. 12 (UP) -- Rescue workers sifted the wreckage of two Flying Boxcars today in a search for bodies from an air collision that killed sixty-six United States servicemen.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point up to 11 points off yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Business men and homeowners in the path of Hurricane Connie will find disaster loans from the Government readily available.
The Transit Authority showed signs yesterday that its honeymoon with the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., was nearing an end.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 12 -- The noblest public relations project yet conceived by the motion picture industry has died aborning.

When will highway officials learn that good directional signs can be one of the most effective ways of ending traffic jams or obviating bottlenecks? There are far too many roads in this area where motorists' confusion -- and accidents -- stems from lack of adequate signs.
DETROIT, Aug. 12 -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., rejected today a contract offer of the Chrysler Corporation and ordered local unions to take strike votes.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 12 -- An educator told the Senate subcommittee on Juvenile Delinquency today that desegregating the public schools would help greatly to reduce delinquency among Negro children.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 12 -- Samuel Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., last night was held to a draw by Dr. Peter P. Lapiken of Los Angeles in the annual open championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation in a fourth-round match. in his three previous matches Reshevsky had triumphed.

The $1,000,000 Shrine of the Ages Chapel, to be built next year on the south rim of the Grand Canyon in Arizona will have separate altars for worshipers of the Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 12 -- A brief anti-Peron demonstration here tonight ended in violence. At least twenty persons were injured in street fighting between the anti-Government demonstrators, who numbered several thousand, and flying squads of organized supporters of President Juan D. Peron.

The Rogers Act of 1924 and the new type of Foreign Service examinations which were introduced about the same time provided a remarkably able and competent body of trained men to undertake the crucial function of representing their country abroad.
HARTFORD, Aug. 12 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff signed a bill today increasing the pay of inmates in the state prison from 15 to 25 cents a day.

The American Sugar Refining Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries had a net profit of $4,085,000 in the first six months of this year against $3,478,000 earned in the corresponding period last year, W. F. Oliver, president, reported yesterday in the semi-annual statement to stockholders.
This country has suffered a tragic loss in the accidental death of John E. Peurifoy, our Ambassador to Thailand. We believe that Thailand also has suffered.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 12 -- Who would venture out into the wet world on a night like this to hear symphonic music ? Several thousand men and women made their way to Tanglewood tonight and sat under the cover of the Big Shed to listen to the Boston Symphony Orchestra conducted by Charles Munch.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- United States experts reported today that a tacit armistice seemed to have developed on the East-West propaganda front following the Big Four meeting in Geneva.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (UP) -- Bob Rush hurled Chicago to a 7-1 victory over the Milwaukee Braves today as the Cubs snapped a three-game losing streak.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Aug. 13 -- United States troops repelled with gunfire and tear gas a 3,000-man assault yesterday on the compound housing Communist truce inspectors at the east coast port of Kangnung.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 12 -- Agreement was reached late today "on a formula" to end the week-old strike by the Screen Actors Guild against the producers of television entertainment films. The announcement was made jointly by the guild and the employer groups, the Association of Motion Picture Producers and the Alliance of Television Film Producers.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 12 -- The trial of Leon Jungschlager, former Dutch military intelligence chief, charged with conspiracy to overthrow the Indonesian Republic was postponed again today.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 12 (AP) -- President Carlos Ibanez del Campo set up a new Cabinet tonight for the eleventh time since he took office Nov. 3, 1952.
VIENNA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Little Austria will become the kingpin of oil-producing nations in Western Europe tomorrow, as four Austrian fields with 1,250 wells are handed back by Soviet authorities.

IN the basement of the combined Village Presbyterian Church and The Brotherhood Synagogue at 141 West Thirteenth Street, the Greenwich Mews Theatre company is presenting a well-acted, excellently staged presentation of Shaw's amusing, little-known playlet, "Village Wooing."

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 12 (UP) -- Weal or Woe, 4-year-old colt from the Jet Stable, clung to a narrow lead in the stretch to score a half-length triumph today in the Vineland Purse. Our Gob was second in the field of seven, another length in advance of Arthur S.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The arraignment of Rea S. Van Fosson, former captain in the Air Force who, was arrested yesterday on charges of misusing a secret document, was postponed today until Sept. 2.

As the United Nations Command braces itself for whatever may follow the expiration of the South Korean ultimatum to the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission to leave by midnight tonight, the Chinese Communist regime has issued another call for another international conference on the Far East to seek a "peaceful settlement of the Korean question."

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 12 -- Settlement of the long strike against Kennecott Copper Corporation's Utah properties was announced here today. The settlement is subject to ratification by 5,500 members of eight unions involved in the forty-two-day walkout.
Hurricane Connie had New York's shipping industry in a dither yesterday.

Archie Moore is a temperamental man. When he says "I won't work today," he means it and his sparring partners might as well go fishing. When he's grouchy it's best to leave him alone. On those mornings when he rises early, orders a big breakfast and announces that he feels good, everyone in his entourage prepares for a big day.

GENEVA, ,Aug. 12 -- The first technical hints about methods of harnessing the energy of the hydrogen bomb were given at today's sessions of the International Conference on Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- In its ten years of existence the United Nations has inherited many an important international problem for solution. Now a different type --a strictly internal poser -- had its executives in a fret of indecision.
Edna Best, Boris Karloff, Julie Harris and Menasha Skulnik will appear on the Columbia Broadcasting System's "United States Steel Hour" telecasts between Aug. 31 and Sept. 28.

LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Laszio Tabori and Sandor Iharos, a pair of Hungarian milers, hit the tape almost together in 4 minutes 5 seconds today in the much-heralded international bid to lower the world record below the present mark of 3:58.
The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service was accused yesterday of "dragging its heels" on the Government's "charter-build" tanker program.
In connection with your editorial "Bulganin Reports," published on Aug. 5, I would like to point out the following facts:
The threatened strike of 1,000 tank truck drivers against twenty-four milk hauling companies was called off last night as union and company negotiators reached agreement on a new contract.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 12 (UP) -- Al Smith hit a homer and Hal Naragon tripled to pace the league-leading Cleveland Indians to a 6-5 triumph tonight in the second game of a day-night bill. Cleveland had won the opener, 17 to 1.

Supervising Assistant Chief Inspector John H. Mitchell, commander of Police commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy's Confidential Squad, posted his retirement application yesterday. Pending final approval after the thirty-day period required by law, it was accepted by the Commissioner.

PANGIM, Goa, Aug. 12 -- Portuguese Goa, a triangular patch of land on the Arabian Sea, now fiercely green under the rains of the monsoon, is all that remains of the rich empires Europe built in India. Lisbon is prepared to use force to hold it.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 12 -- West Germany informed the Soviet Government today that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was prepared to go to Moscow Sept. 9 to discuss diplomatic, economic and cultural relations.

Fernand Leger's big "Composition," on the first floor landing of the Museum of Modern Art, was taken down yesterday and put in safe storage, away from proximity to glass. All over the museum building at 11 West Fifty-third Street picture movers kept ahead of possible hurricane winds.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- President Eisenhower said today that the death of Ambassador Peurifoy cost the nation and the free world "an outstanding champion of freedom and peace."

Paul Muni, star of "Inherit the Wind," has extended his player's contract with the courtroom drama through this and next season. Under the terms of the new agreement, he will remain with the Jerome Lawrence-Robert E. Lee play until May 31, 1957.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that wheat of twenty-three designated "undesirable" varieties, grown next year, will be docked 20 cents a bushel under the grower price support program.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 12 -- The staff orchestra of the National Broadcasting Company will be increased from twenty-one to forty-five members and used on transcontinental commercial shows for the first time as a result of an agreement reached with Musicians Local 47 here.

President Peron is evidently getting second thoughts about the advisability of having a referendum on a separation of church and state in Argentina this November. Perhaps it is as well for all concerned that this otherwise salutary measure should be put through under different auspices.
PARIS, Aug. 12 -- Not all of the membership of Young Men's Christian Associations is young, male or Christian.

Clarence B. Randall is chairman of the Inland Steel Company. Last year he was chairman of the President's Commission on Foreign Economic Policy. What he says on the subject of conflict of interest between private business and public office warrants attention.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 12 -- Thomas Mann, a modern literary giant, died in the Cantonal Hospital here early tonight. He was 80 years old. His death followed a thrombosis, or blood clot.
As one result of last night's washout Brooklyn fans will get their wish to see Robin Roberts and Don Newcombe as mound opponents today.
