Spencer Tracy and Robert Wagner, stars of Paramount's forthcoming "The Mountain," are scheduled to leave New York for Paris today with producer- director Edward Dmytryk and Barbara Darrow, one of the film's principals. Location shooting is scheduled to begin in the French Alps in two weeks.

DETROIT, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today the auto industry's car output for this year passed the 5,200,000 mark this week. It also said retail sales already have topped 4,500,000 units.
SEOUL, Saturday, Aug. 13 (UP) -- President Syngman Rhee said today the Republic of Korea no longer felt bound by the terms of the armistice of July 27, 1953.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Two Southern Governors, both Democrats, came to the defense today of Adlai E. Stevenson, the leading contender for next year's Democratic Presidential nomination.

JACKSONVILLE, N. C., Aug. 12 -- Capricious Hurricane Connie suddenly doubled her speed last night, bypassed Wilmington, N. C., and finally came ashore about 7 o'clock (E. S. T.) this morning. She struck a glancing blow at Morehead City, losing speed as she headed north.
GENEVA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The United States disclosed today that atomic energy had been used for the first time in history as the sole source of light and power in an entire American town.

The numT0er of Sales and leasesI bf:tdustrial .buildings on the lower West Side'executed so fsr thls summer, by the Charles F. N0yes Company, Inc., broker, is higher fhan in any similar period in recent years, the concern reports.
The investigation into the $312,219 hold-up of a Queens bank on April 6 brought about the arrest yesterday of a former city policeman on charges of having participated in a robbery last November.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Hurricane Connie refugees totaling 14,756 have made use of the seventy Red Cross shelters along the North and South Carolina coasts.
A 32-year-old Brooklyn ex-convict was arrested last night by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and charged with being a member of an interstate car-theft ring.

ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Aug. 12 (UP) -- Joseph L. Rauh Jr., chairman of Americans for Democratic Action, said tonight that 1955 would go down as the year that marked the end of "the McCarthy era" and a return to sanity and civil liberties.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 12 -- Miss Nina Gore Auchincloss made her debut tonight at a formal ball given by her father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. Hugh D. Auchincloss of McLean, Va., at Hammersmith Farm, their estate here. More than 700 guests attended.
GENEVA, Aug. 12 -- The Soviet Union is completing the largest atom-smashing machine in the world. It will be twice as powerful as the one recently completed in the United States.
Lutheran Church membership in the United States topped the seven-million mark in 1954.
There are rabbits that have made their mark in motion pictures, comic strips and even scientific research.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Britain is considering placing new restrictions on imports from Japan unless Tokyo agrees to give better treatment to British goods.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Ninety-six contract bridge pairs out of a starting field of 212 pairs qualified this afternoon for tomorrow's final session of the men's pairs event. This is one of the six national championship titles at stake in the ten-day twenty-seventh annual National Contract Bridge championships.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 12 -- The administration of the internal security of Pakistan was assigned today to 82-year-old Fazlul Huq, who was expelled last year from the Government as a traitor. The new Interior Minister was dismissed from the Chief Ministership of East Pakistan fifteen months ago after he had publicly declared that the province would secede.
Trans World Airlines proposed yesterday a new bargain fare on coast-to-coast air coach excursions.

OTTAWA, Aug. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's carryover of wheat from the 1954 crop year totaled 481,363,000 bushels on July 31, the third highest in history, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower had signed a bill to establish a commission to pass upon plans for a memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt. The bill establishes a $10,000 expense account for the commission's use.

CAIRO, Aug. 12 -- Ever since the Second World War the United States has sought to play an increasingly influential role in the Middle East. Our diplomacy has been active. Our economic aid and commercial interests have expanded. We have sought to encourage peace and progress in a backward, uneasy area.
Additional time has been given to 141 longshoremen to clear up legal questions in connection with the Waterfront Commission proceedings against them.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 -- United States Air Force bases might be made available to Russian reconnaisance planes if the Soviet Government accepted President Eisenhower's proposal for an exchange of military blueprints and freedom to reconnoiter.

GENEVA, Aug. 12 -- It was incorrectly stated in The New York Times on Wednesday that British and American experts estimated a price of about $30 a ton for plutonium, the fissile element that is derived from uranium.
VIENNA, Aug. 12 -- Czechoslovakia followed the example of Hungary today by declaring her willingness to improve her relations with Yugoslavia.

Rubber prices tumbled yesterday on the Commodity Exchange, following strength the day before. The decline was attributed to new short selling and speculator liquidation. Trading was influenced by lower London cables.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Officials of the National Coal Board gave dismissal notices today to 193 miners at a colliery in Wales, who, they said, had refused to cooperate in an effort to improve output.

The New York State Public Service Commission will investigate the commuter service of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad. Benjamin F. Feinberg, commission chairman, announced this yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- President Eisenhower signed a $30,000,000 measure to help the states buy poliomyelitis vaccine today. The Public Health Service later announced how the funds would be allocated among the states and territories.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Ralph Guglielmi, L. G. Dupre and Tad Weed combined to lead the College All-Stars to a 30-27 upset of the Cleveland Browns tonight.
TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Two New Jersey Superior Court judges today set Aug. 26 as the date for the thrice-postponed annual meeting of stockholders of the Thermoid Company.
Four Republican candidates withdrew yesterday from the Sept. 13 New York City primary election.

The need for closer economic integration of Europe, and for that matter of the whole Western world, is again illustrated by the latest developments in the old Continent, which, of all things, is running into a "full employment crisis." What this means is that the most advanced European industrial countries, notably Britain and Germany, are being confronted with a growing labor shortage.
In a session with little volume or excitement, the stock market yesterday rose enough to close the week with a small gain.

HEAVY rains that have flooded basements in many parts of New York pose house-cleaning problems not often encountered in the normal life of a housewife. But the United States Department of Agriculture has some valuable suggestions gathered from its experience in the 1937 floods that may make the job easier.

MASSENA, N. Y. -- Sightseers are welcome to view the early construction now proceeding on the immense United States-Canadian St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project in this area. The invitation comes from Robert Moses, chairman of the New York State Power Authority, on its behalf and that of the Seaway Development Corporation.

GENEVA, Aug. 13 -- A vision of a brave new world powered with nuclear energy was outlined here today. The curtain was lifted for the first time on a veritable wonderland of advanced designs of atomic power plants until now classified top secret.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Washington officials regard the Soviet Union's announcement of the coming demobilization of 640,000 men as a "potentially encouraging" sign.

GENEVA, Aug. 12 -- Business representatives in Geneva in connection with the atoms-for-peace fair have been concerned over some of the predictions of the scientists at the United Nations International Conference on Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy. The exhibition and the conference are being held concurrently but separately.

GENEVA, Aug. 13 -- The first week's meetings of the International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy made a deep impression on the several hundred physicists from many countries and as many outsiders, who were all well informed on atomic energy but who wanted to acquire practical information that could be applied at home.

THERE is no reason for a home vegetable grower to be discouraged with the results obtained from his garden so far this year. This has been one of the worst growing years on record, both from the standpoint of the dry weather and the continuous hot weather.

THE whirling, square-ended lathe dog set-screw can be an arm hazard while filing a piece of stock. To save your left forearm, cut a round piece of corrugated cardboard about eight inches in diameter. Cut a cross in the center of the disk and force it on over the stock until it rests against the lathe dog.

LIGHTS suspended from the ceiling, out of favor for a while, are making a brilliant come-back. There is a trend toward using handsome antique chandeliers in contemporary settings to lend a note of glamour as well as provide illumination. And there are modern variations of the chandelier in crystal, brass and even colored plastic.
AROSS the East River and into the tree-lined borough of Brooklyn, they are shooting "Patterns," the film from an original television story about some executives who give one another the business.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The skipper of the shipwrecked Levin J. Marvel poured out his story today of the old vessel's capsizing with a loss of fourteen lives.

HONORS, awards and citations for photographers and worthy recipients in associated fields are scheduled on one of the fullest and most diversified programs in the history of the Photographers Association of America, which will hold its seventy-fifth anniversary convention and trade show tomorrow through Friday.

THE strike by the Screen Actors Guild against the producers of television entertainment films has ramifications for the whole motion picture industry. The actors have long been regarded as the only group possessing sufficient strength to open the way for continuing participation in earnings from re-use, or revival, of motion pictures years after their original exhibition in theatres.

GENEVA, Aug. 13 -- The life and death of man in the presence of nuclear radiation was discussed here by scientists of fifty nations at today's sessions of the International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy.

THE perennial plight of almost all mueeums, lack of space to show the permanent collection permanently, visits the Whitney Museum, established though it is in spick and span new quarters. A virtual hurricane of docker opposition to the reappointment of Jacob Grumet as impartial arbitrator has blown itself out. Last week he quietly started another ninety-day term in the post.

NORTH BEACH, Md., Aug. 13 (UP) -- The Coast Guard ordered today an investigation into the foundering of an "unseaworthy" 64-year-old schooner that apparently cost the lives of fourteen pleasure-cruising passengers.

A practical move toward easing the teacher shortage has been adopted by the Wilmington (Del.) branch of the American Association of University Women. The plan, sponsored in conjunction with the University of Delaware, would re-certify mature college graduates not now in teaching for school careers upon completion of a special course.

BOSTON, Aug. 13 -- The first week of August saw the highest temperatures in Boston in recent years, with inevitable adverse results on retail trade. Department store sales as a whole this summer have been a little ahead of a year ago, but results between various stores have varied widely.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 13 -- With the weather again snarling the Yankees' efforts to improve their prospects in the American League pennant race, Casey Stengel today was able to give his undivided attention to the Bombers next most important problem.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- President Eisenhower acted promptly today to set the special Reserve enlistment programs of the Army and Marine Corps in motion. The President moved as the House Armed Services Committee gave in a pamphlet answers to the fifty most important questions that had poured into its office with regard to the Reserve program.

GRAND MARAIS, Minn. -- In that northeastermnost wedge of Minnesota which is squeezed between the top of Lake Superior and the southern boundary of Ontario, a million acres of virgin forest and some 5,000 lakes make a notable vacation haunt for campers, canoers and other nature lovers. These acres are comprised in the Superior National Forest, largely roadless and virtually unaltered since French explorers and voyageurs pioneered the region in the sevenenteenth and eighteenth centuries.

WHEN Gail Bennett, daughter of an old Yankee family, becomes friendly with Concetta Giminelli, whose parents are recent immigrants from Italy, both families are displeased. As co-editors of the high school paper, the two girls spark a move to establish a youth center for the town, where young people can meet after school and pick their own friends, irrespective of family backgrounds.

Waterman -- "The Science of Producing Good Scientists" (July 31) -- on the critical shortage of trained scientific personnel in America. ANN ARBOR, Aug. 13 -- Three outstanding scientists have been appointed by the University of Michigan regents to establish a mental health research unit at the university's medical school.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 13 -- The Middlesex County Sewerage Authority cleared the way this week for construction of a $23,000,000 trunk sewer to handle industrial and household waste in the Raritan Valley.

DETROIT, Aug. 13 -- Harvey Kuenn's sacrifice fly sent Fred Hatfield home with the winning run in the ninth inning today to give the Detroit Tigers a 9-8 victory over the Chicago White Sox at rain-drenched Briggs Stadium.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 13 -- Retail trade in the Kansas City district, which has been lagging behind the national average for several weeks, has again bounced back to top the country's average. The improvement is coming from the rural areas, where the outlook has brightened.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 -- According to the Wells Fargo Business Review, California in the first half of 1955 attained the highest level of business activity in its history. Initial impetus was provided by the automotive and construction industries.
Court action brought an intermission yesterday in the battle for control of the food-packing concern of Libby, McNeil Libby.

The portents in the almanac of thaw in the cold war were variable last week. The senior partner in the Communist coalition made a new peaceful gesture. But there was uncertainty about the willingness of the junior partner to relieve tensions significantly.

SCRIBNER'S "Poets of Today" series is an experiment in cushioning the costs of poetry publication by publishing three separate first books in a single volume. The idea is simple enough, and not new -- New Directions published a similar series some years back, and it is worth noting that the series provided first publication for a number of poets of talent.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Aug. 13 -- Jamestown, site of the first permanent English settlement in America, is to have new permanency a national shrine.

WITHDRAWAL of the American Automobile Association from supervision of all types of automobile racing in this country has been prompted by recent track deaths and accidents incurred through increasing speeds, soaring engine power and consequent excessive strain on human capacity to control these factors in competition.
MELBOURNE, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Preparations for the 1956 Olympic Games are now ahead of the timetable and are moving along at a fast clip, an official report of the organizing committee said today.

GENEVA, Aug. 13 -- Scientists of all nationalities attending the United Nations Conference on Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy agree, as the conference passes its midpoint, that it is a success so far.

YONKERS, Aug. 13 -- Quick Chief, the favorite in the William H. Cane Futurity Pace for 3-year-olds next Thursday night, gained an easy victory in a tune-up for the event at Yonkers Raceway tonight. He won the $7,500 Huguenot Pace before a crowd of 21,226.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 -- Carin Cone became the first double winner of the Amateur Athletic Union national women's swimming tournament tonight. The unheralded 15-year-old girl from Ridgewood, N. J., scored an upset to win the 100-meter back-stroke title.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 13 (AP) -- President Gustavo Rojas Pinilla said today the Liberal party newspaper El Tiempo had developed into a "superstate" and was exerting "a real dictatorship'' before the Government closed it.
VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 9 -- The sixth investigation since 1928 into the affairs of the Vancouver Police Department has brought out a tangle of evidence on the gambling squad going back to 1949.

WARSAW, Aug. 13 (Reuters) -- Premier Joseph Cyrankiewicz said today that all the Polish Government wanted from Roman Catholic Cardinal Stefan Wyszinski was that he "should not have the possibility of provoking a religious struggle."
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 12 -- The Navy has indicated that it may be able to make room for additional cargo assembly and docking space for commercial ships at the Army's sub-port of embarkation here.

As tuberculosis is both a communicable and a chronic disease, health education of the public and the patient with the arrested illness is of prime importance. CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Barring some unforeseen developments the Governors of most of the forty-eight states, Democrats and Republicans alike, are now looking forward to another Eisenhower-Stevenson contest for President next year.

RAIL travel this summer has been heavy on most lines, especially on those having dome-equipped trains. Trainmen have been more courteous and trains generally on time. But dining car prices are a bit higher and the coaches are too cold at night.

It is a nostalgic reminder of days of band concerts, country fairs and church festivals or picnics when the ears are roasted on an open charcoal fire. CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- The business survey committee of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago disclosed evidence of rising prices in the wake of the latest round of wage increases. SUMMER is the proper time to check up on the condition of a roof, correcting any faults that have developed, before the onset of autumn rains and winter snows. The roofing itself and its substructure are dry and safe to work on, assuming proper caution; asphalt and other roofing cements flow more easily than in cold weather and asphalt shingles are less apt to crack under pressure.

VIENNA Aug. 13 -- Austria regained control of her economy today. The Russians formally handed back to her Government the East Austrian oil fields, 300 industrial enterprises and 240,000 acres of land.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 13 -- Ham Richardson, the 1954 winner from Baton Rouge, La., and Herb Flam of Beverly Hills, Calif., gained the final of the Newport Casino invitation tennis tournament today. They will meet tomorrow.

IN the hospitable South of Frank Slaughter's historical novels, beautiful women prefer medics two to one. No exception is the fast-paced "Flight From Natchez," wherein handsome Dr. John Powers finds himself trapped between two women -- and enjoying his captivity. So (it goes without saying) will Dr. Slaughter's large and well-earned public.

POSTMASTER General Arthur E. Summerfield has begun carrying out a recommendation which the Commission of Fine Arts made in 1953 to President Eisenhower -- "that the Post Office Department and the Bureau of Engraving and Printing give consideration to measures that will increase the prestige and authority of the art factor in the design of postage stamps."

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Francis (Bo) Wininger of Oklahoma City surged from seven strokes back to move into the 54-hole lead of the $100,000 "world" golf tourney by a stroke with 209 today. The third round of the high-pressure quest for the $50,000 first prize saw Bob Rosburg, the half-way leader, soar to an 80 and a 54-hole total of 213.
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Rain-drenched courts forced postponement of the initial card of matches between the United States and England in the Wightman Cup series at the Westchester Country Club today.

DUBLIN, Aug. 9 -- The ways of the Irish Censorship Board are strange. It has banned books by the most reputable Irish authors, including Sean O'Casey, Liam O'Flaherty, Sean O'Faolain, and Ireland's most brilliant short story writer, Frank O'Connor.

SEOUL, Aug. 13 -- Efforts by South Koreans to force the Polish and Czech members of the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission to quit their country created an ugly and potentially explosive situation here this week.

Thomas Mann's death on Friday came more than half a century after the novel "Buddenbrooks" had brought him fame and torment. Torment his life indeed was, at least in part, for he suffered grievously from the collapse of the old Europe and the old values.

ELINOR GLYN was an extraordinary woman with red hair and green eyes. She wrote a number of novels which reached an alarmingly large audience. She also conceived the screen play for "It," in which Clara Bow made her reputation. But this, as anyone will understand who dips into this reverent biography by her grandson, is only half the story.
WITHIN the next few weeks millions of youngsters throughout the, country will be taking the first step of their long school careers. Five's and six's will be off to kindergarten and first grade.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 -- The opening day of play in the Davis Cup interzone final tennis match between Australia and Italy was called off again today.

MARION BAUER, who died Tuesday evening at the age of 68, spent about sixty of those years fighting for the acceptance of modern music in general and the American composer in particular. When she was a child, she once told this writer, she became entranced with the then new sounds of Scriabin; and in her teens she entered the world of the French impressionists.

Mendes-France tries to convert the nation to milk; Georges Simenon (a Belgian, to be sure, but more French than the Republic) keeps writing examples of the Curse of Drink horrible enough to please W. C. T. U. But these dire cautions, though they verge upon the domain of the tract, never forget to be novels. The latest is particularly effective.
GLADIOLUS will have the limelight on the East Coast this week when two traditionally important shows devoted to this tall garden favorite will open their doors.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 13 -- The Great Lakes ore fleet will not have any difficulty meeting or even exceeding the pre-season estimate of 72,000,000 tons of the raw mineral this season.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 13 -- For most of the nation's farmers the big question this week was not one of prosperity, but rather of how much less they would make this year than in 1954.

GAMBLING and games of chance have been an honorable, and sometimes dishonorable, part of man's history from the time the first human being figured that three and four added up to lucky seven. That was a long time ago: dice much like ours have been uncovered in ancient Egyptian tombs and in the ruins of Babylon.

The fiftieth annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association begins today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The Department of Parks Marionette Theatre will begin Friday a final round of seventeen performances of "Hansel and Gretel." The last show will take place Sept. 8.

LULLY'S Miserere, a setting of the Fifty-first Psalm, has not won the fame of Allegri's setting of the same text. Nevertheless, it is a noble and inspired work that ought to be heard more often than it is.

SANTIAGO, second city of the Dominican Republic, is en fete for its annual month-long August fiesta. The many-sided event emphasizes the country's traditional poetry, music and dancing with orchestras competing for honors and native poets and musicians performing original compositions.

WITH a four-disk set of the last five Beethoven String Quartets and the Grosse Fuge, the Hungarian Quartet concludes its series of all sixteen for Angel. On the whole, the series is a well-recorded, cleanly played contribution from a polished ensemble that clearly knows its business. And yet this listener stubbornly continues to prefer the three-volume set made for Columbia some years ago by the Budapest Quartet.
That fickle harpie, Hurricane Connie, wrought her mischief on many people in the past five days, but on none more maliciously than the man who had to divine her intentions.

THE oldest records of gardens often included a drawing of the garden gate. And today this useful and decorative feature still holds a prominent place on the home scene. This is easy to understand since almost every property has at least one appropriate place or setting for an attractive gate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Thirteen Italians, including three priests and a woman, flew here today to testify in a United States grand jury investigation of the wartime slaying of Maj. William Holohan.

CAN the Empire State Music Festival become a fixed landmark of the American summer landscape? Its directors and sponsors fully expect that it will, and for their first season they have undertaken a series of programs ambitious enough to give pause to older and more experienced enterprises of this sort.
LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Viscount Montgomery of Alamein declared today that Anglo-American solidarity was the "hard core" of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 10 -- New Bedford and Fall River have their economic noses pressed against the showcase of industrial opportunity. Each has more than $500,000 in hand to spend on pump-priming devices.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 13 -- Gov. J. Bracken Lee stood firm this week on his right to speak out on what he believed was wrong with the Eisenhower Administration. At the same time Utah Republicans and Democrats stressed with equal vigor what they believed was wrong with Governor Lee.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Tomorrow's twentieth anniversary of the signing of the Social Security Act will find as its administrator a man who helped shape it from the start.

ATLANTA, Aug. 13 -- Business in general continues at a brisk pace in the Southeast, with employment gains reported in practically all major fields of activity. Compared with a year earlier, approximately 175,500 more workers are on non-agricultural payrolls, with total workers reaching an estimated 6,053,500.
THE migration, flight and habitat of the woodcock are as unpredictable as a Maine fog, but thousands of gunners place this long-billed visitor in the No. 1 spot on the game-bird list.

THE odd chance that "I Am a Camera" may be catapulted into a box-office success on account of its risque nature and its having been denied a Production Code seal is one of those passing phenomena that are coming more and more to confuse the motion picture people and expose the anomaly of their regulatory restraints.

When I read the news about the American scientists' plan to create a man-made satellite for earth in 1957-58 I was at once reminded of an almost similar (and successful) attempt described in the "Ramayana," the 2,500-year-old Sanskrit epic of India.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- An armed band of about twenty men staged a daring raid before dawn today on a lightly guarded British Army camp near Reading, forty miles west of here. Authorities said the men were members of the secret Irish Republican Army.
FAIRFIELD, Calif., Aug. 13 (UP) -- Eleven American airmen returned today to the homes they had dreamed of through thirty-two months of Communist imprisonment.

ATHENS, Aug. 13 (Reuters) -- Greece will hold its first annual international music and drama festival at Athens from Aug. 24 to Oct. 2.
The Civil Aeronautics Board has given Pan American World Airways a permanent certificate to operate direct service between New York and Ciudad Trujillo, capital of the Dominican Republic.

VIENNA, Aug. 13 -- The most significant occurrence in East Europe since the visit of Soviet Premier Nikolai Bulganin and Communist party boss, Nikita Khrushchev, to Belgrade last May was undoubtedly Marshal Tito's public criticism in a speech at Karlovac a fortnight ago of Hungarian and Czechoslovakian Communist leaders for not following this conciliatory example.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- It's an old story. On an August morning in 1864 the Saratoga Association ran its first horse race -- the Travers, for 3-year-olds. The favorite lost. The Travers had its eighty-sixth running today. The 9-to-20 favorite finished second.
The United Steelworkers, C. I. O., won yesterday the first major plan in American industry for a fall year of supplementary unemployment benefits.

NEXT to the Italian cuisine, no other national cookery so excites the appetites of Americans as that of the Chinese. The exotic Orient has influenced our taste through restaurants that range from neighborhood joints to sleek establishments specializing in Peking duck, winter melon soup and other subtle palate-pleasures.
A huge growth in markets, research and product development lies ahead for the nation's drug industry in the next ten years, a top executive in the field has forecast.

MAX MILLER is probably best known for "I Cover the Waterfront." Actually he has covered most of the world. As a Navy man in three wars, including Korea, and as a writer, he has journeyed on all the continents and sailed the seven seas. The majority of his twenty-three previous books were about countries far from his home shore.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 13 -- Five members of the visiting Russian farm delegation were guided personally around the 366-acre Illinois State Fair here today by Gov. William G. Stratton.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 13 -- Appointments to the Peronist party's new National Committee appeared to observers today to indicate a revival of Old Guard peronism.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 -- Industrial activity in Pennsylvania rose to an index mark of 113 during June, a gain of 13 points over the same month of 1954, the Bureau of Business Research at the Pennsylvania State University reported this week.

THE commonplace experience of forgetting (a mighty harassing one for adults) is turned into a delightful romp by story-teller Ellen MacGregor and artist Paul Galdone in "Theodore Turtle." Theodore, like every good man, decides to wear his rubbers to go outdoors. He finds all four of them in the attic, but absentmindedly carries only three of them downstairs.

This hasn't been a happy season at the Polo Grounds. The world champion Giants have been fumbling, stumbling and bumbling. Even their most devoted supporters have thrown in the towel on their chances of capturing the pennant again.
HAMBURG, Aug. 13 (AP) -- West Germany's giant shipbuilding industry was headed today toward an all-time annual production record of 1,000,000 tons of new vessels.

MAGDALEN ISLANDS, Province of Quebec -- This small crescent of deep red and emerald islands lies in the great basin of the Gulf of St. Lawrence. It has Prince Edward Island and Nova Scotia to the south, Newfoundland to the northeast, and the eastern tip of Quebec to the north.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Aug. 11 -Tengku Abdul Rahman, the first Chief Minister of the Federation of Malaya, is an affable, unpretentious Malay aristocrat with a feeling for the common man and a knack for practical politics.

MOST suburbanites who are sedentary workers five days a week and general laborers around the home the other two are familiar with the "Tuesday morning bends." These are aches and pains, Charleyhorses and a general stiffness resulting from such necessary exertions as painting a ceiling, working on hands and knees for several hours or setting up and moving an extension ladder.

DUSTY naval accounts attest that on June 12, 1775 -- five days before Bunker Hill -- Captain Jeremiah O'Brien and a makeshift crew of Maine patriots seized the British cutter Margaretta in Machias Bay. This long neglected episode, which, it would seem, should rank in importance with the land battles of Lexington and Concord, is now the basis for an excellent historical novel, centered upon the O'Brien clan.

BALTIMORE -- The frigate Constellation, built in Baltimore and launched Sept. 7, 1797, has just been returned from Boston to her home port and will be established as a shrine here, bedded in gravel in the Fort McHenry National Monument area.

"WE are going to buy it today," little Tony Marconi joyfully tells his friends. Bello cheerfully does his bit in a wonderful series of trades, which makes the Marconi family elated and grateful.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 4 -- A bill authorizing the creation of a Costa Rican Institute of Tourism has passed Congress by unanimous vote and has been ratified by the President.
IN a recent ceremony at City Hall Plaza in New York, thirty men stood proudly, like soldiers at attention, and received medals for heroism from Mayor Wagner. They were not policemen, or firemen.

THE posthumous "Selected Poems" of Robert P. Tristram Coffin represents all the qualities that made him "one of America's best loved and most honored poet." Youth and old age, the Maine seacoast, farm animals and wild animals, country characters, and throughout all, a pervading homesickness for old times and lost boyhood -- these are the familiar themes that have endeared him to readers and audiences for the past thirty years.

BETWEEN now and the middle of November all but five of our forty-eight states will hold their annual state fairs. None has been scheduled for Delaware or Nevada. Pennsylvania, Florida and Montana put on their big exhibitions in January, February and the first week in August, in that order. Illinois' fair is now open at Springfield and will run through the week.

SHRUB althea, variously called rose of sharon, shrub hibiscus, and hollyhock bush, is one of the most spectacular of all summer-flowering shrubs. Coming into flower in July and continuing through August and often through September, the shrub althea shows brilliant color when it is so badly needed in the garden.

THE past week in television has reaffirmed one of the most elementary yet most often ignored principles of good televisions there's no people like non-show people. The TV that deals with actuality, with real unglamourized people behaving as themselves, is still the most fascinating TV of all.
TRENTON, Aug. 13 -- The State Legislature will reconvene here on Monday to act on legislation to increase New Jersey's supply of potable water.

ABOUT 10:30 one morning a few weeks ago, Robert F. Wagner Jr., 102d Mayor of the world's second largest city, after a leisurely political breakfast huddle, stepped into his official Cadillac, said "Good morning" to Pete Bowes, his chauffeur, and to Al Hackett, his plainclothes bodyguard, and set off for City Hall.

The University of Rochester admitted women to its campus for the first time in 1900, largely as a result of a ten-year campaign conducted by Susan B. Anthony, the champion of women's rights. For thirty years the women were merely "tolerated" by the men students and did not have the equal educational opportunities that had been envisioned by Miss Anthony.
HARTFORD, Aug. 13 -- Connecticut's first state-wide adult probation commission was appointed today by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Plant small bulbs for bloom this autumn. Sternbergia will produce yellow crocuslike blossoms in about two months, autumn crocus and colchicum white or some shade of blue flowers in four to six weeks. Plant madonna lily bulbs for bloom next June. Set out strawberry plants.
Alternate - side - of - the-street parking goes into effect tomorrow in a 180-square-block area of northern Bronx.

DETROIT, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The American Motors Corporation and the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., agreed today to extend their contract until Sept. 1. This averted a strike of 24,000 workers that was scheduled for last midnight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Government will announce soon a six-point code of conduct for Americans who some day may become war prisoners and face Communist brainwashing and torture.
Some pentecostal Protestant groups now constitute "a third mighty arm of Christian outreach," according to the Rev. Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, president of Union Theological Seminary.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 13 (AP) -- In a short ceremony, seven early national tennis champions were enshrined today in the National Lawn Tennis Hall of Fame, which is located in the Newport Casino.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 13 -- The bodies of United States Ambassador John E. Peurifoy and his 9-year-old son Daniel lay in the police hospital morgue here today. They are to be cremated tomorrow in a Thai Buddhist temple.

QUEBEC, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Henri Rochon of Montreal upset Lorne Main of Vancouver and Toronto today in a five-set match to gain the final of the Canadian national tennis championship. The lefthander beat the No. 1 seeded player, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 8 -- 10, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2.
SAN SALVADOR, Aug. 12 -- There is evidence that Presidential candidates for the 1956 election are running out of steam almost five months before the earliest date an election can be scheduled.
TASHKENT, U. S. S. R., Aug. 13 -- This remote Asiatic area became an American tourist crossroads for a brief period today.

The Hospital for Joint Diseases, 1919 Madison Avenue, last year gave 5,696 bed patients 93,056 hospital days of care, according to the annual report by Raphael Malsin, president. Of the total number of hospital days, 42,309 were for ward patients of low income. The outpatient department treated 16,765 patients who made 104,681 visits.

A HULKING transport plane put on a remarkable exhibition in Philadelphia recently. Watching its performance was a little like watching the stout, fiftyish secretary do a graceful soft-shoe dance in the Broadway musical "Pajama Game."

IN August the coastal areas are "happy hunting grounds" for those interested in wild flowers. For the wind-swept dunes, the salt marshes and the grassy hills that slope toward the sea claim as their own many fascinating plants vastly different from those that grow inland.

Stock prices retreated for the third successive week as new developments in the field of credit exerted a depressing effect. As measured by the averages, the list on Tuesday slumped to the lowest levels since early June, with "blue chips" bearing the brunt of selling.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 13 -- Unions representing almost 3,000,000 workers in industry, business and the public services have canceled wage agreements in a bid for a larger share of West Germany's current prosperity.

PARIS, Aug. 13 -- Having lost ground in Indochina and India, the French now have to face the same possibility in North Africa. But if they resigned themselves to the inevitable in the Far East, North Africa is another matter. It is too close to home, in more than just a geographical sense.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 13 -- After dipping to a twenty-one-month low of 8,350 the previous week, claims for unemployment compensation climbed to 9,131, with all of the increase being new claims. The rise in claims is attributed to scarcity of parts and materials, which led to layoffs in copper plants.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 13 -- Up to Aug. 1 there had been a 17 per cent increase in the racially integrated use of this city's million-dollar municipal pool at Swope Park. Last year, the first season of mixed swimming here, attendance dropped to one-third the normal level.

Drs. Glenn T. Seaborg (University of California), Joseph W. Kennedy (Washington University), Arthur C. Wahl (Washington University), and Emilio G. Segre (University of California) will receive from the Atomic Energy Commission $400,000 in return for all their rights to methods of making use of the peculiar properties of plutonium.

BOSTON, Aug 13 (UP) -- The Washington Senators pounded four pitchers for eighteen hits and scored their highest total of runs in one game this season as they swamped the Boston Red Sox, 18 -- 9, today in the first-game of a scheduled double-header. The second game was postponed because of rain.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 12 -- A move has begun in New Delhi for the elimination of all outward signs of former British rule. The first step is the "Indianization" of roads and places.

EVERY year about 10,000 visitors, coming from all parts of the country, and some from abroad, pass through the graceful doorway of the Wadsworth-Longfellow House in this peaceful, pleasant town. This is the house in which Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, perpetual poet laureate of the American folk, lived through his early years.

IT is not, often that a playwright wins the boon of two laughs for every funny line he writes. "The Teahouse of the August Moon," John Patrick's impudent lampoon of the clash of culture that occurs when United States Army of Occupation procedures meet the ancient ways of Okinawan life, is doing that in Tokyo.

CERTAINLY Rexford Guy Tugwell's intellect is one of the most profound and prolific that has operated in this country in the last quarter-century. He was among the original architects of the New Deal, and as a political scientist and social planner he has had a pronounced influence on liberal thought both here and abroad.

IN his article "French Fiction and American Reality," Father R. L. Bruckberger writes: "It is the honor and responsibility of American novelists to make their country better known and loved." In this direction, it seen to me, lies fiction even worse than what we are greeted with each week.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 3 -- In a conference lasting less than an hour and a half, a woman from Los Angeles has "sold" the Pakistani Government, United, Nations officials and a general of the United States Army on a 3-cent-a-day nutritional plan.

OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Japan's swimmers bettered the world record in the 400-meter medley relay tonight, edging the United States four, which also beat the previous mark. The event featured a dual meet between the two nations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- The Canadian contract bridge pair of Douglas Drury and Eric Murray, both of Toronto, today retained the United States men's championship. They outscored a 108-pair finalist field to repeat their victory of last year.

SAN MARINO, Monday, Aug. 15 -- The world's smallest republic has chosen to remain the only Communist state in Western Europe.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Ham Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., won the Newport invitation tennis tournament for the second straight year by beating Herbie Flare of Beverly Hills, Calif., 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, today.
It was just thirty-three minutes after 8 o'clock at Ebbets Field last night when Carl Furillo ended twenty-three innings of baseball with a scoring single to left center.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Seven members of the Russian farm delegation toured the Museum of Science and Industry today. Four other members of the party rested at the Conrad Hilton Hotel.
